title: Legislator's Ethics Under Investigation
description: ALBANY, June 2The Eth ics and Guidance Committee of the Assembly is looking into the propriety of a letter sent by a Democratic Assemblyman to a number of business con cerns in which he was offering his services.

title: Yuba City Sheriff Roy Dean Whiteaker
description: Man in the News

title: Governing the Stock Exchange
description: Last February the New York Stock Exchange appointed William McChesney Martin, former chairman of the Fed eral Reserve Board, to study its rules, structure and operations and to recommend changes. Although Mr. Martin is still several weeks away from completing his study, debate is heating up over the key issues expected to be covered in his report.

title: Soviet Protests I.L.O. Election Of French Employer Delegate
description: GENEVA, June 2  The In ternational Labor Organization opened a threeweek meeting here today by electing an em ployer representative as its pre siding officer for the first time since it was founded in 1919. The Soviet Union lodged an im mediate protest.

title: Rome Ceremonies Mark 25th Year of Republic
description: ROME, June 2Italians celebrated today the 25th anniversary of the founding of the republic with a two hour military parade along the Fori Imperiali here.

title: German Women Fight Ban on Abortions
description: BONN. June 2 (Reuters) Twentyfour wellknown West German women actresses, journalists, singers, film stars and fashion modelshad their photographs on the front page of Stern news magazine today with the con fession, We have had an abortion.

title: Sadat Stresses Military Aspect of Soviet Treaty in Report to Assembly
description: CAIRO, June 2  President Anwar elSadat reported today to the People's Assembly, for merly the National Assembly, on the 15year treaty signed with the Soviet Union last week.

title: Term of a Police Corrupter Cut in Appeal
description: The fouryear sentence of a convicted gambler who has been arrested 16 times and has been described as a major cor rupter of the New York Police Department has been reduced to two years by the Appellate Division, First Department.

title: Memorial for Niebuhr Set Tomorrow in Stockbridge
description: A memorial service for the Rev. Reinhold Neibuhr, the dis tinguished Protestant theolo gian, who died Tuesday evening at his summer home in Stock bridge, Mass., will be held in the First Congregational Church there tomorrow at 3 P.M.

title: No Western Union Talks
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 (UPI) A strike against the Western Union Telegraph Company moved into its second day to day, and spokesmen for the company and two unions said that no new bargaining sessions had been scheduled.

title: Southern Baptists Approve Abortion In Certain Cases
description: ST. LOUIS, June 2 (UPI) The Southern Baptist Conven ton called today for the legali zation of abortion in certain cases, including those where there was carefully ascertained evidence of the likelihood of damage to the emotional, mental and physical health of the mother.

title: LAWYERS TO LOBBY FOR ANTIWAR BILLS
description: WASHINGTON, June 2  A group of prominent lawyers announced plans today to lobby in Congress next week for pas sage of legislation that would end American involvement in Vietnam by the end of the year.

title: Screen:
description: It is quite a sight to watch huge, pontooned rigs, with their jouncing human riders and strapped cargo, riding the roaring waters in Run the Wild River. And this sight, enlarged on a theater screen in color, is the main diversion of a feature documentary that arrived yesterday, at the Kips Bay Theater.

title: RICHARD E. ERWAY OF EQUITABLE LIFE
description: Richard E. Erway, senior vice president and general counsel of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, died Tuesday in the Benedictine Hospital, Kingston, N. Y., where he had been since a coronary attack 10 days ear lier. He was 63 years old and lived at 200 East 66th Street.

title: Chinese Nationalists Accuse A Popular Writer of Sedition
description: Li Ao, a popular writer who was arrested in Taiwan in April, has been charged with involvement in a seditious or ganization and participation in its activities, the Chinese Na tionalist Embassy in Washing ton has disclosed.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Many Said to Fear Reprisals
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 2 (AP)  Foreign Minister Tran Van Lam confirmed today that only 13 sick or wounded prison ers of war were to be re patriated to North Vietnam on Friday. He said most of those who refused to go feared re prisals from the Communists.

title: Radio: Serving a Specific Community in the City
description: Forget radio? You should n't. In many ways, particu larly in terms of public access and tackling more controversial issues, it can provide some pertinent tips for Big Brother television.

title: Brooklyn Stores Closed In Protest on Sales Tax
description: Almost 4,000 merchants throughout Brooklyn closed their stores for an hour yester day morning to protest a one cent increase in the state sales tax that went into effect on Tuesday.

title: Arts Center to Open on Berkshire Estate
description: A new arts center in the Berkshire Hills of western Massachusetts, where musical plays, jazz concerts, poetry readings, chamber music and workshop presentations will be given, is opening this sum mer under the codirection of Lyn Austin and Oliver Smith, veteran Broadway pro ducers.

title: CITY TROUPE AIDS ITS MALE DANCERS
description: One of the most gratifying and revealing developments of the New York City Ballet's cur rent season has been the marked improvement in its standards of male dancing.

title: American Colt Epsom Victor
description: EPSOM, England, June 2 (Reuters)Americanbred Mill Reef, owned by Paul Mellon of Pittsburgh and New York, surged out of the pack in the final furlong today to win the 192d Epsom Derby, England's major flatracing classic for 3 yearolds.

title: Mrs. Meir, Home, Says Treaty Expands Soviet Role in Egypt
description: TEL AVIV, June 2Premier Golda Meir declared tonight that the Soviet Union had vir tually acquired the status of permanent settlers in the Middle East through the treaty signed in Cairo last week.

title: RISE IN F14 COST PUT AT $2BILLION
description: The Defense Department yes terday put the cost increase for the Navy's F14 fighter plane program at about $2bil lion.

title: Imports of Textiles For First 4 Months Of Year Rose 42%
description: WASHINGTON, June 2  Textile imports in the first four months of this year were 42 per cent above the record lev els of 1970, the Commerce De partment reported today.

title: SickOut at Suffolk Jail
description: RIVERHEAD, L. L, June 2 Eighteen of the 32 guards on the day shift at the Suffolk County jail called in sick for the second day today in a job action apparently aimed at ob taining greater pay increases. The Suffolk County Sheriff, Philip Corso, reported that the operations at the jail had not been affected by the wildcat work stoppage. Sheriff's depu ties are filling in, he said.

title: 'Train to Rob':McLaglen Work Opens With 'Lost Flight'
description: Andrew V. McLaglen's "One More Train to Rob," which opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters, falls into the tradition of the amiable westerna tradition in which lots of good feeling and jocular comradeship alternates with lots of shoot-em-up. Some of the greatest westerns have been made and are being made in this tradition, and though there is a question as to how many corpses you can reconcile with how much happy glow, that question tends to recede in the presence of a John Ford or a Howard Hawks, and only to emerge in the work of such a lesseralthough amiableimitator as McLaglen."One More Train to Rob" concerns a pair of slippery friends (George Peppard and John Vernon), the woman they love and are variously untrue to (Diana Muldaur), a troop of expendable hired guns, and a shipment of gold from a Chinese mining camp to safekeeping in a San Francisco bank. The plot, built out of these elements, is more than usually complex, and the characters who act it out are more than usually completeand where the movie seems to go wrong is neither in its plot or its people but in McLaglen's inability to bring both into a combination that more than hints the vitality it means to exploit.Because it is too lax, too slow, too mechanical, too timid in its inventions, "One More Train to Rob" never becomes funny. And because it never becomes funny it has no way really to contain or control the violence that is its other side and that falls after a while from the level of rugged amiability to mere blood lust.I have the feeling that McLaglen rather under-directs his actorsas if George Peppard were John Wayne and could fill in the gaps for himself and for everybody else. John Vernon, who seemed so admirable in "Topaz," becomes under this regime stolid, predictable and finally, very dull.At some theaters "One More Train to Rob" is being accompanied by a slightly aged movie called "Lost Flight," directed by Leonard J. Horn and dealing with an airliner that while flying from Hawaii to Australia is forced to ditch near an uninhabited island in the South Pacific.Anybody knowing this much and learning that the plane carries, among others, a brutish businessman, his unhappy mistress, two nuns, a black militant, a black nonmilitant, a racist, a marriage almost on the rocks, a pilot facing dismissal for his quick temper, assorted beautiful young girls, a medical student, a pregnant woman and a little boy suffering from acute appendicitisanybody learning all this will think he has the goods on "Lost Flight." But in fact it is a reasonably entertaining, well-paced, technically ambitious movie that receives great assistance from its performersnotably Lloyd Bridges (the pilot) for good, Ralph Meeker (the businessman) for evil, and Anne Francis (the mistress) for marriage and the family.

title: U.S. Reported to Plan New Aid To Pakistani Refugees in India
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 The United States was reported today to be planning to con tribute $10million to $15mil lion more to care for East Pakistani refugees fleeing into India.

title: MARKET NOTCHES ANOTHER ADVANCE
description: Before the opening of the New York Stock Exchange yes terday morning, analysts were contending that greater volume was necessary for a continua tion of the market advance.

title: The Great Cake Controversy
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) Henry Haller, the White House chef, surprised by the quick queries from many food editors, today asked: Are they working nights?

description: HARRISBURG, Pa., June 2 (UPI)A Baltimore priest to day followed the pattern set by his seven codefendants and refused to respond to charges of plotting to kidnap Henry A. Kissinger, the Presidential ad viser, and to raid draft boards in three states.

title: Credit Markets: A Rally Continues in Bond Prices

description: Metals futures, with the ex ception of platinum, continued to drop yesterday.

title: 10 Held for Picketing Store
description: KILLEEN, Tex., June 2 (AP) Nine men and a girl, among them eight soldiers from Fort Hood, were held in the city jail today on charges arising from their picketing of a jewelry store last night. Dave Zeiger from the Oleo Strut, a down town coffeehouse frequented by youths and soldiers protest ing the Vietnam war, said those arrested had said the store's salesmen solicited cus tomers from among soldiers passing by by talking with them and profiting from their homesickness before inviting them in to buy.

title: General, ExAide Accused Of Murdering Vietnamese
description: WASHINGTON, June 2The Army accused Brig. Gen. John W. Donaldson today of murder ing six Vietnamese civilians and assaulting two others in the winter of 196869.

title: $4Million in Cocaine Seized
description: LOS ANGELES, June 2 (UPI) Ten pounds of uncut heroin land cocaine worth about $4 million on the illegal market were seized in a raid Saturday by Treasury agents, officials disclosed today. Eight persons were arrested.

description: June 3, 1971

title: POPE'S AID URGED FOR SOVIET JEWS
description: ROME, June 2Leaders of the AntiDefamation League of B'nai B'rith urged Pope Paul VI today to intercede on be half of the Jews in the Soviet Union.

title: Disaster Aid for Jobless Sought by Urban League
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 (AP) The National Urban League asked President Nixon and Con gress today to designate 53 cities with high unemployment rates as disaster areas and to create jobs.

title: 2 Women Held in Bronx In Shooting of Grocer
description: Two women who allegedly held up a Bronx grocery last night and shot and wounded the elderly owner were taken into custody after a chase.

description: OTTOWAY, June 2 (Reuters) Canada's foreign exchange re serves rose by $24,800,000 dur ing May to a record $4,870,000, 000, the Finance Department re ported today. The figure com pares with $4,084,000,000 in May, 1970.

title: Dugan, Lucas, Binns Gain In Eastern College Tennis
description: ROCHESTER, June 2 (AP) Dirk Dugan of Cornell, the de fender, scored a 6.2, 62 vic tory over Dick Kadesch of Col gate to reach the quarterfinal of the Eastern intercollegiate tennis championships today.

description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 2 (AP)Dr. Alfred H. Keil, Ger manborn expert in marine architecture and sciences, has been named dean of the Massa chusetts Institute of Technol ogy Engineering School, Dr. Keil succeeds Dr. Paul E. Gray, who becomes chancellor and chief deputy to the school's new president, Dr. Jerome B. Wiesner, effective July 1.

description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., June 2 Ruchell Magee used his own legal knowhow again today to halt the pretrial hearings in volving Angela Davis.

description: The General Foods Corporation announced yes terday the appointment of James W. Andrews as corporate group vice president in charge of the company's Maxwell House and Institutional Food Service Divisions and its Canadian operations. Joseph F. Abely Jr. was named vice president finance and becomes chief financial officer and controller of the company. David M. Brush, treas urer, was elected a corporate vice president and Robert A. Klath was named vice presidentcorporate planning.

title: At the Met
description: For the second perform ance of its June Festival, the Metropolitan Opera staged a Rigoletto on Tuesday night that was well up to its cur rent standard, alas. That is, everything happened on schedule, and nothing much happened. Carlo Franci, con ducting his first Met Rigo letto, skimmea over the sur face of the score with the ease of the born routiner, and only the feeblest stabs at characterization or emo tional credulity were made by anyone else.

title: Fischer Wins Taimanov Match By Taking 6th Straight Game
description: VANCOUVER, British Colum bia, June 2Bobby Fischer of Los Angeles won his match here with Mark Taimanov of the Soviet Union by taking the sixth game, making his score 60.

description: Pencil chewers now have more reason to be nervous than ever before.

The law was de clared unconstitutional last July by the United States Court of Appeals.

title: Homosexual Minister Is Ousted By Southwest Texas Methodists
description: SAN ANTONIO, Tex., June 2 (AP)  A homosexual clergy man has been suspended from the Methodist ministry in an emotional meeting that followed a plea in his behalf by the Gay Liberation Front.

title: Advertising:

description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, June 3 (AP)Re sponding to a South Vietnamese request, hundreds of United States bombers and helicopter gunships struckt at what were reported to be troops of three enemy divisions in eastern Cambodia yesterday.

title: Reinhold Niebuhr
description: Reinhold Niebuhr blended theology and practical poli tics as articulator of the concept of liberal realism. His writings provided the intellectual underpinning for much of what was most constructive in the antitotali tarian left.

description: Seventeen black clergymen and community leaders, acting as jurors in a Brooklyn peo ple's tribunal, found two white policemen guilty of murder in the first degree last night in the shooting of a black man on a BedfordStuyvesant street corner on May 17.

description: EVERY WEEK, more than 26,000 Jain are advertised in The New York Times. See the Employment Columns today.Advt.

title: French Reserves Increase
description: PARIS, June 2 (Reuters) French reserves rose by 368 million francs in May to 29, 311,000 compared with a 396 million rise in April, the French Finance Ministry said today. The French franc is currently, quoted at approximately 18.11 cents.

description: MOSCOW, June 2  Metro politan Pimen of Krutitsy and Kolomna was elected Patriarch today of the Russian Orthodox Church, the largest and most important religious body in the Soviet Union.

description: MIAMI, June 2 (UPI)The passengers and crew members of a hijacked Pan American World Airways jet were re leased today after having been held for four days in Havana.

title: With Simple Recipes, Even a 6YearOld Can Be a Good Cook
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.Jenny White got out the candy thermometer and put it in a cup of warm water. She wanted to make sure the water was not merely lukewarm, but as close to 110 degrees as possible. Anyone who has baked bread will have guessed that Jenny was getting ready to activate yeast, which works best at that temperature.

title: Brilliance Marks Songs Of Poznan Boys Choir
description: Those who went to hear the Poznan Boys Choir in Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night found themselves listen ing to the AllPhiladelphia Boys Choir during the first third of the program. There was some logic behind this. The Philadelphia group toured Poland last year, and it invited its Poznan counter part to visit this country and Canada.

title: American Financing Set; Pan Am Staff Realigned
description: In moves to help meet serious financial problems, American Airlines, Inc., yesterday an nounced plans for selling 3.3 million shares of common stock, while Pan American World Air ways, Inc., announced a major reorganization of its staff just below the office of the presi dent and chief executive offi cer, the 55yearold Najeeb E. Halaby.

description: A State Supreme Court jus tice here ruled yesterday that a community school board in Manhattan had the right to use Federal funds intended to aid povertystricken pupils with out being subject to controls of the Central Board of Educa tion.

title: WOMAN INMATE LOSES BID FOR METHADONE
description: The City Commissioner of Correction is not required to provide longterm methadone maintenance programs for heroin addicts in the city's pris ons, the State Supreme Court ruled yesterday.

description: YUBA CITY, Calif., June 2 Juan V. Corona, a husky MexicanAmerican farm labor contractor, pleaded not guilty today to murder charges in connection with the slaying of 23 men Whose bodies have been dug from graves in peach orchards outside this city.

description: Contrary to the general be lief created by the great pub licity focusing on Edgar Cai bett's Canonero II, there will be other horses in the Belmont Stakes on Saturday besides the excellent campaigner from Venezuela.

title: JOHN KING AND WIFE FILE IN CHAPTER XI
description: DENVER, June 2 (AP)John M. King and his wife, Carylyn, have asked the courts to pro tect them from their creditors while they attempt to resolve their financial difficulties. They have filed proceedings under Chapter XI of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

description: La Compania Mexicana de Teatro, composed of nine Mexi can film and stage actors, will open a limited engagement to night at the Greenwich Mews Theater, 141 West 13th Street, in a Spanish language stage presentation of Henry Denker's play, A Far Country.

description: WASHINGTON, June 2  Manufacturers' new orders fell more than $1billion, or 1.9 per cent, in April with a bigger drop in orders for durable goods than had been estimated previously, the Commerce De partment reported today.

description: NEW ORLEANS, June 2 (AP) The Unifed States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit agreed today to a rehearing by the entire court of its landmark decision directing the town of Shaw, Miss., to equalize public services for blacks and whites.

title: HANOI DENOUNCES SAIGON ON P.O.W.'S
description: PARIS, June 2 (AP)North Vietnam charged today that south Vietnam's offer to free Sick and wounded North Viet namese prisoners was a sham and denounced statements in Saigon that only 13 of 660 prisoners wanted to go home.

title: U.S. GAS POTENTIAL IS VIEWED AS LARGE
description: GOLDEN, Colo., June 2 (AP) Considerable stores of nat ural gas are waiting to be un covered in the United States, but most will be deep in the ground, beneath the oceans, or otherwise expensive to find, ac cording to a report issued today from the Colorado School of Mines.

title: BORGWARNER SETS A PLANT IN JAPAN
description: The BorgWarner Corpora tion announced yesterday the opening of a large plant in Japan to produce automatic transmissions for cars and trucks in a joint venture with the Toyoto Motors Group af filiate, the AisinSeiki Com pany, Ltd.

title: Medical Aid Gains in House
description: WASHINGTON, June 2 (UPI) The House Commerce Com mittee agreed today to finance the medical education of doc tors in return for service in rural areas and urban slums. The measure was part of a $3.3bilion medical manpower package approved by the com mittee and designed to end the shortage of doctors, nurses and medical technicians by 1978. The legislation now goes to the full House and Senate for ac tion.

title: PHYSICIAN DRAWS JAIL IN DRUG CASE
description: A 65yearold physician con victed of running an ampheta mine supermarket in his of fice at 40 Central Park South was sentenced by a Federal Judge yesterday to five years in jail and ordered to pay $10,000 fine.

title: Joe E. Lewis in Coma
description: Joe E. Lewis, the nightclub comedian, was reported in poor condition yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital. The hos pital said the performer, who was brought in by ambulance last Friday, was suffering from diabetic acidosisa diabetic coma.

title: Group of Clothing Workers Picket Union Over Contract
description: A group of cutters of men's and boys clothing walked off their jobs at various shops in the city yesterday and picketed the national headquarters of their union in protest against the terms of a new national contract.

title: Worked With Morrow
description: Arthur David Morse's career was in five distinct chapters: a World War II PTboat skipper, a freelance writer on education; a writer and producer of tele vision documentaries during one of the most creative peri ods of that craft; author of an indictment of the Roosevelt Ad ministration for, in effect, con tributory negligence in the ho locaust of European Jews; and finally, first head of the Inter national Broadcast Institute, which is designed to raise the worldwide level of the elec tronic media.

title: RAYMOND D. O'BRIEN
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 2 Raymond D. O'Brien, president of the New York insurance con cern of O'Brien & O'Brien, died yesterday in Larchmont Hospi tal after a long illness. He was 50 years old and lived at 7 Bay Avenue.

title: BRANDT SENT PLEA BY YALE STRIKERS
description: The local union representing striking service employes at Yale University in New Haven, sent a letter to Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany yes terday asking him not to cross picket lines and accept an hon orary degree at commencement ceremonies June 14.

title: Roundup: Pirates Win and Close Gap
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates, who never were known for the quality of their pitching, even in old Forbes Fieldwhere the fences appeared miles awaysuddenly have come up with plenty of good pitch ing in Three Rivers Stadium, where the park is smaller and the fences closer.

title: Haifa Is Stepping Aside As Teamsters' President
description: WASHINGTON, June 3  James R. Hoffa announced from prison today that he would not stand for reelection as president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: A Derrick and 10 Tons of Steel Plunge 18 Stories on East Side

title: Exit Hoffa
description: James R. Hoffa has done the giant International Brotherhood of Teamsters a service by taking himself out of consideration for reelection to the union presi dency next month. It would have been an affront to the nation If its biggest and strongest union had voted back into office a convict with nine years still to serve for juryfixing and pension fraud.

title: Senate to Get Modified Proposal for War Pullout in '71
description: WASHINGTON, June 3  The legislative battle lines start ed to take shape in the Senate today on efforts to force a troop withdrawal from Vietnam by the end of the year and to require a 10 per cent cut in defense spending.

description: PALISADES PARK, N.J., June 3 (UPI) The winning number in this week's New Jer sey lottery is 602302. The draw ing, held in Bergen County to day, is held in a different com munity every Thursday.

title: Market Place: The Little Guy And His Broker

title: OPERA FLIES PAYS A FOURDAY VISIT
description: Generally speaking, opera is an art form intended for per formance by adult musicians for adult audiences, but in a few instances, composers have created operas planned speci fically for young people. Cop land's The Second Hurricane, Britten's Let's Make an Opera and Hindemith's Let's Build a Town are among the betterknown examples of this category.

title: Screen: Beyond Control
description: It used to be common practice, more so I think than now, for a distributor to buy an unremarkable unre leased movie, usually foreign splice in a little unrelated exploitation, and open the package as a kind of new in timate secrets on view. I've been told that something like this was done with the earliest Ingmar Bergman shown here (how else to sell salacious Swedes?), and I remember rather fondly a movie called $100 Dollars a Night that ran for about 20 years at the Globe, originally a German crime film, in which the sex had nothing to do with the story and the title had nothing to do with either.

title: Concert
description: The marriage some years ago between SaintSaens's Carnival of the Animals and Ogden Nash's wry verses surely was made in heaven, so one hoped to find a sim ilarly happy match in a pot pourri promisingly entitled Carnival of Marriage. pre sented Wednesday night by the New York Philharmonic in its Promenades series. Andr Kostelanetz conceived the idea for the reprise, ar ranged the music and con ducted the premiere, with Tony Randall, the actor and comedian, as narrator and Theodore Lettvin as piano soloist.

description: MOSCOW, June 3  With centuriesold pomp and majes ty, Metropolitan Pimen of Kru titsy anad Kolomna was en throned today as the new Patriarch of the Russian Ortho dox Church.

description: Dr. Albert H. Bowker, who is resigning Aug. 1 as chan cellor of City University, re ceived the university's first honorary doctorate yesterday during doctoral commence ment exercises.Dr. Bowker, who is 51 years old and will become the chancellor of the Univer sity of California at Berkeley, received a standing ovation from about 400 parents, fac ulty and the students at the university's Graduate Center Mall, 33 West 42nd Street.

description: Two rounds of play in the Reisinger Knockout teamof four will be held today art the New York Hilton: the round of 16 at 2 P.M. and the quar terfinals at 8 P.M.

title: Nixon Proposes $50,000 For Slain Policemen's Kin
description: WASHINGTON, June 3  President Nixon called today for Federal legislation to pro vide $50,000 to the family of any policeman slain in the line of duty.

title: Sweep Near the DMZ
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 3 (AP)The Saigon command announced today that 2,500 marines were conducting a sweep in the northwest corner of the country in an effort to smash a North Vietnamese troop buildup.

title: FUTURES IN JUICE ADVANCE IN PRICE
description: Increased sales of concen trated orange juice into con suming channels sent futures prices up yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange here.

title: PAUL A. SEVAREID
description: ST. PETERBURG, Fla., June 3 (AP)Paul A. Sevareid, a for mer Republican party official and Minneapolis television newscaster, died yesterday at St. Peterburg, where he moved in February. He was 61 years old.

title: Shift in Monetary SetUp Is Proposed in the House
description: WASHINGTON, June 3  A leading member of Congress on international monetary issues proposed today what would be, in effect, a major alteration of the world monetary system.

title: Earnings Surge at B.P.;
description: The British Petroleum Com pany, Ltd., realized a 95 per cent rise in firstquarter earn ings on a 27.4 per cent gain in sales and other income, it was reported yesterday from Lon don headquarters.

title: Rogers Asks NATO Talks On Soviet Bid on Troops
description: LISBON, June 3Secretary of State William P. Rogers pro posed today that deputy foreign ministers of the Atlantic alli ance meet later this year to consider negotiations with the Soviet Union on mutual and balanced reduction of forces in Central Europe.

title: HANOI NOW SAYS IT WON'T ACCEPT RETURN OF P.O.W.'S
description: PARIS, June 3North Viet nam announced today that it was canceling all arrangements to receive sick and wounded prisoners of war from the South on the ground that only 13 out of 570 originally announced would be transferred.

title: Fund Already Up to $15,055 For Families of Slain Police
description: The fund to raise money for the families of two policemen slain on May 21 has collected $15,055.36 in little more than a week, the police of the 32d Precinct reported yesterday.

title: EMERGENCY PLAN ON POWER SET UP
description: ALBANY, June 3The Pub lic Service Commission today directed the seven utilities in the state power pool to give the senior dispatcher at a control center near Albany full author ity to decide when a power emergency existed and what steps should be taken to cope with it.

title: SINGAPORE EXPELS AMERICAN NEWSMAN
description: SINGAPORE, June 3 (Reu ters)The Singapore Govern ment has accused an American freelance journalist of interfer ing in the internal affairs of the republic and said it con sidered his continued presence here to be undesirable.

title: MISSISSIPPI AREA MUST REDISTRICT
description: WASHINGTON, June 3The Supreme Court decreed today that Hinds County, Miss., which includes the capital city of Jack son, must be divided into sin glemember legislative districts to give residents of black neigh borhoods a chance to elect members of their own race to the Legislature.

title: 13 Head for Rendezvous
description: ABOARD THE U.S.S. UP SHUR, Off South Vietnam, Fri day, June 4Thirteen disabled North Vietnamese prisoners of war headed back to their home land last night in the air conditioned hospital ward of this luxurious troop transport.

title: Serge Obolensky Marries Mrs. Wall
description: Col. Serge Obolensky, the 80yearold doyen of Inter national Society, and Mrs. Marilyn Fraser Wall, 44, of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich., elopect to Arlington, Va., yes terday and were married by Judge Frank E. Thomas Jr.

title: Postal Regional Head Named
description: Postmaster General Winton M. Blount yesterday named Harold R. Larsen as regional postmaster general of the New York Postal Service Region, one of five United States postal areas set up in a reorganiza tion last month. Mr. Larsen had been head of the New York re gion under the previous 15re gion organizational plan.

title: DANIEL JACOBSON, 66; LAWYER SINCE 1928
description: Daniel Jacobson, long active as a criminal defense lawyer here, died Wednesday in Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospital after a short illness. He was 66 years old and lived at 444 East 52d Street.

title: 3 DEMOCRATS, NIXON RUN CLOSE IN A POLL
description: The most recent Gallup Poll indicates that if the 1972 Presi dential election were held now, three prominent Democrats Senator Edmund S. Muskie, Senator Hubert H. Humphrey and Senator Edward M. Ken nedywould each run a very close race against President Nixon.

title: INDICTED LAWYER GETS UPSTATE JOB
description: LACKAWANNA, N. Y., June 3  Robert M. Murphy, a law yer who is under indictment in an alleged embezzlement plot involving a Buffalobased bank, has been appointed to the $60 aday post of acting City Court judge here.

title: Holtzman Beats Reds on 2d NoHitter;
description: CINCINNATI, June 3 (AP) Ken Holtzman, the Chicago Cubs' 25yearold lefthander, pitched the first nohitter of the season tonight, beating the Cin cinnati Reds, 10.

title: Braves Are 52 Winners
description: ATLANTA, June 3 (AP) Hank Aaron's tworun, pinch hit double broke a 22 tie in the fourth inning tonight as the At lanta Braves, beat the Houston Astros, 52.

title: Racial Hiring Plan In Building Industry Ordered on Coast
description: WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP)  The Labor Department an nounced today that it was im posing a mandatory racial hiring plan for construction workers in Sari Francisco.

title: No Alternative Is Seen
description: BURBANK, Calif., June 3 (AP)  Lockheed denied today that it saw hope for finding an alternative way of financing its Tristar airbus if Congress re fuses to guarantee $250million in private bank loans for the project.

title: GHOST TEST NEAR FOR TRADE CENTER
description: Metropolitan New York's biggest electronic riddleHow will the World Trade Center affect television reception? finally will be answered in the next two weeks.

title: CABINET REPLACED BY SOUTH KOREANS
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 3 President Chung Hee Park appointed Kim Chong Pil, vice president of the governing) Democratic Republican party,), to replace Paik Too Chin as Premier in an abrupt Cabinet change today.

title: Canonero's OTB Line Narrows to 310
description: In English, Spanish and even Chinese, Canonero II continued to be the magic name here yesterday in off track betting on tomorrow's Belmont Stakes.

title: THANT IS EMPHATIC ON HIS RETIREMENT
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 3  Secretary General Thant reiterated today in strongly personal terms his in tention to retire at the end of the year, when his second five year term expires.

title: PAPP WILL PUBLISH THEATER MAGAZINE
description: The founding of two maga zines, Performance and Scripts, was announced yesterday by Joseph Papp, founder and presi dent of the New York Shake speare festival Theater. The editor for both magazines, which are being published by the festical at its Public The ater, 425 Lafayette Street, will be rrika Munk. William Coco will serve, as associate editor.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: LONDON  What probably worried Moscow more than the change of cast in Cairo's top leadership was the surprising resurgence of United States prestige in the Arab world where Soviet influence had been gaining steadily ever since the Dulles era. Undoubtedly this inspired the recent RussoEgyptian pact.

title: CITIES SEEK MORE IN REVENUE PLAN
description: WASHINGTON, June 3A group of bigcity Mayors told a Senate subcommittee today that their communities needed a larger share of the money that would be passed out to states and cities under the Ad ministration's general revenue sharing program.

title: Advertising:
description: The happy workers at Young & Rubicam are hap pier still because of a memo from the leadership that has told them that new business internationally during the first five months of the year has more than made up for the loss of Playtex.

title: Boston Museum Appoints Contemporary Arts Curator
description: Kenworth William Moffett has been appointed curator of contemporary art at Boston's Museum of Fine Arts, it was announced yesterday by Perry T. Rathhone, museum director.

title: Senate Panel, 43, Raises Limit in '72 Spending Bill
description: WASHINGTON, June 3The Senate Rules Committee re wrote the campaign spending bill today to double the amount of money President Nixon and his Democratic opponent could spend on radio and television in 1972.

title: ROCKEFELLER LEADS ATTACK ON MAYOR; CALLS HIM INEPT
description: ALBANY, June 3Governor Rockefeller and Republican leg islative leaders charged today that their efforts to resolve New York City's fiscal prob lems had been hindered by a growing loss of confidence in the Mayor's administration of the city.

title: SUGAR BLOC BACKS OFFER BY MARKET
description: LONDON, June 3Fourteen Commonwealth sugargrowing countries today endorsed the terms obtained for them by Britain in her bid to join the European Economic Commu nity.

title: 24th Body Is Found in Yuba City
description: YUBA CITY, Calif., June 3 (UPI)Sheriff's deputies re covered the 24th body in the Yuba City mass murders to day from a crude grave in the same general area where other victims had been found.

title: JAP TRADEMARK DRAWS A PROTEST
description: The New York chapter of the JapaneseAmerican Citizens League sued in State Supreme Court yesterday to bar a de signer of women's clothing and the product's world marketing agent from using the word Jap as a trademark.

title: Realignment in Cambodia
description: Reports from the key Cambodian border town of Snout indicate that the South Vietnamese withdrawal, which has been described by Saigon army spokesmen as a realignment of forces, was more like a rout, similar in many respects to the recent precipitate South Viet naniese retreat from Laos.

title: Offer to E.F.T.A. Proposed
description: BRUSSELS, June 3  The executive body of the Common Market has decided to recommend that those nations in the European Free Trade Associa tion that do not wish to join the Market should be offered a special agreement for free trade in industrial products.

title: NAME BANDS PLAY ON EAST 86TH ST.
description: Last 86th Street, between Second and and Third Avenues, is not yet quite the musical ?? that 52d Street between Fifth and Sixth Avenues was in the 1930's and 1940's. But it is showing surprising signs ?? becoming a conter for name bands.

title: Record $200,000 Is Bid for a Strad
description: LONDON, June 3  A world's record auction price for a violin was established today when the firm of W. E. Hill & Sons paid 84,000, or a little more than $200,000, for a Stradivarius. The pre vious record, also at a Sotheby's auction, had been set in 1965 for the Marie Hall Stradivarius, which fetched $53,000.

title: Music: Utah Visitors
description: On Wednesday, the eve of its takeoff for a monthlong tour of Latin America, the Utah Symphony from Salt Lake City stopped at Carne gie Hall to give a concert. It was the orchestra's second appearance here, and it was led by Maurice Abravanel, who in his 25 years as mu sical director has built it into a major ensemble.

title: NapolesBackus Bout Tonight
description: LOS ANGELES, June 3 (AP) Billy Backus, the world wel terweight champion, will risk his title in a 15round fight tomorrow night against Jose (Mantequilla) Napoles of Mex ico City.

title: Entry of Laverne Hanover and Rum Customer Favored Tonight
description: YONKERS, June 3  Not since 1960 has so much acri mony surrounded the Inter national Pace, recently re named the Martin Tananbaum International, as is evident in connection with tomorrow night's 12th edition of the $100,000 event at Yonkers Raceway.

title: G.M. to Renovate Offices
description: DETROIT, June 3 (AP)Gen eral Motors Corporation an nounced today a $10million modernization of the G.M. building in midtown Detroit, putting to rest rumors that the corporation might move some of its offices from the city.

title: Covent Garden Plan: It Just Isn't Loverly
description: An Appraisal

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Mrs. Julius Ochs Adler Is Dead; Times Official's Widow Was 68
description: Mrs. Barbara Adler, widow of Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler, former vice president and gen eral manager of The New York Times, died yesterday at The New York hospital. She suf fered a cerebral hemorrhage at her home, 834 Fifth Avenue, on Wednesday. She was 68 years chi. General Adler died in 1955.

title: $190.2Million Phone Rate Rise Urged
description: ALBANY, June 3  An ex aminer for the Public Service Commission today recommended that the New York Telephone Company be granted temporary, rate increases amounting to $190.2million.

title: RATES ON BONDS DECLINE SHARPLY
description: The bond market took a gi ant step toward lower interest rates yesterday.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: June 4, 1971

title: Thieu May Be Unopposed in Wake of House Vote
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 3In the South Vietnam ese Presidential election of 1967, there were 11 candidates, and Nguyen Van Thieu won with only 35 per cent of the vote. In the election on Oct. 3, it appears, the President may have only one opponent, or may even run upopposed, under a bill passed today by the low er house of the South Vietnam ese National Assembly.

title: Concorde Fails Speed Test With U.S. Officials Aboard
description: PARIS, June 3The builders of the Concorde promoted their experimental supersonic jetliner today by taking Senator Barry Goldwater, Transportation Sec retary John A. Volpe and five airline executives for a 90min ute swing over northern France and the Atlantic.

title: ACTIVE LOBBY URGED TO SUPPORT CULTURE
description: Amyas Ames, chairman of the board of Lincoln Center for the. Performing Arts, called yesterday for the organization of an active lobby to support the arts.

title: Lakers Dismiss Mullaney As Coach After 2 Years
description: LOS ANGELES, June 3 (AP) Joe Mullaney has been re moved as coach of the Los An geles Lakers and offered an ad ministrative position with the National Basketball Association team, General Manager Fred Schaus said today.

title: Ferguson Retires Again
description: MONTREAL, June 3 (AP) John Ferguson, a 32yearold left wing, said today he was retiring from the Stanley Cup champion Montreal Canadiens. Ferguson also announced his retirement last fall, but re turned to help the team place third in the National Hockey League's East Division and win the playoff title.

title: The Obligation of History
description: CAMBRIDGE, England  When Thucydides the Athenian described the twentysevenyear war between Athens and Sparta at the end of the fifth century B.C., he declared that his work would be a possession for all time.

title: U.S. Losses Up in Week to 48 As Those of Saigon Drop to 452
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 3 (Reuters)The allied mili tary commands reported today that United States battlefield deaths increased last week while those of the South Viet namese decreased slightly. The estimated enemy toll, they said, dropped sharply.

title: Erin Martin Dances Her Own Creations With Company of 5
description: Erin Martin, a dancer best known for her guest appear ances as the bride in American Ballet Theater's production of Jerome Robbins's Les Noces, Presented three works with a company of five other dancers Wednesday night at the Ameri can Theater Laboratory, 219 West 19th Street.

title: Amtrak Plans to Reinstate Run From Minneapolis to Spokane
description: WASHINGTON, June 3The National Railroad Passenger Corporation, known as Amtrak, will reinstate service June 15 on a 1,300mile route between MinneapolisSt. Paul and Spo kane, Wash.

title: MRS. HYMAN EPSTEIN
description: Mrs. Minnie Epstein, who had been in the restaurant business in Brooklyn with her husband, Hyman Epstein, for many years, died Wednesday in Parsons Hospital, Flushing, Queens. She was 82 years old and lived in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn.

title: Pentagon to Destroy Gas
description: WASHINGTON, June 3, (Reu ters)The Defense Department announced today that it would begin destruction early next month of its mustard gas sup plies at the Rocky Mountain arsenal near Denver. More than 3,000 tons of the gas will be destroyed by incineration in an operation expected to last about five months.

title: Truck Report Not Available
description: WASHINGTON, June 3In tercity truck tonnage reported by the American Trucking As sociations, Inc., will not be available this week because of the Western Union strike. The rail carloadings report usually compiled every Thursday by the Association of American Railroads will be out tomorrow.

title: AirCooled, Optimistic Houston Runs and Grows on Oil
description: HOUSTON, June 3The heat is so severe in the mid dle of the day that most of us lie in the shade and pant, Ashbel Smith. Houston's first physician, wrote in a letter 132 years ago.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: MERGER FOR VISTA CLEARED IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, June 3 The Senate gave final Congres sional consent today to Presi dent Nixon's proposal to merge several volunteer service pro grams, such as the Peace Corps and VISTA, into one agency to be called ACTION.

title: Philadelphia to Curb Sports
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 3 (AP) The city public school sys tem, facing a $100million def icit even before the start of the 197172 school year, an nounced today that it would abandon varsity sports at all high schools and eliminate near ly 2,000 jobs.

title: JOHN HANDRAHAN
description: WEYMOUTH HEIGHTS, Mass., June 3John B. Handrahan, an allEast fullback in his senior year at Dartmouth in 1936 and an insurance executive since World War II, died yesterday in University Hospital, Boston, after a short illness. He was 57 years old.

title: Suffolk Suspends 5 Guards
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., June 3 Five of the Suffolk County jail guards who have been on a wildcat sickcall slowdown were suspended as the job ac tion for higher pay went into its third day today. Sheriff Philip Corso said 40 per cent of the guards, about 15 on each shift, were not reporting for work.

title: Sobel Troupe Gives 5 Dances
description: Sheila Sobel is a choreog rapher of talent who has used pauses, slight hesitancies and nonconventional time to great effect in her past pieces. She is currently working in a lyrical vein that is more in tune with traditional dance phrasing and by that token less individual than her previous work. She and her ensemble presented five pieces at the Cubiculo Wednesday evening.

title: ExCity Aide Called Forger
description: Don D. Dumas, 41yearold former temporary accountant for the Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs Administra tion, was arrested yesterday on charges of forgery, grand lar ceny and the cashing of forged checks. Mr. Dumas, who lives at 11 Varick Street, was said to have cashed three checks total ing $1,238 that he made paya ble to himself on a city bank account.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: WHO is Harry Kellerman and why is he saying those terrible things about me?Advt.

title: Mao, Greeting Ceausescu, Urges Overthrow of All Reactionaries
description: HONG KONG, June 3Mao tsetung called today for the overthrow of imperialism and all reactionaries at a meeting with President Nicolae Ceau sescu of Rumania.

title: Aretha Franklin Soul Ignites Apollo
description: About five years ago, a somewhat unknown singer appeared at the Apollo The ater near the bottom of the bill. This week, at the top of the bill, at the top of every thing, Aretha Franklin re turned.

title: Columbia Pictures and Warner in Deal
description: Columbia Pictures Industries, Inc. and Warner Bros., Inc., announced yesterday that they will form a joint venture to operate a consolidated motion picture and television studio in California.

title: RITA COOLIDGE BOWS IN A BLUES PROGRAM
description: Rita Coolidge, the Delta Lady of the Leon Russell song, is making her New York sing ing debut this week. She should be heard. Since the death of Janis Joplin there hasn't been such a good reason to hear a girl blues singer.

title: Post Office Checks For Missing Cash In Hijacking Here
description: Postal authorities reported yesterday that they had cabled Switerland to determine the contents of 90 mail sacks that were hijacked at Kennedy In ternational Airport on Wednes day night.

title: House Votes $3.4Billion For U.S. Space Program
description: WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) Defeating efforts to cut out two Apollo moon flights and the space shuttle, the House approved today a $3.4billion authorization for the United States space program.

title: Business Trims Its Plans
description: United States businesses are cutting back their planned outlays for new plant and equipment in 1971. Three months ago they were planning to raise capital spending 4.3 per cent above last year's total of $81.8 billion, but a new Commerce Department survey now finds that they plan to spend only 2.7 per cent more than last yearthe smallest increase in a decade. When allowance is made for an expected climb this year of 7 per cent tin prices of capital goods, the outlook in physical terms is for a probable decline of more than 4 per cent in outlays on plant and equipment.

title: Foreign Service Aide Named
description: WASHINGTON, June 3 (Reu ters)President Nixon an nounced today that Thomas W. McElhiney is leaving his post as Ambassador to Ghana to be come Inspector General of the United States Foreign Service. No date has yet been set for his transfer and no successor has been named.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: More Than Administration
description: For almost two years George Washington High School in upper Manhattan was in such disarray that it often had to operate under heavy police guard and from time to time was shut down altogether. Teachers and students feared for their safety as hostile groups faced each other in anger and intruders exploited the turmoil.

title: FARRELL'S 141 WINS WESTCHESTER P.G.A.
description: MOUNT KISCO, N. Y., June 3 Billy Farrell of Stanwich Country Club won the West chester Professional Golfers' Association championship over the Mount Kisco Country Club 6,850yard, par 72 course with a threeunderpar 71, 70141 for 36 holes today.

title: Soviet Jet Lands in Boston
description: BOSTON, June 3 (AP)  A Soviet jet airliner with 54 pas sengers aboard landed in Bos ton last night when weather conditions made it impossible to reach New York. The Aero flot IL62 was the first Soviet liner to land in Boston. Crew men talked with customs offi cials and supervised the load ing of 6,000 gallons of fuel for the trip to New York.

title: Miss Andrews, Peter HillWood Are Wed Here
description: St. James' Episcopal Church was the setting here yester day afternoon for the mar riage of Miss Sarah Hall An drews, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert O'Beirne Andrews of Wilton, Conn., formerly of Grosse Pointe, Mich., and Rye, N. Y., to Peter Denis Hill Wood, son of Mr. and Mrs. Denis HillWood of Hartley Wintney, England.

title: WATCHMAN BILL OPPOSED IN PORT
description: The New York Shipping Association said yesterday that it opposed proposed legislation in Albany that would empower the Waterfront Commission to stipulate the number of watch men that terminal operators must assign to their piers.

title: CREDIT EXPANSION CONTINUES VIGOR
description: The nation's credit managers are continuing to pursue, and even accelerate, their stimula tive monetary policy, weekly banking data released by the Federal Reserve indicated yes terday.

title: RISING JOB TREND IN CITY REVERSED
description: Despite the slowdown in the city's economy last year, all but one of the 10 leading growth industries here continued to add jobs in 1970, posting a net gain for the group of 29,200.

title: Books of The Times
description: DESCHOOLMIG SOCIETY. By Ivan Mich. 116 pages. Harper and Row. $5.95.

title: Why I Left South Africa
description: It is the duty of a lawyer to guard the individual against all invasions of his liberty by authority. It is his duty, too, to expose injustice, corruption and brutality. The measure of freedom in any society is the extent to which lawyers and others can fulfill these functions.

title: Four U.S. Golfers Gain British Amateur Quarterfinals
description: CARNOUSTIE, Scotland, June 3 (AP)American Walker Cup players, past and present, captured half the quarterfinal berths in the British Amateur golf championship today while Mike Bonallack of England was upset in his bid for a fourth straight title.

title: NOVOTNY SAID TO GET HIS PARTY POST BACK
description: PRAGUE, June 3 (Reuters) Communist sources in Eastern Europe reported today that An tonin Novotny, the disgraced former President and Commu nist party leader of Czechoslo vakia, had been restored to membership in the party.

title: Taxing Public Patience
description: Political leaders at both the state and local levels of government are making a shambles of New York City's budgetary process. Mayor Lindsay has been attacking Governor Rockefeller. Governor Rockefeller has been attacking Mayor Lindsay. Yesterday he went so far as publicly to label the Mayor inept. Democrats and Republicans in the State Legislature have been at each other's throats and the City Council has had great diffi culty in obtaining fundamental budgetary data from city agencies. There have been proposals to tax the residents of New York City on their homes, their purchases, their incomes and their businesses. The worst tax in the whole politicsladen process, however, is on the public patience. Those who live and work in the nation's largest city deserve something better.

title: At Last It's Official: Rinfret Was Wrong
description: Pierre A. Rinfret, president of RinfretBoston Associates, is known as an economist who holds strong views and is not bashful about present ing them forcefully and fully.

title: Soviet, Publicizing Vote Data, Unveils Secret City's Existence
description: MOSCOW, June 3The se curityconscious Soviet Union keeps many things secret, in cluding the names and locations of cities associated with the atomic and aerospace indus tries.

title: Tragedy Brings Suicide Of 2d Mayor in France
description: CAEN, France, June 3 (AP) Paul Leboucher, Mayor of the Normandy village of LandessurAjon, was found hanged today, and beside his body was a note saying, I'm joining the Mayor of Sallen. The Mayor of Sallen, Ren Auvray, took his life Monday after 13 persons died when the floor of a village hall col lapsed.

title: Baptists Criticize Delay on Bible Tract
description: ST. LOUIS, June 3  The Southern Baptist Convention the largest Protestant denomi nation in America, with 11.6 million members  ended its threeday annual meeting here today after stanchly upholding its traditional conservatism.

title: Patti Hogan Wins Easily
description: MANCHESTER, England, June 3 (AP)Kris Kemmer of Holly wood, Calif., reached the semi finals of the Northern lawn tennis tournament today by de feating South Africa's Brenda Kirk, 68, 86, 64.

title: Bronx Zoo Has Baby, Rarest Deer in World
description: The Bronx Zob's herd of the rarest deer in the world, the Pere David deer, has been increased to 17 with the birth on April 30 of a male fawn.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: METHADONE CLINIC MAY CLOSE HERE
description: Two Federal agencies have moved to shut down the West Side Medical Center, one of the largest methadonemainte nance clinics in the country, after an investigation showed the clinic was dispensing meth adone indiscriminately.

title: JAMES GREENE, AIDE AT BOTANY CLOTHES
description: James N. Greene, vice presi dent of Botany indus?? ?? clothing concern, and ?? assistant to the president, Michael Daroff, died at the New York University Medical Center on Tuesday after a heart attack. He was 65 years old and lived in Danbury, Conn.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: NEW WEEKLY BIOGRAPHICAL SERVICE The New York Times Biographical Edition. Profiles of today's newsmakers in a loose lest edition. Write: The New York Times, Library Services. Box FP480, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N. Y. 10036.Advt.

title: OSCAR A. DE BOGDAN
description: SOUTHBURY, Conn., June 3 Oscar A. De Bogdan, a re tired architect, died today in Waterbury Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Heritage Village here.

title: G.M. Leads Rise in Auto Sales of May 2131
description: DETROIT, June 3The Gen eral Motors Corporation pro vided the spark for car sales in the last third of May and the full month. The four auto manufacturers today reported 286,607 deliveries of United Statestype cars in the May 2131 period. This was up per cent from the yearearlier 267,548.

title: Hashish Seized on Coast
description: WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) The Customs Bureau said to day it had seized 200 pounds of hashish at Los Angeles and ar rested one person. The bureau said Dennis H. Fieldman was arrested after receiving the shipment, which originated in Damascus, Syria.

title: Israel Presses U.S. on LongTerm Aid
description: WASHINGTON, June 3Is rael is pressing the United States for longterm com mitments on arms deliveries as a result of the 15year treaty concluded last week be tween the Soviet Union and Egypt.

title: Reform Jewish Chief Alfred Gottschalk
description: Man in the News

title: SHIBATA SCORES QUICK KNOCKOUT
description: TOKYO, June 3 (AP)  Kuniaki Shibata of Japan re tained his World Boxing Coun cil featherweight title tonight by knocking out the Mexican challenger, Raul Cruz, in the first round of their scheduled 15round bout.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: BELMONT STAKES ADDS 3 STARTERS
description: A shuffling of the field for the Belmont Stakes occurred yesterday with the introduction of Mrs. George Headley's Twist the Axe, the October House Farm's Pass Catcher and J.M. Davis's Royal J.D. as starters and the withdrawal of Mrs. Taylor Hardin's Sole Mio.

title: SCHOOLGIRL, 17, WINS AT DEVON
description: DEVON, Pa., June 3Around and around the ring they went Rod Jenkins, a seasoned pro fessional, on Impetuous, and Michele McEvoy, a 17yearold high school senior, on Say No More.

title: Front Page 3  No Title
description: EVERY WEEK, more than 26,000 jobs are advertised in The New York Times. See the Employment Columns today.Advt.

title: New Interior Post Created
description: WASHINGTON, June 3 (AP) Interior Secretary Rogers C. B. Morton announced today the creation of a new post of Deputy Under Secretary for Science and Engineering, de voted to keeping up with research and development in the field of environment and ecology. He appointed Frank E. Clarke, a career employe of the department, to the post.

title: Students Redesign Central Park Zoo; Plans Are Praised
description: Eighteen students from the Parsons School of Design gave examples to Parks Commissioner August Heckscher yesterday of how they would like to see the Central Park Zoo redesigned and he said he agreed with their ideas.

title: Amex Shares Advance 4th Day in Row
description: The American Stock Ex change scored its fourth con secutive advance yesterday as the list made a moderate gain in more active trading.

title: Rumanian Venture Formed
description: The Robert B. Anderson Com pany announced yesterday it has negotiated an agreement with the Rumanian State En terprise for Foreign Trade (TERRA) to form a joint trad ing venture called Romanda, Ltd. The company will be or ganized as a Bahamian corpo ration and its purpose will be to foster trade between Ru mania and the United States and other Western Hemisphere countries. The Anderson company made a similar arrange ment with the Yugoslav Gov ernment last July.

title: OffDuty Patrolman Slays Assailant in Playground
description: A 28yearold man was shot and killed by an offduty patrol man yesterday afternoon when he allegedly attacked the policeman with his fists and a stickball bat in the playground of Public School 165 at 153d Street and 71st Avenue in Queens.

title: EASTERN AIR OFFERS AID TO EXECUTIVE AIR
description: Eastern Air Lines and Ex ecutive Airlines announced yes terday the signing of an agree ment under which Eastern would provide Executive with management, airport and reser vation services.

title: Foreigners in Peking Get Daily Summaries of News

title: Antidraft Drive by Two Senators Considered Lax
description: WASHINGTON, June 3  While the Nixon Administra tion has run a careful and ef ficient campaign for its draft extension bill in the Senate, there has been little personal lobbying to counter this effort by the two key Senators who proposed moving faster than President Nixon toward a vol unteer army.

title: PRICES OF STOCKS CONTINUE TO RISE
description: The stock market rally con tinued to roll ahead yesterday despite some large losses in the glamour sector.

title: New York Yacht Club Names British to Conduct America's Cup Trials in '7
description: Unable to arrange a qualify ing procedure for seven would be challengers, the New York Yacht Club yesterday named the Royal Thames Yacht Club of England as the challenger ofrecord for an America's Cup match in 1974.

title: Portugal Plans Shipyard To Build Supertankers
description: LISBON, June 3The Por tuguese oyster is being threatened as plans material ize for the construction of Europe's largest shipyard in the oyster beds of the Sado River estuary.

title: LOCKHEED INQUIRY PICKS WITNESSES
description: WASHINGTON, June 3The Senate Banking Committee de cided today to call on such diverse witnesses as Ralph Nader, Richard W. McLaren and the presidents of competing air craftmanufacturing companies to testify on the Administra tion's plan to save the Lock heed Aircraft Corporation from bankruptcy.

title: Labor Asks $2 Pay Base Now; Early Capitol Action Doubted
description: WASHINGTON, June 3The A.F.L.C.I.O. called today for an Increase in the minimum wage to $2 an hour immediately, without delay, but the pros pect for any Congressional ac tion effective before 1972 ap peared dim.

title: Cholera Toll Among Bengalis Put at 2,000 by Indian Aides
description: NEW DELHI, June 3Indian officials reported today that at least 2,000 refugees from East Pakistan had died of cholera in an epidemic that has been rag ing for a week in their teeming border camps.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Until the Boston Red Sox reeled into an embarrassing swoon during the last week and blew a fourgame lead, they had raised blood pressures in the Fenway Park area such as had not been raised since the virulent attack of pennant fever in 1967. This had been an epidemic of frightful proportions, victimizing millions.

title: SWISS ARE UPSET OVER WATCH DEAL
description: GENEVA, June 3The Swiss watch industry, already appre hensive over its diminishing share of the world export mar ket, was jolted this week by an American company's acquisi tion of the fourth largest Swiss producer, the MovadoZenith Mondia WatchMaking Holding Company, Inc.

description: PHILADELPHIA, June 3  Five Philadelphia companies and a bank announced today plans for a $400million, 50acre housing and commercial real estate development project for downtown Philadelphia.

title: MARIE E. B. BROWN A PASTOR HERE, 90
description: The Rev. Marie Estelle B. Brown pastor of Glad Tidings ??bernacle, 325 West 33d Street, died Wednesday at the age of 90.

The Mayor of Sallen, Ren Auvray, took his life Monday after 13 persons died when the floor of a village hall col lapsed.

title: WASHINGTON

But in any event, the Sena tor from South Dakota is clearly going to influence his party in the coming months, even if he is not chosen to lead it in 1972.

After so long a period, the Israel defense forces are stationed along the Suez Canal and the river Jordan, and the Arab armies, whether united or singly, are not capable of loosing their hold.

In addition, Russia will take 38.4 million more bushels under terms of the 1966 contract and an op tion to buy 10 million more bushels in 1972.

description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 4 When Jim Pearson came home from Vietnam five years ago with several medals pinned to his paratrooper's tunic, he was in no great hurry to go to work.

description: WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP)  United States narcotics agents and Spanish police seized 249 pounds of heroin in Valencia, Spain, last night, At torney General John N. Mitch ell announced today.

description: A Federal Appeals Court in Boston reversed yesterday a lowercourt decision in a mu tual fund case of major signifi cance, ruling a management company guilty of gross mis conduct in not obtaining re funds on commissions paid by a fund it sponsors.

description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., June 4  for the first time in the history of intercollegiate la icrosse the national champion iship will be decided by combat tomorrow as Cornell and Mary land meet at Hofstra Stadium in the National Collegiate Ath letic Association tournament final.

The $2.5million aircraft crashed into Narraganset Bay. Comdr. Harley Hubert Hall, 33 years old, was picked out of the hay by a Navy boat minutes after he landed uninjured, a Navy spokesman said.

description: WASHINGTON, June 4 (Reu ters)  Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird is stilt not saris field with attempts by the South Vietnamese Government to curb the flow of ?? American servicemen, the Pen tagon said today.

title: Books of The Times
description: At a time when our systems of dealing with social deviance and dependence seem in perilous disrepair, when courts and jails are in turmoil, welfare snarled, hospitals swollen, and law and order become no more than the bully's rallying cry, this diligent work of American social history by a young professor at Columbia casts a little quiet light around it. What David Rothman has done is to look at the origins of American ways of handling crime, pov erty and mental illness. Penitentiaries and asylums, as we think of them now, are not ancient institutions. In colonial times, criminals were held in local jails awaiting trial, but incarceration itself was almost never a punishment: fines, whipping, the stocks, banishment and the gallows did the job. The insane were kept at home or tended by neighbors; if violent, they were locked in attics and cellars. Orphans, de linquents and the poor were likewise cared for at home whenever possible; the com munity paid toward their support and built almshouses for them only as a last resort if homes were available.

title: Fire Trucks Slow to Arrive
description: CHARLOTTE AMALIE, Virgin Islands, June 4 (UPI)Gov. Melvin H. Evans will fly to Washington this weekend to find out what happened to five large fire trucks the Govern ment ordered last year. The trucks were ordered after fire men threatened a march on Government House if their de mands for new equipment and better working conditions were not met.

title: House Panel Told About New Drugs To Combat Heroin

Patent 3,582,553 went to Amar G. Bose, pro fessor of electrical engineer ing at the Massachusetts In stitute of Technology. His company, the Bose Corpora tion, Natick, Mass., manufac tures the equipment.

Miss Duke has refused to divulge the father's name.

description: ATLANTA, June 4  Jack Nicklaus drew even today with yesterday's youthful pacesetter John Miller, to share the 36 hole lead by one stroke in the $125,000 Atlanta Golf Classic at 135.

title: Antiques
description: The ingenuity of 18thcen tury Connecticut cabinetmak ers is ably demonstrated in the newly installed furniture galleries at the Connecticut Historical Society in Hart ford.

title: 5 Killed, 33 Injured In. Crash of Truck Carrying Dynamite
description: WACO, Ga., June 4 (UPI) A trailer truck carrying 10,000 pounds of dynamite collided with an automobile on a busy highway tonight and blew up, killing at least five persons and caving in the roof of a nearby school gymnasium where 200 persons were holding a gospel singing.

title: HARTFORD STEED ON AN INCOME TAX
description: HARTFORD, June 4Nego tiations between Connecticut's Republican Governor and the leaders of the Democraticcon trolled General Assembly broke off early today after it had ap peared virtually certain last night that agreement would be reached on a state income tax.

title: 13 Downcast Prisoners, Spurned by Hanoi, Return to Danang
description: DANANG, South Vietnam, June 4Thirteen disabled North Vietnamese prisoners, described as saddened and bewildered by the lastminute refusal of Hanoi to take them back, returned here today after a 24hour sea journey to nowhere.

title: Japanese to Cut Cloth Exports
description: TOKYO, June 4 (UPI)  The Textile Federation will volun tarily reduce shipments of manmade cloth to the United States effective July 1 despite President Nixon's rejection of the Japanese plan.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, June 4  The contem porary critics of our society often speak of its hyprocrisy. It is a charge naturally resented by the so ciety's leaders, for with few excep tions they feel perfectly sincere in what they do.

title: City Prepares Its Beaches For the Summer Onslaught
description: Like a housewife in a flur ry of dusting before the guests arrive, the city is smoothing out the last sandy wrinkles of its 17 miles of municipal beaches for what the weatherman says will be the first good beach weekend of the year.

title: Britons Rushing Cholera Shots to India
description: LONDON, June 4  British relief organizations acted ur gently today to get anticholera vaccine to India, where an epi demic has broken out among refugees from East Pakistan.

title: Bombing in Brooklyn
description: A group of reformminded residents of South Brooklyn banded together not long ago to form a political club, the Independent Neighborhood Democrats. As politically aware citizens they were interested in revising national priorities, improving the delivery of municipal services, registering new voters and supporting enlightened candi dates. They started by distributing questionnaires testing their neighborhood's sentiment on a broad range of issues.

title: U.S. BACKS POLICE ON MISSION GUARDS
description: The United States moved to day to intervene on the side of the New York Police Depart ment in a court case in which the department is a defendant against complaints by apart ment building owners and ten ants in the area around the Soviet Mission on East 67th Street.

title: Melnyk and Simons Capture British Amateur Semifinals
description: CARNOUSTIE, Scotland, June 4 (UPI)Steve Melnyk and Jim Simons won semifinal matches today to line up an allAmeri can final in the 76th British Amateur golf championship.

title: China, With Eye on Soviet and U.S., Pushes RaidShelter Program
description: PEKING, Tune 3On the streets of this capital as well as in rural villages, bricks are piled high and dust rises as a massive program of building airraid shelters goes forward.

title: Eileen Gleason Wed To John P. Hogan
description: CLIFTON, N. J., June 4 Miss Eileen Gleason of Spring field and John P. Hogan of Neptune were married here this evening at St. Philip's Roman Catholic Church by Msgr. Francis H. Murphy.

title: E.F.T.A. Sees Plan Of Common Market Aiding Trade Ties
description: GENEVA, June 4  Sources close to the European Free Trade Association see as a very good beginning for four of its member states the re ported plan of European Eco nomic Community officials for a freetrade arrangement with European countries not seeking entry into the Common Market.

title: Fishbach Gains Net Final
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 4  Peter Fishbach of Great Neck, L.I., seeded second, rallied from a 41 deficit in the third set to beat Steve Ross of Brooklyn, seeded No. 3, 67, 61, 64, in the semifinals of the Long Island men's tennis cham pionships today at the Port Washington Tennis Academy, Fishbach, runnerup in each of the last four years, will play topseeded Gene Scott of New York in the final Sunday. Scott advanced yesterday.

title: Joe E. Lewis, Nightclub Comic Noted for Garrulousness, Dies
description: Joe E. Lewis, the gravel voiced nightclub comedian, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 69 years old.

title: ALBERT CRAIG FISHER
description: ROSLYN, L.I., June 4Albert Craig Fisher, who had been with the New York Telephone Company in various capacities for 40 years, died today of can cer at his home. He was 63 years old and lived at 30 Mine ola Avenue.

title: Drilling Gives Clue to Continental Drift
description: A team of scientists who drilled sample cores from the bottom of the Pacific Ocean has reported finding evidence of a mysterious but major change that took place around the earth between 50 and 100 million years ago.

title: Executives Go to Knitting Class
description: When technology begins to outpace knowledge of how to apply it, there's only one thing to do. Go back to school.

title: Joanee M. McGrath Is Bride in Queens
description: Miss Joanee Marie Mc Grath, a registered nurse on the staff of the New York University Medical Center, and Eugene Paul Ferguson, an administrative analyst with the International Busi ness Machines Corporation, were married yesterday eve ning in St. Kevin's Roman Catholic Church in Flushing, Queens.

title: U.S. COURT VOIDS A STATE'S JOB LAW
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 4 The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit has ruled that state laws per mitting sex discrimination in employment have been invali dated by the Civil Rights Act of 1964. It was the first such ruling by a Federal appellate court.

title: ACCORD IN ALBANY ON CITY TAX PLAN IS REPORTED NEAR
description: ALBANY, June 4Republican and Democratic legislative lead ers were reported nearing agreement this evening on a tax package for New York City of at least $500million.

title: Notes on People
description: William F. Buckley Jr., the conservative editor and col wnnist, has offered to take custody or Edgar H. Smith Jr., who has spent 14 years on Death Row in Trenton State Prison. Smith's con viction for murder was over turned last month, and Mr. Buckley would take custody of him if he were released, pending appeals or the start of a new trial.

title: The Mayor Gets Standing Ovation From His Cabinet
description: Mayor Lindsay's cabinet gave him a oneminute standing ova tion yesterday morning after an emotional speech in which Corporation Counsel J. Lee Ran kin praised the Mayor's behav ior in the budget battle with Governor Rockefeller.

title: U.S. Patent Aide Hopeful of Soviet Deal
description: MOSCOW, June 4William E. Schuyler Jr., the United States Commissioner of Pat ents, voiced optimism today on the prospects of licensing American inventions in the So viet Union.

title: $210 Student Fare Offered By B.O.A.C. on London Trip
description: British Overseas Airways Corporation said yesterday that it would fly students under 26 years of age between New York and London for $210 round trip in the peak summer sea son and $190 during other periods.

title: NATO SEEKS TALKS WITH SOVIET BLOC ON CUT IN TROOPS
description: Text of the NATO ministers' communiqu is on Page 3.

title: IsraelThe 51st State?
description: OWINGS MILLS, Md.A Middle East settlement as envisaged in U.N. Reso lution 242 will depend very largely upon the degree of influence the U.S. is willing to apply to persuade Israel that her ultimate survival depends on acceptance by her neighbors and inter national guarantees, rather than on any specific frontiers secured by con tinuing military superiority.

title: A Question of Borders
description: TEL AVIV  With whom will Is rael sign peace even assuming the best will in the world an the part of Presi dent Sadat? In the twentythree years of israel's existence as a state, there. have been twentysix successful revo lutions in the Arab countries and at least fortytwo unsuccessful revolu tions. In other words, the law of prob ability places in doubt the continued existence in power of any given Arab ruler. Israel must always consider the implications of a possible successor to the partner to negotiations.

title: Soviet Confrontation Threatening Lobster Industry
description: BOSTON, June 4New Eng land lobster men, in an effort to stake out a deepsea fishing claim, have become involved in an international confronta tion that threatens their work in the rich lobster beds of the Continental Shelf.

title: Statewide Branch Banking Is Approved;
description: The State Legislature cleared the way yesterday for a basic overhaul of the banking struc ture in New York.

title: Prisoners as Pawns
description: Hanoi's callous rejection of thirteen sick and wounded North Vietnamese prisoners of war represents the final breakdown of a major AmericanSouth Vietnamese pris oner repatriation effort that never had much chance of success.

title: Mercury in Environment Linked to Burning of Coal
description: The burning of coal around the world may be adding al most as much mercury to the environment as the waste from all industrial processes com bined, a University of Miami scientist has reported.

title: Taiwan Firm on Textiles
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, June 4 (UPI)  Nationalist China and the United States are hopelessly deadlocked over talks on Tai wan's textile exports to Amer ica after four days of meet ings, informed sources said to day.

title: Laverne Hanover and Rum Customer Finish 1, 2 in Tananbaum International
description: YONKERS, June 4The Mar tin Tananbaum International, harness racing's 1mile coun terpart of the Belmont Stakes, wound up with Laverne Han over and Rum Customer giving the Billy Haughton Stable entry a one, two finish at Yonkers Raceway tonight.

title: Flooding Knocks Out Part of IRT
description: Thousands of subway riders had to look for other transpor tation last night when a water main break at Broadway and 72d Street knocked out West Side IRT subway service

title: THE HOSEA STORY BECOMES MUSICAL
description: The Salvation Army's latest stage musical, Hosea, first staged in London last year, will be seen in two performances here with an American cast and chorus of 60 young soldiers and lassies.

title: Mushie, Short of Money, Cuts And Realigns Campaign Staff
description: WASHINGTON, June 4Sen ator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine, whose unannounced Presidential campaign has been plagued by financial and organi zational problems, is again cut ting back and realigning his staff.

title: Music: On Nonobjectivity
description: LONDON, June 4Com posers from all over have come together in London. The occasion is the International Society for Contemporary Music festival. It started last Tuesday and will end next Tuesday, and composers from most of the 25 member coun tries are represented.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Injured Detroit Goalie Retires From Hockey
description: DETROIT, June 4 (UPI) Roy Edwards, 34 yearold Detroit Red Wing goalie who still suffers dizzy spells from a fractured skull he received in a National Hockey League game last December, announced his re tirement today.

title: Peter J. Reidy, ExBuildings Aide Here, Is Dead
description: Peter J. Reidy, the city's Com missioner of Buildings from 1958 to 1962, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital after a long illness. He was 71 years old and lived at 30 Beekman Place.

title: Two Men Sought After Fire Kills 33 Horses at Arlington
description: ARLINGTON HEIGHTS, Ill., June 4 (UPI)  Two discharged employes of a Miami trainer were sought for questioning to day in connection with a fire last night that left 33 horses dead and many injured. at Ar lington Race Track.

title: FUTURES ADVANCE IN NEWCROP CORN
description: Heavy new buying and a scarcity of sellers sent new crop corn futures prices up yesterday, leading a parade of higher commodity prices on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: NEW ISSUE MARKET SHOWS MIXED TREND
