description: The new issue market dis played a mixed performance this week in quiet trading. Only a couple of companies made first public offerings of their common shares.

title: Changes in R.O.T.C. Are Recommended By Education Units
description: WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP) Six national higher education associations today issued statement recommending broad changes in policy in the future role of colleges and universi ties in the Reserve Officers Training Corps.

title: Sink Sets Mark in Track
description: BOWLING GREEN, Ohio, June 4 (UPI)  Sid Sink of Bowling Green set a record of 8 minutes 42 seconds in the 3,000meter steeplechase today at the 46th annual Central Col legiate Conference track and field championships. Western Michigan, with 24 points, led at the end of the first day of competition.

title: ExExecutive to Head ScrippsHoward Fund
description: The election of Matt Meyer, retired ScrippsHow ard Newspapers executive, as president and chairman of the ScrippsHoward Founda tion was announced here yes terday.

title: CAROL MANN GETS ACE, TIE FOR LEAD
description: BALTIMORE, June 4 (AP) The hometown favorite, Carol Mann, who hasn't won a golf tournament in 16 months, shot a holeinone and a threeunder par 70 today to share the first round lead with Jan Ferraris in the $25,000 Lady Carling open.

title: French Push Reform, but Protests Go On
description: PARIS, June 4  The Gov ernment and Parliament pre pared this week to take steps toward the new society that Premier Jacques ChabanDel mas has promised the country. But the country continued to show signs of agitated impa tience with its present lot.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Roundup: 3 Clubs Break Out
description: The Boston Red Sox, Chi cago Cubs and Cincinnati Reds staged their own hit parade last night and it was sour music for 13 opposing pitchers.

title: Rocket Is Fired to Refine Mariner Course for Mars
description: PASADENA, Calif., June 4 (UPI)A short rocket firing switched the Mariner 9 onto a slightly faster course to Mars tonight, lining it up for a swing into orbit around the red planet a day earlier than originally planned.

title: CARNEGIE HALL SETS SIX CONCERT SERIES
description: Six series of symphonic con certs, including the Interna tional Festival of Visiting Or chestras, will be presented during the 197172 season by Carnegie Hall, which will be observing its 80th anniversary year.

title: A Clarification
description: A story in The New York Times from Paris on May 3 re ported that Cofinidus, a holding company owning a 4 per cent interest in the bankrupt Con tinental Company of Financial Management, otherwise known as Fribgest, and based in Lau sanne, Switzerland, was asso ciated with the Bank of Bru xelles. The bank states that while Cofinidus owns shares in the bank, it is not associated with bank.

title: Injury Sidelines Reds' Rose
description: CINCINNATI, June 4 (AP) Pete Rose, an outfielder for the Cincinnati Reds, has been side lined with a sprained right wrist. The Reds said today that the twotime batting champion would undergo an examination to determine how long he will be out. Rose was injured Wed nesday night in the second game of a doubleheader against Chicago.

title: Royals Down Yanks, 62, For 5th Victory in Row
description: The Kansas City Royals, with a new look and a new attitude, added another highlight last night to what is already a most successful season in their three year history.

title: A 10MAN SPY RING SEIZED, ISRAEL SAYS
description: TEL AVIV, June 4The Is raeli Government announced today that it had uncovered a 10man Syrian espionage ring in the occupied Golan heights. It said that the ring had been led by Sheik Kamal Assad Kanj, a prominent figure in the Druse community and once a member of the Syrian parlia ment.

title: COUNCIL VACANCY STIRS A DISPUTE
description: The City Councilman who heads the queens Democratic organization threatened yester day to destroy another Queens Councilman politically in a dis pute over the election of a new Councilman from the borough.

title: Black General in Reserves
description: WASHINGTON, June 4 (UPI) The nomination of the first black general in the military Reserves was confirmed by the Senate today. He is Brig. Gen. Benjamin L. Hunton, 51 years old, of Hyattsville, Md. In civil ian life, General Hunton is assistant director of the United States Bureau of Mines in charge of education and train ing. He will work at the De fense Department on active duty two weeks a year as a minority affairs officer.

title: New Hampshire Measure
description: CONCORD, N. H., June 4 Acting on a promise to keep New ?? Presidential pri mary ?? first in the nation, the state's legislative leadership said today a bill was prepared to move the state's primary ahead by one week.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Joseph Colombo Sr. and Rabbi Meir Kahane will partners in what an ItalianAmerican Civil Rights League spokesman calls the comedy golf tournament of the year next Monday in Eastchester, N. Y. Right now, said Tom Nestro of the league yesterday, I'm waiting for a call from the rabbi to find out how many people he's bringing so I can order kosher meals. Handicaps? Well, Colombo is a pretty good golfer, but I have no idea about Kahane. Oh, no, this isn't our first sports venture. Each of our chapters sponsors a Little League baseball team, we have judo and basketball and for the girls, selfdefense.

title: State Assemblymen Agree Only to Disagree
description: ALBANY, June 4  Demo crats and Republicans in the State Assembly, continuing their fractious, timeconsuming outbursts of recent weeks, could not even agree today on an adjournment date for this prolonged and exhausting ses sion.

title: Windy 0:13.0 by Milburn In the Hurdles Won't Count
description: BILLINGS, Mont., June 4 (UPI)Rod Milburn of South ern University ran the fastest 120yard high hurdles in the history of track at the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics championships today, but it won't count as a world record.

title: 70,000 TripleCrown Fans Expected at Belmont Today
description: The Belmont Stakes, often classified by cynical commen tators in the past as the best kept secret in town, takes rank on its 103d running to day as one of the most popular and widely followed sports spectacles of the year.

title: MRS. JOHN W. STEER
description: Mrs. M. Purcell Wood Steer, a partner in Gillette Camera Supplies of New York for 40 years, died yesterday of can cer at Memorial Hospital. She was 66 years old and lived in Irvington, N. Y., and Glouces ter, Mass. She was the wife of John Wilson Steer.

title: DR. SARA A. BONNETT, PSYCHOANALYST, 75
description: RIDGEFIELD, Conn., June 4 Dr. Sara A. Bonnett, a psycho analyst and past president of the New York Psychoanalytic Society and of the New York Psychoanalytic Institute, died today at her home. She was 75 years old and lived on Bennett Farms Road.

title: Harness the Jordan
description: Palestine awakens again to the con flicting claims of race, religion and government. Both Israelis and Arabs are raking old ashes, stirring smoulder ing fires and fanning fanaticism. Each side refuses to yield an inch. The Is raelis denounce the arming of Arabs by the U.S.S.R. and other bystanders. The Arabs rage at the United States for its support of Israel, and charge it to political pressure by Jewish groups. In spite of hundreds of millions of fol lowers and the sacred relics of his martyrdom, the Galilean has not yet conquered.

title: Dance: Bruce Marks in Danish Debut
description: For Americans perhaps the most interesting and most startling aspect of the 23d Danish Ballet Festival, which ends in Copenhagen tonight, was the appearance of Bruce Marks, of American Ballet Theater, who made his debut with the Royal Danish Ballet as James in La Sylphide.

title: High Cost of Public Pensions
description: Over 11 cents out of every state and local tax dollar represents the retirement and Social Security costs public employes in the State of New York. That startling statistic on the high cost to taxpayers of oldage pro tection for state and city employes comes from Dr. Thomas Norman Hurd, Director of State Operations.

title: Man in the News
description: DETROIT, June 4Close associates who chatted with Frank E. Fitzsimmons, the general vice president of the Teamsters Union, in his of fice today could see the re lease of tension on his face. A month of indecision was over for him, after James R. Hoffa, the imprisoned presi dent of the Team sters, announced yesterday that he would not seek another term as president and would endorse Mr. Fitzsim mons for the post at the union convention on July 5.

title: Pattnan Discloses Details of Reform Bill
description: WASHINGTON, June 4  Chairman Wright Patman of the House Banking Committee dis closed today some details of the bank reform legislation that is likely to emerge from his com mittee.

title: Black Economist Hints at Foreign Aid for Ghettos
description: CHICAGO, June 4A black economics professor said today that if the Federal Government and industry failed to help with the business development of predominantly black ghettos and rural areas then blacks would seek aid from Japan, the World Bank, the United Na tions or the Soviet Union.

title: MARKET EKES ON A SMALL ADVANCE
description: The stock market squeaked through with a gain yesterday, thereby making it five winning sessions in a row, while some bigname issues posted impres sive advances.

title: 4 Oil Companies Scored in Canada On '70 Price Rise
description: OTTAWA, June 4 (AP)The Prices and Incomes Commis sion criticized today four major oil companies  Imperial Oil, Ltd.; Shell Canada, Ltd.; Texaco Canada, Ltd., and the Sun Oil Company, Ltd.for refusing to take remedial action after, it charged, they Increased their prices unduly last year.

title: Witness at Kenny Trial Is Said to Have Received a Death Threat
description: NEWARK, June 4Samuel Di Feo, a Government witness in the trial of nine Hudson County and Jersey City offi cials, has been threatened with death if he does not keep quiet, the United States At torney's office said today.

title: STUDY IS ORDERED ON POLICE ROLES
description: In the aftermath of the kill ing of two patrolmen last month in an upper Harlem city housing project, Mayor Lindsay yesterday ordered a study of ways to improve cooperation and communication between the city police and housing project patrolmen.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: LEGISLATORS PLAN A RISE IN LULUS
description: ALBANY, June 4The State Legislature, which two months ago approved an austerity budg et that resulted in the dismissal of hundreds of state employes and sharp cutbacks in welfare and other services, is planning to increase the expense allow ance of each of its members this year by $2,000.

title: U.S. Construction In Chicago to Get Racial Quota Plan
description: WASHINGTON, June 4 The Federal Government dis closed plans today to impose racial quotas on Federal con struction projects in Chicago, after a voluntary equal hiring program there collapsed.

title: Bridge: Indian Players Are Routed By an International Team
description: BOMBAY, India, June 1 A team of Indian players, whose enthusiasm and occa sional individual brilliance could not compensate for their lack of serious match experience, was crushed here last night by the internation al Precision touring team.

title: Communique Issued by NATO Foreign Ministers
description: LISBON, June 4 (Reuters) Following is the text of the final communiqu issued by the Foreign Ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization here today:

title: Court Dismisses Suit Calling Queens College a Drug Haven
description: A Queens Supreme Court Justice yesterday dismissed a suit brought by two Queens College seniors who charged that the police and college au thorities failed to crack down on narcotics sales and crimes of violence on the campus.

title: FIGHT ERUPTS AGAIN IN CAMBODIAN MARSH
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 4 (AP)  Fighting waned then flared again today in the week long battle for control of the Vihear Sour Marshes, 15 miles east of Pnompenh. The marshes control the eastern approaches to the capital.

title: 2 QUEENS DEATHS LINKED TO HEROIN
description: Two more young residents of the Sunnyside section of Queens were reported dead yesterday of apparent overdoses of nar cotics.

title: Public Jobs for the Jobless
description: The Congressional bill to create public service jobs for the unemployed is a constructive response both to the immediate exigencies of the recession and to the longterm needs of unskilled workers. With nearly five million persons out of work, including many recent veterans of Vietnam, the nation has a moral as well as an economic obligation to take effective action to offset the human consequences of a downswing in the business cycle. The bill, now passed in slightly different versions by both House and Senate, would be at least a modest help because it would subsidize state and local govern ments in hiring 150,000 workers to fill subprofessional jobs.

title: Florida Passes Bill
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., June 4 (AP)The Florida Legislature gave final approval today to a March 14 Presidential primary that could give candidates an alternative to campaigning in New Hampshire.

title: James E. Cahill Jr., Editor Of Aviation News, Dies at 52
description: James E. Cahill Jr., editor and former publisher of Avi ation News, a biweekly news paper for personnel at New York's three major airports, died yesterday at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center after a long illness. He was 52 years old and lived at 628 Duke Street, Westbury, L. I.

title: Brainstorm at the St. RegisHow About a Round Table Like the Algonquin's?
description: It all began when someone decided to try to revive the concept of the Round Table lunches, those informal meet ings of conversational wits that have become part of American literary folklore.

title: Nippon Steel Raises Prices
description: TOKYO, June 4 (AP)The Nippon Steel Corporation said today that it planned to in crease export prices for all of its steel products by about $10 a metric, or about 6 per cent, in idJune.

title: News Analysis
description: The question of how the eventual end of rent control will affect the tenants of New York City is essentially the question of whether private in dustry can work in housing.

title: AIRPORT RAIL LINK GAINS IN ALBANY
description: ALBANY, June 4The Sen ate today passed and sent to the Assembly a bill authorizing the Port of New York Authori ty to finance and construct highspeed rail links from Ken nedy International Airport to Manhattan and from Newark Airport to Newark and its sub urban areas.

title: Council Approves City's Plan To Try to Buy Yankee Stadium
description: The city's plan to negotiate to buy Yankee Stadium was approved by the City Council yesterday, over the objections of its minority leader, who said that Mayor Lindsay had not told the truth about the plan.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Art: Variety of 2d Westbeth Show
description: A few months ago, 12 of the artists who live and work in Westbeth, the artists' hous ing development in the West Village, mounted a large ex hibition of their work in four sizable galleries adjoining the building's courtyard at 155 Bank Street, between Wash ington and West Streets. Now another group of 10 Westbeth artists has mounted a second exhibition in the same space, and this, too, is a series of oneman shows rather than a group survey.

title: ... and a Rare Agreement
description: While this has been one of the most bitterly divisive state legislative sessions in years, a small bill emerges on which both majority Republicans and minority Demo crats seem to find themselves in warm agreement. This is a politician's bill. It provides for a pay boost.

title: BID TO DISSIDENTS HINTED IN KARACHI
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, June 4 The Government of Pakistan appears to be trying to bring some former leading members of the outlawed Awami League of East Pakistan back into the national fold.

title: Governor Vetoes Ban On Oyster Bay Bridge
description: ALBANY, June 4Gover nor Rockefeller late tonight vetoed a bill that would have barred construction of a bridge that has been pro posed across Long Island Sound from Oyster Bay, L. I., to Rye, N. Y.

title: Market Place: How ?? Has Its Values
description: All right, you students of logic: which is better, to be precisely wrong or vaguely right?

title: DOLLAR FALLS AGAIN IN GERMAN TRADING
description: BONN, June 4For the sec ond consecutive day West Ger many's central bank sold an estimated total of $100million at prices that were tantamount to a 3.5 per cent upward reval uation of the mark from its of ficial parity of 3.66 to the dollar.

title: Sato, Opening Campaign, Stresses Foreign Aid
description: TOKYO, June 4Premier Ei saku Sato today opened a three week election campaign for the upper house with an appeal to the electorate to show warm understanding for Japan's foreign aid program, which amounted to $1.8billion last year.

title: RETAIL CHAINS LIST RISES IN MAY SALES
description: Four more major retail chains, including Sears, Roe buck & Co., the country's largest, reported yesterday in creased sales in May over the 1970 month.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: Accord on Relief Reached

title: Mets Defeat Dodgers, 31, On a SixHitter by Seaver
description: LOS ANGELES, June 4 The New York Mets continued to make waves along the West Coast tonight when Tom Sea ver pitched them to a 31 vic tory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Albany's Orderly Procedure...
description: Assembly Speaker Perry S. Duryea has often said recent weeks of intensive activity at Albany that he intended to maintain orderly procedure in the usually hectic windup days of the legislative session. Almost invariably in the past the closing days have been wild and woolly, with deliberation ignored and unexamined bills swept into law by the carload.

title: Naumburg Adds Concert
description: The Naumburg Orchestra, which plays four free summer concerts annually at the Cen tral Park Mall, will offer an ad ditional one on June 23 in mem ory of George W. Naumburg, former president of the Naum burg Symphony Concerts. Mu sic by Bach, Handel and Haydn will be performed by a cham ber orchestra under the direc tion of Frank Brieff. The concert will begin at 8 P.M.

title: U.S. AIDE IN EGYPT WILL MEET ROGERS
description: CAIRO, June 4 The chief United States diplomat in Cairo, Donald C. Bergus, will fly to Paris Sunday for talks with Sec retary of State William P. Rog ers on the current situation in Egypt.

title: Wildness Helps A's Top Senators in 21st by 53
description: WASHINGTON, Saturday, June 5 (UPI)Jim Shellen back walked Reggie Jackson with the bases loaded and then threw a wild pitch for another run in the 21st in ning this morning to give the Oakland Athletics a 53 vic tory over the Washington Senators in the sixth longest game in American League history.

title: Weiss Asks Decontrol Fight
description: A resolution directing the city's Corporation Counsel to challenge the legality of the, recent rent decontrol law passed by the Legislature was introduced in City Council yes terday terday by Councilman Theodore S. Weiss, DemocratLiberal of Manhattan. A spokesman for the Corporation Counsel, J. Lee Rankin, said Mr. Rankin was still examining the matter in detail and had no further comment at this time.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 JUSTICES SCORE DECREE ON VOTING
description: WASHINGTON, June 4  Three dissenting Justices chided the Supreme Court majority today for handing down an 11th hour decree yesterday ordering Hinds County, Miss., to he divided into singlemember legislative districts by June 14.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, June 5  United States officials said that Mr. Burgus had conferred in the last two days with senior Egyptian officials and would transmit their views to Mr. Rogers.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Nixon Offers Broad Plan For More Clean Energy
description: WASHINGTON, June 4 President Nixon announced to day a broad, longrange pro gram designed to assure the nation of an adequate supply of clean energy in the years ahead.

title: CONONERO RATED EVENMONEY PICK
description: He eats 'em up alive, Sa vino Ferraro declared flatly yesterday at Grand Central Terminal. He don't quit, this horse. He's got plenty of re serve.

title: More Phone Lines for Berlin
description: BERLIN, June 5 (AP) Ten new telephone lines were opened today between East Berlin and West Berlin, bringing the num ber to 30. Ten lines were opened Jan. 31, the first for the public in 19 years.

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: Automatic reinvestment of dividends into more purchases of more stock, long a fea ture of investment in mutual funds, is becoming more pop ular with shareholders of other corporations.

title: Mt. Washington Defeats Carling in Lacrosse Playoff
description: BALTIMORE, June 5 (AP) Ab Tiedeman scored the tie breaking goal in suddendeath overtime to give Mount Wash ington a 1211 victory over 1Carling in the Southern Divi sion club lacrosse playoffs today.

title: Six Big Lies About America
description: THE culture of a free society be comes seriously corroded when lies circulate freely as truths; when an unsupported assertion is accepted as a statement of fact rath er than as something to be proved, when the line between possibility and certainty becomes invisible.

title: Announcements
description: Anniversaries

title: U.S. Ties Are Warm, Trudeau Insists
description: OTTAWA, June 5Since his recent visit to the Soviet Un ion, Prime Minister Pierre El liott Trudeau has spoken so expansively of Canadian friendship with our neighbor to the north, that he has aroused new questions about, his fidelity to the neighbor to the south.

title: OBSERVER
description: WASHINGTON, June 5The object of life in America, unless Horatio Al ger, The Saturday Evening Post, the public school system and Al Capone have gravely misled us, is to get rich.

title: 14 NETS' ROOKIES INVITED TO CAMP
description: Fourteen players, headed by John Roche of the University of South Carolina, have been invited to the New York Nets' rookie camp, which wilt open June 20 at Cathedral College in Douglaston, Queens.

title: Cassie Seely Sets Nuptials
description: YARDLEY, Pa., June 5 Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Baggaley Yardley have announced the engagement of Mrs. Yardley's daughter, Miss Anne Cathe rine Seely, to Pvt. William Lippincott RulonMiller, US. A.R., son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel RulonMiller of Ard more.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: M'MICHAEL YACHT WINS Y.R.A, RACE
description: MANIARONECK. N. Y., June 5Howard McMichael, at the tiller of his Etchells22 Class sloop, Kangaroo, was winner of the only long race on Long Is land Sound today when a fleet of 89 sailed in a collapsing breeze in the season's sixth Yacht Racing Association cham pionship regatta, conducted by Beach Point Yacht Club.

title: Humphrey, Now 60, Thinks He Sees a Presidential Opening Ahead, and He Hopes to Plunge Through
description: WASHINGTON, June 5He turned 60 ten days ago, and Hubert H. Humphrey thinks that might be a good age to make another try for the Presi dency.

title: Ratzer Beats Washington
description: Steve Ratzer pitched a no hitter and Alvin Osofsky drove in the runs yesterday as Bowne High School of Queens defeated George Washington, 20, for the Pub lic Schools Athletic League championship at Yankee Sta dium.

title: Dance
description: IF Balanchine says: Bal let is a woman, John Cranko, the director of the Stuttgart Ballet, seems to be saying: Ballet is a man. It is probably just a chance that some of Balan chine's greatest stars are to be found in his superb troupe of male dancers, and that the supertrump in Cranko's pack is a ballerina, Marcia Haydee. No, there is no doubt that Cranko's Stutt gart Ballet, which ended a sixweek season at the Met ropolitan Opera House last weekend, does place an un usual and welcome emphasis on male dancing.

title: Horseplayer Is No. 1 Litterbug
description: There is no litterer like the New York horseplayer, and when 81,036 of them get to gether, which is what hap pened at Belmont Park yes terday, it becomes a night mare for the men with picks who lift trash off the grounds.

title: HARLEM SCHOOL SEEKING $100,000
description: Black parents in Central Har lem are trying to raise $100,000 to preserve a community school experiment that has been sup ported by the New York Roman Catholic Archdiocese even though the curriculum does not include religion.

title: Italians Sign Pact to Save Monuments at Aswan
description: CAIRO, June 5 (Reuters) Egypt has signed an agree ment with a group of Italian companies to save the Tem ples of Philae at Aswan from the rising waters of the As wan High Dam.

title: Laver's Family Beats Tennis at Love
description: Two years ago, just one week after he had won the Wimbledon championship. Rod Laver phoned his preg nant wife at their home at Corona Del Mar, Calif., and was told: If you aren't home Tuesday, don't bother to come.

title: CONFERENCE IS SET FOR SOUTH PACIFIC
description: WELLINGTON, New Zealand, June 5A South Pacific region al conference, considered to have high political significance. is scheduled to be held here Aug. 4 to 6.

title: Gardens
description: A 58  year  old pipefitter who works  of all placesfor a Cincin nati meat packer, has put one over on the nation's professional rose breeders. His rose, named Portrait, is the first hybridized by rank amateur to win an All American Rose Selections award in that organization's 40year existence. AARS is a national plantrating organi zation that tests roses over a twoyear period and awards those of outstanding merit and improvement.

title: Rites Tuesday for Lewis
description: A funeral service for Joe E. Lewis, the nightclub comedian, who died on Friday at the age of 69, will be held on Tuesday at 2 P.M. at the Riverside, Am sterdam Avenue at 76th Street.

title: Horse Show News
description: DEVON, Pa., June 5The United States Equestrian Team will hold dressage tryouts for the PanAmerican Games at Lake Erie College in Paines ville, Ohio, next Saturday.

title: A Dealer Defection at Midas Muffler
description: DETROITThe lean prof its and internal strife in MidasInternational Corpora tion, the automobile muffler replacement giant, have not been relieved by the independ ence of a tall, darkhaired Detroit Midas dealer with a Harvard Business School de gree. His name is Warren L. Jones.

title: Nets Schedule a Series Of Long Island Clinics
description: For the second straight year, the New York Mets of the American Basketball As sociation will stage about 50 clinics in Nassau, Suffolk and Queens Counties. These ses sions will start on July 5 and run through Aug. 20.

title: Paperbacks
description: Recommended New Titles

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE WEEK
description: THE BANKRUPT Penn Central Transportation Com pany is offering for sale 23 parcels of land and several buildings in midtown Manhattan in what could be the largest single real estate deal. Its former parent, the Penn Central Company missed the June 1 maturity date on $50 million of Swiss franc notes.

title: Pop
description: WELL, I can't say I've heard too many dynamite dis taff lead guitarists lately, but that's about the only area of pop music in which the women aren'tat the very leastcoming on strong.

title: DR. LOUIS ODESSKY
description: Dr. Louis Odessky, a patholo gist, died of a stroke yesterday at Montefiore Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived at 7515 180th Street, Flushing, Queens.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONAlthough it does not prove anything, there is some interest in the fact that not one of the 21 questions to President Nixon at his news conference last Tuesday involved the big wage and related price in crease in the aluminum in dustry announced the day before.

title: The Nation
description: The shantytowns that huddle close to the big American mili tary bases in Vietnam all have their scag alleys  the muddy lanes lined with corrugated iron and scrapwood huts where for $5 or so G.I.'s can buy enough heroin to keep at bay for day or so the irritations of military discipline, the boredom of rou tine jobs or the anxieties of com bat patrols at the tag end of an unpopular war.

title: San Francisco's Springtime Flower Tour Of the World
description: SAN FRANCISCOThere are two free walking tours here in the Bay Area that give one a glimpse of an aroundtheworld trip to such farflung places as Africa, India, Australia, Costa Rica, Mexico, Tibet and China.

title: A. K. Moulton, Linda L. Janien Are Wed Here
description: Miss Linda L. Janien and Anthony Kennedy Moulton were married here yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Dr. Harold S. Bosley performed the ceremony in Christ Church, Methodist.

title: About Motor Sports
description: The big teams of the Indi anapolis 500 are planning major design changes for 1972 as the result of the great showing of the three McLaren M16 supercars. Although none of the English built machines won last week's 500, they all had a good shot at winning and they all domi nated the pre race practice. Mark Donohue's M16 turned one 180.9 miles an hour. The competitors who were most impressed were the owners of the winning car, the Colt Ford Johnny Lightning Spe cial driven by Al Unser. Par nelli Jones, a coowner of the Colt, says, We've gone as far as we can go with de sign.

title: Barbara Newman Bride Hereof John Trainer Jr.
description: Miss Barbara Holmes New man was married here yester day afternoon to John Moor head Trainer Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Trainer of Sewick ley, Pa. The Rev. Dr. Terence J. Finlay performed the ceremony in the chapel at St. Bartholomey's Episcopal Church, where the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Allen Newman of Fairmont, N. J., were married 30 years ago. A reception followed at the Colony Club.

title: Austrian HighJumps 63
description: VIENNA, June 5 (AP)Ilone Gusenbauer of Austria high jumped 6 feet 3 inches today, a fraction short of the women's world record held by Romania's Yolanda Balas.

title: Leo Rogers Jr. Weds Carole Garibaldi
description: MERRICK, L.I, June 5 Miss Carole Ann Garibaldi, editor in charge of Right Now, McCall magazine's newsletter section, was mar ried here this noon to Leo J. Rogers Jr., whose late father was mayor of Tren ton.

title: New Ceylon Bid to Rebels
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, June 5 (AP)  The Government an nounced today that 200,000 leaflets carrying Prime Minister Sirimavo Bandaranaike's final call to rebels to surrender would be dropped from airplanes over the jungle hideouts of rebel groups.

title: Brazil Stands Firm on 200Mile Sea Limit and Joins Five Other Latin Nations in Conflict With U.S.
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 5  Brazil has joined five other South American countries that are apparently frozen into a diplomatic confrontation with the United States over control of coastal waters in general and over fishing rights in particular.

title: News of Dogs
description: Grazing in the pastures on the 1,000acre farm of Mrs. Alden V. Keene in Middle town. Del., are 80 Holstein cows, Heloise, a Dorset ewe, and a Tennessee walking horse and her foal. Waddling near the bar are 13 geese. Then there's the Round Table Kennel, housing 45 miniaturepoodles and eight Irish wolf hounds. It is the poodle part of the menage most familiar to thedog show world. Whereas the ordinary fancier brags about breeding one champion. Round Table has accomplished the feat 45 times.

title: The Nation
description: The nation's 5 million unem ployed found themselves last week to be pawns in a battle over public service jobs that may provide more work for politicians than it does for the jobless.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: This is Mondayit must be the Louvre, or in the words of your correspondent Charles Morey, We only have about an hour and must be off to other thingsas he told a guide in his My Three Guides article. Oh, how I admire guide Winkler's restraint and sympathize With his agony at being ex posed to such hurried tour ists as the Moreys. Wouldn't you be irascible with a couple insisting on only the highlights in a stopwatch tour of one of the world's great art museums? For them a dehumanized tape tour might be better. Say, a cas sette played at twice the speed?

title: Staten Island Cricket Victor
description: The Staten Island Cricket Club scored 95 runs to defeat the Brooklyn C.C. by six wick ets yesterday at Walker Park on Staten Island.

title: Ballet: Liebeslieder
description: The season's first perform ance of Balanchine's Liebes lieder Walzer, which came at the New York State Thea ter Friday night, will always be a ballet occasion  but then virtually any perform ance of Liebeslieder Walzer will be a ballet occasion.

title: PLAYER, WITH 204, LEADS AT ATLANTA
description: ATLANTA, June 5  With holes cut in his golf cap to give him improvised airconditioning on this hot, humid day, Gary Player of South Africa moved ahead of Jack Nicklaus to lead the $125,000 Atlanta Golf Classic. I never get tired, said the Johannesburg professional after he posted a fiveunderpar 67 for a 54hole total of 204 and a onestroke lead.

title: On Wodehouse Does Without a Jeeves
description: REMSENBURG, L. I., June 5The afternoon sun pou?? brightly into the large white house on the country lane. P. G. Wodehouse, the author, stood hesitating at the front door.

title: Georgia Burglary Parolee Accused of Ninth Slaying
description: BEAUFORT, S. C., June 5 (UPI)William Pierce, a Geor gia prison parolee, was charged today with another slaying, bringing to nine the number of deaths with which the police have connected him.

title: Queens Residents Are Assured, Local Blackouts Are Unlikely
description: Officers of the 14 community planning boards in Queens are reporting to their members and communities that the borough is likely to avoid the local power blackouts that plagued it last year, but still faces brown outs like the rest of the city.

title: R. F. Pierce 3d, Student, Weds Mary Hetzler
description: RIVERSIDE, Conn., June 5 Miss Mary Evelyn Hetzler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Hetzler Jr., was married here this afternoon to Reginald Franklin Pierce 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Pierce Jr. of Greenwich.

title: PATTERSON EXPECTED TO BOX AT BENEFIT
description: The Patrolman George A. Frees Memorial Fund to aid the families of Suffolk County pol icemen killed or injured in the line of duty, will stage a box ing show at the Long Island Arena in Commack on Friday night.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: BERNAY, FranceAt the end of a long journey through many lands and five continents, the American traveler is forced to conclude that the United States is entering a new and diminish ing phase of national history and in ternational influence. The period of dominance that marked the generation after World War II is rapidly eroding; there never was an American century.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: Outwardly, the Lockheed crisis is that of a private company whose management has been unlucky. Actually, the Lockheed crisis involves the management of a divi sion of the Pentagon's indus trial empire and that man agement's relationship to the Federal central office that controls its affairs (95 per cent of sales). Lockheed is the largest Pentagon subdi vision in the $23billion aerospace industry.

title: TAIWAN MAY SIGN COPYRIGHT ACCORD
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, June 5The Government has decided in principle to sign international copyright agreements, official sources say, putting an end to the sizable book pirating oper ation here.

title: CATHOLIC PRIESTS ACCUSE PORTUGAL
description: ROME, June 5Portugal's colonial policy is still the same but the spirit of the Roman Catholic Church has changed since the second Vatican Coun cil, according to a spokesman for the White Fathers, a Cath olic missionary order. He was explaining the order's decision to withdraw from Portugal's East African territory of Mozambique.

title: Italy Says Coast Resorts Are Seriously Polluted
description: ROME, June 4The most popular areas of the Italian coastline around Rome, Na ples, Genoa and Venice are seriously polluted, Italian authorities declared today as part of a campaign to alert the public to the deteriora tion of the environment.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: June 6Delaware County K.C. altbreed and obedience, Dela ware County Horse Show grounds. White Horse Road and Wayland Avenue. Newtown Square, Pa.; 1,241 entries; 9 A.M.

title: A's Beat Senators, 61
description: WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) Sal Bando's home run in the second inning and Rick Mon day's homer in the fourth helped Jim (Catfish) Hunter and the Oakland Athletics to a 61 victory over the Washington Senators tonight.

title: IN A JAVA VILLAGE, POLITICAL UNEASE
description: DJATINOM, Indonesia, May 31  Tired ponies strapped to family carts with silverstudded harness clop up and down the main street of this central Java nese village as if they are sleep walking. Nothing is new for them along the route to market and back.

title: As Their White House Wedding Nears, a Rare Formal Appearance Together
description: WASHINGTON, June 5The romantic couple of this Administration  Tricia Nixon and Edward Finch Coxappeared together at an official Washington func tion last night for the first time since March 16. That was the date of Presi dent Nixon's confirmation of their en gagement during a White House gala.

title: U.S. SAID TO WEIGH NEW NUCLEAR SUB
description: GROTON, Conn., June 5 (UPI) Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that the United States was actively con sidering a new type of nuclear submarine designed to attack other ships with missiles from beyond the range of their anti submarine weapons.

title: Bobby Unser Gains Pole For Today's 150Miler
description: MILWAUKEE, June 5With the excitement of last week's Indianapolis 500 now history, the United States Auto Club's championship division returns tomorrow to the breadandbut ter circuit from which it draws its vast grassroots audience.

title: SIX SCORE IN 7TH
description: Relief pitchinglast year the New York Yankees spelled it with a capital R and a capital P and never tired of talking about it. This year they use small r and and a small p and would prefer no one mention the subject.

title: What's New?
description: ACHEMICAL stump re mover, Stump Out, when applied as di rected, makes it pos sible to economically remove unsightly tree stumps in six to eight weeks. The material is packed into holes made in the stump with an auger. Kerosene is applied and the stump is ignited. It will smoulder for a time until the wood is dissipated. Stump Out is sold in 8 oz. cans ($1.49) and 16 oz. cans ($2.49). Most hardware stores or Seymour Smith & Son, Inc., Oakville, Conn.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: New Mountain to Climb
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 5 (UPI)Dean Caldwell, one of the two mountaineers who con quered the Wall of Early Morn ing Light on the granite mono lith El Capitan last year, left today on a new expedition to scale an unclimbable 4,000 foot ice wall in the Peruvian Andes. Mr. Caldwell, 27 years old, a Milwaukie, Ore., photog rapher, and his companion, Joe Smith, 24, a Duluth, Minn., climber and skier, hope to top the west face of 20,100foot Mt. Jirishanca on July 4.

title: Showalter Is Elected. Head Of Horse Breeders Group
description: DEVON, Pa., June 5Harry L. Showalter Jr. of Chambers burg, Pa., was elected president of the Eastern Saddle Horse Breeders Association today at the annual meeting of the or ganization.

title: BANKS RELAXING BROWNSTONE BAN
description: There was a cocktail party in one of the more handsome brownstones in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn the other day. But it was no ordinary gettogether.

title: Linda Claire Vanderbilt Is Affianced
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 5Miss Linda Claire Vander bilt and James Sherwood Kitchen, who will be seniors at the University of Denver in the fall, plan to be mar

title: FERDINAND HOPKINS SR.
description: SOMERS, N. Y., June 5 Ferdinand T. Hopkins Sr., a re tired banker and pharmaceuti cal manufacturer, died Thurs day in Northern Westchester Hospital, Mount Kisco. He was 91 years old and lived on Lake Road.

title: Medical Unit Awards Given
description: The Kings County Medical Society has presented its ninth annual Citizens Awards to Mrs. Dorothy Bostic, founderdirec tor of the Junior Academy at 856 Quincy Street: the Rev. Quincy Cooper, minister of the Union United Methodist Church at 121 New York Avenue, and the New York Alliance for the Eradication of Venereal Dis ease.

title: 4 Pilots Die as World War II Planes Crash in Cape May Race
description: CAPE MAY, N. J., June 5 Four pilots were killed today when their World War II planes were involved in two separate midair collisions during a race at the Cape May County Air port. No one else was hurt.

title: Project Making Arkansas River Navigable, Once Scorned, Now Wins Increasing Support
description: The dedication yesterday of the Arkansas River Navigation System, a project once con demned by many as a text book example of porkbarrel politics, comes at a time when the controversial venture is winning increasing support.

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: Can silk survive in a world of manmade fibers? The Queen of Fibers, as it is sometimes called, probably will continue as a viable textile material if it is not priced out of the market. Silk fabrics are still in de mand in the realm of high fashion and will be included in many of the couture lines for the fall season.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: My husband and I spent our honeymoon in Bermuda, and the island Is far more beautiful than John Brooks's article made it sound. I hope that not one reader will have been deterred by his refer ence to the injury he sus tained while riding a motor assisted bicycle. When you are in Bermuda enjoying yourself you don't have time to notice that swollen knee. Go and enjoy.

title: U.S. TO HEED LAW ON LAKE MICHIGAN
description: CHICAGO, June 5The En vironmental Protection Agency disclosed this week that it would heed a littleknown 1910 Federal law and withhold final permission for seven heavyin dustry companies to discharge waste into the southern end of Lake Michigan.

title: Nader Asserts Monopolies Mulct the Public of Billions
description: WASHINGTON, June 5 Ralph Nader and a team of his young investigators charged today that the American public was paying billions of dollars annually in higher prices, lost production, excessive pollution and lack of innovation because of the practices of monopolies that they said no one was try ing to break up.

title: Melnyk Scores, 3 and 2, In British Amateur Final
description: CARNOUSTIE, Scotland, June 5Steve Melnyk, former United States Amateur cham pion, defeated Jim Simons, 3 and 2, in the 36hole final to day and became the first Amer ican since 1967 to win the British Amateur golf cham pionship.

title: President Opens Oklahoma to the Sea
description: CATOOSA. Okla., June 5  President Nixon today hailed the nation's newest civil works project, the vast Arkansas River Navigation System, as a monu ment in action.

title: Wedding Held For Mrs. Paine And an Editor
description: Mrs. Frances N. Paine was married here yesterday after noon to Siadhal Sweeney, an editor with Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, Inc. The cere mony in St. Vincent Ferrer's Roman Catholic Church was performed by the Rev. Arthur O'Brien. A small re ception was held at the Cos mopolitan Club.

title: That Chappaqua Chap Is Back
description: REMEMBER Conrad Rooks? Sure you do: he's that farout fel low who, four years agoat the age of 32wrote, directed and produced Chap paqua, a partially auto biographical movie that de scribed, in exotic detail, the rehabilitation of a narcotics addict. Even though Chap paqua didn't exactly knock 'em dead in Des Moines, Rooks has not had it with the movies. He is, in fact, eager to start work on a new flick, this one entitled Siddhartha, an adaptation of the Herman Hesse novel that was written in 1922 but is a biggie with the college kids of 1971.

title: JEROME W. BRUSH
description: Jerome W. Brush, a former manufacturer and importer of linens, died Friday at Roose velt Hospital after a long ill ness. He was 80 years od and lived at 136 East 64th Street.

title: L.I.'S FIFTH AVE. IS IN GARDEN CITY
description: GARDEN CITY, LI., June 5  When Bloomingdale's broke ground last month for a new branch here, another major New York department store cast a vote for this incorporated village as a key retail location.

title: Favorite Jersey Victor
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., June 5 (AP)  Favorites finished first in both divisions of the Ocean port Handicap at Monmouth Park today as Cragwood Stables Red Reality and An thony Bonuomo's Tudor Reward scored at a mile on the turf.

title: Law
description: WASHINGTONI approve of what they did, and in the event that we have similar sit uations in the future, I hope that we can handle those sit uations as well as this was handled.

title: U.S. LEADS CANADA IN TENNIS, 8 TO 1
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., June 5The United States took an 8to1 lead over Canada in their fifth annual Interna tional Lawn Tennis Club match today on the grass courts of the Piping Rock Club. The Americans won five and split one of the seven singles matches after lending the for mer United States Davis Cupplayer, Ham Richardson, to the Canadians.

title: British Optimistic As Talks on Market Enter Final Weeks
description: LONDON, June 5Negotia tions over terms for British membership in the European Economic Community are en tering their final weeks with London officials optimistic over agreement despite the major issues still outstanding.

title: An Unlikely Twosome of Literary Tours: D.H.L. and Papa
description: The scene of my Nottingham Derby novels all center around East wood, Notts, where I was born. And whoever stands on Walker Street, Eastwood, will see the whole land scape of Sons and Lovers before him Underwood in front, the hills of Derbyshire on the left, the woods and hills of Annesley on the right. The road from Nottingham and Watnali, Moorgreen, up to Underwood and on to Annesley [Byron's Annesley] gives you all the landscape of The White Peacock, Miriam's farm in Sons and Lovers, and the home of the Crich family and Willey Water in Women in Love. The Rainbow Is Ilkeston and Cossall, near Ilkeston, moving to Eastwood. And Hermione in Women In Love is supposed to live not far from Cromford. . . .. from a letter by D. H. Lawrence, April, 1925.

title: Success Story
description: Boogee Boome in the Big Time Boogee Boome was an older girl who had a mudfence for a face and lived and worked in a big plastic hospital. One pro longed evening, inspired by the national hotcakes seller, How to Be In, Expensive and Publish Biweekly, by Prof. Jessie Rolled Oats, Boogee phoned Hollywood, U. S. A., on her princess portable, though her hospital insurance didn't begin to cover even local calls. The great celluloid mogul Attar Wimminsure happened to pick up the wire. As a matter of fact, Attar was at that identical moment scrapdiving for a script about a girl with a mud fence for a face, and when Boogee laid her maidenhood ambition on the line in terms of moneyanglefilmbook, he saw on the acrylic wall eight figures going into nine. Keep mooning on one wire, he privatedialed Robin son Useto, a big downtown editor who was getting ready to go uptown, on another.

title: L.I. Study Finds a Fourth In Junior Highs Try Drugs
description: A druguse study by two Nassau County Medical Center psychiatrists has disclosed that a quarter of 3,807 middleclass junior high school students sur veyed in the county said they had taken drugsmostly mari juanaillegally.

title: Narcotics Are Complicating Sunnyside's Problems
description: Sunnyside, the western Queens community often ignored on official city maps, was noticed last week when one of its residents, a 16 yearold schoolgirl, died from an apparent overdose of hard drugs only a few weeks after her 20yearold brother died of an overdose.

title: Television
description: SINCE cigarette companies no long er may advertise on TV, they've decided to back televised tourna ments to keep their names before the viewing public. Most of the big sports events already have backers, of course, so the tobacco people are using great imagination to come up with pro grams to attract a high rating. Here are some of the interesting programs on the drawing boards for next season:

title: Brookhaven Spurs Its Research Arm
description: UPTON, L. I., June 5 Physicists at Brookhaven Na tional Laboratory are com pleting installation of a $49 million machine designed to soup up this country's most powerful research tool for studying the inner workings of the atom.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. June 5The. United Nations Children's Fund has chartered a plane to fly 30 tons of relief supplies to refugees fleeing from East Pakistan to India, United Nations sources said.

title: 61% in Poll Assert Entry Into the War Was U.S. Mistake
description: WASHINGTON, June 5Six out of 10 Americans now think it was a mistake for the United States to become involved in the Vietnam War, the Gallup Poll reported today.

title: DR. LESLIE NIMS, BIOWGIST, DEAD
description: UPTON, L. I., June 5Dr. Leslie S. Nims, senior biologist and former head of the biology department of the Brookhaven National Laboratory, died last evening of a heart attack. He was 64 years old.

title: Polo Opener at Fairfield
description: WESTPORT, Conn., June 5 The twicepostponed polo game between the Fairfield County. Hunt Club and the New Haven Polo Club has been rescheduled for tomorrow at the Fairfield club at 3 P.M. The game, which will open the Connecticut out door season, originally was scheduled for last Sunday but was called off because of rain. Rain also caused a postpone ment Monday.

title: Unpackaged Japan: A Personal Glimpse Of an Ancient World
description: HAGI, JapanStrolling aimlessly in the evening light, I grinned at a band of young boys playing In the street, and was greeted In return by excited shouts: Gaijin, gaijin!A foreigner, a foreigner! It was a sure sign that I had left the tourist trail behind and reached my goal: the other Japan.

title: BATTLES REPORTED IN KHESANH AREA
description: SAIGON. South Vietnam. Sun day, June 6 (AP) North Viet namese rockets were reported to have struck the port city of Danang yesterday and heavy fighting was reported near Khesanh in the northwestern corner of South Vietnam.

title: Drop Reported in Soviet
description: MOSCOW, June 5Reliable diplomatic sources report that the number of Jews permitted to leave the Soviet Union dropped somewhat in May from the April and March figures, but that it still represented a relatively high figure.

title: Soccer Crown Decided
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, June 5 (UPI)Borussia Moen chengladbach won the West German first division soccer championship today for the sec ond straight year with a 41 victory over Eintracht Frank furt. The victory gave Moen chengladbach an aggregate 50 points from 34 games, 2 points more than Bayern Munich, which lost by 20 to MSV Duis burg.

title: ALBANY APPROVES 333MILLION TO AID PAROCHIAL PUPILS
description: ALBANY, Sunday, June 6 The Legislature has approved a bill designed to provide $33 million in additional state aid to nonpublic schools.

title: Elisabeth C. Maxwell Affianced
description: PITTSBURGH, June 5  Miss Elisabeth Clarke Max well, a secretary at the Sloan School of Management at the Massachusetts Insti tute of Technology, and Robert Harold Sturges Jr., a graduate of M.I.T., plan to be married Aug. 28 in the M.I.T. Chapel.

title: Too Casual on Troop Cuts
description: No one wants the Atlantic Alliance to enter unprepared or divided on important negotiations with the Soviet bloc; but the pace adopted by NATO foreign ministers In Lisbon for talks on mutual force reductions in Europe seems altogether too leisurely. It is now almost certain that NATO's chosen representative will not begin even exploratory talks with the Soviet Union until after meeting of NATO deputy ministers this fall.

title: Hillcrest High Stirring Queens Zoning Furor
description: The Hillcrest High School, nearing completion in Jamai ca, Queens, is not scheduled to open until September, but it has already become the center of an emotioncharged controversy.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: In reply to the letters of Friede F. Rothe and Stanley Lipson referring to my article on the Cultural Exchange pro gram, I should like to clarify certain points.

title: Ousted City Aide Cleared of Fraud In Immigrant Case
description: ALBANY, June, 5An im migration conspiracy charge against New York City's former Relocation Commissioner has been dismissed here.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: After Mick Jagger had left Altamont, he said, If Christ had been there, he would have been crucified. I do not intend to discuss the ac curacy of that remark but rather to point out that Mick Jagger was there, and has been crucified ever since.

title: Religion
description: A giant is gone. Reinhold Niebuhr, the American theo logican, died last Tuesday after more than a decade of serious illness.

title: Front Page 2  No Title
description: WHO Is Harry Kellerman and why is he saying those terrible things about me?Advt.

title: Henry D. Babcock Jr. Marries Mrs. Erica Rohner James on L.I
description: BROOKVILLE, L. L, June 5Mrs. Erica Hohner James of Oyster Bay was married here this afternoon to Henry D. Babcock Jr. of NeW York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Babcock of Mill Neck and Hobe Sound, Fla.

title: Letters To The Editor
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: William Nitze Marries Ann Kendall Richards
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., June 5  Miss Ann Kendall Rich ards of New York was married here today to Wil liam Albert Nitze, whose father, Paul H. Nitze, was a former Secretary of the Navy, a former deputy Secretary of Defense, and currently is a negotiator for the Strategic Arms Limitation Talks in Vienna.

title: Margaret A. Crane Married in Jersey
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., June 5 Miss Margaret Atwater Crane was married here to day to John Mason Morfit at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Thompson Crane Jr.

title: Pratt Institute Is Starting Special Noncredit School
description: Pratt Institute in Brooklyn will offer for the first time, be ginning in October, a program of noncredit courses for which there will be no admission re quirements.

title: Aiken to Oppose Bethpage Today in L.I. Polo Opener
description: The polo season at Bethpage State Park in Long Island gets under way today at 3:30 P.M. when Pete Bostwick, an inter national polo figure, leads Ai ken against Bethpage. Last Sunday's scheduled opener was rained out.

title: Sort for the Moriartys
description: A son was born May 18 to Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Moriarty of New York at the Lyingin Hospital. Mrs. Moriarty is the former Miss Gisela Haffelder. The child, whose father is a vice presi dent for the northeastern district of the Irving Trust Company, has been named Liam MacKenzie.

title: Summer Reading
description: The art of parody lives! On pages 4, 5, 6, 7, ...! Peter DeVries turns P. G. Wodehouse into a black humorist. Frank Conroy sends Donald Barthelme up a mountain. Anthony Burgess rewrites James Joyce as Irving Wal lace. Richard Lingeman solves the latest Ross Macdonald caper. Walker Percy com mits a mercy killing by Richard Brautigan. Mel Watkins does a turn as James Baldwin. Victor Navasky writes ad copy for The Fa mous Editors School. William DuBois re views Summer of '84. James Purdy ushers Boogee Boome into the big time. Jack Nessel plays political bridge. And Richard Brickner strolls down Rue Scribe. All in this issue!!!

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: U.S. Steel Ship Launched
description: LORAIN, Ohio, June 5 (AP) The largest ship ever built on the Great Lakes, the United States Steel Corporations new flagship Roger Blough, named for the company's immediate past chairman and chief ex ecutive officer, was launched here today.

title: RYAN IS CHARGED WITH COAST LOSS
description: LOS ANGELES, June 5The New York Mets' threegame winning streak ended tonight when they wasted 10 hits and were defeated by the Los An geles Dodgers, 30.

title: Movies
description: THE maid who lets me in is named Fatimah; she goes with the gen eral decor of the living room, out of place in a rather banal building on a stodgy residential Paris street. A low, square ottomantype sofa covered with more than a dozen pillows, a huge, brasstopped coffee table, other cushions on the floor. The only chairs are four director's chairs, with orange canvas seats and backs.

title: City coolers
description: The heat's on. And one way to beat it in the steamy days ahead is the almost weightless wrapped dress. Breezy and soft, it folds over the body once lightly showing off curves and tans. For women who don't want to join the shorts or Tshirt brigades, these dresses are an elegant way to keep their city cool.

title: Miss Brocks Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Arthur Brocks of the Bronx have announced the engage ment of their daughter, Miss Kathleen Therese Brocks, to Richard Whiteside, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Jeffer son Whiteside of North Prov idence, R.I.

title: Overseas Earnings Bolster U.S Companies
description: Foreign business made all the difference. ... It pulled us out of the hole....

title: Nashville at the Garden Rocks With Whine of Steel Guitars
description: Madison Square Garden was filled Friday evening with the whine of steel guitars and voices that reflected various reverberations of the twang of the Southern hills. They came from a sampling of Nashville music, bundled together as Nashville at the Garden. More than 11,000 country music followers turned out to hear a collection of Nashville styles that ranged from the tearjerking ballads of Porter Waggoner to the suave croon ing of Jim Ed Brown, from the rockinfluenced beat of Con way Twitty to the coal country song of Loretta Lynn.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: THE WIDENING GAP. De velopment in the 1970's. Columbia University Press. 372 pages. $10.

title: Lewis Rides Altesse Royale to Oaks Victory for Epsom Derby Week Triple
description: EPSOM, England, June 5 (Reu ters)Geoff Lewis completed a classic thoroughbred racing double today when he rode Altesse Royale to victory in the Oaks at Epsom Downs.

title: GORDON IS FASTEST OF JERSEY MILERS
description: HIGHLAND PARK, N. J., June 5Distance runners featured the action in the second week of the New Jersey inter scholastic track and field cham pionships today as five two milers ran under 9:20 and five milers broke 4:20.

title: TWINS ARE DEFEATED BY INDIANS, 10 TO 2
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., June 5 (UPI)Ray Fosse drove in four runs, including three on his third homer of the season, and Craig Nettles hit a bases loaded triple with two out in the seventh to lead the Cleve land Indians to a 102 rout of the faltering Minnesota Twins today.

title: Miss Wilcox Becomes Bride
description: OLD GREENWICH, Conn., June 5Miss Margaret Fran ces Wilcox, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Wilson Wil cox of New Delhi, where her father is a Ford Foundation consultant, was married here this afternoon to Dinsmore Joseph Alter, son of Mr. and Mrs. David E. Alter Jr. of Silver Spring, Md. His father is the Agency for Inter national Development adviser to the Ambassador to the Or ganization of American States.

title: The Vacation TheoryAlways Apply It on Friday
description: I'M going to tell you about The Vaca tion Theory and make you 25 per cent more effective in your business.

title: Stones Set School Record
description: LOS ANGELES, June 5 (AP) Dwight Stones established a national interscholastic record in the high jump in the Califor nia state track and field cham pionships today with a leap of 7 feet 1 inches. Stones erased the previous high school record of 71 set in 1968 by Otis Hailey of Wasco High near Bakersfield, Calif.

title: Are You Ready For Lover Story?
description: THE scene is United Fox Bros. Pictures, located in the heart of down town Manhattan Beach, at the corner of Panic and In decision. As the curtain rises, we see a large oval table around which sit the various studio vice presidents in charge of Sex, Violence, Ob scenity, etc. Standing at the head of the table is Marty Martin Jr., newly appointed 23yearold studio presi dent, holding a copy of Time on the cover of which is Ali McGraw and a line reading, The Return to Romance. Martin speaks:

title: Battrick Is Tennis Victor
description: CHICHESTER, England, June 5 (AP)Gerald Battrick, British Davis Cup player, won the men's title in the Rothmans tennis tournament today by de feating Jan Leschly of Den mark, 62, 98. In the women's final, Mrs. Judy Dalton of Aus tralia heat Janet Newbury of La Jollu Calif., 61, 64.

title: Froehling Bows to Nastase and Kodes Beats Franulovic in French Semifinals
description: PARIS, June 5Ilie Nastase, of Rumania and Jan Kodes of Czechoslovakia gave the French open tennis championships an Eastern European final for the second straight year today.

title: Dorilu Tempera Is Wed
description: BABYLON, L.I., June 5 Miss Dorilu Tempera and Lieut William G. Stratemeier Jr., U.S.A.F. were married here this afternoon by the Rev. John Murray in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church. The bride is a daugh ter of Lou V. Tempera, Suf folk County Commissioner of Labor, and Mrs. Tempera.

title: Czech's Futuristic Novel Is a Satire on Political UpsideDownity
description: BONN, June 5One March 4, dam Juracek, teacher of physi cal education and drawing in a Bohemian spa, became the first person to break the law of gravity, rising gently in his own dwelling and planting his feet firmly on the ceiling, according to the Czech author, Pavel Kohout.

title: 15 COLTS TO RUN IN FRENCH DERBY
description: CHANTILLY, France, June 5 Lord Henry Seymour, one of the originators of thorough bred racing in France was an eccentric in an age of eccen trics.

title: Kathy Whitworth Cards a 68 for 139 and 2Stroke Lead in Lady Carling Open
description: BALTIMORE, June 5 (AP) Kathy Whitworth, a threetime winner of the event, carded a fiveunderpar 68 today and took a twostroke lead in the second round of the $25,000 Lady Carling open.

title: 3Man Spacecraft Orbited by Moscow
description: MOSCOW, Sunday, June 6 A threeman Soyuz space craft went into earth orbit today to attempt another linkup with the Soviet Union's stillcircling space station Salyut, Tass, the So viet press agency, said.

title: SCHOOLS IN SOUTH INTEGRATING FAST
description: WASHINGTON, June 5Fi nal Government figures for the 197071 school year, now end ing, suggest a dramatic drop in the segregation in Southern schools over the last two years, informed Nixon Administration sources disclosed today.

title: Rosemont Bow Scores
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 5 (AP) Bright View Farm's Rose mont Bow, recent victor on the grass in a division of the Cherry Hill Handicap at Garden State, showed her versatility by win ning the $28,700 Bryn Mawr, Stakes on the dirt by two lengths at Liberty Bell today.

title: Minh Assails Saigon's New Electoral Law
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 6  Gen. Duong Van Minh, considered the leading political rival of President Nguyen Van Thieu in the October elections, today publicly criticized South Vietnam's new electoral law.

title: SIX RECORDS FALL IN P.S.A.L. TRACK
description: For one of the few times this spring, weather conditions were ideal yesterday for a scholastic track meet. And the city's Public School's Athletic League athletes responded with some outstanding performances in their championships at Down ing Stadium, Randalls Island.

title: U.S. Panel Urges Reform on Heart Care
description: A national commission of heart disease specialists has urged a comprehensive re form of the way communi ties and the medical profes sion organize their facilities to treat the one million Americans who suffer or die from heart attacks each year.

title: FOR SEEDERS AND WEEDERS
description: Everything goes along now under full speed. All plant ing should be completed.... The first crops of vege tablespeas, radish, lettuce, scallionscan be replanted for summer harvest.... Be alert for aphids and other juice sucking pests that sap young buds; lady bugs and praying mantis make good meals of them or malathion can be used if the pests persist.... Last call to put window boxes in order for summer house displays... Fertilize rosebushes.... Allow bulb foliage to ripen; never, never pull it up or cut it.

title: 330 Men and Women in Field For Annual Wheelchair Games
description: With an eye on next month's Pan  American wheelchair games, as well as individual and team titles, more than 330 men and women from 32 states will compete in the 15th annual National Wheelchair games in Queens starting Friday.

title: Aid to ExShoe Workers
description: WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) The Labor Department has ruled that 550 former shoe workers in Illinois are eligible for special aid because they lost their jobs due to rising for eign imports.

title: CARDS DOWN REDS ON LONG HITS, 53
description: CINCINNATI, June 5 (AI)) Joe Hague drove in four runs today with a pair of homers in powering the St. Louis Cardi nals to a 53 victory over the Cincinnati Reds.

title: Phillies Upset Giants, 53, on McCarver's TwoRun Pinch Homer in Eighth
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 5 (AP)Tim McCarver, a pinch hitter, hit a twoout, tworun homer in the eighth inning to day to give the Philadelphia Phillies a 53 victory over the San Francisco Giants. The de feat stretched the Giants' long est losing streak of the season to four games.

title: Was it, as James Michener says, an accident? Was it manslaughter? Or was it murder?
description: James A. Michener, working with a group of researchers and after ex haustive interviewing, has compiled a detailed account of the grim events that ended in the shooting of four students at Kent State University in May, 1970. Each of his book's 559 pages is crammed with evidence, statements, analyses, and most of those pages suggest also a prodigious effort, on Mr. Michener's part, to achieve evenhanded treatment of his harrowing material. Yet, Kent State: What Happened and Why seems to me to exemplify much of what has gone wrong between America and its childrenmuch, indeed, of the at titudes that helped produce the ter rible, senseless deaths at Kent State. (Mr. Michener will not call them murders or even manslaughter, only an accident, deplorable and tragic.)

title: Welcome Morn Captures Feature at Finger Lakes
description: CANANDAIGUA, N. Y., June (AP)Welcome Morn rallied to beat The Hook by a neck in to day's featured 51,800 eighth race at Finger Lakes race track.

title: Don't Feed People to the Bears
description: AFEW years ago, much to my hor ror, I watched a man move slowly down a slight incline toward what could have been his doom. He was wearing Bermuda shorts and a Hawaiian sport shirt. A Polaroid camera hung from his neck. He was far more intent on figuring out how to work his camera than he was on watching the reaction of the bears he was approaching. The scene of the potential tragedy was a garbage dump near Whitefish Lake in Ontario's Algonquin Provincial Park.

title: Bridge
description: During his term of office, declarer need suffer no inhibi tions. One of his prerogatives is to tell lies, for only the enemy is there to believe them. Dummy cannot react, except on the emotional plane. Victor Mao and Nico Gardner in Card Play Technique

title: Mary Weiner, Student, Bride
description: RIDGEWOOD, N. J. June 5  Miss Mary Christine Weiner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Clarence Weiner Jr., was married in the West Side Presbyterian Church here this afternoon to Todd David Peterson, son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Peterson.

title: Dennison Disheartens Suffolk Democrats
description: CENTEREACH, L. I., June 5  The four telephones in the law offices of Dominic J. Baranello, chairman of the Suffolk County Democratic party, rang continuously this week.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Student Weds Martha Ward
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 5  Miss Martha Leland Ward, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Evans Ward, was married here this after noon to Jay Alden Bonte cou, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Metcalf Bontecou of Millbrook, N. Y.

title: Opposition Deputy, Jailed in Delta, Back in Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 5A prominent antiGov ernment member of South Vietnam's lower house came out of jail this weekend after a brief and bizarre confrontation with authorities in his home district, with his own political fortunes greatly enhanced, and the Thieu Administration's rep utation embarrassingly tar nished.

title: ANTIWAR ACTIVIST ASSISTS JOHNSON
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 5 About a day after Doris H. Kearns, a bouncy, 5foot4 young woman from Long Island who teaches political science at Harvard, was picked as a White House Fellow under President Johnson four years ago, an article by her appeared in The New Republic under the head line How to Remove L.B.J. in 1968.

title: U. S. Begins Action to Enforce Billboard Curbs
description: CHICAGO, June 2The De partment of Transportation, after five years of inactivity, is taking the first steps to force state highway officials to com ply with Federal billboard con trol laws.

title: Steven Scott: Ubiquitous Music Maker
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., June 5Any Long Islanders who go dancing at a country club this weekend are apt to find themselves stepping to the music of Steven Scott.

title: 9 MARKS BROKEN IN MEET ON COAST
description: BERKELEY, Calif., June 5 (UPI)Jorma Kinnunen of Fin land hurled the javelin 288 feet, longest throw In the world this year, and three New York Athletic Club stars, Tom Gage, Barry Brown and Ron Laird, were among nine competitors who set meet records today in the Kennedy Games.

title: PHILADELPHIA FAIR EXPOSES F. B. L
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 5 The Federal Bureau of Investi gation received a good deal of unwanted attention today.

title: Barbecue lesson
description: If there was ever an official opening for the barbecue scene, it must be the first week in June. And to judge from the sale of barbecue equipment these days, that form of primitive cookery borders on national mania. Sauces for barbecued meats range from an elegant tarragon butter with a dash of Chablis to basic redthe Maineto Hawaii favorite that uses catchup as a blastoff point. Southern catchup sauce is listed here, and you can't get more basic than that. Another basic: The step photographs above that demonstrate one method of keeping the chicken flat on the grill. The thing to re member about barbecued chicken is thatif you can't manage barbecue it to a turnit is better overcooked than undercooked.

title: COSMOS SUBDUED BY TORNADO, 20
description: DALLAS, June 5The Dallas Tornado scored twice in the final 7 minutes tonight to score a 20 North American Soccer League victory over the New York Cosmos before 5,476 fans at Franklin Field.

title: If You Think It's Groovy To Rap, You're Shucking
description: WHEN you are trying to be a suburban Dharma Bum you have to try harder. Between the tennis court and the parking lot I read On the Road 15 times and memorized Howl, and managed only to learn about language.

title: Medicine
description: Pain (pn) n. A sensation of hurting, or strong discom fort, in some part of the body, caused by an injury, disease, or functional dis order and transmitted through the nervous system.

title: Summer Racing Looks Up in Florida
description: MIAMI, Fla., June 5Sum mer racing appears to be taking hold in South Florida. The new Calder Race Course needed an average handle of $400,000 daily to break even and the betting has surpassed that by about $85,000.

title: Music
description: IN one respect Czech musicians are better off than their colleagues in the other arts. Music basically is non ideological, and Czech musicians have correspondingly more freedom than drama tists and filmmakers. One can hear avant garde music in Prague, thanks to the group known as Musica Viva Pragensis; and the pieces they playand play well are as contemporary as anything in New York London.

title: Music
description: WHEN Michael Rabin was 3 years old, his musician  parents discovered he had perfect pitch. When he was 15, he made a spectacular debut as a concert violinist, playing the Paganini Concer to No. 1 in D Major with the New York Philharmonic con ducted by the late Dimitri Mitropoulos at Carnegie Hall. Critics hailed Michael as a phenomenal child prodigy, and he was described as a pudgy, pinkfaced, cocky kid. When he was 27, the cocki ness was gone. He had a ner vous breakdown.

title: Money Grows; Wall St. Frets
description: The specter of inflation is haunting Wall Street once again  at a time when progress in halting the steep upward spiral in prices of the last five years has been, at best, no more than mod est.

title: Claire Whitman Engaged to Wed A Lawyer Here
description: BEDFORD HILLS, N. Y., June 5Mr. and Mrs. Peter Morton Whitman of Bedford Hills and Nantucket, Mass., have made known the en gagement of their daughter, Miss Claire Sanford Whit man, to Harry R. Marshall Jr. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Marshall of Mount Kisco. A wedding in September is planned.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: Your critic Clive Barnes asked, with a tincture of sar casm, why my dramatization of Bleak House never had a Broadway production. I don't know. I sold the dram atization to films (with other properties) for one mil lion, two hundred thousand on a capital gains deal. My interest then lagged.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: We spent a great deal of money to see No, No, Na nette, a wonderful show with wonderful actors and ac tresses. It is, however, a shame that the sound had to be amplified with a very bad loudspeaker system. Frankly, any decent hifi set would have given a better reproduc tion of the sound. We sat in the first row of the mezzan ine, and the trumpets sounded as though the angel Gabriel were blowing them from above.

title: Target: The Police
description: Violence against the police is rising to an ominous level. Across the nation, 51 policemen have been killed since the beginning of the year, seven of them in this city.

title: Friday Night Fights
description: Inglewood, Calif.Jos Napoles, 146 pounds, Mexico City, knocked out Billy Backus, 145, Syracuse, 8 rounds, Napoles won world wel terweight championship.

title: Anne Burke Married
description: Miss Anne Patricia Burke, daughter of Francis D. Burke, a captain in the New York City Police Depart ment, and Mrs. Burke of New York and Point Look out, L. I., was married here yesterday morning to Thomas J. Corridan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Corridan of New York. The Rev. John O'Brien, cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass in the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Family.

title: Marine Biology (and for Credit) Brings Out the Best in Students
description: John Dewey High School in Coney Island has become the first in the city to offer Re gents credit to students study ing marine biology.

title: 8 Hydros and Debris on Hand for President's Cup Race
description: WASHINGTON, June 5 A Potomac River swollen with debris from recent heavy rains has added to the problems suf fered by the sensitive sport of unlimited hydroplane racing on the eve of tomorrow's final heat of the President's Cup re gatta.

title: The veranda set
description: Between now and Labor Day, those creaking wicker chairs that conjure up lemonade and lazy afternoons will be in use almost constantly on the Lee Eastmans' veranda. Ever since the New York lawyer and his family moved into their sprawling nineteentwenties summer cottage, left, in East Hampton, they have tended to consider it more a porchwithhouse attached than vice versa. The porch, screened from the street by high hedges, is where the couple and any of their seven children (including Mrs. Paul McCartney, wife of the erstwhile Beattie) and five grandchildren who happen to be visiting, spend most of their time. When the fog rolls in there are inviting rooms to escape torooms simply furnished, brightened with floral patterns and warmed by sunny colors and generous fireplaces.

title: SEARCH FOR BODIES MAY BE NEAR END
description: YUBA CITY, June 5 (UPI) Sheriff's deputies, guided by in frared photographs, failed to day to unearth more victims from the Feather River or chards that have yielded the bodies of 25 slain migrant work ers.

title: Traveling Hard Class On the TransSiberian: Lights Out at 7 O'Clock
description: NAKHODKA, U.S.S.R.  Tucked away in an obscure corner of the Armory Museum within the Kremlin walls in Moscow, 5,500 miles from this port city on the Sea of Japan, are several extraordinarily tiny works of art encased in glass. Of 56 fabled Imperial Easter eggs created by Peter Carl Faberg, only a handful re main to testify to a vanished age of opulence, craftsmanship and beauty. Perhaps his masterpiece was the Great Siberian Railway Easter Egg, made in 1900 to celebrate the near completion of the line. The egg is of green, yellow and blue enamel on which delicate inlays of silver trace the map of Si beria and the route of the TransSi berian Railway.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON President Nixon's assertion to the nation on Tuesday night that he deemed news conferences as in appropriate forums in which to comment on any partisan po litical matters was followed the next day by a flat, and equally straightfaced, denial by his press secretary that neither Mr. Nixon nor his staff was concentrating in any way on the 1972 election.

title: Brooklyn Diocese Reorganizes To Improve GrassRoots Help
description: The Brooklyn Roman Catholic Diocese will undergo a major reorganization this month in an attempt to deal more effectively with the problems of its parishioners at the grassroots level.

title: Ann Sheffer Wed To Jay Allen Reich
description: WESTPORT, Conn., June 5 Miss Ann Elizabeth Sheffer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Sheffer, was married here this evening to Jay Al len Reich, son of Mrs. Alex Reich of Pittsburgh and the late Mr. Reich. Rabbi Byron T. Rubenstein performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents. He was as sisted by Cantor Paul Kwar tin.

title: The World
description: DANANG, South Vietnam Nothing symbolized the hopeless ness of the prisoner of war issue more than the view last Friday morning from the top deck of the U.S.S. Upshur, a comfortable troop transport sailing the South China Sea. The ship, carry ing 13 disabled North Vietnamese prisoners who wanted to go home, and a tug pulling a re modeled barge to transfer the captives to their countrymen were going around in circles.

title: Miss Kingsbury Wed
description: Miss Caroline Hobart Kingsbury, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Henry A.
