Kings bury of Belleair, Fla., was married here yesterday aft ernoon to Naoyuki Sugimoto, son of Mr. and Mrs. Shigeji Sugimoto of Shizuoka Pre fecture, Japan. The Rev. Ro sen Seki performed the cere mony at the Buddhist Church of New York. The bride is a greatgranddaughter of Gar ret A. Hobart, Vice President of the United States under President William McKinley.

title: Mexico, New Zealand Split Davis Cup Singles Matches
description: MEXICO CITY, June 5 (AP) Mexico and New Zealand were tied, 11, today as they split two opening singles in the final of the North American Zone Davis Cup tennis com petition.

title: Criminals At Large
description: As in Ira Levin's Rosemary's Baby and Fred Mustard Stew art's The Mephisto Waltz or to go back to a minor classic  The Greater Trumps by Charles Williams, William Pe ter Blatty's THE EXORCIST (Harper & Row, $6.95) deals with ancient and evil matters. Even in these days of Existen tialism and the Death of God (though we don't hear too much about the latter any more), something in us quivers when thinking of things that go bump in the night. Or bump in the psyche. The phylogeny of man, his climb up the evolutionary ladder, covers a couple of mil lion years. His mind, no matter how liberated, still remains ca pable of inexplicable responses and frightening seizures.

title: National Notes
description: The Nixon Administration lately has been expressing con cern about the recent rash of police slayings in the country. To underscore this concern, and to unveil a proposal to help the families of slain policemen, the White House called a special meeting last week. But when the meeting was over, it may have generated more controversy than anything else. These were some of the results:

title: Hearing on Aid to Lockheed Starts in Senate Tomorrow
description: The Nixon Administration goes before a patently divided Congress tomorrow to begin making its case for the finan cial rescue of the nation's largest defense contractor, the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Carla Anella Married
description: Miss Carla Diane Anella was married yesterday morning to Ens. William P. McHale Jr., U.S.N., in the Roman Catholic Church of the Blessed Sacrament in Jackson Heights, Queens. The Rev. Francis Dobson per formed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass. The bride's parents are Mrs. Ralph Anella of Jackson Heights and the late Mr. Anella. Her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. McHale of West Hempstead, L.I.

title: Drama Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR:

title: Stamps
description: JULY 1 is a historic date in the annals of United States postage stamps. The first Federal issues the 5c red brown Ben Franklin, and the 10c black George Washington stamps had their first day on that date in 1847. Now, on July 1, 1971, that date will inaugu rate the official transfer of the deficitoperated Post Of fice Department to what it is hoped will eventually be a profitable Government cor poration, the United States Postal Service. It will also be the date when another 8cent definitive stamp will be is sueda stamp that will have for its central vignette the official symbol of the U.S.P.S. On that date, too, Postmaster General Winton M. Blount will lose his seat in the President's Cabinet.

title: EVERS MOVE FREES MISSISSIPPI VOTES
description: JACKSON, Miss., June 5 The decision by Charles Evers, the Negro leader, to run for the Mississippi governorship as an independent in November has cast loose 268,000 Negro votes that could become a major fac tor in determining which of six white candidates wins the Democratic gubernatorial pri mary in August.

title: BEVERAGE DEPOSIT PASSED IN OREGON
description: SALEM, Ore., June 5The Oregon legislature has approved a bill that will require a deposit on all softdrink and beer con tainers next year.

title: Mrs. AnneMarie Rockefeller Is Wed to Robert W. Krogstad
description: POUND RIDGE, N. Y., June 5Mrs. AnneMarie Rasmus sen Rockefeller, who was divorced from Governor Rockefeller's son, Steven Rockefeller, last June, was married here this afternoon to Robert W. Krogstad, presi dent of the Leer Manufactur ing Company of New Lisbon, Wis., makers of commercial refrigeration equipment.

title: Eleanor Johnson Is Wed To Kenneth Auchincloss
description: PEAPACK  GLADSTONE, N.J., June 5Miss Eleanor Muir Johnson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Collister John son of Far Hills and West Tisbury, Mass., was married here this afternoon to Ken neth Auchincloss, son of Mrs. Northam L. Griggs of Southampton, LI., and New York and Douglas Auchin doss of New York.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Trout Abound in Allagash
description: UMSASKIS LAKE, Me. Quick and lean and as ebul lient as ever, Camille Beaulieu, North Woods guide, trapper, mail carrier and raconteur paddled his 20foot Grumman canoe along the east shore of Umsaskis Lake on the Allagash Wilderness Water way and said that we would soon have a togue (lake trout) aboard.

title: Rue Scribe
description: Oh, when I hear the Pater of the Cervantes in the morn ing, and their Trilling, I Bellow, Maugham's the word! I'm Schiller sleep! But they keep up their Babel. Kleist, I Isher wood shut up. But I'm Wouk, so I Doderer out of bed feeling Croce, and go Dupee and Shirer. For Brecht Fast orange Joyce Coffin Simenon toast. Nothing to eat Sagan til Dine sen except for Cuppy Tey. Read the Poe Peyre and the Mailer. Then to Ruark. Writing Sa one! You West your Heine on your Benchley (unlike Wolfe, who would Stendhal Day) waiting for your Musil to give you a Bissel idea. Some days, of Corso, you have the Spark. You're sitting Purdy, you could write Warren peace. Aleichem, these days. But author times you Howells, I'm Capote! What's Da Ponte of it all? Life is O'Hara. You could Go gol with arsenic, Ortega dose of cyanide, but you know you Auden, you've Goethe Mon taigne yourself, so you swallow two Empson with a Drinkwa ter. Then you have a few Bierce and a Plato Lamb, and you're feeling Betti, your Malamud is Lessing. And you De Sade, Vidal your Grau Synge, aren't you Berdyaev than the average Mann?

title: The Indian Name Eeseeoh Means River of Cliffs
description: LINVILLE FALLS, N.C.As more and more city dwellers hearken to the call of the wild, many of America's wilderness areas are losing their wildness. Linville Gorge is a rare exception. After a 10minute, drive from this small town in western North Carolina, the visitor can park his car on an improved road, and take to the trail to hike a few hours or set up camp along a deserted trout stream amid the primeval gloom and magic of soaring hemlocks and massive oaks within sound of a 90foothigh water fall.

title: the traveler's world
description: WITH so many people talking like latterday Dan'l Boones about going atenting and atrailer ing in pursuit of the simpler outdoor life, it behooves the conscien tious reporter to make personal sacri fices to check out what they are talking about with so much loud enthusiasm. So we arranged a tightly controlled labora tory experimentnot too far from the creature comforts of home, not too much exposure to the great outdoors and a guaranteed minimum of outdoor physical work.

With its gray Gothic towers looming above the Midway's green lawns, the University of Chicago had the look of instant greatness.

description: Through a nationwide clean up campaign executed by Boy Scouts and adult helpers, thou sands of miles and acres across the country were reported cleared of litter.

description: MOSCOW, June 5  The Soviet Union today criticized Arab political figures who advo cate improved relations with the United States as a way of increasing pressure on Wash ington to cease its support for Israel.

title: An Explorer's Notes
description: Today the last and most difficult part of the ascent was completed. The smooth, pearlgray vertical cliff on our left, whioh afforded so few opportunities for the placement of pitons during the last few weeks, began to show some cracks and fis sures this afternoon. The rough pink wall on our right, previously soft, with a tendency to crumble under our picks, grew firmer. We scrambled up the intersection of these two walls, driving the long pitons into the crack, swinging back and forth to set the short ones in the brittle gray and the firm pink cliff faces alternately. A secure network of ropes was strung and we were able to haul the heavi est equipment boxes, two at a time. The mood of the company brightened as the day wore on. The native boys took up a chant in their mysterious liquid tongue. They had been silent for days.

title: $1Million Belmont Handle Makes It Three for OTB
description: Pass Catcher's glittering $71 payoff on the tote board at Belmont Park yesterday pre vented offtrack betting from completing its own version of a Triple Crown sweep.

title: The Poohlitzer Prizes
description: Among the juvenilebook industry's most coveted awards are the annual Poohlitzer Prizes, or Winnies, as they are affectionately referred to in the trade. A panel of distinguished critics, editors, librarians and bubble gum vendors will soon announce the prizewinners for this year from the following finalists.

title: Summer of '84
description: Harold Rowdy's first novel can best be described as home made citrate of magnesiaI fumble for a more elegant phrasea doityourself pur gative that novelists (mostly, but not always, young) have ingested since novels were in vented. With beneficial effect, as substitute for the analysis they probably can't afford.

title: Ontario Vetoes a Partly Built Expressway in Toronto in Favor of Rapid Transit
description: TORONTO, June 5In a decision that may influence transportation patterns in other North American cities, the On tario government vetoed this week a highly controversial expressway, already partly built, to bring commuter cars into downtown Toronto.

title: Baseball Brings AddictPolice Peace
description: LONG BEACH, L. L, June 5 Babe Ruth struck out, Joe DiMaggio missed an easy pop fly and Christy Mathewson was hit unmercifully as a softball team of narcotics ad dicts undergoing a metha done treatment program at the Long Beach Memorial Hospital played a team of local policemen this week.

title: ORIOLES WIN, 124; REGAIN TOP SPOT
description: MILWAUKEE, June 5  Paul Blair's career grand slam home run capped a six run sixth inning today for Baltimore and the Orioles went on to rout Milwaukee, 124, and regain first place in the American League's Eastern Di vision.

title: The Nation
description: Bella S. Abzug, the tough talking liberal Democrat from Manhattan, jumped into New York's citystate imbroglio last week by launching a drive to make New York City the 51st state. Explaining that she would seek a citywide referen dum to take the issue to Con gress, Mrs. Abzug acknowl edged that both Congress and the Republicancontrolled Leg islature would have to approve statehood, but she argued: When a state government, dominated by farmers and fish ermen and political opportun ists, can turn its back on a city in crisis, it is time to take a serious look at the prospects for obtaining control of our own destiny.

title: BUSINESS LETTER
description: What's a nice big company like Continental Oil doing getting involved with an oil drilling fund? Financing a large chunk of Its domestic exploration program, that's what.

title: HORSE SHOW TITLE TO VAN RAPOPORT
description: DEVON, Pa., June 5Marvin Van Rapoport stood outside the ring at the Devon horse show tonight and looked admiringly at Spindletop Showdown, his great conformation hunter.

title: Chives and Company
description: Cook is most pleased you liked the ragout, sir. You're the finest judge of horseflesh in all of England.

title: The Campfire Next Time A letter from Jimmy Little Dove Baldwin
description: I have known you all your life, Little Knife, I have carried you on my back, kissed and spanked you, watched you learn to walk to the stream at dawn to wash away yes terday's humiliations as had your father and his father before him. You are tough, Little Knife, but vulnerable, more vulnerable than you know. Your face is scarred with ritual markings and the ravages the world has visited upon our tribe, as it were, our people. But it is a time less face; and, when I look upon it, I see all the faces that went before your father, whom I knew I knew and cried for and your grandfather, who, no longer able to abide the perdition that is our plight, took to the circuitous path that is war ant felled Gen. Louis Armstrong Cluster at Funky Big Horn before he himself was felled.

title: Snow Man, $15.20, Victor
description: ALBANY, Calif., June 5 (AP) Snow Man won the $21,400 Emeryville Stakes at Golden Gate Fields today by 1 lengths over Esquiraza. Windy Point, the favorite, was third. Snow man paid $15.20 and was timed in 2:02 2/5 for the 1 mile race.

title: About Pro Football
description: Pro football is now old enough to regenerate its own, meaning to have sons of famous players enter the ranks. The first notable one was Bronco Nagurski Jr., son of an original member of the Pro Football Hall of Fame. Bronco Jr. was for many years a star linemanin the Canadian League.

title: Mulligan Stew Irving Wallace Rewrites Ulysses
description: It was eight o'clock on a June morning with the sun shining on the bay, and the women of Sandy cove were at their household chores or doing their shopping, most of them in their customary attire for summer and winter alike of drab wool and, if they were out of doors, a coarse shawl by way of headgear.

title: Teeming Calcutta: The Focal Point Of Social Change In Today's India
description: CALCUTTA, IndiaIf you go sight seeing here and happen to ask your guide about the famous Black Hole of Calcutta, you will probably be told, according to the offi cial Government line, that there is no such thing and never was. This is not quite true. The Black Hole was a room in which a hundred or so Britishers suffocated in 1756 while imprisoned there by the ruling Indian nawab. The room no longer exists since it was in the old British fort, which has been de molished. The new fort is occupied by the Indian Army and is off limits to tourists.

title: C. I. A. Identifies 21 Asian Opium Refineries
description: WASHINGTON, June 5 United States intelligence agents have identified at least 21 opium refineries in the bor der area of Burma, Laos, and Thailand that provide a con stant flow of heroin to Ameri can troops in South Vietnam.

title: The Nation
description: For years, Nelson A. Rocke feller and John V. Lindsay have publicly denied stories that said they couldn't stand each other. But last week, the Governor finally said in public what he has been saying in private for a long time: He believes the Mayor is inept.

title: Law
description: WASHINGTONIf it's against the law to be obnoxious, how many are sure they would es cape? Yet in manyif not most of the communities in the United States, there had been in effect for many years laws that make it a punishable offense to be, as one legal writer has put it, undesirable, objectionable or generally obnoxious.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  You better take this coffee, Mr. Secretary, because you're going to need it. Because you're in trouble.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Warren S. Josephy's recent letter displays a failure to grasp basic prin ciples of the antiwar movement; Viet namization and, indeed, the entire Indochina policy of the current Ad ministration are based upon the prem ise that yellow Vietnamese lives are less valuable than overwhelmingly white American lives and, therefore, provide a ready substitute in the Asian carnage.

title: Coins
description: AN exhibiton of more than 100 items created by Victor David Brenner, American sculptor and medalist, will open on Satur day  the centennial of his birthat the Chase Manhat tan Bank Money Museum, 1254 Avenue of the Americas at 50th Street.

description: BRUSSELS, June 5, (Reuters) The Common Market's Ex ecutive Commission announced plans yesterday to stimulate investment and create 300,000 now jobs in depressed farming areas over the next five years.

description: WICHITA, Kan.Lawrence Prilliman is a 45yearold aerospace industry draftsman who never worked on the SST, Project Apollo, or a fighter plane for the Pentagon.

description: As football fans expect a quarterback to throw touch down passes, soccer fans ex pect a center forward to score goals. But if a center forward goes scoreless in four games, it is comparable to Joe Na math, say, failing to connect in four quarters.

title: TAKEI CAPTURES GYMNASTIC EVENT
description: MIAMI BEACH, June 5 (AP) Yoshiaki Takei, the twotime National Amateur Athletic Un ion champion, had first, second and third place medals draped around his neck in the first three events at the World Cup gymnastics championships to day.

title: Lenny Lost His Cool...
description: THE tragedy of Lenny Bruce, who is the subject and wouldbe hero of a new floorshow spectacular at the Brooks Atkinson, was that he became the very same obsessed creature he ought to have been sati rizing. Comedy is made of obsession, of compulsion. The great fools we laugh at  in literature or in vaudeville  are victims of urges they can do noth ing to abate.

title: Christian Feucht Is Dead at 92; Operated Coney Island Cyclone
description: Christian Feucht, the dean of Coney Island thrillride opera tors, died in his sleep at his home Wednesday. He was 92 years old and lived at 1704 Avenue N, Brooklyn.

title: Report Warns Suffolk of Loss Of Pure Water Without Sewers
description: MELVILLE, L. I., June 5  Suffolk County will begin to run out of fresh water within 10 years unless a countywide sewer network is built at a very fast clip, according to a comprehensive report on the county's water resources.

title: The Underground Byebye Still Another New Lew Archibald Novel by Ross Macdonald
description: I edged my car gingerly onto the freeway, joining the dense flow of traffic like a lemming hellbent for the seaor was it election? To my left, Simon Rodias's Watts Tower rose like a junk hymn to recycled Coke bottles. The sky above L.A. was like a dirty window in a two dollar whorehouse. Make it 10 dollars with the inflationrecession.

title: An End to the Death Penalty
description: We are in the midst of a great national debate over capital punish ment The debate is being carried on in the legislative, executive and judi cial Chambers of our state and national governments. Since June 2, 1967, there have been no official executions in our land.

title: Canonero II's Trainer Regrets Entering Horse Only 75% Fit
description: A few minutes after he had heard the encouraging cheers of 2,000 Venezuelans in the rec ord crowd at Belmont yester day, Juan Arias said sadly: The horse shouldn't have run. It was only 75 per cent fit.

description: DENVER, June 5  Should museum professionals be union ized? How should trustees be have? And what does it take to make community art facilities work?

description: Bruce Davidoff of Union Temple, seeded third in the Amateur Athletic Union's na tional onewall handball cham pionship, advanced to the fourth round of the tournament yesterday by defeating unseeded Neal Bocian of the Browns ville Handball Club, 2120, 21 12, at the Brighton Beach Baths.

title: Cynthia Casey Bride Of Robert S. Potters
description: RYE, N. Y., June 5Miss Cynthia Anne Casey, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. James D. Casey Jr., was married here this afternoon to Robert Sands Potters, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Potters of Essex Fells, N. J., and Londonderry, Vt. The Rev. Edward Dough erty, a cousin of the bride's mother, performed the cere mony in the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection.

title: An Indiana Town Settled by Two Early Communes
description: NEW HARMONY, Ind.Back in 1815, a strange flotilla drifted down the Wabash River. There were nearly 800 persons in the various boats searching for a new home. Some 50 miles above the spot where the Wabash empties into the Ohio River, their craft headed for a jutting sandbar.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: I have become one of those tightlipped travel consumers Paul J. C. Friedlander wrote about when he discussed tough customers in his col umn (Travel section, May 16). We may never go to the Caribbean again, although we went there often in the nine teensixties. Our 10day visit to one of the islands in 1968, staying at a guesthouse and being served small amounts of cafeteria food, cost $1,050. Our 21day trip to Holland and Ireland in 1969, when we stayed in a lovely canal house, a castle and village inns, cost $1,433. On that vacation we had a variety of scenery and interesting food and a wealth of history, art and charming people. Both of the cost figures I have given included air fares, car rentals, drinks and an occasional tour. There is no question which was the better buy.

title: RUSSIAN REACTION ON NATO HESITANT
description: MOSCOW, June 5The So viet Union reacted cautiously today to yesterday's communi que by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization that called for further probing of Soviet intentions on the reduction of forces in Central Europe.

title: Broncos Obtain Roberts, Receiver, From Redskins
description: DENVER, June 5 (AP)The Denver Broncos obtained Wal ter (The Flea) Roberts, a wide receiver, from the Washington Redskins today in exchange for a Denver conditional draft choice in 1973.

description: To the Editor:

title: Battle Over Power Need Focuses on the Southwest
description: LOS ANGELES, June 5 The Southwest, scene of many a historic military engagement, has become a new battle ground: The testing place of an idea that could affect the whole country and its life style.

title: IN THE PRIME TAKES OPEN JUMPER CROWN
description: READINGTON, N. J., June 5 Ian Crawford made his final appearance in a United States ring a successful one today when he rode Mr. and Mrs. Sam Spata's In the Prime to the open jumper championship at the Four Seasons Farm horse show.

title: Music
description: THE only accredited institution of its kind on the West Coast is the San Francisco Conservatory. It is relatively young (founded in 1917) and not very big (600 precollege students, 125 on the conservatory level). But in the past two years it has been expanding, rethinking its program and planning for the future. Some of the ideas that have come out of this process are provocative.

title: Art
description: THE rule wrote traveling abroad, wrote Haz litt, is to take our common sense with us, and leave our prejudices behind us. This is sound ad vice, whether abroad means foreign and unfamiliar coun tries or, as is largely the case in my own recent travels, only certain cities in our own country which I had not visited in several years. Yet klazlitt's rule is not easily applied. Common sense we may have in abundance, but our prejudices cannot really be left behind us, especially where esthetic issues are con cerned. The most we can hope for is to remain conscious of what these prejudices are, trusting that both common sense and a critical curiosity will act as a brake on some of the temptations that prej udice ineviably proffers.

title: The Vietnam Debate
description: Another serious setback for South Vietnamese forces and a fresh expression of Presidential determination to hang on in Indochina until the Saigon regime can defend itself lend weight to two carefully qualified moves in Congress this week designed to set a cutoff date for United States military action in Southeast Asia.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: Rudolf Bing didn't name the leading singers in the Peter Grimes cast whom [Georg Sold] did not wish to accept and whom I insisted on casting; but one can as sume they were not Jon Vickers and Geraint Evans but only Lucine Amara, whom I find I described in my review as a pallid and tremulousvoiced Ellen Or fordwhich is to say, not extremely successful, as Mr. Bing would have us be lieve. This would make Solti right in refusing to accept her, and Mr. Bing, as usual, as presumptuous as he was wrong in insisting on includ ing her. I say as usual be cause it was not the first in stance of its kind: Szell walked out after a couple of performances of the new Tannhauser in 1953 be cause of Mr. Bing's insistence on his right to make changes in the rehearsed cast without consulting Szell or giving him an opportunity to re hearse the new singer.

title: CONTROLS REDUCE BELLEVUE CRIME
description: Security problems that had turned Bellevue Hospital Cen ter into a stalking ground for drug addicts, thieves and bull ies have been considerably re duced over the last two months by a series of new controls, according to administrators and employes of the medical center.

description: OMAHA, June 5 (AP)Free port High School of Freeport, L. I., has placed first among some 6,000 schools competing in the National Mathematics Contest.

description: BALTIMORE, June 5 (UPI) The Federal bribery conspiracy trial of Representative John Dowdy, Democrat of Texas, has been postponed until October. United States District Judge Roszel C. Thomsen announced the postponement Thursday after meeting with attorneys for both sides.

description: A group of Queens residents has charged that a proposed highrise, highrent housing complex catering to young single transients who double and triple up cannot coexist with Parkway Village's long established family atmosphere.

title: Away Victor at Arlington
description: CHICAGO, June 5 (AP)Away, 5yearold mare owned and bred by Mrs. Elizabeth J. Brisbine of Wilmette, Ill., set all the pace today and won the $27,300 Twi light Tear Handicap by three lengths at Arlington Park.

title: ARMY TERMINAL IS IN DOUBT AGAIN
description: A political battle is again shaping up over renewed ef forts by the Defense Depart ment to move its administra tive offices from the Brooklyn Army Terminal to its facilities in Bayonne, N. J.

description: JERUSALEM, June 5Lug ging his double bass and electric guitar down the ramp of an airliner, Avra ham Band, a 22yearold jazz musician from Soviet Moldavia, immigrated to Israel a few days ago.

title: Mary Hobler Bride of Eric Hyson
description: PRINCETON, NJ., June 5 Miss Mary Bassett Hobler and Eric A. Hyson were married here this afternoon in the Niles Chapel of the First Presbyterian Church by the pastor, the Rev. Dr. Donald Meisel.

title: 5 Local Veterans Among 32 Winning King Fellowships
description: PRINCETON, N. J., June 5 The Woodrow Wilson National Fellowship Foundation named today 32 black veterans of the military, including five from the New York area, as recip ients of Martin Luther King Jr. Fellowships.

title: Indiana Retains Track Crown As 5 Meet Marks Are Broken
Should El Topo Be Elevated To El Tops?
description: NOW and then there comes along, usually from a foreign director, a new movie so quirky in its form and so offbeat in its vision that it beggars the abilities of native criticism to so much as describe it with ordinary cogency. One might recall in this connection La Dolce Vita or L'Avventura or Hiroshima Mon Amour, films which today look quite classical (in the case of La Dolce Vita, almost quaint) but whose first appearances were greeted with a mixed chorus of cultish praise and philistine rejection, the former often as lumpish and uncomprehending as the latter. Something of the same kind of storm lots of thunder, few flashes of illumi nationis already kicking up around El Topo (The Mole), a very strange masterpiece made in Mexico by Chilean Alexandro Jodorowsky which, virtually unadvertised, has been playing for some months at the Elgin Cinema to mostly worshipful, mostly young audiences every night at midnight (1 A.M. Fridays and Saturdays).

title: Drama Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: THOSE of us under 30 who saw Archibald Mac Leish's Scratch dur ing its brief run, who appreciated its address to our generation, to these times, were most disappointed to read Walter Kerr's gratuitous criticisms a week after the production had closed. It is never pleasant to see a dead horse flogged, much less thoroughbred already ham strung by Clive Barnes's hatchet job of the previous week.

title: Jordan Reports Guerrillas Shelled 3 Army Outposts
description: AMMAN, Jordan, June 5 (UPI)A Government spokes man said today that Palestinian guerrillas shelled three Jordan ian Army positions in the Jarash area of northern Jordan tonight.

title: KENT STATE FUND HURT BY APATHY
description: KENT, Ohio, June 3  The semester expires with students talking of studying for finals or having a party  and settling for sitting around in quiet clusters.

title: Portuguese Consulate Raid
description: LUXEMBOURG, June 5 (Reu ters)Eight men forced their way into the Portuguese. Con sulate here last night and made off with hundreds of passports and diplomatic documents. They tied up the Consul, Mendes Costa, and three servants. They said they were protesting the dictatorial regime in Portugal.

title: Zender Posts 63, Leads Sunnehanna Golf at 207
description: JOHNSTOWN, Pa., June (AP)Bob Zender, a Chicago stockbroker, shot a sevenun derpar 63 today and added a 73 for a 54hole score of 207 and the thirdround lead in the Sunnehanna golf tournament of amateur champions.

title: CANONERO IS 4TH
description: Pass Catcher, an unheralded colt who campaigns in the silks of Peter Kissel's October House Farm, surprised a record crowd of 81,036 at Belmont Park yes terday by winning the $162,850 Belmont Stakes.

title: Letters To The Editor
description: To THE EDITOR:

title: Photography
description: DURING the informal dis cussion which closed the symposium on pho tographic criticism held at George Eastman House last Februray, Peter Bunnell, Curator of the Museum of Modern Art's Department of Photography, suggested that among the areas of inquiry not covered by this gather ing was the role of the cura tor critic.

title: Mothers' milk or other milk?
description: MORE personal bias and fan tasy surround the subject of breastfeeding than any other medical topic, including diet ing. It is currently fashionable to breastfeed. For feminine ful fillment. For the good of the in fant. For God knows what juxta position of stars and omens.

title: Letters
description: To THE EDITOR: The vast majority of Amer ican tourists are too lazy to find out anything for them selves before they travel, so must rely on guides. The two pieces on tour guides  by John Brannon Albright, who wrote about tour information on tape, and Charles Morey, who described guides he had met (Travel section, May 16)  served to point up the tourist's nature.

title: After Vietnam Another Witchhunt?
description: THE conviction and sentencing of an American soldier for the commission of war crimes has brought to a head a national crisis and a national debate that, in the period ahead, may well reach historic proportions. What is at stake is the survival of the United States as the representative of such virtues as jus tify the claim it makes to the alle giance of its citizens and the respect of the world. It is never easy, in the midst of a developing crisis, to see its historical significance, but we must nevertheless make the attempt.

title: MORE RESOURCES FOR BLACKS URGED
description: CHICAGO, June 5Black economists predict that the black American economy will grow substantially during the next 10 years but will still lag considerably behind the general economy unless there are ma jor changes in strategies and commitments on the part of government and industry.

title: State Extends Order to Curb New Outbreak of Alleged Blockbusting by Brokers in the Freeport Area
description: FREEPORT, L. L. June 5 Acting on thousands of com plaints from residents of this South Shore village, New York Secretary of State John P. Lomenzo this week extended a cease and desist order to more than 200 licensed real es tate brokers in Nassau Coun ty to stop soliciting the sales of homes here in an attempt to curb a wave of alleged block busting.

title: Leigh Medine Dead at 44; Ran for Hempstead Post
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., June 5 Leigh M. Medine, the Demo cratic  Liberal candidate for North Hempstead town super visor in 1969, was found dead in his apartment Thursday night. He was 44 years old and lived at 15 Hill Park Avenue.

title: HI Q. WINS RACE ON WEST COAST
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 5 (UPI)Lightly regarded Hi Q. took advantage of her 16pound lighter impost today to score a head victory over heavily favored Manta in the 30th run ning of the $107,000 Vanity Handicap for fillies and mares at Hollywood Park.

title: Patricia Hall Townsend Is Bride
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., June 5 Miss Patricia Hall Town send, daughter of Dallas S. Townsend Jr., a correspond ent and broadcaster for the Columbia Broadcasting Sys tem, and Mrs. Townsend, was married here this afternoon to John Allen Burkholder, son of Hospitalman Chief John Herbert Burkholder, U. S. N., and Mrs Burkholder of War minster, Pa.

title: CYPRUS IS ASKING: WILL B00111 LAST?
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, June 1 A boom in citrus exports is bringing profits to this Mediter ranean islandand the prospect of a slump In sales should European trading patterns change.

title: Mrs. Hacin Engaged To Samuel Kaminsky
description: BRONXVILLE, N. Y., June 5Mrs. Phyllis Levitt Hacin, who is on the public relations staff of the national. United Jewish Appeal in New York, plans to be married June 24 to I. Samuel Kaminsky, a partner in the Johnstown, Pa., law firm of Kaminsky, Kelly & Wharton.

title: Poles in U.S. Apparently More Interested in Poland
description: WARSAW, June 4  The long dormant ties between Poland and Americans of Polish origin appear to be stirring under the influence of new factors here and in the United States.

title: A Maverick Again?
description: CHICAGO  The Inland. Steel Company served notice the other day thatno mat ter how large a wage in crease the industry gives in its coming labor negotiations the Chicagobased concern probably would oppose fur ther increases In steel prices this year.

title: Art
description: ONE of the most enjoy able exhibitions I have seen in months has turned up with no preliminary fanfare  and for that matter, no cur rent fanfare  at the Met ropolitan Museum, an insti tution that seldom misses a chance to flourish its trum pets. Called Ancient Egyp tian Writing, if you can imagine such a thing, the show is most instructive, al though to use that word so early in a report is to risk turning the reader off. What could sound more dessicated than an instructive show on ancient Egyptian writing? But this one is as fresh as a daisay.

title: ASTROS WIN, 41, ON DIERKER'S 10TH
description: PITTSBURGH, Juno 5 (AP) Larry Dierker of the Houston Astros posted his fifth con secutive victory and 10th in 11 decisions by defeating the Pitts burgh Pirates, 41, tonight with ninthinning help from Fred Cladding.

title: Julie Anne Goodman, Teacher, Married to Kenneth J. Koerner
description: LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 5The Larchmont Avenue Presbyterian Church was the setting at noon today for the marriage of Miss Julie Anne Goodman, daughter of Julian Goodman, president of the National Broadcasting Com pany, and Mrs. Goodman, to Kenneth Joseph Koerner, son of Mrs. Henry J. Koerner of St. Louis and the late Mr. Koerner.

title: The Birds Of London
Tsarapkin Flies to London
description: LONDON, June 5  Deputy Foreign Minister Semyon K. Tsarapkin flew into London to day, apparently to press the Soviet Union's views on a European security conference and mutual force reductions in Europe.

title: SHORE PROTECTION. DEBATED IN REST
description: SAN DIEGO, May 29Con servationists campaigning for creation of a new state author ity to protect California's 1,073 miles of coastline found themselves this week on a col lision course with the power ful League of California Cities.

title: Ontario Gets Title Golf
description: MONTREAL, June 5 (Canadian Press)The Royal Canadian. Golf Association has selected the Cherry Hill Golf Club at Ridgeway, Ontario, as the site of the 1972 Canadian open golf championship. Dates of the $150,000 tournament will be announced later.

title: MAX COHEN DEAD; A THEATER OWNER
description: Max A. Cohen, longtime owner of theaters in Florida, New York and Connecticut, died Friday of an apparent heart attack. He was 75 years old.

title: News of the Rialto
description: SINCE you can get Philip Roth to the theater but you can't make him write for it (so far, anyway), his good friend Larry Arrick is doing it for him. Last summer Arrick showed East Hampton, L. I., and Roth, too, what he'd done with three of Roth's stories. Under his direction, the Yale Repertory Theater acted Arrick's Story Theatertype version of Conversion of the Jews, Defender of the Faith and Epstein, and hardly had the curtain come down when some 15 producers were on their knees waving pens and pleading. The one who finally succeeded in moving Arrick's pen to a contract was Robert Louis Livingston who exuber antly announces that he'll bring the production to Broadway in the fall, to either the Booth, Royale or Plymouth,. You need to know, also, that the lineup will be somewhat altered. Instead of Conversion of the Jews, Arrick has substituted Roth's Eli, the Fanatic, a story that several times in years gone by has been sought for production. Only then the thinking was to it in terms of conventional dramaturgy.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: Speak Roughly To Your Little Boy
description: This is a nice little collection of verse parodies. I wonder if it will work for children. Let me quote the best parody in the book  Hugh Kingsmill doing A. E. Housman and we'll see.

title: Rondon Stops del Papa in First Round and Retains LightHeavyweight Title
description: CARACAS, June 5 (UPI) Vicente Paul Rondon retained his lightheavyweight title to night, knocking out Piero del Papa of Italy at 2 minutes 30 seconds of the first round of their 15round bout for the World Boxing Association ver sion of the championship.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: NO JOY IN VENEZUELA AS CANONERO FAILS
description: CARACAS, June 5 (UPI) Sadness overcame most of Venezuela's high officials and the people in general who had trusted Canonero II to win the Belmont Stakes today.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, June 5The univer sity students graduating this month have gone through one of the worst periods, of civil disorder and drug addiction in the history of the Republic and are now facing the highest rate of unemployment in nine years.

title: Bouttier, Pride of France, Primed for Shot at Title
description: PARIS, June 5Out in the woods, Michel Jazy, the former world recordholder in the mile, was leading the boys on a merry chase.

description: To the Editor:

title: Gibson to Receive Degree
description: JERSEY CITY, June 5  Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark and Charles Wuorinen, the composer, will receive hon orary degrees tomorrow at the commencement of Jersey City State College here. Dr. James H. Mullen, the college presi dent, will present Mr. Gibson with an honorary degree in let ters and Mr. Wuorinen, the Pul itzer Prize winner in 1970 for music, will receive an honorary degree in music.

title: Expos Beat Padres, 21
description: SAN DIEGO, June 5 (AP) Bob Bailey's tiebreaking single in the tworun sixth inning gave the Montreal Expos a 21 triumph over the San Diego Padres today.

title: DiNardo Signed by Saints
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 5 (AP) Larry DiNardo, an offensive guard from Notre Dame, has signed with the New Orleans Saints, the National Football League club announced today. The Saints also announced the acquisition by waivers of Jim Cox, a tight end, from the Mi ??mi Dolphins.

title: MANU GUERRA IS BACK IN BOHEME AT MET
description: Matteo Manuguerra, a bari tone who made his Metropolitan Opera debut in January, made his first appearance as Mar cello in the company's produc tion of Puccini's La Bohme in the performance given on Friday night. He was in a cast that included Richard Tucker, Colette Bbky and Gabriella Tucci. Miss Tucci replaced the indisposed Teresa Stratas in the part of Mimi. Fausto Cleva conducted.

title: Home Improvement
description: TO the doityourselfer, shopping for lumber for a weekend carpentry project is often a con fusing experience because sizes are never as stated (a 2x4 does not measure 2 inches by 4 inches, and a 1 inch thick board is never ac tually one inch in thickness) and because the terms used to grade or indicate quality are unclear. As a result, he has difficulty specifying or ordering the kind of boards or structural lumber he wants and needs.

title: Mitchell Opposes Integration by Force
description: WASHINGTON, June 5 (AP) Attorney General John N. Mitchell says forced economic integration or America's sub urban areas would be flying in the face of the Supreme Court.

title: Abortion Law Repeal Is Killed by Brydges
description: ALBANY, Sunday, June 6 A bill to repeal the state's liberalized abortion law was killed by its sponsor in the Senate early today, ending the possibility of repeal at the 1971 session.

title: A Potpourri Of Scents n Spices In a Jar
description: BEFORE the perfume industry de veloped in the 1800's, scents were grown in the garden. There was lavender to make clothes fragrant and to deter moths, sweet smelling gera nium leaves and herbs for lotions and ointments, and roses to combine with spices and citrus for the potpourri jars still used today.

title: T.V.A. ASKS GRANT TO REPAIR HILLS
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn. June 5 The Tennessee Valley Au thority is appealing to private nonprofit foundations for a $415,000 grant to help rectify the environmental problems caused by uncontrolled strip mining of Appalachian coal for T.V.A. boilers.

title: A Selection Of Recent Titles
description: The following list has been select ed from titles reviewed since the Christmas Issue of Dec. 6, 1970. Such a list can only suggest the high points in the main fields of reader interest. Books are arranged alpha betically under subject headings. Quoted comments are from earlier issues of the Book Review.

title: Television
description: WHILE dance has been exploding all over the American land scape in the past decade or so, it has rarely even flickered significantly on the American television ?? Banet and modern dance performances on some New York weekends can at tract audiences adding up to tens of thousands. Young au diences, perhaps increasing ly wary of the spoken word, enthusiastically accept invita tions to the dance both on and off campus. In various government programs to show off U. S. culture abroad, dance is the leading com modity.

title: Education
description: The campus has been vir tually free of conflict throughout the entire year. By mutual consent academic activity has been restored to a style and a tempo befitting one of the great intellectual centers of the world.... We have been through a harsh period of reassessment to gether and for the moment at least we are managing quite well.

title: Ann Marie Stuecheli Is Bride Of Roeland Brenninkmeyer
description: BLOOMFIELD HILLS, Mich., June 5  Miss Ann Marie Stuecheli, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Milton Bernard Stuechell of Birmingham, was married here this after noon to Roeland Max Bren ninkmeyer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Brenninkmeyer of Bloemendaal, the Nether lands.

title: We Have Met the Enemy and Found Them Human  Tourisme Engag
description: LAST Decemberwhile relations be tween the Soviet Union and the United States were strained due to allegations of antiSemitism In Russia (leading to bombings and other incidents in the U. S. and to the cancellation of the Bolshoi Theater's scheduled U. S. tour)a group of 33 American citizen diplomats was busi ly roving and probing the Soviet Union. Much of their time was spent in track ing down and talking to their Russian counterparts. They also visited Russian homes, schools and offices. On various occasions they exchanged views with both common citizens and highranking Soviet officials on a wide range of issues  including the question of the Soviet government's policy regarding the emigration of Jews to Israel.

title: $76Million Penalties Paid By U.S. for Canceling SST
description: WASHINGTON, June 5 (UPI) The Federal Government paid the Boeing Company and Gen eral Electric penalties totaling $76.7million yesterday for hav ing to break its contracts with them for development of the supersonic transport plane.

title: For the Class of '71, the Party's Over
description: CHICAGO. THE champagne was gone and so were the petits fours and tea sandwiches. The girls of the Sophonisba Preston Breckenridge residence hall at the University of Chicago were honoring the genteel lady after whom their dormitory was named in the nineteenthirties. As the party was winding down, one coed at an offlobby telephone was urging her date, who hadn't shown up, to come over anyway, even if the food was gone.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In blaming rent control for the deterioration of New York City's housing stock, Commissioner Charles J. Ur stadt is wrong [Point of View, May 23].

title: Municipalities in State Trimming Budgets
description: Hundreds of municipal work ers are being laid off, play grounds closed and services curtailed as cities large and small across New York State generally report budget crises in part attributed to state cutbacks.

title: Lynn Hillyard, Photographer, Wed in Aspen
description: ASPEN, Colo., June 5 Miss Barbara Lynn Hillyard was married here this after noon to Thomas Baird Cam pion Jr. Canon Harry Watts, assisted by the Rev. William R. Shannon, performed the Episcopal ceremony in the Chapel of the Prince of Peace.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: WHO Is Harry Kellerman and why is he anying those terrible things about rne?Advt.

title: Assemblymen Locked In To Keep Them Working
description: ALBANY, June 5Repub lican leaders of the Assembly were so determined tonight to keep the 150 Assembly men at their desks working that they ordered all doors to the chamber locked so that members could not leave although newsmen, lobbyists and pages were permitted to come and go on the Assem bly floor.

title: Guru of the Organic Food Cult
description: EMMAUS. Pa.

title: HORSE SHOWS WEIGH DRUG TEST INCREASE
description: DEVON. Pa., June 5Rich ard E. McDevitt of Malvern, Pa., chairman of the American Horse Shows Association's committee on drugs and medi cation, proposed to the asso ciation's board of directors to day that the list of shows to be tested for violations this vear be expanded from 100 to 150.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: James Egan, who wrote the article about American stu dents in San Miguel de Allen de, Mexico (Travel section, May 2), seems to be unaware that the Instituto Allende and the Academia Hispano Amer icana appear to be two of the many collegecredit mills that have sprouted in Mexico. In regard to the master's de grees being passed around so freely by these enterprises, as well as by others in Latin America, those looking for academic positions with such pieces of paper might find that their hopes will not match reality. The fact is that these Mexican credit mills do not enjoy any recognition on the part of the Mexican Gov ernment and their degrees do not legally qualify anyone to practice a profession in Mexico; nor are college credits granted by them recognized by Mexican institutions of higher education.

title: CONNECTICUT PLAN FOR BETS IN PERIL
description: HARTFORD, June 5Legis lation that would permit a lot tery, parimutuel betting and offtrack betting in Connecticut appeared to he imperiled today as it was scheduled for debate in the House of Representatives.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To THE EDITOR: In a paper which prides itself on showing its readers both sides of the coin, not mainly one point of view, I feel that you have given the Hate Russia Campaigners too much space by printing both Friede F. Rothe's and Stanley Lipson's comments.

title: When this city is in trouble civilization is in trouble
description: Prague is every man's pos session, in the same sense as the music of Mozart, the Sis tine ceiling, the sonnets of Shakespeare. Its unique beauty has universality; its tortured, tragic history is inseparable from the unresolved fate of Western man. When Prague is in the headlines, every votary of humanism and beauty feels invoked and involved. When Prague is silenced, civilization knows itself to be in trouble. The urgent hold of Prague on the Western world is a mys terybut Prague itself is per vasive and mysterious. Some of us have known the city for lifetimes. We have lived in it, loved it, suffered with or be cause of it, as love decrees one must suffer at times. Prague is a part of ourselves that we can never root out. The reasons for this are large ly intangible. They are com prised in the subtitle of an absorbing and gracefully learned book by Joseph Wechs berg called Prague, The Mys tical City.

title: McElroy Has Spikes, Will Travel
description: Brian McElroy would like to travel this summer. The cheapest, most exciting way, he reasoned, was to win a berth on one of America's touring track and field teams.

title: Art
description: AN artist's entrance upon the art scene  the point of entry his art makes into the con temporary art world with its reigning formal values and fads, its publicists and crit icshas a good deal of bear ing upon his critical recep tion and his subsequent ca reer. Rightly or wrongly, it tends to categorize him on the basis of his thencurrent style. His entrance locates his work, with its particular set of formal interests and ambitions, within the rele vant formal conventions of the moment or labels the work as retrograde, to the artist's detriment. Occasion ally, his move onto the art scene at a particular moment provides him with a set of colleaguesinarms, identify ing him with some radical new school or group that is in the of formation.

title: The World
description: JERUSALEMThere was no reason why 73yearold Golda Meir should not have taken a little weekend off during her whirlwind tour of Scandinavia but the place she chose, Ro vaniemi, capital of Arctic Lap land, seemed unlikely, to say the least.

title: The World
description: ANKARAThe Turkish na tional character is supposed to be made up of, stoicism, obedi ence, acceptance and not too vivid an imagination. There is also fervent nationalism. And this is the only trait not con tradicted by the violent events of recent weeks, from the kidnap ping and murder of a foreign diplomat to a shootout last Tues day to free a child hostage held by the killers, members of the Turkish People's Liberation Army.

title: Haber Gets a 25% Share of Austerity
description: Beneath the bare pipes in what used to be the ladies room in the City Hall base ment, Councilman Kenneth Ha ber of Brooklyn sat at his desk chatting about what it was like to be a member of the local Legislature's Liberal mitiority.

title: MAN IN BUSINESS
description: Edward W. Carter, the lean, scholarly merchant who bought Bergdorf Goodman last March and who build BroadwayHale Stores in the last quartercentury into the West's largest retail com pany, was fortunate in hav ing had several career al ternatives. And he was fortu nate, too, in having been able tochoose from among three fields in which he had had either prior professional or undergraduate experience.

title: MICHIGAN U. BARS RAISE FOR WOMAN
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 5 The first woman in the nation to try to force a university to take action on the principle of equal pay with men for equal work has lost her case at the University of Michigan.

title: Elizabeth Stone Spear Is Married
description: BEVERLY, Mass., June 5 In the Dane Street Congrega tional Church here, Miss Elizabeth Stone Spear and Edward Scott Van Winkle were married this afternoon by the Rev. James C. Glasser.

title: Through Rain and Sleet
description: Joseph Streicher and Louis Herman, two stillactive mem bers of the American Stock Exchange, remember when they did their brokerage busi ness outdoors in the middle of Broad Street.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: A sequel to Memoirs of a Bourgeois Hell's Angel: What do you do when you only have two days in Ber muda and you have to make tracks? Answer: Whiz along at breakneck speed on a motorassisted bike, and downhill you do 40 m.p.h. That is, before you are in formed by your landlady that you could get a ticket for speeding. Who at home would believe it if you said you got your first speeding ticket in a country where the speed limit is 20 m.p.h. (15 m.p.h. in Hamilton)?

title: Miss Diana Noyes Dwyer Wed To Michael Christopher Brooks
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., June 5Miss Diana Noyes Dwyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Dwyer Jr. of Laurel Hollow and Hobe Sound, Fla., was mar ried here today to Michael Christopher Brooks, son of Mrs. Charles Welles Brooks of Wilton, Conn., and the late Mr. Brooks.

title: ADULT EDUCATION OFFERS A NEW LIFE
description: A textile mamfacturer de termined to become a psycho analyst, a retailer who has decided to study law and a mother of five who simply wants to know more are among 1,200 students with lit tie formal education who are now working for diplomas in the Adult Collegiate Education program at Queens College.

title: TOURISM HOBBLED BY BERLIN POLITICS
description: BERLIN, June 5EastWest politics this week prevented more than 5,000 West Berliners from spending their holidays at Varna, on Bulgaria's Black Sea coast.

title: Gelding Returns $18.20
description: STANTON, Del., June 5 (AP) Joseph Richards Jr.'s 6year old gelding. Sir Beau, two years older than his seven rivals, won a fivehorse photo finish today in the featured sixfurlong race at Delaware Park.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: If your readers are inter ested in more adventure of the type recounted in Court ing Danger on the Colorado River and The Old Man of the Rapids (Travel section, May 9), I suggest they view the movie, Run the Wild River, scheduled at the Kips Bay Theater In Manhattan. [It was due to begin an engagement of at least two weeks on June 2.] This pic ture, made on the Colorado and on the Grijalva River in Mexico, was filmed by Jack Currey of Western River Ex peditions, and it is one of the most exciting movies I have ever seen. If readers are con sidering where to vacation, Run the Wild River could offer inspiration.

title: ACCUSED GENERAL GETS A PROMOTION
description: WASHINGTON, June 5The Army has promoted a brigadier general to major general while investigating alleged atrocities that occurred under his com mand in Vietnam In 1969.

title: Pike of Suffolk County Expects to Survive Redistricting by State Legislature
description: WASHINGTON, June 5 Whenever Democratic Repre sentatives from New York congregate here these days the conversation turns to the latest rumors about what the Republicancontrolled Legis lature in Albany may be up to in the drawing of the state's new Congressional districts.

title: Jim Turnesa ProAm Has Family Overtones
description: Jim Turnesa, a member of golf's noted family, will be honored at the Briar Hall Golf and Country Club, Bri arcliff Manor, N.Y., with a proamateur tournament on Friday.

title: Sicilian Mafia Suspects Grieve As They Idle Away Island Exile
description: FILICUDI ISLAND, Italy, June 4Calogera Sinatra swung his steely gaze across the Tyr rhenian Sea, westward beyond the peaks of his native Sicily.

title: The Handsome Oriole
description: On all counts, the Baltimore oriole is an exemplary neighbor to have in or near your dooryard. Few songsters have a better voice and only the mimics have a greater variety of songs. The oriole can put a dozen stock phrases together in a hundred different ways; but indi vidual orioles have certain melodies they sing over and over, so one can learn to identify individuals by listening. And the oriole sings from early May when he arrives in the North well into July; and again from midAugust till he starts south again in September.

title: Fisitach, Morgan Advance At Start of State Tennis
description: Mike Fishbach of Great Neck, L. I., and Vern Morgan of New York were firstround winners as the New York State men's tennis championships began yesterday with a record field of 160 at the North Side Tennis and Racquets Club in Bayside, Queens.

title: Sports of The Times
Rock Festival Enjoined
description: PURVIS, Miss., June 5 (AP) Lamar County officials have obtained a Chancery Count in junction to halt a rock festival expected to be held near Purvis starting June 21. The event is expected to draw 60,000 per sons and last eight days. Offi cials cited sanitation and crowd control problems in objecting to the festival.

title: Chess
description: WHILE the eight Candidates are struggling fiercely in matches to determine who will be his next challenger, world cham pion Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union waits calmly in the wings. His entrance into the great drama won't come until the spring of 1972, far enough so that his preparations need not yet have swung into high gear.

title: Music
description: How a composer views the world around him inevitably affects the sort of music he writes. Accordingly, it is not surprising that Hans Werner Henze's attachment to Marx ism in the late sixties should have brought about a change of course in his evolution as a composer. His music has grown more hardedged and less disposed to lose itself in beautiful sounds; and, though he once seemed its last sub stantial prop, he has forsworn traditional opera.

title: Why Does Derby Die And White Death Live?
description: ANYONE still laboring under the impression that critics can make or break movies might investigate the highly dis similar fates of two recent documen taries, Robert Kaylor's Derby and the Peter GimbelJames Lipscomb Blue Water. White Death, both of which opened to rave reviews and one of which died after only five weeks. Be cause movies do not often vanish, or dissolve, or get cut up and sold for scrap after a poor first run, Derby will, I assume, be again available in subsequent run theaters in the not too distant future.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: WELFARE PROJECT BACKED BY NEGRO
description: WASHINGTON, June 5Dr. Andrew F. Brimmer, the high est ranking Negro official in the Federal Government, has endorsed President Nixon's wel fare reform program as a major potential assist to the poor generally and Negroes in par ticular.

title: Judith Pearlman Wed
description: Miss Judith Laura Pearl man daughter of Mrs. Cecile Pearlman of Forest Hills, Queens, and Howard Pearl man of the Bronx, was married here yesterday at noon to Fred Edward Tracy, son of Dr. Edward Tracy, professor of history at Kutz town (Pa.) State University and the late Mrs. Patti At wood Tracy. The Rev. Dr. Walter Donald Kring per formed the ceremony in the chapel of the Unitarian Church of All Souls.

title: Recordings
description: THE opera that Krzysz tof Penderecki created out of Aldous Huxley's The Devils of Lou dun and its dramatization by John Whiting has had mixed receptions where it has been performed. Part of the adverse criticism dealt with the composer's style, which was felt to be too thin and repetitious, making no ad vances over his previous ma jor success, the St. Luke Pas sion The opera poses staging problems, with scenes flowing rapidly into each other as in a film, and the staging appar ently was not always ade quate. The charge was made that, despite scenes of theatri cal violence and power, there was not enough dramatic focus in the libretto.

title: Mounties Quit to Graduate
description: Archbishop Molloy of Queens won the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association baseball championship yes terday on a disqualification.

title: Braves Win in 11th, 64
description: ATLANTA, June 5 (UPI)  Mike Lum reached Ken Holtz man, making his first relief ap pearance of the season, for threerun homer with two out in the 11th inning tonight to give the Atlanta Braves a 64 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

title: Thomas Rankin Weds Mary Cogan
description: CLEVELAND HEIGHTS, Ohio, June 5Miss Mary Patricia Cogan and Thomas Taplin Rankin were married here this afternoon. The Rev. W. Chave McCracken per formed the ceremony in St. Paul's Episcopal Church. He was assisted by the Rev. F. Washington Jarvis.

Andrew J. W. Mullins performed the ceremony in the chapel of St. Bartholo mew's Episcopal Church, where he was'assisted by the Rev. Stephen M. Price.

title: Candy Stocks
description: Price trends for certain commodities carry their im pact over into the stock mar ket. Thus, the price of corn or hogs or silver can affect the profit margins of com panies that depend on these commodities for the products they turn out.

title: In 18 Months, MercuryPoisoned Girl Is Almost Well
description: ALAMOGORDO, N. M., May 27Eighteen months ago, when she was hospitalized along with other members of her fam ily in the worst series of mer cury poisoning ever recorded in the United States, Dorothy Jean Huckleby was considered a hopeless case.

description: SOUTH ORANGE, N.J. June 5  Dr. Bernard Lefrak, an orthodontist, died yesterday in St. Barnabas Medical Center, Livingston. He was 62 years old and lived at 194 Great Hills Drive.

description: WASHINGTON, June 5The area northwest of the White House a decade ago was com posed primarily of row houses, older brick and brownstone apartments, a handful of stolid office buildings and small businesses. Now it is an almost unbroken facade of multistor ied steel and glass.

title: Private Garbage Hauling Is Being Studied by City;
description: Private garbage collection, advocated for New York City by Deputy Mayor Timethy W. Costello, is a longestablished and apparently successful prac tice in such major cities as Boston, San Francisco and Chi cago.

title: WAR ANNIVERSARY FINDS EGYPT CALM
description: CAIRO, June 5Four years ago this morning, antiaircraft guns broke the silence in the desert around Cairo and air raid sirens wailed through out the city. War with Israel had begun.

title: RICHARD J. ANDERSON
description: Richard J. Anderson, editor and publisher of Financial World Magazine, died yester day at his New York home. He was 70 years old and lived at 20 Fifth Avenue and 592 Hol low Tree Ridge Road, Darien, Conn.

title: 4 SEIZED IN BRONX IN HOLDUP, LINKED TO POLICE DEATHS
description: Four men who were arrested early yesterday in an attempted holdup of a black social club in the Bronx are being investi gated in the murder of two city policemen and the wound ing of two others last month, an assistant district attorney said last night.

title: NASSAU PLANNING TO SPEED TRIALS
description: MINEOLA, L. I., June 5 Nassau County intends to use the total resources of county departments and its court sys tem to assure more prompt trials and disposition of crimi nal cases.

title: Woman Asks Backing for World Sail
description: WILLISTON PARK, L. I., June 5  A woman with a dream of becoming the first skipper of her sex to circum navigate the globe under, sail appeared before a meet ing of the Long Island Multi hull Association the other day, and before the session had ended, the dream had taken a step toward reality.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: Town & Country, The Sat urday Evening Post of the very rich, will celebrate its 125th anniversary with its September issue.

title: A FAIR IS COOKING IN HELL'S KITCHEN
description: Hell's Kitchen became the site of a fairground yesterday as part of an effort to rejuve nate the seedy West Side sec tion of tenements and brown stones.

title: TOLL IN WEST BENGAL SAID TO REACH 8,000
description: CALCUTTA, India, June 5 (Reuters)The death toll in cholera epidemic sweeping through four million Pakistani refugees in India's West Bengal State has reached 8,000, diplo matic sources said here today.

title: TIGERS TURN BACK WRITE SOX, 7 TO 3
description: CHICAGO, June 5 (AP)The Detroit Tigers took advantage of three successive Chicago errors to score four unearned runs in the third inning today and beat the White Sox, 73.

title: Hemingway's Michigan: Where Nature Became the Metaphor
description: PETOSKEY, Mich.Gertrude Stein told the young writer his story was inaccroachable. His sister Marcelline simply called it a vul gar, sordid tale and said reading it made her stomach turn over. She was also worried sick that their Michigan friends would read It and be humiliated be yond words.

title: The Nation
description: Labor, management and the Nixon Administration have just gone through another round of the wagepricejawbone cycle this time in the aluminum in dustry. This was the sequence of events:

title: Few City Layoffs Pledged Under Albany Tax Accord
description: ALBANY, June 5Democrat is legislative leaders assured their party's legislators today that there would be minimal layoffs of city workers under the $500million tax package tentatively agreed on by Gover nor Rockefeller and Democratic and Republican legislative lead ers.

title: Marci R. Sherwin Wed to Richard Litt
description: HARRISON, N. Y., June 5 Miss Marci Randi Sherwin and Richard Clayton Litt were married tonight at the Jewish Community Center of Harrison by Rabbi Norton Shargel.

title: Blast Injures 3 in Belfast
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 5 (Reuters)An explosion destroyed an electricity sub station near the center of Bel fast tonight, injuring three persons in a passing car.

title: Pass Catcher's jockey: Right Where I Wanted
description: A bay colt, his neck lath ered with sweat from run ning the biggest mile and a half in American racing, was being led down geranium lined victory lane yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: Soviet Increasing Benefits for the Aged
description: MOSCOW, June 5  The So viet Union, which takes pride on being a welfare state, began today to implement a broad program of improved social benefits promised by Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Communist party leader, at the recent 24th party congress.

title: Kentuckians to Receive Unified Child Services
description: FRANKFORT, Ky., June 5 (AP)Plans for a $4.68mil lion pilot program on unified child development services in 16 southeast Kentucky counties have been an nounced by Gov. Louie B. Nunn.

title: Black and Female: Asset
description: Two minuses add up to plus these days. Or, in the eyes of big business, being black and female is twice as beautiful.

title: FOREIGNERS SEEK EDUCATION ON L.I.
description: FARMINGDALE, LI., June 5 I feel my country needs me, said Consuelo Reyes, a student from Colombia, the other day. I must put my skills to use in the development of my own country.

title: Television
description: HIS life, I always thought, was an open microphone. Back when I was in the ninth grade, in the middle fifties, there he was on WOR every Sunday night from 9 until 1 in the morning, just . . . talking. Talk ing about his mother's rumpsprung bath robe and a baseball game in Chicago, about something he'd just read in the paper and that time in the Signal Corps during the war, about striking out on a date and . . . about absolutely any thing. I'm a kid, see . . . he would begin, launching into another explora tion, and we were all hooked. It was important not to arrive in school Mon day morning looking as if you'd had enough sleep; staying up to the end of the Jean Shepherd show was a very macho thing in the ninth grade.

title: Ens. J. H. Higgins to Wed Miss Vance
description: Cyrus R. Vance, former Deputy Secretary of Defense and Presidential trouble shooter, and Mrs. Vance of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Camilla Vance, to Ens. James H. Higgins 3d, U. S. N. R. He is the son of Mr. Higgins 2d, executive vice president of the Mellon National Bank and Trust Company, and Mrs. Higgins of Sewickely, Pa.

title: FIGHT IS EXPECTED IN MISSOURI SYNOD
description: Well  financed conservative groups within the Lutheran Church  Missouri Synod, the nation's second largest Luther an body, are engaged in a de termined campaign to roll back the liberalizing trends of a decade.

title: Teamsters Aide Confirms Possible Salary for Hoffa
description: DETROIT, June 5 (AP)  A teamsters union spokesman confirmed today that James R. Hoffa would receive a pension as retiring teamsters' president and also would be considered for possible designation as presidentemeritus with an an nual salary.

title: Bridge The von Zedtwitz touch
description: DRIDGE does not distinguish be tween amateurs and profes sionals. Tournaments are open to all regardless of the way they earn their living. Inevitably, however, the names bestknown to the general public are those of the professionals, particularly those who write books with wide circulation. Millions who know nothing else about bridge are familiar with the names of Ely Cul bertson and Charles Goren.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: Robbin's Rest is not a sin gles' community and the Ocean Beach ferries do not link up with the train sched ules (the latter being a situa tion which has annoyed and puzzled me for the past six years while renting in Rob bin's Rest)as was said in the article on summering on Fire Island (Travel section, May 23). As a working wife who commutes between New York and Fire Island on weekends on the Long Island Railroad, enduring the de lays, the heat, the crowds, etc., I think Patricia Stod dard should not make her husband's one hour trip sound like such a breeze. Year after year the railroad has failed to add on cars to allow for the hundreds of ex tra passengers commuting to Fire Island and the Hemp tons. In addition, the author did not point out that her husband would have to wake up around 5:30 A.M. in order to make the ferry to catch the train to arrive in Man hattan close to 9 A.M. on those Mondays when he stayed over Sunday night. I hope this doesn't sound like sour grapes, but I do think those women who get away from it all for the summer sometimes lose touch with reality.

title: Biologist on Fire I. Studies Habits of Birds
description: FIRE ISLAND, L. L, June 5That single flock of five or six blue jays that seems to hover faithfully the year round in some Long Island hack yards may actually be composed of hundreds of jays, one small group at a time stopping for a few days and then flying on.

title: NASSAU TO EXPAND DAYCARE SERVICE
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., June 5 Nassau County will expand Its family daycare program in an effort to provide services for thousands of needy children and to remove mothers from the relief rolls.

title: $6Million Yeshiva High School to Rise in Queens
description: Construction of a new, $5 million complex to house the Yeshiva High School of Queens is scheduled to begin late this month in Forest Hills.

title: If Spirits Move You, Go Ghouling by Black Guidebook In Ghostly France
description: SETTING out on one of my favorite walks in Paristo the cemetery of Pre Lachaiseone day last winter, I noticed in a bookstore window a thick black volume entitled Guide de Paris Mystrieux. It seemed to suit my mood and my destination, so I went in and bought it, in spite of its hefty price of $13.50. I cannot say it has changed my life, but since that day, Parisand all the rest of France as wellcan never be the same for me.

title: Squires Sign U.S.C. Guard
description: NORFOLK, Va., June 5 (AP) The Virginia Squires of the American Basketball Associa tion announced today the sign ing of Dana Pagett of Southern California, the team's fourth round draft choice. Pagett is 6foot2inch guard.

title: Almirante Is No M.s...i.. Yet
description: ROME.

title: WIMBLEDON ACCEPTS ONLY 6 BRITISH MEN
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 5 (AP)  Only six British men were accepted today for the Wimbledon tennis champion ships, the smallest number since World War II.

title: News of the Camera World
description: AMONG the many courses, workshops and semi nars that are being offered to photog raphers this spring and sum mer are the following:

title: Yankees in Fifth Year of Commonality
description: As the New York Yankee fan suffers through the Year Five of his Commonality, a backward glance and a few reflections on how things got this way may be ap propriate.

title: NAVY SINKS ARMY IN THREE EVENTS
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., June 5 Army came into today's sports activity against Navy holding a 76 lead in its annual series with the midshipmen, but Navy won three of four events and took a 98 edge.

title: Doctorate in Law To Be Given Today To Indian Woman
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., June 5Yvonne Knight of Ponca City, Okla., will be among the 56 students to receive jurist doctor degrees at the University of New Mexico law school con vocation tomorrow and Prof. Frederick Hart, director of the Indian program, believes that she will be the first American Indian woman to receive the J.D. degree.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In the News of the Realty Trade article about the close of the Shelton Hotel [May 16] the name of the architect for the project was incorrect. The hotel was designed by Arthur Loomis Harmon, who sub sequently became one of the partners of the firm of Shreve, Lamb & Harmon.

title: CUTE SKETCH TAKES MIAMI STAKES RACE
description: MIAMI, June 5 (AP)Fred W. Hooper's Cute Sketch, the favorite with the crowd of 8,688, got through along the inside on the stretch turn today to beat Flight After Dark to the wire in the $7,500 added Cradle Stakes at Calder Race Course.

title: Music Mailbag
description: TO THE EDITOR: IAM one of the Old Guard whose letters to the Phil harmonic have bothered Harold Schonberg. I doubt that we can be typed as Philistines as readily as he believes. Does he remember that wonderful evening when a few people walked out on Berio's Sinfonia, but most of us stayed to cheer? Most of us. I believe, are eager to hear a provocative mixture of the tried and the new, even if we suspect that most of the new will be found wanting.

title: DICHTER PERFORMS FOR PROMENADES
description: Maralin Niska, who was to have been soprano soloist in the New York Philharmonic's Promenade Romantique on Friday evening, became ill that afternoon. The orchestra had to settle for a pianist as a re placement, rather than another soprano, but It was fortunate to get the services of Misha Dichter, Still a youthful 25 years of age, he has been well known locally since he won second prize in the 1966 Tchai kovsky Competition in Moscow.

title: QUEENS DISTRICT FEARS REZONING
description: The nuts and bolts of the problem of the Jamaica Ave nue El in Queens, the head of the WoodhavenRichmond Hills Community Board says, are in deed the line'sand area's problem.

title: Lundquist Gains in Tennis
description: STOCKHOLM, Rine 5 (AP) JanErik Lundquist of Sweden defeated Georges Goven of France, 64, 63, in the semi finals of the Stockholm inter national tennis tournament to day. Martin Mulligan of Italy won the other semifinal by beating Manuel Santana of Spain, 6.4, 61.

title: The Nation
description: LONDONIn the House of Lords last month, Baroness Bacon put a question to a Gov ernment Minister, Lord Windle sham: Would the noble Lord not agree that there is much more likelihood of trafficking in drugs if genuine heroin addicts cannot receive drugs from prop er treatment centers?

title: DRAMA CONGRESS MEETS IN LONDON
description: LONDON, June 5  Two hun dred men and women of the theater from all over the world have spent this week in London testing its claim to be the con temporary theatrical capital.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTONPoll results mean different things to different readers, but to some political buffs Dr. Gallup's latest findings will tend to confirm what John Mitchell said this week at a Republican dinner in Virginia: You can't beat somebody with nobody and they sure don't have anybody to run against Nixon.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: THE stock market snapped out of its mild month long slump last week without the benefit of any rash of bullish news to propel it upward. It never theless managed to achieve moderate gains slightly more active trading.

title: Miss. Ruth Levinson To Be Bride June 20
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Budd Levinson of New York and East Hampton, L.I., of the engagement of their daugh ter, Miss Ruth Andrea Lev inson, to Richard Richels, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Richels, of Norfolk, Va. The wedding will take place on June 20 in East Hampton.

title: Graduates of Colleges on L. I. Are Finding a Scarcity of Jobs
description: GREENVALE, L. L, June 5 Thousands of students who were graduated from Long Is land colleges this week are finding there is little available for them on the job market.

title: The Good Word: Second Guesses
description: A recent squint at the children 's bestseller list turned up one book that had been there since 1952, and another dating back to 1945. For doting constancy, it could have been an old people's bestseller listand perhaps it was. By contrast, most adult books fling themselves against the lighted window of Womrath's and expire on contact. A strangled scream from the publisher (strangled at once by the business department), a muttered curse from the reviewer and silence. To prolong a few of these pitiful lives, this column will occasionally laundrylist some books it (me) has liked, pick noisy fights with three or four reviews at once and generally carry on like the crowd at Tim Finnegan's wake.

title: Mary Tonseth Becomes Bride
description: LINCOLN, Mass., June 5 Miss Mary Lee Tonseth was married here this afternoon to Peter Cannon Aldrich. The ceremony was performed in the First Parish Unitarian Congregationalist Church by the Rev. William Gregory. He was assisted by the bride groom's uncle, the Rev. Leo S. Camar, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Foreign Notes
description: Nguyen Van Thieu was elected President of South Vietnam in 1967 by only 35 per cent of the vote in an 11man race. A new election is scheduled for Oct. 3, and Mr. Thieu, according to Sai gon reports, would like to make sure his margin is greater this time. He may have the field all to himself.

title: Cornell Turns Back Maryland in N.C.A.A. Lacrosse Final
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. L, June 5 Cornell won the first Na tional Collegiate Athletic As sociation lacrosse champion ship today, beating Maryland, 12.6, at Hofstra Stadium.

title: U.S. Track and Field Squad Heads for Europe Tomorrow
description: Led by the 1971 A.A.U. in door polevault champion, Dick Railsback, a United States men's track and field squad will leave tomorrow for two meets in Europe. Joining the former U.C.L.A. star will be Michigan State's Herb Wash ington in the dashes and the Duke University freshman sen sation, Bob Wheeler, in the middle distances.

title: . . . But Cliff Is a Cool Lenny
description: IF you saw The Boys in the Band, you haven't forgotten Emory, the fluttery fussbudget who made a fool of himself over a sexy dentist. The chief reason you haven't forgotten Emory is that he was brought to side splitting, heartbreaking life by Cliff Gorman. Gorman's performance was so vividly authentic, in fact, that many theatergoers refused to believe that he was not really the swishing, simpering, lasagnabaking queen of the band.

title: Greenberg, Codet And Dayton Take Yachting Honors
