description: Man in the News

title: KUNSTLER CRITICAL OF GRAND JURY USE
description: William Kunstler, a lawyer who frequently defends anti war demonstrators, said last night that the Federal Govern ment was using grand juries to harass Vietnam war dissenters.

title: State Mayors Shocked by Public Job Actions Here
description: Many of the Mayors of the state's 62 cities attending convention here said yesterday that they were shocked and aghast by the actions of rebellious New York City employes.

title: Black Girl Opens June 17
description: Black Girl, a new play by J. E. Franklin, will be produced by the New Federal Theater company at the Theater de Lys, 121 Christopher Street, on June 17. Shauneille Perry will direct a cast that will include Gloria Edwards, Arthur French, Min nie Gentry, Loretta Green and Jimmy Hayeson.

title: Books of The Times
description: If any romance, any gallantry Still clings to the pathetic and turbulent relationship between Queen Elizabeth I and the Earl of Essex, Robert Lacey's book will siphon it off. It is a sec, coldeyed, underplayed pitiless assessment of an aging, imperious woman playing a fanciful game that sud denly gets out of hand and of a man in dangerous waters and clearly out of his depth. No one was more in error in judging his own worth than Essex, and no one ?? more dearly for the mistake. Technically his death sentence was due to the revolt he thought he was heading in the winter of 1601. But, as Mr. Lacey tells it, it was such a Mack Sennett affair, so ludicrous in what it professed, so creaky and inadequate in operation, that a juster sentence would have been to dress up the man in motley and set him in the stocks. The ignominy of a custard pie in the eye would have achieved more in bringing the man to his senses than the separation of his head from his body. But I suppose armed insurrection to the Elizabethans was no laughing affair. The excesses of the War of the Roses were still warm in the memory of the Queen and her council. After all, it was Henry Tudor, Elizabeth's grandfather, who finally brought a little quiet to the kingdom and that was not such a long time ago.

title: Phone Strike Over Wages Is Foreseen by Unionist
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) The top union leader in na tionwide telephone negotiations said today, It looks like there will be a strike of some 500,000 Bell System workers across the nation.

title: Legislature Votes City Taxes and Adjourns
description: ALBANY, Wednesday, June 9 After weeks of intense nego tiations and acrimonious ex changes between Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Lindsay, the Legislature early this morn ing approved a $525million tax authorization package for New York City.

title: Hunt for Air Crash Victims Curbed by Fog and Terrain
description: DUARTE, Calif., June 8 (UPI)The fuselage of a DC9 airliner that collided with a Marine jet in flight Sunday was scattered so widely over the San Gabriel Mountains that the bodies of only 29 of the 50 persons killed had been found by today.

title: Buffalo G.I. Killed in Action
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) The Defense Department said today that Specialist 4 Donald P. Knutsen of Buffalo, of the Army, had been killed in action in Southeast Asia.

title: Two Adelphi Players Reach College Tennis Quarterfinals
description: Ricky November of Adelphi, the defending champion, routed Pat Parks of Kings Point, 60, 61, to reach the quarterfinals of the Metropolitan college tennis championship yesterday at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Roundup: McDowell Wins 5th in Row
description: Sam McDowell, who had trouble winning at the start of the season and then began winning but lacked control, had few problems in posting his fifth straight victory last night.

title: Softer Vietcong Stand Reported
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) Representative Robert L. Leg gett, Democrat of California, said today Vietcong negotiators in Paris had promised him re cently that if a date were set for total withdrawal of United States forces, they would re lease all their American pris oners before that date.

title: B52 Strikes Continue
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, June 9 (AP) Ground fighting reportedly di minished in South Vietnam yes terday, but United States B52's continued their strikes in the northern part of the country and the Central Highlands, in Laos and in eastern Cambodia.

title: Clifford Offers Forrnula For U.S. to Quit Warin '71
description: WASHINGTON, June 8Clark M. Clifford, former Secretary of Defense, said tonight he had reason to believe that the United States could reach an agreement now with North Viet nam to end American involve ment in the Indochina war by Dec. 31 and obtain the release of the American prisoners of war within 30 days.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: June 8, 1971

title: SOME SUGAR PRICES RAISED BY SUCREST
description: The Sucrest Corporation an nounced yesterday it had raised the list price for industrial grades of refined sugar by 20 cents per hundredweight to $12.70. This was in line with similar actions taken earlier by the Amstar Corporation.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: June 9, 1971

title: Saturday Evening Post Returns as a Quarterly
description: The Saturday Evening Post resurrected two and a half years after it died, was back at the newsstands yesterday complete with a folksy cover showing Norman Rockwell, the man who made Post covers famous since 1916.

title: Rumors of a Connally Race Discounted
description: WASHINGTON, June 8John B. Connally Jr., the Democrat in President Nixon's Cabinet, is not likely to seek elective of fice ever again, one of his closest political confidants said today.

title: RANGERS GIVE UP HORTON, 2 OTHERS IN N.H.L'S DRAFT
description: MONTREAL, June 8 (UPI) The New York Rangers picked up Bobby Rousseau, right wing, but lost Tim Hor ton and Larry Brown defense men, and Mike Parizeau, a forward, in the National Hock ey League's draft today.

title: Dr. Alvin Johnson Of New School Dies
description: Dr. Alvin Johnson, a founder of the New School for Social Research here and a leader in American education, died Mon day night at his home in Upper Nyack, N.Y. He was 96 years old and had been president emeritus of the New School since 1945.

title: DEMOCRATS SEEK TV SPENDING CUT
description: WASHINGTON, June 8  The Senate Democratic Policy Committee agreed today that lower radio and television limits should be restored to the campaign spending bill when it reaches the floor next month.

title: Bridge: Tourists Rally to Set Back Mauritius League's Combine
description: CUREPIPE, Mauritius, June 5  After two days of bask ing in a tropical island para dise, the Precision interna tional touring team pulled it self together here last night and defeated the representa tives of the Mauritius Bridge League.

title: MARKET DECLINES AFTER 7 ADVANCES
description: Glamour stocks sagged again yesterday and this time the general market gave ground amid an atmosphere of investor caution. Declines outnumbered advances by more than a 2to1 ratio.

title: Market Place:
description: If you were offered a chance to invest in some of the world's most prestigious addresses  specifically the Park Avenue properties of the bankrupt Penn Central rail roadwould you settle for a return of 8 per cent?

title: City Tax Package Falls Between Mayor's Option 2 and Option
description: The tax authorization pack age being enacted by the State Legislature would lead to the elimination of about 25,000 city jobs and the laying off of 15, 000 workers, according to a projection made by Mayor Lindsay last April.

title: Fox Insurgents Are Angered by Loss
description: The Twentieth CenturyFox Film Corporation reconvened its annual meeting here yes terday to go through the for malities of announcing that management had beaten off a bid for control from a group of dissident stockholders.

title: TV: Hard Look at Vietnam Coverage.
description: All About TV has been a staple of WNYCTV's Chan nel 31 for the last two sea sons. As a UHF outlet the channel is somewhat off the narrow path of popular tele vision fare. As a forum for discussing controversial is sues, the program is quite definitely off that path.

title: The Fragile Cities
description: New York City is supposed to have the power to overwhelm all its squab bling citizens. Like some great ele mental force of nature, it seems as permanent as its great rivers, polluted but irresistible.

title: YORK CLASS IS TOLD OF INTEGRATION GAIN
description: The graduating class at the first commencement exercises at York College was told yes terday that a movement to wards real integration of the races was taking place in the United States.

title: 499 of 856 Applicants Pass State Bar Examinations
description: ALBANY, June 8The State Board of Law Examiners an nounced today, the names of 499 applicants who passed the examination for admission to the bar given last March 8 and 9.

title: Oyster Lovers, Take Heart!
description: For the first time since 1912, New York State resi dents can order oysters in restaurants and fish markets all year long. The conserva tion law that had prohibited their sale from May 15 through Aug. 31 has been re pealed.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: WHO is Harry Kellerman and why is be saying those terrible things about me?Advt.

title: Minneapolis Reelects Stenvig; Margin Is Better than 2 to 1
description: MINNEAPOLIS, June 8 oters gave Mayor Charles S. tenvig a resounding endorse lent tonight for a second two ear term.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Maine Papers Elect Officers
description: PORTLAND, Me., June 8 Directors of the Guy Gannett Publishing Company have elect ed Robert B. Beith publisher and George F. Marshall general manager of the newspaper publishing company.

title: Woody Allen Says He's Still Incompetent
description: In your cinematic works, what is the significance of the recurrent motif of masked parents?

title: $5 Fine for a Lift Voted
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 8 (UPI)The City Council voted last night, 5 to 3, to approve $5 fines for motorists who give rides to hitchhikers. Under the ordinance, drivers will be given warnings on the first two of fenses and would be fined on the third and subsequent of fenses.

title: Notes on People
description: A year ago last May, Rep resentative William M. Mc Culloch of Ohio, ranking Republican on the House Judiciary Committee, fell in his Washington apartment while trying to open a win dow. No complications were noted in a hospital checkup at the time, but last fall a small blood clot was found in his skull.

title: 7 Unions Accuse Post Office of Unfair Practices in Pact Talks
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 Seven unions filed charges of unfair labor practices against the United States Post Office today, accusing it of bargain ing in bad faith.

title: News Analysis
description: It used to be virtually auto matic for the State Legislature to place its stamp of approval on increased pension benefits negotiated by City Hall.

title: Hot Day at Track Brings a Cool $1,200
description: The 90degree temperature at Belmont Park proved cost ly to Johnny Rotz, the jockey, yesterday, but it provided an unexpected pickup of $1,200 for another rider, Chuck Bal tazar.

title: MINE UNION SEEKS SUBSTANTIAL RISE
description: The president of the United Mine Workers of America told the union's national scale and policy committee here yester day that the miners would seek substantial wage in creases, higher management contributions to their welfare fund and paid sick leave in a new contract for the bitumin ous coal industry.

title: Davison Qualifies for Open
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., June 8 Peter Davison, a 24yearold assistant professional from the Oak Hill Club, Rochester, N. Y., who has read about but never seen the site of this year's United States Open golf cham pionship, led the Metropolitan qualifying today for the game's blueribbon event by four strokes.

title: Article 1  No Title
AMEX RETREATS IN SLOW TRADING
description: The American Stock Exchange registered its biggest loss in three weeks yesterday as the list retreated in slow trading.

title: A.B.C. Plans a Secondary
description: American Broadcasting Com panies, Inc., announced yester day that its board has author ized the filing of a registration with the Securities and Ex change Commission for a pro posed secondary offering by the Edward John Noble Foun dation of 300,000 shares of common stock of the company.

title: Rails for the Future
description: Transportation Secretary John A. Volpe and Senator Barry Goldwater, who represented President Nixon the recent test flight in Europe of the BritishFrench supersonic jet, took part in the wrong event. They could have brought home a more useful message from the ex perimental run in West Germany of a prototype train designed to move between cities at speeds of up to 350 miles per hour.

title: Executive Changes
description: The General Foods Corporation announced yes terday that Richard Laster, formerly executive vice president of the Maxwell House Division, was named president of the division and elected a cor porate vice president. Kenneth E. Fulton was made president of the firm's Institutional Food Service division, and Leo E. Shepard becomes director corporate sales and was elected a corporate vice president.

title: Reuthers' Ashes Scattered On Hill Near Union Center
description: ONAWAY, Mich., June 8 (AP) The ashes of the late presi dent of the United Auto Work ers Union, Walter P. Reuther, and his wife, Mae, have been scattered on a hillside over looking the union's Walter and Mae Reuther Family Education Center at Black Lake, near On away.

title: NIXON'S PANEL BARS CONSTRUCTION RAISE
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 (UPI)  In its first rejection of a negotiated pay rise, the Nixon Administration's Construction Industry Wage Stabilization Committee has refused to ap prove a 51 per cent pay in crease over two years for Philadelphia painters.

title: PLAYING IS SPIRITED AT TULLY SAMPLER
description: Two groups of players from the New York Philharmonic pre sided over the second Alice Tully Hall Sampler concert Monday night and everyone concerned played beautifully, with spirit and skill.

title: Eyebrow Raisers Become Classics
description: Back in the nineteenfor ties, a woman could easily have been arrested for loiter ing if she hung around in some of the clothes Halston is showing today. Necklines slashed to the waist. Silver fox boas wrapped around the wrist. Sheer tiedyed ponchos worn over nothing but black satin pants. Sometimes just a sheer chiffon scarf tied above the black satin pants.

title: Agreement in Principle Is Announced by Taiwan on Textile Exports
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, June 8 (Reu ters)  Nationalist China has agreed in principle to limit its exports of manmadefiber and wool textile products to the United States, the Ministry of Affairs said today.

title: One Park Has Business as UsualNo Maintenance
description: The strike carne quietly yesterday to Owl's Head Park in the Bay Ridge section of Brooklynso quietly that nobody noticed it.

title: CHILEAN EXAIDE SLAIN BY GUNMEN
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, June 8  Ambushers firing submachine guns killed today a former min ister who was an outspoken antileftist politician.

title: Malaysian Frog War Really LoveIn
description: Last fall's widely reported frog war in Malaysia ap pears to have been misinter preted. It Is now believed the frogs were making love, not war.

title: Legislative Swing to Right Clips Governor's Power
description: ALBANY, Wednesday, June 9 On April 2, just after the Legislature had chopped a $760million chunk from his proposed budget, Governor Rockefeller said that conserva tive Republicans had got their pound of flesh, and he made it plain that he intended to get some of it back.

title: Suburbs Are Voting on Schools
U.S. Aides Unimpressed By RICHARD D. LYONS
description: WASHINGTON. June 8  Federal space and diplomatic officials said privately today that Moscow's proposal for an international treaty that would bar military activity on the moon was an attempt to fuzz cooperation on other space is sues.

title: Justice Department Considers Shift on Virginia's Voting Plan
description: WASHINGTON, June 8The Justice Department's chief civil rights official disclosed today that the department was re considering its disapproval of Virginia's reapportionment plan in light of a Supreme Court decision announced yesterday.

title: Davis Hearing Postponed
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., June 8 (UPI)Pretrial hearings in the Angela DavisRuchell Magee murderkidnapping case were postponed today until Monday because Miss Davis's attorney was out of town.

title: Article 6  No Title
SLUMP CONTINUES IN BOND PRICES
description: The credit markets, which started to move toward higher interest rates and lower bond prices Monday in response to Federal Reserve action, con tinued to slump yesterday.

title: Jeweler, 77, Shot as Gang Flees With Tray of Rings
description: One of four young bandits shot and critically wounded an elderly jeweler yesterday in his store at 225 West 23d Street. The four bandits, one of whom was a young woman, fled with a trayful of diamond rings.

title: Mine Orphan Aid Rejected
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) A bill to give benefits to orphans of coal miners who died of black lung disease failed to win approval of a House Education and Labor subcom mittee today.

title: SPUR SALES ABROAD, TEXTILE MEN URGED
description: Textile manufacturers were urged yesterday to step up their selling efforts overseas to help the United States's balance of payments.

title: TAPS ON CONGRESS DENIED BY HOOVER
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 (UPI)  The Federal Bureau of Investigation, according to its director, J. Edgar ?? was at one time recently tapping 47 telephone and has sec retly planted at least six micro phones for security reasons or to investigate organized crime. None of them, Mr. Hoover said, was being used on Congress men.

title: LEO BURNETT, 79, LED AD AGENCY
description: LAKE ZURICH, Ill., June 8 (AP)Leo Burnett, founder of the international advertising agency that bears his name and onetime president of the Adver tising Council, died yesterday at his home here. He was 79 years old.

title: Arizonans Sue U.S. For $4Million Loss In Forest Spraying
description: TUCSON, Ariz., June 8Two dozen neighbors of the. Tonto National Forest 100 miles north of here have sued the Federal Government for $4.43million, contending that the use of de foliants had injured their prop erty and personal health.

title: FANNY MAY TO SHUN UNLIMITED BUYING
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 (Reu ters)Oakley Hunter, Pres ident of the Federal National Mortgage Association said to day the association would not buy an unlimited quantity at any price at tomorrow's mort gage auction.

title: Death in Central Park
description: An unidentified boy about 14 years old drowned in Central Park's 72d Street Lake near the Bethesda Fountain about 2:30 P.M. yesterday, the police of the Arsenal Station reported.

title: Banks' Trust Function Is Studied
description: The Presidential Commission on Financial Structure and Reg ulation is considering a propos al to require commercial banks to divest their trust depart ments entirely, a key member of the commission's staff said yesterday.

title: Retail Sales Gain Holds
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 (Reu ters)Assistant Commerce Sec retary Harold C. Passer said preliminary reports showed the April gain in retail sales was extended through May.

title: Disease, Hunger and Death Stalk Refugees Along India's Border
description: KARIMPUR, India, June 8 Sickness, hunger and death are common scenes now along In dia's 1,350mile border with East Pakistan. Millions of Ben galis  unofficial figures put the number over five million have fled East Pakistan to es cape the Pakistani Army, which since late March has been try ing to crush the movement for autonomy, and later independ ence, in East Pakistan.

title: Brandt to Stress U. S.Market Tie in Nixon Talks
description: BONN, June 8While Chan cellor Willy Brandt expects to cover major EastWest prob lems, including the Berlin issue, when he meets with President Nixon next week, he considers the United States' relations with an expanded European Economic Community as the most vital subject on his Wash ington agenda.

title: Kenny Trial Still Recessed
description: NEWARK, June 8The trial of John V. Kenny, the Hudson County Democratic leader, re mained in recess for the second consecutive day today because he has been hospitalized. Mr. Kenny and eight other present or former county and Jersey City officials are on trial in Feder Court on charges of conspiring to extract kickbacks from contractors.

title: 93 Heat in City Results in Record In Electricity Use
description: The mercury did not reach a record yesterday, but New Yorkers behaved as though it had. Between 3 and 5 P.M. they used more electricity than at any time in the city's his tory.

title: Morocco Dances At Benefit to Help Women Prisoners
description: Morocco is her name and Mid East dancing is her style, and Monday evening she shiv ered from top knot to toes for the Women's House of Deten tion Medical Fund at St. Clem on's Church. The occasion was a benefit performance that mixed dull poetry, blandly in teresting folk singing and some genuinely exciting dancing for the cause.

title: U.N. Responsibility Sought
description: LONDON, June 8  The For eign Secretary said today that the responsibility for the ref ugees flooding into India from East Pakistan must be as sumed by the United Nations.

title: Cholera Spreads in Chad; Reported in 2 New Areas
description: FORTLAMY, Chad, June 8 (Agence FrancePresse)Chad's cholera epidemic, which has taken over 400 lives in the last seven days, was reported today to be worsening as new out breaks appeared in two more areas.

title: GLADYS L. ROBINSON, ACTOR'S EXWIFE, 75
description: HOLLYWOOD, June 8 (UPI) Gladys Lloyd Robinson, stage actress and former wife of the actor Edward G. Robinson, died Sunday of a stroke and heart attack at Culver City Memorial Hospital. She was 75 years old.

title: Move, Promoted by U.S., Will Attempt to Balk the Protectionists
description: PARIS  Twentythree ad vanced nations agreed today to try to keep protectionist forces at bay by setting up a special highlevel group to study and seek to resolve the growing number of trade problems.

title: Premier's Plan for Talks Is Rejected by Pathet Lao
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, June  (Agence FrancePresse)  The Pathet Lao and its ally, the Lao Patriotic Front, today rejected Premier Souvanna Phouma's suggestion for peace talks in Vientiane without any precon ditions.

title: Five Convicted of Fraud On Hercules Galion Stock
description: A former national bank chairman and four other men have been convicted of fraud and conspiracy to manipulate the price of Hercules Galion Products, Inc., on the American Stock Exchange. The convic tions, announced yesterday by United States Attorney Whitney North Seymour Jr., grew out of Federal indict ments nearly four years ago during a wideranging investi gation of a series of alleged manipulations on the Amex.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 4  No Title
Fiber Box Use Seen Rising
description: More than 18.25 million tons of liner and 7.5 million tons of containerboard will be required to meet domestic and export demands in 19?? the Fibre Box ?? represents an increase of 80 per cent above present fiber box consumption.

title: Big Leagues Open Baseball Draft Here
description: Danny Kay Goodwin, a 17 yearold high school slugger from Peoria, Ill., was chosen by the Chicago White Sox yes terday as the No. 1 player in the seventh annual summer baseball draft conducted here.

title: Newspaper Strike Continues
description: PITTSBURGH, June 8 (AP) Negotiators for the Pittsburgh Press Company and its striking printers ended another round of talks today with no progress re ported in the 25dayold strike that has left the city without either of its daily newspapers, the afternoon Press and the morning PostGazette.

title: Russians Are Said to Link Troop and Security Talks
description: LONDON, June 8 (AP)The Soviet Union today reiterated its willingness to discuss East West troop reductions but only within the framework of a general European security con ference, British officials said.

title: UTILITIES STRESS REACTOR PROJECT
description: CLEVELAND, June 8  The nation's electric utilities empha sized here today the urgency for proceeding with the de velopment of a fastbreeder, nu clearreactor program. The fastbreeder, nuclear reactor is a device that produces more nuclear fuel than it consumes in the process of generating electricity.

title: Albany Approves a City Housing Corporation With the Power to Lend $700Million
description: ALBANY, Wednesday, June As the State Legislature eased toward adjournment of its 1971 session, the Assembly gave final approval yesterday to a bill per mitting New York City to create a housing development corpora tion with power to raise $700 million through the sale of bonds.

title: 2D WITNESS IS HELD IN YUBA CITY DEATHS
description: The material witness, identi fied as Juan Cervantes Mosqueta 50 years old, a farm laborer, was picked up at Stockton and taken to the Sutter County Jail at Yuba City yesterday, officers said.

title: Branch Banking Bill Signed
description: Governor Rockefeller signed yesterday the bill authorizing statewide branch banking in New York, effective Jan. 1, 1976, that was passed by the State Legislature last week.

title: First Priority: Welfare Reform
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.Welfare re form is urgently needed and should be a priority of Congress.

title: Bulgarian Ban on Flights From West Berlin Is Lifted
description: BERLIN, June 8  Bulgaria today lifted a ban on holiday charter flights from West Berlin to her Black Sea coast, restoring full landing rights at Varna and other resorts to Modern Air, an American charter carrier han dling the tours.

title: Health Grading of Restaurants Urged
description: Dismayed by the continu ing number of unsanitary restaurants here, city health officials want to require all eating places to display the scorecard of their most re cent inspection.The Health Department's restaurant inspectors cur rently use a threepage print ed checklist. Reproduction of this list would be too spaceconsuming. in the view of department officials, and also would be largely incom prehensible to the average customer.

title: Poage Assails Nixon Plan
description: TAMPA, Fla., June 8 (AP) The chairman of the Agricul ture Committee, W. R. Poage, Democrat, of Texas, today de nounced President Nixon's plan to abolish the Department of Agriculture and transfer its functions to proposed new Gov ernment agencies. He referred to the President's recommenda tion for regrouping seven de partments into four reorganized departments.

title: Langhorne 150Miler Canceled When Drivers Shun Old Track
description: About Motor Sports

title: OTTOCARO WEISS, FRIEND OF JOYCE
description: Ottocaro Weiss, Italianborn business executive and cul tural figure, died here Sunday, a few days before his 75th birthday.

title: Patriots Keep Training Site
description: BOSTON, June 8 (AP)  The New England Patriots an nounced today they would re turn to the University of Mas sachusetts at Amherst for the third straight year for their pre season training camp opening July 13. The National Football League club also announced the signing of Jim Cheyunski, Ed Philpott, Ed Toner and Tom Beer.

title: Moscow Offers Draft Treaty for Cooperation on the Moon
description: MOSCOW, June 8  The Soviet Union today made public a draft of a proposed treaty calling for international co operation on the moon and barring any nation, from estab lishing, sovereignty or setting up military bases there. The treaty would also oblige signa tory countries to take steps to preserve the, moon's natural environment.

title: Kennedy Still Not Running
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 (AP) Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, re peated today that he did not intend to run for President in 1972. My position is un changed, he said after the American Broadcasting Com pany said it had obtained a Jan. 28 letter signed by Mr. Kennedy and implying that he was leaving the door open to candidacy.

title: To Some It Looks Like Junk Yard, to Boys It Looks Like Fun
description: The world of East Flatbush in Brook lyn is divided into two kinds of people: those who think that the rubblestrewn vacant lot on the corner of Church Avenue and East 42d Street is a rub blestrewn vacant lot  and the others.

title: Firmness Pays Off
description: The abrupt abandonment last night of the recklessly irresponsible strike by unionized municipal employes does much more than end what had become an undis guised war against the eight million residents of New York City whose health and welfare the strikers were supposed to protect. The backtowork order by strike leaders has made it clear that governmental firmness can triumph over unconscionable abuses of union con trol over vital public services. This outcome could mark the turning point in cityunion relationships that have gotten grievously out of balance, primarily because the community's desire to build up strong, responsible unions in the civil service enabled labor to acquire power faster than social responsibility.

title: 28 INDICTED HERE IN GAMBLING CASE
description: Twentyeight men were in dicted yesterday on charges of criminal contempt in what Dis trict Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn called the first result of the biggest investigation of policeprotected gambling here in more than 20 years.

title: Wall Street Imposes Safeguards To Prevent Theft of Securities
description: Wall Street has taken many steps to curb a rapid increase in securities thefts, a problem that became acute beginning in 1967 when heavy trading vol ume caused operational diffi culties in the back offices of brokerage firms and banks.

title: Article 10  No Title
description: CLEVELAND, June 8 (UPI) The SherwinWilliams Company announced today plans to close down its linseedoil mill in Cleveland, which employs about 100 persons.

title: State Aide Bids Landlords Use SelfControl on Rents
description: State Housing Commissioner Charles J. Urstadt told an over flow meeting of more than 1,000 landlords yesterday that the Legislature that gave them vacancy decontrol could also take it away, and he warned them to use selfcontrol in ap plying the law.

title: HARTFORD'S HOUSE VOTES RELIEF CURB
description: HARTFORD, Wednesday, June 9The Connecticut House of Representatives overwhelming ly approved yesterday a bill patterned after New York State, legislation that would impose a loneyear residency requirement on welfare recipients.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: BEN POLLACK DIES; MUSICIAN WAS 67
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., June a (UPI)  Ben Pollack, for mer bandleader who was known as the father of swing in the 1930's and 1940's, was found dead by hanging in his home here yesterday. He was 67 years old.

title: Judge Mansfield Sworn In
description: Federal District Judge Walter R. Mansfield was sworn in yes terday as a judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, which handles cases from New York, Connecticut and Vermont. Judge Mansfield, 59 years old, had been a judge on the Fed eral Court for the Southern District of New York since 1966.

title: DR. LOUIS BERLIN
description: MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., June 8Dr. Louis Berlin, associate professor of neurology at the Albert Einstein College of Med icine in New York, died today in Mount Vernon Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived at 99 Pennsylvania Avenue.

title: Kelsey Brokerage Concern Loses S.E.C. Registration
description: WASHINGTON, June 8 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission today revoked the brokerdealer registration of J. M. Kelsey & Co. of New York after charging that it had sold unregistered stock.

title: Edgar Smith Is Ordered Freed From Death Row for New Trial
description: NEWARK, June 8  Edgar H. Smith Jr., who has been on Death Row for 14 years, was ordered freed on $5,000 bail today while Bergen County pro secutors prepare to retry him in the bludgeon slaying of Vir ginia Zielinski.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: TroubleRidden Italy Uneasy as Vote Nears
description: ROME, June 8This capital has been decked out like a Christmas tree for the election next Sunday, but the holiday spirit is missing.

title: Newberry Points to Losses in Canada
description: Canadians occasionally complain about American business infiltration into their country, but it isn't very often that a United States company admits to having overexpanded in the vast Northern country.

title: BarLev Assesses Situation
description: TEL AVIV, June 8Israel's Chief of Staff, Lieut. Gen. Haim BarLev, said today that any Egyptian attempt to resume hostilities would not achieve any strategic objective, so the Arab armies would end up no better off than they are now under the ceasefire.

title: Securities Thefts Put at $500Million
description: WASHINGTON, June 8  Attorney General John N. Mitchell said today that by conservative estimate more than $500million worth of securities had been stolen in the last two years, much of it by organized crime.

title: Theater: Brightening Shakespeare.
description: STRATFORD, Ontario, June 8This is the season for the Stratfords of the world to unite, revere Shakespeare, make themselves a buck or two in the process and give a great deal of Shakespear ean pleasure. The Shake speare Festival at Stratford, Ontario, nowadays lasts 22 weeks, six of them primarily for school audiences, and em braces a great deal more than Shakespeare.

title: SPRAGUE ELECTRIC ANNOUNCES LAYOFFS
description: NORTH ADAMS, Mass., June 8 (AP) The Sprague Electric Company announced the dismissal today of 150 of its salaried and hourly em ployes at its North Adams plants and several hundred more at 16 other plants across the country.

title: WRVR WILL SWITCH TO A NEWS FORMAT
description: John Wicklein, a former re porter for The New York Times and for Channel 13, has been appointed general manager of radio station WRVR. His as signment will be to convert the station, which is owned by Riverside Church, from its pres ent format of classical music and jazz to an allnews station.

title: 5Inch Portrait Sold for $156,240
description: LONDON, June 5 (AP)A miniature portrait was sold for $156.240 today, a price believed to be a world record for such an art work. In 1842 it was bought by a peer for 18the annual wage of his butler.

title: Cholera Rampant On Bengal Border
description: NEW DELHI, June 8  The World Health Organization an nounced here today that cholera had spread along the whole of the 1,350mile West BengalEast Pakistan border.

title: CHANNEL 13 PLANS EXPANSION IN ARTS
description: Robert Kotlowitz, who re cently resigned as managing editor of Harper's Magazine, will join WNET (Channel 13) next month in the newly creat ed post of executive editor in the programing department.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARISA new speed record for po litical defection and redefection has perhaps been established by Jozsef Szall, Hungary's senior diplomat, who fled Budapest last autumn, sought asylum in the United States, and has now returned to Europe proclaiming himself a Hungarian patriot and a good socialist.

title: A Warsaw Delegation, Planning Economic Changes, Meets Kosygin in Soviet
description: WARSAW, June 8A Polish Government delegation headed by Premier Piotr Jaroszewicz began talks today in Moscow to prepare the way for major changes in Poland's economic planning.

title: Article 9  No Title
Penn Central Plans To Determine Size Of Crew on Its Own
description: The Penn Central Transpor tation Company notified the United Transportation Union yesterday that the railroad will feel free effective July 15 to determine on its own the size of its train crews.

title: 6 Houston Militants Seized
description: HOUSTON, June 8 (AP)The police arrested six persons to day in a raid on the headquar ters of People's Party II, a black militant organization. Ac cording to the police, one shot was fired as they sought to enter the headquarters with a search warrant. A spokesman said the police did not return the fire.

title: Economic Analysis
description: The international money crisis of May has brought to a head the issue of whether the rich industrial nations are headed for greater protectionism and capital controls or for freer trade and flexible ex change rates.

title: G.O.P. Majority in Albany Votes Panel to Study City
description: ALBANY, Wednesday, June 9 After wrestling for weeks over New York's City's fiscal problems, the Republicancon trolled Legislature voted early today to create a temporary state commission to make a sweeping investigation of the present management, struc ture, organization and the fis cal and governance practices of the Lindsay administration.

title: JERSEY PRIMARY WON BY REGULARS
description: NEWARK, June 8The es tablished powers in New Jer sey's Democratic and Republi can parties won easy victories today in the, state's legislative primary elections.

title: WILLIAM COE DEAD; EXRAIL EXECUTIVE
description: OYSTER BAY, L.I., June 8 William Rogers Coe, a former banker and railroad executive, died on May 26. He was 70 years old and lived in this com munity and in Hobe Sound, Fla.

title: Richardson, After Year on Job, Hailed for Ending Chaos at H.E.W
description: WASHINGTON, June 8One year ago, there was talk around Washington that one of the kindest things President Nixon ever did was to relieve Robert H. Finch from the torments of the Department of Health, Edu cation and Welfare.

title: Savings Banks Set Mark In Net Inflow of Deposits
description: Savings banks in New York had a record net inflow of de posits of $396million during May, the Savings Banks Asso ciation of New York State announced yesterday. This com pared with an increase of $68 million in the same month last year and $76million in 1969.

title: Nassau Asks Court to Bar New Sewage Strike Here
description: An injunction against any new strike by New York City sewagetreatment workers was sought yesterday by Nassau County, in what the County Attorney's office believed to be the first invoking of the Taylor Law by a jurisdiction different from the one struck.

title: Packard Qualifies Support for Lockheed Loan
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 Deputy Secretary of Defense David Packard gave qualified support today to the Admin istration's plan to provide fi nancial assistance to the troubled Lockheed Aircraft Corporation. He said that the argument over whether the company should be saved from impending bankruptcy is not primarily a defense issue.

title: WPIX BEGAN 9 SHOWS AFTER FORUM'S PLEA
description: WASHINGTON, June 9, (AP) WPIXTV began broadcasting nine public service programs after learning its broadcast li cense would be challenged, a vice president of the station tes tified yesterday at a Federal Communications Commission, hearing.

title: FIRES SET AS BANDS ROAM IN BROOKLYN
description: Bands of teenagers roved through a sixblock stretch of Havemeyer Street in the Wil liamsburg section of Brooklyn last night, setting fire to gar bage piles in the street, break ing store windows and throw ing bottles at policemen.

title: Refugee Flow Continues
description: CALCUTTA, India, June 9 (Reuters)East Pakistani refu gees continued moving into the troubled Indian town of Barasat today as five foreign planeloads of medical supplies reached Cal cutta to help fight the cholera epidemic.

title: Stage: Webster's Duchess of Malfi
description: STRATFORD, Ontario, June 9Not for the first time and probably not for the last, because institutions breed traditionsthe second night of the Stratford Festival off set the slight disappointment of the first. Last night's pro duction of John Webster's The Duchess of Malfi was a most cogent performance of a thrillingly evil play.

title: Projected Tax Rise Here
description: ALBANY, June 9  Following is a table showing the effects of the $190million increase in the city income tax authorization on commuters and New York City residents, which was enacted yesterday by the Legisla ture and signed by the Governor. The examples are for a family of four with personal exemptions of $600 person and with a standard deduction of 10 per cent or $1,000, whichever is less.

title: A Spending Limit On Computer Use In Campaign Asked
description: WASHINGTON, June 9  The House Communications Committee was urged today to place spending limits on the new and expensive com puterized campaign techniques as well as on radio and tele vision.

title: Miss Heldman Victor
description: NOTTINGHAM. England, Junel 8 (AP)Julie Heldman of Mous ton gained the semifinals be fore rain halted action in the John Player international tennis tournament today. Miss Held man easily defeated Judy Kirk of South Africa. 61, 63.

title: Groups of Jews in U.S. Are Seeking to Establish Own Scientific and Industrial Communes in Israel
description: JERUSALEM, June 9 Several diverse groups of highly skilled Jewish Ameri cans, attracted by the life style of the commune, have asked to establish new settle ments in Israelnot to work the land in the old Zionist tradition, but to pursue sci entific research or to build industrial plants.

title: Vote on SugarAnd Racism
description: The House of Representatives has an unusual oppor tunity today to accomplish three useful goals in one series of votes. It can break out of an outrageous legis lative straitjacket fashioned by Agriculture and Rules Committee majorities, expose the corruption written into the Sugar Act, and remove an appearance of hypocrisy in United States policy toward South African racism.

title: Briton Urges East Pakistani Settlement
description: LONDON, June 9The Brit ish Foreign Secretary, Sir Alec DouglasHome, made a strong appeal today for a political set tlement in East Pakistan, term ing it an essential condition for any permanent solution to the Pakistani refugee disaster.

title: Magnavox Closing in Urbana
description: URBANA, Ill., June 9 (AP) The Magnavox Company an nounced today it was closing its Urbana plant and would cease production by the end of the year. About 400 people will be asked to transfer and another 400 will be zeleased.

title: Relief Program Planned
description: GENEVA, June 9A special representative of Secretary General Thant of the United Nations today requested the cooperation of the Food and Agriculture Organization and the League of Red Cross Socie ties in a largescale food relief program for East Pakistan.

title: Article 2  No Title
Baby Lenore Custody Fight Gets Under Way in Florida
description: MIAMI, June 9  The custody fight over 12month old Baby Lenore reached into Florida today, bringing to this hot and humid city the same mix of claims and counterclaims and bitterness and sadness that have ac companied the case in New York since January.

title: ExDropouts Attain Goal: Graduation
description: The Harlem Preparatory School graduated 116 former high school dropouts yester day, all with scholarships to such institutions as Harvard, Wesleyan, Columbia and the University of the New World in Switzerland.

title: JULIUS M. HUHN, OPERA SINGER, 61
description: ROCHESTER, June 9 (AP) Julius M. Huehn, an opera singer and chairman of the vocal department at Eastman School of Music, died in Strong Memorial Hospital here yester day after a long illness. He was 61 years old.

title: ANGELA DAVIS GIVES VIEWS IN NEW BOOK
description: A book by Angela Davis, most of which was written in prison, will be published this fall by The Third Press  Joseph Ok paku Publishing Company.

title: Big Four Termed Near Accord On Easing of Access to Berlin
description: BONN, June 9Allied sources disclosed today that the Big Four ambassadors had virtually completed work on a key ele ment of their proposed agree ment on Berlin, an arrange ment for access to West Berlin.

title: Metropolitan to Seek More City Funds
description: By 1976, New York City will be asked to contribute $585,000 a year in additional funds to implement the Metropolitan Museum's mas ter plan, it was revealed yes terday by City Councilman Carter Burden. The sum, for guardianship and mainte nance, represents 20 per cent of the operating expenses of three new wings, figured on the basis of the 20 per cent of the museum's operating expenses that the city now gives. This past year, the city contribution amounted to $2.3million.

title: MAYORS ASK RIGHT TO TAX STATE U.
description: The Mayors of some of the communities in which branches of the State University of New York are situated agreed at a meeting yesterday to seek leg islation making colleges pay for police and fire protection and a variety of other public services.

title: Borough Presidents Split on Secession From State
description: Among Borough Presidents, the idea of making New York City the 51st state got a very mixed reception yesterday from a real cheer in the Bronx to an emphatic include us out comment from Staten Island.

title: Summary of Bills Passed and Killed in Albany During the 1971 Legislative Session
description: ALBANY, June 9Following ere the major actions taken by the Legislature during the reg War 1971 session, which ended early this morning:

title: A NEW HINDS RULING REQUESTED OF COURT
description: WASHINGTON, June 9The state of Mississippi asked the Supreme Court today to recon sider its order, announced last Thursday, that Hinds County must be divided into single member legislative districts.

title: Jersey Center Opens Series With Cliburn
description: There is a time for under statement and restraint, and there is a time for beating the big drum. The opening of the Garden State Arts Center's fourth season on Tuesday night in Holmdel, N. J., definitely fell in the latter category. Henry Lewis led his New Jersey Symphony Orchestra in an allTchaikov sky program topped out with Van Cliburn performing, not surprisingly, the BFlat Minor Piano Concerto.

title: Racially Torn L. I. School Will Reopen for Seniors
description: COPIAGUE, L. I., June 9 Copiague High School, where racial disorders broke out Mon day and yesterday, will remain closed tomorrow and will hold classes on Friday only for seniors, Principal Walter G. O'Connell said today.

title: Wisconsin Coach Resigns
description: MADISON, Wis., June 8 (AP) Wisconsin's track coach, Bob Brennan, resigned today to go Into private business.

title: Passenger in Taxi Accused in Shooting Of a Toll Collector
description: A toll collector on duty at Trihorough Bridge was shot yesterday by a passenger in taxicab, the police reported.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: FORE STBURG N.Y., Dr. James Cinberg caught up wath me at the Dated Rock pool on the Neversink River and we confessed to each other that our creels were empty.

title: OCCUPIED SCHOOL IS CLOSED IN MILAN
description: MILAN, Italy, June 9The Polytechnical University here closed its School of Architec ture today in an effort to end the occupation of the building by the families of homeless workers, most of whom are mi grants from southern Italy.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
PEDESTRIAN INJURED BY BOMB IN STREET
description: A 58yearold Brooklyn man was seriously injured by a bomb early today when he picked up a shopping bag that he saw while walking on a street in downtown Brooklyn.

title: LAIRD, AT POINT, PRAISES MILITARY
description: WEST POINT, N. Y., June Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird told 720 members of the United States Military Academy graduating class to day that they should not be defensive about being mili tary men.

title: SINYAVSKY'S FREEING BY SOVIET REPORTED
description: MOSCOW, June 9 (UPI) Sources in literary circles said today that the writer Andrei D. Sinyaysky was released from orison this week but would now be barred from residing in Moscow.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Arnoldo Mondadori Dies at 81; Founder of Publishing Empire
description: MILAN, June 9 (AP)  Ar noldo Mondadori, who found ed one of Italy's largest print ing and publishing houses, died at his home last night. He was years old.

title: White House Suggests Clifford Is Playing Politics and Raising False Hopes With Proposal on Prisoners
description: WASHINGTON, June 9The White House suggested today that Clark M. Clifford, former Secretary of Defense, and others were raising false hopes about American prison ers of war for domestic polit ical purposes.

title: SENATE APPROVES CEILING ON DRAFT FOR NEXT 2 YEARS
description: WASHINGTON, June 9The Senate adopted today an abso lute ceiling on the number of men the President can draft into the military in the next two fiscal years.

title: Soviet Astronaut, on TV, Demonstrates Spacesuit for Keeping Trim
description: MOSCOW, June 9A Soviet astronaut floated upside down today in the weightlessness of the spacious orbital station Salyut and, pedaling the air, demonstrated a new tension suit designed to keep muscles in condition on long space flights.

title: 800 at Festival Helping Museum of Modern Art
description: Just when everybody thought the Somebodies had crept away exhausted from the May social season to rest up in the Hamptons for fall, along came June and the first benefit for the Museum of Modern Art since anyone could remember.

title: Hunt Chilean Leftist in Slaying of Opposition Chief
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, June 9 The search for the killer of Edmundo Perez Zukovic a leader of the Opposition Chris tian Democratic party, cen tered today on a young extrem list who has reportedly organ ized criminals for revolutionary violence.

title: Mayday Leader Put Under Bail So He'll Appear Before Inquiry
description: DETROIT, June 9A Fed eral grand jury believed to be investigating the March 1 bombing of the United States Capitol acted today to insure that an organizer of the May day protest in Washington would appear when it con vened here next Monday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 4  No Title
Jacklin Tunes Up in $150,000 Kemper Before Defending U. S. Open Title
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., June 9 Tony Jacklin has been in a slump. The 26yearold Eng lishman, who defends his United States Open golf title next week, is here to put his game together again. One piece is here, one is there, he said in attempting to ex plain his dilemma.

title: Article 7  No Title
Eurodollar Borrowing Rises
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 (Reu ters)Eurodollar borrowing by United States banks rose $297 million in the week ended June 2 to $1,869,000,000 outstanding, the Federal Reserve reported today. The rise followed a $48 million decline the previous week.

title: BOND PRICES DROP THIRD DAY IN ROW
description: The bond market's slump moved into its third day yes terday as prices continued to move downward and interest rates kept climbing.

title: Drain Cleaners Face Curb
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) The Food and Drug Admin istration announced today that liquid drain cleaners contain ing more than 10 per cent lye would be banned in 60 days unless packaged in Govern mentapproved childproof con tainers.

title: Municipal Workers Back on Their Jobs, But City Is Facing More Labor Trouble
description: Striking bridge tenders and municipal employes returned to their jobs yesterday with the decision on their critical pen sion issue put off at least until the 1972 legislative session.

title: Insiders' Stockholdings
description: The American Stock Exchange yesterday issued its latest report on changes in stock ownership by director, officers and large stockholders among its listed companies. The New York Stock Exchange did not issue a list yesterday.

title: Eight Meet Marks Set in School Track
description: Vince Cartier, of Scotch Plains (N. J.) High School suf fered his first defeat in 24 ma jor races: eight meet records were set, and Dave Law of Snyder High of Jersey City ran a 46.7second leg on his mile relay team to highlight the 15th annual Eastern States Inter scholastic track championships yesterday.

title: CANARSIE BOYS PLAY SERENADE ON PIER
description: If Brooklyn seems an unlikely source for a bluegrass group, the Canarsie Bluegrass Boys are not apt to disillusion you. But although the Canarsie musicians offered a relatively pale reflec tion of their declared musical idiom on Tuesday evening at an al fresco concert on the deck of the Caviare at the South Street Seaport Pier, Fulton Street and East River, they showed a talent that moved in a different direction.

title: Costumes: Dying Business in Hollywood
description: LOS ANGELES, June 9 Another episode in the self destruction of Hollywood took place this week with a Sotheby ParkeBernet six session sale of 900 costumes from the film and theatrical costumers Max Berman and Sons, Inc.

title: Lansky's American Passport Is Reported Declared Invalid
description: TEL AVIV, June 9  The United States has informed Israel that the American pass port of Meyer Lansky, the reputed underworld financial leader, is no longer valid for, general use and travel, reliable sources said here today.

title: Continental Can Shifts Top Posts
description: A realignment of top manage ment will take place at the Continental Can Company, Inc., large packaging manufacturer, effective Aug. 1.

title: Brothers Who Threw Man From Roof Are Sentenced
description: Two brothers received prison sentences of 20 years to life yesterday in State Supreme Court in Queens for murdering a Housing Authority employe by throwing him from the roof of a sixstory building.

title: Voters in the Suburbs Ballot on Schools and Libraries
description: Voters considering school and library budgets went to the polls yesterday in communities in Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester and Rockland Counties.

title: Polaroid Sets Color Camera To Use a LowerCost Film
description: The Polaroid Corporation an nounced yesterday its intention to introduce a new camera and lowercost film that the com pany contended would produce instant color pictures for about the same price as color pictures from conventional cameras.

title: Goldwater Backs B1
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP)  Senator Barry Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, said to day that development of the B1 bomber was critical and vital to maintain the United States deterrent force. He challenged a report criticizing the airplane.

title: Decorum in the Court
description: NEW HAVENIt is a pity that the New Haven murderplus trial of Bobby Seale and his Panther partner, Ericka Hugginswhich ended with a hung jury and all charges dismissed by the judgecould not have come to its quiet close a short week earlier. Had it done so, it might have servedin light of the impeccable courtroom be havior, week after tense week, of the defendants, their attorneys, the prose cutor, and presiding Judge Mulvey as a shining example of what Warren E. Burger, Chief Justice of the United States, passionately pleaded for as he opened the annual meeting of the august American Law Institute in Washington with remarks on The Necessity for Civility.

title: JACK MORRIS
description: Jack Morris, a designer and creator of lighting fixtures, died, of cancer at his home on Mon day. He was 70 years old and lived at 8539 Avon Street, Jamaica Estates, Queens.

title: Court Upsets Breezy Point Condemnation Award
description: ALBANY, June 9The State Court of Appeals ordered a new trial today in the Breezy Point Park condemnation case and indicated that it considered the $39.7million award made two years ago too high.

title: Strides Are Seen in Taiwan Textile Talks
description: TAIPEI, Taiwan, June 9  Ambassador at Large David M. Kennedy said here today that we have made very great strides toward solving a num ber of economic issues, includ ing the textile issue.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: PEKING, June 9 (Agency FrancePresse)Foreign Minis ter Mirko Tepavac of Yugo slavia arrived here this morning by air at the start of a week long visit at the invitation of the Chinese Government.

title: TV: GreekBearing Britons Offer a Treat Tonight
description: The current Biography series on NET Playhouse has conic up with several outstanding 90minute seg ments in the last couple of months, and it is managing to do so once again with tonight's offering. At 8:30 the Public Broadcasting Serv ice, on Channel 13 in New York, will present Socrates, comprising two dramatiza tions from the dialogues of Plato. Plato? On television? Relax, it all works superbly.

title: MONITORS URGED FOR MISSISSIPPI
description: Three prominent lawyers urged Attorney General John N. Mitchell yesterday to send Federal reg??rars and observ ers into Mississippi to monitor the reregistration of voters and to adequately protect black and white voterregistration volunteers.

title: Worker Displacements Predicted by Kosygin
description: MOSCOW, June 9  Pre mier Aleksei N. Kosygin prob ably shocked many Musco vites today when he told them that under current plans, about a third of Mos cow's 1.35 million workers would be forced to take new jobs in the next four years.

title: Mets Sink Padres, 42, and Lead in East
description: After leaving 12 men on base in seven innings without scor ing a run, the New York Mets broke through for four runs in the eighth inning at Shea Sta dium last night, and wound up with a 42 victory over the San Diego Padres.

title: Head of Cable TV Unit Resigns
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) Donald V. Taverner resigned yesterday as president of the National Cable Television Asso ciation, effective Dec. 31. The association said Mr. Taverner submitted his resignation at a board meeting. No reason was given.

title: Meskill Calls Special Assembly Session
description: HARTFORD, Thursday, June 10Moments after mandatory adjournment of the Connecticut General Assembly last mid night, Gov. Thomas J. Meskill called for a special legislative session to resolve the state's snarled fiscal affairs.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: BUNDESBANK HOLDS TO PRESENT COURSE
description: BONN, June 9 (UPI)The Bundesbank decided today that no new measures were imme diately necessary to deal with West Germany's monetary problems.

title: Vote on Sugar Act Set
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI) The House Rules Committee set the stage today for a yes or no vote tomorrow on threeyear extension of the Sugar Quota Law. Under the terms of the committee's ac tion, unless the House defeats the rule, the sugar act legisla tion will be subjected to three hours of debate but no amend ments will be permitted.

title: Kosygin Terms U.S. Aggressive
description: MOSCOW. June 9Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin accused the Nixon Administration today of following an aggressive pol icy in foreign affairs that he said was blocking any improve ment in SovietAmerican rela tions.

title: N.C.A.A. Upgrades Temple To the University Division
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 9 (AP) The National Collegiate Ath letic Association has granted Temple University's request for university division classification in football, Athletic Director Ernie Casale said today.

title: New Drive in South Vietnam
description: SAIGON South Vietnam, Thursday, June 10 (AP)Sai gon headquarters announced yesterday that 2,000 to 2,500 South Vietnamese infantrymen, rangers and armored cavalry man began a sweep Tuesday 25 miles south of Pleiku in the Central Highlands.

title: Abrams Plans Touring Office
description: Criticizing what he termed the unresponsive nature of city government, Bronx Borough President Robert Abrams an nounced yesterday that he would begin operating a mobile office to communicate with residents. Starting next week, the bus is to tour all sections of the borough from 9 A.M. to 4 P.M. on Tuesday and Thurs days. Residents' complaints will go to Mr. Abrams or to appro priate public agencies.

title: Western Maryland Payout
description: The Western Maryland Rail way, controlled by the Chesa peake & OhioBaltimore & Ohio system, cut its quarterly divi dend yesterday to 20 cents a share from 40 cents. The re duced dividend will be payable June 30 to holders of record June 18. The reduction, the company said, was made to conserve working capital be cause of reduced earnings.

title: Rogers and Aichi Report Final Agreement on Okinawa Treaty
description: PARIS, June 9Secretary of State William P. Rogers and Kiichi Aichi, the Japanese For eign Minister, announced today final agreement on the terms of a treaty to return Okinawa and other islands of the Ryukyu chain to Japanese Sov ereignty. They said they would sign the accord on June 17.

title: Man in the News
description: LONDON, June 9  Prince Philip celebrates his 50th birthday tomorrow, a royal figure seeking to blend the traditions of the monarchy with the demands of contem porary Britain.

title: Knowles and Wright Tie, Forcing Playoff in Golf
description: RYE, N. Y., June 9Jim Knowles of Greenwich, Conn., and William Wright of Clemen ton, N. J., tied at 150 today in the 67th annual United States Seniors Golf Association cham pionship. They will play off over 18 holes tomorrow morn ing here at the Apawamis Club for the title.

title: U.S. Says Israeli Projects Violate a Geneva Accord
description: WASHINGTON, June 9The State Department said today that Israel had violated the 1949 Geneva convention by building large apartment projects in the former Jordanian sector of Jerusalem.

title: Bill to Assist Brown U.
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP)  Legislation that could pm vide Brown University with 2.5million to help finance con version of its twoyear medical education program to a four year medical school was ap proved yesterday by the Health subcommittee of the Senate.

title: EARNINGS LAG HITS BUILDING MATERIALS
description: Profits of 62 large manufac turers of building materials were off 16 per cent in the first quarter of 1971 from their prof it level of last year, according to a compilation by the F. W. Dodge division of McGrawHill, Inc.

title: Tristar Delivery to Start in '72
description: LONDON, June 9 (AP)Lock heed announced here today that the first 12 of its Tristar airbuses would be delivered to United States airlines in June, 1972.

title: Beliveau Closes Career; Sawchuk in Hall of Fame
description: MONTREAL, June 9 (AP) Jean Beliveau, the center and captain of the Montreal Cana diens, considered one of the greatest players of all time, announced his retirement today after 18 seasons.

title: Six Silver Nations To Meet in Mexico On Sagging Prices
description: MEXICO CITY, June 9  Mexico has called a meeting of the world's principal silver pro ducers to consider joint action to increase and stabilize sag ging silver prices.

title: Ceylon Schools, Shut in April By Revolt, Are Reopened
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, June 9 Ceylon's schools reopened to day after having been closed since the first week of April because of guerrilla insurgency. The army believes the uprising is now under control.

title: GRAEBNER, SMITH VICTORS IN TENNIS
description: BECKENHAM, England, June 8 (AP)Clark Graebner of New York and Stan Smith and Jim McManus of California ad vanced today to the quarter finals of the Kent grass tennis tournament today. But Tom Gorman of Seattle was beaten.

title: New Director Is Elected At International Paper
description: The election of Arthur R. Taylor as a director of the International Paper Company was announced yesterday by Paul A. Gorman, chairman and president. Mr. Taylor, who is 35 years old, is an ex ecutive vice president and chief financial officer of the company.

title: Chess: The Manhattan Championship Won by Arthur Feuerstein
description: Arthur Feuerstein, a com puter programmer by profes sion and for a long time now one of America's leading masters, has won the cham pionship of the Manhattan Chess Club with a score of 83. Dr. Orest Popovych was second, a full point be hind, and. Dr. Neil McKelvie third. Popovych and Mc Kelvie are both professors of chemistry, Popovych at Brooklyn College, McKelvie at CCNY.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: WHO Is Harry Kellerman and why is he saying those terrible things about metAdvt.

title: $108 Tag on Tougher Ford Bumpers
description: DETROIT, June 9The Ford Motor Company contends that new damageresistant bumpers on its cars will add $108 to the retail price, apparently far more than car owners would save from lowered insurance rates.

title: Muskie's RevenueSharing Plan Praised
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 (AP) Members of the House Ways and Means Committee told Sen ator Edmund S. Muskie today that his general revenuesharing plan was an improvement over President Nixon's. But there was no sign that a committee majority was ready to approve either.

title: Smith Is Ordered Back to Prison
description: NEWARK, June 9With the deadline for Edgar H. Smith Jr.'s freedom only an hour away, a Federal appeals court today threw out a Federal Court order that had granted his re lease in $5,000 bail.

title: VICTOR LEBOW
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., June 9Victor Lebow, presi dent of Lebow Brothers, New York clothing manufacturer, died yesterday in Good Samari tan Hospital. He was 60 years gold and lived at 170 East 79th Street.

title: ISRAEL ASKS U.S. FOR NEW ARMS AID
description: JERUSALEM. June 9  Pre nier Golda Meir called on the United States today for prompt and farreaching pledges of new aircraft and advanced arma ments for Israel, to balance the military commitments made by the Soviet Union to Egypt last month.

title: WILLIAM O'CONNELL, CIVIL COURT JUDGE
description: MERCED, Calif., June 9 William T. O'Connell, judge of the New York Civil court, died here yesterday of a heart at tack while on a visit to his daughter, Mrs. Therese C. Colleran. He was 69 years old and lived at 440 East 23d Street, New York.

title: The Talk of Pine Bluff
description: PINE BLUFF, Ark., June 8 By some evolution that no one considers it necessary to explain, Foti's Feed and Seed Store has become locally fa mous over the years for sell ing not only feed and seed but also Italian spaghetti and the coldest beer in town. Foti's double lunch counter, standing imperti nently among young tomato plants and sacks of fertilizer, is one of the city's popular gathering places each noon for lawyers and bankers fresh from their air conditioned offices nearby and for laborers fresh, if that is the word, from the cotton fields, pine woods and paper mills that begin at the perimeter of the city.

title: Klein Seeks G.O.P. Nomination For Post of Suffolk Executive
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., June 9 Expressing Concern over a spiraling welfare budget, John V. N. Klein, presiding officer of the Suffolk County Legisla ture, today became the first politician formally to announce his candidacy for Suffolk Coun ty Executive.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Chase Manhat tan Bank announced yes terday the appointment of James W. North as executive vice president and chief of its trust de partment. In his new po sition, Mr. North, who is 47 years old, will be responsible for the ad ministration of Chase's sprawling fiduciary op eration, which has been entrusted with roughly $15 billion in assets. James M. Lane, who is already an executive vice president of the bank, will continue to head the group which has respon sibility for investing these funds.

title: Yonkers City Council Backs Offtrack Betting
description: YONKERS, June 9The Yonkers City Council voted unanimously last night to authorize the city to estab lish offtrack betting. Mayor Alfred DelBello said this morning he hoped a system could be in operation within two or three months.

title: CON ED GRANTED $62MILLION RISE
description: ALBANY, June 9The Public Service Commission authorized the Consolidated Edison Com pany today to increase tem porarily its electricity rates to bring it $52million a year in additional revenue.

title: PIANISTS TEAM UP IN TULLY SAMPLER
description: The nice thing about the piano Is that any number up to three, at least, can play it at the same time. This possi bility was demonstrated in the Tully Hall Sampler concert given on Tuesday night. A pro gram entitled Piano Music for One to Six Hands was per formed by John Ryan and Mar shall Williamson, pianists of Metropolitan Opera Studio, and Judith Alstadter.

title: Francesco Giunta, 84, Is Dead; Secretary General to Mussolini
description: ROME, June 9 (AP)Fran cesco Giunta, who was secre tary general of the Fascist party when Benito Mussolini became Premier in 1923, died yesterday in a hospital after long illness. He was 84 years old.

title: Pot and Kettle
description: The almost simultaneous creation by the state's Repub lican leadership and by Mayor Lindsay of commissions to investigate each other's domain has the ring of one upmanship. Anyone who has followed the affairs of the city's or the state's government will readily concede that expert analysis of the problems and ineptitudes of either could produce an epic volume of suggestions for improve ment. In the recent legislative session, none of the participantsGovernor, Mayor, City Council or the lead ers of either partyemerged with an enhanced reputation for responsibility and wisdom.

title: DARTMOUTH PITCHER FIRST PICK IN DRAFT
description: Pete Broberg, who turned down $175,000 from the Oak land Athletics in 1968 when he was a senior in high school, was selected No. 1 by the Washington Senators here yes terday in the secondary phase of baseball's summer draft. He is expected to sign a generous contract soon, although he still has a year of eligibility left as a pitcher at Dartmouth College.

title: Computer Sciences Contract
description: Under a new contract an nounced yesterday, the Com puter Sciences Corporation will continue to provide mission support services to the com putation laboratory at the Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Ala. The con tract will have a total value of about $20million over threeyear period, with the first year's funding expected to exceed $6million.

title: Morrow's Western, 'A Man Called Sledge,' Opens
description: "How much gold?""Enough for a man to die on: More than that, maybe." Thus the subject and the theme are indicated very early on in Vic Morrow's "A Man Called Sledge," which isn't quite an Italian western (Morrow and most of his leading cast are, of course, Americans) though it was produced in Italy, and though it has in common with many Italian westerns that it cares mostly about its theme and not so much about the people or the places or the sociology or the mythic potential of the old American West.All of which leads to a certain abstractness in movies like "A Man Called Sledge," and though, one may add, a certain purity as well, the end result is really a certain dullnessfor no universal theme can, taken by itself, make up for the people and the places and even the mythic potential that might find their way into any less single-minded fiction.The gold in question is part of a regular shipment sent from the mine in an armed convoy so cautious that it travels only by day, and by night holes up in such unfortunate hiding places as the maximum security cell block of a prison where Sledge (James Garner), guided by The Old Man (John Marley), takes his band of outlaws to steal it. They do, and then set about learning the bitter lesson  more convincing in literature than in life  that gold cannot buy happiness and the wages of sin is death.That really is the point to "A Man Called Sledge," and it is not such an interesting point that a very good movie can come from it despite Mr. Morrow's fancy directing and destiny-driven dialogue. I should say that at almost any given moment "A Man Called Sledge" is a bit better than most Italian westerns and quite a bit better than many recent American westerns  and that it is still not good enough to satisfy the demands of its type.In a movie so given to decorative technique and to purple patches at one level or another, it may seem unfair to pick and choose. But I was especially taken with two sequences. One involves the mounted troops guarding the goldwho at the sound of a horn take up a variety of fancy formations that do more to recall the Spanish Riding School than the Old Frontier, but that are nevertheless fun to watch. The other is the final shoot-outin a deserted, sun-baked Mexican town full of menacing alleys and meaningful junctures. This is not so much a film location as symbolic space, and one need only squint through politically colored glasses to see it in the form of the radical didactic cinema of Glauber Rocha.

title: Columbia Paper Retains Tax Status in U.S. Ruling
description: WASHINGTON, June 9The Internal Revenue Service an nounced today that it had decided, after a twoyear re view, to allow Columbia Uni versity's student newspaper, The Daily Spectator, to keep its taxexempt status.

title: Article 5  No Title
ANGELS TOP YANKS ON RUN IN 9TH, 43
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., June 9 Billy Cowan and Tony Gon zalez, two leftfielders play ing in place of the benched Alex Johnson, beat the Yankees for the California Angels, 43, tonight.

description: Former President Lyndon B. Johnson presented an award here last night to Mrs. Mary Lasker for dedication to the cause of cancer con trol.

title: EDWARD P. STREET SR.
description: MALVERN, Pa., June 9Ed ward P. Street Sr., retired ad ministrator of the Phoenixville Hospital, died apparently of a heart attack on Monday. He was 74 years old and lived on Union Hill Road.

title: Senate Votes to Curb Drug Traffic and Treat Addicts in Services
description: WASHINGTON, June 9  The Senate approved an amendment to the draft bill to day that would require the armed forces to identify drug addicts and to offer them treat ment and rehabilitation.

description: To the Editor:

Supreme Court Justice Thomas J. Hughes performed the cere mony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Charles Ebel, brotherinlaw and sister of the bride.

title: Market Place:
description: Will the trustbusters let New Jersey's fourthlargest banking organization swal low the biggest bank in the bedroom community of Englewood?

title: NEW UNITS AT ARROW AIDING SHIRT OUTPUT
description: The Arrow Company, a divi sion of Cluett, Peabody & Co., Inc., has introduced a numerical control principle for manu facturing men's shirts that it says cuts sewing time by 8 per cent and produces garments of continuously consistent quality.

title: When He Took Off the Paint and Paper, the Wall Collapsed, Too
description: Even by moonlight, that sagging pile of brick and clapboard in a yard between a row of tenements and a garage on the West Side looked like a sagging pile of brick and clapboard.

title: Ronan, at Transit Parley, Says Rider Is Neglected
description: MEXICO CITY, June 9The ordinary passenger who asks nothing more than a safe, comfortable, reliable and mod erately priced ride has been forgotten by the rapid transit industry, Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of New York State's Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said here today.

title: The Okinawa Accord
description: It took 18 months of hard bargaining to hammer out the agreement on Okinawa that was finally concluded in Paris yesterday by Secretary of State Rogers and Japanese Foreign Minister Aichi. The most difficult hur dle for this essential development in United StatesJapa nese relations may still lie ahead if the Administration persists in its plan to submit the pact as a treaty, requir ing a twothirds Senate vote, rather than as an executive agreement which would require at most a majority vote in both houses of Congress.

title: Apaches in New Mexico Build A Resort and a Proud Image
description: MESCALERO INDIAN RES ERVATION, N. M.In the shadow of their sacred moun tain, which they have devel oped into a booming ski re sort, the Mescalero Apaches are building a sprawling play ground for the white man and a fat bank account for their tribe.

title: Capping the Spiral
description: After a disappointing start, President Nixon's con struction stabilization panel is showing some com mendable resolution in its fight on the wageprice spiral. The panel has refused to approve a contract calling for a 51 per cent wage increase over two years for Phila delphia painters.

description: Water pressure in the city has just about returned to the normal range of 35 to 60 pounds a square inch after dropping Tuesday to a low of 10 pounds in some areas, City Water Resources Department officials reported yesterday.

description: COLORADO SPRINGS, June 9Vice President Agnew told the 685 cadets graduating from the Air Force Academy today, Aggression historically has been halted only by the sword, or a convincing willingness to use it.

description: The municipal workers' strikes in New York City in the last few days have offered classic examples of what is wrong with the way in which con temporary Americans are trying to operate their society. It may he the richest and the most advanced tech nological society in history, but late twentiethcentury America is some thing of a political mess.

description: HOUSTON, June 9 (Reuters) An explosion in the engine room of the Danish freighter Michigan killed one crew mem ber and critically burned an other at a dock here tonight.

title: 4 Cubans Convicted
description: KEY WEST, Fla., June 9 (UPI)Four young Cuban fish ing captains were found guilty today of violating United States waters. They were sentenced to six months in jail and fined $10,000 each.

title: NEIGHBORS ASSAIL PLAN FOR TOWER

title: Voters at Shattuck Denn Defeat a Dissident Move

description: MINNEAPOLIS President Nixon has said he wants to see the May and June economic returns before deciding on tax cut speedups and other fiscal stimulants. But there's already a wealth of evidence that says: Why wait?
