description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, June 10 (AP)Eco nomics Minister Pham Kim Ngoc announced today that 160,000squaremile area off the coast of South Vietnam was now officially open for petroleum exploration and ex ploitation.

title: Divided Corona, Foiled on Horne Compromise, United Only in Anger
description: Men and women who have been friends and neighbors in the Corona section of Queens, and who fought to gether to save their homes, screamed insults at one an other yesterday along, the treelined streets where they, their children and even grandchildren nave grown up.

title: Duryea Is Emerging As New State Power
description: ALBANY June 9Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea, who emerged from the 1971 legis lative session as a major polit ical figure in the state, declared in an interview today that the heavy budgetcutting and fiscal retrenchment during the ses sion was not a oneyear phe nomenon but would continue indefinitely.

title: Moon Robot on the Move
description: MOSCOW, June 9 (UPI) The Soviet Union's Lunokhod moon robot crossed 1,500 feet of rugged terrain on the lunar Sea of Rains in its latest jour ney, the press agency Tass said today. The eightwheel robot began moving northeasterly across the surface last night, Tass said. It has covered al most six miles since it was landed on the moon Nov. 17 by the Luna 17 spaceship.

title: Sanford Greenburger, 67, Dies; Publishers' and Writers' Agent
description: Sanford Jerome Greenburger, a prominent literary agent and foreign publishers' representa tive, died yesterday in his home, 30 Park Avenue, at the age of 67.

description: You have this feeling of Jewish consciousness, sort of that Israel is the place where it's happening, said Mrs. Lea Wiener, a darkhaired, 24 yearold American woman with a smiling face. You want to be involved In the mainstream. You want to be part of Jewish history.

title: Bristol Washed Out
description: BRISTOL, England, June 8 (UPI)Rain washed out play on the third day of the $48,000 Wills open grass tennis tourna ment today.

title: Screen: Human Ferocity
description: There is this to be said for "The Deserter," a tough, scroungy English-language western made in Spain, with blood spurring like catchup. The picture is a solid, graphic job by Hollywood professionals that holds interest all the way.The deserter is an Army captain, shattered by the Apache's horrible mutilation of his wife (an opening that will chill you), who takes to the old Southwest hills as a one-man Indian butcher. The story shifts gears. The Army now uses him to mastermind a patrol trek deep into Apache territory.The real star of the picture is the screen writer, Clair Huffaker, trimly etching character and building suspense on the trail, with scorching dialogue spewed by a good, bristling male cast. It's hard to believe but Bekim Fehmiu, having survived a marshmallow blob titled "The Adventurers," is excellent as the deserter, toughest and meanest of the snarling pack.John Huston is wonderfully effective as an earthy Army general. Let's forgive him for "Myra Breckenridge" here and now. The other iron-jaws are fine, especially Albert Salmi and Woody Strode. And encompassing it all, in a sun-baked, craggy sweep of color, is the steady, keen-edged direction of Burt Kennedy.For all the mayhem, this picture graphically equates human ferocity with an irony just as terrible, never spelling it out.

title: McGee Gains Open Berth
description: PINEHURST, N. C., June 9 (AP)  Jerry McGee of Lake Worth, Fla. claimed the last place available for next week's, United States Open golf tourna ment with a suddendeath play off victory today over Ralph Baker of Oklahoma City on the fifth hole of the No. 2 course at the Pinehurst Country Club.

Farm of Florida part of a combination dealing with Pedro Baptista, the Vene zuelan metals executive who owns the winner of the Ken tucky Derby and the Preakness Stakes.

description: ANAHEIM, Calif., June 9 Alex Johnson hasn't been in the California Angels' lineup since last Friday. He may never be in the California lineup againunless the An gels can't find a team willing to try to solve baseball's No. 1 mystery.

title: MISS NISKA SOLOIST; TONES ARE EXCITING.
description: Illness caused Maralin Niska to miss her appearance as soloist in the New York Phil harmonic's Promenade Ro mantique last Friday, but she recovered in time to sing in the repetition of the program on Tuesday. One of the New York City Opera's leading so pranos, she did not disappoint her listeners in VillaLobos's Bachianas Brasileiras No. 5 or the Vocalise and two songs of Rachmaninoff. Her voice seems to have acquired more warmth in recent years, and she poured out tones that were luscious and exciting.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:In his thoughtful letter concerning the extraordinarily vulnerable posi tion of the draft, Dr. George Margolis raises questions of equity and the un witting vectoring of forces toward genasthenia or race weakening.

description: Merchants from around the nation were warned here yes terclay by a top J. C. Penney Company executive that they have a major credibility prob lem on service charges for credit sales.

title: Prime Minister Lee Says He Curbs Press to Preserve Peace in Singapore
description: HELSINKI, June 9Freedom of the press must he subordi nated to the special security, needs and sensitivities of Singa pore, Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew said today.

title: Savings Deposits Rise $2.7  Billion To Record in May
description: Deposits at the nation's thrift institutions scored a record net increase of $2.7billion during May, according to trade re ports published yesterday.

title: Bridge: Mrs. Stayman Shows Talent As a Player and Arranger
description: Two of New York's leading bridge citizens, Sam and Tubby Stayman, once crossed the Atlantic on an Italian ship with a bridgeplaying captain. Maneuvered by his wife into playing with the captain, Stayman courteously inquired what system his partner favored.

title: 2d Yablonski Case Suspect Extradited to Pennsylvania
description: WASHINGTON, Pa., June 9 (AP)A suspect in the slayings of Joseph A. Yablonski, the United Mine Workers insurgent leader, was extradited tonight from Ohio to Pennsylvania.

title: Zany Role for George Scott:' They Might Be Giants' Opens at Beekman
description: Some kinds of sentiment are as lethal as carbon monoxide. When, near the beginning of "They Might Be Giants," George C. Scott, as a once-brilliant, now lunatic New York judge, who believes he's Sherlock Holmes, meets Joanne Woodward, a spinsterish psychiatrist whose name is Dr. Watson, my toes tingled, then imperceptibly curled. The sensation was not entirely unpleasant.A little later, the couple encounter a small colony of eccentrics who have escaped the real world by taking refuge in the balcony of a movie theater that shows only Westerns. Holmes tells Watson she should try to smile. She does. The patient cures the doctorand my balance became uncertain. My ears buzzed.Still later, Holmes, accompanied by Watson, who is now in love with him, comes upon a nutty old pair who have found love and peace sculpturing shrubbery, holed up in a Front Street loft since 1939. The initial sense of odd intoxication had turned into acute discomfort. I almost blacked outlike a canary in a badly ventilated coal mine."They Might Be Giants," which opened yesterday in the air-conditioned Beekman Theater, is an almost drunkenly sentimental comedy about the lazy capitulation of the sanes to the old-fashioned crazies, a romantic concept that not only needs the skills of a director like Frank Capra and a writer like Robert Riskin, but also an audience whose sensibilities are about 35 years more naive than can be easily faked today.There is, indeed, something not so innocently simple-minded in this fable, which enobles retreat in the name of the sort of mysticism with which the Duchess of Windsor, once explained the downfall of an emperor. "The heart," she wrote at some length, without saying very much, "has its reasons.""They Might Be Giants," directed by Anthony Harvey and written by James Goldman, who earlier collaborated on "A Lion in Winter," is a mushy movie with occasional, isolated moments of legitimate comedy, all provided by Mr. Scott with an assist by Mr. Goldman, whose sense of humor seems to surface in peripheral incidents only.There is something pixilatedand I use the word advisedlyin the sight of Mr. Scott, dressed in his cape and his deerstalker, trying to teach Miss Woodward, who is supposed to sign his commitment papers, how to "creep" properly along a crowded New York sidewalk.There is another moment of decent madness when Holmes invades the offices of the New York Telephone Company, and leaves at least one operator in tears. But this scene, like the entire movie, eventually goes soft, which seems to be the fate of comediesthings like "The Madwoman of Chaillot"  that prattle on about the joys of individualism and demonstrate mostly witless arrogance.A common denominator of all of Mr. Scott's performances is the sense of mad possession of the actor by his role, and this gives the movie a certain strength denied by the lines Mr. Goldman has written for him"The earth is shining under the soot!" cries Holmes in an apocalyptic moment toward the end. Miss Woodward acts as straight-woman to her costar, and most of the other actors are distressingly cute.

title: Time for a New Start
description: The precipitate retreat of striking city employes in the face of the state's refusal to be blackmailed could mark the start of a constructive new phase in civil serv ice labor relations.

title: Kubelik Appointed Met Music Director
description: Rafael Kubelik, the 56year old Czechoslovak conductor, has been named music director of the Metropolitan Opera, the first in the history of the com pany. His threeyear contract will begin with the 197374 season.

title: Goodell Warns Graduates Of Simplistic Thinking
description: Former United States Sena tor Charles E. Goodell told 746 graduates at Staten Island Community College yesterday that the younger generation could not just wave a banner and change the world.

title: ARTHUR PRICE DIES; LED PAPER CONCERN
description: GREAT NECK, L.I., June 9 Arthur Price, president since 1953 of the Pennsylvania Gen eral Paper Corporation and long prominent in retail advertising, died yesterday in North Shore Hospital after a short illness. He was 70 years old and lived at 9 Highland Avenue.

title: Shop Talk
description: Six years ago, Fred Bill ingsley, a boutique owner, had an idea. Why not collect and then resell secondhand bluejeans? Mr. Billingsley and his four partners pursued the suggestion, and now their en deavor has turned into a $1,000aweek business. Blue jean recycling, as one of the partners called it, is a wellorgan ized operation. Martin Friedman, another partner, explained that the source of old jeans is a friend known only as Roland, a pro fessional cowboy who travels the rodeo circuits in the West and Southwest. He has the women out there saving blue jeans for him, and once a month he sends us 200 or 300 pairs, Mr. Friedman said. When the jeans arriveat Limbo, at 4 St. Marks Place they are sent to laundries before being sold at the shop and four other boutiques.

title: Advertising:
description: Navy Recruiting will be pulling out of Young & Rubi cam, Chicago, after a four year stay and tying up at Grey Advertising. Surely you've heard of Battleship Grey?

title: UNITE ON RENTS, TENANTS URGED
description: Tenant representatives were urged yesterday by Harold Zucker, counsel to the State Division of Housing and Com munity Renewal, to form coun cils to screen complaints of harassment involving landlords of rentcontrolled apartments.

title: The Crimes of the Fathers
description: JERUSALEMOn my desk before me there are the faces of seven chil dren: serious, smiling, contemplative and one who as yet understands noth ing.

title: EDITOR'S TV DISPUTE LINKED TO BALDWIN
description: Shlomo Katz, editor of Mid stream, a monthly Jewish re view, charged yesterday that he had been taken off The David Frost Show at the last minute because another guest, James Baldwin, objected.

title: 21,000 POLICEMEN FACING CITY FINES IN JANUARY STRIKE
description: The city found 21,000 mem bers of its police force in vio lation of the Taylor Law for their walkout last January and announced yesterday that they would be fined two days' pay for each day of absence and placed on probation for a year.

title: Daniel Berrigan Suffers Spell and Enters Hospital
description: DANBURY, Conn., June 9 (AP)The Rev. Daniel J. Ber rigan, the imprisoned antiwar priest, was taken from the Federal prison here to the Dan bury Hospital today, prison of ficials said.

title: U.S. Generals Shifted
description: DANANG, South Vietnam, June 9 (AP)Lieut. Gen. Wel born G. Dolvin assumed com mand today of all American forces in the northern provinces of South Vietnam. He replaces Lieut. Gen. James W. Suther land Jr., who has been named chief of staff of the United States European Command.

title: Sports of The Times
description: SOUTH ORANGE, N. J.In a treeshaded suburban garden on a street of expensive homes, the Overprivileged Boys Club held its seventh annual graduation party here last Sunday. TwoTon Tony Galento was an honored guest, one of a hundred men, women and children on folding wood en chairs in a circle around the 18 graduates, who were in traditional garbheadguards, mouthpieces and 16ounce gloves. The ceremonies included nine bouts, two one minute rounds each. The oldest to receive a diploma was 15, the youngest 6.

title: ALFREDO LUIZZI
description: BELMAR, N. J., June 9  Alfredo Luizzi, president of A. N. Brabrook, Inc., a New York manufacturer of safety mats, died today at his home of anemia. He was 59 years old and lived at 406 Tenth Avenue.

title: A Protest Over Crowding Empties a Bronx School
description: No classes were held yester day at Adlai Stevenson High School in the northeastern Bronx because the teachers and students were picketing the Board of Education in Brook lyn.

title: Money In Politics
description: The bill to regulate the spending of money in Federal elections continues its tortuous progress through the Senate. The Rules Committee has significantly weakened the bill in one respect and strengthened it in two others. The weakening provision would have the effect of doubling the amounts which candidates could spend on radio and television, permitting an expenditure of $13.9 million next year for electronic advertising, more than was spent for this purpose by the NixonAgnew ticket in 1968. A low ceiling is desirable to keep voters from being swamped by saturation campaign advertising on television.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE DRIFTERS. By James A. Michener. 751 pages. Random House. $10.

title: For African Sculpture, A Jewel Box of a Show
description: Pending construction of galleries to house its collec tion of primitive art, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has initiated a twoyear ser ies of four exhibitions of black African sculpture in a ccswerted gallery on the main floor. The opener is a jewel box of a show of bronzes and carvings from Nigeria and the Cameroon grasslands.

title: Harold Lloyd Jr. Dies; Actor, Son of Comedy Star
description: NORTH HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 9 (UPI)Harold Lloyd Jr., son of the late silentscreen comedian, died at a sanitarium here last night. The catise was not disclosed.

title: Article 3  No Title
DOW OFF BY 2.55 AS TRADING RISES
description: The stock market meandered through another listless session yesterday and closed lower. A midmorning attempt at a rally fizzled and the market sagged in the afternoon.

title: ALBANY BILL ASKS A PENSIONS STUDY
description: ALBANY, June 9  At the request of Governor Rockefell er and Republican leaders here, the Legislature has authorized a sweeping investigation and study of pension and retirement systems for public employes throughout the state.

title: Drug Sentence Reduced
description: TRENTON, June 9 (UPI) An appeals court ruled today that the state's threeyear mini mum sentence for drug offend ers was excessive in the case of a young man convicted for having just a little piece of hashish. The Superior Court's Appellate Division reduced the sentence of Richard Yuhasz of Passaic to IS months on proba tion.

title: 6 POINTS SHELLED NEAR PNOMPENH
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Thursday, June 10 (AP) Enemy forces attacking the eastern defenses of Pnompenh reportedly poured rocket and mortar fire yesterday into four Cambodian strongpoints within 12 miles of this capital.

title: Evening of Tricks Completes Program Of Cubiculo Dances
description: An Evening of Card Tricks and Dances at the Cubiculo Tuesday offered a wistfully beautiful solo choreographed and danced by Aileen Passloff among the seven works pre sented. The piece, A Dream Under a Black Hat, was full of reflective pauses and en chanting bursts of activity.

title: BUCKLEY SEEKING CURB ON LAWYERS
description: WASHINGTON, June 9  Irked that New York Bar of ficials have not disbarred Wil liam M. Kunstler for his con duct in and out of court, Sena tor James L. Buckley asked Congress today to authorize the Justice Department to prosecute disbarment charges against lawyers.

title: Personal Finance: TaxFree Bonds
description: For those who hate to pay taxes there is a way out. Apparently more and more middleincome people are thinking about itnamely taxexempt bonds.

title: Ralph Bunche in Comn
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 9 (Reuters)Under Sec retary General Ralph J. Bunche was reported today to have lapsed into a coma. The 66 yearold Dr. Bunche has been in New York Hospital for more than a week for treatment of complications resulting from a fall at his home.

title: THOMAS P. FOWLER, A STOCKBROKER, 75
description: Thomas Powell Fowler, who formed the New York Stock Exchange firm of Fowler & Rosenau in 1950, died Tuesday at the Harkness Pavilion of ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center of complications follow ing surgery. He was 75 years old and lived at 325 East 72d Street and at Boca Grande, Fla.

title: INVESTIGATION IS SET ON ANTIWAR OFFICER
description: LONDON. June 9  The United States Air Force an nounced today it would con duct a formal investigation into the conduct of Capt. Thomas S. Culver, the legal officer who took part in an antiwar protest in London on May 31.

title: Economic Analysis
description: When Prof. Robert S. Browne of Fairleigh Dickinson University proposed last week that American blacks seek loans for economic development from Japan, the World Bank, the United Nations and the Soviet Union, 600 black busi nessmen and economists cheered him enthusiastically. But later, when several prominent black economic theorists caucused in a suite at the PickCongress Ho tel in Chicago, they could not agree on how, or whether, the economics professor's idea could be pursued.

title: INQUIRY INTO CITY GETS WIDE POWER
description: ALBANY, June 9The Tem porary State Commission to In vestigate the Governmental Op erations of New York City, which was established early this morning by the Legislature, will have some of the broad est powers of any legislative commission in recent history.

title: BOUTTIER OUTPOINTS DURAN, TAKES TITLE
description: PARIS, June 9The educa tion of JeanClaude Bouttier, boxer, continued tonight and when the lesson was over, the pupil had become the European middleweight champion. The 26yearold former butcher, who received much of his previous education in American gym nasiums, admitted he learned a lot tonight from Carlo Duran, an Argentineborn Italian.

title: Vote on Sugar Act Set
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI) The House Rules Committee set the stage today for a yes or no vote tomorrow on threeyear extension of the Sugar Quota Law. Under the terms of the committee's ac tion, unless the House defeats the rule, the sugar act legisla tion will be subjected to three hours of debate but no amend ments will be permitted.

title: Testing Pill That Tricks Taste Buds
description: One of the least frightening items in the United States Army's experi mental arsenal is a small red berry the size of a Spanish peanut. Not part of any biological warfare program, the miracle fruit, as it is referred to by the scientists doing research on it at the Army's labs in Natick, Mass., and elsewhere around the country, is gen tle dynamite.

title: AMEX PRICES FALL 3D DAY IN A ROW
description: Prices and volume on the American Stock Exchange eased yesterday for the third consecutive session.

title: Goldman Band Begins Park Concerts June 23
description: The Goldman Band will open its 54th season of free Guggenheim Memorial Con certs in city parks at Dam rosch Park, Lincoln Center, on June 23. The 180voice AllCity High School Chorus will appear with the 54piece band in a program played under the direction of Rich ard Franko Goldman, con ductor, and Ainslee Cox, as sociate conductor.

title: 2 CONCERNS RAISE CHEMICAL PRICES
description: PPG Industries, Inc., an nounced yesterday that it would raise prices for trichlor ethylene, a metal cleaning sol vent used widely in industrial processes, by one cent a pound.

title: CORN FUTURES UP ON BLIGHT REPORT
description: A report from the University of Illinois that corn blight has been identified in 15 Illinois counties, with the prospect that other areas are affected, sent corn futures up yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Upstate Biology Professor, Thinking Like a Bird, Breeds the Rare Peregrine Falcon in Captivity
description: NEW PALTZ, N. Y., June 9 A peregrine falcon has been successfully bred in captivity by a biology professor who said he had accomplished the feat by thinking like a bird.

title: Mitchell Declares Courts Overstress Rights of Accused
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI) Attorney General John N. Mitchell said today that the Administration was trying to restore fairness to the court room, which he said had suf fered because of preoccupation with fairness for the accused.

title: Vote on Sugar Act Set
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI) The House Rules Committee set the stage today for a yes or no vote tomorrow on threeyear extension of the Sugar Quota Law. Under the terms of the committee's ac tion, unless the House defeats the rule, the sugar act legisla tion will be subjected to three hours of debate but no amend ments will be permitted.

title: Advertising:
description: In San Francisco town, edu cational television station KQED has a reputation for imaginative fund raising. With the June 12 issue of The New Yorker, that repu tation will spread.

title: OBSERVER
description: It's Junebride time again, the soci ety pages remind us, as we sit in the shade of the horse chestnut tree and read happily, half asleep. Through our halfdoze, we are smiling pleasurably. Who says the newspapers have to lead to suicide? Just close your eyes and read, as follows:

title: SUMMER PLAN GIVEN BY BALLET THEATER
description: American Ballet Theater will present one premiere, two new productions, two revivals and a new staging in its summer season at the State Theater from June 29 through Aug. 8. Michael Denard, a principal with the Paris Opera Ballet, will appear with the company during the sixweek engage ment.

title: U. S. Investigating Lansky's Crime Web
description: More than 70 men are cur rently under investigation by a special Justice Department task force set up to examine the web of alliances and business dealings of Meyer Lansky, the organized crime leader now liv ing in Israel.

title: Article 8  No Title
UNICEF Issues Appeal
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 9The head of the United Nations Children's Fund is making a worldwide plea for immediate assistance to ref ugees from East Pakistan.

title: Humphrey Says Nixon Shuns Politics on War
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI)  Senator Hubert H. Humphrey, Democrat of Min nesota, supported today President Nixon's conduct of the Vietnam war against charges by Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, that Mr. Nixon was timing his policy to help win reelection in 1972.

title: Zumwalt Answers Critics
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 9 (AP)Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr., the Chief of Naval Opera tions, today told critics of re forms he has made in the Navy, It is time for us to withdraw our heads from the sand.

title: RUMANIA BIDS CHINA MEND TIES TO WEST
description: HONG KONG, June 9 (Reu ters)Rumania urged China today to normalize its relations with the West in the interests of world peace.

title: LOKER RALEY
description: WOODSTOCK, N. Y., June 9 Loker Raley, a poet who pub lished a volume Salute to the New Born in 1941 and later edited a magazine Blue Stone here, died yesterday at his home after a sudden illness. He was 62 years old.

title: Thefts in Wall Street Termed Rampant
description: WASHINGTON, June 9An assistant district attorney for New York County asserted to day that the stealing of securi ties from Wall Street broker ages was rampant.

title: 2 of Harlem 5 Win Leniency as Two Others Get Prison Terms
description: Two of the socalled Harlem fiveindicted three years ago for allegedly conspiring to kill a cop a week and convicted a month ago of various lesser felony counts of illegal posses sion of guns and homemade bombswere put on five year's probation yesterday by Su preme Court Justice Arnold G. Fraiman.

title: MRS. DAVID HENSCHEL
description: Mrs. Henriette Enoch Hen schel, who founded and directed for 20 years the Ardsley School for Girls at ArdsleyonHudson, N. Y., died yesterday at the Jewish Memorial Hospital. She was 87 years old and lived at the Hebrew Home for the Aged in Riverdale, the Bronx.

title: Br. Ottorino Memmoli, 78, Physician Here Since 1920
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., June 9 Dr. Ottorino Memmoli, a phy sician in New York City since 1920, died yesterday in Flush ing Hospital after a long ill ness. He was 78 years old and lived on Canterbury Road.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Seeks Information
description: WASHINGTON, June 10The State Department said today it had requested the Swiss Em bassy in Havana, which repre sents the United States there, to obtain information concern ing the status and the fate of Americans in Cuban custody.

title: CHRISTIAN CLERICS BACK ISRAELI STAND
description: Twentyfour Protestant and Roman Catholic leaders yester day issued a statement endors ing the reunification of Jeru salem under Israeli jurisdiction and declaring confidence in Is rael's capacity to supervise the holy places in cooperation with Christian and Moslem groups.

title: Nixon Asks Year's Extension of Foreign Aid Programs
description: WASHINGTON, June 10  President Nixon urged Con gress today to approve within the next three weeks a one year extension of the present economic and military aid program but to provide for their separate administration.

title: Barbara L. Geddis Is Married To Lieut. Jonathan W. Wooten
description: JAMAICA PLAIN, Mass., June 10Miss Barbara Lor raine Geddis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Geddis of Chestnut Hill, was married here today to Lieut. Jonathan Wayne Wooten, U.S.N., son of Dr. and Mrs. Clyde Curtis Wooten of Fairfax, Va., and Miami.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. The President saw Jacob Beam, U.S. Am bassador to Moscow, and later he met with railroad company leaders. The Presi dent announced the list of American goods that may be traded with Communist China.

title: Pan Am Prepared to Wait Before Buying Concorde
description: An increasing flow of un favorable views on the Con corde supersonic transport plane have been emanating from some United States air lines that have options to buy the craft.

title: Met Adds to Parks Fare
description: The Metropolitan Opera will preface its concert performance of Mascagni's Cavalleria Rus ticana in Central Park on Tuesday with a short program of excerpts from other works. The performance will consist of the Overture to Verdi's Na bucco, the duet from Act I of Puccini's Tosca, II lacerato, spirito from Verdi's Simon Boccanegra and the cavatina and duet from Donizetti's Don Pasquale. These excerpts will also be given before the Cav alleria performance at the Bronx Botanical Garden next Friday.

title: Soviet Freighter Held
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 10 (Reuters)  Federal Judge George B. Harris refused today to release a Soviet freighter from a writ of attachment holding her as security in a damage suit by a Massachu setts fishing company.

title: Merrill Lynch Earnings Surge; Concern Discloses Stock Sellers
description: Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fen ner & Smith, Inc., obviously still ringing up benefits from the commission surcharge on stock transactions, earned more in the first 18 weeks of 1971 than in all but four full, years in its history.

title: Administration, in Surprise, Withdraws Su pport for Any Kind of Special Census in 1975
description: WASHINGTON, June 10In a reversal of policy that aston ished members of a House com mittee, the Nixon Administra tion withdrew its support today for any kind of special census in 1975.

title: Advertising
description: AlbertoCulver announced yesterday how it was going to divide up the $25Million or so in billings that will be exiting from J. Walter Thompson and N. W. Ayer. And they had a surprise to go along with it because, besides the four agencies already announced, they'll be assigning prod ucts to Compton  AlbertoCulver's first agency and one it left in 1965.

title: Prelate Charges Polish Leaders Distort ChurchState Dialogue
description: LOWICZ, Poland, June 10 The Polish Primate, Stefan Car dinal Wyszynski, attacked the nation's Communist leaders to day for what he characterized as their distortion of recent at tempts to seek normalization of churchstate relations.

title: CITY REORGANIZES DETECTIVE STAFF
description: The detective squads as signed to the 11 precincts of southern Manhattan will be abolished July 1 and replaced by teams that will specialize in one of four groups of crimes: homicideassault, robbery, nar cotics and burglarylarceny.

title: SMITH IS RETURNED TO THE DEATH HOUSE
description: TRENTON, June 10 (AP) Edgar H. Smith was returned to the Death House in the State Prison here today after being thwarted do an attempt to se cure bail while awaiting a new trial.

title: SmallBond Thefts Up Sharply, Treasury Aides Tell Senate Unit
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 Senior officials of the Treasury said today that thefts of series E Government bonds had risen alarmingly in recent years. But they said that the pilfering of large  denomination Treasury securities traded in financial markets was declining.

title: U.S. Court Orders Atlanta To Alter Pupil Assignments
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 10 (UPI)  The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit directed the City of Atlanta today to draw up newt pupil assignment plan complying with the latest United States Supreme Court school desegregation rulings, a decision that could require wide crosstown busing.

title: News Analysis
description: ALBANY, June 10  The month  long struggle over the New York City tax package has been compared by some politicians to an act do which a magician with waxed mus tache and a look of supreme satisfaction yanks rabbits from his tuxedo and saws pretty ladies in half. Like the magic act, the negotia tions haven't al ways been what they seemed. The realities were fre quently obscured, often deliberately, by the rhet oric, pirouetting, dustkicking and diversionary pyrotechnics of the cast of characters. The drama often verged on charade.

title: Sweet Talk and Semantics
description: PARISSoviet diplomacy is thrust ing with unmistakable vigor for European security conference to be convened as soon as possible. The idea is an old favorite of Moscow's but has been given obvious new life. Almost every Russian embassy on this Conti nent is pushing it and a deputy foreign minister was sent on tour by the Kremlin in Scandinavia and London to press for its attainment.

title: Union Voting Halts Work
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 10 (UPI)The International Long shoremen's and Warehouse men's Union called a 24hour work stoppage today on San Francisco bay to hold elections. The union's top international officers were running unop posed, but there was competi tion for Key West Coast labor relations committed posts.

title: Items on China Trade List
description: WASHINGTON, June 10  Following is a summary of those United States products placed by President Nixon today on the general license list for the People's Republic of China. No special license is required for the export of these items.

title: Ohio State Hires Coach
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, June 10 (UPI) Charles R. Clausen, coach at William and Mary Col lege, was named a defensive line coach at Ohio State Uni versity today.

title: Nixon to Nominate Parker As Tariff Commission Aide
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) President Nixon announced today that he would nominate Joseph O. Parker, a local spe cialist in food and agriculture law, to be a member and vice chairman of the Tariff Commis sion.

title: Doctors Protest On Budget Cuts In City Hospital
description: About two dozen physicians at Lincoln Hospital refused yesterday to bill patients for medical services in a protest against anticipated budget cuts for the municipal hospital.

title: Coach Changes Jobs
description: HOULTON, Me., June 10 (AP) Allan S. Wilson resigned to day as soccer and football coach at Ricker College to be come soccer coach at the Uni versity of Hartford.

title: 18 U. S. Concerns May Seek Saigon's Oil
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 10The Economics Ministry announced today that South Vietnam would open bidt this year for oil exploration on its continental shelf in the South China Sea.

title: New Premier in Kabul
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, June 10 (UPI)Dr. Abdul Zahir, Afg hanistan's Ambassador to Rome, was appointed Premier yester day, an announcement from the Rayal Palace said.

title: Podgorny Chides NATO For Stand on Troop Talks
description: MOSCOW, June 10 President Nikolai V. Podgorny today ??? ed the North Atlantic Treaty Or ganization for taking a cautious approach to the Soviet call for negotiations on reducing forces in Central Europe.

title: Benjamin Grosvenor Weds Anne Carter
description: EAST PROVIDENCE, R. I., June 10Miss Anne Carter, daughter of Mrs. Ethel Robin son Carter of Pomfret, Conn., and the late Rear Adm. An drew Francis Carter, U.S.N.R., of Dillon, S. C., was married here this morning to Benja min Grosvenor, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John P. Grosvenor of Pomfret.

title: Early Trades on U.S. Cars
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) The General Accounting Of fice estimated today that the Government could save $5.1 million annually by trading in the 22,500 sedans in the inter agency automobile pool every year, he G.S.A. has a replace ment schedule of six years or 60,000 miles for each car.

title: Ruppert, Jailed in Deaths of 12, Ordered Freed by Appeals Court
description: The State Court of Appeals yesterday ordered Thomas A. Ruppert freed from jail and the case against him dismissed, nearly four years to the day after the youth was convicted of setting a fire that killed nine children and three adults in the Yonkers Jewish Community center in 1965.

title: PRESIDENT ENDS 21YEAR EMBARGO ON PEKING TRADE
description: WASHINGTON, June 10  President Nixon ended a 21year embargo on trade with Com munist China today. He author ized the export of a wide range of nonstrategic items and he lifted all controls on imports from China.

title: Sheffield Watch Creditors Delay Bankruptcy Petition
description: Sheffield Watch Corporation yesterday announced that its major bank creditors repre senting about $8million in claims, have informally agreed to withhold pressing their bankruptcy petition for a short time.

title: RIGHTS PANEL SAYS U.S HOUSING PLAN AIDS SEGREGATION
description: WASHINGTON, June 10  Charging the Federal Housing Administration with abdicat ing its responsibility, the United States Commission on Civil Rights said today that a new homeownership program for lowincome families had been used to perpetuate segre gation.

title: 2 ARE SENTENCED IN A STOCK FRAUD
description: A bank employe who stole more than $25,000 by rigging computer to deliver stock certi ficates and dividend checks on fraudulent orders was sentenced to three years yesterday.

title: DAVID ROTH, EXPERT IN MEMORY COURSES
description: LOS ANGELES, June 10 (AP) David Roth, a memory ex pert Who amazed friends after his 97th birthday last October by reciting the telephone num bers of 600 fellow Rotarians, died yesterday in a convales cent hospital.

title: OTB Looks Like Winner To Maryland's Governor
description: Gov. Marvin Mandel of Mary land apologized here yesterday for calling Howard J. Samuels a bookie.

title: Murphy Denounces Judge of Harlem 5
description: Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy issued a denuncia tion yesterday of State Su preme Court Justice Arnold G. Fraiman for granting probation to two men convicted of pos sessing guns and bombs in tended for use against police men.

title: Savings Office Is Held Up
description: A savings and loan associa tion in Queens was robbed yes terday morning of about $30, 000 by two men who fled after one of them, armed with a sawedoff shotgun, forced five customers and 10 employes against the wall as his partner rifled four cash drawers. The robbers held up the Reliance Federal Savings and Loan Asso ciation branch at 3202 Francis Lewis Boulevard in Bayside.

title: Market Place:
description: Let's have a look at that Glen AldenSchenley merger plan from the point of view of a holder of Glen Alden shares.

title: MARKET MOVES UP IN MODEST GAINS
description: Leading glamour issues showed a mixed, pattern yes terday, while the general mar ket gained a little ground.

title: Governor, in Retort, Calls Mayor Emotionally Upset
description: Governor Rockefeller, re sponding with scorn and sar casm to Mayor Lindsay's criti cisms of him and of the recent session of the State Legislature, said yesterday of the Mayor:

title: 3 AMERICAN CRAFT SEIZED BY HAVANA
description: MIAMI, Fla., June 10 (AP) The Cuban Government an nounced today that it had three private American vessels in cus tody and would try at leastlive of their 13 crewmen.

title: Theft of Barbiturates
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) The Pentagon's Civil Defense chief has urged removal and appropriate disposition of 600 million phenobarbital tablets now in public fallout shelters because of recent thefts.

title: MILLS PROPOSES TAXSHARING PLAN TO AID CITIES ONLY
description: WASHINGTON, June 10  Representative Wilbur D. Mills, who has vowed to defeat the Administration's general reve nuesharing program, unveiled an alternative plan of his own for financial aid to the cities at a secret meeting yesterday with key Democratic office holders from around the nation.

title: Bunker to Consult in Capital
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 10 (AP)The United States Ambassador, Ellsworth Bunker, is to return to Wash ington Sunday reportedly for consultations on the possibility of speeding American troop withdrawals from Vietnam.

title: Rare Crane Count Rises
description: FORT SMITH, Northwest Ter ritories, June 10 (AP)The whooping cranes population has increased to 91, and 12 eggs are under incubation, a Cana dian biologist here reported. Ernie Kuyt said a census had been completed Monday at Wood Buffalo National Park, where the birds spend the sum mer on the AlbertaNorthwest Territories border.

title: Israeli Aide Concedes Link to ExU.S. Racketeer
description: TEL AVIV, June 10A prom inent Israeli political figure acknowledged today that he had a business association with Joseph Stacher, a former Amer ican racketeer who is now an Israeli citizen.

title: Fanny May Holds Special Auction
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 The Federal National Mortgage Association announced today that it had purchased $273.7 million of mortgages in this week's special auction out of $1.1billion offered.

title: SENATE VOTES RISE IN EDUCATION AID
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) The Senate passed today 77 to0 a $5.6billion aidtoeduca tion money bill that exceeded Pres'dent Nixon's budget so substantially there were hints he might veto it.

title: WILLIAM S. M'CANN, TAUGHT MEDICINE
description: ROCHESTER, June 10  Dr. William Sharp McCann, first chairman of the department of medicine at the University of Rochester Medical School, who was widely known as a teacher of physicians, died today in the university's Strong. Memorial If ospital. He was 81 years old.

title: Books of The Times
description: GAUDI THE VISIONARY. Edited by George R. Collins. Preface by Salvador Deli. Essays by Robert Descharnes, Francesc Pujols, Joan Alavedra. Photographs by Clovis Prevost. 247 pages. A Studio Boole. Vihirog Press. $40.

title: Taiwan Terms Nixon Move On Peking Trade Unwise
description: TAIWAN, June 10The Na tionalist Chinese Government today termed President Nixon's decision to end the embargo on trade with Communist China a most unwise and un fortunate move.

title: Screen: The People and Their Guns
description: For something over 40 years, Joris Ivens has been waging his own information war against the forces of ex ploitation, aggression, repres sion and poverty, in his na tive Netherlands, in Spain, in China, in the United States and, most recently, in South east Asia.

title: Consumer Units Here to Pool Records in Computerized File
description: More than a dozen Federal, state and local agencies started a central computerized file of complaints by consumers in the metropolitan area yesterday to begin what they called a large scale attack on frauds and de ceptions against the buying public.

title: Welfare Law on Resumed Hartford Agenda
description: HARTFORD, June 10 The clock on the State Sen ate wall struck midnight yesterday, signaling manda tory adjqurnment, before a vote could be taken on a bill that would have imposed oneyear residency require ment on welfare recipients.

title: Screen: Japanese Saga:Feudal Spirit Survives in 'Band of Assassins'
description: "Band of Assassins" picks up the story of Japan in 1863 and drops it in the spring of 1868, a few months before it was previously picked up by last week's "Red Lion." It is just possible that by following the fortunes of Tohshiro Mifune at the Bijou, program after program, one might progress by brief forward spurts through the whole saga of the Japanese nationin reverse. Of course Mifune dies (the question in these movies is never "whether," but only "how"), but if he keeps on dying several years before each previous death he will achieve a kind of immortal mortality good at least until the dawn of recorded Eastern history.The film's time span covers the last years of the Tokugawa shogunate, the last gasp of the feudal spirit, the last vain struggle to close Japan to modernization and foreign influence. Very little of this seems to get into the film overtly (at least, as well as I can make out by the subtitles), except that the final battle is fought by swords against cannon and rifles. But I think a good deal does get in covertly, and it furnishes the main interest in what is otherwise no better, no livelier, no more subtle and no less bloody a movie than any of the other samurai dramas we have for some time been seeing.Mifune, a farmer turned samurai, joins and eventually leads a band loyal to the emperor and dedicated to eliminating, generally by mass murder, extremist elements of whose loyalties I am not altogether sure.Mifune is strict, severe, solemn, and much given to staring down destinyas evidenced in the portentous profiles that seem to be his favorite way of being photographed in close-up. I don't know what historical status his character has, but its mythic status, like the tremendously solid presence of Mifune himself, is clear enough. He means to transform history, to translate it into personalityand though his films are full of other able, powerful men, they are no more than their ability or power. Only Mifune lives fate inwardly.But "Band of Assassins" knows its time as well as its timelessness, and Tadashi Sawahima, whose name is not familiar, seems to have directed in terms of traditional visual styles. Sometimes his work looks like Ichikawa, sometimes it looks like Ozu, but more often it looks like a tribute to the Japanese print and to the arrangements of space in Japanese architecture. I think this tribute is deliberate, and rather lovely. And although it is eventually submerged in the habitual pieties of the Mifune enterprise, it suggests for a while a spirit and a style that is deeper, more delicate and surely more durable than the heavy heroics for which it serves as a backdrop.

title: Prices in Credit Markets Show Slight Retreat, but Then Stabilize
description: The credit markets declined slightly yesterday and then ap peared to stabilize.

title: 035575 Wins in Jersey
description: CRANFORD, N. J., June 10 (AP)The winning number in this week's New Jersey lottery is 035575. Holders of tickets with all six numbers in the cor rect order win $50,000; with the last five numbers, $4,000; the last four, $400, and the last three, $40. Holders of tickets with the last two digits match ing those of the winning num ber are eligible for a million aire's drawing to be held later this year.

title: Bridge
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, June 10A dazzling performance by the great Italian stars. Giorgio Bella donna and Benito Garozzo marked the exhibition match here last night in which a group of experienced Johan nesburg experts opposed the Precision international tour ing team.

title: PIANO RECITAL GIVEN BY DAVID HANCOCK
description: David Hancock, a pianist and recording engineer, was Wednesday night's recitalist Ott the New York Cultural Cen ter. It is 10 years since he last played in public here; and per baps he has been too long away from the concert stage. He still gets around the keyboard nim bly, and he produced a good ringing tone, yet there seemed to be a nervousness and ten sion in his performances that made them sound uneasy and shapeless.

title: Okinawa Pact Hailed in Tokyo, But the Island's Leader Is Cool
description: TOKYO, June 10Govern ment leaders today hailed the agreement, announced yester day, on returning Okinawa and the other islands of the Ryukyu chain to Japan.

title: Hungary Trails, 20
description: MUNICH, Germany, June 10 (UPI)West Germany took a 20 lead over Hungary today in their Davis Cup. European Zone Group BBB semi final.

title: Knowles's 77 Takes Playoff
description: RYE, N. Y., June 10Jim Knowles of Greenwich, Conn., won the 67th annual United States Seniors Golf Association championship today, beating Bill Wright of Clementon, N. J., in an 18hole medal playoff by two strokes.

title: Moscow Plan Envisions Model Communist City
description: MOSCOW, June 10The So viet leadership announced to day that it had approved a new master plan aimed at mak ing Moscow a model Commu nist city.

title: CANADA IS SEEKING CIGARETTE AD BAN
description: OTTAWA, June 10  The Canadian Government today introduced a bill to prohibit all advertising and promotion of cigarettes as of next Jan. 1 Passage of the legislation, seemed assured.

title: Jersey Boy, 12, Wins National Spelling Bee
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 (UPI)Jonathan P. Kniseley, a 12yearold from Mullica Hill, N. J., won the 44th Na tional Spelling Bee today. I just made a guess at it, he conceded after winning the championship by correctly spelling the word shalloon, meaning a kind of fabric.

title: SIX HUDSON AIDES ACCUSED OF FRAUD
description: JERSEY CITY, June 10A special Hudson County grand jury today indicted all five members of the County Pen sion Commission and the Coun ty Medical Examiner on charges of handing over $392,000 in fraudulent disability pension awards to 100 county employes over a threeyear period.

title: The Case of the F.B.I. Man And Bombing of the Mafia
description: TUCSON, Ariz., June 9The Federal prosecutor here plans to take before a grand jury this summer the bizarre case of former agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who allegedly plotted bombings to foment gang warfare among members of the Mafia.

title: SEVERAL CHEMICALS INCREASING IN PRICE
description: Chemical prices rose yester day on a broad front.

title: Books of The Times
description: Thumb through this slim volume casually and it will appear as a piece of curious exotica. And of course it is: remote in time and in space. It stems from a culture, the Heian period in 11thcentury. Japan, that only an expert will feel at home in. The woodcuts scattered through the book, with their spare geometrical lines, uncluttered spaces, with their figures in stylized dress, add to the feeling of fairytale strangeness. The text is dotted with poems in a minor key, elegiac and somewhat tearful. And the sensibility of the author, frail, delicate, ex quisite, fits into the cozy pattern we think of as Oriental.

title: Mitchell Withdraws Stand That Blocked Virginia Districting
description: WASHINGTON, June 10At torney General John N. Mitchell withdrew today his objections to the creation of multimember legislative districts in Virginia.

title: Natural Mother of Baby Lenore May See Child in Court Today
description: MIAMI, June 10  The nat ural mother of Baby Lenore will confront at least one of Lenore's wouldbe adoptive par ents in court here tomorrow in an effort to regain from them the child she surrendered for adoption one year and eight days ago.

title: Backers of Cancer Agency Nearing Accord in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, June 10  The Nixon Administration and Senate proponents of an inde pendent cancer agency ap peared today to have reached almost complete agreement on the strategy for attempting to conquer that large and deadly group of diseases.

title: Stage: A Serious, FreakedOut Farce
description: The New York Shakespeare Festival and La Mama Exper imental Theater Club are quite a combination, and last night they got together at the Shakespeare Shrine and Supermarket on Lafayette Streetit is still implausibly known as the Public Theatre and produced one or the happiest entertainments in town. Called Dance Wi Me, it is a serious, freakedout farce that I found pure de light.

title: New Post for VISTA Chief
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI) Mrs. Carol M. Khosrovi, di rector of Volunteers in Service to America, was named today asistant director for program development in the Office of Economic Opportunity.

title: Level Is Running at a Rate of 13.3%, Well Over Reserve Goal
description: The headlong monetary ex pansion, which has been deeply troubling to Wall Street re cently, continued unabated dur ing the last two weeks.

title: AIRAGENCY HEADS FOR LOCKHEED AID
description: WASHINGTON, June 10  The heads of the Civil Aeronau tics Board and the Federal Aviation Administration joined today in saying that it would be unfortunate for the country if the Lockheed Aircraft Cor poration went bankrupt.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It is fascinating that when a group of young people threaten unsuccess fully to tie up a city over their protest that thousands are being killed, the Administration and the public thunder that mass arrests are not only in evitable, but appropriate.

title: Equal Women's Pay Urged
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) Women's organizations pro tested to Congress today that the gap between men's and women's pay was widening and that the more educated a woman was the greater the dis parity. Mrs. Lucille Shriver, di rector of the Nation ??? of Business and P. ???.

title: Postal Strike Threatened By Unionists in Cities
description: Postal union leaders from New York, Philadelphia, Detroit and Chicago said yesterday that their memberships would strike next month if contract negotia tions with the new United States Postal Service did not take a more productive turn.

title: Kirby Fans 13 Mets as Padres Score On Colbert's TwoRun Homer, 4 to 2
description: Nate Colbert of the San Diego Padres is not what you would call a flamboyant base ball player. He doesn't play the banjo like Maury Wills. He doesn't have a nightclub act like Mudcat Grant. He doesn't pilot an airplane like Denny McLain. He doesn't even drive to the park in a chauffeured limousine like Joe Pepitone.

title: Cleveland Reserve Bank Elects a New President
description: The Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland announced yes terday the election as presi dent of Willis J. Winn, now dean of the Wharton. School of Finance and Commerce of the University of Pennsyl vania.

title: RCA Unveils VideoVoice Phone
description: The RCA Corporation yes terday introduced a new video  voice communication system that allows users both in the United States and abroad to exchange pictures, charts and other graphic ma terials over circuits capable of carrying the voice at the same time as discussions are being held.

title: Returning Visitor Finds Kaleidoscope Of Changes Since China's 66 Upheaval
description: NANKING, China, June 1 Today's visitor to Chinato commune, department store, factory or schoolinvariably hears officials describe their achievements by comparing 1971 with 1966.

title: White House and Club Sites of Wedding Fetes
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 Like any other couple facing imminent matrimony, Tricia Nixon and Edward Finch Cox separated tonight for their final taste of single life.

title: Recital by Short Honors Cole Porter
description: Cole Porter, who died in 1964, would have been 80 years old on Wednesday. To commemorate the occasion, Bobby Short, who is a quint essential singer of Porter songs, devoted his entire pro gram that night at the Cafe Carlyle, 76th Street and Mad ison Avenue, to the songs of Mr. Porter.

title: Hanoi and Vietcong Give Assurances on P.O.W. Issue
description: PARIS, June 10The North Vietnamese and the Vietcong said today that if the United States would set a date for its withdrawal from Vietnam, they would discuss a full exchange of prisoners without relation to any other questions.

title: Miss Sadwith Wed in Jersey
description: COLTS NECK, N. J., June 10The marriage of Miss Barbara Anne Sadwith to Henry Alfred Emery Jr., son of Mrs. Emery of New Glouces ter, Me., and the late Mr. Emery, took place here this afternoon. Rabbi Joseph Goldman performed the cere mony in the garden at the home of Mr. and Mrs. How ard M. Sadwith, parents of the bride.

title: Nixon Confers With Railroad Executives
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 President Nixon met today in the White House for about an hour and 20 minutes with 11 of the nation's top rail road executives, Transporta tion Secretary John A. Volpe and Peter Flanagan, an assist ant to the President.

title: NASA Announces Centers To Manage Space Shuttle
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 The National Aeronautics and Space Administration an nounced today its general plans for managing the space shuttle program, considered a key to the nation's major efforts in manned space operations after the Apollo program of landings on the moon.

title: The Politics of Money
description: WASHINGTONAlmost every major domestic problem in America has it's roots, in my view, in a deeper, more basic malady: the manner in which we finance political campaigns, with Can didates heavily dependent on inter ested givers who expect a return on their investment, usually in the form of some governmental favor or largesse.

title: Alvin Johnson
description: Dr. Alvin Johnson, who died at the age of 96, combined a farmbred skepticism about academic institutions with the abiding love of a scholar and teacher for academic excellence. His two extraordinary contributions to Ameri can society were the founding of the New School for Social Research in 1919 and the creation in 1933 of the university in exile as a haven for refugee scholars from Nazi persecution.

title: Puerto Rico Parade Sunday
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday (proclaimed June 7 to 13 as Puerto Rican Cultural Week. At la City Hall ceremony, the Mayor met a number of offi cials of the Puerto Rican pa rade, which will run from 44th to 3rd Streets along Fifth Ave nue, starting at 1 P.M. on Sun day.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: ORANGEBURG, S. C.A quake sim ilar in intensity to the one that struck California in February, 1971, has struck South Carolina.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: 9 STUDENTS DEAD IN MEXICO RIOTING
description: MEXICO CITY, June 10At least nine students were killed and more than 130 persons were wounded here tonight in the worst street fighting in volving antiGovernment stu dents since the protest move ment before the Olympic Games in 1968.

title: List of Road Bottlenecks
description: Motorists driving in and out of the metropolitan drea this weekend may encounter delays because of con struction work at the following points listed by the New York Automobile Club:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Treasury Suggests Issuing One Security for Several
description: The Treasury, acting to consolidate a host of Federal credit assistance programs, proposes creation of an umbrellatype agency that would offer its own securities in the market.

title: MRS. GUSTAVE J. ROSEN
description: WESTPORT, Conn., June 10 Mrs. Rhoda Cedarbaum Ros en, a Westport civic leader and the wife of Gustave J. Rosen, died Tuesday at Norwalk Hos pital. She was 67 years old and lived at 311 South Compo Road.

title: F.T.C. to Order Industries To Substantiate Their Ads
description: WASHINGTON, June 10The Federal Trade Commission, invoking previously unused authority, announced its inten tion today to order all major industries to substantiate their advertising claims. Orders to file data in support of claims involving the safety, perform ance, efficacy, quality and comparative prices of adver tised products will be issued, industry by industry, about every three months. The files will be open to the public.

title: HATFIELD OPENS VIETNAM DEBATE
description: WASHINGTON, June 10  The Senate began debate today on the McGovernHatfield amendment, which would re quire the withdrawal of all American forces from Vietnam by the end of this year.

title: Sergeant Convicted of Stealing Funds of Vietnam Army Clubs
description: REDSTONE ARSENAL, Ala., June 10 (AP)M. Sgt. William Higdon was convicted today of stealing $7,200 in cigarette promotion funds and taking $723 in kickbacks while run ning Army clubs in Vietnam.

title: Weiskopf's 66 Leads Four By 2 Strokes at Charlotte
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., June 10  Tom Weiskopf's 66 led the opening round of the $150,000 Kemper open today in the last test for the pro golfers before next week's United States Open.

title: Lehrman New Head Of Synagogue Council
description: The Synagogue Council of America, the representative body of the congregational and rabbinic arms of the three branches of Judaism, announced yesterday the election of Rabbi Irving Lehr man as its new president.

title: 2 BIGBOARD STOCKS FACE SUSPENSIONS
description: The board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange voted yesterday to suspend trading in two issues and dis cussed the submission of a pro posed new commissionrate schedule to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The boys deserve it. It was pleas ant to read that ecumenical judgment of Stanley Steingut, Democratic lead er of the State Assembly, expressing his approval of an increase from $3,000 to $5,000 in expense allowances for members of the Legislature. This proves that when the chips are down; strident voices are lowered, and party differences are forgotten.

title: Passer Discerns Trend Toward Price Stability
description: WASHINGTON, June 10A high government official ex pressed complete confidence to day that economic policies and forces are working toward eventual price stability, though he conceded that the various indicators of inflation had recently been giving off mixed signals.

title: EDWARD J. KELLY
description: SPRING LAKE, N. J., June 10 Edward J. Kelly, who retired in 1959 as general manager of the radio and television divi sion of Westingthouse Electric Corporation, died yesterday at his home, 15 York Avenue. He was 70 years old.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company an nounced yesterday the appointment of Edwin B. Lancaster as senior vice president and chief ac tuary. Mr. Lancaster, 54, has been a senior vice president of the company since 1969, in charge of personal insurance oper ations. With his new responsibilities as chief actuary, he will be in charge of the daytoday operations of the actu arial department, re porting to Joseph B. Crimmins, executive vice president. Mr. Lancaster is currently president of the Society of Actuaries.

title: U.S.Canada Lakes Pollution Pact Set
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 The United States and Canada agreed today on a joint pro gram to eliminate water pollu tion in the Great Lakes by 1975.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Front Page 1  No Title

title: Railroad Freight Traffic Is Lower Than Year Ago
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 Freight traffic on United States railroads in the week ended June 5, which included the Memorial Day holiday, totaled an estimated 14.0 billion ton miles, 5.2 per cent below the yearearlier week.

title: Black Officials in Tribal Capital Sit With South Africans and Laud Apartheid
description: ONDANGUA, South  West Africa, June 10  Officials of the South African Government and black notables sat side by side at the Finnish Lutheran Mission Hospital in this tribal capital today.

title: Ike and T. R. vs. Nixon
description: GREENWICH, Conn.  The debate over. President Nixon's controversial plan for nostrings Federal revenue sharing with the states promises to burn on throughout this session of the Congress.

title: REFUSE PICKUPS IN DISPUTE HERE
description: Leaders of a heavily Puerto Rican section of Brooklyn charged yesterday that garbage in their section had not been picked up for several days.

title: Farmers in Midwest Aiding U.S. In Plan to Wipe 0ut Marijuana
description: ELKHORN, Wis., June 9 In these busy weeks, when farmers here in Walworth County need every minute of the long summer day to tend their fields, many are steal ing hours to seek out and destroy stands of the In dian hemp plantthe source of marijuana  that have grown up unbidden on the waste places of their land.

title: 2 Governing Parties in Chile Accuse C.I.A. in Killin
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, June 10 The Communist and Socialist parties, the mainstays of Chile's coalition Government, charged today that the United States Central Ihtelligence Agency was involved in the assassination of Eduardo Perez Zukovic, Christian Democratic party leader.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Willie Mays has reached the age at which life is sup posed to begin. He is 40 years old. If there is an area in which the lifebeginsat40 doctrine has any validity, it's a lead pipe cinch that it is not sports. Most athletes have departed from the scene by their 40th birthday and those who remain are faced by the law of diminishing returns.

title: Brazil Devalues Cruzeiro
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 10 (UPI)Brazil's central bank to day announced another mini devaluation of the cruzeiro, ef fective tomorrow. The dollar will be sold at 5.285 cruzeiros and bought at 5.25 cruzeiros.

title: McCarthy May Enter New York's Primary in 1972
description: Former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy said yesterday that he might enter 1972 Democratic Presidential primary elections, particularly the New York pri mary, to try to win enough del egates to have some influence at the party's national conven tion.

title: Prof. Adam M. Parry and Wife, Classicists, Are Killed in Crash
description: PARIS, June 10Prof. Adam M. Parry, chairman of Yale University's Classics. Depart ment, and his wife, Anne Rein berg Amory Parry, also a classicist, were killed last Fri day in a traffic accident near Colmar.

title: Advertising:
description: For the last 11 years, the St. Regis Paper Company has been giving awards to college students for winning package designs.

title: End of an Embargo
description: President Nixon yesterday ended the legal barriers which have prevented any significant SinoAmerican trade since the Truman Administration. In the short run, this step has far more political than economic significance, and it represents a logical advance as the Chinese People's Republic and the United States move toward normal relations. Two months ago Peking opened its borders to American visitors, and now President Nixon has opened American doors to a wide variety of goods that may be exported to or imported from China.

title: TRUCKS AND BUSES RECALLED BY G.M.
description: DETROIT, June 10  The General Motors Corporation recalled 19,000 trucks and 900 school buses today to correct defects linked to some 50 in juries.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Aide to Queen Responds To Estimates on Fortune
description: LONDON, June 10  Buck ingham Palace spoke today on the dispute that followed Queen Elizabeth's request for an in crease in the royal budget. The palace supported speculation that the Queen's personal for tune was about $4.8million.

title: 300 CLINICS URGED TO TREAT ADDICTS
description: WASHINGTON, June 10A bill, to establish a network of more than 300 drug addiction treatment centers at a cost of $160million was introduced in the House today by Represent ative Paul. Rogers, Democrat of Florida. The addiction treat ment facilities would be graft ed onto existing and future centers of the National Insti tute of Mental Health.

title: Man in the News
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 Ten years ago, the Rev. Theodore Martin Hesburgh wrote: There are the un spoken but very effective conspiracies of builders, real estate brokers and good neighbors who are down right arrogant in preserving the blessings of democracy for their own white selves alone. Today, the harsh indictment of the Federal Housing Administration is sued by the United States Commission on Civil Rights, which Father Hesburgh heads, elaborated the same theme. The report was a mark of the consistency and persistency with which Father Hesburgh has pursued equal rights for all Amer icans for more than a decade.

title: Battista Denies Deal on Corona Homes
description: Assemblyman Vito Battista yesterday denied Mayor Lind say's charge that he had made a deal with Assembly Speaker Perry B. Duryea that killed a compromise bill to relocate homes now occupying a planned school site in Corona, Queens.

title: PAKISTAN SEEKS REFUGEES RETURN
description: KARACHI. Pakistan, June 10  The Pakistani overnment appealed today to all refugees from East Pakistan to return home and offered a general amnesty extending to military deserters and politicians.

title: NETWORK OFFICIALS ASK HIGHER CEILING
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 Officials of the three major net works agreed today that cam paign spending limits for radio and television should be twice as high as those on which Sen ate Democratic leaders have agreed.

title: City Hall Releases Report Hailing Plan for Statehood
description: Mayor Lindsay, moving ahead with discussions on the possi bility of statehood for New York City, released a detailed staff memorandum yesterday that hailed the idea.

title: MUSKIE PROPOSES STAY ON TV AD USE
description: WASHINGTON, June 10  Senator Edmund S. Muskie of Maine is proposing that he and his rivals for the Democratic Presidential nomination agree to spend nothing for television advertising until after the party has selected its nominee.

title: PARCEL UNION GAINS A TENTATIVE PACT
description: Representatives of three Teamster locals on strike since May 20 reached a tentative agreement yesterday with the United Parcel Service.

title: BAHNSEN WINS 4TH IN A ROW AS YANKS DOWN ANGELS, 32
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., June 10 Cpl. Stan Bahnsen, working for the Yankees before going to work for the United States Army Reserves for two weeks, pitched a fivehitter tonight as New York edged the California Angels, 32.

title: EIGHT U.S. BUCKS EXHIBIT IN GENEVA
description: GENEVA, June 10 Henri Ghent, director of the Brooklyn Museum's Community Gallery, submitted 75 works by eight AfroAmerican artists at a pre view here today.

title: Christian Science's New President: Her Emphasis Is on Love
description: BOSTONWhen the Christian Scien tists of this world had their annual meeting here recently, they breezed through the agenda with practiced as surance.

title: The City's Tax Victory
description: The embattled City of New York won from the Legis lature power to impose $525 million in new and addi tional local taxesfar more than city officials say they expected to win from Albanybut the city lost in the heavy infighting on two key points of its total revenue program. It failed to get the Legislature to restore the full share of state incometax revenues that had been promised to localities on the basis of prior commitments. It also failed to win from this suburbandominated ses sion the right to impose a reasonable proportion of the city's incometax burden on commuters.

title: Boyer, Fined for Football Bets, Is Cleared to Seek Baseball Job
description: Clete Boyer, who sought and received his uncondition al release from the Atlanta Braves in acrimonious cir cumstances last month, was cleared yesterday to continue seeking baseball employment after being fined $1,000 by Commissioner Bowie Kuhn for betting on football games in 1968 and 1969.

title: STEEL. PRODUCER WILL LAY OFF 250
description: The WheelingPittsburgh Steel Corporation yesterday became the first of the nation's major steel producers to announce layoffs and facility shutdowns. It said it was laying off 250 employes and banking a blast furnace.

title: Illinois Train Accident Kills 10
description: SALEM, Ill., June 10 (AP) The City of New Orleans pas senger train derailed at more than 90 miles per hour in a hail of twisted metal and flame today, killing 10 persons and injuring 94.

title: POLLUTION PACT SET ET U.S. AND 3 CITIES
description: WASHINGTON, June 10  William D. Ruckelshaus, the head of the Environmental Pro tection Agency, said today that his agency had reached water pollution agreements with three cities.

title: Farewell Party Triumphs by Nose Over Bobby Dees Boy at Belmont
description: Farewell Party of the Rokeby Stable and Bobby Dees Boy, sporting the silks of Martin Wygod, waged a stirring duel in the final phase of the feature race at Belmont Park yesterday, with the former win ning by a nose.

title: Notes on People
description: Robert Moses, the master planner and builder, divested himself of some typically curmudgeonly Moses musings yesterday when he addressed the 1,300 graduates of Queensborough Community College in Bayside, Queens.

title: Steel Representative Named
description: Oremco, Inc., of New York, a new company headed by Robert E, Leon i, has been ap pointed general representative in the United States and Ca nada of the Royal Netherlands Blast Furnaces and Steel Works, Ltd. Koninklijke Nederlandsche Hoogovens en Staalfabrieken N. V.) of Ijmuiden, the Neth erlands. Oremco was formed jointly by Royal Netherlands and Mr. Leoni, former chairman of William H. Muller & Co., an international mining and mar keting company specializing in ores for the steel and the metallurgical Industries.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: It is not usually considered proper for a foreigner to comment on the political affairs of the United States, but perhaps an exception may proper ly be claimed for one who has been for twenty years a voteless taxpayer and is deeply disturbed by the deterio rating condition of his adopted home.

title: Court Tells City Welfare Unit Not to Replace Stolen Furniture
description: ALBANY, June 10  The State Court of Appeals today reversed a lower court's deci sion that a New York City woman who was receiving wel fare aid and whose apartment had been burglarized was en titled to have the stolen and vandalized property replaced by the city's Department of So cial Services.

title: 100 J.D.L. BACKERS SEIZED IN PROTEST
description: More than 100 supporters of the Jewish Defense League, in cluding its militant leader, Rabbi Meir Kahane, were ar rested on disorderly conduct charges late last night when they sat down in the intersec tion of Third Avenue and East 67th Street, half a block from the Soviet Mission to the United Nations.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, June 10In his life long study of the art of diplomacy, Sir Harold Nicholson reached the conclu sion that imprecision of language was one of the greatest barriers to success ful negotiation between nations, and this is proving to be true once more in the Paris talks on Vietnam.

title: 3 Fires in 24 Hours Force the Closing Of Washington High
description: George Washington High School was forced to close yes terday after three fires in less than 24 hours caused damage estimated at $8,000 inside the building.

title: HOUSE UNIT BACKS AID FOR EXPORTS
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 The House Banking and Cur rency Committee approved to day a big expansion of the lending authority of the Export Import Bank and exemption of the bank's operations from re strictions of the Federal budget.

title: Addict Center Opens On Lower East Side
description: Mayor Lindsay officially opened a new private drug addiction treatment center on the Lower East Side yes terday, one of the largest such agencies in the country.

title: Mary J. Coffee Is Bride of Ensign
description: ANNAPOLIS, June 10 Miss Mary Joyce Coffee and Ens. Gregory Baird Dies, U.S.N., were married this afternoon in the Main Chapel of the Naval Academy by Capt. Henry Duncan, Chap lain Corps, U.S.N., a Metho dist clergyman.

title: TRIAL SEVERANCE GIVEN J. V. KENNY
description: NEWARK, June 10John V. Kenny, the key defendant in the Jersey CityHudson County conspiracy extortion trial in Federal Court here, was severed from the trial today because of illness.

title: Texan Is Stabbed to Death In MidtownArea Mugging
description: A 52yearold man was stabbed to death in a mugging early yesterday in front of the Roxy Hotel at 405 West 42d Street, near Ninth Avenue.

title: W. T. Gossett Named Fox Film Chairman
description: William T. Gossett, a De troit lawyer, was elected chairman of the Twentieth CenturyFox Film Corpora tion yesterday. He succeeds Darryl F. Zanuck, who re signed on the eve of the an nual meeting last month and was named chairman emeri tus.

title: MICHAEL LENSON, 68, ARTIST AND TEACHER
description: NUTLEY, N. J., June 10 Michael Lenson, painter and art teacher, died yesterday in the Orange Memorial Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 16 Enclosure here.

title: STRIKE AT GARDEN ENDS AFTER 6 DAYS
description: A sixday strike that had caused cancellation of several events at Madison Square Garden was settled yesterday when striking employes of the Garden agreed to accept a new twoyear contract.

title: Polish Ship Saves 3 on Raft
description: BOSTON June 10 (UPI)The Pomorze, a Polish ship, picked up three American fishermen yesterday who had spent seven hours aboard a rubber life raft after their boat sank 35 miles south of Nantucket. The men, the crew of the 66foot Tocsin out of New Bedford, suffered no ill effects, the Coast Guard said.

title: Silvester's 2299 Beats Discus Record
description: YSTAD, Sweden, June 10 (AP)Jay Silvester of the United States bettered his listed world record In the discus today with a throw of 229 feet 9 inches.

title: Stans, Industry Differ
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., June 10Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans and key figures of the country's $50billion chemical industry offered sharply different assess ments today on the state of the economy.

title: 925 Are Graduated Here In Yeshiva U.'s 40th Class
description: Yeshiva University held its 40th commencement exercises yesterday and awarded 925 de grees to graduates of 10 of the university's undergraduate, graduate and professional schools.

title: Episcopalian Is Named Clergyman of the Year
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 The Right Rev. John E. Hines, presiding bishop of the Epis copal Church, was named Clergyman of the Year today by Religious Heritage of America, an interfaith, non profit organization that seeks to instill JudeoChristian ideals into all areas of Ameri can life.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, June 10  The Nixon Administration does not foresee an avalanche of trade with China but it hopes that today's relaxation of the twodecade embargo will stim ulate the business of diplomacy between Peking and Wash ington.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: Committee for Program and Coordination10:30 A.M., P.M. and 8:30 P.M.

title: Airlines Widen Battle On Atlantic Youth Fares
description: What started out last week as a mild skirmish involving two airlines and the price of a ticket between New York and Belgium has blossomed in to an airfare freeforall,

title: SUGAR BILL VOTED BY HOUSE, 229128
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 The House passed today a threeyear extension of legisla tion regulating sugar production after rejecting an effort to re strict imports from South Africa.

title: Legislative Panel Kills Reagan Plan On Welfare Reform
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., June 10A California State Senate committee killed last night bill encompassing Gov. Ronald Reagan's legislative proposals for welfare reforms.

title: A Second Life for an Old Butcher Shop
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I.It 91'10 longer looks like a butch er shop. But then how many modern kitchens have meat hooks on the wall, chopping blocks on the floor and sausage maker serving as the kitchen sink?

title: Parkinson Sets Out to Defy His Own Law
description: C. Northcote Parkinson, the British author and humorist, has set out to defy Parkin son's Law  that corporate growth leads to complexity and complexity leads to de cay. So far he seems to be succeeding.

title: Mrs. Holmes Wed To Everett Arbour
description: HARTFORD, June 10 Mrs. Marie Heller Holmes of Longmeadow, Mass., widow of Frank R. Holmes, was married here this afternoon to Everett J. Arbour, a widower and executive vice president of Associated Transport of Hartford and New York. The Rev. Ward Smith, an Episcopal priest, and the Rev. Dennis Ferri gano performed the cere mony in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Cathedral.

title: Room Leased by Columbia Held in DayCare Protest
description: Forty adults and children yesterday occupied a large fourthfloor room leased by Co lumbia University at Audubon Avenue to demand that it be turned into a communityspon sored daycare center.

title: Council Is Given Bills to Enact Most Revenue Authorizations
description: City Councilmen shuffled through piles of form letters protesting a proposed $15a year autouse tax yesterday, then formally received the bills that would enact most of the revenue package authorized by Albany.

title: CANADIENS NAME BOWMAN COACH
description: MONTREAL, June 10 (UPI) Al MacNeil resigned today amid a swirl of controversy as coach of the Stanley Cup winning Montreal Canadiens of the National Hockey League and immediately was replaced by Scotty Bowman.

title: REDSKINS PICK UP BIGGS, JETS END
