description: The Jets lost Verlon Biggs, their 6foot4inch, 270pound defensive end, to the Washing ton Redskins yesterday. Biggs who had played out his option with the Jets, signed as a free agent with Washington.

title: Connecticut Bishop Elected
description: HARTFORD, June 10 The Rev. Morgan Porteus, rector of St. Peter's Episcopal Church in Cheshire, was elected Suffragan Bishop of Connecticut today on the fourth ballot at a conven tion at Christ Church Cathe dral. Bishopelect Porteus, who is 53 years old, has been rector of St. Peter's since 1944.

title: BLACK POLICEMEN DENOUNCE RACISM
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 10  Black policemen and white of ficials of police fraternal or ganizations clashed today at a black policemen's conference over the question of racial po larity in police departments.

title: Canadian Bill Rates Rise
description: OTTAWA, June 10 (Canadian Press)The Government today auctioned $165million of new 91day Treasury bills at an average price of 99.241 and average yield of 3.07 per cent, compared with last week's 99.246 and 3.05 per cent. To day's $45million of 182day bills brought 98.349 and 3.37 per cent, against last week's 98.357 and 3.35 per cent.

title: Pakistan Gets Grant From U.S.
description: KARACHI, June 10  The United States today granted Pakistan $1million in foreign exchange to pay for relief work in areas of East Pakistan affected by last November's cyclone.

title: Canadian Envoy in Peking
description: HONG KONG, June 10 (Reu ters)Ralph E. Collins, Can ada's first Ambassador to Pe king since diplomatic relations were established in October, presented his credentials today, Hsinhua, the Communist press agency, reported.

title: Iris Graff Wed To A. R. Morse
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., June 10Miss Iris Joan Graff and Andrew R. Morse were mar ried here this evening at the Sunningdale Country Club by Rabbi Jack Stern Jr.

title: Fine French Food and Authentic Italian
description: The restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their service, atmosphere and ddcor (four triangles to none).

title: Commodity Price Index Off 0.5 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials slipped to 107.2 from 107.7 last week.

title: Ky is Reported Planning Race With the Aid of Minh
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 10  Supporters of Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky, whose chances of running for the Presidency appeared con siderably diminished by new electoral legislation last week, now say he will try to run any way.

title: SADAT SAYS ARABS FACE LONG BATTLE
description: CAIRO, June 10President Anwar elSadat declared today that the Arabs faced a battle for generations against Israel, which, he said, would hang like the sword of Damocles over the Arabs long after they had recovered the lands lost in the 1967 war.

title: 2 Menu Ideas for Weekend
description: In the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: Michael Rennie, Film and TV Actor, Dead at 62
description: LONDON, June 10Michael Rennie, the actor, Who played Harry Lime in the television series The Third Man, died today In Harrogate, Yorkshire. He was 62 years old.

title: The Lockheed Precedent
description: In his testimony before the Senate Banking Committee, Deputy Defense Secretary David Packard virtually knocked the props from under the Nixon Administra tion's case for the Government to guarantee up to $250 million in loans to the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.

title: LORENTZ SOBSTAD
description: OLD LYME, Conn., June 10 Lorentz Nickolai Sobstad, a sailmaker, whose business was known as Larry Sobstad Yacht Sails, died last Friday in Nor wich. He was 57 years old and lived here.

title: JULIE HELDMAN, MRS. COURT WIN
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, June 10 (AP)Julie Heldman of New York gained the women's final of the Nottingham tennis championships today by beat ing Helen Amos of Australia, 62, 60.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Sir Roy Harrod's recommendation of a tripling in the price of gold [letter May 18] is sweet music to the gold miner, who has been a victim for years of worldwide inflation. But how does Sir Roy propose to achieve this ob jective?

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In recent months, the fishing con troversy between American lobster fishermen and foreign trawlers off the coast of New England has apparently increased in frequency, intensity and publicity.

title: Store Sales Reported
description: WASHINGTON, June 10The Commerce Department today estimated last week's depart ment store sales at $746million, up 5 per cent from the year earlier $712million. Total retail store sales last week were about $7,294,000,000, virtually unchanged from $7,272,000,000.

title: FUTURES IN GRAIN INCREASE IN PRICE
description: Grain futures prices took off yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade as a result of reports that the Southern corn blight is spreading. Sharp in creases were recorded not only for corn but wheat and oats futures as well.

title: TRUST SUIT ROUND WON BY BIG BOARD
description: The New York Stock. Ex change won the first round yesterday in its eightmonth battle to defend itself against a $3billion antitrust suit and class action filed here last October by Hans Randolph Reinisch, a 39yearold New Yorker.

title: Foundation's Head to Quit
description: Dr. Orville G. Brim Jr. has resigned as president of the Russell Sage Foundation here, effective June 30, 1972. The foundation, which has assets of $40million, supports social science research. Dr. Brim, sociologist and psychologist, is leaving the post to pursue writing career has been on the foundation's staff since 1955 and its president since 1964.

title: Roundup: Orioles Streak Hits 8 as Twins Bow, 120
description: The Orioles unleashed a doublebarrelled attack last night against Minnesotathe pitching of Jim Palmer and the slugging of Frank Robin sonto coast to their eighth straight victory, a 120 rout of the Twins at Baltimore.

title: U.S. and Soviet Exchange Lunar Soil to Mark Pact
description: MOSCOW, June 10  The United States and the Soviet Union exchanged, samples of lunar soil in a brief ceremony today marking an expansion of cooperation in space research and exploration.

title: QUEENS VANDALS BELIEVED RACISTS
description: The police and the office of the Queens District Attorney are Investigating vandalism at a new, unoccupied, $50,000 home in the Rosedale section of Queens. Neighbors said it took place because area resi dents thought a racially mixed couple was about to move in.

title: U.S. War Deaths, 19 for Week, At Lowest Level Since Late 65
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 10United States battle field deaths last week dropped to the lowest point since the start of the big American troop buildup in Vietnam in late 1965.

title: SON OF MTARTHY FREE IN CAPITAL
description: WASHINGTON, June 10  Michael McCarthy, the 20 yearold son of former Senator Eugene J. McCarthy, was set free today after District of Columbia prosecutors said they were unable to produce evi dence to support a charge of disorderly conduct against him.

title: Mr. Tsarapkin's Travels
description: The current travels of Semyon K. Tsarapkin raise new doubts about the seriousness of Soviet intentions on negotiating mutual force reductions and resolving the Berlin problem. Mr. Tsarapkin is no innocent abroad even though he showed up in Britain without invitation or advance notice. He knows the Atlantic Alliance in sists on a Berlin solution as prerequisite for the cher ished Soviet project of a general European security conference.

title: Prices Close Mixed In Tradingon Amex; Index Advances 0.01
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange yesterday fin ished mixed as dull trading continued.

title: MISSES BLALOCK, AHERN TIED AT 70
description: SUWON, Mass., June 10 (UPI)Jane Blalock and Kathy Ahern braved stiff breezes and tough pin placements today to shoot threeunderpar 70's and share the firstround lead in the $55,000 Ladies Profession al Golfers's Association cham pionship at the Pleasant Valley Country Club course.

title: Prospects for Fishing and Boating This Weekend in Nearby Waters
description: AREA A Bluefishing is picking up generally along the New Jersey shore. At Point Pleasant, catches of 5 or 6 pounds are reported and in the Barnegat waters inshore fisherman are pulling in 2pounders with regularity. Off the Ridge, blues of a bigger species are responding to trolling and chumming. In Barnegat Inlet, stripers are being taken on large shrimp and off Manasquan Ridge, stripers of as much as 30 pounds have been caught. Plenty of flukes in the 3to4 pound range are south of Manasquan Inlet and there is an abundance of ling in the same area, about three miles offshore. Flounder in the 2 pound class are keeping fishermen busy along the beach at Barnegat.

title: Pentagon Is Asked To Explain Its Ad For News Monitor
description: WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) The Pentagon is advertising for bids from small businesses in the Washington area to re cord verbatim all newscasts emanating from all metropolitan area radio and TV stations.

title: Views of Women, In Art and Protest
description: Any institution with the chutzpah to present an art show about women these days is asking for it, as the Brooklyn Museum has just found out. Trying1 sup poseto be topical, it has culled its splendid graphics collection for works on the subject of women, and ar ranged the resulting miscel lany (no pun intended) of more than 150 prints and drawings into Pride and Prejudice: A Woman's Exhi bition.

title: Library Is Planning To Shorten Hours Of Research Units
description: A $1million reduction in funds has forced the curtail ment of hours at the research division of the New York Pub lic Library from 78 hours a week to 40 beginning July 1, Richard W. Couper, president of the library, announced yesterday.

title: Merger News
description: The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation said yesterday it is holding talks with the Chilean Government, at Chile's request, to explore the possible purchase of I.T.T.'s 70 per cent interest in Com pania de Telefonos de Chile, its telephone subsidiary in that country. Of the remaining 30 per cent, 24 per cent is already owned by Corporation de Fomento, a Chilean Government agen cy, and 6 per cent is owned publicly in Chile.

title: Linda Booth Is Bride Of Eric Schweikardt
description: TIBURON, Calif., June 10 Miss Linda Louise Booth, an editor with the Book Find Club in New York, was mar ried here this morning to Eric Schweikardt, a pho tographer for Sports Illus trated. The Rev. John Crum lish performed the ceremony in St. Hilary's Roman Catho lic Church.

title: Earnings of Collins & Aikman For First Quarter Set a Record
description: Record sales and earnings were announced yesterday by Collins & Aikman Corporation for the year's first fiscal quar ter which ended May 29.

title: Cairo Turns the Clock Back
description: President Anwar elSadat's belligerent radiotelevision address this week marked a harsh reversion from the hopefully positive Egyptian diplomacy of recent months to the uncompromising Arab negativism that has brought conflict to the Middle East and humiliation and misery to the Arabs for more than two decades.

title: Solo, or With Group, Elton John Thrills Carnegie Audiences
description: Elton John appeared Thurs day and again last night before an impassioned audience at Carnegie Hall, in what must be the bestproduced rock concert there in a great long while.

title: DR. HAIM SHEBA
description: TEL AVIV, June 11 (AP) Dr. Haim Sheba, director of Tel Hashomer Hospital here for 18 years, died last night of a heart attack. He was 63 years old.

title: Bronx Units Back Roberts
description: The executive committees of the Bronx Democratic and Liberal parties announced yes terday that they had each unanimously nominated the Bronx District Attorney, Bur ton B. Roberts, for a fouryear term in the November election.

title: Nader Plans Bank Study; Focus on City Bank Is Set
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 Ralph Nader, the consumer ad vocate, said today that much more information is needed about how banks operate if citi zens are to be able to evaluate their performance.

title: Bullfight Plea Dismissed
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (UPI)The Federal Communi cations Commission has dis missed an appeal that a closed circuit telecast of a live bull fight be stopped on the ground of cruelty to animals. The Humane Society of the United States asked for a showcause order to block the telecast, scheduled Sunday. It is to be transmitted from Spain by Western Union International, Inc. The commission said yes terday it had no jurisdiction over the telecast, since it was by common carrier.

title: Congress Gets Nixon's Plan To Aid Kin of Slain Police
description: WASHINGTON, June 11. (UPI)The Nixon Administra tion sent Congress today pro posed legislation to provide a $50,000 payment to the sur vivors of any state or local po liceman killed in the line of duty.

title: Now, Is There a Gap Between Generations or Isn't There?
description: WASHINGTONWhen in December, 1969, President Nixon appointed me National Chairman of the White House Conference on Children and Youth my instructions were to listen well to the voices of American youth. I have tried hard to fulfill this Presidential mandate although at times it was been near impossible to hear the voices in the midst of all the shouting.

title: Tonlinttattang
description: HERZBRUNIra and Lillian Elsentadt of Boro Perk are happy to announce the Bar Mitzva of their grandson, Edward Herzbrun, today.

title: JOE NEWMAN JAZZ SHOWS WIDE SCOPE
description: Small jazz groups have a ten dency to mark off a small mu sical area for themselves and to concentrate on this territory to such an extent that their performances soon fall into pre dictable patterns. But the Joe Newman Quintet, which played yesterday afternoon at the Jazz Center, 57 West 57th Street, showed how wide a scope such a group can have with the ap plication of a little imagination.

title: ACCAMBRAY SETS MARK IN HAMMER Kent State Freshman Wins Federation Title at 2135
description: WICHITA, Kan., June 11 Randy Matson and Jacques Accambray shattered meet rec ords with their 16pound im plements today at the United States Track and Field Federa tion's ninth outdoor champion ships at Wichita State Univer sity.

title: A Demilitarized Zone Sought for Angkor Area
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 11 (AP)Cambodia ap pealed today for a demili tarized zone encompassing the ancient ruins of Angkor Wat and Angkor Thom to protect them from battle damage.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. The President met H.E.W. Secretary Elliott L. Richardson and Dr. Roger O. Egeberg, a consultant to the Secretary on health mat ters. Later in the morning the President saw Senator John Sherman Cooper, Republican of Kentucky, and Representa tive Samuel J. Devine, Repub lican of Ohio. He also saw Robert Hill, U.S. Ambassador to Spain. Later in the evening the President attended a wed ding rehearsal dinner for his daughter Tricia at Blair House.

title: U.S. Stepping Up Efforts For Spanish Link to NATO
description: MADRID, June 11  The United States has stepped up its efforts to establish formal links between Spain and the North Atlantic. Treaty Organi zation.

title: Article 5  No Title
description: Article 5  No Title

title: Cosmo 427 Put Into Orbit
description: MOSCOW, June 11 (AP) The Soviet Union launched an other unmanned satellite today in its Cosmos program, Tass, the Soviet press agency, report ed. Cosmos 427 was put into an orbit with the maximum distance from the earth 209 miles and the minimum dis tance 131 miles.

title: U.S.China Relations: Diplomatic Turnaround
description: WARSAW, June 11A car carrying the Chinese Ambas sador to Poland backed into a driveway of the United States Embassy here today, starting a rumor that diplo matic talks were under way between Washington and Peking.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Robert K. Otterbourg, in his recent OpEd article entitled Black Business: A Study in Failure, alleged that black business remains a national failure.

title: Dominican Quake Injures 2 And Damages 4 Buildings
description: SANTO DOMINGO, Domini can Republic, June 11 (AP) An earthquake that registered 6.5 on the Richter scale struck the Dominican Republic today, sending thousands of people into the streets just before 8 A.M. It severely damaged four buildings here, including the Church of Mercy, a relic of Spanish colonialism and a land mark.

title: Dr. Ralph Cleland Dies at 78; Botanist Taught at Indiana U.
description: BLOOMINGTON, Ind., June 11Dr. Ralph Erskine Cleland, Distinguished Service Professor of Botany Emeritus of Indiana University, whose studies of the evening primrose threw light on the theory of evolu tion, died today, apparently of a heart attack, in his office at the university. His age was 78.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX SHOW MIXED TONE
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange finished mixed yes terday for the second consecu tive session in continued light trading.

title: R. C. Herrick Weds Geraldine Hraban
description: PORT JEFFERSON, L. I., June 11Miss Geraldine Su san Elizabeth Anne Hraban, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Louis Hraban of Stony Brook, was married here this evening to Robert Chanler Herrick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clifford Ernest Her rick Jr. of Lexington, Ky., and a greatgrandson of the late Lewis Stuyvesant Chan ler, who was a Lieutenant. Governor of New York.

title: WHEAT FUTURES DIP AFTER RALLY
description: After a weak opening, wheat futures prices rose sharply yes terday but later profit taking halved the gain.

title: James Earl Ray Released From Solitary Confinement
description: PETROS, Tenn., June 11  James Earl Ray is out of solitary confinement and has regained some of his prison privileges after his attempt to escape a month ago, warden Robert II. Moore of Brushy Mountain State Prison said to day. The prison, in the hills of East Tennessee, is the state's maximum security prison.

title: Rumanian Theater Plays Vital Part in Daily Life
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania  As much as any theater in Eastern Europe, the Rumanian theater plays a vital part in national life, and if we hear less of it than of the Czecho slovak or Polish theaters it is largely because the Rumani ans have no taste for heroics. Instead, they have always cultivated the arts of survival.

title: Voting in 8 Model Cities Areas Invalid Due to Irregularities
description: New Model Cities elections will be held June 18 in eight of 21 slum districts because of Irregularities during the bal loting three weeks ago.

title: You Can Have Your Cities
description: JANESVILLE, Wisc.Now they are saying the inland towns are dying, that the prairie towns are giving way to'the coyote's call, the railroad's rumble, and the vast strips of cities we call urban sprawls corrode the landscape.

title: Auto Output Up Sharply
description: DETROIT, June 11 (AP) United States automobile pro duction rebounded sharply this week after a slowdown last week for the Memorial Day hol iday.

title: Whites Joining Minority Groups In University of Florida Protest
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla.  Final examinations were held this week at the University of Flor ida but nobody has yet found an answer to the painful ques tion that disrupted this 22,000 student campus all spring:

title: Article 3  No Title
description: Article 3  No Title

title: Economic Analysis
description: PARIS, June 11French of ficials are dropping hints that the Government is becoming more favorable to exchange rate flexibility.

title: Merger News
description: The General Motors Corpora tion announced yesterday it had submitted a proposal to the Japanese Government to ac quire a 34.2 per cent interest in Isuzu Motors, Ltd., a motor vehicle producer.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, June 11All over Eng land this week children are coming home from school asking their parents for a few pence to give for relief of the East Pakistan refugees. In the newspapers the refugee tragedy has been the dominant story for many days; the largestcirculation tabloid has spread a relief appeal over page one. The House of Commons has been de bating how Britain can do more to help.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The dying of Congressional Medal of Honor winner Dwight Johnson on the floor of a grocery store has the impact of a modern tragedy. Jon Nord heimer's perceptive report of May 26 portrays Sergeant Johnson's feelings of apathy and estrangement, demorali zation by unemployment, a sense of being exploited by the Army even while hospitalized. His haunting fan tasies about being shot at pointblank range were finally lived out in his violent death.

title: HIGH COURT REFUSES TO DELAY A TV SHIFT
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) The Supreme Court declined today to delay the takeover of Channel 3 in Jackson, Miss., by a nonprofit organization.

title: ENGLISH BLUESMEN APPEAR AT GASLIGHT
description: They were peeling English musicians off layer by layer at the Gaslight at the Au Go Go, 152 Bleeker Street, this week. First there was Jon Mark and Johnny Almond, the guitarist and saxophonistcum organistvibraphonist, etc., who came over here two years ago with John Mayall, the seminal English bluesman. They were booked in for a threenight stint during time off from their current tour with Elton John. But after one night, they duck ed out, leaving the field to Long John Baldry, who, like Mr. Mayall, is a seminal Eng lish bluesman.

title: INDIANS EXPELLED FROM ALCATRAZ
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 11 (UPI)A Government force of 35 marshals recaptured Alca traz Island without resistance today, removing 15 Indian hold outs remaining from an occu pation that begun 19 months ago.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The shooting of a polar bear [news story June 6] raises the question: Should zoos be permitted in which ani mals are caged and are at the mercy of visitors who clearly cannot be con trolled?

title: Rhode Island News Bill
description: PROVIDENCE, June 11 (AP) The Rhode Island House gave final legislative approval today to a bill that would protect newsmen from having to dis close confidential information or its source. The measure now goes to Gov. Frank Licht, who is expected to sign it into law.

title: Allende Bloc Defeated in University Vote
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, June 11 Chile's governing Marxist co alition suffered a significant defeat today when a key legal adviser to President Salvador Allende Gossens lost in an at tempt to be elected rector of the University of Chile.

title: Pan Ocean and Bow Valley Awarded Production Rights
description: Pan Ocean Oil Corporation and Bow Valley Industries, Ltd., announced yesterday that their group had been awarded a pro duction license covering Block 25/4 in the Norwegian North Sea. The block contains about 135,000 acres.

title: Reverse Stock Split
description: The Strauss Stores Corpora tion announced yesterday reverse stock split of its com mon shares whereby each two shares of common will be ex chaged for one shares. The effective date of the move will be June 15.

title: Referendum on War Voted
description: CONCORD, N. H., June 11 (AP) The New Hampshire Senate has approved and sent to the House a resolution that provides for a state referen (him on the Vietnam war at the state's Presidential primary next March.

title: Americans Are Barred From Spy Raids in Laos
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 The Nixon Administration has decided that Americans will no longer be permitted to enter southern Laos as leaders of teams keeping watch on enemy movements along the Ho Chi Minh Trail network.

title: SYMPHONY LEAGUE PRESENTS AWARDS
description: SEATTLE, June 11  The Gold Baton, the highest honor of the American Symphony Or chestra League, was awarded posthumously tonight to Martha Baird Rockefeller of New York City, the widow of John D. Rockefeller.

title: 2 BOMBINGS LAID TO 4 IN HOUSTON
description: HOUSTON, June 11A state grand jury investigating right wing terrorism in Houston in dicted four young men on bombing charges today. Two of those indicted have been publicly identified by a leader of the Ku Klux Klan as being klan members.

title: Jersey Beaches Called Unaffected by Sewage
description: New Jersey's Department of Environmental Protection an nounced yesterday that the beaches at Sandy Hook and in the Monmouth County and Raritan Bay areas had not affected by the raw sewage discharge that resulted from the recent New York City strike of municipal workers and would therefore be open to bathers this weekend.

title: Special Hartford Session Opens To Settle State's Budget Issues
description: HARTFORD, June 11 The Connecticut General Assembly went into special session today in a second attempt to work out a state fiscal program for the coming year.

title: New Look at Revenue Sharing
description: The capacity of Representative Wilbur D. Mills make constructive adjustments in his approach to novel legislative ideas is a major factor in the enormous authority he has come to wield as chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee.

title: Shop Talk
description: Ray Urban, a Swedish jew elry designer who recently switched from working with gold to silver, says that he did so because silver is the most difficult metal to conquer. Every surface, every facet, does some thing different when it's pol ished; the final form Isn't seen until the last second. The 42yearold Mr. Urban, who started when he was 5 by making nuts and bolts in his father's hobby shop and went on to get a degree from the Royal Academy of Arts and Crafts in Stockholm, now works in Copenhagen. And it is from the studio that he shares there with Age Faus ing, a silversmith, that has come a collection now being shown at Rosenthal Studio Haus, 584 Fifth Avenue (near 48th Street).

title: Jersey Policeman Acquitted In Boy's Killing in Cemetery
description: JERSEY CITY, June 11 (AP) A Jersey City patrolman was acquitted of a charge of murder today in the shooting of a teen age boy last year in a cemetery in Kearny.

title: Dance: Putting Best Foot Forward
description: A great ballet company is just as good as the great ballet school behind itand the School of American Bal let, the school behind New York City Ballet, is one of the world's best. Every year, in common with most state schools across the world, it gives a performance then shows off the students and gives the public its first chance to get acquainted with the dancers of tomor row and the week after.

title: U.S. Trade Talks At Common Market In Turn for Better
description: BRUSSELS, June 11Trade relations between the United States and the European Eco nomic Community appeared to have taken a decisive turn for the better after two days of talks between Deputy Under secretary of State Nathaniel Samuels and Common Market Commissioner Rolf Dahren dorf.

title: DR. JANE R. WINER OF BOOTH MEMORIAL
description: Dr. Jane R. Winer, director of the rehabilitation medicine department of Booth Memorial Hospital, Flushing, Queens, died Monday of cancer in Me morial Hospital. She was 52 years old and lived at 501 East, 179th Street.

title: The Talk of Palermo
description: PALERMO, Sicily, June 11 The screech of brakes. Re volver shots. The tinkle of broken glass. The wail of a car horn held down by the weight of a dying man. Day after day the sounds of vio lence echo through Palermo's littered streets, followed by the scream of sirens. In recent months a wave of spectac ular crimes has hit many Italian cities, and espe cially this sultry Mediterranean port.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: As a young man over from Ireland in 1910 and driving a team of horses for a chain grocer there was very lit tle respect for a member of the Team sters Union. One time the boss I had admired my horses. He told me they cost plenty money and then reminded me the likes of me he could get for nothing.

title: Wayne Thiebaud's Graphics at Whitney
description: It was only one year ago that the Whitney Museum of American Art established its department of graphics. One might think it odd that one of the country's most impor tant museums took so long to institutionalize a very impor tant art form.

title: Growing Appeal of the Montessori Gospel
description: WASHINGTON  Fiveyearold The ressa Holloway, the youngest of eight children, is completing her second year in a local Montessori school, and if her mother has any complaint, it's that her daughter now sure talks a lot.

title: New York Women Golfers Triumph in Griscom Cup
description: NEWTON, Mass., June 11 (AP) Mrs. Walter Cooperstein and Mrs. Vincent Larkin led New York to a decisive victory over Philadelphia and Boston today in the 65th annual women's in tercity team golf matches for the Griscom Cup.

title: HARVARD NINE WINS SERIES OPENER, 41
description: OMAHA, June 11 (AP) Bill Kelly fashioned a four  hitter and Pete Varney clubbed a two run homer today, giving Har vard a 41 victory over Brigham Young in the opening game of the 25th annual College World Series.

title: Thang Reelected in Hanoi
description: HONG KONG, Saturday, June 12, (Reuters)Ton Duc Thang has been reelected President of North Vietnam, Hsinhua, the Chinese press agency, reported last night, in a dispatch from Hanoi.

title: Pakistani Airlift Plan Causing Concern
description: CALCUTTA, India, June 11 American officials here are growing concerned about their planned airlift of East Pakis tani refugees to camps in India's extreme northeast.

title: Klein Sees Peril to Press In F.T.C.'s Plan on Ads
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., June 11 (AP)  Herbert G. Klein, the Administration's communica tions director, said today that a move by the Federal Trade Commission to require adver tisers to prove contentions about their products posed a precedentsetting danger to a free press.

title: Aid to Be Distributed
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 11An official of the United Nations who has just returned from Pakistan said to day that President Mohammad Agha Yahya Khan's Govern ment would distribute United Nations relief supplies in East Pakistan.

title: KHEEL GETS HEARING ON PORT AGENCY SUIT
description: A Federal judge agreed yes terday to consider whether the Port of New York Authority's covenant with its bondhold ers did in fact amend the inter state compact by which the authority was set up and there fore should have been ap proved, like the compact, by Congress.

title: U.S. Judge Rejects Motions for Mistrial In Corruption Case
description: NEWARK, June 11  Fed eral District Court Judge Robert Shaw today denied several motions from the defense in the Hudson CountyJersey City of ficials corruption trial to de clare a mistrial on the ground that indictments on charges of pension fraud returned by a Hudson County grand jury yes terday might prejudice the chances of a fair trial here.

title: Harriman Asserts Nixon Delays Pullout to Save Saigon Regime
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  W. Averell Harriman, former United States representative at the Vietnam peace talks in Paris, said today that the Ad ministration was unwilling to discuss a date for the with drawal of American troops from Vietnam because it is quite clear that the President wants to see the present Gov ernment in Saigon maintained.

title: DISTRICTS IN SOUTH TOLD TO INTEGRATE
description: RICHMOND, June 11 (UPI) The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit told four Southern school dis tricts today to broaden inte gration plans and warned other education officials in its five state jurisdiction that further delay in achieving desegrega tion will not be tolerated,

title: Senators, in BedfordStuyvesant, Hear Praise for Development Unit
description: Community development corporations that promote economic development in poor communities around the country were praised during a United States Senate sub committee hearing in Brook lyn yesterday as a new hope for the inner city. The daylong hearing was conducted by Senators Edward M. Ken nedy and Jacob K. Javits at the BedfordStuyvesant Res toration Corporation, the largest of some 75 develop ment corporations in the nation. Situated in a newly refurbished, blocklong, for mer milk pasteurizing plant at 136890 Fulton Street, the fouryearold BedfordStuy vesant corporation is budget ed for $6million a year and is one of 37 corporations that receive Federal funds. Sen ator Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, who presided at the meeting of the Sub committee on Employment, Manpower and Poverty, a continuation of the national bearings on the extension of the Economic Opportunity Act, praised the accomplish ments of the Brooklyn unit and said, We must bring the lesson of BedfordStuyvesant to the nation. More than 30 witnessescommunity leaders, politicians, businessmen, resi dents, officials of development corporations from other cities and economiststestified that while the corporations had not solved the problems of poverty they had brought hope to many people.

title: Daubings Protest Geneva Show Of Paintings by AfroAmericans
description: GENEVA, June 11The out side walls and doors of the Rath Museum, where an exhibi tion of works by eight black American artists will open to morrow, were smeared last night with black paint and with the slogans, in English, black power and Kill the pigs.

title: Antiques
description: Auction records were bro ken for the second time in a month last Tuesday when an 18thcentury American desk was sold for $104,000 at the Samuel T. Freeman Galleries in Philadelphia.

title: Hearing on Lenore to Consider Issue of Infant's Best Interests
description: MIAMI, June 11Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas DeMartino, the wouldbe adoptive parents of Baby Lenore, won the chance today for a full hearing in court of their contention that the child's best interests require that she stay with them rather than return to her natural mother.

title: Springs Mills Expands
description: COLUMBIA, S. C., June 11 (UPI)  Springs Mills, Inc., announced today plans to build a $20million knitting, dyeing and finishing plant near Mul lins, S. C., to employ up to 500 persons. Spring Mills has pur(chased a 50acre site and a 73,000squarefoot building at Mullins formerly occupied by Schneider Mills. The plant will be capable of processing double knit, warp knit and woven fila ment fabrics and should be in operation by early 1972, the company said.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: STOCKHOLM, June 11 (UPI) Lieutenant Vequist said in an interview here yesterday that he had left the armed forces because I just felt in my con science that I could not serve in Vietnam; I could not go along with the idea of killing people who had not really harmed American citizens.

title: Grandparents Have Copped Out
description: I would like particularly to talk about the need to develop a new style of aging in our own society. I would like to suggest that maybe we could do a little more for the older Ameri can than, we are doing in the present. Everyone who is aging has a chance to develop this new style. Everyone who is working with old people can contribute to this new style.

title: FLORIDA COLLEGE GIVEN $10MILLION
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., June 11Florida Presbyterian Col lege announced today a com mitment of $8.5million for its endowment fund from Jack M. Eckerd, board chairman of the Jack Eckerd Corporation, and an additional $1.5million to pay off immediately all of the college's shortterm in debtedness.

title: Fatal Nerve Disease Wanes as Cannibalism Is Banned
description: Kuru, one of the strangest and most insidious diseases known, is fading away in its New Guinea habitat, apparent ly because of a ban on ritual istic cannibalism.

title: Solzhenitsyn's Novel Published in Paris
description: PARIS, June 11The Nobel Prizewinning novelist Aleksan dr I. Solzhenitsyn defied So viet censorship with the pub lication here today of what he called the most important work of my life.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It should be obvious to anyone who has followed the recent events in Pakistan that Gen. Yahya Khan's pledge for an orderly transfer of power (news story May 25) is noth ing but a ploy to attract foreign eco nomic assistance which he desperately needs to be able to continue his war of suppression against the Bengalis.

title: Met Opera Soliciting Season Subscriptions
description: The Metropolitan Opera which used to turn people away, is now soliciting sea son subscriptions.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: Front Page 1  No Title

title: DR. HARRY R. BRINDLE
description: BRIELLE, N. T., June 11Dr. Harry R. Brindle, former chief of staff of the Jersey Shore Medical Center in Neptune, died yesterday at the medical center. His age was 62.

title: Philharmonic Offers a Gliere Concerto
description: The New York Philharmon ic's June Promenade concerts being given this weekend are offering the first New York performances of some very pretty music by Reinhold Gliere, the Russian composer. The work is a Concerto for Coloratura and Orchestra, and it was composed during the grim days of World War II.

title: Article 7  No Title
description: Article 7  No Title

title: Court Nullifies F.C.C. License Policy
description: WASHINGTON, June 11A Federal court of appeals here nullified today a 17monthold Federal Communications Com mission policy not to consider license challenges against radio and television stations that have substantially met the programing needs of their com munities.

title: 7 Missing in River Crash
description: CHESTER, June 11 (AP) A car carrying 10 persons plunged into the Mississippi River today, apparently carry ing seven children to their death, the Illinois State Police reported.

title: Roberts Links 2 Holdup Suspects to Police Shootings
description: Bronx District Attorney Bur ton B. Roberts said in court yesterday that evidence con necting two suspects in a so cial club holdup to last month's shooting of two patrolmen on Riverside Drive was in posses sion of the police and the New York County District At torney's office.

title: YANKEES HALT A'S WITH 4RUN RALLY IN EIGHTH, 6 TO 4
description: OAKLAND, Calif., June 11 Like Stan Bahnsen 24 hours earlier, Steve Kline pitched for the Yankees against Oakland tonight just before he had to leave for Army Reserve duty.

title: All Eyes Are on Porsche at Le Mans
description: LE MANS, France, June 11 The race is not always to the swiftest and the way the swiftest are talking, the 39th edition of the 24 Hours of Le Mans might not be a race at all.

title: MARKET MOVES UP FOR SECOND DAY
description: Strength in American Tele phone, which rose 1 points to 46, helped to steady a stock market that saw prices edge higher for the second session in a row.

title: Chicago Bank Board Elects
description: The Inland Steel Company announced yesterday that Fred erick G. Jaicks, president, who becomes chief executive officer July 1, was elected to succeed Joseph Block of the steel com pany on the board of the first National Bank of Chicago, ef fective July 1. Mr. Block will retire as chairman of the ex ecutive committee of Inland on that date.

title: Cambodia May Seek Aid
description: PNOMPENH, June 11 (Reu ters)Two Cambodian generals flew to Saigon for talks with South Vietnamese military lead ers today as fighting just out side Pnompenh reached the heaviest level of the 15month old war.

title: Naughton Defends Role at Lockheed
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 Daniel J. Haughton, chairman of the board of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation, defended his company today against charges that it has been mis managed to its present state of nearbankruptcy.

title: PROGRAM SPEEDS MEDICAL TRAINING
description: The University of Miami an nounced yesterday that it would begin a program next month to train doctoral scien tists to become medical doc tors after two years of addi tional education.

title: NGUYEN VAN TUOI
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 11 (UPI)  Nguyen Van Tuoi, publisher of the Vietnam Guardian, one of Saigon's three Englishlanguage daily newspapers, died today after twoweek illness. He was 48 years old.

title: BOSTON FIRM CITED IN S.E.C. COMPLAINT
description: BOSTON, June 11 (AP)The Securities and Exchange Com mission said today it has filed a complaint in Federal court seeking a preliminary injunc tion against C. H. Wagner & Co., Inc., a Boston broker dealer and its president, Clar ence H. Wagner, from further alleged violation of the com mission's net capital rule.

title: 2 Die in Mine Accident
description: MORGANTOWN, W. Va., June 11 (UPI)Two miners were killed today and two were injured when a roof collapsed in a tunnel 830 feet below the surface in the Federal No. 2 soft coal mine, about 20 miles northwest of here. Don Levelle, 41 years old, of nearby Man nington, and Richard McCauley, 43, of Cassville, were killed. State and Federal mine offi cials began an investigation into the accident, which oc curred about 1 miles inside the mine. It was the first fatal accident at the mine, which began operations five years.

title: EEC BIDS U.S. ACCEPT PRINCIPLE OF PARITY IN ARMS
description: MOSCOW, June 11Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Communist party leader, called on the United States today to accept military parity with the Soviet Union and join in efforts to insure equal security for both sides.

title: Miss Austin Cards a 68 for 141 Total to Lead L. P.G. A. Golf by Three Shots
description: SUTTON, Mass., June 11 (AP)  Debbie Austin, a 23 yearold blonde bidding for her first victory since turning pro in 1968, tied the course record with a fiveunderpar 68 today to take the lead at the half way mark of the $55,000 Eve Ladies Professional Golf Asso ciation championship.

title: Yonkers Harness Racing
description: Yonkers Harness Racing

title: Article 9  No Title
description: Article 9  No Title

title: Japanese to Deal In Foreign Stocks
description: TOKYO, June 11 (Reuters) The Finance Ministry an nounced today that Japanese individuals would be allowed to buy and sell foreign securities starting July 1.

title: WILLIAM G. GRACE, SHIPS ENGINEER
description: BATH, Me., June 11  Wil liam G. Grace, who aided in the rescue of the crew of the submarine S5 in 1920, died in Bath Memorial Hospital yes terday after a long illness. He was 85 years old.

title: FRIGIDAIRE PLANS TO LAY OFF 1,152
description: DAYTON, Ohio, June 11 The Frigidaire division of the General Motors Corporation has announced it will lay off 1,152 more hourly employes on June 18, raising the total employe cutback since last No vember's labor contract nego tiations to 3,222.

title: A ROLE IN. CLASH DENIED BY MEXICO
description: MEXICO CITY, June 11The Mexican Government said to day that it was not involved in any way in last night's armed attack on an antiGov ernment student demonstration.

title: Ann Robinson Moore Is Married
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., June 11Miss Ann Robinson Moore, daughter of Comdr. Sumner Kittelle Moore, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Moore of Alexandria, was married here this evening to Richard Hustis Milnor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bennett Mil nor Jr. of Mountain Lakes, N. J. The Rev. Samuel E. Purdy, assister by the Rev. Leon N. Laylor, performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

title: Laverne Hanover Triumphs in Good Time Pace by Nose
description: YONKERS, June 11At the finish of the $35,000 mileand aquarter Good Time Pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight, George Sholty, driving Laverne Hanover, wasn't sure he had won and Jack Kopas, handling Super Wave, wasn't sure he had Jost. The camera separated them, giving Laverne Hanover a nose decision over the Cana dianowned Super Wave.

title: Sergeant Given Discharge And a Fine for Kickbacks
description: HUNTSVILLE, Ala., June 11 (UPI)M. Sgt. William E. Hig don has been sentenced to a dishonorable discharge and fined $25,000 by a military jury that convicted him of accepting kickbacks and misappropriating funds while operating an en listed men's club in Vietnam.

title: METROPOLITAN PLANS AIRCRAFT COVERAGE
description: The Metropolitan Life Insur ance Company based in New York State, is planning to enter the aircraft insurance business, according to Gilbert W. Fitz hugh, chairman of the board. It has to wait, however, until enabling legislation, passed last week by the New York State Legislature, is signed by Gov ernor Rockefeller.

title: Yuba City Witness Freed
description: YUBA CITY, Calif., June 11 (UPI)Sheriff Roy D. Whiteaker said today that a material wit ness in the Yuba City mass slayings had been released sub ject to a subpoena to testify at a preliminary hearing for Juan V. Corona. Mr. Corona, 37yearold labor contractor has been charged with slaying 10 of 25 men whose bodies were found in graves along the banks of the Feather River. The material witness, Juan C. Mos queda, 50, was arrested Monday, in Stockton and released yes terday.

title: Books of The Times
description: In The Live Goat, Cecil Dawkins's tal ent is a plant too big for its pot. The book is one of those symbolic journey affairs in which everyone gallops toward a con frontation with himself. The landscape is spiritual, rocky with rhetoric, the weather heavy. The comparison with Faulkner hangsinappropriatelyin the air. Southern writers with metaphysical lean ings seem to dote on halfwits  if Miss Dawkins's Isaac is one. Young, deaf and dumb as well as halfwitted, he murders Eily on the morning of her wedding day. He loves her, and murder is a sign of strong emotions in Southern meta physics. Murder and bombast. When he flees on a neighbor's prize mule, the dead girl's father and a number of neighborsincluding a mannish womanride out after him for some 500 miles,

title: Financial Control Bidding Is Open for Hockey Team
description: VANCOUVER, British Colum bia, June 11 (AP)Financial control of the Vancouver Ca nucks of the National Hockey League became open for bids today, a day after a United States company failed to repay a $3.5 million debt.

title: Article 12  No Title
description: ANCHORAGE, Alaska, June 11 (UPI)An earthquake at the bottom of the Pacific Ocean, 130 miles west of Amchitka Island, was detected today. It registered 6.6 on the Richter scale.

title: Article 11  No Title
description: Article 11  No Title

title: 11th, 12th OTB Shops Due to Open Next Week
description: The city's Offtrack Betting Corporation will open two new offices next week, in creasing its total to 12.

title: Estimate card Asks Cut In Albany Tax Package
description: A revised city budget that could avoid imposing $69mil lion of the new taxes author ized by Albany was suggested yesterday by the Board of Estimate.

title: WORTV Promotes Snowden
description: George W. Snowden, WOR TV's programing director, has been named the station's vice president in charge of pro graming, it was announced yesterday by Robert L. Glaser, Channel 9's vice president and general manager. Before join ing WORTV in May, Mr. Snowden held various posi tions with the Columbia Broadcasting System.

title: PENTAGON REJECTS PROXMIRE CHARGES
description: WASHINGTON, June 11, (UPI)The Pentagon accused Senator William Proxmire to day of seeking publicity in charging that the Pentagon plans to expand snooping ac tivities by recording and transcribing Washington area news broadcasts.

title: Excerpts on Foreign Policy From the Address to Voters by Brezhnev in Moscow
description: Following are excerpts from a summary of a speech de livered yesterday by Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet Com munist party leader, at an election meeting in Moscow. The summary was distrib uted in New York by the Soviet press agency, Tass.

title: Overdoses of Illegal Methadone Lead to Deaths of 5 in the City
description: Five persons died in a recent fiveday period from drinking overdoses of illicitly obtained methadone, the Medical Exam iner's office reported yesterday.

title: DAVID PIKE
description: David Pike, a real estate broker, died on Thursday eve ning while visiting friends in Long Beach, L.I. He was 60 years old and lived in Pom pano Beach, Fla.

title: Mitchell Upholds Wiietap Of Dangerous Radicals
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 Attorney General John N. Mitchell said today that never in our history has this country been confronted with so many revolutionary elements deter mined to destroy by force the Government and the society it stand's for.

title: Minor League Slates Draft
description: The fourteam Atlantic Coast Football League said yesterday it would hold its player draft at Roanoke, Va., on Monday.

title: $7.4Million for Florida Aid
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) The Labor Department said today that $7.4million in dis aster relief had been paid to more than 28,000 Florida farm workers left jobless after a freeze destroyed crops last winter.

title: Chemical Makers Increase Prices Of Some Lines
description: Price increases were an nounced yesterday on a variety of chemical products. Dow Chemical U.S.A., a unit of the Dow Chemical Corporation, said it will raise the price of four propylene series dowanol glycol ethers by onehalf of a cent a pound, effective June 151 to spot customers and July 1 to contract customers. The sol vents are chemical intermedi ates used in a variety of resin, coating and specialty applica tions.

title: VATICAN REVISES ANNULMENT RULES
description: ROME, June 11The Vatican announced today new legal procedures to expedite the handling of petitions for annul ment of Roman Catholic mar riages.

title: WEEK IS ACTIVE FOR NEW ISSUES
description: The newissue market sprang to life this week in what trad ers described as one of the busiest periods so far this year.

title: Article 8  No Title
description: VIENNA, June 11 (UPI)  Czechoslavakia led the Soviet Union, 10, today at the end of the first day's play in a Euro pean semifinal of the Davis Cup. Frantisek Pala beat Vlad imir Korotkov, 63, 64, 75.

title: Breckinridge Goodwin Is Wed To William T. Longstreth Jr.
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 11 St. MartinintheFields Epis copal Church, Chestnut Hill, was the setting this after noon for the marriage of Miss Breckinriclge Goodwin to William Thacher Long streth Jr., son of Mr. Long streth, Republican candidate for Mayor of Philadelphia, and Mrs. Longstreth of Chest nut Hill. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. E. Howard Goodwin of New York, where her father is manager of sales for the Bethlehem Steel Corporation. He was formerly sales man ager of the Philadelphia dis trict for the company.

title: YOUTH IS ARRAIGNED IN STONING OF TRAIN
description: A Bronx teenager who al legedly hurled a rock through a window of a train, causing a Penn Central conductor to lose an eye and another to suf fer impaired vision, was ar raigned yesterday in the Bronx.

title: Libel Law Restricted
description: The latest Supreme Court ruling in the troubled area of libel law significantly extends the protection of freedom of speech and press provided by the First Amendment. In a case involving this newspaper, which was decided in 1964 and in subsequent cases, the Court held that public officials and wellknown public per sonalities could not collect libel damages unless they could prove that a defamatory falsehood was printed with knowledge that it was false or with reckless disregard of whether it was false or not.

title: HERMAN Z. ROTHSTEIN
description: Herman Z. Rothstein, a law yer who practiced in Harlem for 55 years, died on Thursday at his home, 941 Jerome Ave nue, the Bronx. He was 81 years old.

title: F14 Manager Named
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (UPI) Capt. Leonard A. Snead, corn mending officer of the aircraft carrier Forrestal, has been se lected for a promotion to rear admiral. He will take over next month the management of the financially troubled F14 fighter plane program. He will succeed Capt. Lionel E. Ames as Navy manager of the program.

title: GRAEBNER GAINS KENT SEMIFINALS
description: BECKENHAM, England, June 11 (AP)  Topseeded Clark Graebner of New York and Stan Smith of Pasadena, Calif., ad vanced today to the men's semi finals in the Kent lawn tennis championships.

title: 3 Salyut Astronauts Perform Weightlessness Tests
description: MOSCOW, June 11 (AP) The three men aboard the Salyut space station devoted their work schedule today to scientific experiments and studies on the effects of weightlessness.

title: Miss McGivern Wed Here to James Shea
description: Miss Eileen McGivern of Ossining, N. Y., and James Michael Shea of Brooklyn were married here yesterday afternoon in the Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral, The Rev. Vincent J. P. Fox performed the ceremony.

title: Toward Chaos on Rails
description: Refusal of the Supreme Court to review a lower court decision giving railroad unions an enigmatically qualified right to call selective strikes injects new uncertainty into the chaotic structure of rail labormanagement rela tions. This legal puzzle adds urgency to the longexisting need for Congressional action to provide effective public protection against transportation strike emergencies.

title: RECORDER FINDS DC9 FLEW FOR 8 MINUTES
description: DUARTE, Calif., June 11 (UPI) The flight recorder recovered from the wreckage of an Air West DC9 showed today that the plane was airborne for only eight minutes before it collided with a military jet, killing 50 persons.

title: New G.E. AirConditioners
description: The General Electric Com pany announced in Louisville, Ky., yesterday that it Is intro during three 1972 room air conditioners in the medium capacity range. They will be available to retailers as they are manufactured here late this month. The three new Thinline 1972 units, will carry prices about 5 per cent higher than their 1971 counterparts.

title: Hatred Now Splits Pakistanis in Britain, Too
description: BRADFORD, England, June 6At dusk the Pakistani men gather in clubhouses along Lumb Lane and Corn wall Terrace, sipping sweet tea and speaking in whis pered fury.

title: Ross Gains Net Semifinal
description: Steve Ross of Brooklyn, Vitas Gerulaitis of Howard Beach, Queens, and Bill Colson, a Princeton student from Coral Gables, Fla., yesterday reached the semifinals of the New York State men's tennis champion ships at the North Shore Tennis and Racquets Club, Bayside, Queens. Ross defeated Tony Vincent of New York, 6.2, 63. Gerulaitis beat Dr. Hal German of New York, 6.3, 62, and Col son eliminated Claude Schoen lank of Staten Island, 6.0, 3.6, 62.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: Article 4  No Title

title: SEAGRAM'S PROFIT ROSE IN QUARTER
description: Sales and earnings of Dis tillers CorporationSeagrams, Ltd. rose in the quarter and ninemonth period ended April 30, the company announced yesterday.

title: PHILIP M'SWEEN, 67, FINANCE EXECUTIVE
description: ARLINGTON, Va., June 11 Philip A. MacSween, former president and chief executive officer of the American Install ment Credit Corporation, died today in the Arlington Hospital after a long illness. He was 67 years old and had lived here since moving from Floral Park, L.I., in 1960.

title: Notes on People
description: I must say that I am thrilled, the new knight at the opera said yesterday. This honor comes at the right moment, when hardly anyone is talking to me any more.

title: Naum Gabo, Sculptor, Gets Order of the British Empire
description: Naum Gabo, the pioneer con structivist sculptor, has been made an Honorary Knight Com mander of the Order of the British Empire. The badge and star of the order were present ed to Mr. Gabo earlier this week in Washington by Lord Cromer, the British Ambassador, in rec ognition of outstanding serv ices to Great Britain and Anglo American relations.

title: Medical Institute Plans Strong Policy
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  The first president of the Na tional Academy of Sciences new Institute of Medicine said today that his organization in tended to be vigorous and ag gressive in confronting health issues important to the nation.

title: U.M.W. Official Convicted
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) Ray Thornbury, 56 years old, of Lebanon, Va., a United Mine Workers official, was convicted yesterday by a Federal district court jury of embezzling union funds. The money allegedly was used in the 1969 reelection campaign of W. A. Boyle, the union president. Thornbury faces a possible maximum sen tence of five years in jail, a $10,000 fine, or both.

title: Members of the Medical Institute
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 Following is a list of the mem bers of the Institute of Medicine of the National Academy of Sciences whose names were made public today:

title: Town Hall Will Present Jazz on Saturday Evenings
description: A series of six Saturday evenings jazz events entitled Connoisseur Concerts will be presented by Town Hall from July 10 through Aug. 14.

title: Market Place A Rich Old Bag Enjoys Investing
description: Ask a man, Do you trust your wife? and he'll prob ably tell you, Yes. But add the phrase  with mon ey? and he may say, No.

title: NIXON TO ENFORCE RIGHTS MEASURES FOR U.S. HOUSING
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  President Nixon pledged today to enforce existing prohibitions against racial discrimination in housing, but said he would not use Federal leverage to force local communities to accept low and moderateincome housing against their wishes.

title: No Time for Mudslinging
description: Respect for city and state government is damaged by the escalating verbal warfare between Governor Rocke feller and Mayor Lindsay. It is obvious that no solvent can wipe out the unfortunate personal animosities be tween the two leaders. But the electorate has a right to insist that these animosities be kept out of the de termination of public policy at Albany and City Hall. It has an equal right to expect that both officials will maintain civility in their public expressions about one another.

title: Excerpts From President's Statement on Federal Equal Housing Policies
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 Following are excerpts from President Nixon's statement today on Federal policies on equal housing:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: A May 27 letter from Daniel Bauch charged that Ralph Nader and a clutch of law students had petitioned the Federal Trade Commission asking that the automobile industry somehow be compelled to stop changing car styles.

title: Annapolis Names Dean
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 11 (AP)Dr. Bruce M. Davidson,. chairman of the Department of Civil Engineering at Wash ington State University in Pullman, Wash., has been ap pointed academic dean of the United States Naval Academy. He will assume his new duties in July. He relieves Dr. Ed ward J. Cook, who has been serving as the academy's interim academic dean since the death of Dr. A. Bernard Drought last September.

title: Largest Soviet Steel Mill Is Set for Central Russia
description: MOSCOW, June 11The So viet Union plans to build up an existing Mill into the na tion's largest iron and steel plant in the heart of European Russia, near the principal metal markets.

title: Brandt Reform Plans a Shift of Tax Burden to Rich
description: BONN, June 11  Chancellor Willy Brandt's Government announced today plans for a major tax reform program aimed at easing the burden on lowincome groups and increas ing taxes on the rich.

title: AIR FORCE OPENS OFFICER'S HEARING
description: LAKENHEATH, England, June 11  The United States Air Force today opened an official public investigation of Capt. Thomas S. Culver, a legal offi cer involved in antiwar activ ities.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 Harry and James Huisman of New York will receive a pat ent June 22 for the methods they use in cutting 144 facets on their diamonds  a far greater number of reflecting sur faces, they say, than other dia mond cutters sup ply. Patent 3, 585,764 refers to parts of the elaborate pattern created by the process as promoting the extraordinary fire and brilliance of the resulting gem. According to Harry Huisman, most other dia mond cutters are content with. 58 facets, or a few more.

title: Hudson County Reform Group Plans AllOut Election Drive
description: JERSEY CITY, June 11  A coalition of reforrn political forces in Hudson County today announced an allout election drive this November against the scandalridden Hudson County and Jersey City Democratic or ganizations.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The Times June 8 headline Javits Blesses McCloskey's Bid was mislead ing. I did not give my blessing to Rep resentative McCloskey's challenge to President Nixon. I have not changed my position of supporting President Nixon for reelection as of now. I said at my news conference that I thought the Republican insurgency is helpful, and that any ferment in the party, making it lively and provocative, is desirable. I said I bless those engaging in the insurgency for doing so.

title: Amin's Uganda Delegation Wins Seats at O.A.U. Talks
description: ADDIS ARABA, Ethiopia, June 11 (UPI)President Idi Amin's Uganda delegation won a nocontest victory for seats at a ministerial session of the Organization of African Unity today. But the delegation said it would boycott next week's ministerial meeting and a later summit session.

title: Plane Hijacked In Africa
description: LUANDA, Angola, Saturday, June 12 (UPI)A Portuguese plane on a chartered flight from Luanda was hijacked to day to Pointe Noire in the Re public of the Congo, ANI, the Portuguese press agency, said.

title: REAGAN SPEECH FEE CLARIFIED BY G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) The Republican National Committee said today that Gov ernor Ronald Regan of Califor nia had agreed to make fund raising speeches for the party for a fee of $25,000 or 20 per cent of the gross, whichever is smaller, for each appearance.

title: DOLLAR GLUT SEEN TROUBLING S.D.R'S
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, June 11The glut of dollars is buy ing troubles for Special Draw ing Rights, the world's newest reserve asset.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: With the reference to your editorial suggestion of May 24 that the United States and other members of the World Bank's AidtoPakistan Con sortium stick to their reported de mand that the Yahya Government seek a political accommodation with the Bengalis as a condition for the re sumption of assistance for Pakistan, I must point out that thq proposal is fraught with what could be grave consequences.

title: Article Questioning STP Halts Trading of Stock
description: Trading in STP Corporation stock was halted all day yes terday in the wake of an article by Consumer Reports stating that the company's oil treatment for automobile engines is actually a worth less oil thickener that may violate a new car's warranty.

title: Article 10  No Title
description: Article 10  No Title

title: Talk of the Wedding
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 Edward Finch Cox walked Tricia Nixon home tonight. It wasn't far  just a few yards across Pennsylvania Avenue from Blair House to the White House. But, for the first time since their friends and families gathered in the capital for the latest White House wed ding, the pros pective bride and groom acted, in public, like a couple in love. Tricia said her two rehears als this afternoon went well and her rehearsal dinner in Blair House was beautiful.

title: Witness in Colombo Trial Draws 9 Months in Jail
description: Richard Salomone, pri nci pal Government witness in the trial last February of Joseph A. Colombo Jr. for conspiring to melt silver coins, was sentenced yesterday to nine months im prisonment after pleading guilty to the conspiracy charge on which Colombo was acquitted.

title: Bridge: Fallibility of Experts Shown By Deal in World Title Play
description: Those few readers of this column who are prepared to admit that their bridge game is not always completely ac curate can be comforted by the thought that the experts are also human.

title: Postel Says Cuite, a Realty Man, Killed 70 Council Housing Bills
description: The majority leader of the City Council was accused yes terday of an obvious and ap parent conflict of interest be tween his position as president of a realty concern and his legislative duties.

title: U.S. TROOPS WAGE FIVEHOUR BATTLE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 11 (AP)  An American armored column patrolling the southern edge of the demilitar ized zone yesterday ran into a North Vietnamese force, touch ing off a fivehour battle, the United States command report ed today.

title: Constantino Sworn as Judge
description: Mark A. Costantino of Staten Island was sworn in yesterday as a judge of the United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York. The new 51yearold judge has served since 1958 as an acting justice of the State Supreme Court. He was first elected to the former City Court in 1956. He will as sume his new duties on Mon day.

title: Mayors Plead for U.S. Aid
description: WASHINGTON, June 11  Mayor Lindsay and a group of his fellow bigcity Mayors ap pealed to the House Ways and Means Committee today to en act some form of revenue sharing program. They received in turn, strong hints from some committee members that fiscal help for the cities may be on the way.

title: A Lawyer Finds Happiness as Dress Designer
description: Eight years ago Sara Shel burne left her native Rich mond, Va., to study law abroad. Today, she's happy as a lark, living in Paris in an apartment in Montmartre with a huge terrace and loads of flowers.

title: Suffolk County Democrats Delay Designating Session
description: CENTEREACH, L. I., June 11 The Suffolk County Demo cratic chairman, Dominic J. Baranello, announced today that the party's annual desig nating convention, originally scheduled for next Thursday, was being postponed until June 21.

title: General, Censured Over Mylai Killings, Will Retire June 30
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) An Army general censured for allegedly failing to meet the required standards of per formance in investigating the Mylai massacre will retire June 30.

title: Approval Is Granted for Acquisition of 35% of Mitsubishi Motor
description: TOKYO, June 11 (AP)The Japanese Government granted approval today for the Chrysler Corporation to acquire a minor ity interest in the Mitsubishi, Motor Corporation. The linkup with the American automobile maker was the culmination of an effort begun by the two companies in 1968.

title: Fort Marcy Heads Field Of 8 at Belmont Today
description: The situation will be just about normal for a Saturday at Belmont Park today, in contrast to last week's activity, which drew a record total of 82,299 fans to the Belmont Stakes.

title: Vocal Chamber Music is Given In Cozy Evening at Tully Hall
description: Alice Tully Hall is a mite larger than most parlors, but it served admirably instead of one Thursday night. Eight mu sicians from the Metropolitan Opera Studio, plus one piano, added up to a cozy night of the sort that used to be com mon in the days when there were far fewer people in the world but far more parlors with pianos in them. An Evening of Vocal Chamber Music, as the program was called, was pre sented as part of the Hall's Sampler series.

title: 3 Arabs Reported Killed In 2 Gaza Strip Incidents
description: TEL AVIV, dune 11 Bomb attacks today killed two Arab workers in the Gaza Strip who had been waiting for buses to take them to their jobs in Israel, according to an official announcement here. Eightyone Arabs in the area, which is occupied by Israel, were reported injured.

title: Black City Policeman Assails Transfers to Political Infiltration
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 11 The president of the Guardians Association, whose members include most of the 2,300 black policemen in New York City, said today that black patrol men and detectives were being transferred from narcotics un dercover work to political in filtration.

title: Giants Defeat Mets in 10th, 32
description: The New York Mets carried 52,486 persons in Shea Stadiurh through the Perils of Pauline for 10 innings last night befere losing to the San Francisco Giants, 32, on a mixup be tween their catcher and pitcher.

title: Cambodian Battle Continues
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 11 (AP)  Cambodian authori ties ordered a news blackout today on the battle for the Vihear Suor marshland, which is 12 miles east of the capital of Pnompenh and part of its defense line.

title: BANK OF ENGLAND IN WARNING ON PAY
description: LONDON, June 11 (Reuters) The Bank of England warned today that rapid inflation would continue in Britain un less the British Government curbed pay demands.

title: Garcia Heads Filipino Parley
description: MANILA, June 11The con stitutional convention, which convened June 1 to institute political and social reforms, has elected as its president Carlos P. Garcia, who was President of the Philippines from 1957 to 1961.

title: WALDORF DEFENDS SUNDRIES CHARGE
description: The WaldorfAstoria Hotel yesterday defended as legiti mate and necessary its former practice of adding to guests bills fee for sundries that amounted to 2 per cent of the room charge.

title: Major League Box Scores
description: Major League Box Scores

title: City Hospital Meeting Upset by Fights
description: A steady barrage of insults and profanity, interrupted, by an outbreak of fist fights, greeted the directors of the city hospital system yesterday at the first public meeting they have held since they took over last July 1.

title: Lunn Gets 6UnderPar 66 For 135 to Lead Golf by Shot
description: CHARLOTTE, N, C., June 11 Bob Lunn, who found a for mula to reduce his weight, in dicated he had another for re ducing his golf score today. With a sixunderpar 66 in the second round of the $150.000 Kemper open, the 26yearold Californian led by one stroke with a 36hole aggregate of 135.

title: MRS. ETHEL PAULLIN, PAINTERDECORATOR
description: BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y., June 11Mrs. Ethel Parsons Paul lin, a painter and decorator, died Wednesday at High Ridge House, a sanitarium here. She was 83 years old and lived at 54 West 74th Street in Manhat tan, Her husband was the late Telford Paullin.

title: LOUIS BRUNO
description: Louis Bruno, publisher of The TriBoro Post, a weekly, died Thursday of a heart ailment in Coney Island Hospital. He was 52 years old and lived at 2356 McDonald Avenue, Brooklyn.

title: The Ugly Face of Race Hatred in Queens
description: The two women sitting on the porch of their house mid way down 148th Drive in Rosedale, Queens, wondered what all the fuss was about.

title: ASSISTANT MANAGER APPOINTED FOR MET
description: Schuyler G. Chapin hap been named assistant manager of the Metropolitan Opera, begin ning with the 197273 season. Goeran Gentele, who becomes the company's general manager that season, has announced the appointment. No details about Mr. Chapin's responsibilities were disclosed.

title: COURT ORDER ISSUED IN WELFARE CASES
description: The state and the Westches ter County commissioners of so cial services were directed yes terday to show cause in Fed eral Court next Tuesday why they should not be held in con tempt for refusing to comply with an Oct. 14, 1969, order of the court that enjoined them from applying a oneyear resi dency requirement for welfare assistance.

title: Hijacker Is Seized at Kennedy After Man Is Killed in Chicago
description: A hijacker surrendered to the police early this morning at Kennedy Airport after board ing the plane in Chicago in gun battle that left one man dead.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Coastal States Gas Producing Company an nounced yesterday the appointment of Harry G. Fair as president, succeeding Oscar S. Wyatt, Jr., who continues as chairman and chief executive of ficer. Mr. Fair was previously an executive vice president of Pullman, Inc.

title: Elizabeth W. Pearson Is a Bride
description: NEWBURY, Mass., June 11  Miss Elizabeth Winsor Pearson and Daniel Davis Savage were married here this afternoon.

title: Yale's Repertory Theater Plans a Rotating Policy
description: The Yale Repertory Theater will institute a policy of rotat ing repertory with its sixth year of professional operation start ing Oct. 14.

title: Governor Warns a Union On Plan for a State Strike
description: ALBANY, June 11Governor Rockefeller attempted today to avert a strike of state employes due to begin at midnight next Wednesday, and he warned that the state would impose the full penalties of the Taylor Law if the strike occurred.

title: HARRY DEJUR
description: Harry DeJur, a founder and a former officer of DeJur Amsco, Inc., photographic products concern, died yester day in London, apparently of a heart) attack. He was 78 years old and lived at 24 Cen tral Park South.

title: Allot Sues President Over Housing Funds
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 11 (UPI)Mayor Joseph L. Ali oto sued President Nixon to day, demanding that the Ad ministration release $350mil lion in urban renewal and housing funds.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: ExPlohn Officer Barred From Brokerage Firms
description: The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that Edward C. Jaegerman, former managing partner of Charles Plohn & Co., had been permanently barred from association or employment with any member organiza tion of the exchange.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Swifty Knox, the manager, led a group or newsmen through the locker room. The Birds were sprawled on benches and chairs, sweatsoaked, beaten. The relief pitchers had stuffed themselves into the top shelves of their lockers, and the first baseman was unsuccessfully trying to drown himself in the diathermy tub. Every time he jumped in, the water slopped out.

title: Art: Guggenheim Greets the Summer
description: It is one of the ironies of modern museological practice that socalled permanent collections are so little avail able to the public so much of the time. Museums are constantly acquiring new ad ditions to their permanent collections, but these collec tions are more often in stor age than on public exhibition.

title: Battle on Air Fares To Europe Widens To Include All Ages
description: The world's airlines, which are embroiled in a chaotic price war over youth fares, are on the verge of an even more bit ter battle over the cost of transAtlantic tickets for the notsoyoung.

title: Democrats Tighten Rules On Convention Next Year
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 The Democratic National Con vention of 1972 will ban all floor demonstrations and lengthy speeches, shake up the traditional alphabetical rollcall and make the nomination of favoriteson candidates all but impossible.

title: HUNGARIAN TO GET A DEGREE UPSTATE
description: SCHENECTADY, N. Y., June 11A thaw along the academic front of the cold war will take place here tomorrow when an eminent Hungarian novelist playwrighteditor receives an honorary degree and delivers the commencement address at Union College.

title: London's New Buildings Are Closer to Miami
description: LONDON, June 10If you think of London as a grand, grayskied city of pomp, cir cumstance and Portland stone, think again. And put on your sunglasses.

title: A Training School for Public RelationsMilitary Style
description: INDIANAPOLISTraining for military public relations, a program now in a storm of controversy, takes place in tranquil, bucolic setting on the outskirts of this city.

title: SPIESS IS MANRICO IN MET TROVATORE
description: Il Trovatore can subsist very well on robust vocalism, although it would be nice to have some musical sensibility as well. Since Thursday night's performance of the Verdi work by the Metropolitan Opera was long on the first quality, if short on the second, it was at least a rousing experience.

title: Soviet Ship Held on Coast 3 More Days in Lobster Suit
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 11 (UPI)The Soviet freighter Su leyman Stalskiy was ordered today to remain in port here for at least three more days while a Federal court decides whether it was proper to seize her because of a Massachusetts lobsterman's lawsuit against the Soviet Union.

title: Consumer Group Elects
description: The Coordinating Commit tee for Consumer Protection in the metropolitan area yes terday elected Bess Myerson, the city's Commission of Con sumer Affairs, as its new chairman. Eugene Gold, the Brooklyn District Attorney, was elected vice chairman. The committee is a cooperative venture formed by Federal, state and local agencies to pool information on consumer complaints.

title: U.S. Army in Germany Lists Antiwar Officer as Deserter
description: HEIDELBERG, West Ger many, June 11 (UPI)A United States Army spokesman said today that First Lieut. John R. Vequist, a West Point graduate who disappeared from his artil lery unit three weeks ago, has been listed as a deserter.

title: Roundup: Dodgers Trio Paces 121 Rout of Expos
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers threw three coins in the fountain during the offseason and obtained three wishes the persons of Rich Allen, Al Downing and Duke Sims.

title: C.A.B. Clears Storer Loan To Aid Northeast Airlines
description: WASHINGTON, June 11, (AP)  The Civil Aeronautics Board gaev the Storer Broad casting Company, Miami, per mission today to lend an addi tional $1million to Northeast Airlines, Boston.

title: Board of Hospitals Corporation
description: The board of directors of the Health and Hospitals Corporation consists of five city officials who serve ex officio, plus 10 unpaid members who are appointed, half by the Mayor and half by the City. Council.

title: Saigon Announces Changes in Cabinet
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sat urday, June 12  President Nguyen Van Thieu, moving to strengthen his Government's position before the legislative and presidential elections here later this year, today made the first important changes in his Cabinet since its formation in September, 1969.

title: Retreat on Reapportionment
description: The Supreme Court's ruling in Baker vs. Carr in 1962 against the unfair, undemocratic apportionment of legis lative districts was a historic accomplishment. That decision and those which derive from it broke the rural grip which had been strangling many state legislatures, did away with the startling disparities in population between comparable legislative and Congressional dis tricts, and rescued Negroes from various kinds of racially inspired gerrymandering.

title: TV Newsman Sentenced
description: LOS ANGELES, June 11 (AP) Stan Duke, a television sportscaster, was sentenced today to a prison term of five years to life for the slaying of Averill Berman, a radio newsman, at the home of Mr. Duke's estranged wife last Feb. 7. Superior Court Judge James Kolts imposed the sen tence on Duke, 35 years old, after denying defense motions for a new trial and for reduc tion of the seconddegree mur

title: Amtrak President Names Five to Executive Posts
description: WASHINGTON, June 11 (UPI) Amtrak, the recently formed National Railroad Passenger Corporation has named four new vice presidents and a con troller.

title: 2 RIGA REFUGEES GRADUATED HERE
description: How do you get accustomed to freedom, asked Gabriel Goldberger.

title: L.I. Boatmen Form Committee To Oppose New Pollution Code
