description: PORT WASHINGTON,. L.I., June 12The problem of pro viding sanitary holdingtanks for boats has reached such state of concern in the North Shore area that boatmen have banded together to fight what they consider unenforceable and unconstitutional laws.

title: Susan Shenker Plans Nuptials
description: Miss Susan Shenker, a stu dent at the Hebrew Univer sity in Jerusalem, plans to be married to Lieut. Moshe Zirkel of the Israeli Army on June 29 at Kibbutz Shoval in the Negev, Israel.

title: Queen Now Reigns Over Busy Fleet Of Landbound Ships
description: LONG BEACH, Calif.After three years of delay and about $32 million of unexpected extra ex pense, the grand old Cunard liner Queen Mary is now refurbished and open for tourists here. She joins a unique fleet of some 50 vessels scat tered along the Atlantic and Pacific coasts, the Great Lakes and other inland waterways, a fleet that almost never puts to sea and which consists of old and modern warships, whalers, schoon ers and other craft that have been pre served and restored or accurately re produced.

title: 2d Solar Boat Pit Posing Problems for Egyptians
description: CAIRO, June 12  For nearly 17 years, a long, stonesealed pit near the southern face of the Great Pyramid of Cheops has tantalized archeologists and other specialists in ancient Egyptian history and culture. They believe, the pit holds a 4,500 yearold wooden boat similar or identical to one found nearby in 1954.

title: Sports of The Times
description: On, the day Charlie Fox was born in the Bronx, the Giants were outscoring the Yankees in the third game of the World Series enroute to becoming the champions of the baseball universe. That was on Oct. 7, 1921, and Charlie is dreaming up peachy gift that could be presented him on his 50th birthday.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: In her article on summer ing on Fire Island Patricia Stoddard says that when you tire of battling the surf  you can opt for a dip in the gentle bay. She fails to mention that battling the surf is a daredevil trick and that each summer several people drown there. Even the lifeguards do not dare enter the surf to save a life before another lifeguard has secured a long rope around the first. The gentle bay, on the oth er hand, has jellyfish which suck your blood as they cling to you. The matter of bring ing supplies from the main land means an extra charge per package on the ferry.

title: To THE EDITOR:
description: Ned O'Gorman's article is a disturbing one, not because he presents a view critical of the Catholic left but because a man of his talent and depth has become a victim of half truths.

title: A Town with Room for Living
description: A PLACE is more than so many cubic feet of earth. The place referred to was Lincoln, Mass., 15 miles west of Boston, the oc casion was the dedication, on a May morning in 1892, of the new town hall. Twelve years later, at the sesquicenten nial celebration of the town's founding, the speaker was more explicit. The dwellers in the homes of their fathers inherit something which is not known among the changing population of a city or its suburbs. Today only a small minority of Lincoln's five thousand in habitants live in the homes of their fathers, and by most definitions the town would have to be called suburb.

title: Law
description: WASHINGTON  Until 1964, anyone outraged by a news item about him had a pretty good chance of col lecting damages in a libel suit. In a series of decisions over the last seven years, the Supreme Court has made it difficult for public offic ials and other prominent per sons to sue successfully. Last Monday, the Court, while di vided 5 to 3, extended its freepress doctrine to news about private individuals  the millions of anonymous little men who make up the vast majority of the pop ulation.

title: When Mays Comes to Town, New Yorkers Find They're Giant Rooters at Heart
description: They came to Shea Sta dium by subway, automobile, dozens of charted buses and shanks mare yesterday to see wonderful Willie Mays and the Giants do battle with the Mets, but at least two in the crowd of 48,918 came by air.

title: Memo From the Joint Chiefs On September's Covert Raids
description: Memorandum from Maj. Gen. Rotten H. Anthis, an Air Force aide the Joint Chiefs of Staff, to Assistant Secretary of State Bundy and Assistant Secretary of Defense McNaughton, Aug. 27, 1964. The subject of the memo randum was given as OPLAN 34ASeptember Schedule.

title: Moose Liquor License Lost Over Race Clause
description: MADISON, Wis., June 12 (AP)The Madison City Council has denied the Made ison Moose Lodge renewal of its liquor license because of its whiteonly membership clause.

title: U.S. Health Crisis Called Severe for Minorities
description: A union healthcare confer ence was told here yesterday that insufficient financing and medical personnel shortages had created a national health crisis that bore heaviest on mi nority groups, the poor and the elderly.

title: EISENHOWER TALK SCORED MOON RACE
description: WASHINGTON, June 12 Soon after he left the White House, former President Dwight D. Eisenhower, in a secret speech to the Naval War Col lege, warned against overem phasis on the race with the Russians to be first to the moon. He also amplified his warnings against the influence of what he called the military industrial complex.

title: Criminals At Large
description: John Creasey, who produces a book a week (or is it a day?) is said to have over 500 to his credit. One can see how. His writing, rapid and perfunctory, is virtually devoid of grace or character. It is as though he dictates four or five books si multaneously, using much the same kind of characters, and much the same kind of prose to describe them. There is, of course, a professional finish to his work. Often the plotting is ingenious, but his mysteries are ruined by the flat, stereotyped wrting.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: Your report on Maurita nia An Oasis in the Saha ra(Travel section, Feb. 7) mentioned that even though it occurs during the hottest season of the year, Moham med's birthday, which usually takes place in late May or early June, is a good time to visit [the town of) Boutilimit. Readers may be interested to know that in other Moslem areas of West Africa, the sallah celebrations of Idel Fitr and IdelKabir are more important and more interest ing to the visitor. The first marks the end of the month long fast of Ramadan, and the second is when many Mos lems try to make their pil grimage to Mecca. The ap proximate date of the next IdelFitr is Nov. 19. Idel Kabir should come on Jan. 24, 1972. The sallahs are marked by prayers and colorful pro cessions in the major Moslem cities.

title: American MadeIn Japan
description: TOKYO  Executives of Chrysler Corporation and Mitsubishi Motor Corporation are walking around with satisfied smiles these days. After two years of intensive talks with each other, alter nating with efforts to per suade an originally reluctant Japanese Government, the two companies have become the first to complete a deal involving capital participa tion by a major American car manufacturer in a Japa nese carmaking company.

title: SEATTLE F.B.I. SPY TELLS OF ACTIONS
description: SEATTLE, June 9A former informer for the Federal Bureau of Investigation has said that he spied on defense prepara tions in the Seattle Seven con spiracy case and in two other cases involving radicals.

title: East GermanChile Accord
description: BERLIN, June 12 (AP)East Germany and Chile issued a joint announcement today of plans to negotiate longterm treaties for cooperation in science, technology, trade, cul ture, air traffic, shipping and other fields.

title: Summary of Taylor's Report Sent to McNamara by Joint Chiefs.
description: Excerpts from Summary of Ambassador Taylor's first mission report from Saigon, on Aug. 10, 1984, as transmitted on Aug. 14 by Col. A. R. Brownfield, acting special assistant to the Joint Chiefs of Staff for counterinsurgency and special activities, to Secretary McNamara, through Col. Alfred J. F. Moody, the Secretary's military assistant. Colonel Brownfield's covering memorandum said this summary had also been supplied to Gen. Earle G. Wheeler, Chairman of the Joint Chiefs, and to Deputy Secretary of Defense Cyrus R. Vance, their appearance before the House Armed Services Conunittee on Aug. 18.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONWe will not seek to impose economic inte gration upon an existing local jurisdiction; at the same time, we will not countenance any use of economic measures as a subterfuge for racial discrimina tion.

title: Havana's Communist Party Gets a New First Secretary
description: MIAMI, June 12Cuba an nounced this week the appoint ment of Jose R. Machado Ven tura as the first secretary of the ruling Communist party of Havana Province, one of the most important posts in the country.

title: News of the Rialto
description: IN the theater, never say never. Take Garson Kanin. He thought he was finished with Broadway and, in deed, hasn't been in the precinct since 1966, when ho staged We Have Always Lived in the Castle (before that, he is remembered for directing such as Funny Girl, The Diary of Anne Frank and his own Born Yes terday).

title: Texas Police to Learn Spanish Curse Words
description: EL PASO, June 12 (UPI) The state of Texas is spending $61,000 to teach El Paso policemen to curse in two languages.

title: Staneps
description: BOWLING, the sport for millions of Americans who find the 710 split, knocking over the two outer corner pins, as exas perating as does a pitcher trying to overcome Willie Mays, is coming into its own  postally, that is. On Aug. 21, for the opening in Mil waukee of the Seventh World Tournament of the Interna tional Bowling Federation, the United States Postal Service will issue an 8cent embossed stamped envelope to come memorate the event. The de sign of the embossed stamp is to be released.

title: Gail Frances Wightman Is Bride
description: PRINCETON, N. J., June 12s In the Princeton University Chapel here this afternoon, Miss Gail Frances Wightman, a May graduate of Beaver College, was married to Rich ard John Morgan, who gradu ated from Princeton Tuesday with high honors in chemical engineering. The Rev. Dr. Donald M. Meisel performed the Presbyterian ceremony.

title: Gardens
description: SPRING showers often bring in addi tion to Spring flowers, wet base meets, lawns and yards. Man has not developed the art of weather management to the point where its can control rainfall. However, he can over come the adverse effects of too much water in the wrong plate at the wrong time.

title: The Choice for Thousands: Heroin Or Methadone?
description: I have known the police sergeant who speaks here for five years. I have visited him again and again in his home and spent time with him while he does his workin Boston. In the following selections from long, tape recorded conversations I have tried hard to do justice to the range of his feelings, their ambiguity and complexity. I have wanted to learn how it goes for him in a difficult job, and he has been willing to let me knowhe is, in fact, a passionate teacher.

title: Water Project Approved
description: WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) Senator Jennings Randolph, Democrat of West Virginia, has announced a $672,000 Fed eral grant for a demonstration project in the Dents Run water shed of Monongalia. County near Morgantown, W. Va. The project, a demonstration of the technique of water infiltration control to clean out acid mine drainage, is to be the first under legislation sponsored by Mr. Randolphthe Federal Water Pollution Act.

title: Susan B. Kelly Attended by 4 At Her Bridal
description: WESTPORT, Conn., June 12Miss Susan Bea Kelly and Edward Preston Palmer were married here this after noon in the United Methodist Church by the Rev. Douglas Verdin.

title: Guatemala: Always La Violencia
description: I FLEW south to Guatemala from Mexico City during a thermal inversion; a blanket of thick, brownish smog stayed beneath us until we neared the border, when thinned to a pencil line that gave way, as we landed in Guatemala City, to the pure translucent sunlight I had taken for granted as a child. After a 12year absence, I was to fall in love again with my native country, only to discover that I had become its unwitting enemy.

title: Olivia d'Ormesson Plans July 1 Bridal
description: Miss Olivia d'Ormesson and Manley O. Hudson Jr. plan to be married on July 1 at the estate in Ormesson surMarne, France, of Count and Countess Olivier d'Or messon, parents of the fu ture bride. Her fianc is the son of Mrs. Hudson of Cam bridge, Mass., and the late Judge Hudson, who was Be mis Professor of Internation al Law at Harvard Univer sity and a former member of the Permanent Court of International Justice at The Hague.

title: Judge Fuld Is Honored
description: Stanley H. Fuld, chief judge of New York State, has the distinguished service medallion of the Bar Association of Nassau County. The award was presented at the association's 72d annual dinner in the Garden City (L.I.) Hotel.

title: ONEJUDGE PLAN TESTED IN COURTS
description: A twoyear experimental pro gram in Federal Court here In which cases were handled by a single judge from inception to completion has been praised as a succes in a report issued by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.

title: Miss Tenney Is Married
description: NEWBURGH, N. Y., June 12Miss Victoria Williams Tenney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Thomas Tenney, was married here this after noon to Richard Loring Baker, son of Dr. and Mrs. William Henry Baker of Bel mont, Mass. and Nonquit, Mass. The Rev. George Bean of Lynchburg, Va., performed the ceremony assisted by the Rev. William E. Ridgeway in St. George's Episcopal Church.

title: Nixon May Give $70Million To Cities Combating Drugs
description: WASHINGTON, June 12 President Nixon plans to ear mark $70million for grants to cities combating drug addic tion, with $45million going to the 10 largest cities, according, to Representative Robert H. Steele, Republican of Connecticut. Mr. Steele said today that these funds would be made available under the direction of a new Federal agency that he believed would be headed by Dr. Jerome H. Jaffee, director of the Illinois drug abuse pro gram. He said that he expected formation of the agency, with a staff of 100 persons, to be announced Wednesday by the President.

title: Payroll Jobs Rose By 13,000 in April In New York Area
description: Wage and salary employment in the New YorkNortheastern New Jersey area rose by 13,000 in April, 1971, to a total of 6,626,000, it was announced yesterday by Herbert Bienstock, regional director of the United States Department of Labor's Bureau of Labor Statistics.

title: RYUN DOES 1:49.3 IN 800METER RUN
description: HAYWARD, Calif., June 12 (UPI)  Jim Ryun, a late entry in the Pacific Association's Amateur Athletic Union track and field championships at Hayward State, won the 800 meter run today in a minute 49.3 seconds.

title: 23 Journalists Receive Nieman and Stanford Honors
description: Two universities announced the names of 23 journalists yesterday who have been select ed for special fellowships for 197172. Twelve journalists were appointed Nieman Fellows at Harvard University and 11 will study at Stanford Univer sity.

title: Thieu Said to Reconsider Curb on Rival Candidates
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 12After reshuffling his Cab inet to strengthen his position before the legislative and presi dential elections later this year, President Nguyen. Van Thieu appears to be having second thoughts about, a measure he supported to limit the number of candidates for the presidency.

title: Wagner Would Include Suburbs If City Became the 51st State
description: If New York City is to be come the 51st state, the sur rounding suburbs should be in cluded former Mayor Robert F. Wagner said last week.

title: Geraldine's Long Journey
description: IT'S been 32 years since Geraldine Fitzgerald knelt beside Bette Davis in the vegetable garden of the last reel of Dark Victory, fighting tears as Bette fought blindness. The brothers Warner had just wooed her away from the New York stage, and Louelia, Hedda and all the lesser prophets had predicted immediate stardom  all save Orson Welles, soothsayer extraordinaire. Or son simply stared at me, you know how he does, Geraldine explains in her exceptional voice, the sort that might gently scratch diamonds, and told me it would be ages and ages before would do what I could do. I burst into very real tears. I said to him, Unsay that, unsay it! Because Orson always had a weird way of being right in those matters.

title: Staneps
description: THE books on stamp col lecting and volumes of philatelic periodicals that required 450 feet of shelf space at the Bos ton University Libraries have been transferred to the Amer ican Philatelic Research Li brary at State College, Pa., an educational affiliate of The American Philatelic So ciety. Announcement of the transfer was made jointly by John Laucus, director of the Libraries of Boston Universi ty, and Edward L. Willard, president of the American Philatelic Research Library.

title: Et Al.
description: Messick plowing his old fur row (The Silent Syndicate, Secret File), but this is a superior effort. Lansky is one of the most durable figures in organized crimeand also one of the richest; Messick says he may have made $300 mil lion, although no one is sure and the IRS has never been able to get anything on him. Messick posits something called the Na tional Crime Syndicate as the ultimate cartel of crime in the U.S., beside which the Mafia is a minor operation. Lansky, he says, is a key figure, though not the head man.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON  There were further signs last week of a groping in various high places for a world monetary system not dependent on one or two key currencies, the dollar in particular.

title: All's Well That Ends Well Abroad
description: AMERICAN tourists not infrequently return from Europe out and en raged at having been chiseled by avaricious cabbies, schem ing patrones, venal cashiers, menda cious merchants and other low sorts. The letters column of this jour nal's Travel section periodically docu ments cases of private and statutory greed encountered abroad. We all know that our homegrown taxi drivers, motel keepers, restaurateurs and retailers are just as capable of petty meanness and deceit, but that doesn't seem to placate us. I have developed an approach to the problem that helps me keep my cool when I find myself euchred on foreign shores, Call it Tuped's Law. Simply stated: It all evens out.

title: Torres Upsets Davidoff in A.A.U. Handball Tourney
description: Al Torres of the Brownsville Handball Club, sixth seeded, scored a 721, 2111, 2114 up set victory over thirdseeded Bruce Davidoff of Union Temple in the quarterfinals of the Na tional Amateur Athletic Union's onewall handball tournament at the Brighton Beach Baths in Brooklyn yesterday.

title: Dostoevsky as Rorschach Test
description: The plain fact of it is that Fyodor Dostoevsky was a novelist, a literary artist who wrote works of imagina tive fiction. To say this is not to belabor the obvious: much of what one gets to read and to hear on the subject of Dostoevsky could very easily lead one to believe, if one didn't know better, that he was a theologian, a political analyst, an ex istentialist philosopher or some sort of revolutionary. Back in 1940, Er nest J. Simmons, in one of the earliest American books on this writ er, had to remind his readers that whatever other dimensions Dostoev sky's books may possess, they are, after all, novels. That reminder is still as timely as ever.

title: Home of Steinway Piano Keeps Its Jobs in Tune
description: One hundred years ago, on farmland sloping down to Bowery Bay in the Astoria section of Queens, a com munity took root around a piano.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: PRAGUE, June 12 (AP) Czechoslovakia stood within one game of winning the dou bles from the Soviet Union to day before darkness halted their Davis Cup European Zone A semifinal series.

title: Harness Writers to Hold An Awards Dinner Tonight
description: The MonticelloGoshen chap ter of the United States Har ness Writers Association will hold its 13th annual awards dinner tonight at Kutsher's Country Club.

title: Mississippi State Acts
description: STARKVILLE, Miss., June 12 (AP)Mississippi State Uni versity has announced the ap pointment of Dr. Allan W. Rogers, associate dean of stu dents at Indiana State Uni versity, as its new dean of student development. The university said Tuesday that the post was newly created to provide leadership for coordin ating various student programs.

title: Announcements
description: Announcements

title: Donald McVickar, 67, Dies; Member of Curb Exchange
description: Donald McVickar, a member of the former Curb Exchange, now the American Stock Ex change, died yesterday in the Veterans Administration Hos pital. He was 67 years old and lived at 419 East 57th Street.

title: Fresh Yankee, Bargain Beauty, Equals Trot Mark at Yonkers
description: YONKERS, June 12Fresh Yankee, truly an amazing mare, overcame a breaking Dayan and captured the $25, 000 Star's Pride trot by two lengths tonight at Yonkers Raceway. Her time of 2:00 45 tied the track record for trotting mares going one mile.

title: Cable From President to Lodge On Escalation Contingencies
description: Cablegram from President Johnson to Henry Cabot Lodge, United States Ambassador in Saigon, March 20, 1964.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTON  It will be many weeks before the military draft bill becomes law. But from the Senate votes over the last 10 days, two important facets of the new law have become clear:

title: Km Ranch Agrees To Buy Canonero, Baptista Asserts
description: CARACAS, June 12  Pedro Baptista, owner of Canonero the Kentucky Derby and Preak ness winner, said today he had reached a gentleman's agree ment with the King Ranch of Texas for the colt's sale.

title: Announcements
description: Announcements

title: Clifford Odets: Playwright
description: Perhaps because of the heavy political message in his plays, Odets has not had sat isfactory critical attention. Mr. Weales has the framework for such a book here but is cu riously unwilling to commit himself to a full literary esti mate. The plays have dated to a degree; but the author of Waiting for Lefty, Awake and Sing, Till the Day I Die, and many film scripts, deserves a fulllength study that shows his considerable part in the de velopment of the American theater. This isn't it.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: Obituary 1  No Title

title: YOUTHCRIME PLAN URGED IN SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, June 12  A Senate subcommittee headed by Birch Bayh, Democrat of In diana, has begun to draft a billiondollar legislative pro grain that would encourage states to use new techniques to rehabilitate young offenders of the law.

title: Action Backed on Trade
description: Fairer rules of internation al competition that would ban export cartels and sub sidies are a prime need for the solution of American trade problems, according to a former trade  policy con sultant, Dr. Horace J. Dc Podwin.

title: 3 Fish Caught Near a Battery Factory on the Hudson Contain Up to 1,000 Times Normal Cadmium
description: WASHINGTON, June 12 Three fish caught near the out wash of a federally built bat tery factory on the Hudson River have been found to con tain up to 1,000 times as much cadmium as might normally be expected, a Senate subcommit tee reported today.

title: Advance Guard Triumphs
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., June 12 (UPI)  Burt Bachrach's Ad vance Guard scored a head victory over heavily favored Manta today in the 31st run ning of the $78,800 Inglewood Handicap at Hollywood Park.

title: State Department Aide's Report On Actions Taken After Tonkin
description: Part VIII, Immediate Actions in the Period Prior to Decision, of outline for Assistant Secretary Bundy, Nov. 7, 1964. Markings indicate that was drafted by Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Marshall Green.

title: The Imitable Perelman
description: Had you pattered past the sleeper in New York's Century Club recent ly, you might have glimpsed a re cumbent figure, half shrouded by the gloom, resembling a startled yawn. In peccable tweed and shirt of many colors, mustache limp and granny glasses clouded, he waved tentatively as you approached.

title: Tia Pan Sets Track Mark On Turf at Suffolk Downs
description: BOSTON, June 12 (AP)Al bion Stable's Tia Pan led all the way in the $6,000 Gover nor's Purse today at Suffolk Downs before a crowd of 14,253.

title: The DifferenceHeroin vs. Methadone
description: THE recent proposal by the May or's Narcotics Control Council to provide heroin to selected addicts as part of a research project raised the question of the advantages of keeping a patient on methadone, a synthetic opiate developed in Ger many during World. War II, instead of on the real thing.

title: Susan Koch Is Wed To Robert F. Slimmon

title: Australian Women's Lib Says: Make War, Not Love
description: SYDNEY, Australia, June 12 On the inside of the wooden front door at 67 Glebe Point Road in the middleclass sub urb of Glebe, someone had scrawled with crayon in big letters: Make War, Not Love.

title: Wine Said to Cheer Nursing Home Patients
description: HYANNIS, Mass., June 12 There is nothing like a little wine to make life hap pier for patients at nursing homes, the operator of a home believes.

title: White Jesuit Educator Thriving at Negro University
description: CHARLOTTE, N. C., June 12 In the year since he resigned the chancellorship of Ford ham University, the Rev. Leo McLaughlin has, among other things, returned to teaching (My joy) and overseeing the production of a spot television commercial for Southern fried chicken.

title: Taiwan Gives U.S Protests on China And Okinawa Pact

title: Norwegians Win Again In Sag Harbor Festival
description: SAG HARBOR, L. I., June 12A nineman Norwegian crew defended its title here today by winning the inter national harpoon trophy for the second year in a row at the ninth annual Old Whalers Festival.

title: To THE EDITOR:
description: May I sing public praise of Ned O'Gorman's article? So much is at stakenot only in the theater and the arts, not only do the Roman Catholic Churchall of American life is implicated.

title: Newyork
description: The pencilpushers showed that they had plenty of muscle. The only trouble is that they swung at Rockefeller and wound up kayoing themselves and Lindsay.

description: BOSTON, June 12A lot of vultures are going to come to hear you sing, Sarah Caldwell told Beverly Sills during the Opera Company of Boston's rehearsals of Norma.

title: U.S. to Offer Summaries Of Environment Reports
description: WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) The Government has an nounced a new service making summaries of environmental impact statements available to the public at low cost.

title: Customs Post Blown Up
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 12 (UPI)Two armed ex tremists blew up a British cus toms post at Killeen on the border with the Irish Republic tonight.

title: Dr. Anita Stevens Wed to John S. Harper
description: The marriage of Dr. Anita Stevens of New York and Roaring Brook Lake, N. Y., to John Sanford Harper of New York and Ringwood, N. J., took place yesterday morning at the home of Dr. and Mrs. Bernard Tillis at Candlewood Lake, Conn. The ceremony was performed by Justice of the Peace W. Ed win Harrison of Danbury, Conn.

title: Television
description: THE first meeting was brief. The scene was a reception at the Ca thedral Church of St. John the Divine, and I explained that I had to go home and watch the Emmy Awards on television. He genially re called Mason Williams's observation that getting an Emmy is like getting kissed by someone with bad breath.

title: Books:
description: THE GREAT SLUMP. By Goronwy Rees. Harper & Row. 310 pages. $8.95.

title: Blue Finds New York Fast, Vice Versa
description: OAKLAND, Calif., June 12 Vida Blue, Oakland's 12 game winner who sometimes is made out to be a com bination of Walter Johnson and Sandy Koufax, proved 11 days ago he's too fast for the New York Yankees. Now Blue has disclosed that the feeling is somewhat mutual.

title: Scince/Medicine
description: WASHINGTON  There are about 20 nuclear power sta tions in the United States today and you could probably march up and down all year outside any one of them without collect ing enough radiation to expose an ordinary chest Xray film.

title: Article 3  No Title
description: MUNICH, June 12 (UPI) West Germany beat Hungary, 41, today and reached the final of the European Zone Group B Davis Cup tennis competition.

title: Has Company in Suffolk Started by a Black Man
description: HUNTINGTON STATION, L.I., June 12A bus com pany that is probably the first franchised bus opera Rion owned by a black in Suffolk County, finished its first week of service here.

title: Conigliaro Hospitalized
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., June 12 (UPI)Tony Conigliaro, a Cali fornia Angel outfielder, was sent to St. Joseph Hospital in nearby Orange today for treat ment of a pinched nerve in his neck. Dr. Jules Rasinski or dered traction and physical therapy and said the ball player would be in the hos pital two or three days. Rasin ski diagnosed the injury as a cervical muscle spasm and said it may be due to an old football injury.

title: Editorial Cartoon 1  No Title
description: Editorial Cartoon 1  No Title

title: WORLD OF SEVENTH AVE.
description: American manufacturers have a tight hold on the mar ket for men's and women's jeans and do not have too much to fear from imports, Larry Baxter, president of the Big Yank Corporation said last week. The big names in the fieldLevi Straus & Co.; the H. D. Lee Company, Inc., Blue Bell, Inc., and his own companydeliver styl ing that is in demand all over the world including Japan and the Far East.

title: MINISTERS REPORT CAREER STRESS
description: ATLANTIC CITY, June 12 Most Protestant ministers have been victims of severe career stress at some point in their lives, much of it generated by problems with their congrega tions, according to a survey made public here last night.

title: The Secret Boss Of California
description: The firstperson, astoldto story of Art Samish, lobbyist extraordinary to the California State legislature. Samish worked for a variety of interestsliq uor, beer, cigarettesand did his job well. His mode of politi cal operation was select and electthat is, canvass legis lators for those sympathetic to his intentions, then cajole the pertinent industry into cough ing up campaign money. He was a brilliant political advertising man and succeeded in getting a number of propositions re pealed or passed. He claims never to have bribed anyone and got into trouble only once, over a Federal tax matter (the Feds, he says, were out to get him). He is retired now and looks back with pleasure on his career. A good portrait of the lobbyist in action.

title: Law
description: Law

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In spite of the overwhelming pollu tion which emanates from a modern superhighway, the resulting annual gasoline tax revenue is at most , per cent of the cost of land acquisition and construction. Not only is our present automotive transportation system uneconomical but it is also ugly, noisy and dangerous, and tends to immobilize the young, the old, the poor and the handicapped.

title: Table Tennis Stars Will Start Play at Vanderbilt Club Today
description: Table tennis, which came into international prominence with the recent visit of the United States team to China, has attracted some of the world's best players to the Vanderbilt tournament starting today.

title: Ryan Presses Rodeo Curbs
description: WASHINGTON, June 12 (UPI)Representative William F. Ryan, Democrat of Manhat tan, introduced a bill Wednes day that would make it illegal to ship in interstate commerce any animal used in rodeos for such events as calf roping, steer wrestling and bronco busting. The bill would also prohibit interstate shipments of such devices as the bucking strap, flank strap and electric prod used to make animals bolt from chutes.

title: HARPER'S SMOKEY LIGHTNING LEADER
description: SOUTHPORT, Conn., June 12 Stephen Harper of the Lake Winnipesaukee (N. H.) fleet, sailing Smokey, placed first and second off the Pequot Yacht Club on Long Island Sound today to take a 1point lead in the Northeast regional championship of the Lightning Class.

title: Loft in Brooklyn Is a HalfwayHouse Between Street and School
description: Brooklyn intermediate school students who could not function in a normal classroom atmosphere be cause of behavorial problems are receiving special instruc tion in a schoolawaytrom school program designed to return them to the classroom as productive students.

title: HUNTERS PURSUE L.I. OR SEALS
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., June 12A bill to protect Long Is land's harbor seals from hunt ers died in committee this week when the State Legisla ture adjourned.

title: Pat Rizzo Bringing BigBand Sound to Queens Every Week
description: Long Island gets an oc casional taste of the celebra ted big bands as they pass through the metropolitan areathe Glenn Miller Or chestra tonight at Raffael's in Corona, Queens; Harry James last month at the Pan American Steak Pub in Elm hurst, Qutens; Count Basie at San Su San in Mineola, L. I., last March.

title: Music; More Leisure? More Music!
description: ONE afternoon a couple of years ago, Carlos Moseley was quite nat urally thinking about the New York Philharmonic, since he was its manager (he is now its president). He thought of the epigram about people dreaming of immortal ity but not knowing what to do on a Sunday afternoon. He thought of labor unions, which were working towards a fourday week and whose members increasingly had leisure time. He reached for the phone and called Harry Van Arsdale, president of the New York City Central Labor Council.

title: Bidding for Bargain at Custorns Auction
description: A little under 7,000 pounds of Oriental hair, 450 pounds of distilled lime oil, 46 Jade Buddhas, one large Moroccan bird cage, 43 used pace makers, about 10,000 false eyelashes, one casket, two motorbikes, a large assort ment of liquor and 725 uku leles all went on the block at the Bureau of Customs quar terly auction last week.

title: A lust for God's earthly forms
description: When Cynthia Ozick's novella Envy; or, Yiddish in America was first published, I had never read any thing of hers before, and having no particular expectations or preconcep tions about her work, I found my self overwhelmed by the story it self and was amazed at its effect on me. I.read it, reread it and lent it to friends, all as in a fever; it brought back for me those early years in adolescence when reading is ob sessive, when all literature is new and opens itself out before you with the sensuous and exploding hypnotic draw that real life cannot begin to compete with. After adolescence, there are probably relatively few writers who are able to overtake and own one in this wayBorges, Kawabata and Garcia Marquez come to mind. With the publication of this collection of stories, I think Cynthia Ozick can lay claim to being one of them.

title: PUBLIC TO LEARN POSTAL CHANGES
description: WASHINGTON, June 12  The Post Office Department will send fourpage newsletters to 60 million households next week in an effort to explain its changing status in the Gov ernment and to get people to use the mails more efficiently.

title: Cable From Taylor Warning On the March North Campaign
description: Excerpts from cablegram from Ambassador Taylor in Saigon to the State Department, July 25, 1964.

title: Residents Form AstoriaL.I. City Health Croup
description: An experimental coalition of citizens groups and local health services is moving through pilot programs, legis lative pressure and longrange study and planning to bring about major improvements in health care in the industrial AstoriaLong Island City area of Queens.

title: CATCHER FOR METS IN ANTIDRUG ROLE
description: Duffy Dyer, wearing a neat gray suit instead of a Mets uniform, got some practice ielding questions from several hundred students at Long Is land City High School last week.

title: White Sox Enroll Friess
description: OSHKOSH, Wis., June 12 (AP) Jack Friess, a center fielder for Oshkosh State University, signed with the Chicago White Sox today.

title: Pulitzer Poet Weds Helen D'Aiessandro
description: Miss Helen D'Alessandro was married here yesterday afternoon to Anthony Evan Hecht, who won the Pulitzer Prize for poetry in 1968. The Rev. John Maguire of Loyola University in Chicago per formed the ceremony In the garden of the bride's apart ment.

title: Television
description: GOOD GRIEF! A time of heightened women's lib eration consciousness. A time when women are finally beginning to func tion seriously on television, covering major reporting assignments, handling the an chor positions on news shows. A time when even ladies magazines are in the process of changing their tunafish casserole formats and begin ning to address women as intelligent adults concerned with the profound problems of their society. At such a time, Channel 5 gives us Joyce and Barbara, an in terview show hosted by Joyce Susskind and Washington Womanabouttown Barbara Howar. It is a TV innovation that just may have the revo lutionary effect of giving that old Ladies Home Jour nal jive, now being slowly driven out of print, new life television.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: TO the Editor: The Nixon Administration's decision to waive the previously established $75million ceiling on aid to Latin American countries for the purchase of arms is shortsighted and contrary to United States interests in the south ern hemisphere. There is no evidence that an easier supply of armaments for Latin  American armed forces will either strengthen hemispheric security or solidify support among the military regimes in Latin America for United States foreign policy goals.

title: Staneps
description: CANADA'S second stamp in its Maple Leaf in Four Seasons series will be issued in Ot tawa on Wednesday. A mul ticolored adhesive, it shows the maple leaf, Canada's na tioinal emblem, as it appears in summer.

title: Nun, Alderman of The Hague, Weighs Her First Year in Office
description: THE HAGUE, June 12 (UPI) When Sister MarieJoseph van Deven decided to run for a seat on The Hague City coun cil a little more than a year ago, an alderman told her she was too emotional to be in politics.

title: Cowboys Sign 5 Players
description: DALLAS, June 12 (AP)The Dallas Cowboys of the Nation al Football Conference signed today Steve Maier, wide re ceiver, Northern Arizona, sixthround draft choice; Steve Goepel, quarterback, Colgate, 12th round; John Romer, cen ter, Hemphis State, 17th round, and Ed Perry, quarterback, Buffalo, and Kenny Price, line backer, Iowa, free agents.

title: British Banks Face Changes
description: LONDONBanks in Brit ain  clearing banks, mer chant banks, and not least the 30odd American banks with branches here  are now undergoing the most serious bout of soulsearching in more than a decade.

title: Golfer Rakes In $480 With His Pair of Aces
description: NORWICH, England, June 12 (Reuters) John Hudson, 25yearold English golfter, has been awarded $480 for his two successive holesin one in the Martini tourna ment here yesterday.

title: Official Birthday of the Queen Marked by a CenturiesOld Ceremony
description: LONDON, June 12 (UPI) More than 1,000 guardsmen, wearing brilliant scarlet and glittering gold, marched be fore Queen Elizabeth II and millions of her subjects to day torecreate a centuries old ceremony marking the monarch's official birthday.

title: Young and Knifton, 1,2 in Walk, Gain U.S. PanAmerican Team

Pre liminary diagnostic interviews are required and may be ar ranged by telephoning Prof. William F. Meade, director of the center, at (212)8346265.

description: EDINBURGH, Scotland, June 12 (UPI)David Bedford of Brit ain ran the second fastest 5,000 meters today when he broke the European record at the British International Games.

description: CHICAGO, June 12 (AP) Heisanative won the $17,060 Hyde Park Stakes and Fleet Wing scored in the $20,350 Olympia Handicap before a crowd of 22,466 at Arlington Park today.

description: MINEOLA, L. I., June 12 Representative Lester L. Wolff has embarked on a se ries of programs to aid the plight of Long Island vet erans of the war in Vietnam in the areas of employment, hospitalization and drug ad diction.

description: Massive rent strikes and the widespread seizure of empty buildings and vacant apart ments by squatters were urged here yesterday by the Metro politan Council on Housing, which favors public ownership of all housing here that has more than four dwelling units.

description: FAR HILLS, N. J., June 12 Bootlegger, owned and ridden by Melanie Smith, scored a double at the Far Hills horse and pony show today by win ning the green and amateur owner working hunter chain pionships.

description: KANSAS CITY, June 12 (AP) The Kansas City Royals signed today their top choice in the secondary phase of the free agent draft, Roger Schmuck of Arizona State. The 6foot3 inch first baseman will join El mira AA farm, Monday.

description: BARCELONA, Spain (AP) Manuel Orantes and Juan Gis bert won the doubles, 63, 46, 63, 62, from Pierre Barthes and Francois Jouffret to send Spain into a 21 lead in the European Zone Davis Cup to day.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: Clive Barnes's story on ballet in Europe (Travel sec tion, May 30) said, Tickets to the Royal Ballet [In Lon don] can be obtained in New Yorkthe British Tourist of fice can arrange it I'm afraid this is not quite accu rate. We can furnish (in limited quantities) programs, which contain mail  order blanks, for the Royal Ballet. In New York tickets can be ordered through Keith Repre sentatives Ltd., 667 Madison Avenue, New York, N. Y. 10021, telephone 3716679.

title: Ford Foundation Grants To Aid Crime Research
description: The Ford Foundation has an nounced grants totaling $617, 000 to three institutions for national and international re search on problems of crime and criminaljustice adminis tration.

description: MINEOLA, L. I., June 12 Since Earth Day last year, dozens of voluntary drives have been held in Nassau communi ties to collect old newspapers and other discards for re cycling.

title: LUNN'S 206 LEADS KEMPER BY SHOT

They failed. The 26yearold Califor nia professional, after a one underpar 71 for a 54hole ag gregate of 206, still led by one stroke.

title: Grace Butler To Be a Bride Special to The New Yak Mares
description: RYE, N.Y., June 12Mr. and Mrs. Jonathan Fairchild Butler have announced the engagement of Mr. Butler's daughter, Miss Grace Tucker Butler, to Jotham Johnson 5th, son of Mrs. Jothani Johnson of New York and Sodus Point, N. Y., and the late Professor Johnson, who was chairman o fthe depart ment of classics and archeol ogy at New York University.

title: Miss Faas Wed To W. A. Smith, A Textile Man
description: LA JOLLA, Calif., June, 12 In All Hallows Roman Catholic Church here at noon today, Miss Mary Charlene Faas, daughter of Capt.

title: Bachrachs Have Child
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 12 A daughter was born on June 2 to Mr. and Mrs. William Bradford Bachrach of Ger mantown in the Albert Em stein Hospital here. Mrs. Bachrach is the former Miss Catherine Posselt of Kent, Conn. Her husband is with the Great Lakes College As sociation here. The child, who has been named Jaime, is the granddaughter of Brad ford K. Bachrach of Wellesley Hills, Mass., president of Bachrach, Inc., the photogra phers.

title: What We Don't Know Nearly Always Hurts
description: IT is so easy to forget to ask the obvious ques tion. At the Negro En semble Company, for in stance, in a play by John Scott called Ride a Black Horse, a young black sociol ogist is caught in a racial bind. He has considerable in fluence in the white commu nity. But the more militant blacks want no more gradu alism, They want a deal now. A fantastic deal, as they ad mit. (It's so fantastic it's almost appealing.) They want the sociologist to go to the mainly white city coun cil and get an agreement for the blacks to take over all powerall positions, all au thorityfor one month.

title: ExBerliners Are Reunited in Program of Free Visits for Those Who Fled Nazis
description: BERLIN, JUNE 12  Alfred Rudermann and Mrs. Amalie Strauss, childhood friends half a century ago, had an unex pected reunion in a Berlin sightseeing bus this week.

title: The President and The Cake Pass Tests
description: WASHINGTON, June 12The bride's father made it through his first per formance as a public dancer without stepping on his daughter's toe. The wedding cake did pretty well, too.

title: Capone The Life and World of Al Capone. By John Kobler. Illustrated. 409 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $8.95.
description: As the mother lode for an appar ently endless stream of sociological tracts, memoirs, biographies, maga zine pieces, novels, plays, movies (and, more recently, television dra mas) Al Capone is hard to match. Alphonse Capone, also known as Scarface Al and All Brown, was massive, liverlipped street brawler from Brooklyn who, as they say, made it big in Chicago, and the ques tion immediately arises: Can there be life in the old boy yet?

title: Margaret A. McDowell Married
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., June 12 Miss Margaret Ann Mc Dowell, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert McDowell, was married here at noon today in St. Ann's Roman Catholic Church to Seaman Apprentice Philip C. C. Walsh 5th of the Coast Guard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walsh 4th of New Ver non, N. J. The Rev. John Corr of New Vernon performed the ceremony.

title: Chappell Wins Singles Title In N.C.A.A. College Tennis
description: GREENCASTLE, Ind., June 12 (AP)Bob Chappell of the University of California at Irvine defeated John Lowman of Rollins, 75, 64, to win the National Collegiate college di vision tennis championship at Depauw University today.

title: Greenhill Team Qualifies In Royal Windsor Polo
description: COWDRAY PARK, England, June 12 (AP)Greenhill Farm of the United States, led by James (Hap) Sharp of Tulsa, Okla., qualified in a preliminary round of the Royal Windsor Polo Cup at Cowdray Park to day with a 63 victory over San Flamingo, a local team.

title: Letter to the Editor 5  No Title
description: To THE EDITOR: Who can argue against the contention that the militant Catholic left lacks imagina tion and humor? I won'tI know them too well.

title: Penrnarric
description: Penmarric is a leaden lump of a novel flecked with a stillprecious ingredient: mis ery among the high and the mighty. You think you've got trouble? Look at this Cornish tin heir, Mark Castallack. He lives in a grotesque man sion on the Cornwall coast and he's rich, but he's not happy. His mistress doesn't get along with his wife (who was his father's mistress) and there's friction between his legitimate children (7) and his bastards (2). Things slide steadily down hill in the 50 years or so the novel covers. The nadir is reached when Jan  Yvres, Mark's youngest son, kills his young nephew Jonas in a scuf fle and disposes of the corpse in a handy mine. Jonas's moth er Rebecca had just died after a bungled abortion. Rebecca was the daughter of her hus band's cousin and his mother's stepson, in case you're inter ested. The Castallacks are a clannish bunch.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The vacancy decontrol legislation approved by Gov ernor Rockefeller may achieve unexpected results. It may result in lockingin tenants for a long duration. Tenants are already forming in groups to maintain the statusquo of their occupancies and for concerted efforts to counter act anticipated actions by landlords to remove them from their homes.

title: Cosmos Will Meet Stars Here Tonight After Open House
description: The St. Louis Stars of the North American Soccer League, made up predominantly of Americanborn players, will make their debut at Yankee Stadium this evening with a new coach when they meet the New York Cosmos at 6 o'clock.

title: The Political Pro Who Runs Defense
description: NOW in his third year of the most demanding job in Wash ington except for the Presi dency, Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird gets along well most of the time with the generals and admirals. The military likes him because he has turned back to them many of the decisions Robert S. McNamara insisted on making when he was Secretary of Defense. Laird does not have the control over the Pentagon that McNamara had. But he does not want it.

title: HAWAII VOTES LAW CURBING WELFARE
description: HONOLULU, June 12 (AP) Hawaii's state government has set up a oneyear residency requirement for welfare recip ients, mainly to discourage thousands of young people looking for carefree days in tropical paradise.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: After reading the sugges tion in a letter that travelers will spot their luggage more easily if they mark it with an X in adhesive tape (Travel section, May 16), I can picture the consequences each and every suitcase going around the carousel will bear an X. My sugges tion (and I have been doing it for years): Tape on your own initial  why get con fused with the Xaviers?

title: MOUND STAFF HEADS N.A.I.A. ALLSTAR NINE
description: PHOENIX, Ariz., June 13 (UPI)A threeman pitching staff, with a combined won lost record of 355, heads the 14player allstar baseball team announced by the National As sociation of Intercollegiate Athletics.

title: Tricia Nixon Takes Vows In Garden at White House
description: WASHINGTON, June 12  After a tensionfilled delay be cause of rain, Tricia Nixon was married today in the Rose Gar den of the White House to Edward Finch. Cox, the man she has described as my first and last love.

title: Vacation Cut Irks School Employes
description: A move by. School Chancellor Harvey B. Scribner to limit the traditional summerlong vaca tions of some school employes has stirred a controversy.

title: Movies
description: NOW is the time for then. Movie makers, like most people today, are busy looking backward to see what made gangsters, mara thon dancers and pubescent boys tick in the good old days. Now Mel Ferrer has decided to look backway back. He's planning to produce a movie called Burns, a musical biography of Robert Burns, the poet, songsmith and ladies man of 18thcentury Scotland.

title: Foreign Notes
description: Reporting on a private luncheon meeting between Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky and Ellsworth Bunker, the American Ambassador to for Vietnam, a spokesman for Mr. Ky said last week the two men had discussed a possible situation that could be very embarrassing for the United States. Under a law pushed through the National Assembly the week before, President Nguyen Van Thieu could turn out to be the only Presidential can didate running in the elec tions scheduled for Oct. 3.

title: The World
description: At almost 11,000 feet, Mount Etna in Sicily is Europe's biggest volcano and, potentially, its most dangerous. When Etna erupted in 1669, more than 27,000 villagers were left homeless and countless others killed by lava. In 1693, more than 60,000 died when an eruption was accompanied by an earth quake. Last April, the volcano erupted again, with the lava flowing not out of the crater but from fissures on the mountain's crest and sides. After two months of activity, during which the lava ruined 300 acres of farmland and caused more than $5 million in damage, Etna fell silent. Then, last week, it erupted again, and again seemed to stop. We wait and we pray, a villager said.

title: RALPH B. NOVAK, 63, AIDED NEWS GUILD
description: DETROIT, June 12 (AP)  Ralph B. Novak, former vice president and secretarytreas urer of the American Newspa per Guild, died yesterday in a hospital. He was 63 years old.

title: Title to Miss Heldman
description: NOTTINGHAM, England, June 12 (AP) Julie Heldman of Houston won the women's sin gles title at the John Player tennis tournament today by de feating Betty Hawcroft of Aus tralia, 64, 79, 63, in the final.

title: The Last Word: Two (?) Modern Masters
description: Marshall McLuhan and George Orwell slipped into town last week, off a Viking submarine from England, wearing book jackets that identified them as Modern Masters in the Frank Kermode essay seriesalong with Camus, Marcuse, LdviStrauss, Lukacs, Wittgenstein, etc. Frankly, the heart sinks. If McLuhan is, according to Mr. Kermode's editorial scheme, a modern mas ter, one of the men who have changed and are changing the life and thought of our age, what does that make Orwell? orders of magnitude, we are talking about a lightbulb and Sirius the Dog Star. McLuhan exists mostly as an excuse, the means which admen and TV executives forgive themselves for their many crimes against intelligence and decency. Whereas Orwell  well, as writers and as people, most of us aren't fit to carry Orwell's aspidistra.

title: RoundTrip Space Shot
description: WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) The space agency said today that it planned to launch 206pound spacecraft from Wal lops Island, Va., next Wednes day to an altitude of 234 miles and then fire it back into the atmosphere at 15,000 miles an hour. The experiment will pro vide information for studying the structure and composition of another planet's atmosphere on future exploratory missions.

title: Bears to Open Rookie Camp
description: CHICAGO, June 12 (AP) The Chicago Bears will open a rookie training camp Monday for more than 25 newcomers, including all of the National Football League club's 18 draft choices. Joining the rookies at Tam O'Shanter Country Club will be Jack Con cannon and Bobby Douglass, quarterbacks, and Doh Hyland, a center,

title: REV. JOHN H. C. ALBOHM
description: The Rev. John H. C. Albohm, pastor of Concordia Lutheran Church in the Bronx from 1927 until his retirement in 1956, died Friday in the Wartburg Lutheran Home for the Aging in Brooklyn. He was 85 years old.

title: Delberta Brunner Is Bride of Writer
description: Miss Delberta Joanne Brunner and David Sanders Thomson were married here yesterday afternoon in the Episcopal Church of the Ascension by the Rev, Wil son W. Sneed.

title: North Defeats South in Lacrosse, 96
description: MEDFORD, Mass., June 12 (AP)The North squad de feated the South, 9.6, today in the college allstar lacrosse game at Tufts University.

title: National Notes
description: Among Hollywood movie di rectors, the name John Ford ranks near the top. The Grapes of Wrath, How Green Was My Valley, Stagecoach and a host of highlevel westerns have borne his stamp.

title: Vietnam Archive: Pentagon Study Traces 3 Decades of Growing U. S. Involvement
description: A massive study of how the United States went to war in Indochina, con ducted by the Pentagon three years ago, demonstrates that four administrations progrestively developed a sense of com mitment to a nonCommunist Vietnam, a readiness to fight the North to pro tect the South, and an ultimate frustra tion with this effortto a much greater extent than their public statements ac knowledged at the time.

title: The World
description: WASHINGTONMany Amer icans probably had visions last week of latterday equivalents of graceful clipper ships, com plete with Yankee trader cap tains, sailing into such exotic ports as Canton and Shanghai to carry on a profitable trade with the teeming millions of China.

title: The Stately Game
description: A rueful memoir (by Stuart Symington's son) of two years as head Washington ritualist (Chief of Protocol) under Presi dent Johnson, along with ran dom thoughts about this and that political issue.

title: Dr. Henry S. Pascal, 97, Surgeon Here 64 Years
description: CHEVY CHASE, Md., June 12 Dr. Henry S. Pascal, a sur geon in New York from 1896 until his retirement in 1960, died today at his borne at the age of 97.

title: Agnew the Unexamined Man
description: A profile of the Vice Presi dent by the director of his gubernatorial campaign. Marsh reports that initially he had the subject's cooperation in doing this study, but lost it when he was deemed not objective (i.e., friendly); and, in fact, the view here is cool. There is lit tle about the early life; Marsh gets going with Agnew's push to the chairmanship of the Baltimore County zoning board, goes on to his fight to become county commissioner, then the governorship, ending with Nixon's nod at the 1968 convention. Marsh finds Agnew honest, a good administrator but inordinately ambitious, ego tistical and sensitive to slights from the press (does this have a familiar ring?). He seems to Marsh to have no deep political convictions of his own, and his main fault is a lack of self awareness.

title: Reader's Report
description: If you, happen to have missed the several fictional and fac tual accounts that have al ready been compiled on the death of a giant magazine, Julia Savarese's swiftlypaced novel will tell you everything you need to know. Here is tale of corporate foul play that might be considered excessive ly Byzantine, except that its analogues have been docu mented in the daily press.

title: Eilbracht Wins Trophy
description: OMAHA, Neb., June 12 (UPI) Lee Eilbracht, the executive secretary of the American As sociation of College Baseball Coaches, was named today the 1971 recipient of the Silver Tro phy for distinguished service to college baseball.

title: Mrs. Elizabeth. Weicker Remarried
description: Mrs. Elizabeth Weicker of New York, East Hampton, L.L, and Paris and Tassos Fondaras of Paris were mar ried here yesterday. Judge Frederick L. Strong of the New York City Criminal Court performed the cere mony, which was attended by a few members of the family and close friends, in the bride's apartment here.

title: L.I.R. Is Offering Weekend Specials For Izaak Waltons
description: The Long Island Railroad is now offering its weekend fish ermen specials to Captree State Park on a daily basis through Labor Day.

title: KANGAROO TAKES PRIZE IN SAILING
description: MAMARONECK, N. Y., June 12A lack of wind on Long Island Sound today caused the first cancellation of the Yacht Racing Association champion ship season after seven suc cessful starts.

title: Truman Capote, Sage of Sagaponack, Is an L. I. Booster
description: SAGAPONACK, LI., June 12Just as Capistrano is un thinkable without its swal lows, so is this wellmani cured village on the Atlantic dunes impossible to imagine without Truman Streckfus Persons Capote.

title: Pop
description: ELTON JOHN: Sound track Friends (Para mount). Yes, Elton is in a rut, but it's such a nice rut. Imagine, in one year, to appear from no where, get proclaimed a su perstar, produce three fine albums, and already get tied down by his own style. That's fast work.

title: To THE EDITOR:
description: May I offer my sincere gratitude for Ned O'Gorman's most articulate and incisive article?

title: Jury Finds Hilliard Is Guilty of Assault In 1968 Gun Battle
description: OAKLAND, Calif., June 12 (UPI)  A jury of seven men and five women found David Hil liard, Black Panther chief of staff, guilty of assault today but not guilty of attempted murder in connection with a 1968 gun battle with the po lice. The jury returned the ver dict after more than two days of deliberation.

title: Saints Sign Morrison
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 12 (AP) The New Orleans Saints to day) signed Don Morrison of TexasArlington, an offensive tackle, to a National Football League contract.

title: Theater in London
description: WITH Landscape and Silence in 1969, it be came clear that Harold Pinter was burrowing toward some new mode of expression which, when achieved, could never be Pinterian quite the same way that word applied before. In those oneact plays, language, instead of capturing the splin tered ambiguities of naturalistic speech, narrowed and tightened the way it does in a prose poem. No longer concerned with the immediacies of an extreme situa tion, Pinter used words to crystallize certain indelible moments from the past; characters backstroked through time in order to discover and unravel germinal ex periences.

title: RUMANIA LEADS IN DAVIS CUP, 20
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, June 12 (UPI)Rumania led Yugo slavia, 20, in the European Zone Davis Cup tennis semi finals today as Ion Tiriac beat Boro Jovanovic, 64, 75, 26, 64.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Mobile homes have been attracting the interest of in vestors, businessmen, shelter seekers, academicians and public officials.

title: Caso Says Bus Service Is in Dire Peril
description: MINEOLA, L.I., Juno 12 County Executive Ralph G. Caso this week forecast a bleak future for bus service in Nas sau, saying it was in dire peril.

title: The Covert War
description: The Pentagon papers disclose that in this phase the United States had been mounting clandestine military attacks against North Vietnam and planning to obtain a Congressional resolution that the Administration regarded as the equivalent of a declaration of war. The papers make it clear that these far reaching measures were not improvised in the heat of the Tonkin crisis.

title: Edith DeVoe Jersey Bride
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 12Miss Edith Marion DeVoe, a greatgreatgrand daughter of George W. De voe, a cofounder of the De voe paint Company, was married here this morning to David Charles Klink. Canon Frank Van Hise Carthy per formed the ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church.

title: LongHaired Patrolman Is Suspended Indefinitely
description: John Bal, the longhaired policeman who was suspended briefly a year ago, was sus pended indefinitely from the force Friday for failure to com ply with a directive to submit to a psychiatric examination.

title: Scramble for Africa
description: A sweeping history of the colonization of South Africa. The Dutch settlements, Great Britain muscling in, the subse quent Boer War. Well re searched by the author whose previous books have been main ly about the Middle East.

title: CITY PLAN BOARD 110 HIT IN QUEENS
description: The City Planning Commis sion reached Flushing last week in its series of public hearings in Queens on its proposed Mas ter Plan and in baseball par lance the commissioners were 0 for 11.

title: Lyn Hogen Wed to C. Vaughan Mason Jr. Special to The New York Time
description: CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., June 12Miss Lyn Hogen, an as sistant buyer with the women's shop of Lord & Taylor, was married this afternoon to C. Vaughan Mason. Jr., who is in the executive management pro gram at Lord & Taylor.

title: Highlights of Tonkin Period
description: Here, in chronological sequence, are highlights of the period covered in this article:

title: Uganda Cholera in Control
description: KAMPALA, Uganda, June 12 (Reuters)Health officials said today that a cholera outbreak in northeastern Uganda was well under control. In the last week three more persons have died, bringing the total to 15 since the outbreak began May 19. No new outbreaks have been reported, however.

title: The Nation
description: Six months ago Ralph Nader and other consumer protection groups filed petitions with the Federal Trade Commission, ask ing it to take action against advertisers who make vague claims which give consumers no real understanding of their product, and who invoke clinical tests with little scientific basis to substantiate claims and otherwise deliber ately mislead and confuse the consumer.

title: 6 Arrested in Plot to Bomb Reservoir in North Jersey
description: KINNELON, N. J., June 12 (UPI)Six persons, including five juveniles, were arrested in this North Jersey community today in an alleged plot to bomb a reservoir supplying water to 25,000 people, accord ing to the police.

title: New Rome Palace: British Embassy
description: ROME, June 12The British Embassy staff will move into its new building next to Michel angelo's venerable Porta Pia tomorrow, with criticism and some praise from many sides.

title: Staneps
description: BRITAIN'S regional decimal currency stamps bearing the Arnold Machin portrait of Queen Elizabeth II, which have dominated British stamps since 1967, will be released July 7.

title: DRUMTOP SETS MARK IN BOWLING GREEN AT ELMONT
description: Drumtop not only beat a half dozen male rivals in the $56,800 Bowling Green Handicap at Bel mont Park yesterday, but James Moseley's 5yearold mare did it in recordbreaking time with Chuck Baltazar in the saddle.

title: 150 Protest at Coast Ball Honoring Agnew and Hope
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., June 12 (AP)Peace demonstrators cursed, spit and kicked at auto mobiles carrying guests to an Army Ball, tonight honoring Vice President. Agnew and Bob Hope.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Did you ever hear the story of the hypochondriac who wrote on his tombstone this inscription:

title: 3 Cub Homers Sink Reds
description: CHICAGO, June 12 Ken Holtzman's bid for a third con secutive shutout was shattered in the seventh inning today, but Ron Tompkins went in to preserve the victory for him as the Chicago Cubs beat the Cincinnati Reds, 52.

title: Scottish Terrier Is Judged Best Among 1,898 Dogs at Greenwich Fixture
description: STAMFORD, Conn., June 12 A 3yearold black brindle Scottish terrier, Ch. Balachan Naughty Gal, owned by Mrs. Charles C. Stalter of Woodcliff Lake, N. J., won her first best inshow award today at the 39th annual Greenwich Kennel Club dog show and obedience trial on the grounds of the Richard A. Colhoun estate.

title: L. L Artists Get Invitation
description: HUNTINGTON, L. I., June 12 Six artists from this area have been invited to exhibit their paintings and prints this spring at the Galeria Interieur in Zurich, Switzerland. They are John Black, Stan Brodsky, Lillian Dodson, Henrietta Liebo witz, and Catherine McDonald, all of Huntington, and Stanley Twardowicz of Northport.

title: Merion, Site of the Open, Is a Thinking Man's Course
description: ARDMORE, Pa., June 12If any golf course in the country can claim both history and romance, it is Merion, site of the United States Open that begins Thursday.

title: Music
description: A WEEK ago Thursday, Sotheby and Co. auc tioned off the Lady Blunt Stradivarius, and It fetched $201,000, al most quadrupling the previ ous record for a violin. That had been established in 1968 when the Marie Hall Strad came up for sale, also at a Sotheby auction.

title: Brewers Rally to Defeat Indians, 4 to 2, and End EightGame Losing Streak
description: CLEVELAND, June 12 (AP) Dave May drove in three runs and scored one today to pace the Milwaukee Brewers to 42 victory over Cleveland. The triumph halted'the Brewer's eightgame losing streak.

title: WHITE SOX HAND ORIOLES 73 LOSS
description: BALTIMORE, June 12Rich Reichardt drove in five runs with a homer and double to night and paced the Chicago White Sox to a 73 victory over Baltimore that ended the Ori oles winning streak at nine games.

title: 2d Lieut. William E. Benedict Weds Miss Barbara McClure
description: BURLINGTON, Vt., June 12 Miss Barbara Jane McClure and 2d. Lieut. William Ed ward Benedict, U.S.A., were married hero at noon today.

title: DANIELS RUNS 9.2 IN 100YARD DASH
description: WICHITA, Kan., June 12  George Daniels, a Colorado freshman from Ghana, equaled the fastest 100yard dash time tin the world this year with a 9.2second clocking at tonight's concluding session of the United States Track and Field Federation championships at Wichita State University.

title: Art
description: THE opening of the new wing of the Museum of African Art id Washington is the lat est ohapter in a sevenyear success story that could warm the cockles of the chilliest lieut. Not that It is a spec tacular story. Its appeal, rath er, is in its quietness. Instead of fireworks and high jinks it offers proof that a group of declasse virtues such as faith, tact, and a willingness to work hard can still set you on the course from rags to riches, or at least from mod est beginnings to temporary solvency.

title: I Found Gold and Well Mannered Win Divisions of Keystone at Liberty Bell
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 12 (AP) Caesar P. Kimmel's I Found Gold and Bwamazon Farm's Well Mannered captured the $20,000added divisions of the Keystone Handicap today at Liberty Bell Park.

description: The World

title: Law on Prostitution Applies to Men, Too
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. L, June 12 The village fathers struck a blow for equality of the sexes here this week when a longstanding ordinarie prohibiting prostitution was amended to apply to men as well as women.

title: What's Doing In Photography
description: NEW publication recent ly introduced should be helpful as a refer ence guide for ama teur and professional photog raphers and film makers, and for all those interested in keeping track of what is being written in the field of photog raphy. Intended as an adjunct to existing magazines, trade papers and other publications rather than as a replacement for any of them, this new publication is actually an index to material that has been published about photog raphy and related fields (journalism and electronics, for instance) in dozens of dif ferent magazines and news papers.

title: Athens Dampens Hope for Return to Democracy
description: ATHENS, June 12The Gov ernment today minimized hopes that recent contacts between Premier George Papadopoulos and former politicians were steps toward an early restora tion of democracy in Greece.

title: Francis Burde Weds Miss Duryee
description: TARRYTOWN, N. Y., June 12Miss Deborah Jane Dur yee and Francis Gregory Burde were married here this afternoon in the Butler Chapel at Marymount Col lege.

title: MADISON AVE.
description: I haven't been an art di rector since the day I start ed working at Doyle Dane Bernbach.

title: Home Improvement
description: THE painting of walls, ceilings, woodwork or exterior trim is un doubtedly one of the most popular of all doit yourself activities around the home (this includes many apartment dwellers who oft en have no choice but to do their own work nowa days). Part of the reason is certainly the fact that paint ing techniques are not dif ficult to master, butas with most other projectsthere are still many timesaving pointers and worksaving. tricks of the trade that can make the job even easier.

title: AUSTRALIA SENATE GETS AN ABORIGINE
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Juno 12 The Queensland State Parlia ment has endorsed an aborigi nal, Neville Bonner, to fill a seat in the Australian Senate. He is the first aboriginal mem ber of any Australian parlia ment.

title: Enemy Drive Is Said to Peril South Laos
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 12 (AP)A new North Vietnamese drive threatened today to cut across southern Laos and give enemy forces control of more major road and river supply routes, reports from the Laotian capital.

title: State Allocates Federal Anticrime Funds
description: Governor Rockefeller an nounced yesterday the distri bution of more than $16million in Federal funds for crime and drug addiction control pro grams in the state, with almost half of the amount allocated to New York City.

title: Art Notes
description: DENVER, a delightful cow town dressed up as a great big city, is not the likeliest setting for a meeting of museum types. But last week the plush, findesiecle lobby of the Brown Palace Hotel was crawling with them  directors, curators, conservators, registrars, pre parators, controllers, admin istrators, assistants, security officers, docents, exhibition designers and even trustees from museums of art, sci ence and history.

description: Marriage Announcement 2  No Title

title: NEW MOSCOW BID TO PEKING HINTED
description: MOSCOW, June 12Western diplomats speculated today that the Soviet Union may have un dertaken a new diplomatic effort to promote improved re lations with Communist China.

title: Cool Girl and Breach of Promise Record $1,291 Daily Double at Monmouth
description: OCEANPORT, N. J., June 12  Cool Girl and Breach of Promise accounted for a $1,291.60 daily double payoff today at Monmouth Park.

title: OBSERVER
description: Dear Abbie (Hoffman, that is): In reading your latest work, Steal. This Book, I had just gotten to the directions for cheating the telephone company when, following your com mand, somebody stole the book.

title: Et Al.
description: Autobiography of a Viennese school mistress who went in for discipline, as they say: birching the bottoms of beauteous belles, as well as other delights. She loved her mother, you see, too much. There seems to be an other volume on the way to tell of her happy life after her crim inal trial in the twenties. Will Grove erotica never cease?

title: Environmental Standards Sought in Aid Programs
description: WASHINGTON, June 12 By the end of this summer the World Bank and other mayor aid agencies hope to have guide lines permitting them to set uniform environmental stand ards for their projects in de veloping countries.

title: Grace Gunster Fiancee
description: RIDGEWOOD, N. J., June 12Mr. and Mrs. Herman Gunster have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Grace Eileen Gunster, to Mayor Louis Joseph Tullio of Erie, Pa. He is the son of Mrs. Anthony Tullio of Erie and the late Mr. Tullio. The couple plan to be married July 31.

title: Levitt to Begin Audit Of City's Books July
description: State Controller Arthur Levitt said yesterday that his office would start auditing New York City's fiscal hooks on July 1, as required by recent aot of the State Legis lature.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: The May 31 letter by Max Gordon excoriates President Nixon for his policies in Vietnam. While his harsh comments might have been emotion ally satisfying, they were characterized by distortions and specious reasoning.

title: Scince/Medicine
description: For the first time since World War II, when venereal disease in the United States was al most as common as the common cold, gonorrhea has reached epi demic proportions and is now beyond the control of public health officials. The caserate in crease last year soared by 16 per cent. And syphilis, while not yet out of control, showed a caserate increase of 8 per cent.

title: Guardsmen to Aid Scouts
description: LACONIA, N. H., June 12 (UPI)The 135 men in Com pany B of the 368th Engineer ing Battalion of the New Hamp shire National Guard will go to a Boy Scout camp in nearby Gilmanton on Monday to build roads and buildings. Capt. Charles Thomson, commander of the unit, said permission had been granted for the company to substitute the camp project for its annual summer training exercise.

title: New Fashions in Honeymoons: Hip, Super Hip And Super Square
description: SHEPARD and Linnette Erhart got married in a field near the old mill in Cornwall, Conn., where they had been living together for 18 months. Shepard, a 28  year  old Yale grad uate, had been working as a cabinet maker, and Linnette, a 26yearold grad uate of Middlebury College, had been taking courses at the Institute of Fine Arts in New Haven.

title: 2 ARIZ. STATE STARS ON ALLAMERICA NINE
description: OMAHA, June 12 (UPI) Western players dominated the 1971 allAmerica baseball team selected by the American Asso ciation of College Baseball Coaches and announced today.

title: Horse Show News
description: The United States Eques trian Team has been scratch ed from the PanAmerican Games by the United States Olympic Committee because of an outbreak of Venezue lan Equine Encephalomyeli tis (VEE).

title: Letters
description: TO THIS EDITOR: In my article on the Teamsters (What the Little Fellow Says to the Teamsters Is What Counts, May 30) I quoted a truck driver's remark about F.B.I. agents taking packages out of hijacked trucks and loading them into their own cars. The F.B.I. informs me that the removal of few items from trucks brought into the Greenpoint yard after recovery from hijackers is a standard practice sanctioned by the Justice Depart ment. The items are brought to the regional F.B.I. offices and held in the evidence file for use when the hijackers are brought to trial. The rest of the truck's contents and the truck itself are then restored to the rightful owner. A. H. RASKIN.

title: Theodore Milo Stans Marries Miss Diane Catherine Richter
description: Miss Diane Catherine Rich ter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Richter of Wester leigh, S. I., was married yes terday morning to Theodore Milo Stans, son of Maurice H. Stens, Secretary of Com merce, aid Mrs. Stans of Washington. Msgr. Francis Glenn performed the cere mony in the Roman Catholic Church of the Holy Family in Westerleigh.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In the wake of the recent announce ments by various airlines concerning special transAtlantic student fares, we would like to raise the issue of dis crimination against the muchmaligned overthirties and older students. The legality of such fares is questionable in the light of other rulings on dis crimination by age and it merits great er attention than it has received. Isn't It about time that we stopped favoring special interests and extended special benefits to all? NEIL HENRY

title: CITY TO DISCLOSE BUDGETARY TRIMS FOR DEPARTMENTS
description: Mayer Lindsay has sum moned his supercabinet, the heads of all major city depart ments; to Gracie Mansion this morning to tell them the cuts that their departments face in his revised budget.

title: 108 Million Vehicles Were Registered in'70
description: WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP)More than 108 million motor vehicles were regis tered in the United States in 1970, the Department of Transportation has reported. That total does not include motorcycles and trailers.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: TONIGHT. LIVE PROM PUERTO RICO. PABLO CASALS CONDUCTS A CONCERT SPECIAL. SEE IT AT 10 PM ON CHAN NEL 13ADVT.

title: Bridge
description: TOURNAMENT bridge is a demo cratic gamein theory, at any rate. A beginner can walk into a na tional championship, enter for an open event, and find himself playing two deals against a world champion.

title: NIXON CRITICIZED AS MAYORS MEET
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 12  President Nixon's foreign and domestic policies were sharply criticized and at times de fended today in a number of resolutions introduced at the opening session of the 38th annual United States. Confer ence of Mayors.

title: McNamara Report to Johnson On the Situation in Saigon in 63
description: Following are the texts of key documents accompanying the Pentagon's study of the Vietnam war, for the period December, 1963, through the Tonkin Gulf incident in August, 1964, and its aftermath. Except where excerpting is specified, the documents are printed verbatim, with only unmistakable typographical errors corrected.

title: Council Seeks New Corona Solution
description: An effort to patch together the socalled Corona Compro mise killed by the State Leg islature will be started tomor row in the City Council.

title: Sessions SprintCar Victor
description: ROSSBURG, Ohio, June 12 (AP) Sam Sessions swerved round a pileup today that took out the frontrunner, Larry Cannon, on his way to his sec ond United States Auto Club sprint car victory in less than 24 hours. Sessions, from Nash ville, Mich., was second for more than half of the 40lap race, but a threecar crash on the 23d lap eliminated Cannon and gave Sessions the lead.
