The next step will be an even bigger one. That will be registra tion in the A.K.C. stud book and the right to compete for championships and bestinshow awards. There are 116 breeds re corded. The last to have been ac cepted was the Shih Tzu on Labor Day, 1969.

title: 28 Hijackers of Planes Are Serving 350 Years
description: WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP)The 28 persons con victed by Federal courts of hijacking aircraft or related crimes since 1961 are serv ing sentences totaling more than 350 years, the Federal Aviation Administration said yesterday.

title: G.M. May Produce A German Engine
description: DETROIT, June 11The General Motors Corporation is rumored to be readying the revolutionary Wankel engine for production, possibly in a tiny new car for 1975.

title: Allies Propose Clearing Military From Korean DMZ
description: PANMUNJOM, Korea, June 12The United Nations Com mand proposed today that the demilitarized zone between North and South Korea be gradually cleared of all military installations and soldiers and reclaimed for farming by civilians.

title: Religion
description: A young man and a mid dleaged woman stared silently at each other across long, narrow table in a room in a tan brick building in Washington, D. C., one day last week. A guide explained that they were engaged in an exercise known as train ing rudiment zero so as to make them more able to confront another life source.

title: The Florida duPont
description: Edward Ball and Alfred I. duPont are understood to have been boyhood acquaintances. They traveled separate routes, however, before arriving in Florida in the early nine teentwenties. Mr. duPont was Delawareborn, the great grandson of Eleuthere duPont, founder of the first Ameri can powder plant.

title: UNITY HOPES FADE AMONG EMIRATES
description: BAHRAIN, June 12 (Reuters) Hopes are fading for the early establishment of a union of all nine Arab emirates in the stra tegic Persian Gulf area.

title: Banker Heads Hospital Fund Drive
description: The United Hospital Fund of New York has announced that John F. McGillicuddy, president of the Manufac turers Hanover Trust Com pany, will serve as general chairman of the 1971 cam paign.

title: PIRATES WIN, 43, ON HOMER IN 9TH
description: ST. LOUIS, June 12 (AP) Al Oliver hit his second home run of the season with two out in the ninth inning tonight, lilt ing the National League East leading Pittsburgh Pirates to a 43 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: THE WEEK IN FINANCE
description: FROM commentary, conversations and other sound ings, it is clear that there is currently a wide division of opinion among businessmen, economists and Government officials about the vitality of the econ omy as midyear approaches.

title: FLORIDA INDIANS ASSUME OWN RULE
description: MIAMI, June 12The Mic cosukee, a small, proud and fiercely independent Florida Indian tribe, have assumed con trol over their own affairs under an agreement with the Federal Government.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARISNew developments in the Soviet Union's increasingly important naval diplomacy may easily follow this weekend's general election in the tiny independent state of Malta. Should Dominic Mintoff, neutralist leader of the Labor party, succeed in ousting the proNATO Government of Dr. G. Borg Olivier, Moscow's strik ingly successful penetration of the eastern Mediterranean might well be able to edge farther westward.

description: OMAHA  Food prices, meat in particular, are headed upward and the rise probably will bring frowns to Washington officials.

description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 12Miss Charlotte Cornelia McKee and Stevens J. Wor cester were married here this afternoon.

description: BLANTYRE, Malawi  The commu niqu was polite and to tie point: Please pull over to the left and stop when encountering the Presi dent's entourage.

title: SCIENTISTS END. SUIT AND RECEIVE HONORS
description: WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) Four American atomic sci entists, who brought suit against the Government in 1956 on a patent claim involvin the proc ess that contributed to the birth of the atomic age, have dropped their claims and are being given $30,000 each in scientific awards.

description: BERKELEY, Calif., June 12 (UPI)The new liberalradical majority on Berkeley's City Council has decreed an end to summer roundups and deporta tions of youngsters in this uni versity community.

description: MANHASSET, June 12 North Shore Hospital is of fering a series of lectures from 7 to 9 P.M. Wednesdays in the Cohen Pavilion to familiarize its nursing staff with all as pects of the narcotics problem.

description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va., June 10Fiftyfive foreign graduate students gathered this week in this historic city to ponder their American experience before returning home, and they ap peared perplexed over the American predicament.

description: HOUSTON, June 12Indus tries and cities along the Hous ton ship channel, said to be the world's dirtiest stream, will be allowed to continue polluting it for the time being

description: SYDNEY, Australia, Sunday, June 13A 29yearold Aus tralian, housewife bore nine babies this morning, seven of whom are alive.

description: TO THE EDITOR: Ned O'.Gorman's article comes close to expressing my own frustration with the Catholic left. The talk at our student Masses here at Har vard is repetitive and weari some:

description: A new film, Bonsaithe Art of Training Dwarfed Potted Trees, is available for put chase or rental at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

description: Brooklyn politicians, busi nessmen and unionists believe the borough has gained a key economic victory in the deci slag of the State Legislature lost week to order a Wood haven Junction stop on the proposed highspeed rail link from Penn Station to Kennedy International Airport.

description: The financial problems of the nation's universities have grown so rapidly that there no longer is a question of whether the Federal Govern ment should offer help; the questions now are what form the aid should take and in what amounts.

description: Commissioner Urstadt's article is little more than the usual bureaucratic evasion of real issues. He ignores facts and elementary psy chology of landlord behavior.

title: Balloon Sets New Record
description: FORT COLLINS, Colo., June 12 (AP)A Denver balloonist, Chauncey Dunn Jr., soared to an altitude of 34,000 feet in a hotair balloon today for an un official world record. Karl H. Stefan, an engineer, soared to 31,500 feet in the same balloon Wednesday. The previous rec ord was 28,765 feet.

description: PORTLAND, Ore., June 12 (UPI)Doris Brown of Seat tle lowered her American record in the mile run to 4 minutes 39.6 seconds today in the Portland Rose Festival track meet.

title: The World
description: CALCUTTAThe cholera epi demic came to eastern India with a column of 100,000 refu gees who had trekked 60 gruel ing miles westward from East Pakistan in the third week of May. Exhausted, hungry and without adequate shelter, the refugees were easy prey for the particularly virulent strain of the disease they had brought with them.

title: Middle Atlantic Turns Back East for Sears Tennis Cup
description: BROOKLINE, Mass., June 12 (AP)  The Middle Atlantic States took five of six singles on the way to a 7.2 victory over the Eastern States in the final of the Sears Cup women's in tersectional competition at the Longwood Cricket Club today.

description: To the Editor: In a recent letter former Repre sentative Richard L. Ottinger charac terized as dangerously misleading William D. Ruckelshaus defense of the Nixon Administration's proposed permit program under the Refuse Act of 1899.

title: Newyork
description: When I prepare for the Al bany journey, I think of Henry Hudson, who began his own journey as captain of the stately Half Moon and ended it in rowboat somewhere off the coast of Canada.

description: KARACHI, Tune 12  Feroz Abdullah, a truck driver who ran over and killed Poland's Deputy Foreign Minister, Zyg fryd Wolniak, at Karachi Air port last Nov. 1, was hanged here today.

description: David Cohen, an enterpris ing 47yearold Philadelphia lawyer, has discovered it pays good dividends to acquire some bankrupt companies.

description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 12 James F. Baldwin's 61foot sloop, Sorcery, which sails out of Edgartown, Mass., today won the second race of the In dian Harbor Yacht Club's an nual fourpart Whitmore Tro phy cruising yacht series on Long Island Sound.

title: About Baseball
description: Did you ever read a base ball rulebook closely?

title: Letter to the Editor 13  No Title
description: To THE EDITOR: Toward the end of Brigid Brophy's generous review of The Prisoner of Sex (May 23), she lights upon my phrase politics rendered every pride and concludes it is a malapropism. Surrendered does he mean, asks Miss Brophy, or rent? Well, I guess a number of us know something about the kitchen that Brigid don't. Render is used to describe that process where fat heated upon a fire is returned to oil and clarified of its impurities. So too can the hot and compromising hands held in politics melt pride on occasion down to shame. But how was it ever possible that the modest manifestos of The Prisoner of Sex could yet have Tendered Brophy's nectar into surrenders of vinegar and rents of urea's hot torrent? Brave and broiling Brigid. We must find a man good enough to kiss her hem. Ahem! Yours, and cordially.

title: Burtis's Guachero Victor In Sea Cliff Star Sailing
description: SEA CLIFF, L. I., June 12 Alan Burtis's Guachero set the pace in Star Class competition today after sailing at the Sea; Cliff Yacht Club was delayed for 1 hours.

title: Mitsubishi's Turboprop
description: A $450,000 airplane from Japana descendant of the agile, Zero fighter of World War IIis proving to be an increasingly effective foe in the competitive United States corporate plane market.

title: They Traded Stocks for Pies, Rockets for Snails
description: LONDON  Friends who visit the United States frequently tell me they often meet Americans who have quit (or are planning to quit) their executive suites to seek happiness in the country by opening an antiques shop, buying a farm or running a smalltown restaurant. Re cently I have been looking up some of their counterparts in Britainmen and women who have dropped out of the bigcity rat race, including some who have embraced the art of hospitality and good food as the proprietor of an inn or restaurant amid the fresh air and slowerpaced life of the countryside.

title: 400 Guests Invited, but No Congressmen
description: WASHINGTON, June 12J. Edgar. Hoover was in but Congress was out as Tricia Nixon became the bride today of Edward. Finch Cox.

title: Reader's Report
description: This novel of estrangement from America is itself part of the American literary tradition. Aram Tomasian drops out of Armenian Hoboken and goes underground in search of im ponderables to which his blood will respond. Armenian as Aram is (Mr. Najarian corn presses the history of a people in a brilliant smattering of lyrical impressions), I was re minded of Bruce Dudley, the Wanderer in Sherwood Ander son's Dark Laughter, drop ping out of Chicago and down to New Orleans in puriuit of liberation.

title: PROSPECTS GOOD FOR U.N. CENTER
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 12  After a number of false starts, the building of United Nations visitors center and of office and hotel space for diplomats, is about to get under way.

title: U.S. URGES INDIANS AND PAKISTANIS TO USE RESTRAINT
description: WASHINGTON, June 12The United States appealed today to India and Pakistan to exercise restraint and urged the Paki stanis to restore normal condi tions in East Pakistan through peaceful political accommoda tion.

title: Queens Society Elects
description: Four participantshistorians have been elected as trustees, until 1974, of the Queens His torical Society. They are Miss Mary Bromharn of Whitestone, Robert Kalish of Flushing, Henry F. Ludder of Whitestone and Dr. Kenneth Scott of Douglas ton.

title: Janice Irene Thomson Is Bride Of Roy Levin, a Yale Alumnus
description: WILTON, Conn., June 12 Miss Janice Irene Thom son, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald W. Thomson, was married here this after noon to Roy Levin in his toric Wilton Congregational Church, erected in 1790. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter R. Levin of Wilton. The Rev. W. Stewart MacColl minister of the Wil ton Presbyterian Church, performed the ceremony.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Perhaps the rationalization most fre quently advanced to explain our par ticipation in the immoral and senseless Vietnam war is that we are fighting to establish the right of the local pop ulation freely to elect a government of its own choosing. Passing over the fact that a logical extension of this doctrine would seem to warrant our intervention in Greece, Portugal and many other countries, it is surely a bitter irony, that the election law just adopted in Saigon will doubtless have the desired effect of insuring that President Thieu will be unopposed in his bid for reelection. The silence from Washington Is practically deaf ening.

title: New York
description: One of the most emotional, contentious, bitterly divisive and prolonged sessions of the New York State Legislature fi nally adjourned in the black hours of Wednesday morning at Albany last week. The session raft New Yorkers both with heavier tax burdens and with cutbacks in services, especially in ghetto areas.

title: Miss Sandra S. Thornhill Married
description: EDGARTOWN, Mass., June 12  Miss Sandra Susanne Thornhill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Thornhill Jr. of Wellesley Hills and Edgar town, was married here this afternoon in St. Andrew's Episcopal Church to Thomas Marshall Brushart, son of Mrs. Charles Swan Weber of Chevy Chase, Md., and the late Dr. Marshall Brushart.

title: Gottliebs Down Hartmans In FatherandSon Doubles
description: SOUTHAMPTON, L. I., June 12Bill Gottlieb of Kings Point and his son, Steve, beat the firstseeded team of Leonard and Steve Hartman of Wood mere, 63, 61, to reach the semifinals of the Eastern father songrass tennis championship today at the Meadow Club. Steve and Peter Ogilvy of New Rochelle, N. Y., also gained the semifinals by upsetting Bill and Pete Adolph of Bronxville, N.Y., seeded second, 61,46,61.

title: Take an old mill
description: With Americans busily acquiring chateaux abroad, Europeans are at tempting to save a few domestic treasures for themselves. French artist JeanLouis Germain managed to take possession of this 18thcentury mill in the region of Fontainebleau before the foreigners could grab Over the years the stone building had been added on to until today its roofs and gables resemble a tiny medieval settlement. Mr. Germain had to install modern conveniences, but in all ways he preserved the rhythm of the old architecture. Inside, he applied the artist's quixotic temperament to the furnishings. Where he wished to be traditional (the dining room), he was And when the urge to own Barcelona chairs over took him (the living room), he succumbed. The marriage of old archi tecture with contemporary art and furniture can as this renovation shows, be a happy one for all concerned.

title: Texas Reapportionment May Bring South's First Black Congressman Since 1901
description: WASHINGTON, June 12The Texas Legislature has passed legislation that will almost cer tainly lead to the election of the first black member of Con gress from a Southern state since Reconstruction.

title: DEVICE BREAKS UP FOG AT AIRPORTS
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., June 12 (AP)Science has found a way to disperse flightdelaying fog at airports but the method is so costly it is feasible only for busy airports, an official of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration has reported.

title: Puerto Rican Parade Is Set for 1 P.M. Today
description: The 16th annual Puerto Rican Day parade will begin at 1 P.M. today. The marcious will go up Fifth Avenue from 44th Street to 86th Street.

title: Show Will Feature Art By Mentally Ill Children
description: An exhibition of artwork by mentally ill children un der care by the New York State Department of Mental Hygiene will be displayed in the community gallery of the Brooklyn Museum from June 27 through July 25. Admis sion will be free.

title: North Vietnamese Reelect President And Other Leaders
description: HONG KONG, June 12 (Reu ters)North Vietnam's new Na tional Assembly has reelected almost all the nation's top lead ers, including its 83yearold President, Ton Duc Thang.

title: Letters:
description: To THE EDITOR: Only an incurable optimist could possibly describe the Spanish town of Ronda as being within short driving distance of Malaga. It is not eight milesas stated in the article Beaches, Bulls and Pablo, Too (Travel section, May 23)but 68, the latter half of which (going via the coast to San Pedro and then north on C.339, the most di rect route) is a beautiful but tortuous mountain road with a multitude of hairpin curves and an absence of guardrails. It takes close to four hours to negotiate the trip. Inci dentally, the spelling of Malaga's mighty fortress is not Alcabaza but Alcazaba.

title: Focus Turns to Bombing
description: As the Vietcong rebellion gathered strength, so did interest in bombing the North as a substitute for successful prosecution of the counterinsurgency campaign in the South, or at least as an effort to force Hanoi to reduce guer rilla activity to a level where the feeble Saigon Government could handle it.

title: Ashe, Riessen Win
description: BRISTOL, England, June 12 (UPI)Arthur Ashe and Marty Riessen advanced today in the $48,000 Wills grass tennis tour nament as rain finally let up to permit play.

title: Lucky You, $23.80, Wins Finger Lakes Dash by Neck
description: CANANDAIGUA, N.Y., June 12 (AP)Lucky You, a 10to1 shot, returned $23.80 for $2 to day, after beating Capital Host by a neck in the feature race at Finger Lakes Race Track.

title: Dunwoody Captures Soling Laurels
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 12 William McComb Dunwoody led at every mark of a 6.3mile Gold Cup course on Long Island Sound today and won the Soling Class race with Chance's Are.

title: Miss Serina Martin Is Married In Palm Beach to Jorge Sanchez
description: PALM BEACH, Fla Jude 12  St. Edward's Roman Catholic Church was the setting here this evening for, the marriage of Miss Serena Anne Bradley Martin, daugh ter of Mrs. Edwina Atwell. Martin of Palm Beach and Brookville, L. I., and Esmond Bradley Martin of Old West bury, L. I., to Jorge Alberto Sanchez, a 1971 graduate of Villanova University. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Rafael E. Sanchez, formerly of Havana.

title: Article 4  No Title
description: STANTON, Del., June 12 (AP) Herbalist, a Greentree Stable colt who won last year's Ar kansas Derby, ran his best race since in capturing today's fea tured purse at Delaware Park.

title: Horses Tranquilized
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 12 (UPI)  Three thoroughbreds were tranquilized in their stables at Liberty Bell Park this week, a track spokesman dis closed today.

title: Miss Ramsey Has Nuptials
description: STAMFORD, Conn., June 12Miss Marianne Ramsey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Cornwall Ramsey, was married here this afternoon to Terry Ashton Louderback, an engineering student at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The Rev. Robert Dresser performed the cere mony in St. Francis Episco pal Church, Long Ridge, here.

title: Whatever Became of Richard Burton?
description: IN Villain, his latest and least interesting bad movie, he makes a real oldfashioned Star Entrance: the camera first sees a figure in deep shadow lying on bed. Someone knocks on the door and calls the man. He gets up, stumbles through the gloom into what turns out to be the loo, and turns on a switch by the medicine cabinet. There, suddenly, in the flat brilliance that is the particular, dismal quality of fluorescent light, especially in a bathroom, staring back at himself in a mirror, is face so blank that it appears to be almost featureless. Oval, if a little heavy in the jowls below, with tiny eyes above, the hair a little too long, but not really in the style of today, or in the style of the London hood he is playing, but in the style of someone relaxing at Downey's after the night's performance of Shakespeareinthe Park. The star has made his entrance, the actor has arrived, but character never shows up.

title: L.I. School Finds Austerity Is Painful
description: EAST QUOGUE, L I,. June 12 This small Southartipton community, the only Suffolk County school district that sident the entire academic year without a voterapproved budg et, provides a vivid picture of what could be in store for the 52 Long Island school districts that Adler this year have failed to, approve their budgets.

title: MRS. KROLL SCORES IN WHEELCHAIR MEET
description: Mrs. Rose Marie Kroll, rep resenting the MidJersey Paras of West Orange, N. J., raised her gold medal production in the 15th annual National Wheelchair Games to three yes terday by winning a pair of field events at Bulova Park, Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: George A. Hamid Dead at 75; Ran Steel Pier in Atlantic City
description: ATLANTIC CITY, Tune 13 George A. Harnid, a Lebanese born tumbler who became worldfamous impresario and the millionaire owner of the fa mous Steel Pier here, died to night of cancer in Atlantic City Hospital. He was 75 years old.

title: Medicine Blends With Politics In Office of Mayor of Harlem
description: My office is not an office any more, it's a center, said Dr. Benjamin W. Watkins, podiatrist, chiropractor and mayor of Harlem, as he glanced around a small room cluttered with crates of Coca Cola and huge boxes of Fig Newtons.

title: Franklyn MacCormack, 63, Chicago Radio Performer
description: CHICAGO, June 13 Frank lyn MacCormack, a radio per former who was known for his reading of poetry to music, died yesterday in Loretto Hos pital after suffering a heart attack while doing his allnight radio show on station WGN. He was 63 years old and lived in Lake Zurich, Ill.

title: Britons Seek to Bar Sale of Titian to Any Foreigner
description: LONDON, June 13British art circles, dismayed over the upcoming sale of a Titian masterpiece, have begun vocal and somewhat angry campaign to keep the paint ing in this country.

title: RICHMOND LANDON, 20 OLYMPIC VICTOR
description: LYNBROOK, L. I., June 13 Richmond W. Landon, a retired advertising executive who won the Olympic high jump as Yale undergraduate in 1920, died today at his home, 19 Devon Lane. He was 72.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Political ambition reaches its highest point when the Mayor advocates that a citystate be carved out so as to bypass the alleged political tyranny of the Governor and the State Legis lature. It should be obvious that there is a limit to the Federal Government's ability to tax individuals and corpora tions, and the condition of the na tional economy would indicate that limit has been reached.

title: U.S. Plans to Increase Aid to Foreign Police Forces to Help Fight Subversion

title: Adelle Davis: 67 and Going Strong
description: She's 67 and the strong features are laced with un abashed wrinkles. But the pink and white skin glows and the blue eyes are as vivid as a sunlit sea.

title: Rusk Cable to Embassy in Laos On Search and Rescue Flights
Bachelor Rally, Begun as Prank, Is No Joke to Hopeful
description: NEW SALEM, N.D., June 13  This weekend, all the lonely people came to this prairie town of 942 persons, swollen to three times its normal size for Bachelor Days, where men met wo men against a backdrop of rodeos and country music, carnivals and beer.

title: Italians Voting Local Elections That May Influence Government
description: ROME, June 13  Italians began two days of voting to day in local elections that could strongly influence the uneasy centerleft coalition Government of Premier Emilio Colombo.

title: The Hour Approaches

Mr. Bundy ex plained that the memorandum encom passed, besides his own thoughts, those of Mr. Forrestal, head of the interagency committee, and Ambassador Unger, who had recently been transferred back to Washington from Vientiane.

title: Porcelain Boehm Birds Attract a Flock
description: ATLANTIC CITY, June 13 Boehm birds and Boehm birdlovers flocked here this weekend for an unconven tional convention, highlight ing a new series of porcelain sculptures.

title: 19 POLICE INJURED AT PARADE HERE
description: Twenty people were arrested and many others, including 19 policemen, were injured yester day when hundreds of Young Lords and members of other radical Puerto Rican groups in terrupted the 16th annual Puerto Rican Day Parade with protests over their political and social status in the Unite:, States.

title: Conrad Hurlimann Dies at 54; A Vice President of CibaGeigy
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 13 Conrad G. Hurlimann, a vice president and director of Ciba Geigy Corporation, chemicals, died today at his home on Frost Road after a long illness. His age was 54.

title: Mets Win, 5 to 4, on Sacrifice Fly in 10th;
description: It took the New York Mets 10 innings to outlast the San Francisco Giants yesterday and 5 hours to outlast the weatherbut they did both and defeated the Giants, 54, before 52,010 persons in Shea Stadium.

title: GREYTON TAYLOR WINE MAKER, DIES
description: HAMMONDSPORT, N. Y., June 13Greyton H. Taylor, vice president of the Taylor Wine Company and president of its Pleasant Valley Wine Company division, which makes Great Western Cham pagne, died today in Genesee Hospital, Rochester. He was 68 years Old.

title: Plan of Action Attributed To McNaughton at Pentagon
description: I. Analysis of the present situation. The situation in South Vietnam is de teriorating. Even before the government sank into confusion last week, the course of the war in South Vietnam had been downward, with Viet Cong incidents in creasing in number and intensity and military actions becoming larger and more successful, and with less and less territory meaningfully under the control of the government. Successful ambushes had demonstrated an unwillingness of the population even in what were thought to be pacified areas to run the risk of informing on the Viet Cong. War weariness was apparent. The crisis of the end of Augustespecially since the competing forces have left the govern ment largely faceless and have dam aged the government's ability to manage the pacification programpromises to lead to further and more rapid deteriora tion. The objective of the United States is to reverse the present down ward trend. Failing that, the alternative objective is to emerge from the situa tion with as good an image as possible in US, allied and enemy eyes.

title: Kathy Whitworth Scores a 74 for 288 to Recapture L.P. GA. Title
description: SUTTON, Mass., June 13 (AP) Kathy Whitworth regained the Ladies Professional Golf As sociation championship that had eluded her in playoffs in 1968 and 1970 by winning the $55, 000 Eve tournament today. She had a 72hole total of 288 for the par73 Pleasant Valley Country Club course of 6,130 yards.

title: U.S. Filly Takes $280,000 French Oaks
description: CHANTILLY, France, June 13 Mrs. Alec Head's Amer icanbred filly, Pistol Packer, trained by her husband and ridden by their son, Freddy, won the 123d running of the $280,000 Prix de Diane today in a microscopic photo finish.

title: 1 KILLED IN UNREST IN ALBUQUERQUE
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., (UPI) A crowd of about 500 per sons burned and looted down town stores and battled the police with rocks, bricks and firebombs last night. One man was shot to death.

title: JULIUS KUSCHNER
description: Julius Kuschner, a lawyer who had specialized in estates and real estate law until his re tirement two years ago, died yesterday in New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived at 1122 Avenue N, Brooklyn.

title: Shop Talk
description: The name of Emilio (Emi lio Pucci, that, is) has for so long been associated with those featherweight silk jer sey print dresses that it comes as a bit of surprise to know that someone named Emilia (Emilia Bellini, that is) not only designs similar dresses but does so in the very same Italian city: Florence. The Bellini dresses may be found here at Lillums, a shop at 703 Madi son Avenue (between 62d and 63d), and they bear the designer's signature, just as the Pucci ones do. They also cost about the same$135 for a longsleeved sheath, $220 for a floorlength one. And then there are the gossamer wool jerseys like Pucci makes, and these are around $135.

title: Hulme Captures Opening CanAm R'ace After Steward's Early Challenge Fails
description: BOWMANVILLE, Ontario, June 13For 25 minutes this afternoon Jackie Stewart did reasonably well in the role of Jack the Giant Killer. In the end, however, his slingshot failed him, and the bright or ange cars of the McLaren Rac ing Team wonas usualthe first two places in the opening CanadianAmerican race of the season.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Your opposition to Senator Mans field's proposal for a unilateral with drawal of half our forces in Europe is based on a fallacy you have exposed often enough in the past. Why do you believe that governments any more than people will give in only when punished or threatened enough? Mass bombing brought neither the English nor the Germans nor the North Viet namese to their knees. The drive for superiority in weapons, even for a bal ance of power, does nat facilitate nego tiation, it only perpetuates an arms race.

description: Special assistant to Presidents Ken nedy and Johnson for national security affairs, 196166  since 1966, presi dent of the Ford Foundation. Born Bos ton March 30, 1919  graduated from Yale, 1940, majoring in classics and mathematics  ran as a Repub lican for seat on Boston City Council, 1941  served as aide to Adm. Alan G. Kirk, World War II  foreign policy adviser to Thomas E. Dewey, Re publican Presidential candidate,.1948 joined Harvard faculty, 1949  be came dean of Faculty of Arts and Sci ences, 1953  named by President Kennedy to White House post  often described as principal architect of U.S. Vietnam policy  was recalled briefly by President Johnson during the Arab Israeli crisis in summer of 1967  Often seen as a potential Secretary of State  just as visible  and con troversial  as foundation head as when directing foreign policy from White House basement office  now lives in New York.

The unemploy ment rate average was 20 per cent.

title: Taylor's Briefing of Key Officials On Situation in November, 64
description: After a year of changing and inef fective government, the counterinsur gency program countrywide is bogged down and will require heroic treatment to assure revival. Even in the Saigon area, in spite of the planning and the special treatment accorded the Hop Tac plan, this area also is lagging. The northern provinces of South VietNam which a year ago were considered al most free of VietCong are now in deep trouble. In the Quang NgaiBinh Dinh area, the gains of the VietCong have been so serious that once more we are threatened with a partition of the country by a VietCong salient driven to the sea. The pressure on this area has been accompanied by continuous sabotage of the railroad and of High way 1 which in combination threaten an economic strangulation of northern provinces.

title: Making a Case in Public
description: By this time, the Administration felt that it had sufficient information on in filtration to make a public case for bombing the North. The intelligence com munity had obtained evidence that a minimum of 19,000 and a maximum of 34,000 infiltrators, mostly former south erners who had fought against the French in the Vietminh, had entered the South since 1959. Chester L. Cooper, a former intelligence officer, had put together a major report on Hanoi's sup port and direction of the guerrillas, but the Administration had decided earlier in December against public dis closure of the document itself because this might create undesirable specu lation, and had instead instructed the Ambassador to continue the piecemeal approach. Now, the analyst says, Mr. Rusk wanted this halted as well for fear that more publicity might create pres sure for action prematurely.

title: Screen: 'Unman, Wittering and Zigo'
description: I think it was Franois Truffaut who said that he could usually tell within the first five minutes whether or not a movie was any good. In the history of connoisseurship this ploy may be worth recording, but for practical criticism I doubt that it has much to recommend itignoring as it does movies that take a while to find themselves (at least in the viewer's mind), and movies that from a position of relative strength work inexorably toward a condition of absolute, unredeemable loss.In the latter category belongs John Mackenzie's "Unman, Wittering and Zigo," which opened yesterday at Cinema II, and which begins full of ripe and gruesome promise that very shortly turns overripe and openly ridiculous.Unman, Wittering and Zigo are the last three names on the roll call for Lower 5B, a form full of malignant malcontents at Chantry, a second-rate British public school, where young John Ebony (David Hemmings), fresh from the disillusionments of a job in advertising, has come to teach. His appointment is something of a fluke, his predecessor having died in midterm from a tumble down a nearby cliff, and almost no time at all is lost before the gentlemen of Lower 5B inform their new master that the death was no accident; his predecessor was pushed, and they did the pushing.Ebony's problem, as Lower 5B knows full well, is that if he reports the murder, nobody will believe him (he doesn't, at first, believe it himself), but if he keeps quiet and does a few favors for the classnot much work, decent grades for those who want them, bets placed and winnings collected from the local bookie, etc.they will protect his academic career and perhaps let him survive the semester as well.A modus vivendi, the boys call it, but one that fails when Ebony learns that his appointment is not to be renewed and that he has, at Chantry, no academic career to protectbut only his own sanity and the well-being and perhaps respect of a wife (Carolyn Seymour) who is not long on wifely indulgence. It is when this happens, when the mood has all been built and the story begins to move, that "Unman, Wittering and Zigo" really falls apart, though it had never been too well glued from the beginning.But at the beginning it is easy to make excuses. And Mackenzie's spectacularly subjective camera and his Latin-encrusted boys' school and even his Lower 5B, which speaks in unison or to instantaneous cuelike some evil, over-trained minstrel troupeinvite if not the willing suspension of disbelief at least the expectation of pleasurable surrender to efficient nonsense. When that expectation is not satisfied, when the movie becomes too absurd in its inventions and too indifferent in how it works them out, the failure seems of more than ordinary proportions.Most of the performances are good, up to the level asked of them. David Hemmings's neophyte master suggests enthusiasm without sentimentality, and the boys mostly manage to project malevolence minus any regrets for their lost innocence. Nicholas Hoye as Cloistermouth, the prettiest of the fallen angels, is especially scary. Carolyn Seymour plays the young wife as if she were competing for the Glenda Jackson award in emotional reserve. But when the chips are down and she must show some feeling, it becomes apparent that there isn't any reserve; there is only no emotion.

description: The Eastern Paralyzed Vet erans Association, using a well balanced squad, dethroned the University of Illinois Gizz Kids in the 15th annual National Wheelchair Games, which ended three days of competition yesterday at Bulova Park, Jack son Heights, Queens.

title: Forrester's Law

title: Theater: Merry Wives of Windsor
description: STRATFORD, Conn.The American Shakespeare Fes tival Theater has started its season here, moderately well with a moderately fair pro duction of The Merry Wives of Windsor. I wonder why. It would seem that the only possible justification for a production of The Merry Wives is the presence of a great clown determined against all reason to play the lesser Falstaff. Such circumstances did not here obtain.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Whatever one's opinion of the wis dom of vacancy decontrol, the irref utable fact is that it has passed, and is now the law. The angry cries of local officials might better be replaced by serious attention as to how the law's benefitsa rise in income for ownerscan be made to outweigh its perilsthe possibility that owners may make present tenants so uncomforta ble that they will be forced to move. Above all, everyone should direct his thoughts as to how the increased in come may be used to improve housing conditions.

title: Playboy Plans to Go Public To Finance Its Expansion

title: Highlights of the Period

title: 1936 Bugatti Is Sold for 59,000 in 5Minute Auction

The blue touring car is be lieved to be one of two of its type remaining in the world. Dr. Peter Williamson, a neurologist from Greenwich, Conn., who is president of the American Bugatti Club, bought his 13th Bugatti in the onelot Sotheby Parke Bernet sale which lasted only five minutes.

She was checking art work for ads that are to appear in the next few weeks, planning a backtoschool booklet of next fall's fashions and flipping through photo graphs of glamour girls of the nineteen thirties, taken before she was born.

title: Account of Taylor's Meeting With Saigon Generals on Unrest

I told you all clearly at General Westmoreland's dinner we Americans were tired of coups. Appar ently I Wasted my words. Maybe this is because something is wrong with my French because you evidently didn't un derstand. I made it clear that all the military plans which I know you would like to carry out are dependent on gov ernmental stability. Now you have made a real mess. We cannot carry you for ever if you do things like this. Who speaks for this group? Do you have a spokesman?

title: News Analysis
description: It was an academic year that began with trepidation and ended with cau tious optimism. Administrators who spent last summer and fall beefing up their campus security forces and formu lating contingency plans to deal with disturbances were surprised, but none theless relieved, when tranquility descended upon America's colleges and universities. Assuredly, there were disturbances. But neither in number nor in intensity did they compare with what administrators said that they expected after the frenzied conclusion to the 196970 school year when Cam bodia, Kent State and Jackson State became war cries among the nation's young.

title: Draft Objectors Group Gains Respect

title: Books of The Times
description: Without any ands, ifs or buts, let it be said that Pierre Salinger has written a su perior suspense novel that is thoroughly absorbing, splendidly plotted and scrupul ously written. And he has done it by mak ing the suspense derive not from gore, mayhem and derringdo, although the book has its share of these, but from the haz ards of political maneuvering, the clash of ideologies and from the natural complex ity that is inherent in all human situa tions. Although it can and surely will he classed as an entertainment, his book has a darkly se rious side, with a conclusion that may not please everyone. But I can't imagine anyone who will not be pleased along the way. It reveals an ex pertise that rings true on every page. Wheth er the incidents are true, whether govern ment procedures, for eign policy and party maneuvering are shaped as the book says, deponent knoweth not. But they certainly carry a great deal of conviction. After all, Mr. Salinger was press secretary to Presidents Kennedy and Johnson. The writing and dialogue are crisp and always to the point. As a former newspaperman, who knows what it is to face a parcel of predatory copy editors, he never wastes a word. All his sentences are fundamental. This qual ity speeds the story along and leaves the reader with the feeling that something is happening on every page. True, his char acters run to types. They are neither high ly original, nor very complicated, and he has leavened the text with some melodra matic exchanges. But these are not defects. His novel is modest; he knows his own strengths and he uses what serves him best.

title: Screen: Nicholson's 'Drive, He Said':Movie Marks Actor's Debut as Director Tale of College Athlete Opens at Tower East
description: "Drive, He Said," loosely adapted by Jeremy Larner and Jack Nicholson from Larner's 1964 Delta Prize novel, and directed by Nicholson (his directorial debut), comes close to being the sort of movie about the anxieties and dilemmas of the sixties that no one ever made in the sixtieswhich were constantly confused with the more innocent fifties. It is not a great film, but it is an often intelligent one, and it is so much better than all of the rest of the campus junk Hollywood has manufactured in the last couple of years that it can be indulged its sentimental conventions.Specifically, it's about a star college athlete, Hector Bloom, to whom basketball is what boxing is to Private Prewitt what playwriting maybe to Tennessee Williams and what risking an arm or a leg or a life probably is to Peter Gimbel. Like some forms of art, it is, simultaneously, a heightened response to the world, a mystical retreat from it, and a practical way of getting along in it.In the course of his senior year, Hector begins to feel, in his word, disconnected. The old game doesn't quite mean what it once did. He is more than a little surprised to find that he is in love with Olive, the professor's wife with whom he's been having an affair, and he is shocked when the joy of his discovery isn't shared by Olive, who is not so simply pregnant.Hector admires and envies the campus radicals, who are so committed to a cause that they can interrupt a basketball game for an anti-Vietnam demonstration, staged as guerrilla theater. He himself hasn't the faintest idea where he is going or why. When a pro ball club asks him to sign, he demands only that the club improve the quality of the frankfurters it sells to the public, and cut the price from 50c to a quarter.In fact, Hector is so disconnectedat least in terms of the character as writtenthat it comes as a major surprise, late in the film, to learn that he is a Greek major. This bit of information, which I assume is presented seriously, is as unsettling as learning that someone you thought you knew extremely well is, in reality, one-half of a pair of twins. It means that an important (or, at the least, a time-consuming) part of Hector's life has been kept secret.Also fairly secret is Hector's state of mind, though William Tepper, a tall, dark-haired young man who may or may not have studied the collected works of Dustin Hoffman, defines well enough Hector's individual attitudes of frustration, anger and what might be called romantic campus lassitude. A reading of Larner's novel fills in a lot of these gaps, but otherwise the novel might mislead the filmgoer into expecting satiric fantasy (which the movie never achieves), having to do with unnamed wars (not in Vietnam), with a lot of bizarre characters who might have been created by Waugh, and with middle-class American-Jewish intellectual and social life.One result of this secrecyperhaps simplification is a better termsis that most of the other characters in the film, just because they are the supporting characters in the film as well as in Hector's life, are more thoroughly and quickly defined, and thus more vivid and appealing than Hector. I especially liked Karen Black as the besieged Olive, a woman who once might have ben fated to be misunderstood and badly used by men, but who finally liberates herself; Robert Towne, as her husband, who would prefer to dry his beard with an electric comb than wory about cuckoldry; Bruce Dern, as the intensely clean-living coach, and Michael Margotta, who looks like a young Elisha Cook Jr., as Hector's radical roommate whose ultimate act of survival provides the film with its obligatory, if shopworn, irony.Most importantly, al of the film's characters, and all of the performances, are touched with the kind of unexpected sensibility and decency that are rare in most films of this genre. It's a quality that I associate with the performances Nicholson himself gave in both "Easy Rider" and "Five Easy Pieces." Nicholson not only is good with actors, but he also chooses to avoid most of the visual (and aural) clichs of the day, and when he does indulge himselfas in the fine basketballl sequencesthey no longer seem clichs since the rhythm of the sport more or less demands the treatment. I wish I could report that Hector was as interesting as the film that surrounds him.

title: Nader on Monopoly
description: Antitrust, said the historian Richard Hofstadter, is a faded passion of American reform. Indeed, many lib erals now accept the proposition that modern technology has led to the emergence of what John Kenneth Galbraith calls the new industrial state in which huge corpora tions dominate the marketplace and the political process as well. According to this view, it is useless to try to revive competition as a force for regulating corporate behavior, improving efficiency and serving consumer interests; the only hope is for government to civilize and regulate huge corporations and thus make them, in effect, a detached and autonomous arm of the state, but responsive to the larger purposes of the society.

title: Lieut. Gov. Sargeant Reynolds Of Virginia Is Dead Here at 34

title: Min in the News

Last night the Na tional Council of Police Societies, a federation of black police groups, honored Mr. Lamb for his work throughout the country to improve relations between black communities and the police, and for his technical assistance to black police officers as a member of the department's Commu nity Relations Service in New York.

title: The StarSpangled Banner

Iconoclasts (literally, breakers of ikons) rarely provoke greater opposition than when they begin to attack or destroy our most cherished ikon, the flagwhich became the national symbol by act of Congress 194 years ago today. There should have been no surprise at the vehemence of the hardhat workers who defended Old Glory by beating student antiwar demonstrators. The recent Federal law imposing a $1,000 fine and/or a year in jail for those who desecrate a flag which may have cost only a few dollars reflects a widespread scale of values.

Such strikes should be spread out over a period of several weeks, and targets should be limited to those deemed suitable for attack by T28s and listed Para. 8 Vientiane's 581, excluding Mu Gia pass and any target which Lao will not hit without U.S. air cover or fire support since decision this matter not yet made.

title: Short Workday for City of a Summer Tradition
description: The city's policy of allowing its officeworkers to go home an hour early each day in the summer dates to the mid nineteentwenties, long before the era of airconditioning.

title: Parley on War Victims Is Inconclusive
description: GENEVA, June 13A three week debate on possible changes in the 1949 Geneva conventions for the protection of war victims ended here in conclusively yesterday.

title: French Left Nears Unity; Communist Issue Remains
description: PARIS, June 13The bat tered and divided democratic Left in France pulled itself together a hit today but failed to resolve its overriding prob lem: whether to try to form a united front with the Com munists.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In its May 29 issue, The Times published an editorial entitled Threat to Chile's Freedom, in which it is asserted that there are grounds for doubting that free institutions can survive the economic straitjackets being fashioned by the Allende coalition. One of these institutions is Chile's free press.

title: Fluor Corp. Shows Drop of 28.1% in Earnings for the Quarter
Britain's Trade Surplus Hit $67.2Million in May
description: LONDON, June 14Britain last month recorded a visible trade surplus of $67.2million, but the Department of Trade and Industry warned today that the result might have been erratically high.

title: Taylor Cable to Washington On StepUp in Ground Forces
description: This message undertakes to summarize instructions which I have received over the last ten days with regard to the introduction of thirdcountry combat forces and to discuss the preferred way of presenting the subject to the GVN.

title: L.I. Church DayCare Center Rejected
description: MINEOLA, L. I., June 14A longstanding controversy over plans by a Garden City church to establish a daycare center for 27 disadvantaged children was apparently ended today when the Nassau County Board of Supervisors refused funds for the facility.

title: WEEDEN PARES LOSS FOR 2MONTH PERIOD
description: Weeden & Co., a major overthecounter brokerage concern, disclosed yesterday that it had incurred a net loss of $306,055 in the two months ended May 31, compared with a loss of $415,144 in the comparable period of 1970.

title: ISRAELI PIPELINE TERMED A TARGET
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 14The Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, which claimed responsibility for the rocket attack Friday against Israelichartered tanker bound for Israel, has warned that it may carry out further operations.

title: Senate Panel Hears Integration Ousts Black Principals in South
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP)  The Senate Committee on Equal Educational Opportunity was told today that hundreds of black school principals in Southern states had been romoved or demoted as a result of school desegregation.

title: 4 Americans Reported Killed By North Vietnamese in Ambush
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam Tuesday, June 15 (AP)North Vietnamese forces ambushed an American unit 42 miles northeast of Saigon killing four Americans and wounding eight the United States command said today.

title: Thai Malaysian Pledge
description: KUALA LUMPUR June 14 (AP)Premier Thanom Kittikachorn of Thailand and Prime Minister Abdul Razak of Malaysia pledged tonight to cooperate, closely to fight Communist guerrillas operating along common borders. The Thai Premier is visiting here.

title: Prison For Women, Shut Down by City, To Be Demolished
description: The Women's House of Detention, from which the last of 422 inmates was removed Sunday morning, will remain closed during the summer and will eventually be demolished, Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday.

title: Mr. Nixon on Housing
description: President Nixon's statement of policy concerning racial discrimination in housing recognizes that there is a decisive difference between desegregation and integration. Desegregation forbids any racial barrier to the purchase or rental of property and precludes a community's use of the zoning power to keep out federally assisted housing which would be racially integrated.

title: Vatican Acts on Sainthoods
description: ROME, June 14 (Reuters)The Roman Catholic Church today took the first steps in declaring five new saints, one of them a Polish priest who died in the Nazi concentration camp at Auschwitz in 1941.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: THE PRESIDENT Activities. The President had a morning meeting with top diplomatic ambassadors, Secretary of State William P. Rogers, Treasury Secretary John B. Connally Jr., H.E.W. Secretary Elliot L. Richardson and Attorney General John N. Mitchell to discuss the narcotics problem in Vietnam and the United States. The President participated in swearingin ceremonies for Mrs. Jayne Baker Spain as a vice chairman of the Civil Service Commission. Later in the afternoon the President saw the United States Ambassador to West Germany, Kenneth Rush, and then he met with railroad union leaders. The President also met with his top economic advisers.

title: Jesus People Are Happy With Their Life in Love Inn
description: FREEVILLE, N. Y., June 14 The sign on the big barn right off Highway 13 reads Love Inn, and it's wellknown in the area as a crash pad. The longhaired youths who congregate there are clearly middleclass dropouts.

title: Books of The Times
description: Her feet are frozen; her stomach growls with hunger; her eyes are halfshut after sleepless night of air raids; her gums are bleeding from malnutrition; dysentery churns her bowels. This is how Hildegard Knef (Neff in films) begins her career on the German stage during the Second World War. In this first role, she says only two words, and the sirens usually interrupt the play before she comes on. Her first film for the war effort  is called Journey to Happiness. She is no luckier with her first love. He is a film official, a protg of Goebbels, a Nazi. When the Russians enter Germany, he is sent to the front lines, and because she has nowhere better to go, she disguises herself as a man and accompanies him. By this time, the German Army is so disorganized that no one notices. After doortodoor fighting, they are imprisoned by the Russians, she escapes and never sees him again.

title: Dr. Joseph L. Riesner Dead; Led Dental Health Service
description: Dr. Joseph L. Riesner, a dentist with ofices at 745 Fifth Avenue and former president of the Dental Health Service, died yesterday in White Plains Hospital, after a brief illness. He was 73 years old and lived at 177 East Hartsdale Avenue, Hartsdale, N. Y.

title: JULES ORTEIG DEAD; A WINE IMPORTER, 86
description: Jules Pierre Orteig, who retired as a wine and liqueur importer here 10 years ago, died yesterday, in Boca Raton, Fla., at the age of 86. He also lived at 235 East 73d Street.

title: MARKET TUMBLES IN SLOW TRADING
McCone Memo to Top Officials On Effectiveness of Air War
description: McCone did not inherently disagree with the change in the U.S. groundforce role, but felt that it was inconsistent with the decision to continue the air strike program at the feeble level at which it was then being conducted. McCone developed his argument as follows:

title: UNOFFICIAL HEADQUARTERS: Representative David H. Pryor, Arkansas Democrat, with Patricia Roberts, left, staff director of his Committee on Aging, and Dr. Anna
description: WASHINGTON, June 14Representative David H. Pryor made an end run today around the House leadership which has denied Congressional office space to his unofficial Committee on the Aging.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 Attorney General Mitchell has attempted to describe to the Virginia Bar Association the firm legal basis which he says underlies the doctrine that the Government has the unlimited right to tap the telephone conversations of anyone it considers a threat to the national security. The Supreme Court will be the ultimate judge of his case, but those who have argued that unauthorized national security wiretapping is bad policy and a threat to liberty ought also, in fairness, to deal with Mr. Mitchell's legal basis.

title: ROBERT B. JONES
description: NORWALK, Conn., June 14Robert B. Jones, operations manager for Trans World Airlines, died Saturday night saver suffering a heart attack in his home at 11 Rolling Lane here, His age was 53.

title: Indians Fined $5,000 by Kuhn For Illegal Bonus Agreements
description: Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn fined the Cleveland Indians $5,000 yesterday and invalidated performance bonus understandings between the American League club and four of its players.

title: Harvard Eliminated in Baseball
Letter From Rostow Favoring Commitment of Troops by U.S.
description: Following on our conversation of last night I am concerned that too much thought is being given to the actual damage we do in the North, not enough thought to the signal we wish to send.

title: Frederick Haddad Dead at 41; Aide of Management Consultant
description: Frederick William Charles Haddad, vice president of the United States Research and Development Corporation here, management consultants, died Saturday of a heart attack on a business trip to Battle Creek, Mich. He was 41 years old and lived at 50 Fielding Court, South Orange, N. J.

title: New Jersey G.I. Killed
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP)  The Defense Department announced today that Sgt. 1st CI. Leon J. Jackson of Burlington, N.J., of the Army, had been killed in action in Southeast Asia.

title: Advertising:
description: Young & Rubicam, which already has two American Home Products accounts, Whitehall Laboratories in Canada and American Home Foods, has just been given a couple of assignments from the company's BoyleMidway division. They are for EasyOn Speed Starch and EasyOn Miracle Spray. Together the billing package conies to around $2million.

title: OIL MEETING TOLD OF ATOMIC BEASTS
description: MOSCOW, June 14  Soviet and American specialists told the eighth World Petroleum Congress today that their countries had obtained encouraging results from the use of underground nuclear explosions to stimulate and expand the output of oil and natural gas.

title: New Warnings of Failure
description: Before the opening of the air war in the spring warnings were sounded high in the Administration that it would not succeed. Now there were warnings that a ground war in the South might prove fruitless. The warnings came not only from Under Secretary of State George W. Ball, long known as a dissenter on Vietnam, but also from John A. McCone, Director of Central Intelligence, who felt the actions planned were not strong enough.

title: Britain Bars Aid to Stop Upper Clyde Liquidation
description: LONDON, June 14The Government announced today it would let another major British company go into liquidation rather than bail it out of finnancial difficulties with further public funds.

title: Democratic Coalition Holds Mock Convention
description: In a mock Presidential nominating convention, the New Democratic Coalition yesterday selected George C. Scott, the actor, as its candidate for President.

title: McNamara's Memo on July 20, 1965, On Increasing Allied Ground Force
description: In a memorandum to the President drafted on 1 July and then revised on 20 July, immediately following his return from a weeklong visit to Vietnam, he recommended an immediate decision to increase the U.S.Third Country presence from the current 16 maneuver battalions (15 U.S., one Australian), and a change in the mission of these forces from one of providing support and reinforcement for the ARVN to one which soon became known as search and destroyas McNamara put it, they were by aggressive exploitation of superior military forces... to gain and hold the initiative... pressing the fight against VCDRV main force units in South Vietnam to run them to ground and destroy them.. . .

title: Belkin Upset in Final
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 14 (AP)  Humphrey Hose of Venezuela combined a powerful service with stroke accuracy to upset Mike Belkin of Canada, 75, 60, 76, in the final of the annual BlueGray tennis tournament yesterday.

title: Pressure From Military
description: The strategy of base security having been ended by National Security Action Memorandum 328, a highlevel meeting began in Honolulu on April 20 to sanctify and structure, as the Pentagon analyst puts it, an expanded enclave strategy.

title: Cable to U.S. Envoys in Asia Announcing Sustained Bombing
description: Policy on VietNam adopted today calls for the following:

title: Alitalia $199 Youth Fare To Rome to Defy C.A.B.
description: Alitalia, the Italian airline, introduced a $199 youth fare between New York and Rome last night despite a ruling by the United States Civil Aeronautics Board prohibiting it,

title: Soviet Says U. S. Fleet Harassed Grechko Ship
description: MOSCOW, June 14The Soviet cruiser carrying Defense Minister Andrei A. Grechko on his visit last weekend to the Soviet naval squadron in the Mediterranean Sea was constantly followed and harassed by United States ships and aircraft a Soviet newspaper said today.

title: SOVIET WARNS I.L.O. ON BUDGET DEFICIT
description: GENEVA, June 14The Soviet Union announced today that it would refuse to bear any of the cost to the internaticinal Labor Organization that might result from the failure of the United States to pay its regularly assessed dues.

title: Budget Wrought by Blood and Sweat Brings Tears
description: Over a sandwich luncheon in Mayor Lindsay's City Hall officeham and roast beef, with chocolate chip cookies and iced teaBudget Director Edward K. Hamilton first explained to the Mayor and a fiscal advisory committee of five outside bankers and economists the new city taxes authorized by the State Legislature.

title: The Rape Victim: Is She Also the Unintended Victim of the Law?
description: Rape. To women, it is perhaps the most frightening word in the language. Rape incorporates outrage, violation, shame, sometimes guilt, in the victim. It is a crime that is no respecter of age, social status or locality. Very young children and old women are raped. It happens in the ghettos, in houses on treelined suburban streets and in posh neighborhoods where even uniformed doormen are not positive protection against the vicious intruder.

title: Groppi and 10 Arrested in Yale Protest
description: NEW HAVEN, June 14Father James Groppi and 10 other demonstrators were arrested today as they sought unsuccessfully to disrupt the Yale University commencement exercises. Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany was honored at the commencement.

title: Navy to Scuttle That Old Sailor Suit
description: WASHINGTON, June 14Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr., the Chief of Naval Operations who brought beer and beards to the mod Navy announced today that bell bottoms and sailors round hats were being abolished in the most sweeping uniform change in United States naval history.

title: The First Environmentalists
description: URBANA, Ill.When a giant coal corporation recently approached the Navajos and Hopis for strip mining rights to Black Mesa on their Arizona reservation, the Indians first concern was not the money they would receive, but the damage that might be done to their land. No people in the United States need money more than these Indians, whose family incomes average less than $3,000 a year, yet they refused to sign until they secured a binding agreement that Black Mesa would be returned to them in as good condition as received, the terrain replaced, and native vegetation replanted.

title: Dodgers Beat Mets, 32, OnThree Hits Off Seaver
Brandt to Talk With Nixon
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (Reuters)West German Chancellor Brandt arrived here tonight for talks tomorrow and Wednesday with President Nixon, Secretary of State William P. Rogers and other members of the Administration.

title: The Ocean Dump
description: Alarmed by the destruction of valuable fisheries and the pollution of priceless beaches, Governor Cahill of New Jersey has signed a toughbut probably futilenew law requiring that most of New Jersey's sewage sludge and industrial wastes be dumped 100 miles out into the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Lightning Halts Apollo Test
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., June 14 (AP)Lightning struck power equipment near the Apollo 15 launching pad tonight, delaying an important test for the July moonlanding mission.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: In his May 24 letter Algernon D. Black asserts that the question of public funds for nonpublic schools raises issues beyond the principle of separation of church and state and concludes with the statement that diversion of even one dollar from public schools for nonpublic schools would be unwise and dangerous.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Rise at Weekly Sale
Cleveland to Lay Off 352
description: CLEVELAND, June 13 (AP)Officials of financially troubled Cleveland announced today that 352 city workers, including 193 policemen, would be laid off the first week in July in austerity cutbacks. The city also announced that 171 employes aged 70 or older would face mandatory retirement as of June 30.

title: Four Basic Categories For Atantic Flights
Study Is Demanded on Force Police Used in 3 Arrests in Queens on Sunday
description: A group of black homeowners in Queens vowed yesterday to demand a full and complete investigation of the arrests of a Springfield Gardens couple and their neighbor, a Port Authority patrolman, in incidents after Sunday's rainstorm.

title: PROLIFERATION,$9, TIES TRACK MARK AT BELMONT PARK
description: Proliferation of the Cragwood Stable contributed the finest effort of the season for the mile and an eighth distance at Belmont Park in the feature event on yesterday's card. Opposing eight rivals in the test for older horses. Proliferation came through with a decisive triumph, negotiating the sloppy track in 1:46 45 to equal the track record.

title: Emergency Plans Made for State Employes Strike
description: State agencies made emergency preparations yesterday to deal with a strike threatened for midnight tomorrow by the Civil Service Employes Association.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Even though your June 2 editorial The Wrong Lesson is right in objecting to the exploitation of schoolchildren who are whipped into a command performance of rote letter writing in behalf of teacher interests, it is wrong in assuming that all educators employed this crass approach in the recent letterwriting campaign on the budget cuts.

title: Rostow Memorandum on Victory And Defeat in Guerrilla Wars
description: In the press, at least, there is a certain fuzziness about the possibility of clearcut victory in South Vietnam; and the President's statement that a military victory is impossible is open to misinterpretation.

title: Withdrawal When?
description: The brusque rejection by the White House of former Defense Secretary Clark M. Clifford's proposal to set a fixed date for withdrawal of all American forces from Indochina in return for the release of American prisoners reinforces doubts about the Administration's policies in respect both to negotiation and Vietnamization.

title: Charges for International Mail Revised
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI)The United States Postal Service announced international rate changes today that will increase revenues by $20.6million a year but permit some reductions in airmail postage.

title: Tricia's Gown Is Going Public
description: Brides to be who liked Tricia Nixon Cox's wedding gown will he able to buy copies of it sometime next week.

title: PASARELL, RICHEY SCORE IN TENNIS
description: LONDON, June 14  With Wimbledon a week away and the players short of match play on grass, pelting rain forced the abandonment of the World Championship Tennis tournament at the semifinal stage in Bristol, postponed the South of England event at Eastbourne and dripped dismally) through the glass roof on the courts as the London grass championships moved indoors today at the Queen's Club.

title: Rev. Paul Dano Dead at 47; Pastor of St. Mary's Church
description: The Very Rev. Paul Dano, pastor of St. Mary's Byzantine Catholic Church since 1956 and builder Of its new glasswalled church on Second Avenue at 15th Street, died Sunday in St. Joseph's Hospital, Stamford, Conn., after suffering an attack while at church picnic. He was 47 years old and lived at 219 East 12th Street.

title: 20 Held in Albuquerque As Guard Curbs Rioters
description: ALBUQUERQUE N. M., June 14National Guard units patrolled the streets of this city tonight to curb marauding bands of hippies Negroes and MexicanAmericans who had created serious disorders through the day.

title: EUROPE'S BANKERS REJECT U.S. STAND
description: BASEL, Switzerland, June 14The transAtlantic debate over the dollar sharpened today as a strong body of European monetary opinion apparently rejected Washington's assertions that it was up to the other industrialized countries to help the United States economically.

title: Theater: The Tempest in Connecticut
Supreme Court, by 8 to 1, Rules Against Thrift Units on Taxes
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI) The Supreme Court ruled to 1 today that some 4,500 statechartered savings and loan associations are not entitled to claim tax deductions on millions of dollars in premiums they were assessed by the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation.

description: On Thursday, April 1, The President made the following decisions with respect to Vietnam:

title: Hines Gets Jazz Award
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., June 14Earl Hines yesterday received the third annual James P. Johnson Award from the Rutgers Institute of Jazz Studies. The award, presented in recognition of his contributions to American music, was made during the fourth annual conference on discographical research, held at Hickman Hall on the campus of Douglass College.

title: Pacific Search Plane Spots Debris
description: HONOLULU, June 14 (UPI) Debris was sighted today in the South Pacific, where an Air Force C135 transport vanished with 24 persons aboard, apparently while monitoring French nuclear tests.

title: INTERNES, RESIDENTS WIN PAY RAISE HERE

General Wheeler suggested that he would have you head up the group and that the group would be fairly small. Secretary McNamara indicated that he wanted your group to work with me and that I should send down a memorandum suggesting some of the questions that occurred to us. Here are our suggestions:

description: KANSAS CITY Mo., June 14 (AP)Joseph A. Beirne president of the Communications Workers of America announced today that union members had voted 205,431 to 82,009 in favor of a strike against the Bell Telephone System.

description: SAIGON, South Vietnam Tuesday, June 15 (AP)North Vietnamese forces ambushed an American unit 42 miles northeast of Saigon killing four Americans and wounding eight the United States command said today.

The embassy in Saigon, while recognizing the seriousness of the situation in South Vietnam, was less then sanguine about the prospects for success if large numbers of foreign troops were brought in.

description: Six young American Indians were arrested here yesterday and accused of defacing the state's memorial to President Theodore Roosevelt with several buckets of red paint.

description: The refusal of two unions representing the bulk of the city's whitecollar employes to go along with Mayor Lindsay's request that their members voluntarily renounce their customary summer siesta time is characteristic of the union response to every aspect of the city's budget crisis.

title: WHEAT AND CORN SHOW DECLINES
description: Scattered rain over sections of the growing areas in the central portion of the United States tended to influence selling of wheat and corn futures on the Chicago Board of Trade. A report that corn blight had been found in Iowa failed to shake the early bearish sentiment on these two commodities.

description: The question of final Presidential approval of the 17battalion recommendations now became academic as the enemy started attacks that provided the Pentagon and General Westmoreland with a battlefield rationale for their campaign to have American troops take over the major share of the ground war.

description: Thirtytwo actors, including such luminaries of stage and screen as George C. Scott, Dustin Hoffman, Maureen Stapleton and Rod Steiger, have agreed to participate in a new theater organization, Solar Theater, Inc.

description: WASHINGTON, June 14The Supreme Court declined today, 8 to 0, to upset the Federal Communications Commission's decision to strip The Boston HeraldTraveler of WHDHTV, a Columbia Broadcasting System affiliate that the newspaper corporation has been operating since 1957.

title: HORN &
description: Horn & Hardart, one of the city's largest restaurant chains, paid $7,500 in fines four months ago in Criminal Court after admitting to numerous violations of the city Health Code in its West 50th Street central bakery.

title: A Catholic Bishop Leaves the Ministry
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., June 14The Most Rev. Bernard M. Kelly, Auxiliary Bishop of Providence for seven years, resigned today from active ministry as a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Zoo Cat's Death Starts LeadPoison Study
description: Lead from paint and possibly from the atmosphereapparently has caused serious illness in two leopards at the Staten Island Zoo, and animals in captivity elsewhere could be similarly affected, a team of veterinarians and physicians said yesterday.

title: Joseph A. Lussier, 79, Went Over Niagara Falls in Ball
description: NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., Jute 14 (AP)Joseph A. Lussier, who once went over the Horseshoe Falls inside a rubber ball, died today in Memorial Medical Center. He was 79 years old.

title: Retirement at 72 Sought
description: WASHINGTON, June 14 (UPI) Senator Jack Miller, Republican of Iowa, proposed today constitutional amendment to set mandatory retirement for all Congressmen and Federal judges at 72.

title: Screen: Fellini's Affectionate Memoir Unfolds:'The Clowns' Recollects Circus Experiences Director and Entourage Seek Out Performers
description: At its best moments, which constitute approximately one-third of its running time, Federico Fellini's "The Clowns" is a lovely footnotealmost a coda, reallyto a career that, like some of the circus extravaganzas his movies often resemble, has evolved inside three distinct rings. His first films have their roots in post-war Italian neo-realism. Then, in the mid-fifties, came the unique poetic neo-realism of "La Strada" and "Nights of Cabiria," a style that gradually gave waythrough films like "La Dolce Vita" and "8"to the triumphantly neo-surreal "Satyricon" last year."The Clowns," which Fellini made for Italian television, is an affectionate memoir, a lyrical documentary in which Fellini himself, often on-screen as movie ringmaster eulogizes his lost fantasy world. He evokes the circuses he saw as a boy, especially the clowns who terrified him, spends some time in Paris interviewing surviving clowns, and finally stages an elaborate, mock, clown funeral that ends, as all Fellini films end, in a kind of reconciliation with fate.If I admired Fellini less, I might have admired "The Clowns" more. As it is, I didn't dislike itit would be impossible to dislike a film so full of good spirits, so full of love, a show that on occasion virtually erupts with brilliance. I'm not talking about brilliance of dcor, because, indeed, it's this kind of brilliance that makes me uneasy."The Clowns" is the movie that seems to give cause to those critics who have described Felliniincorrectlyas a master of spectacular, superficial effect and sentimentality. This, they are likely to say, is his greatest film, simply because this is all there is. I disagree.The first section of "The Clowns" is pure enchantment as Fellini recalls his earliest memories of circuses, of people being buried alive for days, of very masculine female wrestlers with names like Miss Tarzan and Miss Matilde, of clowns whose existences were an unending series of physical assaultsmashed fingers, gouged eyes, split skulls, and the like.For the child Fellini, as well as for the adult movie director, the clowns weren't really funny. They reminded him of the village idiot who made obscene propositions to the farm women, of the crazy midget nun who spent her time doing missions that the saints would entrust to no one else, of the pompous stationmaster whom schoolboys could effectively torment with insults no more mortal than Bronx cheers.In the film's second section, which might have been subtitled Pretended Pirandellian Reality Recalled, Fellini goes to Paris attended by his staff, including such real-life clowns as a beautiful dumb-blonde secretary named Maya, who can't withdraw a piece of paper from the typewriter without tearing it, and his wardrobe mistress, a woman with the face of a rumpled Modigliani, who exists only to look scenically comic in a mink coat somewhat too large.In simulated cinema vrit style, Fellini, his secretary, wardrobe mistress, cameraman and soundman pretend to interview survivors of the Age of The Circus, "discovering" them at their homes, or eavesdropping on their arguments about who was the greatest White Clown. We sometimes see the camera that is recording it all, and there is a good deal of talk about whether or not the circus deserved to die, but the film is clearly vamping until time for its finale.At this point, "The Clowns" almost recoups with its riotous funeral for Auguste, the legendary low clown of clown ritual, the butt of the elegant White Clown's jokes, the clown whom Fellini describes as a "sub-proletarian image," a clown "capable of revolt but not of revolution."As Fellini sits on the sidelines watching the funeral go to pieces in strictly clown terms, a journalist asks him what he means to say in this new film. Fellini starts to answer and a bucket falls over his head rather abruptly. The movie director, obviously, is not only ringmaster and White Clown, but also the ridiculous Auguste.The funeral carries on in little explosions of mounting chaos, confusion and confetti, reaching, at last (and I do mean at last, since the show carries on somewhat longer than can be supported by the quality of the spectacle), those moments of the end of "Cabiria" and "8."There are fire engines, cannons, procession of clowns, clowns dancing with each other, even the front halves of clown-horses dancing with their rear-ends. The marvelous Nino Rota music ( a lot of it from "Juliet of the Spirits") wells up and, although there shouldn't have been, there were at least two dry eyes yesterday at the Lincoln Art Theater, where "The Clowns" opened.It's not that "The Clowns" is not a good deal of fun, or that it is boring; it's just thatto me, anywaythis sort of coda doesn't do justice to the entire career. It acknowledges Fellini's debt to theater, to masquerade and masks, to the magic of fantasy (which is only harnessed madness), but this is only a small aspect of his discipline, which can be both more interesting and more adventurous.

title: Lehigh Paper Wins Contest
description: HAZLETON, Pa., June 14 (AP)  Lehigh University's student newspaper, The Brown and White, won first place yesterday in the 1971 Middle Atlantic Council collegiate journalism contest of the American Newspaper Guild.

title: Texas Banker Put on ProbationIn Case That Shook Politicians
description: HOUSTON, June 14 (AP)Frank Sharp, whose bank loan and stock deals shook the highest echelons of Texas government earlier this year, walked free from a Federal courtroom today on his promise to belave for three years.

title: Coast Governor and Chief Hit Legal Marijuana Plea
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 14Gov. Tom McCall of Oregon and Police Chief Al Nelder of San Francisco today opposed legalization of marijuana while Dr. Michael Aldrich appealed for free legal backyard marijuana.

title: Raina Kabaivanska Sings
description: Raina Kabaivanska, who made her Metropolian Opera debut in 1962, has gathered to her a vociferous troop of fans since then. Many of them turned up to cheer at Sunday evening's Alice Tully Hall Sampler, An Evening of Russian Music featuring the handsome Bulgarian soprano. Miss Kabaivanska chose five songs by Tchaikovsky and five of Rachmaninoff, and kept in the Slavic vein with a Bulgarian group.
