description: LUXEMBOURG, June 15Against mounting pressure to return the mark to a fixed parity, West Germany today refused to name a date for ending the temporary float and reactivated its proposal for a general float of Common Market currencies.

title: Advisory Team Cutback
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 15 (AP)  The United States command announced today a cutback in the system of American advisory teams for South Vietnamese army units.

title: 4 Police Officials Ousted in Warsaw In Apparent Purge
description: WARSAW, June 15  Four officials of Poland's Interior Ministry were reported today to have been dismissed and arrested recently, apparently on criminal charges.

title: NIXON TO ASK AID FOR G.I. ADDICTS
description: WASHINGTON, June 15President Nixon's new antinarcotics program, scheduled to be unveiled at the White House Thursday, will include proposal that servicemen who have become addicted to drugs in Vietnam be requested to undergo three weeks of mandatory treatment at West Coast rehabilitation centers, informed Government sources disclosed today.

title: Freud's Office Now Vienna Museum
description: VIENNA, June 15Sigmund Freud's office and study, where psychoanalysis was born; were formally opened today as museum.

title: ACTORS AND LEAGUE SPUR ETHNIC CASTING
description: During current negotiations on new Broadway contract, Actors Equity Association and the League of New York Theaters have agreed on a plan designed to increase the employment of ethnic miniorities in the theater.

title: PRIESTS IN CHICAGO CENSURE A CARDINAL
description: CHICAGO, June 15 (AP) The Association of Chicago Priests voted 144 to 126 tonight to censure John Cardinal Cody, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Chicago, for allegedly failing to speak out on behalf of the needs of priests.

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Scholars. President Nixon announced the selection of 10 outstanding high school seniors as President's Australian Science Scholars for 1971. The scholars will be honored at special ceremonies in Washington in midAugust. They will then join similar student groups from Britain and Japan and will travel to Sydney, Australia, to attend an international science school from Aug. 23 through Sept. 3.

title: PATERSON RULES OUT A SURROGATE RACE
description: Former State Senator Basil A. Paterson, who has been ?? by many of his political associates to seek the Democratic nomination for Manhattan, Surrogate, announced yesterday that he would not enter ?? race.

title: Harlem Better Business Office Is Center of Dispute
description: The Harlem office of the Better Business Bureau of Metropolitan New York, established five years ago to expose fraud and to educate consumers, is becoming the subject of a simmering controversy.

title: BLACKS UPSTATE VOICE PESSIMISM
description: NEWBURGH, N. Y., June 15 William Lockwood, the director of the 400member Newburgh Chamber of Commerce, said this afternoon that the economic future of this river port city of 27,000 was amazingly rosy.

title: Federal Judge Retires
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP)The retirement of Herbert S. Boreman, 73 years old, of Parkersburg, W. Va., as a United States Appeals Court judge for the Fourth Circuit was announced today by President Nixon.

title: PLAN BOARD BACKS NEW HIGH SCHOOL
description: The City Planning Commission approved yesterday a zoning change that would permit construction of a commercial high school and a 720foot tower for the New York Telephone Company on a Lower East Side site.

title: Carbide Sets Price Rise
description: The Union Carbide Corporalion announced yesterday that it would raise prices on two propylene oxide based glycol ethers by 0.5 cent a pound, effective July 1.

title: Texts of Government Papers in Complaint Against The Times arid judge's Order
description: Complaint

title: Shnayerson, Time Editor, to Get Top Job at Harper's
description: Robert Shnayerson, a senior editor of Time magazine, has been selected as the new editor in chief of Harper's magazine, succeeding Willie Morris, who resigned last March in a dispute with the magazine's management.

title: Nuclear Power Plans Set
description: The Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation announced yesterday preliminary plans for a second nuclear generating unit at its Nine Mile Point site six miles east of Oswego on Lake Ontario. Bids are being sought for a plant of 900,000 kilowatt capacity and an alternate 1.1million kilowatts based on existing designs in the industry. The Stone and Webster Engineering Corporation is architectengineer for the project.

title: Nationalization Asked
description: LONDON, June 15 (AP)Angry Scottish labor leaders demanded today that the Government nationalize the Upper Clyde Shipbuilders. And the stateowned British Steel Corporation stopped deliveries of steel to the shipyards going into liquidation.

title: East German Chief Hints at Softer Stand
description: BERLIN, June 15Erich Honecker opened the Eighth Congress of his ruling Communist party today with a lowkeyed speech containing several indications that East Germany would stop obstructing EastWest efforts to ease tensions in Central Europe.

title: An End of Most Controls On Nickel and Scrap Due
description: W. Robert McLellan, an Assistant Secretary of Commerce, told a news conference here yesterday that the Government would end most controls on the export of nickel and nickelbearing scrap within a week or 19 days.

title: SENATE STUDY SET
description: WASHINGTON, June 15Amid continuing Administration criticism of the publication by The New York Times of data from a secret Pentagon study on Vietnam, Senator Mike Mansfield said a Senate committee would hold public hearings on how the United States had become involved in the war.

title: S.E.C. AIDE URGES UPPER PENALTY
description: WASHINGTON, June 15A Securities and Exchange Commission hearing examiner recommended today that Arthur Lipper 3d and the brokerage firm that bears his name both be suspended from the securities business for a year.

title: Music
description: Some musicians, and good ones, seem to struggle to make music, to wrestle it out of themselves; others play as smoothly and effortlessly as politicians lie, and as effectively. The trio that appeared at Carnegie Recital Hall on Monday gave the latter impression, and it made for a wholly enjoyable program.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Scott Paper Conway announced yesterday in Philadelphia the appointment of Charles D. Dickey Jr. as chief executive officer of the company in addition to his post as president. He succeeds Harrison F. Dunning, chairman, in the chief executive post. It is Mr. Dunning's plan to retire as chairman in September, 1971. Mr. Dickey was elected president and chief operating officer of Scott in 1968. Prior to that and from 1967. he had been executive vice president with management responsibilities for the company's consumer and industrial packaged products business. Mr. Dunning was named chairman in 19,68 and, has served 36 years with the company. He was elected a director in 1955 and in 1962 was elected president.

title: PHILIP CORTNEY, EXHEAD OF COTY
description: GENEVA, June 15Philip Cortney former president of Coty, Inc died here Friday at the age of 76.

title: Government Carries Commons
description: LONDON, June 15 (Reuters) The British Government tonight survived a fierce opposition attack in the House of Commons over its refusal to stave off the financial collapse of the partially stateowned Upper Clyde Shipbuilding consortium.

title: Rejection of Waterfront Budget Urged
description: The New York Shipping Association urged Governor Rockefeller and Gov. William T. Cahill of New Jersey yesterday to reject the Waterfront. Commission's budget request for $4,157,000 for the fiscal year beginning July 1.

title: State Aides Scored in Albuquerque Riots
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., June 15The city's top elected official today accused the Lieutenant Governor of New Mexico and the State Attorney General of inciting yesterday's fourhourlong riot by making speeches in which they agreed that the Albuquerque police had been brutal to hippies, MexicanAmericans and Negroes.

title: New Herman Band Breezes Into Town On Wings of Solos
description: Everyone, including WoodyHerman, long ago gave up trying to keep track of the various Herman Herds that the bandleader has headed during the last 25 years. After the First Herd, the Second Herd and the Third Herd, the identities became so scrambled that numbers were abandoned.

title: BRANDT AND NIXON CONFER ON BERLIN
description: WASHINGTON, June 15President Nixon and Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany agreed today that continued progress in negotiations on the status of West Berlin might soon open the way for talks between the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the Warsaw Pact on reducing military forces in Europe.

title: House Is Given Chance to Vote
description: WASHINGTON, June 15Opponents of an extensive welfare reform nrogram won significant victory today when the House Rules Committee decided to permit a separate vote on the heart of the welfare plan when the 600page bill incorporating it reaches the floor.

title: An Ear to Civilizations in Space Sought
description: Space scientists are exploring the possibility of building a vast, antenna system sensitive enough to eavesdrop on distant civilizations  if any exists within 100 light years of the earth.

title: Tariff Body Finds Dumping Of Pig Iron by 3 Nations
description: WASHINGTON, June 15The Tariff Commission ruled today that imports of pig iron at dumping prices from Canada, West Germany and Finland have injured the domestic Industry.

title: Telescopes, Camera, Code and Patience Helped Police Smash Alleged CarTheft Ring
description: Patient policemen based behind the redshaded window of a cubicle atop a Bronx school and nearly undone by a curious and talkative cleaning man gathered the evidence that led to yesterdays indictment of 17 alleged participants in a major auto theft ring.

title: MRS. ROOSEVELT, 73, DIES IN CAR CRASH
description: COLD SPRING HARBOR, L. I., June 15  WS. Grace Roosevelt, the wife of Archibald Roosevelt, the only surviving son of President Theodore Roosevelt, was fatally injured in an automobile accident here today. Her age was 73.

title: U. S. Plans Ways to Bolster Saigon for 72 Enemy Push
description: WASHINGTON, June 15The Nixon Administration is engaged in a broad policy review aimed at determining courses of action that might improve South Vietnam's ability to withstand military assaults next year, after most American forces have been withdrawn.

title: Advertising:
description: Horst G. Denk, the innovative president of Sunshine Biscuits, is no longer president of Sunshine but is still innovative.

title: Bulls Get Rights to Porter In Agreement With Condors
description: CHICAGO, June 15 (AP) The Chicago Bulls of the National Basketball Association today completed a deal for the rights to Howard Porter of Viljanova.

title: YAHYA SAID TO DELAY PLAN FOR CIVIL RULE
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, June 15 (Reuters)President Agha Mohammad Yahya Khan has postponed the announcement of his plan for the transfer of power to a civilian government, Zulfikar All Bhutto, chairman of the Pakistan People's party, said today. The President, who rules by martial authority, said May 24 that he would announce the plan in two to three weeks Lime.

title: PACIFIC OIL &
description: The Pacific Oil and Gas Development Corporation announced yesterday that it had signed an agreement for the acquisition of various oil and gas properties for a maximum of 5,068,861 shares of its common stock valued at about $25million at present market prices. The properties, including both producing and nonproducing tracts in the United States and overseas, are operated by the Fundamental Oil Corporation on behalf of several investor concerns and limited partnerships. The transaction is subject to the approval of shareholders of the various concerns.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: Your June 4 editorial Taxing Public Patience is well taken.

title: La Mancha to Close At 2,328 Performances
description: Man of la Mancha, the longrunning musical, will close on June 26 after 2,328 performances and a profit of $5million on its original investment of $200,000.

title: U.S. Open Rivals Show Respect For Course
description: ARDMORE, Pa., June 15Ninetyseven per cent of the field is not equipped to play Mellon, said George Archer, a former Masters champion, today as he reviewed prospects for the United States Open golf championship that begins here Thursday. They just don't have the shots.

title: Tanker Nears Elath
description: TEL AVIV, Israel, June 15 The tanker attacked Friday neared her destination at Elath tonight with metal workers and painters aboard apparently repairing damage from the attack.

title: Veteran Boxers Clubhouse Almost Ready for Bell
description: Slightly more than a year after the start of its fundraising campaign, the Veteran Boxers Association, Ring 8, displayed yesterday its nearly complete clubhouse at 167 West 29th Street.

title: Major Banks Hold to 5;
description: The nation's major banks sat tight with their 5 per cent prime lending rate yesterday, despite strong upward cost pressures that most bankers believe will lead shortly to a rise in this minimum charge on business loans.

title: LEONARD BEATON, 41, BRITISH RESEARCHER
description: LONDON, June 15 Leonard Beaton, a former director of studies at the Institute of Strategic Studies here, died last Wednesday in Venice, Italy, at the age of 41.

title: U. S. Judge Limits F.B.I.'s Distribution Of Arrest Records
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 (AP), A Federal judge ordered the F.B.I. today to quit distributing arrest records from its files to employers, banks and others outside of law enforcement agencies.

title: Unmarried Teacher Gains Right to Adopt a Child, 8
description: BUFFALO, June 15 (AP)Erie County Family Court has approved the adoption of an eightyearold girl by an unmarried school teacher.

title: A. &P. SAYS PROFIT FELL IN QUARTER
Olin to Close Permanently Virginia Soda Ash Plant
description: The Olin Corporation said yesterday that its soda ash operation at Saltville, Va., will be permanently closed on July because unsold production was overflowing its storage capacity and because the operating rate could not be reduced further.

title: Rogers Bars the Abandonment Of U.S. Goals to Free Captives
description: WASHINGTON, June 15Secretary of State William P. Rogers said today that the United States could not abandon its national objectives in Vietnam to meet the ransom being demanded by North Vietnam for the release of American prisoners of war.

title: Salinger Expresses Suspicion
description: PARIS, June 15Pierre Salinger, the former press secretary. to President Kennedy, expressed his suspicion tonight that the Nixon Administration was responsible for the leak of a secret study on the Vietnam war to The New York Times.

title: ARGUMENT FRIDAY
description: United States District Judge Murray I. Gurfein yesterday ordered The New York Times to halt publication of material from a secret Pentagon study of the Vietnam war for four days. Argument on publication thereafter will be heard Friday.

title: Caveat Auditor
description: When it comes to putting a fair market price on speech, particularly a political one, truthinpackaging and even unitpricing rules offer little by way of guidelines. Yet, even in the absence of more accurate yardsticks, California's Gov. Ronald Reagan may have carried free enterprise to new frontiers by setting the fees for his Republican fundraising speeches at $25,000 20 per cent of the gross, whichever is smaller. Mr. Reagan could find himself in trouble if the high cost of listening were to lead to an audience revolution of rising expectations.

title: PRICES ADVANCE IN BOND MARKET
IMPERIAL PAPER FINDS PURCHASER
description: The Collins & Alkman Corporation, diversified manufacturer of specialty textile products, , announced yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire the Imperial Paper Company, a Clevelandbased producer of wall coverings.

title: OBSERVER
description: How to get to work: I. On waking, turn on the radio to the roundtheclock badnews station to get the latest unemployment figures. These strengthen the resolve to get to work among persons lucky enough to have work to get to. Strengthened resolve is very important. Persons who do not have strengthened resolve often go back to sleep, mumbling that getting to work is not worth the struggle.

title: Brandeis Merger Is Set For Riverside Museum
description: The Riverside Museum, small pioneering institution that came on the scene nearly half a century ago, is leaving the city in defeat at the end of the month to merge into Brandeis University at Waltham, Mass.

title: Paul Scofield Stars With Joan Plowright In Pirandello Drama
description: LONDON, June 16After purloining a Hedda Gabler from Ingmar Bergman's theater and a Coriolanus from the Berliner Ensemble, the National Theater (opening a summer overflow season at the New Theater) now takes its cue from a recent Italian production of Pirandello's The Rules of the Game.

title: U.S Conned Australia On Troops, Laborite Says
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Thursday, June 17Publication by The New York Times of secret papers on the Vietnam war has caused a controversy here on the Australian involvement in the conflict.

title: Fiery Faust Sweeps Prospect Park Into Summer
description: Faust in Brooklyn. That might sound like the title of an avantgarde drama, but it merely documents the fact that the Metropolitan Opera's fifth consecutive summer of free performances in the parks got under way last night with Gounod's classic. The openair season began belatedly owing to the cancellation of the scheduled opening at Central Park on Tuesday. (That program, which includes CavaIleria Rusticana, is rescheduled for tonight in the Sheep Meadow, weather permitting.)

title: A Bag Man Testifies He Feared Kenny
description: NEWARK, June 16  A vice president of a contracting company doing business with Hudson County and Jersey City told a Federal Court jury today that fear of the wrath and power of John V. Kenny had kept him from complaining about participation in kickback rackets.

title: Man, 27, Indicted In Bank Robbery Called Brains in 5
description: A man described as the brains behind five Long Island bank robberies was held in $75,000 bail in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday on an indictment involving one of the robberies.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: It would be the height of folly and the path of dishonor for the United States to withdraw completely from Vietnam by Dec. 31 of this year. The inescapable reality in the formulation of American policy is that the American nation has made a solemn commitment, consecrated by the lives of nearly 50,000 of our dead, to the right of the South Vietnamese people freely to determine their own future.

title: 3 JUSTICES ASSAIL HOGAN'S BEHAVIOR
description: Three justices of the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court have criticized District Attorney Frank S. Hogan of Manhattan in court for, publicly denouncing a judge who handed down a decision favoring a defendant.

title: Astronaut's Wife Injured
description: COLUMBUS, Miss, June 16 (AP)Joan Roosa, wife of Stuart Roosa, the astronaut, was slightly injured yesterday in an accident on U.S. 82 near here. Highway patrolmen said that a tank truck ruptured and spewed 2,500 gallons of jet fuel along the highway. At least four cars that hit the slick fuel left the highway.

title: Edward G. Baird, Educator And a Probate Court Judge
description: BELFAST, Me., June 16Edward G. Baird, a former educator and a Probate Court Judge in Waldo County for 22 years, died in the Waldo County General Hospital here yesterday after a brief illness. He was 71 years old.

title: Fritz the Cat to Get New Life in Feature
description: A fulllength animated feature, Fritz the Cat, based on Robert Crumb's lascivious feline character in the underground Head Comics magazine, is being produced by Steve Krantz and Ralph Bakshi.

title: GUARDSMEN ORDERED TO PATROL SANTA FE
description: SANTE FE, N. M., June 16 (Reuters)  Gov. Bruce King ordered 100 National Guardsmen into the state capital today as a precautionary measure after the firebombing of a Federal office building.

title: PHONE BUILDING PLAN IS UNDER FIRE AGAIN
description: Strong dissents have been filed by two members of the City Planning Commission to its decision to authorize a 720foothigh, almostwindowless industrial building on a Manhattan site just north of the Brooklyn Bridge.

title: AtLarge Legislative Elections Ordered in Mississippi County
description: JACKSON, Miss., June 16 (AP)The Federal District Court here ordered today that legislative representatives from Hinds County be elected at large.

title: Soyuz in Orbit 11th Day
description: MOSCOW, June 16 (UPI)Three Soviet astronauts in the Salyut station began their 11th day in orbit today, and observers said they might attempt to break the 18day space endurance record set by the Soviet Union a year ago.

title: White House Gets Plan to Redeploy Nuclear Weapons Stored on Okinawa
description: WASHINGTON, June 16The Defense and State departments have proposed to the White House that hundreds of tactical nuclear weapons stored on Okinawa be moved to storage sites on Guam and In South Korea, Taiwan the Philippines and the United States.

title: Senate RollCall Vote On Vietnam Deadline
Another Meeting in Seoul
description: SEOUL, June 16 (UPI)United States and South Korean officials met today for the second time in as many days an an effort to come to an agreement on restrictions of Korean textile shipments to the United States.

title: Attack in Dacca on Aid Officials Reported
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, June 16Knowledgeable sources reported today that officials of an international aid consortium headed by the World Bank narrowly escaped death in East Pakistan last Thursday from bombs presumed to have been thrown by Bengali separatist extremists.

title: Boyer Signs Contract To Play With Hawaii
description: HONOLULU, June 16 (AP) Clete Boyer, the third baseman released by the Atlanta Braves after a dispute with club vice president Paul Richards, signed today to play with the Hawaii Islanders of the Pacific Coast League.

title: Senate, 55 to 42, Defeats McGovernHatfield Plan
description: WASHINGTON, June 16The Senate, in a victory for the Nixon Administration's Vietnam policies, refused twice today to set a deadline for the withdrawal of American forces, from Indochina.

title: Fortune and Men's Eyes' Bows
description: A compassionate viewer troubled by man's inhumanity to man, is, nevertheless, left with the disturbing impression of having been shortchanged by "Fortune and Men's Eyes," which opened yesterday at the Trans-Lux East and Trans-Lux West Theaters. John Herbert's adaptation of his play (staged here in 1967 and 1969) about the corrosive, sometimes destructive results of imprisonment, vacillates between an explicit, largely homosexually slanted dramatization and an implied, surface indictment of callous penal practices that does little justice to either approach.Simply stated, Mr. Herbert, who once was jailed in Canada and obviously is deeply concerned, is saying that men do turn to each other for sexual satisfaction in an all-male prison society. More importantly, he is stressing that some inmates often have no choice and are forced into this life through rape or seduction with disastrous effects.Filmed in color at Canada's Quebec Priosn under the uninspired direction of Harvey Hart (he replaced Jules Schwerin who had clashed with the producers), the bleakness of incarceration is projected with depressing authenticity. However, the shameful fact that prisons breed criminals, including deviates, is hardly new to films or strikingly presented here in interlocking stories involving the naive newcomer who is thrust into the embraces of a tough cellmate in order to avoid gang rape; the equally tough but comic "queen" who is at home in the system, and the forlorn, delicate, oppressed type, among others.The sincerity of the principals' performances cannot be questioned. But it is difficult to believe Wendell Burton's quick switch from a confused, terrified, pink-cheecked youngster to the rock-hard guy who beats up Zooey Hall, his rough oppressor, and is about to become a bad case himself. Mr. Hall is properly glum, ominous and moody but he doesn't appear to be the type who would succumb that easily.Danny Freedman is limp and passive as the delicate victim of a series of attacks, who recites the Shakespeare sonnet from which the title is derived. But the acting honors go to Michael Greer as the uninhibited homosexual (he appeared in the 1969 stage version) who is often fascinatingly funny and campy in a larger-than-life role.Nothing is resolved, of of course. But the film's major accent is on the discreetly staged rape scenes (there is a brief flash of frontal nudity in a striptease by Mr. Greer), the shocks of several fights, a brutal beating, a riot, a bloody suicide and a plethora of four-letter words. Unfortunately, not too much sympathy is generated for the men, who in the Bard's words, are "in disgrace with fortune and men's eyes" when all the bitchiness, brutality and sexuality has passed in review.

title: Promoter of Powder Ridge Fete Indicted on 6 Counts of Perjury
description: The Chief promoter of the Powder Ridge rock festivalwhich sold $20 tickets to more than 20,000 youths last summer but allegedly failed to refund their money when the festival, did not take place was indicted yesterday by a Manhattan grand jury on six counts of perjury.

title: A 35Year Wait
description: MADRID, June 16 (AP)The elderly Spanish widow who is once again the painting's apparent owner said tonight that she did not want to discuss the recovery of the modello because she was going out to dinner.

title: Mets Down Dodgers, 72;
Nixon to Address A.M.A.
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) President Nixon will fly to Atlantic City next Tuesday to address the House of Delegates of the American Medical Association, it was announced today. Ronald L. Ziegler, the White House press secretary, said Mr. Nixon would arrive there in late morning and would return immediately to Washington after his address.

title: Nebraska Town, Slowly Drowning Near Federal Dam, May Move to Higher Ground
description: NIOBRARA, Neb. June 16 When the Santee Sioux named their river Niobrara, or Running Water, a few centuries ago, they probably never dreamed of the cellars that would flood or the Army Corps of Engineers that would clog up their river with silt. Now this tired

title: Prizes for Design Go to 2 Universities For Buildings Here
description: Two university building projects were singled out yesterday for the 1971 Bard Awards for excellence in architecture and urban design.

title: Two Nominations Approved
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) The Senate Labor Committee approved today the nominations of Merlin K. DaVal Jr. of Tucson, Ariz., to be. Assistant Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, and Wythe D. Quarles Jr., a native of Richmond, as a member of the Railroad Retirement Board.

title: Mexicans Begin a SecretArmy Inquiry
description: MEXICO CITY, June 18 (Reuters)  Special investigators today began to sift through documents in the city hall here in search of evidence to support charges that city officials had maintained a secret army of rightist youths.

title: Man Jailed in Nixon Threat
description: ROME, N. Y., June 16 (AP)An unemployed father of five was charged today with threatening the life of President Nixon and ordered jailed in lieu of $100,000 bail. Three Secret Service agents picked up John P. Stark, 43 years old, at his home in Ithaca and took him before United States Magistrate Robert W. Arthur here for arraignment.

title: Cosmos Trounce Stars, 41, Here
description: The New York Cosmos routed the St. Louis Stars, 41, at Yankee Stadium last night to widen their lead in the Northern Division of the North American Soccer League to 14 points over secondplace Rochester.

title: LEE H. BURTON, 83, A LAWYER 61 YEARS
description: Lee H. Burton, a lawyer here since 1910, died yesterday in his home at 60 Sutton Place South after a short illness. He! was 83 years old.

title: SWITZERLAND BUYS MORE OF U.S. GOLD
description: ZURICH, Switzerland, June 16 (AP)  The Swiss National Bank disclosed today it had converted $50million into United States gold.

title: Southern Presbyterians to Study Merger
description: MASSANETTA SPRINGS, Va., June 16  Despite strong con servative opposition, the General Assembly of the onemillionmember Presbyterian Church in the U. S. (Southern), agreed last night to study carefully a proposed draft of a plan of union that would eventually reunite the Southern Church and the threemillionmember United Presbyterian Church. The division occurred over the slavery issue during the Civil War and has persisted ever since.

title: Advertising:
description: After a very short while in New York in the exalted role of corporate creative executive vice president of Walter Thompson, Robert L. Edens Jr. has resigned from the company to return to his beloved Chicago.

title: BOROWIAK SCORES IN N.C.A,A. TENNIS;3 Metropolitan Area Entries Eliminated at South Bend
description: SOUTH BEND, Ind., June 16 (AP)The three remaining metropolitan New York area players in the National Collegiate tennis tournament were eliminated today, but the defender, Jeff Borowiak, led a trio of University of California, Los Angeles, players into the quarterfinals.

title: Statement by Houthakker
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (Reuters)Hendrick S. Houthakker, a member of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, called today the gain in personal income for May quite encouraging.

title: Social, Worker Chief Named
description: Mitchell I. Ginsberg former Welfare Commissioner here will become president of the National Association of Social Workers on July 1. Mr. Ginsberg. dean of Columbia Undversity's School of Social Work will succeed Alan D. Wade as head of the 52,000member association. He will serve a twoyear term.

title: Screen: Bumpy Kabuki
A Mail Thief Says That He Got 100Million in Loot at Airports
description: WASHINGTON, June 16A master mail thief said today that he had committed nearly 200 thefts, stealing more than $100million worth of goods, in four years and had also stolen highly sensitive Government documents in the process.

title: Books of The Times
description: Edward Abbey's Black Sun is a picture postcard with a dead bird in the foreground. There is no message on the back: the recipient will have to supply his own or be satisfied with the scenery. Will Gatlin, the hero of the hook, has given up his wife, his son and his teaching job in order to study himself. Signing on as a solitary forest ranger in the Southwest, he tries to recover that landscape that Spengler says we have lost inside ourselves, a landscape whose order, according to Kant, is the pattern for our own. Gatlin is flourishing like a cactus until Sandy MacKenzie comes to upset the ecological balance. The moment he sees the freckles on her nose, his monklike existence, his fru gal diet of meditation and independence, are doomed. She is a bunny in his vegetable garden, consuming everything. Thowing off his taciturnity, he begins to talk like Mellors in Lady Chatterley's Lover, crooning aye and lass, quoting poetry and bursting into song.

title: PHONE STRIKE DATE IS SET FOR JULY 14
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., June 16 (UPI)  The Communications Workers of America announced today that it would strike the Bell Telephone System July 14 unless agreement on a new wage contract was reached.

title: Misleading, Canada Says
description: OTTAWA, June 16Canada's Secretary of State for External Affairs, Mitchell W. Sharp, complained today to the United States Ambassador, Adolph W. Schmidt, that the account in the Pentagon papers published by The Times of Canada's role as an intermediary between Washington and Hanoi was misleading.

title: Swedes Triumph in Table Tennis
description: Stellan Bengtsson and Kjell Johansson of Sweden combined to upset Japan, three games to none, in the team finals of the Vanderbilt International table tennis tournament before a crowd of 750 at the Felt Forum last night.

title: French Force Leaves Chad
description: FORTLAMY, Chad, June 16 (Agence FrancePresse)  The last French troops sent to reinforce the Chadian Army in its campaign to quash a rebellion were pulled out of the country today.

title: Brezhnev, in East Berlin, Sees Bright Future for Bloc
description: BERLIN, June 16Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet party chief, told East Europe's Communist leaders today that the worst was over in their efforts to secure their rule in the region and ho painted an inviting picture of the future.

title: Corona Hearing in Killings Is Continued Until July 13
description: YUBA CITY, Calif., June 16 (AP)Juan V. Corona sat silent and expressionless today at the opening of his preliminary hearing on mass murder charges.

title: Monetary Hearings Held
description: WASHINGTON, June 16The Federal Reserve Board disclosed today a sharp increase of $738million In loans and other transfers of dollars abroad by larger United States banks in the week ended May 12, reflecting the international monetary turbulence of that period.

title: Executive Changes
description: The ParkerHannifin Corporation announced yesterday that Patrick S. Parker, president, has been elected chief executive officer of the company. Mr. Parker takes over his additional responsibilities on June 30 from Robert W. Cornell, who will continue as chairman. Mr. Cornea indicated that the change stems from his own desire to reduce his current work load in the business. Mr. Parker has been president since 1968.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Bill Maloney, slim and blond, his choirboy face just beginning to crack and fade at 31, laid his jacket and cue case on a metal tray that slid under the billiard table out of reach of junkies and boosters. He screwed the halves of his stick together with quick, sure twists of slender hands as graceful and efficient as fishsnatching birds. He prowled the table, smoking, drinking coffee, but lithe and relaxed, as if he had purged his mind of a thousand deals and poured all his energies down into the cue. Players from other tables gathered to watch his match, part of McGirr's current threecushion billiard tournament, another attempt in the long, vain disjointed campaign to make something profitable of this complex and absorbing game.

title: Thant Appeals for Aid
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 16  Secretary General Thant appealed to the world community today for assistance to East Pakistan. He declared that improved conditions in East Pakistan would help to halt the flow of refugees crossing the border into India.

title: Market Place: Gauging Banks With New Tools
description: If you're a small trader and you like bank stocks, watch out. In the future, you'll be competing with institutions that have an analytical tool at their disposal that will make the informal methods used by some bankstock salesmen less reliable than usual.

title: Moving on Drugs Nationally
description: In announcements scheduled to be made by President Nixon today, the Administration's fragmented drug programs are at last to be brought together and given professional leadership. For the first time, there will be basis for hope that the sluggishness in the Administration's approach to the national drug crisis is ending.

title: TEXAS CUTS OUTPUT FOR OIL DURING JULY
description: AUSTIN, Tex., June 16 Texas has cut back its oil production for July, after several major companies presented lowered production nominations to the Texas Railroad Commission.

title: School Budgets Suffering in Tax Rebellion
description: In the last six weeks taxpayers in New York City's suburbs have been voting down their school budgets in record numbers, striking back at what they see as increasingly crushing tax burdens.

title: Rogers Meets Dobrynin on Troop Issue
description: WASHINGTON, June 16The United States and the Soviet Union today began exploring the posstbility of EastWest negotiations on a mutual reduction of forces in Europe.

title: U. S. Judge Voids Formula For Democratic Delegates
description: WASHINGTON, June 16The Democratic party's new formula for allocating 1972 convention delegates among the states was invalidated today by Judge June L. Green in Federal District Court here.

title: Rent Rise Figure Corrected
description: The Rent Guidelines Board said yesterday that its announcement of Tuesday that the new maximum permissible lease increases effective July for tenants in rentstabilized apartments amount to two percentage points more than last year's increases was incorrect. The correct figure, the board said, is one percentage point.

title: Immunizations Lag Called Peril in City
description: Prompted by the start of the polio season this month and by an incidence of measles cases this year almost five times higher than last year's, the Health Department issued a sharp warning of danger yesterday to parents of the tens of thousands of children here who had not had immunizations. against infectious diseases.

title: European Allies Make No Complaints
description: LONDON, June 16America's European allies say that they have made no complaints to the State Department and asked no questions about the ?? by The New York Times of documents on the Vietnam war.

title: REPORTS SAY TEXTS MIGHT HELP SOVIET
description: WASHINGTON, June 16The Defense Department declined to comment tonight on anonymous reports that Government officials feared that the Soviet Union could break United States Codes of the 1960's by studying the texts of diplomatic cables published by The New York Times.

title: Judge Clears Plan to Return Penn Central Cars
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 16 (AP)A Federal district judge has approved an agreement between the Penn Central Transportation Company and two (companies controlled by Joseph S. Bonanno for the return of 352 box cars that the railroad had said were missing.

title: City School Board Backs Use Of U.S. Aid to Retrain Teachers
description: The Board of Education approved last night the use of $60,000 in Federal funds to plan new programs to retrain the entire staffs of four city schools to meet the special needs of urban schoolchildren.

title: Tire Prices Raised
description: The Firestone Tire & Rubber Company and the B. F. Goodrich Company announced yesterday higher prices for nearly all types of tires, following the lead taken earlier this month by the Goodyear Tire & Rubber Company.

title: Huskies'
description: The University of Washington's unbeaten crew begins defense of its national championship in Syracuse today, heavily favored over Navy, rated the best of 13 challenging eights from the East Coast.

title: Nixon as a Keynesian
description: LONDONFor thirty years or more the world has suffered from a continuous increase in prices. Governments, especially progressive ones, have fallen in consequence. The old and the housewives in particular rose up in protest.

title: Opponents of War In Congress Decry U.S. Suit on Study
description: WASHINGTON, June 16Congressional opponents of the war in Indochina criticized the Nixon Administration today for having sought and obtained a court order temporarily preventing The New York Times from publishing further material from a secret Pentagon study on Vietnam.

title: The Human Lib Movement: I
description: A new movement is evolving from the core of the consciousness of the antipower culture. It is variously called a Men's Liberation Movement, a Human Alternatives Movement, a Human Liberation Movement, or a group of men in favor of women's liberation. All of the designations are correct but only the combination is complete her body becomes territory to be conquered and explored; the date becomes a physical adventure.

title: Bengalis Ride a Refugee Train of Despair
description: BARASAT, India, June. 16 Two thousand ragged Bengali refugees are stacked on a 12car train meant to hold fewer than a thousand. Five thousand more lie on the station platform, waiting their turneven though the next train is not due to leave for 24 hours.

title: Stage: The Maturity of a Black Girl
2 L.I.R. Trainmen Indicted For Perjury in Derailment
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., June 16 (AP)The engineer and fireman of a, Long Island Railroad train that derailed on Jan. 24, killing a conductor and injuring 40 persons, have been indicted for perjury before a grand jury.

title: Figures for May Indicate Economy Is Expanding at a Moderate Pace
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 Personal income and housing startstwo important indicators of the economyshowed moderate strength in May, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: IN THE NATION
description: The Government has alleged that The New York Times, in publishing the Defense Department's own record of the nation's involvement in Vietnam, has prejudiced the interests of the United States and the publication of additional excerpts... would further prejudice the defense interests of the United States and result in irreparable injury to the United States. That is a travesty of fact and common sense.

title: Workers Defer Pay Rise
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 16 (APLocal 190 of the Plumbers and Steamfitters Union has voted to defer a 35cent pay increase due its membrs July 1.

title: Vive la $10.5Million Cruise!
description: The France lived up to her reputation as one of the world's most expansive floating hotels yesterday evening by holding a champagne party for 150 peoplepeople who will be paying out anywhere from $5,000 for an inside cabin to nearly $100,000 for a grand luxe suite for five on an upcoming cruise.

title: Clyde Shipyard Workers Launch Protest
description: LONDON, June 16 (UPI)Irate Scottish shipyard workers marched on 10 Downing Street today. Afterward they said they got only tea and sympathy from Prime Minister Heath.

title: Rail Pension Bill Gains
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP) The Senate Labor Committee approved today a bill increasing railroad retirement benefits 10 per cent for 722,000 beneficiaries. The increase would be retroactive to Jan. 1 this year.

title: Peace in State Labor
description: Unionized state employes have shown better judgment in calling off their projected strike than they did threatening it.

title: Attack In Pnompenh Reported
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 16 (UPI)  Enemy commandos reportedly raided naval guard) posts four miles north of downtown Pnompenh early today, killing four Cambodian navy men and wounding 11.

title: It's Politics as Usual in Jersey City
description: JERSEY CITY, June 16Walter Wolfe, reelected chairman of the Hudson County Democratic committee last night, was still a little weteyed at his extortion conspiracy trial in Federal Court in Newark this. morning.

title: PRICES ON AMEX DIP IN SLOW DAY
State Denies Deal on Plans for Layoffs
description: ALBANY, June 16  The decision early this morning of the Civil Service Employees Association to call off a midnight strike was not based on any compromise by the state of plans to lay off workers, state officials insisted today.

title: Two Here Seek to Bar Sale Of Braque Oil in London
description: Gertrude Stein, proprietor of an art gallery at 998 Madison Avenue bearing her name, and Maurice A. Gribin, a Los Angeles industrialist, sued in State Supreme Court yesterday to bar the sale of an oil painting by Georges Braque, the cubist, at a London auction on July 7.

title: Medina Judge to Sift Influence Charges
description: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., June 16 (UPI)  A military judge sidetracked today the pretrial hearing of Capt. Ernest L. Medina on charges of mass murder at Mylai and ordered a separate hearing on whether improper command influence had been exerted in bringing him to trial.

title: Urban League's Head
description: Several years ago, while he was director of the Southern Regional Council's votereducation project, Vernon Eulion Jordan Jr. had to leave Atlanta in a hurry to resolve a dispute among a group of black leaders in Mississippi. He described his peacemaking method to a friend: You

title: Prosecutor Says New York Lawyer Ordered the Slaying of Panther
description: BALTIMORE, June 16  The prosecutor of Arthur F. Turco Jr., a white New York lawyer charged in connection with the 1969 torture and murder of a suspected Black Panther police informer here, maintained in his opening argument today that Mr. Turco had ordered the killing.

title: STALLION STAKES WON BY LENGTHS
description: Plum Bold of the Calumet ?? off so much of his opposition in the $30,625 National Stallion Stakes, colts and geldings division, that only two horses chose to run against him.

title: Lord Reith, 81, Former Director Of B.B.C., Dead in Edinburgh
description: LONDON, June 16  Lord Reith, the first director general of the British Broadcasting Corporation, died in a nursing home in Edinburgh today. He was 81 years old.

title: INSURERS WILL PAY IN MURDER DISPUTE
description: A New York insurance company agreed yesterday to pay $400,000 in the death of Lebanese national who, the in surer contended, was murdered while engaged in espionage.

title: Roundup: Stoneman Stops Padres, 20
description: It was a fast ball that brought Bill Stoneman to the major leagues in 1967, as relief pitcher with the Chicago Cubs. But it's a curve ball that the little Montreal Expos righthander has since developed that may make him a 20game winner.

title: Brooklyn School Boycotted In a Playground Protest
description: Pupils boycotted Public School 38, at 450 Pacific Street, Brooklyn, yesterday while their parents staged a demonstration in the borough at Board Education headquarters, 110 Livingston Street.

title: Warning System on Ocean Waste Sought
description: Because the oceans of the world have become one gigantic septic tank in which poisonous wastes are accumulating at rates many consider alarming, an international effort is being planned to identify the most dangerous changes before it is too late.

title: Chess: Korchnoi Is True to Form In His Victory Over Geller
Advertising:
description: Spreads are spreading across the face of this nation. Ham? Chicken? Tuna? What'll you have? (Besides Pabst Blue Ribbon, that is).

title: Washington: For the Record
description: Activities. The President had a morning meeting with his National Security Council and then saw the United States Ambassador to Saigon, Ellsworth Bunker. The President also greeted the Teenage Republican Conference and then saw Ambassador and Mrs. E. Ross Adair Jr. Later in the afternoon the President saw the Indian Foreign Minister.

title: MAYORS DEMAND PULLOUT BY 1972
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 16The United States Conference of Mayors, by a 54to49 vote urged President Nixon today to pull all United States troops out of Vietnam by Dec. 31.

title: CLINTON RICKARD, 91, TUSCARORA'S CHIEF
description: LEWISTON, N. Y., June 16 (UPI)  Chief Clinton Rickard, grand president and founder of the Indian Defense League of America, died Monday. He was 91 years old.

title: Second OTB Parlor Computerized Today
description: Computerization of the city's offtrack betting system will be extended to second office today.

title: VASILY V. PARIN, 68, SOVIET PHYSIOLOGIST
description: MOSCOW, June 16 (AP) Vasily V. Parin, a prominent Soviet expert on the effects of space travel on the human body, died yesterday, Tass, the official Soviet news agency, reported. He was 68 years old.

title: Nicklaus to Spare Driver In Open Starting Today
description: ARDMORE, Pa., June 16Jack Nicklaus intends to use a driver at only three holes in the United States Open golf championship that begins here tomorrow. To avoid the long, thick rough and to gain the right position for his second shots to the greens of the Merion Golf Club course, Nicklaus will adopt a special strategy on the other 15 holes. Depending on wind and weather conditions, he will select a No. 3 wood or a No. 1 iron instead of the driver, the customary power club that most of the 150 entrants will be using from the tees.

title: MARKET EDGES UP AS CAUTION REIGNS
HOUSE VOTES HALT IN FUNDING OF F14
description: WASHINGTON, June 16The House voted today to halt funding of the Navy's F14 swingwing jet fighter, pending completion of a Pentagon study of the plane's excess cost.

title: Ceylon Tightens Censorship
description: COLOMBO, Ceylon, June 16 (Reuters)The government has further tightened censorship laws now in force under emergency regulations. No proposal by any minister or by the Government nor any matter before the Cabinet may now be published without approval by competent authority.

title: Bridge: Even Experts Have Trouble In Foreseeing Squeeze Play
description: Most players find it hard to visualize a squeeze when they are playing the hand, and equally hard to foresee in defense that they may be subjected to a squeeze. Failing to anticipate that one's partner may be squeezed is on an even higher plane, but experts expect their partners to rise to the occasion.

title: G.E. Says It Sold Shares Of Honeywell on June 4
description: The General Electric Company yesterday confirmed reports that it sold on June 4 a total of 375,000 common shares of Honeywell, Inc., for more than $40million. This stock came from 1.5 million Honeywell shares G.E. received last October when G.E. sold its principal computer manufacturing operations to a new Honywell subsidiary.

title: Mrs. Ilyana Lanin Wed in Croton
description: CROTON ON HUDSON, N. Y., June 16  Mrs. Ilyana Yankwich Lanin, associate director of community medicine at the Cornell Medical CenterNew York Hospital, was married here today to David C. Adams, executive vice president of the National Broadcasting Company. The Rev. Noel Sokoloff performed the Episcopal ceremony in the garden at the bridegroom's home.

title: World Press Overwhelmingly Supports Publication of Documentation on Vietnam
description: Editorials in the press here and abroad have overwhelmingly supported the publication by The New York Times of a series of secret documents dealing with the origins of the United States involvement in the Indochina War.

title: MARIAN M'PARTLAND SHOWS A NEW STYLE
description: The Cookery, which is at University Place and Eighth Street, is in one of those areas in which entertainment is limited to the use of stringed instruments and one voice, No drums or wind instruments are allowed. For a jazz performer, these requirements, particularly the ban on drums, might be restricting. But in the case of Marian McPartland, the pianist who is currently playing there, the situation has opened up an interesting performing potential that she might not otherwise undertake.

title: Liguori Looks Almost Unbeatable in the N.C.A.A. Mile
description: SEATTLE, June 16  If the fate of the supersonic transport still is undecided in the minds of local citizens, hardly anyone can find a challenger for Marty Liguori in the mile run at the National Collegiate outdoor track and field championships.

title: Madrid Psychiatrist Faces Jail For His Sex Survey of Students
description: MADRID, June 16"In many countries an investigation of this type would bring offers of fellowships. I suppose it is a matter of some sociological interest that here it has led to criminal charges.

title: Inland Steel Unit Expanding
description: The Inland Steel Company said yesterday in Chicago that a subsidiary, the Schult Mobile Home Corporation, would build its eighth plant at Navasota, Tex. Inland said it would have a capacity of 1,500 mobile homes a year.

title: BIAS IS CHARGED IN STATE U. HIRING
description: Employment practices for jobs in teaching and administration in the 27 institutions of the State University of New York system have been termed grossly discriminatory against black and Puerto Rican educators and administrators in a finding of the New York State Advisory Committee to the United States Commission on Civil Rights.

title: Notes on People
description: It's Royal Ascot Week, Britain's annual extravaganza for horses  equine and clothes variety  and yesterday, a day late because of a soggy track, Queen Elizabeth II rode round the course in an open carriage despite threats that the royal box would be bombed.

title: Fulbright Sees Deception
description: LONDON, June 16Senator Fulbright said tonight that publication of the documented Vietnam war history would help restore the American constitutional balance.

title: A CHILEAN LEFTIST KILLS 2 POLICEMEN
description: SANTIAGO, Chile June 16A comrade of the two leftwing extremists who were killed by the police for the slaying of a Christian Democratic leader attacked police headquarters today and killed two detectives.

title: Atomic Bomb Is Tested Under Nevada Desert
description: MERCURY, Nev., June 16 (AP)After the longest halt in United States nuclear testing in almost a decade, the Atomic Energy Commission detonated today what was described as a lowyield atomic bomb under the Nevada desert.

title: Habitat, 71: New Homes For the Ape
description: It seemed to visitors at the Bronx Zoo yesterday that Briggs, the 10yearold orangutan from Borneo, was having some difficulty deciding whether he liked his new quartersa glassedin indoor cage that contained a simulated treetop.

title: Aid for Pakistan?
description: The appeal of the United States Government to India and Pakistan to avoid exacerbation of tensions rising out of the civil strife in East Pakistan and the flight millions of refugees into India is long overdue. represents belated acknowledgement of the grave international implications of a conflict that Washington has tried to dismiss as a domestic affair.

title: Homemade SausagesLinks to the Past
description: In Dutch genre painting, there is stock figure sometimes referred to as Hans Wurst. Strings of sausages dangle from every part of him. His face is plump and red with excess, and he is the soul of simple revelry from a day and a place where handmade sausages stood for good flavor and a holiday mood.

title: Meskill and Democratic Leaders Struggle Vainly to Work Out Fiscal Accord
description: HARTFORD, June 16  The Connecticut General Assembly reconvened today in a special session called to work out the state fiscal program for the year that starts July 1, but the real business was conducted in the Governor's office.

title: Senate Panel Approves Move To Establish a Cancer Agency
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (AP)  The Senate Labor and Public Welfare Committee approved today a bill to set up a new agency to combat cancer.

title: The Search for Gems in the Rough
description: For a family in the mood for a different but not too expensive vacation, here's a suggestion: toss the kids, some magnifying glasses and flashlights into the car and go surface mining for rubies, sapphires, amethysts, garnets and a flock of other gems.

title: Wood, Field and Stream: Weakfish Return to Narragansett Bay After 20 Years
description: WARWICK; R. I.When prized gamefish returns to waters he jhas not frequented for 20 years, there is cause for rejoicing and I rejoiced as the first squeteague came over the rail.

title: GEORGE COPELAND, A DEBUSSY EXPERT
description: PRINCETON, N.J., June 16George Copeland, the pianist who was an apostle of Debussy's music in this country from the day of his concert debut in his native Boston in 1905 until less than a decade ago, died today in the Merwick Unit of Princeton Hospital after a long illness. He was 89 years old.

title: Celebration Is Barred
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 16 (UPI)Law officers and politicians in Louisiana and Mississippi said today they would not allow on their soil the Celebration of Life, an eightday rock festival that boasts of voodoo workshops, Ferris wheels and men on a flying trapeze.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: James Reston's survey of the China field today (The New China Hands, May 12 column) misses certain fundamental realities which we feel are more cause for concern than for optimism.

title: Former Saigon Leader Recalls Ouster
description: PARIS, June 16Gen. Nguyen Khanh, who led the Government of South Vietnam and was commander of its armed forces in 1964, said here today that he was in constant conflict during that period with the United States Ambassador, Maxwell D. Taylor.

title: Proposed Member Of Economic Panel Flexible on Parity
description: WASHINGTON, June 16 (Reuters)  The newly proposed member of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, Ezra Solomon, said today that he was not against a floating, selfadjusting peg for the dollar as a way to avoid future international monetary crises.

title: FEE SHIFT BACKED BY BIG BOARD UNIT
description: Sweeping changes in sales charges for stock transactions were endorsed yesterday by a highlevel committee of the New York Stock Exchange and sent to the exchange's governing board for approval.

title: American Air Losses Up
description: American Airlines reported yesterday a $2.1million loss for May and a five months loss of $27.7million. In May, 1970, the airline operated at a loss of $492,000; the loss in the first five months of 1970 was $6.8million.

title: Albany Is Shifting Its Narcotics Chief To Youth Division
description: ALBANY, June 16  Milton L. Luger is expected to resign shortly as chairman of the State Narcotic Addiction Control Commission and resume his former post as director of the State Division for Youth.

title: Can America Grow Up?
description: In 1950, there were 151 million Americans. Today, there are 208 million. By the year 2000only 29 years from nowthat number is expected to swell to roughly 300 million. In other words, if present growth patterns persist, the population of the United States will double in the last half of the twentieth century.

title: Laver Tops Franulovic in Tennis
description: LONDON, June 16A little rusty until the chips were down, Rod Laver fought back to win a threeset centercourt thriller from ZeLilco Franulovic as the sun finally broke out at the Queen's Club in the London grass tennis tournament today.

title: Researcher Finds the FrontRunners Usually Win Presidential Nominations
description: WASHINGTON, June 15 William It. Keech, a research associate at the Brookings Institution, remarked to a group of political reporters at lunch last week that his studies suggested that frontrunners usually win Presidential nominations. Specifically, said Mr. Keech, who is on leave as an associate professor of political science at the University of North Carolina, the man who leads the Gallup Poll of rankandfile members of his own party just before the start of the Presidential primaries is likely to win at the convention.

title: Rosewall Beaten by Goven

title: Newley's 'Summertree' Opens:Hume and Yafa Work Revisits the 40's Death of a Serviceman Fixes the Action
description: Anybody old enough can remember, and anybody not old enough may imagine, the mood of sentiment about the land and the ordinary people and the quality of tree-shaded life in middle-America that gripped the popular arts, and especially the movies, during and for a few years after World War II. The mood passesfor a good many reasonsby the early 1950's, but a certain nostalgia for it remains. That nostalgia has been felt in several movies recentlymovies that mean to recreate the 1940'sand it now appears brought up to date in Anthony Newley's "Summertree," which opened yesterday at neighborhood theaters and which attempts indicting the barbarities of Vietnam in terms of decent emotional strategies developed to illustrate life on the home front 30 years ago.I never saw the successful Ron Cowen play upon which "Summertree" is based, but I gather there have been a lot of changesmostly directed toward "relevance" and a slight juicing up of the action. There is a new character, a little black boy (Kirk Callaway), who speaks for separatism. And the girl friend (Brenda Vaccaro) is now a somewhat older woman who already has a husbandin Vietnam. But the boy (Michael Douglas) with each toss of his rugged head, each glance from his friendly eyes, bespeaks Young America. And the gruff dad (Jack Warden) who nervously loves his son and finally betrays him into war, and mom who cares and puts on the coffee  they are an older America that appropriately lives for the young. Barbara Bel Geddes plays mom, and one closed-mouth smile of hers is surely worth 350 apple pies cooling in the kitchen window.The central image of the summertree itself  a backyard retreat where the boy goes to dream his life into beingsurvives in rather ridiculous ways: especially in a bit of tinkly music, and a worm-eaten leaf pattern superimposed on the screen over his first night of lovemaking with the girl friend. And his death, which is in fact the reason for the drama, is there also, as a final bitter irony of the war that the movie, not too stupidly, admits wholly through the medium of the television screen."Summertree" is a bad movie, but its badness proceeds not from its intentions, which seem honorable, or from its stylistic analogies to past modes, which in different hands could have been interesting. The badness exists, rather, moment by moment, in the insufficiency of each acted scene, in the niggling insecurity of Newley's camera, in the improverishment of each evocation of a quality of lifefrom the boy's dull guitar playing, which is supposed to be great, to the father's love of hunting, which should recreate the landscape, but only signifies a thoughtless and cruel pastime.Nobody's performance quite works in "Summertree," but it is possible at least to respect Jack Warden's tense privacies and Michael Douglas's restraint in projecting a youthful goodwill without either petulance or excessive charm. Brenda Vaccaro is reasonable off-type casting, but she does not seem resourceful enough even to explore the limits of this small, appealingly pathetic role.

Hesburgh, chairman of the United States Civil Rights Commission, charged today that the Federal Government, despite all the laws we need, had been deficient in ending racial and economic polarization. title: The Screen:'The Anderson Tapes' Stars Connery
description: Professionalism in a movie director, the ability to understand the job at hand and to know how to go about doing it, is a virtue that tends to be overlooked by serious moviegoers and critics, partly because it offers no unusual edge for comment, and partly because in the history at least of commercial American film production it has tried to be nearly invisible. But it has been altotherer too nearly invisible in movies lately to go unremarked when it does appear. And in Sidney Lumet's "The Anderson Tapes" the quality of professionalism appears in rather lovely manifestations to raise a by no means perfect film to a level of intelligent efficiency that is not so very far beneath the reach of art."The Anderson Tapes" is a caper movie, a most unpromising type, dealing with an ambitious attempt at a heist from an upper Fifth Avenue mansion that has been divided into luxury apartments guarded by a television security system that must rival the Pentagon's. Wanting all that loot and confronting all that surveillance stands John Anderson (Sean Connery) exconvict and current lover of the lady in 2B (Dyan Cannon), whose principal support (Richard B. Schull) has had her apartment bugged by Peace of Mind, an organization dedicated to getting the goods on wayward wives and mistresses.As anybody who has read the movie's source will recall, "The Anderson Tapes" is a fiction with a gimmick. Lawrence Sanders's novel purports to be a compilation of tapes, depositions, Xeroxed letters and the like, by means of which the caper is revealed and intimate secrets are put on view. The movie preserves the gimmick and even improves upon it to the extent that almost everything in it happens before the electronic eyes and ears of the F.B.I., the I.R.S., the H.U.A.C., the N.Y.P.D., and of course P.O.M. (Peace of Mind surveillance)  none of whom know about the others' work and each of whom is spying on the Mafia, the Reds, junkies, a misbehaving mistress, but never on John Anderson.About the gimmick I am of several minds, mostly negative because it has very little to do with the development of action, and at the end functions as an irrelevantly topical sour joke. But for almost everything else I am full of admirationfor the superb pacing, the tactful understatement of the location shooting, the sharp feel of the citywhich is never in any extraneous sense "poetic" but always exactly functional to what is after all a summer's entertainment.Except for Sean Connery's laconic, attractive, beautifully subdued John Anderson, the various roles in "The Anderson Tapes" are all character vignettes of more or less detail, but in any case stronger in recognition value than in dramatic development. To a great degree, these vignettes make the movie, and to do them decent credit would require almost a complete cast listing. Among the principle ones I especially liked Alan King as the expansive Mafia captain (a charming stereotype) who finances the caper and Garrett Morris as a black police sergeant whose unspectacular heroism ultimately does it in.Sidney Lumet doesn't usually make great movies, and though he tends to be very selective about his sources, (the plays of O'Neill, Chekhov, etc.) his average has not been too much better than a workmanlike 50 per cent. But when he has a subject or a source that is more alive to him than it is certifiably important he does work of exceptional depth and beauty. Over the years, in movies like "The Group" and "Bye, Bye Braverman," he has developed a sort of corner on the subject matter of New York, and in "The Anderson Tapes" he takes his profit on it with an assured and harrowing and even good humored understanding. A great deal gets into "The Anderson Tapes," which in telling its minor story shows a quite wonderful accessibility to the multiplicity of life.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARISDisposition of the troublesome Okinawa question as a result of protracted U.S. Japanese negotiations marks a triumph of good sense. Premier Sato has long argued that generation after the war one million Okinawans shouldn't be under foreign administrationabove all when it remembered that more than sixty countries gained independence during that period. The obstacle of Okinawa must be surmounted, he insisted.

title: Drug Abuse Fighter Jerome Herbert Jaffe
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 How do you expect to deal with Washington bureaucracy? Dr. Jerome.Herbert Jaffe was asked today just after President Nixon named him to head a new White House office on drug abuse control. With the same unrealistic optimism with which I dealt with Illinois bureaucracy, the doctor replied. When he arrived in Illinois in 1966 from the Bronx, there wasn't a single statesupported bed for the treatment of drug addicts in Illinois. Now there are 1,800.

description: WASHINGTON, June 17 (Reuters)A State Department investigation was under way today into reports that a Brazilian patrol boat fired warning shots near a United States fishing vessel 70 miles off the coast yesterday morning.

Fighting in Laos
description: VIENTIANE, Laos, June 17 (AP)  Heavy fighting was reported today in southern Laos between the key Government town of Pakse, in the Mekong River Valley, and the Boloven Plateau to the east, which was seized by North Vietnamese forces last month. Defense Minister Sissouk Na passak said that 700 enemy soldiers had been killed and three tanks and four antiaircraft guns destroyed in recent days.

title: OnceFeared Regents Tests Face Hazy Future
MRS. WARREN LOCKWOOD
description: Mrs. Helen Robinson Lockwood, widow of Warren J. Lockwood, former assistant Federal housing administrator, died Wednesday in Midtown Hospital. She was 87 years old and lived at 130 East 30th Street.

title: Senate Bars Plan Allowing Draftees To Have Counsel
description: WASHINGTON, June 17The Senate rejected today a measure that would have permitted potential draftees to be accompanied by lawyers when they appeared before their draft boards. The vote was 44 to 32.

title: Striking Miners, Heeding Boyle, Begin Returning After 4 Days
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va., June 17 (UPI)An estimated 90,000 striking coal miners began returning to their jobs tonight, obeying a directive from the president of the United Mine Workers of America, W. A. Boyle, to end a fourday walkout.

title: Liguori Does 4:00.7 Just to Qualify
description: SEATTLE, June 17Marty Liguori ran the mile in 4:00.7 today, and it was only a preI view of coming attractions at the National Collegiate outdoor track and field championships.

title: For the Housewife With Career, Life Is a Big Balancing Act
description: WASHINGTON  The liberated woman who has a family needs two words to describe the mechanics of her daily life: finagle and finesse.

title: Underworld Figure Gets 9 Years in Bond Scheme
description: BALTIMORE, June 17 (AP)Carlo Mastrototaro, described by a Federal prosecutor as a leading figure in the Boston underworld, was sentenced today to nine years in jail and a $5,000 fine for aiding in the in terstate transportation of some $300,000 in stolen bonds.

title: Excerpts From Oral Arguments on U.S. Effort to Obtain Documents From Times
description: MR. HESS: Your Honor, the Government brought on an order to show cause yesterday before your Honor late in the afternoon, asking that this motion be brought on today and asking for inspection of the documents in the hand of The New York Times. This is pursuant to Rule 34 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure.

title: Dr. Itelson Is Bride
description: Dr, Osnat nelson of Tel Aviv, a gynecologist and obstetrician, was married at the SheratonTel Aviv on May 24 to Dr. William A. Wexler of Savannah, Ga., president of B'nai B'rith and chairman of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations, Rabbi Mordechi Piron performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is a graduate of the Southern College of Optometry in Memphis. His first wife died.

title: Plot to Fix Criminal Cases Laid to Bergen Prosecutor
description: TRENTON, June 17The New Jersey state grand jury today indicted Robert Dilts, the superseded Bergen County Prosecutor, and a codefendant, Michael Schiro, on charges involving bribery, obstructing justice and misconduct in office.

title: Swift Agrees to Limitation On Claims for Baby Foods
description: WASHINGTON, June 17Swift & Co. of Chicago has signed a Federal Trade Commission consent order prohibiting it from making false nutritional claims in advertisements of its baby foods.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:The Pentagon Study of the Vietnam War (June 13) is a disclosure of Machiavellian duplicity. We have sent our young people to die in battle, we have devastated vast areas and we have slaughtered countless civilians on the pretense that we were defending allies from aggression. The record now seems clear that we betrayed our ideals as we arrogantly applied our power to further our political goals.

title: Philadelphia Will Get a Condominium
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 17Plans for a Philadelphia's first luxury hotel and first major condominium were announced today by Mayor James H. J. Tate, Philip Johnson, the architect, and two developers.

title: Wisconsin Is the 34th State To Back 18YearOld Vote
description: MADISON, Wis., June 17Wisconsin became today the 34th state to ratify the United States constitutional amendment to permit 18yearolds to vote in state and local elections.

title: Rock Roi, 2 to 1, Triumphs In Gold Cup Race at Ascot
description: ASCOT, England, June 17 (UPI) Favored Rock Roi scored a fourlength victory today in the $43,617 Gold Cup, glamour event of the Royal Ascot race meeting. The victory was worth $29,829.

title: When the Potter Has Talent and Wit
description: Monsters gurgle in a wading pool. A lifesized penguin with angel's wings strapped like a parachute to its back stands poised for takeoff. A red, white and blue cow nibbles on the Washington Monument.

title: ALEXIS FERMI, 101, TEACHING PIONEER
description: Alexis C. Ferm a pioneer in education died on Wednesday's in Fairhope Ala., where he had been living since his retirement in 1950. He was 101 years old on Feb. 19.

title: Mayor Calls U.S. Suit A Threat to Freedoms
description: Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that The New York Times should be permitted to continue publishing its series on the United States involvement in the Vietnam war and added that it would be useful for public education.

title: Apollo 16 Crewmen To Put Observatory On Moon in March
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 (UPI)  The space agency disclosed today that two Apollo 16 astronauts would set up an astronomical observatory on the moon next March. No such station now exists.

title: Dance: Balanchine Offers PAM TGG
description: Even the career of a great choreographer such as George 11,alanchine has got to have a, nadir. Last night, at the New York State Theater, the New York City ballet offered, with some effrontery, I felt, a ballet called PAMTGG, and I suspect that the nadir was nadired. This one hit rock bottom wih the dull thud of ineffable triviality.

title: Commons Vote on Market Entry Scheduled for Fall
description: LONDON, June 17The House of Commons will make its decision next fall on whether to bring Britain into the European Common Market.

title: How to Get Power to the People
description: There is no national shortage of electrical power today Rather there is a disastrous maldistribution of generating and transmission capacity and a shocking lack of effective coordination between systems. The true cause of the power shortage that faces certain areas is the individual power companies themselves and their refusal to engage in the national planning.

title: EEC: Mr. Heath Delays
description: Prime Minister Heath's decision to delay until fall the first test vote in the House of Commons on Britain's bid to join the European Economic Community is disappointing. Mr. Heath had originally hoped to force a yesorno test vote before the Commons recessed in August.

title: Roundup: Kessinger's 6for6 Paces Cubs
description: Don Kessinger, the National League's AllStar shortstop for the last three years, reawakened some memories yesterday at Wrigley Field, Chicago.

title: Most Authors Were Given A Promise of Anonymity
description: The majority of the approxi mately 36 authors who wrote the narrativeanalysis sections of the Pentagon papers were career military and civilian officials who were promised anonymity when they were recruited for the project, according to former Government officials anonymity, only a relatively small number of authors names have so far emerged. These include the following:

title: Kennedy Asks U.S. Data
description: WASHINGTON, June 17Senator Edward M. Kennedy called today for full disclosure of secret Government data on Vietnam policies and actions during the Administration of President John F. Kennedy.

title: JUDGE IS CRITICIZED ON BABYCASE DELAY
description: A State Supreme Court justice chided a Family Court judge yesterday for failure to rule on a childcustody case, that went to trial last October.

title: SERPICO CREDITED IN EXTORTION CASE
description: A New York City detective whose information led to criminal and departmental corruption charges against 20 policemen, was credited yesterday with the arrest of a housing inspector who was accused of extorting money from one of his neighbors in Greenwich Village.

title: EXAIDE INDICTED IN HUDSON COUNTY
description: JERSEY CITY, June 17 (AP) The former director of the defunct Hudson County Mosquito Commission was charged with five others today with extortion from contractors and embezzlement from the county totaling $280,000.
