description: ROME, June 17 Kenneth Macpherson Scottish novelist and editor, who was the literary executor for the estate of Norman Douglas, author of the philosophical fantasy, South Wind, died Monday at hiS home in Cetona, Tuscany. His age was 68.

title: Soviet Seizes on Secret Papers To Criticize Policies of Nixon
description: MOSCOW, June 17The Soviet Union sought today to turn the publication of parts of the Pentagon papers on the Vietnam war into an attack on the policies of the Nixon Administration.

title: Weekend Fishing and Boating
description: Fishing Report

title: Outlays for TV and Radio Ads by Gubernatorial Candidates in the 1970 Elections
Johnson's Publisher Says Data Won't Affect Book on Presidency
description: Former President Lyndon B. Johnson has completed the manuscript of his forthcoming book on his White House years and does not plan to change his account of the Vietnam war as a result of the publication of parts of a secret Pentagon study covering the same period.

title: RECORD CLEARED FOR EXF.B.I. MAN
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has agreed to remove the phrase with prejudice from the resignation record of a former agent who was accused by 3. Edgar Hoover, the F.B.I. director, of atrocious judgment because he wrote a letter critical of the agency.

title: SUSPECT IN THEFTS BARS TESTIMONY
description: WASHINGTON, June 17An alleged leader in an organized crime syndicate in Brooklyn invoked the Fifth Amendment 36 times today before a Senate subcommittee investigating massive thefts of securities and other valuables.

title: New Hurdle for Welfare Reform
description: In line with its regular practice of digging pitfalls for progressive legislation, the House Rules Committee has done its best to insure defeat of welfare reform when that crucial measure comes up for House action before the end of the month.

title: Agnew Will Circle Globe in July In Goodwill Trip to 10 Countries
description: WASHINGTON, June 17Vice President Agnew will spend most of July circling the globe on a goodwill mission to 10 countries in Asia, Africa, the Middle East and Europe, the White House announced today.

title: Minh Calls on Saigon to Keep Fighting, but in the Cause of Peace
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 17General Duong Van Minh, who was expected to declare his peace candidacy today for the October presidential elections, called for South Vietham's armed forces to keep fighting, but for a. righteous causepeace.

title: The Playing Fields of Peking
description: PEKINGThe icehockey team from the province of Heilungkiang was playing against the province of Kirin, in one of the big sport stadiums in Peking.

title: The Human Lib Movement: II
description: Once a man becomes secure enough not to have to prove his masculinity by being the primary breadwinner and playing all the man's roles, he can broaden the concept of what constitutes a good working relationship with women.

title: Bridal for Lucille Grubel
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., June 17Miss Lucille A. Grubel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Grubel of Kew Gardens Hills, Queens, was married here today to Richard M. Goldsmith, son of Mrs. Henry Goldsmith of Briarwood, Queens, and the late Mr. Goldsmith. Rabbi Bernard N. Cohn performed the ceremony at Leonard's. The bride is a junior at the Bernard Baruch College of the City University of New York. Her husband, a graduate of the University of Rhode Island, is a systems analyst at Mosler's Informations Systems, a division of the Mosler Safe Company.

title: 57% of City's Public School Enrollment Is Black and Puerto Rican
description: Negroes and Puerto Ricans, who a decade ago comprised 38.9 per cent of the enrollment in public schools here, now make up 57.2 per cent of the total, according to statistics released by the Board of Education.

title: N.F.L., Players Agree On Bargaining Contract
description: MINNEAPOLIS June 17 (UPI)The National Football League Players Association and the club owners straightened out their injury grievance procedures today and signed a fouryear collective bargaining contract.

title: Store Sales Increase
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 The Commerce Department today estimated last week's department store sales at $833million, up 17 per cent from the yearearlier $715million.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:Instead of digging into the history of the 19641965 period under the Johnson Administration, I suggest that The Times undertake to discover and present the decisions that already have been made by the Nixon Administration to be implemented in the spring of 1973.

title: U.N. Aide Reiterates 65 View Of Thant on the Vietnam War
description: UNITED NATIONS, June 17 A United Nations spokesman today in effect reiterated a sixyearold statement by Secretary General Thant that if the American public had known the facts about Vietnam in early 1965 it would have agreed then that the bloodshed there should end.

title: Heads of N.A.A.C.P. and Urban League Assail Nixon's Record
description: ATLANTA, June 17  The Nixon Administration's record in behalf of black Americans was condemned here today by both Roy Wilkins, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People and Harold R. Sims, acting executive director of the National Urban League.

title: Jobless Black Youths Called Peril to Cities
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP)A private foundation said today. that 2.5 million unemployed black youths would create a potentially explosive situation for the nation's cities this summer and urged that Federal, city and state government jobs be created for them.

title: FiveYear Plan Offered
description: BERLIN, June 17 (UPI)A fiveyear economic plan for 197175 offered to the East German party congress today called for more housing, higher wages and increased production.

title: U.S.C. Nine Retains Crown By Beating So. Illinois, 72
description: OMAHA, June 17 (AP)Southern California used 10 hits and the pitching of Steve Busby to post a 72 victory over Southern Illinois tonight and successfully defend its College World Series title.

title: Pact for Okinawa Return Signed
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 Twentysix years after American troops captured Okinawa the United States today signed a treaty with Japan to restore the island to Japanese sovereignty.

title: House, Like Senate, Bars Deadline in Troop Pullout
description: WASHINGTON, June 17The House, following the lead of the Senate, refused today to impose a Congressional deadline on the President for withdrawal of American forces from Indochina.

title: Isbrandtsen Resigns Here As American Export Head
description: American Export Industries, Inc., which lost $15.6million last year and ran another deep deficit in the first quarter of this year, said yesterday that Jakob Isbrandtsen had resigned as president and chief executive officer of the company.

title: P.S. Kalikow Weds Mary T. Jacobatos
description: Miss Mary Typaldos Jacobatos and Peter S. Kalikow were married here yesterday afternoon. Rabbi Ronald Sobel performed the ceremony at the Plaza.

title: Excerpts From Latest Editorial Reaction in U. S. and Abroad to Publication of Documents on Vietnam War
description: Following are excerpts from the continuing editorial reaction in this country and abroad to the publication by The New York Times of secret documents dealing with the origins of the United States involvement in the Indochina war:

title: Rusk States He Never Heard Of Study Before Times Series
description: DECATUR, Ga., June 17 (AP) Former Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today he had never heard of the secret Pentagon. Vietnam study that The New York Times has been temporarily enjoined from publishing.

title: RUSSELL H. WILLIS
description: Russell H. Willis, a former builder and real estate developer in suburban areas here and in Sarasota, Fla., died Wednesday in Sarasota, where he moved in 1957. He was 86 years old and formerly lived in Pelham Manor, N. Y.

title: S.E.C. Chief Is Resisting Reformers Demands on Securities Law
description: WASHINGTON, June 17William J. Casey, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, opposes attempts that are being made by some reformers to use the securities laws to force corporations to adopt what they feel are more socially conscious policies.

title: Mayor Tells Graduates of Legacy of Frustration
description: Mayor, Lindsay gave the graduating class of Brooklyn Law School a mordant view yesterday of the world awaiting them and their profession.

title: Harvard's Commencement Unmarked by Protests for First Time in 4 Years
description: CAMBRIDGE, June 17Undisturbed by student protests for the first time in four years. Harvard College graduated 1,066 men at traditional commencement ceremonies today. For the second year, Radcliffe College joined in the ceremonies, awarding Harvard Bachelor Arts degrees to 270 women.

title: Martini Luther King Day Is Vetoed in Connecticut
description: HARTFORD, June 17  Gov. Thomas J. Meskill vetoed a bill today that would have designated Jan. 15 each year as a legal holiday, to be known as Martin Luther King Day.

title: Screen: A Horror Bill From Britain:Sangster Is Director of 'Frankenstein' Christopher Lee Takes Role of Dracula
description: Boys will be boys, hence "Scars of Dracula" and "Horror of Frankenstein" at neighborhood theaters, in one double-bundle from Britain. But hold on a minute.Avoid "Dracula" like the plague. It's garish, gory junk. The surprise is the first hour of "Frankenstein," about two-thirds of the picture. It's not only painless but also fun. Hammer Productions has finally spared the hammer and applied some deft needlework and snug embroidery.Imagine a kind of "Kind Hearts and Coronets" detour. Instead of a sly blade gently murdering legacy obstacles, there's a personable young baron, Ralph Bates, crisply dispatching friends and relatives while setting up a castle laboratory for you-know-what.The screenplay, credited to Jeremy Burnham and Jimmy Sangster, the director, is as bright as can be. And the wry, pointed dialogue is nicely clipped off by a game cast, including Graham James, Kate O'Mara and Veronica Carlson. And lo and behold, there is Dennis Price, who bumped off eight Alec Guinnesses in "Kind Hearts and Coronets."One scene, when young Baron Victor Frankenstein casually eyes a brain prospect over the dinner table, is funny enough to have come from the earlier film. So far, so goodneat, tasteful, with a steely edge of incoming horror and no gore to the fore.Then the infamous monster materializes, a lumbering giant, casting a pall over the remainder of the movie, much as if the rabbit had appeared in "Harvey." The film shatters, with awkward horror pitted against rather bland sheepishness. But it was good fun while it lasted. Hammer almost had something special.

title: ANGELS UNARMED, PHILLIPS INSISTS
description: KANSAS CITY, June 17 (AP) Manager Lefty Phillips denied vigorously tonight that weapons were being carried by the California Angels and pointed at Alex Johnson as the cause of reported strife on the club.

title: Venezuela Nearing TakeOver of Oil Operations
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, June 17The Venezuelan Congress, in an unusual display of unity, is rushing legislation that would place all foreign petroleum companies under effective Govern. ment control. And when the present concessions expire, starting in 1983, they would revert to the state without compensation to the companies.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 (UPI)Union and management representatives of competitors of the Lockheed Aircraft CarIporation urged Congress today to defeat a proposed Governiment guarantee of a $250mi1lion loan as a threat to free competition and a reward for mismanagement.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:Interesting to note in the June 6 report in The Times that Ralph Nader's team of young investigators has not named the biggest monopolists of them allthe unions.

title: Many in Appalachia Hungry Despite U. S. Aid
description: CHARLESTON, W. Va. Pockets of hunger remain in the hollows of Appalachia despite the Nixon Administration's pledge to put an end to hunger and malnutrition, and after nearly a decade of massive Federal aid to the distressed region.

description: WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) The Senate confirmed today the nomination of Ezra Solomon, a Stanford University professor of finance, to be a member of the President's Council of Economic Advisers. He is replacing Hendrick S. Houthakker.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: BRASILIA, June 17 (Reuters) A spokesman for the United States Embassy here today deInied that Brazilian patrol boats had fired at United States vessels.

description: OTTAWA, June 17The Government reported today a record onemonth increase in jobs and a big drop in unemployment for May.

description: CHICAGO, June 17 (AP)Three teenage boys were charged today with slaying an offduty policeman, Sidney Sam, 33 years old, yesterday. The suspects, Robert Dismukes, 17, David Lee Johnson, 18, and Louis Allen, 19, all of Chicago, were charged with murder and armed robbery.

title: Advertising:

description: Some sentimentalists might be tempted to withhold official status from the United States Open golf championship that began yesterday at classic Merlon just outside of Philadelphia. title: Quake Hits Northern Chile

The seismic movement was recorded in an area between Antofagasta and Copiapo. The Ministry of Interior said it had an intensity of seven on the Richter scale, which has a maximum is 10. Provincial authorities in Antofagasta identified the dead miner as Pedro Marin at the copper mine near Catalina.

description: Officials of the Metropolitan Museum of Art will journey to the Soviet Union within the next few weeks to explore possibilities for an exchange of art exhibitions between the United States and the Soviet Union, it was learned yesterday.

description: More than half the tenants in a luxury apartment building on 239 Central Park West are withholding about $40,000 in rent in a battle with the management over maintenance.

description: WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP) In a statement prepared for the committee, George Meany, the president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, said Federal underwriting of the loan would enable Lockheed to continue work on the Tristar jumbo jet. A potential job loss estimated at 45,700 in at least 35 states was cited by the federation as its reason for endorsing the proposal.

description: WASHINGTON, Tune 17 (AP) Robert G. (Bobby) Baker, former secretary to the Senate Democratic majority, purchased a case of stolen goods taken from prominent Washington area homes by an interstate burglary ring in 1969, the Government alleged today.

description: Buzz Linhart can be called one of those unusual cases. As a singer and guitarist, he is so different from the general run as to make you wonder if he really isn't a brilliant fantasy that happened to work out.

description: To the Editor:

title: U. S. Judge Curbs Capital Counsellors
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission announced yesterday that a Federal judge had enjoined Capital Advisors, Inc., Capital Counsellors, Inc., and two men from alleged violations of the securities laws that involved losses of $2.5million.

description: While municipal politicians bicker over the budget, alarm is spreading throughout the city's community school boards. Those responsible for education cannot dodge a simple truth: reduced services to children will prove equally damaging whether they result from actual teacher layoffs or from a policy of planned attrition.

title: MRS. WILLIAM SALTER

title: Vandalism in Jacksonville Resumes as Blacks Protest
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., June 17 (UPI)The police, repelled twice by barrages of debris, armed themselves with riot equipment tonight and swept through a black residential neighborhood, dispersing crowd of 400 youths in the second night of violence here.

title: Wyman Is Renamed On a Recess Basis; Gets New Deputy
description: ALBANY, June 17In a further diminishing of the power of George K. Wyman, of the state's Commissioner of Social Services, Governor Rockefeller today announced the Commissioner's recess appointment and the setting up of the new post of executive deputy commissioner.

title: TOP CHANGES MADE AT TELEPROMPTER
description: The top management of the Teleprompter Corporation was realigned yesterday for the second time since the end of March.

title: Books of The Times
description: If the citizenry of California, where Kenneth Lamott now lives, get together to escort him out of town, it should surprise no one, least of all the author. For what he saying is that the Chamber of Commerce, Rotarian view of California is not only fakehardly any Californians live that waybut that this propaganda only obscures the frightening realities that do exist. He sees the state as the place where the strands of society are becoming unraveled. And he sees what will take its place as a technological antidemocratic construction in which men of liberal ideas will not be able to live. He is serious about the parafascist in the title. The Chamber of Commerce view, one that magazines like to phasize, complete with Technicolor photographs, is that California is an outdoor paradise and the inhabitants happy innocents in it. They spend their time surfing, skiing, driving sports cars at high speeds, opening bottles of seltzer water and generally living the good life. This view scarcely jibes with that of the author's. It is a view that disregards the great bulk of the people who simply slave away their week like unnumbered others in less favored climes.

title: A Pessimistic Outlook
description: PARIS, June 17The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said to day the rate of unemployment in the United States this year would not fall much below per cent.

title: Sato Hails New Era
description: TOKYO, June 17Foreign Minister Aichi today affixed his signature, first in bold brushstrokes and then in Western script, to the agreement to return Okinawa to Japanese rule.

title: Mack Rose Originals Files A Reorganization Petition
description: Mack Rose Originals, Inc., manufacturer of women's coats, filed a petition yesterday in Federal Court for reorganization under the Chapter XI provisions of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. The concern listed liabilities of $1,154,222 and assets of $954,258.

title: Blast Convictions Upheld
description: NEW ORLEANS, June 17 (AP)A Federal court rejected today the appeal of two men convicted of dynamiting 33 school buses in Longview, Tex., to prevent busing of Negro children to achieve integration. The Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit upheld the convictions of Fred L. Hayes and Kenneth R. McMaster in the July 4, 1970, incident.

title: Mother Guilty in Son's Death
description: A 24yearold Bronx mother pleaded guilty yesterday to criminally negligent homicide in the death of her 8monthold son who starved last year. Mrs. Edna Mae Young of 4526 Park Avenue, whose son, Mark, weighed five and a half pounds at his death, is to be sentenced in State Supreme Court on Sept. 10. She faces a maximum sentence of four years in prison.

title: Warning on Waste Disposal
description: CHICAGO, June 17 (UPI)William D. Ruckelshaus, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, said today that the nation was running out of places to dispose of waste materials. He gave the keynote address at the Seventh International Refuse Equipment Show and Congress.

title: U.F.T. AND RIVAL TO TALK MERGER
description: ALBANY, June 17The president of the State Teachers Association proposed today merger with the United Federation of Teachers, its traditional rival.

title: SAN DIEGO DOUBTFUL ON BEING G.O.P. HOST
description: SAN DIEGO, June 17The City of San Diego informed the Republican National Committee today that it might not be able to afford playing host to the party's national convention next year, even though President Nixon favors the choice.

title: Rockwell Would Junk Jet
description: Willard F. Rockwell, chairman of the North American Rockwell Corporation, confirmed yesterday that his compony would consider taking over Lockheed if it was forced into receivership. He said, however, that if his company took over Lockheed it would junk Lockheed's Tristar program.

title: MISS BACON TO FACE BOMB CHARGES HERE
description: SEATTLE, June 17 (UPI) L,eslie Bacon, tired and nervous, said today that she would be in New York City by June 30 to face a Federal charge linking her to an unsuccessful plot to bomb a Manhattan bank.

title: WILLIAM D. CONWELL
description: William D. Conwell a partner in the law firm of White & Case, 14 Walt Street, died Wednesday at his home. He was 42 years old and lived at 40 East 81st Street.

title: Advertising:
description: When Julian Cohen and Dan Aron joined a rather large luncheon group at the haughty Plaza Hotel one day a week ago, they were pretty far from, the officenot. in miles, but atmosphere.

title: Nixon Is Reported To Reverse Stand On Veto of Job Bill
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP)  The Nixon Administration has reversed itself and indicated it wants to sign a public service jobs bill into law,

title: Executive Changes
description: The Armstrong Rubber Company has elected Joseph L. Stewart, chairman; James A. Walsh, president; John H. Cordes executive vice president and treasurer, and John R. Marchiando, vice president for personnel and employee relations. As chairman, Mr. Stewart will serve as the company's chief executive officer. He joined Armstrong in 1965 as senior vice president. Mr. Walsh will be the chief operating officer. There previously was no chairman. The presidency had been open since May 28 when Frank L. Dwyer died.

description: In the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

title: Excerpts From President's Message on Drug Abuse Control
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 (UPI)Following are excerpts from President Nixon's message to Congress today proposing an emergency program to combat narcotics addiction:

title: MRS. G. GOULD LINCOLN
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 17 Mrs. Delia Hazeltine Lincoln, wife of G. Gould Lincoln, retired political editor for The Washington Star, died today at the PutnamWeaver Home at the age of 84.

title: Fate Spells Death in Venice
DR. HARRY GOLDBERG, EYE SPECIALIST, 56
description: Dr. Harry Goldberg an eye specialist, who was a cofounder and chief of the department of ophthalmology at Deepdale General Hospital Douglaston Queens died Wednesday of heart attack at the Westbury (L. I.) Club. He was 56 years old and lived 315 Willetts Road Albertson, L. I. His offices were at 8802 150th Street, Jamaica, Queens, and in Albertson.

title: Komeito Group in Peking
description: TOKYO, June 17 (UPI)A ninmember delegation representing the second largest, opposition treaty in Japan, arrived in Peking today, Hisbumba, the Chinese press agency, reported today Hsinbua reported that a 10member Iraqi economic and technical delegation also arrived in Peking today.

title: Saigon's Marines Said to Repel Attack on Outpost Near DMZ
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, June 18 (AP)Outnumbered South Vietnamese marines, helped by American jets and helicopters, reportedly beat off a North Vietnamese attack yesterday on their jungle outpost in the northwestern corner of the country.

title: Ruth Series Opens Aug. 21
description: TRENTON, June 17 (UPI)The 20th annual International Babe Ruth World Series for boys 13 to 15 years of age will begin Saturday, Aug. 21, in Albuquerque, N. M., and conclude the following Saturday.

title: Paper Gives List Identifying Material It Has
description: The Justice Department failed yesterday  at least for the present  to obtain a court order forcing The New York Times to turn over for the Government's inspection the secret Pentagon study from which the newspaper's series on the Vietnam war has been drawn.

title: Westvaco Paring Output
description: The Westvaco Corporation announced yesterday it will suspend production of bleached paperboard at its Covington, Va., mill for a week beginning July 5 to balance out its inventory of finished products.

title: Jack Robinson Jr. Dies in Car Crash
description: NORWALK, Conn., June 17  Jack R. Robinson Jr., the 24yearold son of Jackie Robinson, former star of the Brooklyn Dodgers, was killed here early this morning in an automobile accident.

title: VISTRON TO RAISE FERTILIZER PRICES
description: The Vistron Corporation, a subsidiary of the Standard Oil Company of Ohio, announced yesterday that It would raise several basic fertilizer prices on Aug. 1 and again on Feb. 1, 1972.

title: AMEX PRICES SUP IN SLOW TURNOVER
Boycott Stars for English In Test Against Pakistani
description: LONDON, June 17 (Reuters)  Geoff Boycott showed he had lost none of his flare for international cricket when he returned to the England team today with an unbeaten innings of 61 against Pakistan in the second test at Lord's.

title: Schenley Holders Back Merger Into Glen Alden
description: Shareholders of Schenley Industries, Inc., at their annual meeting in Wilmington, Del., voted yesterday to approve the merger of the company into the Glen Alden Corporation.

title: Ky Says He Didn't Miss TargetEntire North
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 17 (AP)Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky says it is untrue that he bombed the wrong target in the first reprisal strikes against North Vietnam on Feb. 8, 1966, because, he says, all of North Vietnam was a good target.

title: Freedom and Security
description: Here various news we tell, of love and strife,

title: In Apparel, Dad's Day Is 2d Noel
description: The second Christmas for the men's apparel industry arrives on Sunday, with indications that sales are firming after an extended period of lower volume.

title: Harris's 67 Leads U.S. Open by Shot
description: ARDMORE, Pa., June 17 They have been calling Merion the thinking man's course. Scholarly looking Labron Harris Jr. of Stillwater, Okla., seemed to fit the leader's role in appearance and ability.

title: Australian Leader Asks Inquiry On '65 Commitment of Troops
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Friday June 18  Prime Minister William McMahon has called for an urgent report by a highlevel committee on the circumstances under which Australia committed troops to the war in Vietnam.

title: 6 of City's Beaches Fit for Swimming; 3 Are Held Unsafe
description: Six of the city's nine beaches have been approved for swimming Dr. Mary C. McLaughlin, Commissioner of Health, announced yesterday.

title: Senate Panel Backs New Post for Otepka
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 (AP)The senate Judiciary Committee approved today President Nixon's nomination of Otto F. Otepka for a full term on the Subversive Activities Control Board.

title: Can the O.A.U. Survive?
description: The Organization of African Unity has opened a crucial series of meetings in Ethiopia with little unity evidence. Unless the foreign ministers can tap some hidden reserves of goodwill, including a willingness to compromise, the summit meeting scheduled for next week is likely to be a fiasco, with the very survival the O.A.U. in doubt.

title: Orioles Beat Yankees, 31, on Hendricks's Home Run
Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:Before Governor Rockefeller swoops down on New York City to investigate us and examine our books and records, and in the process squander a quarter of a million dollarsmost of which he collected from New York Cityhe should direct his upstate legislators to get acquainted with two important maxims in equity.

title: Books of The Times
description: Oh boy! Frank Capra An autobiography by the film director Frank Capra, who made It Happened One Night, Mr. Deeds Goes to Town, You Can't Take With You, It's a Wonderful Life and the rest of that delicious Capracorn At least I think Oh, boy! because except for periodic TV viewings of It Happened One Night (which seems to grow more charming with age and nostalgia) I last saw my favorite Capra films in the full flush of adolescence so the warm glow his name evokes may be a vestige. But sure enough I begin The Name Above the Title and there it is againthat old sentimental magic. Take a dirtpoor Sicilian peasant kid fresh out of steerage. Make him scrappy and streetwise Give him an abiding love for his mother and determination to get educated. Send him to Caltech; graduate him with honors and the prospect of a brilliant future as chemical engineer Bring on World War postwar unemployment. Make the young man penniless and sick, but have him turn down a $20,000 offer to build stills for a bootlegger. Wander him into a movie studio, put his eye to a camera, and see him get the doggonedest attack of goose pimplesand thrills that shook me from head to foot. Propel him upward, and get ready for a fortyfiveyear ride on the magic carpet of Film!

title: Engine Failure Is Reported On Soviet SST in Warsaw
description: WARSAW, June 17 (UPI)The Soviet TU144 supersonic transport, returning from the Paris Air Show made an emergency landing at the Warsaw's airport today with engine failure, airport sources said.

title: BONDPRICE RALLY SPURRED BY SALES
F.C.C. Finds Democrats Spent Most for Radio and TV Ads in'70
description: WASHINGTON, June 17The Democrats outspent the Republicans for radio and television advertising in the 1970 political campaign by about $4million the Federal Communications Commission reported today.

title: Integration Table
Ulbricht Is Stricken With Circulatory Disturbance
description: BERLIN, June 17The East German press agency reported today that President Walter Ulbricht suffered an acute circulatory disturbance late Monday and had been confined to bed.

title: J. L. LEWTHWAITE, 87 OF MACHINE CONCERN,
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 17Jerome L, Lewthwaite, president for the last 18 years of the T. H. Lewthwaite Machine Company, a machinetool builder of 311 East 47th Street, New York, died yesterday at his home. He was 87 years old and lived at 13 Bar Beach Road,

title: Vatican Sets Guidelines On Religious Instructions
description: ROME, June 17  The Vatican today issued new guidelines for the religious instruction of Roman Catholics.

title: List of Road Bottlenecks,
description: Hawthorne Traffic Circle in Westchester County major reconstruction at the interchange of the Saw Mill River, Bronx River and Taconic Parkways.

title: Laver Upset by Gorman in London Tourney
description: LONDON June 17With Wimbledon four days away the No. 1 seeded star, fourtime winner and shortprice favorite Rod Laver was beaten today by Thomas Warner Gorman of Seattle in the quarterfinals of the London grass court championship at Queens Club.

title: BigBand Fete ReCreates Old Sound
description: Nostalgia ran rampant through Madison Square Garden Wednesday night at a Big Band Festival that brought together four bands and three singers who made their reputations during the bigband era.

title: F.B.I. Continues Investigation 0f How Times Got Documents
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation in Washington said yesterday that it was continuing its investigation to determine how The New York Times obtained a copy of the secret Pentagon study on Vietnam.

title: ENGLE IS ELECTED TO NEW MUSIC POST
description: Donald L. Engle, director of the Martha Baird Rockefeller Fund for Music, hasbeen elected president of the Minnesota Orchestral Association effective Sept. 1. He will be the first fulltime professional president in the history of the 68yearold orchestra, which was known as the Minneapolis Symphony until 1968.

title: Connecticut G.I. Dies
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 (UPI) The Defense Department said today that Specialist 5 Anthony A. Price of Milford, Conn., of the Army, had died of wounds received in action in Southeast Asia.

title: Miss Robbins Marries on L.I.
description: ROSLYN, L.I., June 17Miss Elizabeth Jane Robbins and Andrew Crystal of New York were married here this evening in Temple Sinai by Rabbi Norman Kahan. Rabbi Avram Goodman and Cantor Norman Belink assisted.

title: James L. Ferguson Dead at 70; Led Newspaper Representatives
description: James Larnard Ferguson chairman of the board of the Sawyer Ferguson Walker Company, newspaper representatives 245 Park Avenue died yesterday afternoon in Roosevelt Hospital after an illness of two months. He was 70 years old and lived at 41 Ludlow Road Westport, Conn.

title: Susan Sennet's Nuptials
description: GREAT NECK, L. I., June 17Miss Susan Jane Sennet daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chester Sennet was married here this evening to Mark Edward Lachtman son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Lachtman of San Francisco. Rabbis Jacob Philip Rudin and Jack Stern Jr. performed the ceremony at Temple Beth El.

title: HiC Fruit Drinks Contain From 1% to 30% Juice
description: WASHINGTON, June 17The fruit juice content of various HiC beverages ranges from 1 per cent to 30 per cent, according to information supplied to Mrs. Virginia Knauer President Nixon's special assistant for consumer affairs.

title: One Study Participant Sees No Security Harm
description: TRENTON, June 18 (AP)A Princeton University educator said today that he had played a small part in the preparation of the secret Pentagon papers and that he knew of nothing In the classified study that would harm the nation's security.

title: DR. CHARLES RANK, EDUCATION AIDE
description: Dr, Charles F. Rank, former president of the New York city Board of Education, died yesterday of a coronary attack at his home. He was 80 years old and lived at 6070 Woodbine Street, Ridgewood, Queens.

title: U.S. Orders Atlanta Plan in Building
description: ATLANTA, June 18  Assistant Secretary of Labor An.. thur A. Fletcher announced today the immediate implementation of an Atlanta Plan that is aimed at bringing more black workers into the higherpaying areas of the construction trades in metropolitan Atlanta.

title: Study Said to Show Diem Barred Vote
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP)The Washington Post said today that a Pentagon study asserts there was no connivance in 1955 between the United States and the Saigon Government to prevent the elections throughout North and South Vietnam that had been agreed upon by the 1954 Geneva Conference.

title: BUDGET MEETING ENDS IN DISCORD
description: A 90minute summit meeting at City Hall yesterday failed to produce any agreement on Mayor Lindsay's proposed $8.8billion city expense budget and its accompanying $525million tax package.

title: Japan Air Lines Appoints
description: Yoshiro Fuse has been named vice president for North and South America for Japan Air Lines, He succeeds Shigeo Kameda, who was made managing director and vice president of sales and will move to the home office in Tokyo.

title: Testing to Start Tomorrow
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 18The urinalysis tests on all soldiers and officers, male and female, will begin Sunday, the United States Command announced today.

title: Colbert and Erickson Share U. S. Open Lead By Shot Over McGee With 138's
description: ARDMORE, Pa., June 18Jim Colbert and Bob Erickson unexpectedly became the co. leaders at the halfway mark in the United States Open golf championship today as Jack Nicklaus criticized pin placements and Arnold Palmer called the slow play unfair.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, June 18 The press is no more perfect than any other institution. Newspapers can be vulgar or silly or craven; they can cry freedom of the press when nothing is at stake but their desire to sensationalize for profit.

title: East German Premier Reports Failures in Industry Last Year
description: BERLIN, June 18Premier Willi Stoph of East Germany, in a report to the Eighth Congress of the ruling Communist party, reviewed today some of the nation's economic difficulties last year.

title: Sports of The Times
description: At 6:45 each morning, the jockey agent starts his day Selling. Look, here's one of the greatest jockeys in Venezuela, he tells the trainer. How about giving him a chance?

title: Defense Presses U.S. Witness In Corruption Trial in Jersey
description: NEWARK, June 18  Frank G. Maiming, the former Hudson County engineer who is the Government's principal witness in the Jersey CityHudson County corruption trial in Federal Court here, resisted defense efforts today to reduce his credulity and to reduce doubts about his insistence that he was a reluctant and unhappy bag man for John V. Kenny.

title: Frei Asks Allende to Ban Armed Groups
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, June 18 Eduardo Frei Montalva, the Christian Democratic leader and former President, said today that the disbanding of all armed groups by the Chilean Government was necessary to achieve political stability here.

title: Jury Rules Against Finley
description: OAKLAND, June 18 (UP1)A jury today awarded William Cutler; the owner of the Portland Beavers, $13,500 damages in a suit against Charles O. Finley of the Oakland Athletics. However, the judge in the case indicated he would reverse the jury verdict and give Cutler nothing. Cutler brought the suit against Finley in May, 1969, when he was dismissed. He claimed he was owed $100,500 on a contract With Finley.

title: ACCOUNTING CLAIM PAID TO EXCHANGE
description: The New York Stock Exchange apparently has decided to extend the scope of liability for some of last year's memberfirm collapses to the public accounting field.

title: Cambodian Town Attacked
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 18 (Reuters)Vietcong troops attacked a Government position near the crossroad town of Srang this morning, killing two Cambodian soldiers and wounding 11, a Cambodian spokesman announced.

title: Bauxite Group Weighed
description: TOKYO, June 18 (Reuters)Eight companies from four countries, including American Metal Climax, Inc., and the Anaconda Company from the United States, have concluded a provisional agreement to form a consortium for the $366million Kimberley bauxite mine project in Western Australia, it was announced here today.

title: MERGER PLANNED BY U.S. FINANCIAL
description: U.S. Financial announced yesterday it had agreed in principle to acquire CoBuild Companies, Inc., a builder of lowand moderatepriced single family and multifamily housing in the Virgin Islands and New Jersey, through an exchange of stock valued at about $45.5million. Under the agreement, U.S. Financial will exchange 44 shares of its common stock for each 100 shares of CoBuild, which as of March 31, had 1,866,940 shares outstanding. U.S. Financial closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at 55, down 1 points.

title: Soviet Official Terms SST No Peril to Environment
description: MOSCOW, dune 18A ranking Soviet aviation official defended today the importance of the supersonic transport plane and said American concern about possible environmental and health problems from such aircraft was unfounded.

title: Barend Biesheuvel Named New Netherlands Premier
description: THE HAGUE, June 18 (AP)  Barend W. Biesheuvel, a former Deputy Premier and Minister of Agriculture, was named to as Premier of the Netherlands, ending seven weeks of negotiations.

title: Muskie Gathers Campaign Staff
description: WASHINGTON, June 18The political staff for Senator Edmund S. Muskie's Presidential campaign is taking shape after a long period of disorganization and internal conflict. Under John F. English, the Democratic National Committeeman from New York, who is in overall charge, will be a group of about six key operatives. Among them are George Mitchell, the National Committeeman from Maine; Tony Podesta and James Johnson, veterans of Eugene J. McCarthy's 1968 campaign; James Hall, from the staff of former Senator Albert Gore of Tennessee and Hugh H. Smith Jr., a staff member of the Senate Banking Committee.

title: THE TIMES SERIES STILL HELD UP PENDING COURT RULING TODAY;
description: Federal District Judge Murray I. Gurfein refused yesterday to permit The New York Times to resume publication immediately of its material from a secret Pentagon study on Vietnam although The Washington Post began publishing a series of articles based on the study in its Friday issue.

title: Mt. Pleasant Fights Plan to Construct 1,000 Housing Units
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 18 (AP) A plan to build 1,000 housing units for students and employes of a proposed medical center in Mount Pleasant was announced today by the Urban Development Corporation.

title: Orioles Win, 64, on Yankee Errors
description: BALTIMORE, June 18The New York Yankees lost a fourrun lead tonight in Memorial Stadium, lost the game to the Baltimore Orioles, 64, on four unearned runs, lost Thurman Munson in a terrific crash at the plate and lost Roy White with a pulled hamstring in his right leg.

title: HERBERT WEINER, 45, OF ACCOUNTING FIRM
description: Herbert Weiner, a partner of Touche Ross & Co., public accountants of 1345 Avenue of the Americas, died yesterday of leukemia at the New Rochelle Medical Center, He was 45 years old and lived at 65 Catherine Road, Scarsdale, N. Y.

title: Secrets and Security
description: No historian regards the present situation regarding access to American archival materials from the World War II period to the present as satisfactory. The chief villain usually cited is, the State Department; but I hasten to add that not all scholars agree on the source of their troubles. Since most diplomatic historians working in this area sooner or later (generally sooner) seek out State Department records, the brunt of criticism has fallen on that agency. In my opinion, deservedly so.

description: To the Editor:
