description: To the Editor:

title: Bronfmans Offer Rheingold Shares
description: The Bronfman family, whose members head the vast Seagrani whisky interests, is selling most of the shares of the common stock it holds in the Rheingold Corporation. A form, S1, was filed yesterday in this connection with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Gain in Power by LeRoi Jones Shown in Newark Poverty Vote
description: NEWARK, June 18The first reported attempt by Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson to prevent LeRoi Jones from increasing his power here has been defeated in an antipoverty election that promises to have profound political repercussions.

title: JAPANESE PONDER TRADE IMBALANCE
description: WASHINGTON, June 18A highlevel Japanese business delegation agreed today to convey to businessmen and Government leaders in Japan the sense of urgency expressed by their United States counterparts that Japan must act massively to reduce the large and growing trade imbalance between the two countries.

title: Rockefeller Signs Bill Doubling Names Needed on Vote Petitions
description: ALBANY, June 18Changes in the state election law requiring generally a doubling of the number of petition signatures to put a candidate on the ballot have been signed into law by Governor Rockefeller.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: RENT DECONTROLS FACE SUIT BY CITY
description: The city will move within 10 days in State Supreme Court to block the new state law decontrolling rents on apartments as they become vacant, Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday.

title: FINDINGS UPHELD ON TEXAS GULF
description: WASHINGTON, June 18In a new decision in the Texas Gulf Sulphur case, the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit has upheld the bulk of the district court's decision imposing penalties on officers and employes on the basis of inside information.

title: Roundup: Indians Win a Wild One, 70
description: Chris Chambliss had his best game in the major leagues last night, but the spotlight was not all his.

title: Merion Pins Cause a Nicklaus Outcry
description: ARDMORE, Pa., June 18 With the same forcefulness that characterizes his style as a golfer, Jack Nicklaus criticized today one of the most subtle aspects of every United States Openthe placement of the cup on each green.

title: Appeals Court Decision
description: WASHINGTON, Saturday, June 19Following is the text of the decision by three judges of the District of Columbia Circuit Court of Appeals, overruling a lower Federal court decision and ordering The Washington Post of halt publication of a series of articles on the roots of the Vietnam war:

title: Nixon Sees 30% ax Cut In RevenueSharing Plan
description: ROCHESTER, June 18President Nixon, in another regional conference designed to arouse support for his domestic programs, today called his proposal for revenue sharing the only hope for reducing local property taxes.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: F.T.C. Head Warns Advertisers on SelfRegulation
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 Miles W. Kirkpatrick, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, warned advertisers today against assuming that they could escape Federa by a program of tion.

title: market Place: Brilund Mines Gives a Report
description: You remember Brilund Mines. The company has been seeking mineral wealth in SouthWest Africa for some time now and its annual report is in the form of a progress statement.

title: Young America: Pouring Into London
description: LONDON, June 15Like most of the 1,000 hotels, guesthouses and hostels in London, the King George VI Memorial Hostel was unusually busy this morning.

title: Italian Leaders Trying to Bolster Coalition After NeoFascist Gain
description: ROME, June 18Leaders of Italy's centerleft coalition have been conferring this week on ways to strengthen their alliance in the wake of the gains made by neoFascists in local elections this week.

title: Albert Muller Dead at 74; ExOfficial of Bankers Trust
description: Albert Muller, a former vice president of Bankers Trust Company, died Thursday in Green Village N. J., where he lived. He was 74 years old.

title: Apollo 15 Spacecraft Named Endeavor and Falcon
description: HOUSTON, June 18 (UPI) The Apollo 15 astronauts today named their command ship Endeavor and their moonlanding craft Falcon.

title: GENTRY 2HITTER BEATS PHILS, 20
description: Ken Singleton provided the righthanded hitting power and Gary Gentry the righthanded pitching power as the New York Mets went right on with their winning ways against lefthanded pitching by defeating the Philadelphia Phillies, 20, before a crowd of 45,428 last night at Shea Stadium.

title: Arthur V. Lewis, 75, Is Dead; A Partner in Lewis &
description: Arthur Vaughan Lewis, a retired vice president and partner in. Lewis & Conger, a former housewares firm at the southeast corner of Avenue of the Americas and 45th Street, died Wednesday in Boston, after a short illness. He was 75 years old and had lived in Camden, Me., since his re. tirement 15 years ago.

title: OTB Hopes to Accept Belmont Bets Monday
description: The city's Offtrack Betting Corporation remained hopeful last night it could begin accepting bets next Monday on thoroughbred races at Belmont Park.

title: The Pearse Motel, Play About Ireland, Is Staged in London
description: LONDON. June 18Hugh Leonard's The Patrick Pearse Motel at the Queen's Theater picks up the threads from John Bull's Other Island by showing Ireland exploiting its national relics to bolster the tourist trade: the difference being that where Shaw prophesied an invasion of British developers, Mr. Leonard portrays the Irish as fully capable of Americanizing their country without any help from outside.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Press Weekly and Guild Score Censorship Effort
description: Editor & Publisher, the newspaper industry's weekly trade magazine, said in an editorial yesterday that the attempt of the Nixon Administration to suppress publication by The New York Times of a Pentagonprepared digest about the origins and developments of the Vietnam war is an assault on the freedoms of the American people and an affront to their intelligence.

title: CREDITORS PROPOSE HELP FOR SHEFFIELD
description: Trade creditors holding $1.5million of $2million in outstanding trade debts have recommended that the Sheffield Watch Corporation, currently in bankruptcy proceedings, be given a 90day moratorium to get its affairs in order.

title: M'GHEE BAND GIVES SWINGING PROGRAM
description: When a big jazz band is both loose and togethertight and precise in Its ensemble playing but free and easy in its attack the result is apt to be an unusually swinging performance. The 13piece band that Howard McGhee brought to the Jazz Center, 57 West 57th Street, yesterday afternoon, offered some brilliant examples of this kind of swinging.

title: 3Way Tie In Women's Golf
description: SOUTHBURY, Conn., June 18 (AP)Kathy Whitworth, shooting for a recordtying fourth straight L.P.G.A. tournament victory, shot a threeunderpar 70 today to tie with Sandra Spuzich and Kathy Farrer for the firstround lead in the Heritage open.

title: Navy, Cornell and Brown Crews Qualify in Repechage for I. R. A. Final
description: SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 18The varsity crews from Navy, Cornell and Brown qualified today for tomorrow's final of the intercollegiate rowing championships, joining Washington, Pennsylvania and Rutgers.

title: Japan Presses Yen Program
description: TOKYO, June 18 (Reuters)The Japanese Cabinet's council of economic ministers decided today to step up the implementation of the eightpoint program adopted June 4 to avert growing pressure for an upward revaluation of the yen, Cabinet spokesmen said today. The eight points are import liberalization, preferential tariffs to the developing nations, tariff cuts, capital liberalization, removal of nontariff barriers, promotion of economic cooperation, normalization of exports and flexible manipulation of fiscal and monetary policies.

title: Sky Marshal Foils Hijacking Attempt At Carolina Airport
description: WINSTONSALEM, N. C., June 18 (UPI)A Federal sky marshal disguised as a pilot subdued a Tennessee man aboard a Piedmont Airlines jet today, thwarting an attempt to hijack the plane to Cuba.

title: Unit Combing City To Ferret Out VD.
description: Ninetytwo young men and women are spending most of their days and a good part of their nights searching for names on mailboxes, knocking on the doors of ratinfested tenements, scrutinizing the clientele in gin mills, brothels, private clubs and steam baths, meeting people surreptitiously in cars, bars, hallways and public toilets.

title: SENATOR MORANINO, ITALIAN RED, WAS 51
description: ROME, June 18Francesco Moranino, Communist Senator and controversial figure of the Italian Resistance, died early this morning at Grugliasco near Turin, at the age of 51.

title: DAYAN SAYS CHANCES OF BATTLE INCREASE
description: TEL AVIV, June 18Defense Minister Moshe Dayan said today the likelihood of renewed fighting on the Suez Canal front had increased sharply. He said he believed renewal of hostilities in the next few months could be avoided only if there was political progress, such as negotiations for a partial settlement, or another domestic crisis in Egypt resulting in another round of purges.

title: Rain Halts Cricket Test
Florida Guard Put on Alert After Jacksonville Unrest
description: JACKSONVILLE Fla., June 18 (UPI)Gov. Reuhin Askew ordered about 500 Florida National Guardsmen placed on standby alert late today after two nights of racial unrest in black neighborhoods.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Nixous in Florida
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., June 18 (Reuters)President and Mrs. Nixon arrived here tonight for a long weekend at his Florida home. They will celebrate their 31st wedding anniversary here Monday.

title: DC10 FINANCING SET BY CONTINENTAL AIR
description: Continental Airlines announced yesterday it had arranged a $125million financing program for its acquisition of a fleet of eight McDonnell Douglas DC10 trijet aircraft on which it expects to begin taking delivery next spring.

title: Exposing the Hidden War
description: It may be debatable whether the Nixon Administration has violated the letter of a 1970 amendment barring the use of defense funds to finance free world forces fighting for the Government of Laos, as Senator Fulbright, author of the amendment, and other Senators have charged. The amendment contained a rather large loophole specifying that it should not bar the President from taking actions needed to insure the safe and orderly withdrawal or disengagement of U.S. forces from Southeast Asia, or to aid in the release of Americans held as prisoners of war.

title: Excerpts From Arguments in U.S. Case Against Times Over Vietnam Documents
description: ALEXANDER M. BICKEL, for The TimesYour Honor, the new matter I wish to bring to your attention came to our attention first thing this morning. The Washington Post has begun publication, under a headline, and I will go into that in a moment more thoroughly, 'Documents Reveal U. S. Effort in 54 to Delay ?? Election, heavily quoting from the same documents that The New York Times is alleged to possess, and the publication proceeds from portions of those documents which The New York Times has not yet published. It is the first in a series.

title: MURPHY ADVANCES IN AMATEUR GOLF
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., June 18 Bob Murphy, the 22yearold defending champion, whacked a No. 7 iron shot over a row of 60foot oak trees to get a birdie 3 at the 18th hole today and reached the quarterfinal) round of the 48th Long Island amateur golf tournament at Garden City Country Club.

title: Instant Urban Renewal
description: The flames dance high as heat bites into old woodwork, searing and twisting the wooden frame until it gives in floor by floor, wall by wall. Condemned to death by the living, the abandoned building on East 4th Street burns madly. A couple of Molotov cocktails carefully ignited and carelessly thrown light up the block as hundreds of local residents mill about, singing and dancing, having a good time. An impromptu block party. In their smiling faces can be seen the last power left to poor people. Fire power.

title: Screen: Affinity for Rats:Davison Plays Lead in Horror Film 'Willard'
description: Willard, says a close friend of his mother, who has made him the man he isn't today, "is basically an extrovert, but it's all inside." Willard is 27 years old, a thumb-biter in moments of crisis, the sort of fumbling, neurotic mess whom anonymous bus drivers delight in humiliating. He lives with his dotty old mum (Elsa Lanchester), works for the man (Ernest Borgnine) who took away his late father's business and seethes with undisciplined hatred until, one day, he discovers his gift for communicating with rats."Willard," which opened yesterday at the Penthouse Theater, attempts to be the kind of horror film that allows us to share the satisfaction of Willard's revenge, as he goes around the neighborhood letting his rats run opportunely loose, while simultaneously sharingwith pleasurethe terror of his victims.The movie, however, persists in crossing its lines of stimulation, resulting in a series of little short-circuits that effectively limit pleasure to an occasional line or bit of business. It is quite funny, and sad, for example, when old Mum reduces Willard to the status of a souvenir that she can't, in good conscience, throw away. "The only evidence of my struggle with the world is you," she says in one of those rare moments of introspection when her thoughts aren't concerned with the broken television set.The problem is in the writing (by Gilbert A. Ralston) and in the direction (by Daniel Mann), which tries to find horror in a cheerful, sunny, everyday environment and finds nothing more than a cheerful, sunny, everyday environment. The only halfway interesting characters are the people the movie means us to hatethe rude, penny-pinching boss, played by Borgnine, and a maniacally nosy neighbor, played by Jody Gilbert.Then, too, the rats, whom we get to knowsuperficially, anyway  as Wilbur trains them, seem not so voracious as the people they must eventually attack. They are no more scary than fat, friendly hamsters, except for one or two shots when they are seen by the hundredsand hundreds of anything might be a scary sight, even hundreds of bishops. I, for one, tend to sympathize with the rats as Willard directs them with the same sort of ultimatums as Borgnine has been directing at him.Instead of playing on our fears of rats, by keeping them at a mysterious distance, in a different metaphysical dimension, as Hitchcock did in his "Birds," Mann and Ralston anthropomorphize the rats to such a convincing extent that they become little furry people whom society, especially Willard, has badly used. In this respect, "Willard," which is otherwise a dull movie of no major consequence, is a rather astonishing footnote to a major urban problem.

title: MISS REDGRAVE WAITS FOR VISA
description: Vanessa Redgrave, the English actress, wants to come to the United States to discuss the writing of her autobiography and to talk about a possible motion picture, but for three months she has been unable to get a visa.

title: Kent State Freshman Sets N. C. A. A. Hammer Mark
description: SEATTLE, June 18A Frenchman who fell in love with Kent, Ohio, a decathlete who improved his high jump by watching The Tonight Show, and a longjumper who bounces in name and number highlighted a rainy second day of the National Collegiate outdoor track and field championships today.

title: Notes on People
description: The unflappability of former Prime Minister Harold Wilson showed signs of flapping yesterday, as he conferred with his lawyers in London to determine what should be done about what he thinks the British Broadcasting Corporation might have done to him.

title: Helen Canning Young, Led Westchester Welfare Unit
description: SOMERS, N.Y., June 18Mrs. Helen Canning Young, who retired in 1958 as director of the Westchester Department of Family and Child Welfare, died yesterday in a nursing home here. She was 80 years cad and formerly lived in Mount Kisco.

title: Two Given 3Year Terms In Girl's Death From Drugs
description: Two men who pleaded guilty to negligent homicide in the drugrelated death of a Barnard College freshman more than year ago were sentenced yesterday to three years in state prison.

title: Tentative Pact Is Reached In Yale Maintenance Strike
description: NEW HAVEN, June 18A sevenweekold strike by Yale University service and maintenance workers appeared drawing to an end today, as agreement was reached on a new contract for Local 35 of the Federation of University Employes.

title: DECEIT FAVORED IN TODAY'S OAKS
description: Deceit of the Windfield Farms is the favorite to take the Coaching Club American Oaks at Belmont Park today and win the New York Racing Association's triple crown for 3yearold fillies. The winner of the $131,625 race will earn $78,975.

title: U. S. Weighed Moves to Halt The Times Series Within Hours of First Publication
description: WASHINGTON, June 17 Within hours after The New York Times published secret Pentagon documents Sunday, Attorney General John N. Mitchell and Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird began discussing possible attempts to stop the articles.

title: U. of California Radiation Labs Aiding A.E.C. Are Realigned
description: LOS ANGELES, June 18The regents of the University of California administratively, rearranged today the research laboratories where university employes work on contracts for the Atomic Energy Commission.

title: AXELROD OUSTED IN TITLE FENCING
description: BERKELEY, Calif., June 18 (AP)Upsets marked the first day of the United States Fencing championships on the University of California campus.

title: Oklahoma Mayor Drowns
description: ST. ELMO, Colo., June 18 (UPI),Wilson J. Bentley, 55 years old, the Mayor of Still water, Okla., drowned in creek near here while fishing, the Chaffee County sheriff's office said today. Bob Willcox, sheriff's deputy, said Mr. Bent, ley's wife, Eva, had told him, that Mr. Bentley was fishing', in the creek yesterday and fell into the swift waters. She said she tried to reach him, but failed.

title: COMMODITY PRICES. LISTED IN THE WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 Daily index numbers and spot primary market commodity prides June 8, 1971 to June 15, 1971.

title: Boise Cascade Will Take An Extraordinary Charge
description: The Boise Cascade Corporation, producer of building materials and paper products and also engaged in land development, homebuilding, mobile and modular homes, Is continuing to have operating problems and will take a nonrecurring extraordinary charge of $78million, before taxes, in the second quarter this year.

title: Shelter Island Seeking a Doctor
description: SHELTER ISLAND, L. I., June 18Dr. George M. Stroll, Shelter Island's only physician, is 71 years old. Every morning for the last 10 years he has climbed into his car to make the rounds of the sick and infirm he cares for all alone on this island of 1,500 yearround residents and 5,500 summer visitors.

title: Three Attend Miss Susskind In Bridal Here
description: St. James Chapel of the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine was the setting here yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Constance Davidson Susskind to Keeler George Thompson. The Rev. Richard R. Kirk performed the ceremony.

title: Nixon's Drug Control Plan introduced Into Congress
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 The Administration introduced into Congress today legislation to authorize President Nixon's $155million program for control of drug addiction.

title: Canada Plans Wide Tax Relief, Removing a Million From Rolls
description: OTTAWA, June 18 The Government submitted to Parliament today sweeping tax reform legislation that would remove one million persons from the tax rolls, cut taxes for 4.7 million and impose capital gains taxes in Canada for the first time.

title: Budget Sophistry: Albany Style
description: Tucked away in the fine print of the fiscal authority that New York City's absentee landlords in Albany gave Mayor Lindsay to help balance the municipal budget a perfect example of the sophistry that characterized the whole operation.

title: BrazilYugoslavia Deal
description: BRASILIA, June 18 (UPI)Brazil and Yugoslavia announced today a multimilliondollar swap deal involving railroad cars and coffee. Brazil has agreed to buy 1,750 railroad cars for $40millioa while Yugoslavia will receive $56million in coffee in return, the announcement said. The railroad cars, to be partially built and assembled in Brazil, are to be used to haul petroleum derivatives, minerals and grains. They are part of a $100million Government railroad expansion plan, the announcement said.

title: Meteor Findings Back Theory Of Extraterrestrial Life Origin
description: Analysis of a meteorite that fell in Kentucky has disclosed the same mixture of 18 chemical building blocks of life found earlier in a meteorite that fell in Australia.

title: HARVARD PRESENTS HONORARY DEGREES
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 18 Harvard University, in its commencement exercises yesterday, awarded honorary degrees to 12 persons, as follows:

title: Pirated Book Stand Protected
description: WASHINGTON, June 18Mrs. Corinne McGrady of Northport, L, I., who organized a public protest last summer against a New York concern she accused of pirating her design for a transparent cookbook stand, was granted protection for it this week. She was awarded Design Patent 220,911, with a term of 14 years. Mrs. McGrady and other designers of modern furnishings picketed the Dione Lucas Gourmet Center last July. Since then, she said this week, two other New York companies and reportedly one in Texas have made unauthorized copies.

title: Patrolman Is Fined $1,000
description: A Bronx Patrolman, Carmello Zumatto, who had pleaded guilty to lying to a grand jury investigating gambling payoffs was given a probationary sentence yesterday and fined $1,000 by Supreme Court Justice William Kapelman. He was accused of lying to a Bronx grand jury in November, 1968, about a gambling raid he and other policemen made in the Bronx on Dec. 24, 1966.

title: MAIL THIEF OFFERS DEAL TO TELL ALL
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (UPI)A nervous young convict surprised Senate investigators today by promising to tell all he knows about, a New York mail theft ring with crime syndicate ties if he is granted court immunity from prosecution,

title: TV Review
description: Is anyone still interested in a rock concert? Ever since Altamont, the rock market has gone queasy. The Maysles brothers fine doctImentary of that Rolling Stones fiasco didn't  help matters  much. And. now that Bill Graham has decided to pull his two Fillmores from the scene, a scene that the feisty impresario from the Bronx insists has gone fatally rotten, the future is undeniably bleak.

title: SOYBEAN FUTURES ADVANCE IN PRICE
description: After declining early in the session on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday, soybean futures prices rallied under, new buying and closed higher.

title: Splendid November' Stars Lollobrigida
description: Shocked that his still attractive widowed mother desires other men, 17-year-old Nino Paolo Turco), turns his affections to his aunt Cettina (Gina Lollobrigida). Shocked that Cettina also desires other men, including her own husband, he marries his rich pretty young cousinan act of pique that is both a cynical acquiesence in the world's preference for money lust over all other kinds of lust, and also a way of leaving Cettina in the lurch with only her husband and her lovers for consolation.There you have the beginning and the middle and the end of Mauro Bolognini's "That Splendid November," a movie that you may not want to see, now that I've spoiled the suspense.Actually, "That Splendid November" displays a certain quota of dj vu without any help from me. Its faces are out of Fellini; its attitudes, out of Bellochio; its Sicilian locale, out of "L'Avventura" (also Gabriele Ferzetti, still an architect, and still selling his soul for a mess of pottage); its rabbit hunt, out of "Rules of the Game;" and its story, theme and several crucial camera angles, out of "Before the Revolution."With so much going for it or, more accurately, going along behind it, one might expect a certain stylistic knowledgeability in "That Splendid November." But Bolognini ("La Notte Brava," "La Viaccia," etc.), who often makes fancy movies rarely makes good ones, and the enterprise this time leads to cluttered stylistics without much knowledge.Miss Lollobrigida seems wrong for her part not because she is too old (she isn'tquite), but because she is too nervously bright and eager. She brings to her role a kind of infinitely monotonous vivacity that suggests neither seductiveness nor doomwhich, I take it, is what her part should be all about.But it is difficult to discuss performance when everybody has been dubbed into a language resembling English but in fact only spoken in Dubbing Land, where the phonetic laws demand that the sounds never match the lip movements and the speech rhythms never achieve expressiveness.This language fills "That Splendid November" with phrases like "Well, well! Ahem! Yes, yes!"  which takes time, means nothing and may cover anything from untranslatable imprecations to the sonnets of Petrarch.

title: Jersey Youth, 17, Gets Perfect 800 In 6 College Boards
description: EATONTOWN, N. J., June 18 What does a 17yearold :do when he scores a perfect 800 on six College Board examinations?Well, Nicholas Cataldo Jr., who achieved such a record, is planning on entering Harvard next fallas something between a sophomore and a junior. I want to take a lot of everything, I want to know lot about everything, he said.

title: INTEREST STIRRED ON SOVIET PLANT
description: The State Department said yesterday that at least two United States companies, besides Mack Trucks, Inc., were interested in participating in the development of the Soviet Union's $1.4billion Kama River truck plant

title: Soviet Stand on Solzhenitsyn Awaited
description: MOSCOW, June 18  With the Congress of Soviet Writers set to open in 11 days, many intellectuals here are curious whether authorities will react to the publication abroad of Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn's new novel and its simultaneous appearance in Moscow in typewritten copies.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Sunbeam Corporation annouced yesterday at its annual meeting in Chicago that it plans to name R. P. Gwinn, who is currently president and chief executive officer, to the chairman's post. W. J. Pfeif, former executive vice president and president of Sunbeam's international division, is scheduled to be elected president and chief operating officer.

title: Art: Metropolitan's Florentine Painting Collection
description: The Metropolitan Museum has just issued a new catalogue of its entire collection of Florentine paintings, from a Madonna and Child by Berlinghiero (active by 1228, dead by 1242, and the earliest Italian painter known by name) on throughoh, Giotto, Fra Angelico, Botticelli, names like that  to Cesare Dandini (born 1596; died 1656). In celebration, the total collection, probably the largest single group of Florentine paintings outside Florence, including those in poor condition or of little importance and usually kept in storage, has been hung in chronological order.

title: TEXTILE WORKERS PARADE IN KOREA
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 18About 3,000 textile industry leaders and workers staged, a rally here today, opposing, any restrictions on South Koroan exports of manmade and wool textile goods to the United States. American and Korean officials continued negotiations on the issue.

title: Miss Conna Adios, $7.60, Takes Cardigan Bay Pace for 7th Straight
Wisconsin Names Perrin
description: MADISON, Wis., June 18 (AP) William E. Perrin, the University of Wisconsin assistant track coach, was named today to succeed Bob Brennan as head coach.

title: Polish Party Tells of Leaders'
description: WARSAW, June 18An official Communist party report on last December's foodprice riots. provides a dramatic account of the confusion within the party leadership the day the fighting began in Gdansk stated briefly by Mr. Giereki and other party leaders at the, lime, that a demonstration by port workers with legitimate grievances was mishandled by party leaders in Warsaw.

title: Oil Men Assay Venezuelan Bill
description: The international oil industry, still recovering from the buffeting it took from the producing countries in the negotiations in Teheran and Tripoli earlier this year, is in the midst of another crisis.

title: Ousted Jersey Prosecutor Enters Plea of Not Guilty
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., June IS (UPI)Robert Dilts, the ousted Bergen County Prosecutor, pleaded not guilty here today to charges of conspiracy, misconduct in office, obstructing justice and bribery.

title: Grounded Tanker Freed
description: SOUTHPORT, N.C., June 18 (AP)Tugboats pulled free a Greek registry tanker today more than 15 hours after the vessel ran aground just off North Carolina's southeast coast while carrying a load of crude oil. The 615foot tanker Demosthenes V, bound for Wilmington, 30 miles up the coast, ran aground about 10 P.M. Thursday. The Coast Guard had expressed concern over possible oil spillage, but none was reported.

title: Chile Alleges Kennecott And Anaconda Owe Taxes
description: The Government of Chile alleged yesterday in Santiago that the Aanaconda Company and the Kennecott Copper Corporation, the two principal mining concerns in the South American nation, were in arrears in taxes totaling about $100million.

title: Brandywine Museum Honors 3 Wyeths With Display
description: CHADDS FORD, Pa., June 18  This village on the Brandywine River, is known not only for its luxuriant natural beauties but also especially as the home of Andrew Wyeth, the artist, and his family. Now admirers of the environment and the art of Mr. Wyeth and his clan will be able to enjoy both at the same time.

title: July House Hearing Set
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (Reuters)  Representative Wright Patman, chairman of the House Banking and Currency Committee, announced today that his panel would open hearings ,on July 8 on the Administration's proposal to aid Lockheed,. He said he gave the goahead for the hearings after receiving from the Treasury Department, Defense Department information analyzing Lockheed's finances.

title: Met's Kathryn Long Singers Give Betty, Donizetti Opera
description: Since this year's Tully Hall Sampler series has not occasioned much critical rejoicing, it is agreeable to report that the concert given Thursday night by the Kathryn Long Singers of the Metropolitan Opera was a rewarding event.

title: Kaiser Aluminum Elects
description: John E. Merow, a partner of Sullivan & Cromwell, has been elected a director of the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation.

title: Yankee Lobstermen See Red
description: A continuing confrontation between New England lobstermen and Soviet trawlers in international waters off Nantucket points to the urgent need for clarification and strengthening of the law of the sea.

title: Nixon Hails Brooklyn, New York Police Chiefs
description: The Chief of Police, New York, New York and the Chief of Police, Brooklyn, New York received letters from President Nixon yesterday discussing the June 3 White House, conference on the killing of policemen.

title: The Deweys Are Interred In a Mausoleum in Pawling
description: PAWLING, N. Y., June 18 (AP)The remains of former New York Gov. Thomas E. Dewey and his wife, Frances, were permanently interred last Wednesday in the Pawling Cemetery. The bodies had reposed in a vault at the tery pending completion of a mausoleum.

title: New Hope for the Campus
description: The proposal by Secretary Richardson to provide direct Federal grants to colleges and universities represents an important reversal in the Administration's higher education policy. It is a welcome shift from an earlier White House position that such aid could not be offered until research had shown how colleges might be operated with greater academic effectiveness and administrative efficiency.

title: PRODUCTION OF CARS DECLINED FOR WEEK
description: DETROIT, June 18 (AP)United States automobile production sagged this week as shutdowns began for the Changeover to 1972 models and the Ford Motor Company began cutbacks in an attempt to reduce dealer inventories.

title: 13 Married Laymen Ordained as Catholic Deacons
description: DETROIT, June 18A labor economist, a mailman, an engineer and 10 other menall marriedwere ordained as Roman Catholic deacons tonight by John Cardinal Dearden, Archbishop of Detroit, filling an office that had been in disuse for more than a thousand years.

title: British Study Proposal
description: LONDON, June 18 (Reuters)  the British Government carefully studied today a Soviet proposal for a disarmament conference of the nuclear powers, informed British sources here said.

title: Doctors Consider Pledge to Curb Amphetamine Prescriptions
description: Doctors around the country, alarmed by the spreading abuse of amphetamines, are considering a voluntary pledge to stop prescribing the nighly addictive drugs for all but two relatively rare conditions.

title: DOUGLAS JAMES
description: Douglas James, a former real estate man, died on Thursday in the Lefferts General Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 74 years old and lived at Brooklyn.

title: Andretti Escapes Injury
description: ZANDVOORT, the Netherlands, June 18 (AP)  Mario Andretti, the Nazareth, Pa., Grand Prix driver, escaped unhurt today in a spectacular crash at 120 miles an hour during the first day practice for the Dutch Grand Prix.

title: Senate Securities Study to Begin in July
description: Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. said yesterday that the nucleus of his staff that would make a major study of the securities business would be ready to start work early next month.

title: U.S. Seeks Data on Sloop
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP)The United States today asked Switzerland to inquire about the fate of the Saturna, a privately owned American sloop that was taken in tow by a Cuban vessel yesterday. Five persons were reported to be aboard the sloop, which is owned by Thomas Caulfield of Berkeley, Calif.

title: Presbyterian Unity Is Foreseen; Compromise War Stand Taken
description: MASSANETTA SPRINGS, Va., June 18The onemillionmember Presbyterian Church in the United States (Southern) ended its sixday General Assembly here this afternoon determined to stay together.

title: Farewell to the NationState
description: WASHINGTONThe nationstate obsolete. Because of radical changes in the world environment, the basic political unit around which international society has been organized for almost 400 years is no longer capable of meeting desperate human needs. The crisis is particularly acute for the large nations which are increasingly unable to use their unparalleled accumulations of power to decrease the sum of human misery.

title: Knapp Unit Calls City Aide and Judge
description: One of Mayor Lindsay's closest advisors and the former head of the Department of Investigation have been questioned by the special city commission investigating the extent of corruption within the New York Police Department.

title: 48.2MILLION OUTLAY SET ON PERU COPPER
description: LIMA, Peru, June 18 (UPI)Peru's military Government said today that the United Statesowned Southern Peru Copper Corporation had agreed to invest nearly $48.2million between October, 1971, and December, 1972, in exploiting the country's richest copper deposits at Cuajone.

title: Buying Health Foods Is Easier Now
description: Whether fad or trend, health food stores are multiplying in both city and suburb. Some of the shops are individually owned and operated, but more and more they are members of chains that see financial growth through the increase in ecologymind

title: 5 Nations Walk Out of African Parley
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, June 18Representatives of five West African nations walked out of a meeting of the Council of Ministers of the Organization of African Unity today when the meeting refused to delay a debate on whether African states should open a diplomatic dialogue with the white Government of South Africa.

title: Hearing Ends in Britain On Captain's Protest Role
description: LONDON, June 18  A preliminary investigation into the part taken by Capt. Thomas S. Culver of the United States Air Force in a protest against the Vietnam war ended today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Mrs. Louise Ross Physician's Bride
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 18 Mrs. Louise Davidson Ross, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Wetmore Davidson of Brooklyn Heights, New York, was married here today to Dr. Donald Heyneman, son of Paul Heyneman of Berkeley and Mrs. Paul Wormser of La Jolla. The Rev. Frank Evans of the Community Congregational Church in Triburon performed the ceremony at Mr. and Mrs. Murry J. Waldman's home.

title: Mortgage of $150Million Given on Skyscraper Here
description: A halfton steel girder, painted gold, was hoisted to the top of a 53story building skeleton in the financial district of lower Manhattan yesterday.

title: Compromise on Jobs
description: Persistently high unemployment and the cries anguish from the nation's financiallysqueezed mayors have apparently persuaded the Administration to reexamine its opposition to the public service jobs bill. President Nixon last year vetoed a Democraticsponsored manpower bill which included Federal subsidies for jobs on city and state payrolls. Another veto had been predicted for the public service employment bill now in HouseSenate conference.

title: PRECEDENT SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, June 18A high Administration spokesman says that President Nixon is more concerned that a precedent might be set for future disclosures of secret documents than he is over whether The New York Times endangered national security by publishing a Pentagon study.

title: Karen Knapp Bride in Ohio
description: ZANESVILLE, Ohio, June 18Miss Karen Lynn Knapp was married here tonight to David Hays Johnson in the Grace United Methodist Church. The Rev. Howard Spitnale performed the ceremony.

title: Uniroyal Is Joining In TirePrice Rise; Zinc Cost Up 2.4c
Obituary 1  No Title
$1,000 Fine on Job Safety Urged for Allied Chemical
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (AP) A Labor Department official reported today that a $1,000 fine had been proposed against the Allied Chemical Corporation plant in Moundsville, W. Va., because of an allegedly serious violation of the new Federal occupational health and safety law. The charge involved allegations of a mercury vapor poisoning threat.

title: STOCKS ON AMEX DECLINE SHARPLY
description: The American Stock Exchange turned in its worst performance in more than a month yesterday. The list declined in steppedup trading.

title: Jean Campbell Wed to Newsman
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., June 18Miss Jean Trinder Campbell and Albert Dickinson Barton were married here this evening in St. John's Episcopal Church. The Rev. Kenneth E. Mackenzie, the rector, performed the ceremony.

title: Weather Fails to Dampen Fashion at Ascot
description: LONDON, June 18  Late yesterday afternoon the sun shone at last on what has been the worst Ascot weather for many years  icy cold and windy, with heavy showers. It made the going so heavy it upset all racing form.

title: Chief of S.E.C. Says Lockheed Erred on Secrecy
description: WASHINGTON, June 18William J. Casey, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, told Congress today that officials of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation did the wrong thing, in 1967, when they failed to inform their shareholders and the public of the troubles they were encountering on the production of the C5A military transport.

title: Schroder Names Three
description: Robert S. Damarjian, Martin B. WitSchi and Peter 9. Wodtke have been elected senior vice presidents of J. Henry Schroder Banking Corporation.

title: Stock Market Drop Sharpest in a Year
description: Stock prices plunged yesterday in their sharpest drop in nearly a year as a series of factors, popping like Chinese firecrackers, unsettled the market.

title: 3 Men in Bronx Sentenced For Conspiring to Kidnap
description: Three Bronx men were sentenced yesterday to indeterminate prison terms of up to five years for conspiring to kidnap several outoftown girls who said they had been forced into prostitution.

title: Beachwear? Streetwear? It's All Starting to Look the Same
description: The new freedom in dressing is fabulous, said Mrs. Norton Sloan, who had carefully keyed her multicolored sweatshirt to her denim shorts with a multicolored belt. The only trouble is, you have to keep shopping to keep up with it.

title: JAIL FOR WOMEN DEDICATED HERE
description: Welcome to New York's newest and perhaps best hotel, Correction Commissioner George F. McGrath said yesterday, greeting city officials at the dedication of the gleaming new City Correctional Institution for Women on Rikers Island.

title: Complaint Board Head Abraham Paul Chess
description: The new chairman of the Civilian Complaint Review Board, Abraham Paul Chess, is a rarity in city governmenta civilian who has made a career in the Police Department and enjoyed the confidence of a series of top police officials. Mr. Chess, who was sworn in yesterday, is a law

title: Bridge:; ?? ??  On Victorious Note in Rome
description: ROME, June 17  The Precision international team ended its world tour here Wednesday night. In a series of 12 matches that began in Taipei, Taiwan, a month ago and stretched through much of Asia and part of Africa, the touring group of Benito Garozzo, Giorgio Belladonna, both of Rome, and Katherine Wei, Dorothy Hayden and this writer, all of New. York, was defeated only once, by a young Tel Aviv team.

title: WASHINGTON POST RESTRAINED
description: WASHINGTON, Saturday, June 19In a 2to1 decision this morning the United States Court of Appeals reversed the ruling of a lower court and ordered The Washington Post to stop publication of a series of articles, based on classified information, on the history of the nation's involvement in the Vietnam war.

title: Mexican Horses Banned
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (UPI) Alarmed by the rapid northward spread of a virus disease that kills 80 to 90 per cent of the horses it strikes, the Agriculture Department banned today the entry of horses into the United States from Mexico. The action came one week after announcement of a joint United StatesMexican program to halt the spread of the disease, Venezuelan equine encephalomyelitis, in two northeastern Mexican states.

title: Goodyear Sets Brazil Plant
description: AKRON, Ohio, June 18 (UPI) The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company announced today plans to build a $25million tire plant near Americana, Brazil, to be owned and operated by its Brazilian subsidiary, Companhia Goodyear do Brazil. Goodyear said it expects construction to begin in August with initial production beginning late next year.

title: PAUL E. BOOZ, 56 ECONOMIST DIES
description: Paul E. Booz, assistant Ford Foundation representative in Indonesia, died in Jakarta on Thursday of a heart attack. He was 56 years old.

title: U.S. IS STUDYING SOVIET ARMS BID
description: WASHINGTON, June 18 (Reuters)  The United States is studying a Soviet proposal for a fivenation nuclear disarmament conference, the state department said today.

title: LIEBERMANN NAMED PARIS OPERA CHIEF
description: PARIS, June 18Rolf Liebermann of the Hamburg State Opera will head the Paris Opera as of 1973.

title: 514 Addicts Died in City From Jan. 1 to June 17
description: The Medical Examiner's Office reported yesterday that 514 addicts, 89 of them teenagers, died in the city between Jan. 1 and June 17.

title: Books of The Times
description: Were you surprised to read that a spokesman for the State Department last Monday had no comment to make on this newspaper's publication the previous day of excerpts from the Pentagon study of the Vietnam war because the department had not had time to locate its copy, of the report, or even to determine..whether it had one"? Maybe you thought the spokesman was stalling? I believed him'just having finished The Foreign Affairs Fudge Factory, John Franklin Campbell's scathl ing diagnosis of elephantiasis and fragmented responsibility in our foreignpolicy bureaucracyand was only surprised that the 47volume report was located a mere several hotirs later. Mr.. Campbell, Foreign Service officer on leave; is the young managing editor of a lively new magazine, Foreign Policy; he is a wit, muckracker, a stablecleaner. His devastating picture of the disarray of our foreign policy is a plea to simplify, restore and demoralized State Department.

title: Cavalleria Rusticana in Central Park
description: Mayor Lindsay was on hand to throw out the first joke, and a sizable audience halffilled the Sheep Meadow as the Metropolitan Opera's summertime season in Central Park began on Thursday night. In a brief talk to the crowd before the program, which included a concert version of Cavalleria Rusticana, the Mayor said that since he had taken the blame for the rain that postponed Tuesday's program, he felt entitled to claim credit for the fair weather on this night. As his jests go, it may have been slightly under par, but it suited the occasion.

The reinforcements are to strengthen security forces during traditional Protestant marches in Ulster this month and next.

The Swedish krona is equivalent to about 19 cents in United States currency.

title: The New Play
description: DANCE WI ME, the New York Shakespeare Festival's production of a comedy with music by Greg Antonacci, got one enthusiastic and six unfavorable reviews. Clive Barnes: One of the happiest entertainments in town. It is a serious, freakedout farce that I found pure delight. Mr. Antonacci daydreams back to the good old days of the nineteenfifties, with its dances, its early rock music and its sports. And he fantasizes. Boy, how he fantasizes. At times this freefall, freewheeling excursion into the more neurotic byways of a city life goes completely, zanily, mad. But it is always very funny. And all its humor has a firm basis in real life. It is satirical but never pompous, and its humor is often very physical, with roots going way back to the old vaudeville routines. The staging by Joel Zwick is perfect. He draws from such sources as Ladislas Fialka and even, perhaps, Grotowski, but everything is absorbed into a fine group effort. The acting is remarkable,

Edward Herbert, Democrat of Louisiana, said today that he had refused to allow the Columbia Broadcasting System to use a film clip of himself interviewing a former prisoner of war. He was the second high Government figure to refuse to cooperate with C.B.S. in the production of a documentary, P.O.W.'s  Pawns of War, which is to be shown Tuesday. Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird refused to allow his comments to be taped.

title: A colored man who plays
description: Bobby Short is a musician, a singerpianist of particular and special accomplishment, who sings only the best songs from the enormous literature of 32bar pop, musical comedy, jazz, and (for want of a better term) showbiz music. With Mabel Mercer, he is associated with a tradition intimate, tasteful, highly sophisticated music characterized by a skillful blend of words with melodic line, performed in each case (one might almost say acted, as in opera) in mood or manner consistent with the found meaning of the song. His standards are high, his taste impeccable, and it has been said of him that he is his tradition, that he has come to own a small bit of the musical landscape because there is no one who does what he does as well as he does. He is also a Negro.

title: Joseph Needham, the Real Thing
description: Our vocabulary for describing what is great has been so impoverished by the misuse of Hollywood publicists (Stupendous!!! Colossal!!!) that it is hard to find suitable words to describe the real thing. And Joseph Needham is the real thing: he is one of the great intellects of our time. Merely to call him a polymath gives no idea of his achievement: a fellow scholar at Cambridge University, a man who is not given to making rash judgments and who is wellversed in the British art of understatement, recently commented to me that you have to go back to Leonardo before you can find anyone with such a grasp of the whole of human knowledge. History, philosophy, religion, mathematics, astronomy, geography, geology, seismology, physics, mechanical and civil engineering, chemistry and chemical technology, biology, medicine, sociology, economics.... just to list the topics covered in his massive Science and Civilisation in China would take more than the space of this article (the summary of contents in the publisher's prospectus covers more than 12 closely printed pages.) And, at the same time as dealing with China, throughout the work Needham compares and contrasts with what was going on all over the rest of the world. In spite of Hollywood, it is stupendous, it is colossal.

title: Reader's Report

title: The Legs Of the Moon
description: To create a story within the framework of a known folklore requires humble study and thorough familiarity with it. It is unfortunate that the publisher has described this book as told in the manner of an old Hawaiian folktale. In telling the story of Paka, the littlest of all the menehune, the little people with red, bushy beards who come out at night, and Paka's struggle to catch the legs of the moon and hold back time, Francine Jacobs has used the appealing pattern familiar to European folklore of the smallest and least likely to succeed performing a prodigious feat and becoming a hero.

Mack Woman Is Promoted To Immigration Post Here

title: No principles, no patterns, no feelings
description: Solzhenitsyn's labor camps have redeeming graces hidden among the horrors. When a Solzhenitsyn hero is removed from the pressures and distortions of the outside world, he comes face to face with freedom for the first time and finds himself revitalized. Jan Benes's camps have no use whatsoever. Never has any part, any part, of what we have had to experience and survive been to any purpose, says one of his heroes.

title: Music
description: PTERRE BOULEZ is finally making the New York scene but he is traveling light. He rents no apartment, subletting a different one each time he is here, and though he will take over as musical director at the New York Philharmonic in September, he avoids all the props of today's American musical life. With no manager, press agent, secretary, maid or wifewithout even a telephone answering service the 46yearold Frenchman lives simply and alone. He says that his aim as musical director of the Philharmonic is to supply a model of musical life as conceive it, a musical life that is part of genuine culturenot a kind of secondrate enjoyment.

title: SAN DIEGO BALKS AT CONVENTIONS
description: SAN DIEGO, June 19Presi1 dent Nixon flew into San Diego immediately after his nomination in Miami three years ago and in a burst of affection proclaimed this to be my lucky city, where he could always count on a thumping big vote.

title: 100MILE CONTEST TO TEST BICYCLISTS
description: Top Eastern bicycle racers are expected to compete next Sunday in the White Mountains 100, an Olympic development race sanctioned by the Amateur Bicycle League of America. The course will be a 10mile loop over paved roads in the towns of Lyman and Lisbon, N. H.

title: 71 MOZART FESTIVAL SLATES 25 CONCERTS
description: The 1971 Mostly Mozart Festival will be presented at Philharmonic Hall from Aug. 2 through Aug. 28 by Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. The series of 25 concerts will be sponsored by the Herman Goldman Foundation.

title: Melba Moore, Star Of Purlie, Singing At Empire, Room
description: When Melba Moore walks out into the spotlight in the Empire Room of the WaldorfAstoria Hotel, slim, trim, with a wide, girlish grin, she is briefly held there, almost motionless, by waves of welcoming applause.

title: OTB and Belmont Link Up Tomorrow
description: The city's Offtrack Betting Corporation will begin accepting wagers tomorrow on the ninerace card at Belmont. Until now, regular OTB action tied to a race track has been limited to harness races at Roosevelt Raceway and Yonkers Raceway.

title: James Higby Weds Judith Hood Fulton
description: BERNARDSVILLE. N. J., June 19Miss Judith Hood Fulton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James M. Fulton of Far Hills and Vineyard Haven, Mass., was married here this afternoon to James Harland Higby, son of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Higby of Eden, N. Y.

title: BIRTHDAY PARTY IS HELD IN SPACE
description: MOSCOW, June 19The Solet astronauts aboard the orbiting Salyut space laboratory, took a break from their routine today, and two of them raised tubes of prune paste to toast the 38th birthday of Viktor I. Patsayev, the craft's test engineer.

title: The World
description: CALCUTTAWe will have to go through hell to meet the situation, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi told the Indian Parliament last week. She spoke, during a debate, about the 6 million frightened Bengali refugees who have fled into India to escape Pakistani military repression in East Pakistan. The refugees will have to go through hell, too.

title: ... and to Malapportionment
description: Two cases pending in the Federal courts in the District of Columbia seek to upset another part of the O'Hara Commission's workthe compromise formula for apportioning convention delegates agreed upon last February. That formula provided that approximately onehalf the delegates be allotted according to a state's strength in the Electoral College and the other half according to the state's Democratic vote in the last Presidential election. The Electoral College approach tends to overrepresent the small states, while one based on the Democratic vote favors the large industrial states where the party strongest.

title: The Wisdom of Eisenhower
description: On a President's Responsibility. Your research and your study means that you've got to understand what a new weapon or new weapons system means to the economy, what it does to the psychology of our people. To illustrate what I mean, we know that the Communists seek to break the economy of the United Statesan economy that is based on free enterprise and sound currency. If we, therefore, put one more dollar in a weapons system than we should, we are weakening the defense of the United States.

description: BALSAM GROVE, N. C., June 19  Vernon McCall has fol. lowed his house trailer to the grave, but his legal fight with the United States Forest Service is still alive.

title: Art
description: COLLECTIONS no less than the styles of art they favor, sooner or later acquire a historical patina. No collection is ever pure in the way an individual work of art may be. The circumstantial history of its growth leaves a residue of something worldly and impure"an inescapable aura of associationin our experience of a collection as a collection. Until we mentally edit a collection to conform to the esthetic specifications of our own tastes or until it is physically dispersed, it remains for us precisely a chapter of historysomeone else's history.

Gurfein's decision yesterday denying the Government's plea for a preliminary injunction to bar this newspaper from publishing articles about a secret Pentagon study of the Vietnam war marks a significant victory for press freedom in the United States and for the right of the American people to be informed about the operations of their Government.

title: PAKISTAN CRISIS IMPERILS SCHOOLS
description: ISLAMABAD Pakistan June 17  Continuing political upheavals a financial crisis and traditional Moslem attitudes have produced a crushing effect on mass education in Pakistan where experts estimate only 8 per cent of the population is literate.

June 19 (AP)The Atomic Energy Commission has announced that it will construct a $440,000 aquatic facility at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory to study the effects of heated water on fish and other aquatic life. The facility is scheduled to be completed in February, 1972.

title: Local Boy, 26, Makes Good in Majors...as Umpire
description: There are 43 umpires in the big leagues, eight of them rookies, and the biggest and youngest of the new ones is a bluesuited jumbo named John McSherry, who was calling balls and strikes on the sandlots of the Bronx only five years ago.

title: Well written and unreadable, readable with little meaning
description: With paperbacks now selling at hardbound prices and high costs forcing out experimental fiction and unknown authors, Knopf's publishing innovation  new novels at plausible prices, known in the trade as Borzoi puppies  is good news. The first two selections are In the Animal Kingdom by Warren Fine (his third book) and Burnt Toast, a first novel by Peter Gould. They are both visionary tales.

title: Luck of the Draw Puts Howe Under the Gun
description: LONDON, June 19 (UPI)Bob Howe failed in qualifying tests for Wimbledon's tennis championships, but the Australian was lucky loser No. 1, which made him eligible to replace the first man to withdraw. When Boro Jovanovic of Yugoslavia withdrew, he put Howe in Monday's first round.

title: Smith and Mrs. Court Take Finals in London Tennis
description: LONDON, June 19The tipsters have been shouting his name as an outside shot for some time now and today Pvt. Stan Smith of the United States looms as a real threat to the Australian dominance at Wimbledon.

title: Reader's Report
description: This is a tactless and you might say provocative act that Peter Forbath has committed. Now that Alexander Dubcek has become an unperson, and Czechoslovakia's most recent rape has been mercifully obliterated from the selective conscience of World Opinion he has written a novel to rake up the unholy mess all over again. Shame! Who wants to remember that 500,000 Soviet troops invaded Czechoslovakia in the summer of 1968? That women and children were murdered in Wenceslas Square? That an attempt at Titoism was thwarted with the same gangster tactics that concocted the suicide of Jan Masaryk in his country's second great betrayal after Munich?

title: Herman Kahn thinks about the thinkable
description: Herman Kahnoverviewer, mathematician, gamestheorist, thinktanker (RAND Corporation, Hudson Institute) and just possibly coprototype for Dr. Strangeloveis irrevocably associated with Thinking About the Unthinkable, the title of his stillcontroversial 1962 book on thermonuclear war. Indeed, On Thermonuclear War is another of his works, along with On Escalation: Metaphors and Scenarios and The Year 2000. Recently Kahn was interviewed in Davos, Switzerland, by the British scholar G. R. Urban. Here is an excerpt from their conversation, one of a series initiated by the University Programs of Radio Free Europe. It will be included in a volume edited by Urban, to be published by The Bodley Head (London) this year, entitled Can We Survive Our Future?

title: Coles, With 208, Leads Carroll Golf by Stroke
description: WOODBROOK, Republic of Ireland, June 19 (UPI)  A Ryder Cup golfer, Neil Coles, shot par 72 today for a threeround total of 208 to hold off a strong Australian challenge in the $24,000 Carroll's golf tournament.

Roller of Rego Park, Queens, were married here last evening. Rabbi Mordecai Efrom performed the ceremony at the Hillcrest Jewish Center in Flushing, Queens. title: VETERANS'
description: Returning Vietnam veterans are being treated as 10th class citizens lacking jobs and adequate medical facilities a condition that reflects complete misunderstanding of their situation, according to speakers yesterday at a special conference on veterans problems.

title: KENNEDY ROAD, 25, WINS QUEEN'S PLATE
description: TORONTO, June 19 (Canadian Press) Kennedy Road, a favorite at 25, pulled away in the stretch today and won the 112th running of the Queen's Plate by three lengths.

title: Photography
description: A FIVE WEEK workshop in fashion photography begins tomorrow at the Fashion Institute of Technology, State University of New York, 227 West 27th Street. The workshop will meet on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday mornings from 9 to 12, or in afterPoon sessions from 1 to 4. There will be professional models for advertising and editorial assignments, and the techniques involved in composing pictures, posing models and working in the darkroom will be discussed. Tuition for the course will $38. Phone (212) LA 41300, extension 304.

title: Art in Mexico
description: THE great Mexican muralist, David Alfaro Siqueiros, is nearing completion of his largest and most ambitious work an entire cultural center with paintings across its vast inside and outside walls. Work on the center, called the Polyforum Siqueiros, has consumed ten of the artist's 74 years and is the culmination of his concept of sculptural painting. It is, in every sense, a gigantic work, covering almost two acres and costing over one million dollars.

description: JOHANNESBURG, South Africa June 19 (Reuters)  A slim volume of poetry by black South African has shot unexpectedly to the top of the bestseller lists here.

title: Columbia Dean Recommends Dropping of Graduate Studies in Linguistics
description: Columbia University apparently is preparing to speak the fatal, final word for its linguistics department, one of the pioneers in modern linguistic studies.

title: Key Buddhist Site Said to Be Found In Kashmir Valley
description: SRINAGAR Kashmir June 19The site of a set of copper plates engraved with decisions of a Buddhist conference held :some 1,900 years ago reportedhas been found in the foothills of the Kashmir Valley about 50 miles south of Srinagar.

title: Saigon Parades Army's Growing Power
description: SAIGON, June 19The South Vietnamese Government celebrated Armed Forces Day today with a snappy show of its growing military muscle and promises from President Nguyen Van Thieu that the army would assure a South Vietnam free of Communism in any form.

title: Another Mitchum, Another Wayne
description: WAYNE and MITCHUM. The flagwaving super patriot cowboy and the iconoclastic, pioneer pot smoker with the fight in his fists, right? Not always. Not any more. It could be Michael Wayne'Big Duke's No. 1 son, who is now producing his father's films, And it could be Jim Mitchum, Bob's oldest boy, whose career as an actor has been sidetracked somewhat by a series of beach party movies.

title: Recession Helps Suffolk to Fill Its County Jobs
description: RIVERHEAD, L. I., June 19  The economic recession that has hit the New York metropolitan area, leaving thousands unemployed, has apparently also brought an unexpected payoff to the Suffolk County government.

title: Art
description: DEAR Chuck: How goes it? Thought of you last week when I was in Washington to see the 22nd National Exhibition of Prints at the Library of Congress and wondered Why you weren't in it. Didn't you get around to submitting? God knows enough other artists did. There were more than 1,700 prints, they tell me, from 712 artists. Naturally I didn't see the rejects but I thought of you especially because 27 of the 85 artists that the jury passed were from the Midwest, more even than from the East Coast including New York and the West Coast with all those print foundations etc., and many times more than from the South, Southwest, or New England. Every time I turned around there was another print from Madison, Wisconsin, or Champaign, Illinois, or any one of half a dozen places in Michigan. It all seemed to be up in that part of the country, mostly in colleges and universities to judge from the addresses.
