description: Following are excerpts from the argument yesterday before the United States Cir cuit Court here by Whitney North Seymour Jr., the United States Attorney, and Alex ander M. Bickel, a member of counsel to The New York Times, in the Government's case against The Times:

title: Chou Says U. S. Shield at Taiwan Is a Main BartoDiplomatic Ties
description: PEKING, June 21Premier Chou Enlai said tonight that the security screen the United States haderected around the island of Taiwan, now ruled by the Government of Chiang Kai shek, was a key obstacle to the establishment of diplomatic ties with the United States.

title: New Rochelle Told To End Surveillance Of Lawful Persons
description: A Federal judge here has ordered the New Rochelle Po lice Department to stop the surveillance of persons nei ther suspected of criminal ac tivity nor engaged in criminal activity.

title: RICHARD E. NIPPER
description: LENOIR, N. C., June 22 (AP) Richard E. Nipper, publisher of The Lenoir NewsTopic, died of a ruptured chest blood ves sel last evening in a hospital in Daytona Beach, Fla. He was 43 years old.

title: HUERT AS STOPS HARP IN 7TH ROUND HERE
description: Benny Huertas of Brooklyn was awarded a seventhround knockout victory over Johnny Harp, a Syracuse lightweight making his New York debut, in the Felt Forum main event last night.

title: 61 Moslems Reported Slain In Southern Philippine Town
description: MANILA, June 22High Gov ernment officials said today that a 20man group clad in military fatigue uniforms mu sacred 61 persons last Saturday in the predominantly Moslem town of Carmen on Mindanao Island in the southern Philip pines.

title: Text of Order Curbing Boston Globe
description: BOSTON, June 22Follow ing is the text of an order issued today by the United States District Court restrain ing The Boston Globe from further publication of its Vietnam articles:

title: Fifth Avenue Coach Lines Revises Net Income Upward
description: Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., advised its stockholders yesterday that 1970 net in come had been revised upward by $378,000, or 43 cents a, share as a result of an adjust ment by the auditors Ernst & Ernst. S. Hazard Gillespie trus teereceiver sent a revised statement to stockholders that placed net income at $594,223, or 68 cents a share, compared with $216,223, or 25 cents a share, as reported on June 4.

title: Nixon Assails LiberalPlan For National Health Care
description: ATLANTIC CITY, June 22 President Nixon for the first time today strongly attacked a bipartisan liberal proposal for national health insurance, tell ing the American Medical As sociation that it would tear apart the present health care syatem.

title: Soviet Astronauts Show Sprouts Grown in Their Garden in Space
description: MOSCOW, June 22 (UPI) The crew of the orbiting Salyut scientific station showed televi sion viewers their space gar den today.

title: Sabotaging the I.L.O.
description: Heedless of the grave potential damage to America's world position, the House Appropriations Committee is dancing to the tune set by Representative John J. Rooney of Brooklyn in his irresponsible campaign against United States funds for the International Labor Organization.

title: Margot Fonteyn Here July 20
description: Dame Margot Fonteyn of Britain's Royal Ballet will ap pear with the Stuttgart Ballet during the first week of the German company's engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House from July 20 through Aug. 1. She will be seen in six performances of Pome de l'Extase, the Scriabin ballet created for her by John Cran ko. The company, which per formed here this spring, is on tour.

title: Sail Through of the King Ranch Scores in Debut at Belmont Park
description: Robert J. Kleberg Jr., owner of the famed King Ranch, who came to New York to inspect Canonero II for a possible acquisition, saw one of his $100,000 purchases make winning debut at sunny Bel inont Park yesterday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S.Chilean Relations Running Into Serious Snags
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, June 21 Relations between the United States and the leftwing Gov ernment of Chile are running into serious snags.

title: Article 8  No Title
Winners of Coty Awards
description: Halston, a favorite of fashionable women, and Betsey Johnson, who makes farout clothes for the young, are the recipients of the 1971 Coty American Fashion Awards. The an nouncement was made at a luncheon for members of the fashion press yesterday. Both winners are connected with boutiques and design massproduced wholesale col lections.

title: Miss Oremland Bride in Jersey Of Dr. Sosnow
description: ALPINE, N. J., June 22 Miss Phyllis, Irene Oremland and Dr. Joseph David Sosnow were married here this eve ning by Rabbi Alter Kriegal at the Tamcrest Country Club, where a reception for 200 guests also was held.

title: Educational Unit Elects Teachers College Head
description: PRINCETON, N. J., June 22Dr. John H. Fischer, president of Teachers Col lege, Columbia University, has been elected chairman of the board of trustees of the Educational Testing Serv ice for 197172, it was an nounced today.

title: V. A. to Add 27 Drug Addiction Centers
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 The Veterans Administration announced today a more than fivefold expansion of its spe cial drug addiction clinics to cope with a flood of military addicts from Vietnam and other overseas posts.

title: MAXWELL E. FILLET
description: Maxwell E. Fillet, a consul tant to the PepsiCola division of Pepsico, Inc., died yesterday after a short illness in Univer sity Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived at 400 East 56th Street.

title: Overhauling Economic Policy
description: The sharp rise in consumer prices last month is an unpleasant reminder of what inflation is continuing to do to the value of the dollar. Announcement that the price index went up sixtenths of 1 per cent in May came just after President Nixon's chief economic adviser, Dr. Paul W. McCracken, gave the first official word that the Administration is dissatisfied with the way its economic game plan is working out. The economy growing too slowly to bring unemployment down below the 6 per cent level it reached last December. With large numbers of graduates and veterans entering the labor force, the jobless rate may even rise.

title: Advertising:
description: Did you ever get the urge to reply to the remark, So you're little GooGoo's dad; with No, dummy, little Goo Goo is my son.

title: Books of The Times
description: WILLIAM DEAN HOWELLS. An American Life. By Kenneth S. Lynn. 372 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $13.95.

title: Philadelphia Club Takes Saber Title in U.S. Fencing
description: BERKELEY, Calif., June 22 (AP)  The Cziszar Club of Philadelphia upset the New York Athletic Club today to win the saber team title in the United States fencing cham pionships.

title: Urban Mooney, Associate In Stock Brokerage, Was 68
description: Urban D. Mooney, a senior associate in the New York of fice of Singer, Deane & Scrib ner Inc., stockbrokers, was pronounced dead in Polyclinic Hospital on Monday after ap parently suffering a heart at tack while riding in a taxi. He was 68 years old and lived at 215 East 68th Street.

title: Champlain Sludge Remains Problem
description: TICONDEROGA, N. Y.  The air and the water in this village at the foot of the Adirondacks are purer than they were several months ago. The contamina tion from the town's main industry, a big paper mill, has been checked.

title: 1968: L.B.J. and Rostow in White House
description: CHICAGO Anyone With the self righteousness of a Melvin Laird or a Tom Wicker has little difficulty de termining the proper outcome of the present controversy between the Gov ernment and The New York Times. But certitude is only an anagram of and not a synonym for rectitude. The respective battle cries of free speech and national security frame the question; they do not answer it.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: New Hampshire Action Set
description: CONCORD, N. H., June 22 Despite the Florida, challenge, New Hampshire legislative lead ers vow that this state will con tinue to hold the first Presiden tial preference primary in the nation.

title: Florida to Hold Primary on March 14
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., June 22 (AP)  Gov. Reubin Askew signed into law today a bill giving Florida a Presidential preference primary next March 14, the earliest in the nation.

title: NILS O. OHLSON
description: SHORT HILLS, N. J., June 22 Nils O. Ohlson, who had been president of the Board of Edu cation of Millburn for 15 years, died yesterday of a heart at tack while driving in Newark. He was 60 years old.

title: Melnyk in British Open
description: JACKSONVILLE, Fla., June 22 (UPI)Steve Melnyk, win ner of the British Amateur, said today he would complete in the British Open golf championship July 7 to 10.

title: SunTimes Tells of Ouster
description: CHICAGO, June 22 (AP) The Chicago SunTimes said today that it had obtained topsecret State Department documents showing that high ranking Kennedy Administra tion officials had advance knowledge of the coup d'etat that toppled Predident, Dinh Diem of South Vietnam.

title: Washington Appeals Court Continues Ban on The Post's Series on Vietnam
description: WASHINGTON, June 22  Nine Federal Appeals judges continued tonight a ban against publication by The Washington Post of articles based on secret Pentagon documents. They said that the ban would remain in effect until they ruled on the propriety of the Government's attempt to stop the articles.

title: Refugees Greet Hussein Warmly on Tour of Camp
description: ZIZIA, Jordan, June 22 Palestine refugees gave King Hussein of Jordan a tumultuous welcome today as he visited one of their camps for the first time since the civil war last September between his army and Palestinian commando forces.

title: Notes on People
description: Last year, when he turned 60, his admirers were oha grined to learn that Aleksandr Tvardovsky, for more than a decade the Soviet Union's leading liberal editor, was not chosen by the authorities for the Order of Lenin. In stead, he received the less important Order of the Red Banner.

title: JACKSON TO SPUR PUPIL INTEGRATION
description: JACKSON, Miss., June 22 Civil rights Iawyers and public school authorities here agreed today to a bold new elementary school desegregation plan in volving extensive busing, clos ing of ghetto schools and con struction of two modern edu cational parks in outlying areas.

title: De Sapio Ordered to Surrender On Friday to Begin Jail Term
description: Carmine G. De Sapio, former leader of Tammany Hall, the New York County Democratic organization, was ordered by a Federal judge here yesterday to surrender Friday to start serv ing a twoyear term for bribery conspiracy.

title: OTB's Telephone Room Good Line on the Future
description: This is OTB, says a cheer ful voice at the other end of the line. Are you betting Belmont or Yonkers?.

title: Times Case Heard, Restraint Extended; U.S. Action Halts a Boston Globe Series
description: The United States Court of appeals here heard arguments yesterday on the Government's effort, to enjoin The New York Times from publishing secret information on the Vietnam war. A prompt decision was Promised.

title: 100,000 Jobs for Veterans Goal Of Appeal of a Business Group
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 The Nixon Administration will announce tomorrow a pledge by the National Alliance of Busi nessmen, a group of volunteer business executives, to seek out at least 100,000 jobs over the next 12 months for Vietnam veterans.

title: Article 2  No Title
About Motor Sports
description: The old girl is perking up with new finery about $2 million worth. The Watkins Glen Grand Prix road course in the Finger Lakes district of upstate New York is be ing refurbished in stages, with the first deadline a Pro gram of races in July and August, and the other dead

title: SENIOR POSTS FILLED AT STOCK EXCHANGE
description: Robert W. Haack, president of the New York Stock Ex change, announced yesterday, that John J. Alexander Jr., Lee D. Arning, Samuel A Gay and Eugene Miller had been named senior vice presidents of the exchange.

title: Bank in North Carolina Sued
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) The Justice Department filed suit today against a North Car olina bank contending that an agreement it made with a shop ping center for location of a night depository was anticom petitive.

title: News Analysis
description: Councilman Bertram R. Gel land, a Bronx Democrat, tells of a recent conversation with an Assemblyman who had al Ways coveted a judgeship.

title: Sparkman Sees Lockheed Aid Gaining
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 (Reu ters)Senator John Sparkman, chairman of the Senate Bank ing and Currency Committee, said today he expected his panel to approve legislation to pre vent the Lockheed Aircraft Cor poration from going into bank ruptcy.

title: Land Management Bureau To Get a New Director
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 (AP) Interior Secretary Rogers C. B. Morton announced today the appointment of Burton W. Sil cock as director of the Bureau of Land Mnaagement, an agency with responsibility over some 460 million acres of Federal land.

title: West Germany Captures Two Title Canoeing Events
description: MERANO, Italy, June 22 (AP) West Germany Won two gold medals of the five at stake to day in the world canoeing championships to raise its total to three.

title: STOCKS DECLINE IN AMEX TRADING
description: The American Stock Ex change yesterday registered its seventh consecutive decline as prices finished lower after sell ing pressure in the lad two hours of trading wiped out a midsession rally.

title: Union Penalized for Strike
description: The New York State Public Employment Relations Board hag found that Local 1396 of the State, County and Munici pal Employes violated the no strike provision of the Taylor Law when its members, bridge and tunnel workers, walked off August. The board ordered a ninemonth forfeiture of the dues checkoff privilege for the local. The board supported the findings of Harvey Milowe, a hearing officer, that the Tri borough Bridge and Tunnel Authority was not guilty of ex treme provocation.

title: Article 4  No Title
SCHOOLS CUT BACK SUMMER COURSES
description: City high school students will not be able to take advance courses this summer as a re Sult of the Board of Educa tion's economy cutback in sum mer school programs and ac. tivities.

title: William W. Heath Dead at 67; Ambassador to Sweden, '6769
description: AUSTIN, Tex., June 22Wil liam W. Heath, the former Ambassador to Sweden, died tonight at his home of a heart attack. Mr. Heath, who was 67 yearsold, had spent the day working at his law office in downtown Austin.

title: Packwood's View
description: WASHINGTON, June 271 (UPI)Mr. Sparkman and Sen ator Robert W. Packwood, Re publican of Oregon, said the committee might set aside the Administration's bill, which was aimed specifically at rescuing Lockheed and might vote in stead for a measure applicable to many concerns facing trouble.

title: James H. Couey Jr., Publisher Of Honolulu StarBulletin, Dies
description: ROME, June 22James H. Couey Jr., publisher of The Honolulu StarBulletin, died to day, apparently of a heart at tack, at Fiumicino Airport. He was 47 years old.

title: New or Increased Taxes
description: Several new taxes were imposed on New Yorkers yes terday. Others that had been authorized by Albany were rejected by city officials. The new or increased types are as follows:

title: Yankees Divide
description: The Detroit Tigers exploded with five runs in the ninth inning yesterday to stun the New York Yankees in the first game of a doubleheader, 74. But Stan Bahnsen restored the Yankees to sanity by pitching them to a 21 decision in the second game for his sixth straight victory.

title: DEMOCRATS SET SLATE IN NASSAU
description: BALDWIN, L. I., June 22 Democratic county committee men met here tonight to en dorse candidates for District Attorney, judges of the Family, County and District Courts and a candidate to replace the late State Senator Edward J. Speno.

title: Floridian Rifle Victor
description: FORT BENNING, Ga., June 22 (AP)Sgt. James McQuien of Plant City, Fla., won the Army rifle championship today by scoring 1,940 of a possible 2,000 points.

title: Occidental Reports Accord On an ItalyLibya Oil Deal
description: LOS ANGELES, June 22 (AP) A crude oil transportation agreement between the OCci dental Petroleum Corporation and AGIP the Italian Govern ment oil company has been approved by Libya, Occidental officials said today.

title: City Reports Mercury Level In Fish Eaters' Diet Is Sate
description: Health Department investiga tors here reported yesterday that a fivemonth study dis closed no differences between ?? levels in longtime fish eaters and in persons on a normal American diet.

title: Nader Asserts U. S. Lets Banks Violate Consumer Credit Laws
description: WASHINGTON, June 22 Ralph Nader accused Federal regulators today, of permitting rampant violations of con sinner credit laws by national banks.

title: Union Gallery For Art Shows Opens at Hall
description: An art exhibition hall opened yesterday in the Mar tin Luther King Jr. Labor Center, Local 1199, at 310 West 43d Street.

title: KING RESOURCES CO. IN DEFAULT ON, DEBT
description: PORTLAND, Me., June 23 (UPI) The King Resources Company, the financially trou bled oil and gas exploration con cern being sued for more than $100million by Investors Over seas Servides, Ltd., today was declared in default to trade creditors on aabout $9million of debt secured by mortgages on oil terminal properties in Maine and on Long Island.

title: Mrs. Henry Luce 3d, Investment Analyst, Is Dead
description: Mrs. Claire McGill Luce, wife of Henry Luce 3d, pub lisher of Time magazine, died Tuesday evening after a long illness at their home on Fishers Island, N. Y. She was 47 years old and lived also at 4 Sutton Place South in New York and in Gladstone, N. J.

title: Lawrence B. Smith, Broker, Author and Automotive Aide
description: PLAINFIELD, N. J., June 23 Lawrence Breese Smith, a for mer broker and automotive manufacturing executive who wrote numerous books and ar ticles on shooting, game pres ervation and dude ranching, died yesterday after a long ill ness in a nursing home here. He was 82 years old.

title: ISSUE SOLD AT $28 BY MERRILL LYNCH
description: Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., the world's largest investment house, went public yesterday in a stock offering that made Wall Street history.

title: Secondary Offer Expected Of Flying Tiger Corp Stock
description: A secondary offering of 848,077 shares of common stock of the Flying Tiger Corporation, a holding com pany, is expected to be made shortly, according to Wayne M. Hoffman, chairman.

title: Senate Votes Closure in Debate on Draft
description: WASHINGTON, June 23  With only a week to go before the Government's basic au thority to conscript men into the military service expires, the Senate voted today to cut off debate on the bill to extend the draft.

title: Kenyan Official Jailed
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, June 23 Gideon Munyao Mutiso, a mem ber of the Kenyan parliament, was sentenced today to nine and a half years in prison after he pleaded guilty of conspiring to overthrow the Government of President Jomo Kenyatta.

title: Auto Sales Off 18% in 10 Days;
description: DETROIT, June 23New car sales continued to lag in June with the Big Four car makers reporting 221,188 deliveries of Americantype autos in the June 1120 period, down from 304,493 a year before.

title: Long Will Push Welfare Bill in Senate
description: WASHINGTON, June 23  The chairman of the Senate Fi nance Committee where wel fare reform legislation died last year, predicted today that the committee would report a bill to the floor later this year.

title: Heston Flexing Muscles for Antony
description: MADRID Antony and Cleopatra, one of Shake speare's most beautiful but least manageable plays, has had few successful perform ances and has never been made into a movie.

title: LOEWS INCREASES PROFITS BY 91.8%
description: The Loews Corporation real ized an increase of 91.8 per cent in net income and 13.5 per cent in revenues during the third fiscal quarter ended May 31 and gains of 72 per cent and 7.5 per cent, respectively, for the ninemonths period, accord ing to results reported yester day.

description: MIAMI, June 23 (UPI)The article published by the Knight papers said that the Pentagon documents indicated the fol lowing:

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Lakes and ponds are just as difficult to fish, in their own way, as rivers or streams, and there is simply no sub stitute for hours, weeks and even years of angling on a particular body of water.

title: WALSH AND U.S. AIDE DISAGREE ON HOUSING
description: Albert A. Walsh the city's Housing and Development Ad ministrator, and a I ederal housing administrator dis agreed on whether the Govern ment was providing sufficient funds for housing at the dedi cation of a 524unic apartment project in the ?? sec tion of Brooklyn yesterday.

title: Shubert Award for Kaye
description: Danny Kaye, star of Two by Two, received the Sam S. Shubert Foundation Award yesterday from Lawrence Shu bert Lawrence at the Drama tists Guild, 234 West 44th Street, in recognition of his outstanding contributions to the Amrican Theater in 1970 71. The award consists of a gold medal.

title: News Analysis
A Space Endurance Record Set By Three Astronauts in Salyut
description: MOSCOW, Thursday, June 24The threeman Soviet crew of the Salyut orbital station broke this morning the endur ance record for man in space.

title: Goldberg Urges Easing Of Secrecy on U.S. Data
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 Arthur J. Goldberg, the Amer ican delegate to the United Nations during the Johnson Ad ministration, asserted today that only 10 per cent of the Government's sensitive docu ments should remain secret for long.

title: Senator Mansfield's Compromise
description: The Administration narrowly escaped a direct consti tutional confrontation with Congress Tuesday when the Senate defeated by only one vote an amendment to the Selective Service Act aimed at cutting off funds for United States military operations in Indochina in nine months if North Vietnam agreed to free American prisoners of war.

title: LONDON BALLET GALA HELD TO SAVE TITIAN
description: LONDON, June 23 (AP)It was billed as the Greatest Show on Earth, but the ballet extravaganza staged to help retain Titian's Death of Ac taeon turned out to be some thing of an artistic and finan cial flop.

title: Rent Chief on Hunt For Violations Here Is Trapped by One
description: The City Rent Commissioner, several of his aides and a building inspector looking for violations in a Broadway build ing got stuck in the elevator yesterday after they crowded in too many people.

title: Senate to Set Up Joint Group that Will Hold Hearings On Origin of the War
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 The Senate leadership laid the groundwork today for creation of a special joint panel of the Senate Foreign Relations Com mittee and the Senate Armed Services Committee to hold public hearings into the origins of the Vietnam war.

title: Yiddish Productions Planned
description: Jacob Jacobs has leased the Eden Theater, 189 Second Ave nue, for the presentation of Yiddish productions next fall. It was originally the home of the Maurice Schwartz's Yid dish Art Theater. One theater's last two attractions were Oh, Calcutta! and Man of La Mancha., Last year, Mr. Jacobs appeared in a YiddishAmeri can program at the Billy Rose Theater.

title: Governor Says State Helps City Meet Responsibilities
description: Governor Rockefeller de clared yesterday that the new ly created state commis sion studying New York City administration and other legis lative actions such as state audits of the city were designed to bring the city underneath the supervision of the state.

title: Washington: For the Record
Suspect Found Abroad
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 23 (UPI) District Attorney Arlen Specter said today that George Fassnacht, sought since an arsenal was found Sunday in his home here, had been found in the Netherlands. Mr. Specter's office said that the former em ploye of the Central Intelligence Agency was under surveillance by the State Department.

title: Box Scores of Major League Games
Article 5  No Title
Leader of War Study Sees No Security Threat So Far
description: WASHINGTON, June 23  A former Governnient official who had overall responsibility for the preparation of the Pentagon's study on the Viet nam war said today that, in his view, hone of the material published so far, could endan ger the national security.

title: DAVID M. PALLEY
description: David M. Palley, a retired lawyer who argued many cases before the United States Su preme Court, died Tuesday at his home, 233 East 69th Street, after a long illness. He was 82 years old.

title: A.C.L.U. Scores Pentagon's Drug Plan
description: WASHINGTON, June 23  The American Civil Liberties Union challenged today the right of the armed forces to tell law enforcement agencies the results of urinalysis tests that servicemen returning to this country from Vietnam must now undergo.

title: Monetary Reserves of the U.S. Declined $505Million in May
description: WASHINGTON, June 23  Total United States monetary reserves declined by $505mil lion in May, including a loss of $357million in gold, the Treasury disclosed today.

title: WILLIAM NELSON JR.
description: EDGARTOWN, Mass., June 23William H. Nelson Jr., a Boston lawyer, died here at Martha's Vineyard Hospital yesterday of a coronary embo lism. He was 57 years old.

title: Knee Surgery on McCovey Put Off Till End of Season
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 23 (UPI)Willie McCovey of the San Francisco Giants won't undergo knee surgery this sea son. When informed by Dr. Robert S. Kerlan of Los Angeles that surgery was not man datory at this time, the Giants decided to postpone sur gery until after the season.

title: Music: Met's Fidelio
description: Crocheron Park, in Bay side, Queens, was the setting for the Metropolitan Opera's first performance of a Ger man opera in the free outdoor concerts it gives annually in the five boroughs of the pity.

title: Shop Talk
description: If you can't quite afford fine antiques but don't want to settle for the anonymity of mass  produced furniture, don't give up hope. There are still a few cabinetmakers left who will design and exe cute reproductions to order. One of these is Hector Petel in, who, was born in Trieste, studied geometri cal design in Italy and has had a workroom / shop here for 10 years. His essentially oneman operation, on the third floor at 1070 Second Avenue (between 56th and 57th Streets), goes by the name of Petri (because it sounds more Italian than Petelin).

title: Prague Group in Debut
description: Of the great church and court composers of the early Renaissance, Josquin des Prez ranked as the greatest, a Flemish musician whose im portance compares to Bach's or Beethoven's. He was the ideal artist, in fact: both innovator and consolidator, capable of refining the con trapuntal techniques of his day and yet willing to inject something new, a secular grace and a melodic expres siveness that keep his music from turning to dust in the way the works of some of his contemporaries can for us.

title: Stockholder in Solitron Is Planning Proxy Fight
description: A stockholder of Solitron Devices, Inc., has announced his intention to open a proxy fight to unseat the incumbent management. Harold S. Brady urged other stockholders in a letter not to attend the annual meeting next Tuesday.

title: Article 8  No Title
ALEXANDER J. METZGER
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., June 23  Alexander J. Metzger, who retired in 1963 as a national circulation roadman for The New York Times, died today at his home. He was 82 years old.

title: Democrats, at Union Parley, Assail Nixon Over Economy
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP)Senator Birch Bayh and other Democrats criticized President Nixon's economic pol ciies today at a labor conven tion.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: TOP HANOI AIDE DUE TO HEAD PARIS TEAM
description: PARIS, June 23 (Reuters) A senior North Vietnamese leader, Le Duc Tho, is return ing to Paris to head Hanoi's negotiating team in the peace talks here, the North Vietna mese delegation said today.

title: No New Articles Planned
description: DETROIT, June 23Lee Hills, executive editor of the Knight newspaper group, said tonight that his organization had no plan at this time to publish further material from the Pen tagon papers.

title: Space LinkUps Discussed
description: HOUSTON, June 23 (Reuters) Soviet and American space experts agreed today to study the possibility of experimental linkups between Apollotype spacecraft and orbiting stations like the Russian Salyut now circling the earth.

title: Spencer Trask Reports Earnings for First Time
description: Spencer Trask & Co., a lead ing brokerage house, disclosed its annual earnings yesterday for the first time in 103 years and announced that August Huber, president of the con cern, had been named chief ex ecutive officer.

title: Ratliff Upsets Van Nostrand In Tennis, 36, 61, 76
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., June 23Jim Ratliff of Green wich, Conn., ranked No. 4 in Eastern junior tennis, upset King Van Nostrand of Bright waters, L.I., 36, 61, 76, in the fourth round today to gain the quarterfinals of the Eastern men's clay court tennis cham pionships at the Port Washing ton Tennis Academy.

title: $50,000 Bail for Weems
description: Supreme Court Justice Ar nold G. Fraiman set bail at $50,000 yesterday for Donald Weems, one of the 21 Black Panthers originally indicted here two years agoon charges of conspiracy to commit mur der and arson and to kill policemen.

title: Sams and Kimbro Are Sentenced to Life in Panther Killing, but Eventual Parole Is Expected for Both
description: NEW HAVEN, June 23 After saying he wished them well and would say a prayer for them, Judge Harold M. Mulvey today sentenced to life imprisonment the state's two chief witnesses in the recent murder and kidnapping trial of the Black Panther leader, Bobby G. Seale, and Mrs. Ericka Huggins.

title: Mrs. Elizabeth Sharpless Wed To Harlan R. Ellis 2d, Lawyer
description: Mrs. Elizabeth Anne Apple dorf Sharpless and Harlan Reed Ellis 2d, doctoral can didates at Columbia Univers ity, were married in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia yesterday afternoon. The Rev. Jeffery Craig Sontesi fer performed the Unitarian ceremony.

title: BLACK AFRICANS REJECT DIALOGUE
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, June 23The Organization of African Unity reaffirmed today but by a split voteits op position to any moves by black states to open an independent diplomatic dialogue with the white Government of South Africa.

title: Westerners Filling a Technology Gap for Algeria
description: PARIS, June 23Americans and other Westerners are work ing in increasing numbers in Algeria, applying management techniques to her socialist economy and helping to broaden her economic relations.

title: Volkswagen Increases Its Prices
description: Volkswagen of America, Inc., announced yesterday that in creasing production costs have forced the company to raise suggested list prices on Volks wagens sold in the United States by an average of about 3 per cent.

title: Pompidou Hails Accord
description: PARIS, June 23  President Pompidou today hailed the agreements reached for British entry into the Common Market as an important date in our history and in the history of Europe.

title: Lending Activity High
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 (UPI) Small Business Ad ministration announced today that its lending activity is at a high.

title: Military Judge Elevated
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) President Nixon today chose William H. Darden, 48 years old, to serve as chief judge of the United States Court of Military Appeals, the nation's highest military court. He has been a member of the three man panel the last two years. Judge Darden succeeds Judge Robert Emmett Quinn, who has been chief judge since the court was created in 1951. Judge Quinn, 77, will remain on the panel.

title: Rabbi Asks Jews to Reexamine The Role of Jesus as a Prophet
description: ST. LOUIS, June 23An American Reform rabbi urged the Jewish religious community today to reexamine the role of Jesus as a prophet and teacher within the Jewish tradition.

title: TIMES SERIES IS DELAYED AGAIN; PAPER TO APPEAL TO HIGH COURT;
description: The United States Court of Appeals here ordered a further. delay yesterday in the publi cation by The New York Times of material from Pentagon pa pers on the American involve ment in the Vietnam war.

title: City Gets Complaint on Secrecy
description: Mayor Lindsay expressed surprise yesterday at news men's complaints that de liberatiobs of his administra tion's health agencies were shrouded in secrecy.

title: Judge in Baltimore Strikes Testimony In Panther Killing
description: BALTIMORE, June 23A Criminal Court judge today ordered three days of testi mony of a key prosecution wit ness stricken from the record in the trial of Arthur F. Turco Jr., a white New York lawyer accused of being an accessory to the murder of a suspected Black Panther police informer.

title: PRICES ON AMEX POST AN ADVANCE
description: The American Stock Exchange posted its first advance in eight sessions yesterday as most is sues finished higher in slower trading.

title: A.M.A. Chief Asks Role for Young Men
description: ATLANTIC CITY, June 23 Reacting to charges that the American Medical Association was no longer relevant, the group's new president urged today that it reorganize and give a greater voice to younger doctors.

title: Advertising:
description: Doyle Dane Bernbach, which was nurtured in its in fancy with retailadvertising accounts, is diversifying into the retail business.

title: STOCKS ADVANCE IN SLOW TRADING
description: The stock market finally posted a gain yesterday, but the reduced level of activity in dicated that traders were not particularly impressed by the rebound.

description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Mrs. Hart Advances to Golf Semifinal
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 23  Three New Jersey players and one from Long Island reached the semifinal round of the 68th annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship today.

title: Sorcery Sweeps Newport Race Honors
description: NEWPORT, R. I., June 23 Sorcery, a new 61foot sloop owned by James French Bald win of Locust Valley, L. I., wrapped up first place on cor rected time in the biennial An napolistoNewport yacht trace today.

title: Advertising:
description: Instead of going along with the recommendation of its review board as it usually does, the full television board of the National Association of Broadcasters yesterday re jected the idea of allowing hemorrhoid commercials.

title: Big Rise in Pakistani Disease Toll Feared
description: KARACHI, Pakistan, June 23 Doctors here expect deaths from polio, smallpox, malaria and other diseases to increase sharply as the result of new Government strictures on pub lic health spending and the importation of drugs.

title: Rondeau, 1to20 Choice, Scores by 11 Lengths at Belmont
description: Rondeau of the Calumet Farm was the absolute best of a nearminimum lot in the $32, 225 Filly Division of the Na tional Stallion Stakes at Bel mont Perk yesterday.

title: Adequate Defense Claimed By Russo in Suit by S.E.C.
description: MEADVILLE, Pa., June 23 (UPI)Rusco Industries, Inc., has adequate defense against a Securities and Exchange Com Mission suit filed against it Monday, Jack Catain Jr., chair man and president, told the an nual shareholders meeting to day.

title: LAG IN NEGRO JOBS TERMED CRITICAL
description: Warning that we are at an alltime danger level, the Na tional Urban League issued report yesterday that focused on the critical unemployment and other major social prob lems in 53 cities.

title: 2 CONVICTIONS UPSET IN SLAYING IN RIOT
description: TRENTON, June 23The murder convictions of two black defendants convicted of killing a white patrolman dur ing the July, 1967, riot in Plainfield were overturned to day by New Jersey's second highest court.

description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Judge Upsets Conviction, Assailing Legal Aid's Defense
description: A man who has been in prison three and a half years was ordered freed yesterday unless the state can give him a swift retrial, because his orig inal defense shocked the con science of the court.

title: OBSERVER
description: Carl and Louise were living happily ever after one night in late June when Carl, who had arrived home in an all toofamiliar mood, noticed something highly usual in his newspaper's listings of the evening's television highlights.

title: W.ALLSTON FLAGG, 75, INVESTMENT BANKER
description: OYSTER BAY, L. I., June 23 W. Allston Flagg, an invest ment banker and former gov ernor of the New York Stock Exchange, died today in the Westchester Division of New York HospitalCornell Medical Center after a brief illnets. He was 75 years old and lived, at 25 Cove Road here.

description: To the Editor:

title: 50 From Rikers Island Studying Outside to Be Youth Counselors
description: A group of 50 young inmates on Rikers Island serving time for such crimes as man slaughter and robbery are commuting to a training pro gram designed to get them jobs as group counselors.

title: Senate's RollCall Vote On Motion for Closure
State Finds Drug Abuse Is Rising
description: A yearlong study conducted by the state's Narcotic Addic tion Control Commission sug guests that more New Yorkers are using heroin than had pre viously been thought and that the use of LSD and speed is increasing.

title: Ervin Asks Ban on Lie Detectors for Job Seekers
description: WASHINGTON, June 23  Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., chair man of the Senate Subcommit tee on Constitutional Rights, plans to introduce tomorrow a bill that would prohibit the use of lie detectors for appli cants for Federal jobs and in many sectors of private busi ness.

title: Coast Grand Jury Studies How Times Got Papers
description: LOS ANGELES, June 23 A Federal grand jury here is investigating how the secret Pentagon study on Vietnam reached The New York Times.

title: Steel Industry Is Aiming At Recycling of All Cans
description: PITTSBURGH, June 23The American steel industry an nounced here today a major drive to recover and recycle used steel cans. Toplevel spokesman for the industry said the eventual aim was to put all of the 60 billion such cans used each year by American consum ers back into steelmaking fur naces.

title: UTILITIES' RESERVE TERMED ADEQUATE
description: The nation's electric utilities have entered the summer with a reserve generating capacity of 18.3 per cent, according to the 49th semiannual electric power survey published by the Edison Electric Institute.

title: Scheinman, Hochstin Fined $5,000 by Stock Exchange
description: The New York Stock Ex change confirmed yesterday that it had imposed a $5,000 fine and censureship on one of its member firms, Scheinman, Hockstin & Trotta, Inc., for fail ing to segregate properly some customers' fully paid securities from excess margin securities.

title: 1966: L.B.J.and Ky in Honolulu
description: Publication by The New York Times and other news media of portions of the secret Pentagon Vietnam study has raised basic questions of propriety that have long been a simmering issue between government and a free Press. Now it is out in the open.

title: Rostow on Bombing
description: In an interview yesterday on the ABC Evening News, Walt W. Rostow, a former White House adviser to President Johnson, was asked if he thought it proper for President Johnson to have depicted himself in the 1964 Presidential campaign as the candidate of reason and restraint in the light of recent disclosures from Pentagon docu ments that there was an as sumption during the campaign that it would be necessary to bomb North Vietnam.

title: Ban on Faculty Sabbaticals In City Colleges Is Upheld
description: City University faculty mem bers whose applications for paid sabbaticals were not ap proved by the Board of Higher Education before April 12, the day the State Legislature barred such leaves for one year, are not entitled to them, State Supreme Court Justice Isidore Dollinger ruled yester day.

description: The Medical Investment Cor poration said yesterday that preliminary figures indicate its loss for 1970 will approximate $2.7million, primarily resulting from extraordinary items and losses from discontinued opera tions. Thomas K. Scallon, presi dent, said final audited figures were expected to be available within two weeks.

Stone, was called to the Foreign Min istry today for clarification of a report in The New York Times that two Pakistani ships had sailed from American ports carrying United States military equipment, including aircraft and spare parts for army ve hicles.

title: Article 10  No Title

description: The State Supreme Court is sued a temporary injunction yesterday against the further operation of a Manhattan abor tion clinic on the ground that it had violated state health and business corporation laws.

title: Personal Finance
description: Watch out for the sharks in your swimming pool.

title: Nixon TV Speech July 3 Will Open Bicentennial
description: President Nixon will speak on television Saturday, July 3, opening the nation's bi centennial celebration. The address will be carried live on television and radio from 10:30 to 11 P.M.

title: Pakistani Areas Inspected
description: UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 23The United Nations High Commissioner for Refu gees said here today that he had made helicopter inspec tions of areas disrupted by civil strife in East Pakistan and had found that life is slowly returning to normal.

title: Major Impact onthe U.S. By Market Pact Doubted
description: WASHINGTON, June 23  The impact on the United States of the prospective Brit ish entry into the European Common Market will in no event be rapid and may never be very large.

title: Capra, 74, Looks Back at Film Career
description: You know what I tell people today about the scar city of laughterof real comedyon the screen? mused Frank Capra. When people say to me, especially the young moviemakers, What is there to laugh at? I say, Look at yourself in the mirror. Mr. Capra smiled, as did most of his best known pictures.

title: Riegel Suing ExCellO
description: The Riegel Paper Corporation said yesterday it had filed a tripledamage patent infringe ment suit against the ExCellO Corporation alleging violation of its patent on a flattopped container with a reclosable spout.

title: Jersey Defendant Says Money He Received Was Contribution
description: NEWARK, June 23Walter Wolfe, the 48yearold Hudson County Democratic chairman, testified today that any money he might have handled in an alleged kickback conspiracy he understood to be contribu tions to the Democratic Party for Christmas Parties or politi cal dinners.

title: Arson Sentencing Put Off Pending Bribery Inquiry
description: The sentencing of a convicted arsonist was postponed here yesterday in State Supreme Court pending the outcome of an investigation into his charges that he had bribed court officers and an assistant district attorney to take care of everything.

title: Inaction on Credit Laws Is Conceded
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 The Federal regulatory authori ties acknowledged today that national banks were not po liced for possible violations of state laws against unfair con sumer credit practices.

title: MRS. ANNA SILVERY, LAWYER HERE, 71
description: LARCHMONT, N. Y., June 23 Mrs. Anna Seidenstein Silver, a Manhattan lawyer and for mer president of the Larchmont and Westchester County League of Women Voters, died yester day in Montefiore Hospital, the Bronx, after a short illness. She was 71 years old and lived at 21 North Chatsworth Avenue with her husband, Frederick Silver, Who was also her law partner.

title: MRS. GOODFRIEND
description: Mrs. Blanche Weiss Good friend, Wife of George Good friend, former president and chairman of Holly Stores, since 1965 a subsidiary of S. S. Kres ge Company, died yesterday in Beth Israel Hospital after a short illness. She was 61 years old and lived in Essex House.

title: DISCUSSION URGED ON DOLLAR'S ROLE
description: WASHINGTON, June 23A former high Government official proposed today that the United States for the first time offer to negotiate the special role of the dollar in the world mone tary system.

title: Flag Honoring Hero Stolen
description: NORWALK, Conn., June 23 An American flag was reported stolen today from the flagpole of the Pfc. Daniel J. Shea Memorial here. The memorial, at Calf Pasture Beach, honors a posthumous winner of the Medal of Honor in Vietnam and 15 others who were killed there. The Honor America Committee has offered a $100 reward for the flag's return.

title: In '51, Nixon Criticized Truman Secrecy on Korea
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP) Twenty years ago, Richard M. Nixon accused the Truman Administration of holding back classified documents for political rea sons.

title: Johnson Trip Cited
description: CHICAGO, Thursday, June 24 (UPI)The Chicago SunTimes said today that President John F. Kennedy sent Vice President Lyndon B. Johnson to Saigon in May, 1961, to persuade South Vietnam to request United States ground troops.

title: OLYMPICS INTERRUPT COSMOS' STREAK, 31
description: MONTREAL, June 23Keith Wallace scored two firsthalf goals tonight to, spark the Montreal Olympics to a 31 up set victory over the New York Cosmos before 3,200 fans at the Autostade.

title: Cambodians Report Headquarters Lost By Enemy Regiment
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 23 (AP)The Cambodian com mand said today that its troops had overrun a North Vietnam ese regimental headquarters within 15 miles of Pnompenh and had inflicted heavy cas ualties.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 (UPI)  Murray L. Weiden baum, the Administration's leading expert on revenue sharing, has resigned from Government service, the White House announced today. No successor was named.

title: Deduction for City Tax To Increase 2.6 Times
description: Mayor Lindsay said yes terday that the withholding of the city income tax and commuter earnings levy would be collected at 2.6 times the current rate for the next six months to pay for the retroactive increases in the city income tax adopt ed by the City Council late Tuesday.

title: Pressure Maintained Near DMZ
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, June 24 (AP)North Vietnamese forces were report ed keeping up pressure on allied outposts south of the de militarized zone yesterday, while fighting elsewhere in South Vietnam subsided into small and scattered skirmishes.

title: Arrests of Bengalis Reported
description: DACCA, Pakistan, June 23 Reports spread through Dacca today that a large number of Bengalissome reports put the figures as high as 400had been arrested by the army dur ing the night.

title: BELL THEATER PLANS 7 SPECIALS FOR FALL
description: The Bell System Family Theater will begin its second season on the National Broad casting Companys television network in the fall with a series of seven specials, it was announced yesterday by John M. Otter, N.B.C. sales vice president, and Ed Block, assist ant vice president of the Ameri can Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: MADDOX MAY JOIN PRIMARIES IN '72
description: ATLANTA, June 23Lieut. Gov. Lester G. Maddox of Georgia, whose combination of segregationist and populist ap peals has proved widely popu lar in this state, has tentatively decided to enter two and pos sibly three Presidential pri maries in the South next year.

title: A Love Story of a Western:Holden and O'Neal Star in 'Wild Rovers'
description: "Wild Rovers" is about a couple of good-natured, none-too-bright Montana cowboys who, on the spur of the moment (and with a fine lack of reluctance), rob a small-town bank of $36,000 and then take off, in the direction of Mexico, with some vague idea of finding a cowboy paradise.As might be expected of Blake Edwards, a director and a writer whose strengths are in romantic comedy ("Darling Lili"), in farce ("A Shot in the Dark") and in his own sophistication, "Wild Rovers' is a very odd, very peculiar Western. It uses just about an of the conventions known to the genrefrom barroom brawls and crooked poker games to pursuing posses and passive prostitutesto tell what is essentially a love story. It is, however, a love story in which the only real love takes the form of the idealized comradeship of two men.Although the film, which opened yesterday at the Astor, Juliet 2 and 34th Street East Theaters, is rather long on narrative detail of no great excitement, it's made interesting, at least for me, by its conflicting impulses toward low comedy, realism, adventure and myth. It is, I suspect, exactly the sort of Western that someone who's never tried one before would elect to makea first meal by a cook whose enthusiasms range from bitter melon soup to pche Melba.Ross Bodine (William Holden), pushing 50 and with nothing to show for it except the lines in his face, and Frank Post (Ryan O'Neal), who is half Ross's age, short-tempered, affectionate and tough, are William Remington cowboys, without pasts or futures. They are men who exist only in terms of their jobs. Their mistake, prompted by the accidental death of a friend, and some rather comic musings on their own mortality, comes when they attempt to alter fate.They have no great difficulty in knocking over the bank, but it is apparent, as soon as they do, that they are lost cowboys, doomed not by the posse that follows them but by their own witlessnesses.Holden, who is aging with immense vigor as an actor, and O'Neal, who has what is basically the role that Ali MacGraw played in "Love Story," are most engaging as the odd couple on the range, a relationship that Edwards defines in a slow-motion montage that is more legitimately dramatic than lyrically effective: as Holden sets about to break a wild bronc, O'Neal, who is watching, turns somersaults in the snow in the kind of love dance that Arthur Hiller staged earlier in Harvard Yard.Life was tough in the Old West, Edwards seems to say, and love had a way of getting worn out early or misplaced. The young 0'Neal almost kills a man who wants to take his dog away from him. Leora Dana, as the wife of the rancher for whom Holden and O'Neal work, allows her husband (Karl Malden) to dominate their sons, and blame her for their faults. In extremis, a puppy must be nursed by a mother cat.It is possible, as you might have guessed by this time, to read all sorts of things into "Wild Rovers," which makes it worthy of the attention of film aficionados, though less committed audiences may well become restless.The film is magnificently set in Western locations that lead, finally, to that greatest set of all (built, you might believe, for John Ford), that is, Monument Valley. It is an appropriate backdrop for the conclusion of a film that is more compelling as the work of a specific director (whose thoughts have here turned west) than as an isolated entertainment, as an end in itself.

title: Negotiations at Luxembourg Were Long and Tough
description: LUXEMBOURG, June 23 Just a month ago in Paris, Prime Minister Heath and President Pompidou reached agreements that virtually assured successtin the 10yearold effort of Britain to join the Common Market.

Some of the results were arrived at in unexpected ways, but form prevailed throughout.

description: WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP)  Domestic steel producers turned out 12,940,000 tons of steel in May, the highest one month total ever, the American Iron and Steel Institute re ported today.

title: Article 9  No Title
Schlesinger: Truth or Reputation?
description: In seeking to suppress the Vietnam documents, the United States Govern ment asserted that their continued pub lication in The New York Times would cause irreparable injury to the de fense interests of the United States. If this assertion were true, then the case against publication would have been strong indeed. The protection of military security constitutes an entirely proper limitation on the freedom of the press and on the people's right to know. When on Dec. 4, 1941, three days before Pearl Harbor, the Chicago Tribune published the secret Army war plans; When on June 7, 1942, dur ing the battle of Midway, a Chicago Tribune story revealed that we had broken the Japanese naval codes, these were disclosures that might well have caused irreparable injury to the de fense interests of the United States.

title: Quebec Premier Thwarts a New Canadian Charter
description: OTTAWA, June 23The Que bec provincial government to day rejected a federally spon sored draft for a new Cana dian constitution, in effect killing Prime Minister Pierre El liott Trudeau's efforts to unite Canada in a federation freed of ties to the British Parlia Ment.

title: Market Place: Sludge Removal At Lake Argued

title: Steve McQueen, a Racing-Car Buff, Sets Pace in 'Le Mans'
description: Racing-car buffs will probably flip over "Le Mans." The color photography of this film, encompassing every conceivable technical aspect of this world-famous competition, is dazzling. Thanks to director Lee H. Katzin and his semi-documentary framework, and to a pair of ace cameramen, you are really there, roaring around the road web centering on Le Mans, the French village hub.And let's say this for Steve McQueen, a noted speed wheeler off the screen: The actor, who is the only familiar name in the cast, looks perfectly at home behind his wheel here.But the star's exchange of monosyllabic utterances and long, meaningful stares with other drivers, and especially with Elga Andersen, a sensitive-faced blonde, add up to tepid, monotonous drama during the two-day race intervals. Dramatically, the picture is a bore. And neither the oblique approach to these time-out sequences nor a ripe score by Michel Legrand manages to juice things up.The sound-track roar of the motors eventually becomes a long drone as the picture levels off episodically. Harry Kleiner's script does hold one interesting exchange of dialogue between McQueen and Miss Andersen.What's so important about driving faster than anyone else?" asks the girl, widowed by a previous race. "It's life," says McQueen. "Anything that happens before or after is just waiting." What a life!

title: Birth Pangs of a New Era
description: The longoverdue treaty pledging the return of Okinawa to Japan next year, signed in Washington and Tokyo last week, has been hailed by Premier Sato as marking the birth of a new era of Japanese American cooperation. This is perhaps an overoptimistic assessment of proceedings that were flawed on both sides of the Pacific, that still must be ratified by the legislative bodies of both countries and that, at best, will only clear the way for attacks on a host of new tests of JapaneseAmerican friendship.

title: Eroding the Tax Base

The Treasury has sought to buttress its new rules against legal challenge by linking the useful lives of plant and equipment as claimed for depreciation purposes to the actual lives of such assets.

title: Man In the News

Mr. Sprague, the first assistant district attorney of the city and county of Phila delphia, entered the Yablonski case 18 months ago with a record of more than 10,000 criminal prosecutions.

title: G. I.'s in Vietnam Say Test for Heroin Addiction Can Be Beaten

title: Merger News

The inlaw in this case was the British Petroleum Company, Ltd. Burmah holds 23 per cent of B.P.'s common stock. The ex change of these shares for B.P. as sets, particularly oil and gas re serves and exploration acreage, was considered the essential element of the proposed merg er, which would have formed the world's eighth largest oil company. The companies de clined to give any reason for the termination stating simply that they had been unable to develop a mutually acceptable basis for combination.

title: Screen:
