description: A policeman shot and killed one of three muggers who were attempting to rob a Greek sailor on a Harlem street corner last night, the police said.

title: Keino Wins 1,500Meter Run
description: AARHUS, Denmark, June 23 (AP)Kipchoge Keino, Kenya's Olympic champion, won the 1,500meter run tonight in 3 minutes 26.9 seconds at an in ternational track and field meet, the fastest time recorded in the world this year. In the same meet, inaugurating the first Tartan stadium in Den mark, Jay Silvester, a world recordholder from the United States, beat Rielly Bruch of Sweden, throwing the discus 216 feet 11 inches against Bruch's 208 feet 2 inches.

title: A Decline in Costs For Home Loans Reported in May
description: WASHINGTON, June 23 (AP)  Conventional home mortgages costs dropped slightly in May, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board re ported today, with some indi cation that rates could rise in the months ahead.

title: LOUIS LECOIN DEAD; FRENCH PACIFIST, 83
description: PARIS, June 23Louis Le coin, who has been described as France's most militant paci fist, died today in a hospital at suburban PavilionsSousBois after surgery. He was 83 years old.

title: 2 Share Sweepstakes Prize
description: CHICAGO, June 23 (UPI) Albert Caldwell, an unemployed cab driver, and Mrs. Robbie J. Williams, an unemployed wait ress receiving $14.50 a month from the welfare department, shared the super prize of $480,000 today in the Irish Sweepstakes draw. Mr. Cald well, 37 years old, bought the winning ticket for Mrs. Wil liams, whose name was pulled from a revolving drum contain ing 4,554,560 tickets through out the world.

title: Dance: Balanchine's A Mid summer Night's Dream
description: George Balanchine's full length ballet A Midsummer Night's Dream came back last night to the State Theater. The annual series of seven performances will wind up the New York City Ballet's spring season on Sunday night.

title: The Prosecutor in Illinois Panther Raid Case Cleared of Contempt
description: CHICAGO, June 23  The Illinois Supreme Court reversed today the contempt citation against the special prosecutor in the case of a Black Panther raid for refusing a judge's order to call additional wit nesses and voided a $50an hour, aroundtheclock fine against him.

title: U.S. Acts on Guard's Filling of Marsh
description: In what may be the first Federal action to protect the ecology of a tidal marsh, the Government sought an injunc tion yesterday to prevent the New York National Guard from dumping debris into a marsh near Camp Smith. The camp is near Peekskill, N.Y.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Interpace Raising Prices In Lapp Insulator Division
description: The Lapp Insulator division of the Interpace Corporation said yesterday that it would in crease prices on some insulator products and hardware by 6 to 7 per cent, effective July 12.

title: Grand Jury Questions Another Friend of Ellsberg
description: LOS ANGELES, June 24A Federal grand jury that is in vestigating the disclosure of a secret Pentagon study on Viet nam focused today on the activities of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg.

title: F.T.C. Asks Warning in Cigarette Ads
description: WASHINGTON, June 24  The Federal Trade Commission disclosed today that it would take action next week to force the six major cigarette manu facturers to include clear and conspicuous health warnings in their advertisements.

title: Mafia Suspects Moved From Tiny Italian Isle
description: FILICUDI, Italy, June 24 (UPI)Fifteen reputed Mafia leaders exiled 29 days ago to this tiny island in the Tyr rhenian Sea were removed today by the police while islanders cheered.

title: Margo Coleman Is Wed in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, June 24Mar go Coleman, who writes a column of social commen tary for The Chicago Daily News, was married at Sinai Temple here this afternoon to Jules L. Furth, president of Furth & Co., funeral direc tors. Rabbis Sam Karff and Simeon Maslin officiated.

title: PAPER ON COAST ESCAPES ACTION
description: The Justice Department an nounced yesterday that it would not take legal action at this time against The Los Angeles Times and the 11 newspaper Knight chain, which yesterday published articles said to be based on secret Gov ernment documents.

title: LE ROI OPERTI DIES; SINGER AND ACTOR
description: Le Roi Operti, a singer and actor whose career spanned 57 years, died on Tuesday at Roosevelt Hospital after a long illness. He was 75 year old.

title: MOVE TO PAY I.L.O. REJECTED BY HOUSE
description: WASHINGTON, June 24  The House of Representatives rejected today an amendment to an appropriations bill that would have authorized the United States payment of dues owed to the International Labor Organization.

title: DERWENT AWARDS GO TO TWO ACTORS HERE
description: Two Off Broadway perform ers were chosen yesterday as this season's winners of the Clarence Derwent awards for best individual male and female supporting roles.

title: Results Expected Today In Coast Dock Strike Vote
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 24 The International Longshore men's and Warehousemen's Union will announce tomorrow the result of a vote among its 15,000 members from Seattle to San Diego on authorization to call a West Coast dock strike after the present contract ex pires June 30.

title: MRS. C. ALSOP COLE, MOTHER OF WRITERS
description: AVON, Conn., June 24Mrs. Corinne Alsop Cole, the head of a family long prominent in Connecticut Republican politics and the mother of Joseph and Stewart Alsop, the columnists, died last night at her home here. She was 84 years old.

title: Cruguet Rides Princess Pout, $4.40, to Length Victory on Belmont's Turf
description: Jean Cruguet, the Parisian jockey who does so well in grass races, guided June Mc Knight's Princess Pout to vic tory in the main event at Bel mont Park yesterday.

title: Common Market Panel Mapping A Curb of Hot Money Into Bloc
description: BRUSSELS, June 24  The European Common Market Commission has put forward plans for discouraging the flow of hot money into community countries, and for limiting the harm these flows do to anti inflationary policies pursued by governments of the sixnation unit.

title: Preserve the S.I. Ferry
description: The City Council has wisely rejected the Lindsay administration's proposal that the fare on the Staten Island ferry leap from a nickel to an unconscionable 25 cents. An increase to a dime would have made sense, but it did not become the Council's fallback position. Now a more important issue remains: the gradual erosion in ferry service in the last few years as the economic screws have tightened.

title: Merger News
description: A long fight for control of the $1billion Security National Bank, Huntington, L. I., ap peared to have come to an end yesterday. The Abacus Fund, Inc., the bank's largest stock holder, announced that it had agreed to sell its 766,710 shares of Securityroughly 25 per cent of the total outstand ingfor $43 a share, or almost $33million.

title: Retail Group Names Aide
description: Richard I. Hersh has been named executive vice president of the Metropolitan New York Retail Merchants Association, succeeding John E. Hopkins Jr., who has resigned. Mr. Hersh was previously director of gov ernmental relations for Ag way, Inc., Syracuse, and before that had been assistant direc tor of governmental relations for the National Retail Furni ture Association, Washington.

title: DANCE ENSEMBLE SHOWS OWN WORK
description: The members of the N.Y.U. Dance Ensemble obviously know, respect and admire one Mothers' skills, and Wednes day evening they prepared a program of dances featuring themselves and invited the Public to the School of Arts Theater. The tonality was warm and humorous and the perform ers, Nora Guthrie, Rachel Lam pert, Andrea Stark, Ted Ro tante and Byron Wheeler, were ?? coy and generally engag ing.

title: SAIGON RETAKES KEY BASE AT DMZ
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Fri day, June 25Fresh South Viet namese troops were flown in American helicopters to the bombshattered Firebase Fuller and retook the mountaintop position early this morning, just a day after it had fallen to North Vietnamese troops.

title: If Only Liberace Would Quilt the Roof of His Car
description: Even the dogs were curi ous yesterday morning when five VISTA workers draped their paneled truck in boldly patterned patchwork before taking to the streets of New York in search of store buy ers.

title: Samuel Friedwald, 68, Head Of Candy Equipment Firm
description: Samuel H. Friedwald, a lawyer and president of the American Chocolate Mould Company, 173 Lafayette Street, died Wednesday night in South Nassau Community Hospital, Oceanside, L.I. He was 65 years old and lived at 70 East 10th Street and in Hollywood, Fla.

title: 5 SENATORS BACK PEKING SEAT IN U.N.
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 Five liberal Senators  four Democrats and one Republican called on the United States, today to change its longstand ing policy and press for the admission of Communist China to the United Nations.

title: Medical Investment Draws S.E.C. Suspension on Audit
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP)  The Securities and Exchange Commission has ordered a 10 day suspension of overthe counter trading in securities of the Medical Investment Corpo ration, Minneapolis, for failure to supply audited financial statements required by the reg ulatory agency.

title: The War: The Record and the U.S.
description: WASHINGTONThere is not the slightest doubt in my mind that The New York Times will receive many journalistic awards for its publication of the Pentagon Papers on Indochina. After all, a scoop that runs a million and a half words is not exactly to be sneezed at in journalistic circles.

title: Mayor Acts On Charges Of Secrecy
description: J. Lee Rankin, the city's Corporation Counsel, was di rected by Mayor Lindsay yes terday to review procedures of all city agencies with rule making functions to insure that their meetings are open to the public.

title: HEINZ'S EARNINGS INCREASE BY 15.6%
description: The H. J. Heinz Company realized a 15.6 per cent in crease in earnings for the fis cal year ended April 28, set ting a record for the eighth consecutive year, the food proc essing company reported yes terday from its Pittsburgh headquarters.

title: SovietIraqi Pact Signed
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 24 (AP)The Soviet Union and Iraq have signed a protocol of cooperation, the Baghdad radio reported today.

title: Nonplaying Member
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) President Nixon was made an honorary member of the Na tional Football League Players Association today.

title: Bridge:Scientific Bidding Nets Slam, But Bashing Can Get Results
description: Two approaches to slam bidding are usually available: careful science and carefree bashing. There is something to be said for both methods, and the diagramed deal illus trates this. It was played in the semifinal of the Reisinger Knockout Team Champion ship here earlier this month.

title: Business Is Dandy at the Union Pacific
description: NEWARK, June 24While many major railroads are com plaining that business is softer than they had anticipated, the head of the Union Pacific Rail road said here today that his system's business right now is dandy.

title: Excerpts From Petition to High Court by The Times
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 Following are excerpts from the petition by The New York Times to the Supreme Court for review:

title: Airlift Stock Is Delisted
description: Airlift International, Inc., one of the hot stocks traded on the American Stock Exchange prior to the market slide that began late in 1968, will be de listed as a result of a vote yesterday by the Amex board of governors.

title: 3 G.I.'s Killed in Germany
description: ASCHAFFENBURG, West Ger many, June 24 (Reuters)  Three United States soldiers were killed when their tank plunged 35 yards to the ground off a highway bridge near this Bavarian town today, the po lice said.

title: US. Is Enjoined in ShipSubsidy Case
description: The Maritime Administration has been enjoined from paying an unspecified portion of $36.8 million in operating subsidies due eight major steamship lines.

title: Trade Conflict With Japan
description: The most troublesome problems between Japan and the United States remain those in the economic area. The Japanese textile industry has said it would put into effect July 1 its program of selfrestraint on textile ex ports to the United States. Under this program, overall Japanese textile shipments to this country would grow by 5 per cent in the next twelve months and by 6 per cent in each of the following two years, but there would be no specific quotas on categories of products.

title: Economic Parley Urged
description: GENEVA, June 24A member of President Nixon's Commis sion on International Trade and Investment Policy urged today the launching at the highest political level of a major inter national economic negotiation.

title: Riessen Tops Ashe, Gains Round of 16
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 24  Gone from Wimbledon tonight was Arthur Ashe, the fifthseeded player and former United States champion, felled by the hammer blows of Marty Riessen, the pros' pro.

title: Miller and Freed Brazilian Discuss New Satire Genre
description: Arthur Miller, the Ameri can playwright, and Augusto Boal, a leading stage director in Brazil met the other day to talk about newspaper the ater, a form of revolutionary satire gaining wide popularity in Latin America as a means of outwitting Government censorship.

title: Shanker Accuses A District in Bronx Of Racist Policies
description: Albert Shanker, president of the United Federation of Teachers, demanded yesterday an immediate investigation of allegedly racist activities by Andrew G. Donaldson, the superintendent of Community School District 9 in the Bronx.

title: Restless U.S. Youths Surging Into Copenhagen
description: COPENHAGEN, Denmark, June 21 Thousands of young Americans, anxious about, their inability to find jobs at home, have swarmed into Copenhagen far the start of a muted and surprisingly som bet summer holiday.

title: Law Student Weds Sherry Starkman
description: Miss Sherry Beth Stark man and Kenneth M. Endel son were married here yes terday evening at the Plaza by Rabbi Judah Nadich.

title: Notes on People
description: The Archbishop of Newport, Wales, said yesterday that he had recently considered making a national television comeback, but that not enough stations in the United States were interested.

title: 5,000 in Hartford Protest Meskill's Fiscal Program
description: HARTFORD, June 241n a demonstration mounted by the insurance industry, more than 5,000 people marched on the State Capitol here to day to protest Gov. Thomas J. Meskill's tax program.

title: MRS. HART GAINS GOLF FINAL AGAIN
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 24 Mrs. A. Sherburne Hart of Baltusrol and Mrs. William Tracy of Essex Fells will meet in the 36hole final of the 68th annual Women's Metropolitan Golf Association championship tomorrow.

title: Meyner Clashes With Prosecutor in Jersey Trial
description: NEWARK, June 24  For mer Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey and defense law yers clashed with the Federal prosecutor here today at the conspiracyextortion trial of eight Jersey City and Hudson County officials.

title: Palafox, Ross, Schwartz Gain Semifinals in Tennis
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., June 24Jayson Schwartz of Roslyn won two matches to reach the semifinals of the Eastern men's claycourt tennis championship at the Port Washington Tennis Academy today.

title: A Cut Force Is Checking City Stores
description: The city's job freeze has reduced the force of Con sumer Affairs Department Inspectors from 200 to 80 during the last two years, the agency's Commissioner, Bess Myerson, disclosed yes terday.

title: Bronx Prosecutor And Brother Seize A Narcotic Suspect
description: An alliance between two brothers in public service  one the Bronx District At torney, the other an official of the city's Department of Cor rectionresulted yesterday in the arrest of a prison guard accused of trafficking in nar cotics.

title: Miss Stewart in Final
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., June 24Pat Stewart of New York and Marilyn Aschner of Holliswood, Queens, reached the final of the Long Island women's tennis championship today. Miss Stewart, the defender, defeated Mrs. Adria Price of Roslyn Heights, 61, 61, and Miss Aschner ousted Mary Nammack of Oyster Bay, 63, 61.

title: Tax Details Issued by City For Workers and Buyers
description: Details of the city's new withholding tax rates were made public yesterday, along with the impact of the new cigarette tax and the pos sibility of an expansion of the new plasticcontainer tax.

title: Commodity Price Index Up 1.1 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials rose to 108.9 from 107.8 last week.

title: Jaywalkers Beat AutosSometimes
description: Pausing at the curb, flash ing a glance to her right, Barbara Lynn cut across Madison Avenue in a slow, ladylike gait in midblock yes terday morning. Then she saw the taxi headed toward her.

title: 3d ArmsCargo Ship to Pakistan Noted
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 The State Department said to day that a third Pakistani freighter loaded with military equipment sailed from New York for Karachi after the United States had banned de liveries of arms to Pakistan.

title: Coast Tunnel Blast Traps 18; Bodies of Six Recovered
description: LOS ANGELES, June 24A powerful explosion early this morning trapped 18 workmen behind a wall of fire and dense smoke in a tunnel under con struction in suburban Sylmar. Six bodies have been re covered and littel hope was held out for 11 other workman.

title: EXCHANGE HERE GETS ITS FIRST BLACK FIRM
description: Daniels & Bell, Inc., was voted into membership on the New York Stock Exchange yes terday, becoming the first blackoperated member firm in the history of the Exchange. The concern's plans to join the Exchange had been disclosed earlier.

title: U.S. Deaths in Combat Pat at 25 Last Week
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tune 24 (UPI)The United States command reported to day that 25 Americans died in combat in Indochina last week. This was the same number as the previous week and well under the average of 46 a week so far this year.

title: Louis XVI Writing Table Sold For $415,800, a World Record
description: LONDON, June 24A Lou is XVI writing table was auc tioned here today for $415,800, more than twice the previous world record price for a piece of furniture.

title: FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARISWho is doing what to whom and why in Madagascar is a question deeply disturbing to several capitals and especially to Washington which has been accused of fomenting a conspiracy against President Phili bert Tsiranana. One consequence of this murky tale of plot and counter plot is that U.S. Ambassador Anthony Marshall is being quietly withdrawn.

title: China Easing Severe Restrictions on Foreign Newsmen
description: CANTON, China, June 24  The Goverment eased some of its restrictions on the activities of American newsmen in China during my visit, allowing broader access to information and more ex tensive travel.

title: The War: The Record and the U.S.
description: CAMBRIDGE, MassEverything se cret degenerates, was Lord Acton's warning. Sunlight is the most powerful of disinfectants, was Justice Brandeis' admonition. But concrete issues of dis closure and secrecy have a way of making even the most ardent liber tarians see that the right to know is not onedimensional, all warp and no woof. Brandeis himself was the intel lectual father of a legal right of privacy.

title: Arab Given Life Sentence
description: TEL AVIV, June 24For the first time since Israel occupied the Gaza Strip in 1967, a life sentence was imposed there today by a military court for armed infiltration. The pris oner, Ibrahim Ahmed Kablan, was said to have commanded Arab guerrilla groups that shelled the Israeli towns of Beisan and Kiryat Shmona from Jordanian territory.

title: Maryann Allgaier Bride of Newsman
description: SHREWSBURY, Mass., June 24Miss Maryann Allgaier, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ed ward A. Allgaier, was mar ried here today to Howard F. Angione, a newsmaneditor at the control desk of The Associated Press headquar ters in New York.

title: Summer and Smoke Bows as an Opera
description: ST. PAUL, June 24Min nesota's Twin Cities are do ing very well by opera. The Center Opera of Minneapolis has made some highly pro vocative experiments with the form, and this summer is touring two of its produc tions on the East Coast, Faust Counter Faust by John Gessner and H. Wesley Balk and The Mother of Us All, the old but still avant garde work of Virgil Thom son and Gertrude Stein.

title: Reform Jewish Rabbis Elect New President
description: ST. LOUIS, June 24The Central Conference of Ameri can Rabbis, the rabbinic arm of American Reform Juda ism, today elected Rabbi David Polish of Evanston, Ill., as president.

title: Washington: For the Record
Nagle Finishes With 62 For British Senior Title
description: ELIE, Scotland, June 24 (UPI)Kel Nagle of Australia smashed the 6,294yard Elie course record with a final round, 8under par 62 today in winning the British senior professional golf champion ship. The 50yearold Nagle carded a thirdround 69, then his 62 for a 72hole total of 269.

title: BONN MOVES TO BUY U.S. PHANTOM JETS
description: BONN, June 24The Defense Committee of the West German Bundestag or parliament, ap proved today the purchase of $1.1billion worth of Phantom F4E reconnaissanc aircraft from the United States.

title: World Bank Sets 4 Loans
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 (Reuters)The World Bank said today it had approved four loans totaling $88.7mil lion for projects in South Korea ($54.5million), Ivory Coast ($20.5milion), Guinea ($9million) and Liberia ($4.7 million). The loans are for as long as 24 years at 7 per cent interest.

title: Equity Settles Tentatively With Theaters
description: A tentative agreement on terms of a new threeyear Broadway production con tract was reached early yes terday morning by Actors Equity Association and the League of New York Thea ters.

title: 965321 Wins in Jersey
description: ATLANTIC CITY, June 24, (AP)  The winner number in this week's New Jersey lot tery is 965321. Holders of tickets with all six numbers in the correct order win $50,000, with the last five numbers $4,000, the last four $400 and the last three $40.

title: Farmer Goes to Michigan
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich., June 24 (AP)Dixon Farmer, track coach at Occidental College since 1967, was named track coach at the University of Michigan today, succeeding Dave Martin, who has taken a university administration position.

title: 3 Boats Missing as Fog Hampers Trysail Race
description: BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., June 24Itching to go after three days of nonracing, a huge fleet of nearly 200 boats played hideandseek today in the fog that has plagued Block Island all week.

title: HEAD OF SCHOOLS QUITS DISTRICT 23
description: Mrs. Nellie R. Duncan has re signed as superintendent of Community School District 23 in Brooklyn after a threemonth controversy in which she was charged by the district board with misusing $18,000 in Fed eral education funds.

title: 4 MISSING IN BLAZE ON VESSEL IN YARD
description: LORAIN, Ohio, June 24 (AP) Four workmen were missing and feared dead today as fire fed by oil from a broken fuel line, raged in the engine room of the $20million ore carrier Roger Blough being built by the American Ship Building Company.

title: Boston Mayor to Run Again
description: BOSTON, June 24 (AP) Mayor Kevin H. White an nounced today his candidacy for reelection. He was elected to his first term in 1967.

title: Stake in Texas Bank Sold
description: W. W. Overton, instrumental in building the Texas Bank & Trust Company to the largest state chartered institution in the state, has sold a 12 per cent interest to a group of Dallas investors for about $2 million, it was announced yes terday.

title: A.M.A. Divided by Appeal To Give Role to Young Men
description: ATLANTIC CITY, June 24 The American Medical Asso ciation's annual convention ended in confusion today after a rift opened among the new president, the presidentelect, the board of trustees and the policymaking House of Dele gates.

title: Secrecy Label Is Used Too Often By Pentagon, ExAide Testifies
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 A recently retired civil ser vant who spent many years in the Pentagon reviewing the classification of sensitive docu ments asserted today that only one half of 1 per cent of them contained genuine secrets that should be kept from the public.

title: VESCO IS ON BOARD OF I.O.S. OFFSHOOT
description: GENEVA, June 24Robert L. Vesco, president of the Inter national Controls Corporation, and Richard E. Clay, a mem ber of the company's board, have become board members of Global Natural Resources Properties, Ltd., an offshoot of Investors Overseas Services.

title: Kennedy Asks Action on Children's TV
description: Senator Edward M. Kennedy, who was unable to attend, summed up the feelings of many who did attend the final session of a twoday seminar on children's programing yes terday when he called for a clear commitment to action.

title: Pele Here for Game in Jersey Amid Complaints
description: Even the nondrinkers at Leone's sounded intoxicated yesterday as they waited for the King to arrive from Toronto.

title: Corona to Leave Hospital
description: YUBA CITY, Calif., June 24 (UPI)Doctors said today that Juan V. Corona, suspect in the mass murder of itinerant farm workers here, had suffered no heart damage and was well enough to be returned to jail from the Sutter County Gen eral Hospital. Sheriff Roy White aker said Mr. Corona would be brought back to the Yuba County jail in Marysville to morrow. He has been undergo ing tests since he was taken to the hospital a week ago complaining of chest pains.

title: Minor Leaguers Beat Yanks
description: ROCHESTER, June 24 (AP) The International League All Stars pounded three Yankee pitchers for 17 hits, then held on to defeat New York, 1513, tonight. A crowd of 11,001 saw the Stars slam three home runs and take a 157 lead. George Pena of Syracuse drove in five runs.

title: Fish Dish: It's Pure Poetry
description: The restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated both for their food (four stars to none) and for their service, atmosphere and dcor (four triangles to none).

title: U.S. LOSES IN MOVE TO CURB POST
description: WASHINGTON, June 24  The Justice Department failed today to win a new hearing in the Court of Appeals on its ef fort to stop The Washington Post from resuming publication of information contained in the secret Pentagon study of the Vietnam war.

title: Railroad Freight Traffic Down by 3.4% for Week
description: WASHINGTON, June 24  Freight traffic on United States railroads in the latest week ended June 19 totaled an esti mated 15 billion tonmiles, 3.4 per cent below the correspond ing week a year ago. The As sociation of American Rail roads also reported that load ings in the same week totaled 526,564 cars, a decrease of 37, 044, or 6.6 per cent below the same period last year, largely due to wildcat strikes in the bituminous coal fields.

title: Jack Goode, a Veteran Player In Musical Comedies, 63, Dies
description: Jack Goode, a musical comedy performer who had ap peared in leading roles in many major productions in this city, on tour and abroad, died yester day at Doctors Hospital. He was 63 years old and had lived for many years in French town, N. J.

title: Explosion and Fire Rip Hercules Plastics Plant in New Jersey
description: SAYREVILLE, N.J., June 24 Flames reaching almost 100 feet into the sky cast a fiery glow for miles tonight after an explosion ripped through a plastics manufacturing plant of Hercules, Inc., in this residen tial community.

title: American Officials Score Trading Practices Abroad
description: WASHINGTON, June 24  Two high Government officials renewed today the refrain of criticism of some trading policies of the European Common Market, Japan and Canada. Paul A. Volcker, Under Sec retary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, and Na thaniel Samuels, Deputy Un der Secretary of State for Economic Affairs, testified before a subcommittee of the Joint Economic Committee seeking to explore the general problem of foreign economic policy in the coming decade.

title: Blast Witness Is Indicted in a Bombing Plot Here
description: Leslie Bacon, a material wit ness in the March 1 bombing of the Capitol in Washington, was indicted by a Federal grand jury here yesterday and charged with conspiring to firebomb a Manhattan bank.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Executive Changes
description: AMP, Inc., has elected Joseph D. Brenner as president. Mr. Brenner, formerly vice president of operations, succeeds S. S. Auchincloss who was elected vice chairman and continues as chief executive officer. C. J. Frederickson, formerly vice president and chief financial officer was elected chairman of the finance committee, a new post.

title: City's Hospital Chief Promises Better Jobs to Minority Groups
description: Dr. Joseph T. English, presi dent of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, said yes terday that he was totally dis satisfied with the corporation's practices on the hiring of mem bers of minority groups. He said he would take immediate steps to bring blacks and Puer to Ricans into toplevel policy making jobs.

title: Panel Favors Ending Elite Doctors' Corps in Public Health Service
description: WASHINGTON, June 24  The Commissioned Corps of the Public Health Service, the elite cadre of Federal doctors for almost a century, would be abolished if the Nixon Admin istration took the advice of an advisory committee report that was made public today.

title: SENATE APPROVES DRAFT EXTENSION FOR 2 MORE YEARS
description: WASHINGTON, June 24The Senate passed today the bill continuing the military draft for two more years.

title: Weekend Fishing and Boating
description: Fishing Report

title: Man in the News
description: Frank Stanton came to New York in a Model A Ford in 1935, spent his first night at a Y.M.C.A. and swiftly earned a reputation as the boy wonder of broadcasting.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: New Underground ATest
description: MERCURY, Nev., June 24 (AP)Another underground nu clear blast, the second test in two days, was set off today under the Nevada desert as part of the United States atom ic weapons development pro gram, the Atomic Energy Com mission announced. The atomic device, described as having a force of between 20,000 and 200,000 tons of TNT, was ex ploded at 7 A.M. without any problems, the A.E.C. said.

title: Books of The Times
description: TARANTULA. By Bob Dylan, 137 pages. The Macmillan Company. $3.95.

title: Paris Opera Reopens Soon
description: PARIS, June 24.  The Paris Opera, closed since last July 30 for repairs and general reorgan ization, will reopen Sept. 30, it was announced here today by Bernard Lefort, interim director of the house pending the take over by Hamburg's Rolf Lieber mann in 1973. Wieland Wagner production of Wagner's Walk uere has been chosen for the reopening.

title: A New Shoulder Patch Adopted by City Police
description: The Police Department has adopted a goldandbiue shoulder patch designed to make it easier to distinguish the 31,000 members of the force from other policemen, such as the housing or tran sit police and private patrol men.

title: Concorde Agreement Extended
description: DENVER, June 24 (UPI) The president of United Air lines, Edward E. Carlson, today announced the airline had ex tended for six months an agree ment reserving delivery posi tions for six supersonic Con corde aircraft.

title: H. Leslie Hoffman, 65, Dead; Founded Electronics Concern
description: H. Leslie Hoffman, founder end chairman of the Hoffman Electronics Corporation of El Monte, Calif., died yesterday in Zurich, Switzerland, after a long illness. He was 65 years old.

title: EDMOND MURPHY OF LINCOLN BANK
description: GARDEN CITY, L. I., June 24  Edmond G. Murphy, president of the Lincoln Savings Bank, died last night, apparent ly of a heart attack, at the Cherry Valley Club. He was 61 years old and lived at 77 Brompton Road.

title: LEADERS REASSIGNED AT GRANITE SERVICES
description: Granite Management Serv ices, Inc., disclosed at yester day's annual meeting in Los Angeles that Arthur G. Sher man, president, and Herbert I. Cooper, executive vice presi dent, are giving up their posts but will continue as directors. They had been elected to their executive posts only last, month.

title: Dirty Writers of America Unite To Fight for Our Dirty Money
description: Stop talking revolution and talk money, shouted the wife of a writer of dirty books, in terrupting her oration on the greed of publishers of such books.

title: Nixon Dedicates Plaque To His Mother in Indiana
description: VERNON, Ind., June 24 President Nixon paid a nos talgic visit today to his mother's birthplace in rural Indiana and used the occasion to exhort several thousand wellwishers to cling to the values that she knew as a Quaker girl around the turn of the century.

title: HUMANITIES POST OF U.S. IN DISPUTE
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 Anger and suspicion over the reported White House choice of Stephen Hess to be chair man of the National Endow ment for the Humanities are growing rapidly among schol ars across the nation.

title: China: Maoist Man
description: The following dispatch, the first of a series, is by the assistant managing editor of The New York Times, who covered China from 1946 to 1949 and followed develop ments on the mainland from Hong Kong from 1963 to 1966.

title: Advertising Executive Drowned After Falling Off Yacht Here
description: An advertising executive ap parently tumbled from a yacht in the Hudson River last night and drowned, despite efforts by the crew and passengers to save him.

title: THOMAS MITCHELL SR.
description: Thomas E. Mitchell Sr., father of Thomas E. Mitchell Jr., vice presidentcontroller and assist ant to the president of WPIX, Inc., which operates television station WPIX in this city, died Wednesday in Oneonta, N. Y. Mr. Mitchell, a former Post Of fice employe, was 89 years old.

title: Suffolk to Require Jobs For Some on Welfare
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., June 24  A program requiring some Suffolk County welfare recipients to accept jobs in county departments or face a termination of their relief payments will begin next week, according to Social Services Commissioner James E. Kirby.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Rose at Monthly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 Yields on United States Treasury bills rose sharply in the Government's monthly competitive sale today of these shortterm securities.

title: GUARD FOR HOOVER AT SENATE HEARING
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 (UPI) J. Edgar Hoover told Con gress today that violence and terrorism among leftist and black extremists was on the increase, causing a sharp rise in Federal investigative work in the internal security field. He testified amid tight security.

title: NEW CHIEF COUNSEL FOR F.D.A. IS CHOSEN
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 Peter Barton Hutt, 36yearold lawyer with 11 years of experi ence in food and drug law, has been chosen as chief lawyer of the Food and Drug Adminis tration.

title: MALACHI DODSON, 65, JERSEY RESORT AIDE
description: ATLANTIC CITY, June 24  Malachi Dodson, director of public relations and advertis ing for this seashore resort, died of a heart attack today at his home. 1917 Kuehnle Ave nue. He was 65 years old.

title: HOFFA RELINQUISHES ALL UNION OFFICES
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 (UPI)James R. Hoffa resigned today from all remaining posi tions of leadership in the teamsters' union, including the presidency of Detroit Local 299, which he used as a spring board to the presidency of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters.

title: Books of The Times
description: LIVING WELL IS THE BEST REVENGE. By Calvin Tomkins. Illustrated. 148 pages. Viking. $6.50.

title: Court Tells Waldorf To Refund $113,202 In Sundries Fees
description: The WaldorfAstoria Hotel was ordered yesterday to re fund $113,202.83 that it charged 64,338 customers for sundries between December, 1969, and May 1970.

title: 1,000 Are Evacuated In Coast Gas Threat
description: IMPERIAL, Calif., June 24 (UPI)Poisonous gas from a fireengulfed pesticide stor age area forced evacuation of nearly 1,000 persons from their homes today in this Southern California commu nity.

title: A Tennessee Dark Horse Drawn to New Hampshire
description: PORTSMOUTH, N. H., June 24The magnetic attraction of New Hampshire's Presidential primary reached futher into the Democratic party today, draw ing Representative William R. Anderson.

title: To Vietnamese, Safety Before Politics
description: DUCDUC, South Vietnam, June 18The villagers here, a district seat of huts and muddy paths, do not look ahead. Their war is only a short distance away and memories of the at tack last March by North Viet names troops are very fresh.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: City's Health Department Going Under State Control
description: Governor Rockefeller has signed a bill that abolishes the historic independence of the New York City Health Depart ment and places it under state supervision.

title: WIRETAP HEARING SET HERE TODAY
description: A hearing on the legality of a Justice Department wiretap on the Jewish Defense League will be held in Federal District Court in Brooklyn this morn ing.

title: Another Sale Tomorrow
description: A total of $857,471.80 was obtained in a sale by Christie's of some of Mrs. Dodge's jew elry in Geneva last month. To morrow, two immense paintings by Francois Bouher, several works by Jean Honor Fragon ard and a portrait by Van Dyck will wind up the sale of the Dodge art holdings in London.

title: Light on a Murder
description: The guilty plea by one of the five persons accused in the killing of a reform leader in the United Mine Workers offers the first solid hope for a complete resolution of this gruesome crime. It is clear from both the confession and the courtroom testimony that the death of Joseph A. Yablonski and his wife and daughter was a case of murderforhire. What matters now is to find out who paid $5,200 to have this union rebel assassinated.

title: LOOKING GLASS GIVES FREE ROCK CONCERT
description: Looking Glass, a rock group from Glen Gardner, N. J., gave a free concert Wednesday after noon at Damrosch Park, Lin coln Center.

title: Mrs. Carner, With 70, Ties Donna Caponi in U. S. Women's Open
description: ERIE, Pa., June 24 (AP)Mrs. Joanne Carner and Donna Ca poni posted twounderpar 70's at the Kahkwa Club golf course today to share the firstround lead in the United States Wom en's Open.

title: 7,544 Plymouths Recalled
description: DETROIT, June 24 (UPI) The owners of 7,544 Plymouth Cricket passenger cars of the 1971 model year are being no tified to return them to dealers because of possible insufficient lubrication of the front wheel bearings, the Chrysler Corpo ration announced today.

title: PRICES INCREASE FOR MOST BONDS
description: The bond markets, Which have been staggering since early Monday afternoon, seemed to regain their balance yesterday.

title: Cowboys Keep Hayes With 5Year Contract
description: DALLAS, June 24 (UPI) The Dallas Cowboys an nounced today that their star flanker, Bob Hayes, who played out his option last season and had threatened to play elsewhere, had come to contract terms.

title: The War: The Record and the U.S.
description: CAMBRIDGE, MassThe Pentagon study on Vietnam reveals how a small group of technocrats and crisis man agers, acting in secret and relying on the espionage provisions of the Federal code to conceal their deception, con spired to engage the United States in an everwidening war of aggression in Indochina.

title: Liabilities in Apparel Field Surged With Beck's Filing
description: A $58million failure of a large retail shoe chain was a major reason for a big jump in liabilities of apparel and textile industry concerns in May, ac cording to the Credit Clearing House, the apparel trades divi sion of Dun & Bradstreet, Inc.

title: STAND ON PULLOUT CLARIFIED BY SEOUL
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 24South Korean officials said today that the Seoul Gov ernment was discussing with Saigon its plan to withdraw only one division of South Korean troops from Vietnam at present.

title: ALPHONSE DE RIESTHAL
description: Alphonse T. de Riesthal, who retiretd in 1968 as general pas senger traffic manager of United States Lines after 48 years of service, died yesterday at his home, 9511 Shore Road, Brook lyn. He was 66 years old.

title: PRICES ARE MIXED IN SLOW AMEX DAY
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange ended mixed yesterday in the lightest trad ing in more than five months.

title: Impact of a Lockheed Collapse Is Shown by Study of 21 Banks
description: What would be the effect on the 24 banks that have lent $400million to Lock heed should the giant de fense company go under and be unable to repay any of this debt?

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, June 24The partial disclosure of the Pentagon Papers has already produced two important devel opments. It has forced the Administra tion to turn over all the documents in the McNamara study to Congress for analysis, and it has started a powerful movement to reform the present sys tem of distributing and classifying of ficial information.

title: Airline Hostess Found Slain In Her Apartment in Yorkville
description: A 23yearold airline hostess was found murdered in her Yorkville apartment last night. The police said she had been raped and then strangled by stockings that were wrapped around her neck.

title: Coast Paper Says U.S. Barred Aide's '63 Plan to Quit Vietnam
description: The New York Times is re strained by Federal court order from publishing further articles in its Vietnam series. This dis patch was based on an article in The Los Angeles Times and was distributed by The Asso ciated Press to all its news paper, radio and television subscribers.

title: BAY BEA, HARPOON VICTORS IN SAILING
description: NEWPORT, R. I., June 24 Winners in four of the five classes in the Annapolisto Newport yacht race were de termined this afternoon, but most of the fleet was still struggling through fog five days after the start.

title: Britain Voices Concern About Confidentiality
description: LONDON, June 24 The British Government said to day that it has informed the State Department of its con cern for the confidentiality of diplomatic exchanges.

title: Beame Is Upheld Again on Consultants
description: The Appellate Division ruled yesterday that all city consult ant contracts of more than $2,500 required public hear ings, competitive bidding and approval by the Board of Esti mate, unless the board itself made an exception.

title: N. B. A. MODIFIES ELIGIBILITY RULE
description: BOSTON, June 24 (AP)The National Basketball Association modified its socalled four year rule, today to permit hardship cases among colle gians to join its pro ranks.

title: Going, Going, Era of Fashion Is Gone With Auctioneer's Gavel
description: A short time ago women who are accustomed to pay ding up to $2,500 for an eve ning gown were happily being fitted for summer and fall designs at Mainbocher's salon. This week, the last of those outfits were delivered to their owners, and yester day a chapter of the old order passed on with a brief burst of noiseand fust a few sighs.

title: Senate Panel Approves Bill To Extend Renegotiation Act
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 (AP) The Senate Finance Commit tee approved today a House passed bill extending the Rene gotiation Act for two years.

title: Lockheed's Rescue Plan May Aid Other Concerns
description: The Nixon Administration is helping a Senate committee draft a new bill that would expand the proposal for rescu ing the Lockheed Aircraft Cor poration by making it possible to salvage other companies that get into similar financial trouble.

title: Merger News
description: The Union Carbide Corpora tion announced yesterday that it had reached a tentative agreement to sell all its oil and gas interests to Ashland Oil, Inc., for about $90million in cash and possible future contingency payments. These include payments based upon production from Union Car bide's overseas properties that are to be sold to Ash land. Under the agreement, Ash land will acquire the stock of the Union Carbide Petroleum Corporation, a sub sidiary of the Union Carbide Corporation that is engaged in petroleum exploration and production, and other related companies.

title: Missing Link in the Middle East
description: Reports of imminent rapprochement between the Soviet Union and Israel may be premature, but hints that both nations are open to some kind of accommodation deserve all possible encouragement. The resumption of diplo matic relations between Moscow and Jerusalem, or even direct contacts short of formal relations, could provide a vital missing link in the chain of diplomatic efforts to secure an ArabIsraeli peace.

title: 450 Automatic Pistols Stolen at a Factory Here
description: Nine cartons containing 50 new automatic pistols each were stolen yesterday from a downtown gun factory by thieves who broke through an inside wall to bypass a burglar alarm.

title: A CHARGE DROPPED IN SERGEANT'S TRIAL
description: QUANTICO, Va., June 24 (AP)  A military judge dis missed today one charge and amended others in the case of Sgt. Jon M. Sweeney, the only United States serviceman to be charged with communicating with the enemy in Vietnam.

title: MISS TAYLOR SINGS AT TRUDE HELLER'S
description: When a singer has as many interesting qualities as Marian Taylor does, it is disconcerting to find that her songs frequent ly do not come out the way she apparently expects them to or as the listener might reasonably expect them to.

title: Roundup: Lefebvre and Dodgers Stack the Cards, 114
description: Jim Lefebvre is a utility infielder for the Los Angeles Dodgers at the age of 28, only six years after he was the rookie of the year in the National League in 1965.

title: Saudi Arabian Agreement On Oil Price is Reported
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 24 (AP)The Saudi Arabian press agency reported a new price agreement between the Saudi Government and the Arabian American Oil Company today. The agreement increases the price of Saudi oil available at the Lebanese Mediterranean terminal of Sidon to bring it in line with the price of other Arab oil available west of Suez. The new price was not disclosed.

title: Cornell Names Gilbert
description: ITHACA, N. Y., June 24 (AP) Richard W. Gilbert was ad vanced from assistant to head coach of swimming today at Cornell University, succeeding Peter S. Carhart, who resigned.

title: ADVANCES SCORED IN SILVER FUTURES
description: After opening lower, silver futures prices closed near the of 200 to 210 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) in ex panded trading.

title: SANS MARQUE VICTOR IN FAIRFIELD SHOW
description: WESTPORT, Conn., June 24 Sans Marque, a seasoned performer who never has man aged to reach the top of the division, captured his second consecutive open jumper class today at the Fairfield County Hunt Club horse show.

title: Richmond Negro Named To Board of Symphony
description: RICHMOND, June 24 Henry L. Marsh 3d, Rich mond's vice mayor, has been named to the board of di rectors of the Richmond Symphony, the first black to be named to a policy posi tion with the orchestra in its 14 years.

title: Yankees Recall Blomberg, Outfielder, From Syracuse
description: Ron Blomberg, a 23yearold lefthandedhitting outfielder, was recalled by the New York Yankees from their Syracuse farm yesterday. He will rejoin the club in time for tonight's opener of a fourgame series against Washington at the Sta dium.

title: Democratic Chiefs Support Backer for Surrogate
description: The New York County Dem ocratic executive committee en dorsed Supreme Court Justice Frederick Backer for Manhat tan surrogate yesterday, but he faces a fight for the party nom ination in the Sept. 14 primary.

title: Pollution Case Halted by Clash on Law
description: PITTSBURGH, June 24The trial of a chemical company charged with polluting the Monongahela River was sud denly adjourned today while the judge and the defense at torney heatedly discussed the law on which the trial is based.

title: NAUMBURG CONCERTS START PARK SERIES
description: The Naumburg Orchestral Concerts, 66 years old this year, began their summr sea son at the Central Park Mall on Wednesday night with a program of Baroque music. Frank Brieff, conductor of the New Haven Symphony Orches tra, led the Naumburg Sym phony or, rather, an appro priately reduced chambersized version of itin Handel's Con certo Grosso in D (Op. 6, No. 5), Bach's Orchestral Suite No. 1 in C, Corelli's Concerto Gros so in D (Op. 6, No. 7) and Haydn's Symphony No. 21 in A.

title: GoAhead for Apollo 15
description: CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., June 24 (AP)Dr. Rocco A. Petrone, director of the Apollo program, gave the goahead today to proceed with preparations for launching the Apollo 15 astro nauts to the moon on July 26. He made the decision after a ninehour flight readiness re view in which all aspects of the mission were assessed.

title: Pennsylvania High Court Voids State's First Tax on Income, 52
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 24  The Pennsylvania Supreme Court, in a 5to2 decision, de clared the state's first personal income tax unconstitutional to day.

title: Pilotless Plane Circles Yuma Before Crashing
description: YUMA, Ariz., June 24 (AP) A twoseat Cessna 150 crashed near here today aft er it circled the city for al most three hours without a pilot.

title: GOLDMAN BANDMEN OPEN 54TH SEASON
description: The opening on Wednesday night of the 54th season of Guggenheim Memorial Con certs played by the Goldman Band was enriched and en livened by the presence of the AllCity High School Chorus, which sang four selections with the band in the middle of the program.

description: To the Editor:

title: Hanoi Aide, Back in Paris, Adopts Conciliatory Tone
description: PARIS, June 24Le Due Tho, a highranking member of the North Vietnamese hierarchy, returned to the peace talks here today after more than a year's absence and said he was ready to stay as long as my presence is needed.

title: Pope Emphasizes Peace Efforts In Vietnam and the Middle East
description: ROME, June 24Pope Paul VI emphasized today the ef forts of the Roman Catholic Church to promote peace in Vietnam, the Middle East and other trouble centers.

description: HARRISBURG, Pa., June 24 (UPI)There was only guard ed reaction today from Gover nor Shapp in the state capital here.

title: Seaver Homer Tops Expos, 21
description: MONTREAL, June 24Tom Seaver of the New York Mets and Bill Stoneman of the Mont real Expos, two of the Na tional League's better pitchers, hooked up in a mound duel to night. But it was Seaver's bat that made the difference.

title: Market Place : Applied Health:  Picture Is Split
description: How do you view Applied Health Services, Inc.? Well, there are at least two schools of thought. It may be a hot stock. So far the market seems to think so.

description: WINSTONSALEM, N. C., June 24Jim McDaniels, 7foot center from Western Kentucky, scored 26 points to lead the Carolina Cougars to a 121110 victory over the New York Nets in a rookie squad basket ball game tonight.

description: American Airlines, Inc., raised $89.92million yesterday with the sale of 3.3 million new common shares, a move putting it among several others in the industry that have tapped the equity markets recently.

Cosmos 428 had an initial orbit period of 89.1 minutes. It was a minimum of 129 and a maximum of 167 miles from the earth's surface. The orbital inclination was 51.81 degrees.

description: WARSAW, June 24Poland unveiled a new fiveyear eco nomic plan today that shifts priorities from investment in heavy industries to the needs of the nation's hardpressed consumers.

title: Soviet Defends Its Policy of Improving U.S. Relations
description: MOSCOW, June 24The So viet Union today defended its policy of seeking better rela tions with the United States as necessary to reduce the risk of a new world war.

description: WASHINGTON, June 24A Washington chemist questioned today the truth of statements by soldiers in Vietnam that they or their friends had beat en the urinalysis system being used in Vietnam to detect mili tary personnel returning to the United States who have taken drugs within 72 hours of the test.

title: Olivier Stages an Amphitryon Fantasy
description: LONDON, June 24 Jean Giraudoux, last seen in London in Harold Clurman's shortlived production of Judith 10 years ago, is as ripe for revival as any midcentury French drama tist, but the National Theater is not helping his cause with Laurence Olivier's production (at the New Theater) of Amphitryon 38, the work that embalms him in postwar memory as a lightweight fan tasist.

title: Fraud Laid to Memorex;
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today that it had filed a complaint in Federal District Court in New York seeking an injunction against alleged violations by the Memorex Corporation and two individuals of the anti fraud and periodicreporting Provisions of the securities laws.

title: Continental Can to Close Wilmington Crown Plant
description: The Continental Can Com pany announced yesterday that it would discontinue manufac turing crown closures in Wil mington, Del., by Sept. 3 be cause there was no way to make the plant profitable. Bond Crown Division activities will be moved into its metal can plants, where they are be ing tied into more sophisticated and efficient support equip ment.

description: BAY SHORE, L. I., June 24 (UPI)  A teenager drowned early this afternoon in the Atlantic Ocean off Robert Moses State Park on Fire Island.

title: Sports of The Times
description: An offensive tackle is a disciplined introvert, the strong silent type, while a defensive tackle is the opposite extroverted, individualistic, hell bent. Similarly a wide receiver is a body cultist and a showoff while a defensive back demonstrates arrogance and aggression. Quarter backs? They may show a variety of traits, but the good ones always demonstrate confidence.

description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 24  The money is pouring in to Box 1972, Montgomery, addressed to The Wallace Campaign.

description: The airpollution code that is expected to be passed next month by the City Council would crack down on city fa cilities, which a Councilman described yesterday as prob ably the city's worst violator, including Con Edison.

description: The stock market went through a dress rehearsal of the midsummer doldrums yesterday.

title: Priorities on Drug Abuse
description: As evidence of drug abuse has continued to mount, so too, until a few days ago, has evidence of society's failure to deal adequately with it. President Nixon's enlightened action in creating a single drug agency to coordinate the Federal Government's awkwardly frag mented antiaddiction efforts and in emphasizing the need for more fundamental drug research now offers hope for overdue change. This new commitment on the President's part deserves emulation by state and local authorities.

title: Store Sales Increase
description: WASHINGTON, June 24 The Commerce Department to day estimated last week's de partment store sales at $890 million, up 19 per cent from the yearearlier $750million. Total retail store sales last week were about $7,873, 000, 000, up 5 per cent from $7, 497,000,000.

title: Brazilian Court Clears the Way For DeathSquad Prosecutions
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, June 24 The Brazilian Federal Court of Appeals today cleared the way for prosecution of policemen who have executed petty crim inals in the name of anonymous vigilante groups called death squads.

title: The Screen: 'McCabe and Mrs. Miller':Miss Christie Portrays Prostitute in West Betty Is a Gambler in Altman's Film
description: In the course of Robert Altman's new film, "McCabe and Mrs. Miller," there is a shot of Warren Beatty steaming off a drunk in an old-fashioned, wooden, bathtub, his arms draped along the sides, his eyes closed and his bearded face hanging limply forward. When such a shot prompts the woman behind you to hisswith the excitement of someone who has spotted Rod McKuen at the Russian Tea Room: "He looks just like Jesus!", you may be sure you're in the presence of a movie of serious intentions. Shots that make the characters look just like Jesus don't happen by accident.The intentions of "McCabe and Mrs. Miller" are not only serious, they are also meddlesomely imposed on the film by tired symbolism, by a folk-song commentary on the soundtrack that recalls not the old Pacific Northwest but San Francisco's hungry I, and by the sort of metaphysically purposeful photography that, in a tight close-up, attempts to discover the soul's secrets in the iris of an eye and finds, instead, only a very large iris.Such intentions keep spoiling the fun of what might have been an uproarious frontier fable about a smalltime gambler named McCabe (Beatty), a frizzy-haired whore named Mrs. Miller (Julie Christie), and the systematic destruction of their small, free American enterprise by Big Business, with the not so innocent cooperation of organized religion.When McCabe first comes to the bleak little mining town of Presbyterian Church, it doesn't seem as God-for-saken as not yet discovered by God, for whom a church is under construction. It's a scenic mess of squalid shacks, bordered by an even more squalid ghetto for Chinese laborers.McCabe, a man of common sense but very little arithmetic, sets out to bring civilization to Presbyterian Church in the form of a casino and a three-bed bordello. He doesn't do very well, however, until he is joined by Mrs. Miller, who has the heart of a bookkeeper, the aspirations of a madam, and connections with a house in Seattle. They make a marvelous, practical team, and are immensely successful until The Company moves to take over their businesses, via assassination when it becomes apparent McCabe won't sell.There is one moment in the film that achieves, I think, just the right balance between comedy and satire that Altman seeks, unsuccessfully, for the entire film. McCabe, who is not exactly keen on being murdered, asks the help of a lawyer who lectures him on the American way and cheerfully concludes: "If men stop dying for freedom, freedom itself will be dead!" When poor McCabe gets hoodwinked into believing he's protecting free enterprise by accepting a showdown with the hired killers, the contemporary allusions become rather thick.I don't automatically object to contemporary allusions, but I prefer to find them myself, and "McCabe and Mrs. Miller" is so busy pointing them out to us that the effect is to undercut its narrative drive and the dignity of its fiction. Dignity may sound like a curious word to use in this case, but the characters of "McCabe and Mrs. Miller," as written and as played, do have an essential dignity that is very real and honest. Beatty's gambler-turned-businessman is a truly comic, clay-footed entrepreneur, and Miss Christie's tough-talking whore is about as appealing as that sentimental character can be until she's required to drift off into opium oblivion, a woman-turned-into-society's victim.As in "M*A*S*H" and "Brewster McCloud," Altman fills his screen with sometimes exceptionally vivid detail, such as the casually viewed fight between a knife-wielding prostitute and her customer, the overheard small talk between miners standing at the bar, and the physical growth of Presbyterian Church in the course of the film.As "McCabe and Mrs. Miller" progresses, however, there is also an increasing suspicion that these details are loaded with ulterior motives, which have not as much to do with the time and place of the film, as with its pretentions. One thing the movie does have in beautiful and extraordinary abundance is weatherrain, snow, sleet, wind (it was photographed on location in Canada), which is most attractive, especially to someone who spends most of his life looking at the world through windows sealed for air-conditioning.

title: COMPANIES LISTED IN BOSTON GET VOICE
description: The Boston Stock Exchange annouced yesterday that its board of governors had voted to let a representative of listed companies join the board. Ex change governors normally are representatives of member in vestment firms.

title: RULING DUE TODAY ON MEDINA TRIAL
description: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., June 24A military judge said today that he would rule to morrow on whether Capt. Er nest L. Medina would stand trial on Charges of premedi tated murder of 102 South Viet namese civilians at Mylai.

title: LINDSAY'S TACTICS SCORED BY ALBANY
description: Decrying a cloud of credi bility about the Lindsay ad ministration, Earl W. Brydges of Niagara Falls, majority leader of the State Senate, warned yesterday the law makers would remember the Mayor's hysterical misstate ments about mass layoffs when they meet next January.

title: INDICTMENTS KEPT SEALED IN CHICAGO
description: CHICAGO, June 24A spe cial grand jury investigating the fatal Black Panther raid of Dec. 4, 1969, returned an unde termined number of sealed in vestments tonight.
