description: WASHINGTON, June 24  Following is the text of a denial by the Court of Ap peals today of a Government petition for a rehearing in The Washington Post case and excerpts from the Gov ernment's petition to the Supreme Court:

title: MAINBOCHER: AN APPRAISAL
description: What I have stood for is to keep the couture alive, said Main Rousseau Bocher.

title: Leftist New Democrats Sweep Saskatchewan Province Election
description: OTTAWA, June 24 The New Democratic party won a sweeping victory over the in cumbent Liberals in elections in the prairie province of Sas katchewan yesterday.

title: TIMES ASKS SUPREME COURT TO END RESTRAINTS ON ITS VIETNAM SERIES;
description: WASHINGTON, June 24  The New York Times asked the Supreme Court today to permit it to resume publication of material from the Pentagon study of the Vietnam war.

title: CHESTER G. ABBOTT
description: PORTLAND, Me., June 24 Chester G. Abbott, retired pres ident and board chairman of Maine National Bank, formerly First National Bank of Port land died in his home here to day after a brief illness. He was 81 years old.

title: CONCERTS ON HUDSON TO BEGIN ON JULY 17
description: A series of five concerts en titled Summer of Music on the Hudson will be given on the grounds of Lyndhurst, the former Jay Gould estate, by the Orchestral Society of West chester under the direction of Stephen Simon. The weekly Saturday night concerts will begin July 17 and run through Aug. 14.

title: CORNELL OARSMEN QUALIFY FOR FINAL
description: SYRACUSE, June 24 (AP) Three members of Cornell's National Collegiate champion crew qualified today for Satur day's finals in the United States rowing trials for the PanAmerican Games.

title: J. LOUIS RADEL
description: NORWALK, Conn., June 25 J. Louis Radel, founder of the oyster company bearing his name here, died yesterday after a fall at his home, 148G Brook side Drive, Fairfield. He was 69 years old.

title: U.S. NEWSPRINT USE FELL BY 2.5% IN MAY
description: Total newsprint consump tion in the United States in May was 838,763 tons, a 2.5 per cent decline from May, 1970, the American Newspaper Publishers Association reported yesterday.

title: AIDES OF RESERVE HIT MONETARISTS
description: KONSTANZ, West Germany, June 25  American monetary authorities would have faced a swing in short  term interest rates above 17 per cent in the first quarter this year had they tried to hold the money supply to a 6 per, cent an nual growth rate, Federal Re serve Board officials disclosed today.

title: Holy Modal Rounders Playing Fractured Country Music Here
description: The Holy Modal Rounders, in their latest configuration, are playing a program of their usual fractured country music through tomorrow at Folk City, 130 West Third Street.

title: Pentagon Study Prominently Reported in Europe
description: PARIS, June 25It's a great lesson for us, said a young French journalist.

title: Study Said to Show McNamara Pessimism on War
description: ST. LOUIS, June 25 (AP) The St. Louis PostDispatch said today that former Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara labeled the pacification pro gram in South Vietnam a bad disappointment in 1966 and told President Johnson he saw no reasonable way to bring the war to an end soon.

title: Moczar Loses Key Polish Party Job
description: WARSAW, June 24Mieczy slaw Moczar was relieved to day of his key position in the Secretariat of the Communist party's Central Committee.

title: AIR GROUP OPPOSES UHF SATELLITE BAND
description: GENEVA, June 25The In ternational Air Transport Asso ciation voiced strong opposition today to the proposed use of the ultrahighfrequency band in satellite communications along air routes over the oceans.

title: Gordie Howe's Mother Dies
description: KALKASKA, Mich., June 25 (UPI)Mrs. Catherine Howe, mother of Gordie Howe, the Detroit Red Wings hockey star, died early today after a fall down a flight of stairs at her son's cottage on Bear Lake in northern Michigan. Her age was 76. She was the wife of Albert Howe.

title: In Los Angeles, a Woman's Place May Be in the art Gallery
description: LOS ANGELES  One came from the Social Regis ter, another from the field of advertising, a third from the fringes of show business.

title: Military Race Relations Institute Will Open in Florida in October
description: WASHINGTON, June 25A military race relations institute, planned by the Defense Department since March, will open in October at Patrick Air Force Base in Florida, just south of Cape Kennedy.

title: 3 Women Killed in Collision
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 25 (AP)  Three women were killed and a fourth was badly injured In a headon collision on the Connecticut Turnpike near Exit 4 shortly after 11 A.M. today. The state police identified the dead women as Mrs. Janette P. Runge, 60 years odd and Mrs. Carol M. Runge, both of Farmingdale, L. I., and Mrs. Siriratan Jon tugdee, 31, of Paterson, N. J, The survivor, Mrs. Luming San giem, 31, of Mount Vernon, N. Y., was taken to Greenwich Hospital.

title: Titian Auctioned for $4Million, 2d Highest Art Price
description: LONDON, June 25Titian's The Death of Actaeon was sold today for $4,032,000, the second highest auction price for a work of art.

title: Merger News
description: Directors of Lines Brothers, Ltd., a British toy manufac turer, announced yesterday that they had accepted the of fer of Gallaher, Ltd., the Brit ish tobacco subsidiary of Amer ican Brands, Inc., to acquire 55 per cent of Lines by late 1976. The toymaker's acceptance is subject to approval by the British Govern ment. Lines said it would call a spe cial stockholders' meeting to vote on the proposal as soon as possible.

title: Hoffa Asks Now Hearing
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP)  James R. Hoffa, former head of the teamsters union, sought today a rehearing by the United States Board of Parole on its latest denial of his bid for freedom from prison sentences for mail fraud and jury tampering. George J. Reed, Parole Board chairman, indi cated that Hoffa's application contained information that Hof fa feels the board did not con sider when it turned down his bid for parole last March 31.

title: SENATORS SEE BOY BUY HEROIN HERE
description: Four United States Senators watched a 16yearold boy buy five glassine bags of heroin for $10 from a pusher at 137th Street and Lenox Avenue in Harlem yesterday.

title: GUARD IS SUSPENDED OVER FIGHT IN WARD
description: A city correction officer who was involved in an altercation with an inmate in the Kings County Hospital prison ward has been suspended without pay pending an investigation of the incident.

title: Democratic Contenders to Meet On Curbing Costs of Primaries
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  The major contenders for the Democratic Presidential nomi nation will hold another unity meeting next month in search of agreement on ways to hold down the cost of campaigning against one another.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, June 25It is not only in myth that kingdoms are lost for want of a nail. In the real world, what seem little matters of timing and procedures may affect great political events. So history may see the deci sion of the British Labor party's ex ecutive, just taken, to hold a special party conference next month on whether this country should join the European Common Market.

title: Book of The Times
description: CRAWLSPACE. By Herbert Lieberman. 306 pages. McKay. $6.95.

title: Extradition Order Upheld By Court in Yablonski Case
description: CLEVELAND, June 25, (UPI) The United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit cleared the way today for ex tradition to Pennsylvania of two more persons charged in the killing of Joseph A. Yablonski, United Mine Workers official, and his wife and daughter.

title: LEO J. KILEY
description: Leo J. Kiley, a retired statis tician and the father of Richard Kiley, the actor, died Thursday in Summit Park Hospital, Po mona, N.Y. He was 83 years old and lived at 138 Strawtown Road, West Nyack, N.Y.

title: When the Culprit Is Summer
description: At least in Boston and Brockport, N. Y., a suburb of Rochester, the law has found a way to keep cool. Patrolman Paul Hoy strides down Brockport's Main Street in his department's summer gear. The uniformshorts, a straw stet son and shortsleeved shirtis option al. The woman member of Boston's Traffic Division, directing traffic at Columbia Road in the city's Dorchester section, was wearing culottes. But she preferred to keep her identity secret.

title: MSGR. J. R. SEARSON, CHAPLAIN AT N.Y.U.
description: Msgr. James R. Searson, Roman Catholic chaplain to the Washigton Square campus of New York University, died yesterday morning. He was 46 years old.

title: U. S. Proposes Limited Price Controls in Construction Industry
description: WASHINGTON, June 25. (UPI) The Government announced today its first moves to control inflation of prices and white collar compensation in the con struction industry. The an nouncement came nearly three months after the Nixon Admin isiration began clamping down on wage increases for construc tion workers.

title: John Mueser Weds Miss Ellen Tholfsen
description: Miss Ellen Tholfsen and John Alan Mueser were mar ried here yesterday evening in St. Paul's Chapel of Co lumbia University.

title: CATHOLIC GROUP SEES NEW APATHY
description: The National Association of Laymen, a group devoted to reform of the Roman Catholic Church, opened a three day an nual meeting here yesterday amid its members growing con viction that the churchrenewal movement was sorely in need of new directions.

title: Wild Shot on 56th St. Kills Man Watching An Argument Below
description: A 67yearold man sitting at an open fourthfloor window in his West Side apartment early yesterday morning was shot through the head and killed by a random bullet fired from a car on the street below.

title: Senate Panel Votes to End Funds for Airlift From Cuba
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) The Senate Appropriations Committee voted today to cut off Government financing for 1 he airlift that has brought about 250,000 Cuban refugees into the United States in the last five and a half years.

title: Bridge: Holder of High Cards Finds Justice to Be Elusive Thing
description: It is fatally easy for a player with a wealth of high cards to overestimate his defensive potential.

title: S.E.C. PROCEEDING NAMES STEADMAN
description: WASHINGTON, June 25The Securities and Exchange Com misson announced today that it had ordered administrative proceedings against Charles W. Steadman of Washington and a group of investmentadvisory and other corporations related to mutual funds that he controls.

title: STOLEN ART WORKS RECOVERED IN TURIN
description: TURIN, Italy, June 25 (UPI) The police said today they had recovered stolen art works worth $3.2million and detained two persons, including a grand son of Benito Mussolini's Pop ular Culture Minister.

title: Mrs. Perse Married
description: The marriage of Mrs. Har riette A. Perse to Alfred W. Kleinbaum, a partner in the investment banking house of Wertheim & Co., took place here yesterday morning at the headquarters of the American Friends of Hebrew University. Justice Samuel M. Gold of the State Supreme Court performed the cere mony. Previous marriages for the couple ended in divorce.

title: M. B. MORRISON SR., PHYSICIAN, WAS 82
description: PAWLING, N. Y., June 25 Dr. Milnor B. Morrison Sr., physician whose patients in cluded Lowell Thomas, the broadcaster and world travel er; the late Gov. Thomas E. Dewey and the late Edward R. Murrow, radio and television personality, died today of a heart attack at his home. He was 82 years old and lived at 1810 Townsend Avenue.

title: Group in Brooklyn Is Given $437,000 To Aid Exconvicts
description: A group of Brooklyn business men has received a $437,000 Federal grant to start a pro gram of rehabilitation for for mer convicts.

title: Youth, 15, Drowns; 2d Death in 2 Days In L.I. Guard Strike
description: A 15yearold boy drowned at Jones Beach yesterday, the second drowning in two days at state parks being struck in a spay dispute by 350 lifeguards.

title: Guard Shuts Old Armory On 34th St.
description: The 71st Regiment Armory, the redbrick fortress over looking Park Avenue at 34th Street, will close today after 79 years of service as a mili tary installation, sports arena and a convention and exhibi tion hall.

title: Battle With Reagan Leave Coast Colleges Divided and Worried
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 25 After four years of ideolog ical and financial conflict with Gov. Ronald Reagan, California's much praised college and uni versity system is torn by in ternal dissension over where it is going and how much it should spend to get there.

title: W. Ward Marsh, Film Critic For Cleveland Plain Dealer
description: CLEVELAND, June 25 (AP) W. Ward Marsh, film critic for The Cleveland Plain Dealer for more than 50 years, died Wednesday night at St. Thomas Hospital in Akron at the age of 77.

title: Roundup: Merritt Loses 10th
description: Part of the total reason for the strange collapse of the Cincinnati Reds, last year's National League Champions, has been the ineffective pitch ing of Jim Merritt, the left bander who won 20 games in 1970.

title: DR. HENRY H. BEINFIELD
description: Dr. Henry H. Beinfield, an ear, nose and throat doctor who developed the widely used Beinfield technique for treat ing nose abnormaiities, died yesterday at his home. He was 79 years old and lived at 20 East Ninth Street.

title: Kenny Washington Dead at 52; Was West Coast Football Star
description: LOS ANGELES, June 25 (UPI)Kenny Washington, one of the West Coast's greatest collegiate football players, died last night at U.C.L.A. Medical Center. His age was 52.

title: Labor Agencies Elect Chief
description: FRESNO, Calif., June 25 Jay Kramer, chairman of the New York State Labor Rela tions Board, has been elected president of the National As sociation of State Labor Rela tions Agencies at a meeting here. He was a founder of the association and served as its first president from 1961 to 1962.

title: 12 Are Convicted On Arrests in '65 In Alabama March
description: MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 25After six years of litigation in Federal and state courts, the City of Montgomery called for trial today the cases of 160 persons arrested on minor charges during the Selmato Montgomery march in the spring of 1965.

title: PATHET LAO RENEWS CALL FOR CEASEFIRE
description: PARIS, June 25The pro Communist Pathet Lao has re newed a proposal to the Vien tiane government for a cease fire in Laos followed by talks to bring about peace and na tional agreement. The pro posal was announced by the North Vietnamese delegation to the peace talks here and con firmed by reports from both Vientiane and Hanoi.

title: GORMA, LAVER, NEWCOMBE GAIN
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 25Thomas Warner Gorman is in privileged company tonight following a 63, 86, 64 victory over Ross Case of Australia that enabled him to gain the quarterfinals of the allEngland Lawn Tennis championships with topseeded Rod Laver and John Newcombe, the defending champion.

title: N.A.B. BOARD BACKS C.B.S. ON PENTAGON
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) The board of directors of the National Association of Broad casters went on record today in support of Dr. Frank Stanton of the Columbia Broadcasting System and of newspapers that have printed excerpts from a secret Pentagon study of United States involvement in Vietnam.

title: SUPREME COURT AGREES TO RULE ON PRINTING OF VIETNAM SERIES;
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  The Supreme Court agreed to day to hear arguments tomor row on the Government's ef fort to enjoin The New York Times and The Washington Post from publishing material from the Pentagon papers on Vietnam.

title: FLEXIBLE PROGRAM AT CITY U. BACKED
description: ALBANY, June 25  The State Board of Regents today granted approval for students at the City University of New York to earn a Bachelor of Arts degree through a person ally selected curriculum.

title: De Sapio Begins 2Year Sentence In Bribery Case
description: Carmine G. De Sapio, once the leader of Tammany Hall, surrendered yesterday after noon at the Federal Peniten tiary in Lewisburg, Pa., to be gin a twoyear term for bribery and Conspiracy.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: 11 Equivalency Diplomas Are Awarded in Harlem
description: A little awkwardly, but with obvious pride, 10 men and one girl strode up to the, dais in the Mount Morris Park Amphi theater in Harlem yesterday to receive their high school equiv alency diplomas.

title: St. Regis Paper Facility Set
description: The St. Regis Paper Company announced plans yesterday to construct a multimilliondollar facilty at Hinton, Alberta, for the production of lumber for home construction.

title: Report Notes Failure to Prosecute a City Detective
description: A confidential police report says that Chief Assistant Dis trict Attorney Frederich M. Ludwig of Queens decided not to prosecute a narcotics detec tive on a perjury charge despite Mr. Ludwig's stated belief that there was sufficient evidence for conviction.

title: Screen:
description: Just in the last few min utes, almost as an epilogue to Hiroshi Inagaki's Machi buse, which opened yester day at the Bijou, eight furtive, heavily cloaked men appear in the mistshrouded middle distance of a snowy landscape. In from the right side of the screen walks Toshiro Mifune, he imme diately kills all eight (one of whom is his deadliest enemy), and walks out of the screen to the left.

title: Sports of The Times
description: The socalled fouryear rule, which many considered immoral, was also declared illegal several months ago. What does the National Basketball Association do with a rule that is not only immoral, but illegal? This week, during the league's annual meeting, the rule was modified. Now, N.B.A. clubs can sign a college player before his college eligibility expires if he can prove hardship on the basis of financial condition, his family, his academic record, or lack of it, and his ability to obtain employment another field.

title: Mrs. Tracy's Rally Wins Area Title on 37th Hole
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 25 Mrs. William Tracy of Essex Fells won the 68th annual Women's Metropolitan Golf As sociation tournament today, defeating the defending cham pion, Mrs. A. Sherburne Hart of Baltusrol, on the 37th green. Mrs. Hart had a 2up lead after 34 holes.

title: SPACE EXPERTS END PARLEY ON DOCKING
description: HOUSTON, June 25 (AP) Soviet and American space ex perts completed five days of discussion on development of a compatible docking system here today and announced that a study was under way on plans for the linkup, in space of American and Soviet spacecraft.

title: From Government Data
description: CHICAGO, June 25 (UPI) The Chicago SunTimes, in its copyrighted story signed by Morton Kondracke and Thomas B. Ross, said its information had come from secret Govern ment documents.

title: AGNEW SEES PRESS IN CHEAP OPERATION
description: PHOENIX, Arizona, June 25 Vice President Agnew, in a spirited defense of the Nixon Administration's record in at tempting to end the Vietnam war, called the newspaper pub lication of topsecret Pentagon papers a common, cheap, fenc ing operation.

title: Miss Cheston Is Wed To Raul Betancourt Jr.
description: WHITEMARSH, Pa., June 25Miss Charlotte Murray Cheston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Cheston of Ambler, was married here this afternoon to Raul Betancourt Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Betancourt of Riverton, N. J. The Rev. Richard T. Hawkins per formed the ceremony, assist ed by the Rev. Dr. James R. MacColl.

title: IMPASSE IS REACHED ON TAXI WAGE PACT
description: A marathon meeting of taxi owners, union leaders and city and state officials failed yes terday to resolve an industry controversy over an unratified wage agreement and the mount ing number of gypsy cabs cruising for passengers on the streets of New York.

title: Patents of the Week
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 An invention patented this week makes welding by ultrasonics, or silent sound, even more silent. In such welding, materials are joined through heat cre ated by waves that are beyond human hearing. The trouble is that one of the pieces being welded may vibrate at a lower frequency within the audible range, generating noise. Stanley E. Jacke, president of the Branson Sonic Power Com pany, Danbury, Conn., was granted Patent 3,586,122 for a cone that surrounds the tool and workpiece, shutting in any sound.

title: Antipoverty Setup Abetting Ethnic Conflict
description: A Congressional subcommit tee heard testimony yesterday that the city's antipoverty agencies had become mechan isms to foment ethnic conflict between blacks and Puerto Ricans and between blacks and Jews.

title: Mets Conquer expos, 41, 42
description: MONTREAL, June 25The New York Mets swept a double header from the Montreal Ex pos tonight in Jarry Park, but only picked up half a game on the divisionleading Pitts burgh Pirates. The scores were 41, 42.

title: Water at Resorts Polluted
description: THE HAGUE (Reuters)The water at five Dutch seaside re sorts is so polluted it is a dan ger to swimmers, Holland's consumers association said.

title: Spending Authority Backed
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (UPI)  The Senate Appropria tions Committee approved to day a Housepassed resolution to let Government agencies continue spending at current rates into the new fiscal year starting July 1.

title: Yanks Get Swoboda for Woods;
description: Ron Swoboda, the rebel of the Mets returned to New York last night in the uniform of the Yankees.

title: ELLINGTON OPENS PARK MUSIC SERIES
description: The sixth year of the Schae fer Music Festival at the Woll man Rink in Central Park opened big on Thursday eve ning  a big crowd, two capac ity audiences of 5,000 each at the evening's two concerts, and two big bands, Duke El lington's Orchestra and the Thad JonesMel Lewis Orches tra.

title: Nov. 28 Deadline Set
description: The Inland Steel Company, the nation's seventh largest steel producer, announced yes terday in Chicago that it would guarantee not to raise prices on steel sheets before next Nov. 28.

title: Puff, After 3d Victory, Close to Morris Trophy
description: BLOCK ISLAND, R. I., June 25  The Block Island Race Week IV jinx of fog, calm, fog, foul current and more fog showed a new face todaysun shine and flat water. Neverthe less the harried Storm Trysail Club committee persisted and finally got off to a shortened race.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Wheelabrator to Redeem $1.50 Preferred July 26
description: The Wheelabrator Corpora tion announced yesterday that it had called all outstanding shares of its $1.50 cumulative convertible preferred stock for redemption July 26.

title: Soviet Court Sentences Jew Who Wanted to Emigrate
description: MOSCOW, June 25An Odessa court has sentenced Reiza Palatnilc, a Soviet Jew who had sought to go to Israel, to two years in a prison camp for planning to disseminate antiSoviet material, a court official said today. He said by telephone that the Odessa Re gional Court had delivered its verdict yesterday.

title: U.S. TRADE LOSS IS SEEN BY SPANS
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  The Secretary of Commerce, Maurice H. Stans, declared un equivocally today that the United States has been losing, and is continuing to lose, its competitiveness in world markets.

title: FRANCES HOGAN ROMES
description: Mrs. Frances Hogan Romes, chief switchboard operator for the boxing department of Mad ison Square Garden, died Thurs day after a long illness. She was 65 years old and the wife of Morris Romes. The couple lived in Hicksville, L.I.

title: Newsmen at House Hearing Accuse U.S. of Attempting Censorship
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 Representatives of the nation's news media accused the Gov ernment today of attempted censorship in blocking publica tion of the Pentagon study of the Vietnam war.

title: Executive Changes
description: PrudentialGrace Lines, Inc., announced yester day that it has formed an executive committee. The chairman of the committee will be Spyros Skouras Jr., who was elected chief executive officer of the corporation. The other members of the new committee are Spyros P. Skouras Sr., who also con tinues as chairman, James J. Connolly, who con tinues as executive vice president of the corpora tion, and A. T. DeSmedt who hat been elected president.

title: Extending Draft, Not War
description: Congressional efforts to speed the end of American military involvement in the Indochina conflict have be come focused appropriately this year on Selective Service legislation now moving toward final action.

title: N.A.S.D. Punishes 7 Brokerage Firms On Rule Violations
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (UPI)The National Associa tion of Securities Dealers, which regulates overthecoun ter trading, has taken discipli nary action against seven firms and Al individuals for viola tions of its rules of fair prac tice.

title: FUTURES HIGHER ON ORANGE JUICE
description: Talks in the trade of an im minent rise in the processor price for frozen orange juice sent futures of that commodity higher yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

title: CANNED II SOLD FOR $1MILLION
description: Canonero II, the horse that nobody wanted, has been sold for a sum in excess of a mil lion dollars. W. J. (Buddy) Hirsch announced yesterday that Robert J. Kleberg Jr., the master of the King Ranch in Texas, had purchased the Ken tuckybred colt from his owner, Pedro Baptista, of Caracas, Venezuela.

title: Federal Warrant Is Issued For the Arrest of Ellsberg
description: WASHINGTON, Saturday, June 26The Justice Depart ment announced this morning that a Federal magistrate in Lds Angeles had issued a war rant for the arrest of Dr. Daniel Ellsberg on charges that he had unauthorized possession of topsecret documents and failed to return then.

title: Screen:
description: Saul Landau's Fidel, which opened yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Cinema, is the 96minute version of the onehour documentary that was originally presented here on Channel 13 in June, 1969. Having missed the television presentation, I can only report that the theatrical Fidel is all of thattheat ricalas well as funny and moving and very persuasive.

title: Forget the Heat, It's the Season to Think of Furs
description: Ben Kahn and Leo Ritter brought the curtain down this week on a month's round of fur showings. And just in time, too. The temper ature outside during Mr. Rit ter's display was a steaming 88 degrees, and even Russian crown sable seemed too far in the cold future to be tempting.

title: 20 Other Italian Groups Meet With State Rights Chief in Complaints of Bias
description: The State Commissioner of Human Rights, Jack M. Sable, promised to investigate com plaints of discrimination he re ceived yesterday in a twohour meeting with 20 representa tives of ItalianAmerican civic, labor, political and church groups.

title: Medina Trial Set on Noncapital Basis
description: FORT McPHERSON, Ga., June 25Capt. Ernest L. Me dina was ordered today to stand trial for murders at Mylai but the possibility that he could get the death penalty was eliminated.

title: Lord Boyd Orr, 90, F.A.O. Leader, Dies
description: LONDON, June 25  Lord Boyd Orr, the first director of the Food and Agricultural Or ganization and a winner of the 1949 Nobel Peace Prize, died today at his home near Brechin, Angus, Scotland. He was 90 years old.

title: 1965: McNamara inspects American troops in Vietnam
description: In South Vietnam, the U. S. had stumbled into a bog. It would be mired down there a long time. Nihita Khrushchev to Ambassador Thompson, July 1962.

title: State Publishers Appoint
description: SYRACUSE, June 25 (UPI) Raymond C. Kennedy, president of the New York State Publish ers Association, announced to day that W. Melvin Street would become the association's executive director and general manager on Aug. 16. Mr. Street has been business manager of The Baltimore News American since 1967 and before that was general manager of the Syra cusebased Publishers Associa tion for 11 years.

title: G.I. DRUG CRACKDOWN UNDER WAY IN DELTA
description: CANTHO, South Vietnam, June 25 (AP)The most sweep ing crackdown so far against illegal drug use by American servicemen in South Vietnam is under way in the Mekong Delta.

title: Jamie Gould Rosenthal, Editor, Bride of David M. Wolf, Writer
description: STAMFORD, Conn., June 25Miss Jamie Gould Rosen thal was married here today on her 25th birthday to David Martin Wolf. Judge Cameron F. Hopper of the Probate Court in Greenwich per formed the ceremony in the garden at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Laurence Rosenthal, parents of the bride. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Wolf of Van Nuys, Calif.

title: EXNEWSPAPER AIDE SHOT BY F.B.I. IN GARY
description: GARY, Ind., June 25 (AP) A former employe of The Gary PostTribune was critically wounded last night in a gun battle with agents of the Fed eral Bureau of Investigation, who arrested him on charges of attempting to extort $30,000 from Walter T. Bidder, publisher of the paper.

title: Tie Now With Israel Unthinkable, Assert Soviet Aides at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, New York, June 25Soviet officials said here today that it was unthink able that the Soviet Union would consider resuming diplo matic relations with Israel as long as the Israeli Government had not withdrawn all its sol diers from occupied Arab terri tories.

title: Market Place: How Funds Did From '46 to '70
description: We know that in May more mutual fund shares were cashed in than soldthe first time this has happened since the Investment Company In stitute started keeping tabs in 1954.

title: East Side Is Searched in Slaying of Stewardess
description: A team of 25 detectives combed the Yorkville section of Manhattan yesterday in doortodoor search for leads in the murder of a young air line stewardess.

title: Mrs. Carner, at 143, Leads U.S. Open Golf by 2 Shots
description: ERIE, Pa., June 25 (AP) Joanne Gunderson Carner fired an erratic oneoverpar 73 in the second round of the 19th United States Women's open today, then watched it stand up for a twostroke lead as Donna Capons, the defending cham pion, slid to a 75.

title: CHANGES IN PRICE NARROW ON AMEX
description: Trading was slow and price changes narrow on the Ameri can Stock Exchange yesterday.

title: NIXON ASKS DRIVE TO IMPROVE HOMES FOR THE ELDERLY
description: CHICAGO, June 25Presi dent Nixon called today for a national effort to upgrade nurs ing homes for the elderly, which he said were too often warehouses for the unwanted dumping grounds for the dy ing.

title: G.O.P. Official Sees White House Confidence Gap
description: HEMPSTEAD, L. I., June 25 A 32yearold urban econo mist who callia himself prob ably the youngest and the poor est black Republican appointee in the Nixon Administration criticized the Administration sharply tonight, saying it had not made a moral commitment to social justice, to stemming poverty, to tap the spirit of the young.

title: Nixon's Consumer Aide Assails Advertiser SelfRegulation Plan
description: WASHINGTON, June 25A program of selfregulation drafted by advertisers and the Council of Better Business Bureaus drew unexpected crit icism today from a Presidential aide.

title: Hess Saddened by Opposition To Him for Humanities Position
description: WASHINGTON, June 25  Stephen Hess, whom President Nixon is considering for the chairmanship of the National Endowment for the Humani ties, said today that he was saddened by reports of oppo sition to his nomination by many American scholars.

title: Mayor Asks 3 M.T.A. Officials For Plan to Avert a Fare Rise
description: Mayor Lindsay warned yes terday that city subway and bus riders were in imminent danger of a sizable fare in crease, and he asked the three cityappointed members of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to develop a plan to save the 30cent fare

title: All Quiet in Cambodia
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 25 (Agence FrancePresse)  The Cambodian high command said today that the country had passed a militarily quiet 24 hours for the first time in sev eral weeks.

title: The Talk of Windhoek
description: WINDHOEK, SouthWest Africa, June 17This staid little capital of a remote ter ritory that does not know whether it is a country, a colony or just another prov ince of the South African Republic has, as of this Week, what the Continental Hotel proclaims as a new form of enter tainmentgogo girls. One dancer who signed up for Conti  Go  Go, Cerise Yooste, a 21yearold secretary and parttime model, was bub bling. Man, this is some thing new! she said. I don't really think they are that square here.

title: Shapp Will Request Alternative Tax
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 25  Gov Milton J. Shapp an nounced today that he would ask the Legislature for a new tax, following a 5402 ruling yesterday by the Pennsylvania Supreme Court that the state's first personal income tax was unconstitutional.

title: JUDGE HOLDS UP CHICAGO CHARGES
description: CHICAGO, June 25Judge Joseph A. Power refused today to open sealed indictments against law enforcement offi cials who were involved in raid in which two Black Pan thers were killed by the police.

title: B.O.A.C. STOPS ORDER FOR FOUR 747 JETS
description: LONDON, June 25 (UPI) The British Overseas Airways Corporation, citing a glum long range outlook, disclosed today it has canceled orders for four Boeing 747 jumbo jets sched uled for delivery in 1973.

title: SPECIALISTS URGE TIES WITH PEKING
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 The Senate Foreign Relations Committee today heard three prominent specialistsa his torian, a scientist and a China scholarurge the United States to establish diplomatic relations with Peking.

title: Reform Rabbis Reaffirm View on Mixed Marriages
description: ST. LOUIS, June 25 (AP) By a narrow margin, the Cen tral Conference of American Rabbis rejected yesterday an attempt to move the reform group's position closer to the conservative and orthodox branches of Judaism on the subject of mixed marriages.

title: ROGER W. M'ADAM, WRITER, WAS 71
description: KEARNY, N. J., June 25 Roger Williams McAdam, an authority on steamboating on Long Island Sound, died today of cancer at Presbyterian Hos pital, Newark.,He was 71 years old and lived at 48 Hillcrest Road.

title: British Business Receives Terms on Market Warmly
description: LONDON, June 25  British businessmen are generally giv ing a warm reception to the terms obtained for British entry into the European Economic Community.

title: From Government Data
description: CHICAGO, June 25 (UPI) The Chicago SunTimes, in its copyrighted story signed by Morton Kondracke and Thomas B. Ross, said its information had come from secret Govern ment documents.

title: Mitchell Shoots a 64 for 130 and Stroke Lead
description: CLEVELAND, June 25 (UPI) Bobby Mitchell, who never has won a Professional Golfers Association tour event, gained the lead after 36 holes today in the $150,000 Cleveland open golf tournament with a seven underpar 64. His total of 130 gave him a stroke edge over Dan Sikes.

title: EQUITY RATIFIES 3YEAR CONTRACT
description: Sixtyfive members of Actors Equity Association's council, the union's governing board, unanimously ratified yesterday the terms of a new threeyear Broadway production contract.

title: China: Mass Efforts Achieve Great Feats
description: PEKING, June 20  In China today one sees every where evidence of what peo ple powerenormous num bers of men and women equipped with only primitive tools but all thinking alike and acting in concert can accomplish.

title: Gas Area Decontaminated
description: IMPERIAL, Calif., June 25 (UPI)Decontamination crews hosed down today the streets around a pesticide storage area, wrecked by fire yesterday, where poisonous gas forced the evacuation of nearly 1,000 people. The residents of the 28square block area in this ag ricultural community were or dered to keep out of the area for at least 48 hours.

title: Mangel Licenses Drug Unit
description: The Mangel Stores Corpora tion announced yesterday that it has licensed Shoppers Drug of America, Inc., to operate all ofg the health and beauty aid departments in the balance of the Mangel's Shopper Fair dis count department store chain, comprising 44 stores.

title: EDWARD C. REILLY JR.
description: RUMSON, N. J., June 25 Edward C. Reilly Jr., municipal engineer for the towns of Perth Amboy, South Amboy, Union Beach and Lakehurst, died yes terday at Riverview Hospital, Red Bank.

title: LEADER IS CHOSEN
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., June 25The Rev. Dr. David G. Col well of Seattle was elected to day moderator, or spiritual leader, of the twomillion ment ber United Church of Christ. His election opened the, five day biennial general synod of the denomination, in the Grand Rapids Municipal Auditorium.

title: Bernard G. Richards, 94, Dies; A Jewish Leader and Author
description: Bernard G. Richards, a Jewish leader, author and answer man, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital. He was 94 years old and lived at 310 West 106th Street.

title: Mrs. Lewis W. Douglas Jr., Interior Decorator on Coast
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., June 25Mrs. Virginia Welch. Doug las, wife of Lewis W. Douglas Jr., a real estate developer, died Wednesday in the Cedars of Lebanon Hospital in Los An geles, after a short illness. She was 48 years old and lived in Beverly Hills.

title: ANTIPOVERTY UNIT SUES OVER REPORT
description: WASHINGTON June 25 Lawyera for the California Rural Legal Assistance. Project filed suit in Federal Court to day to force the Office of Economic Opportunity to re lease immediately a study of the antipoverty project.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Little Red Rocky Hood
description: For some time an almost fairytale quality has pervaded relationships between New York State and New York City. Velvet words often shield iron action; things fre quently are not what they seem; and on every hand there is a now you see it, now you don't atmosphere in the interchange between New York and Albany.

title: Daughter Greets President
description: CAMP DAVID, Md., June 25 (AP)President Nixon flew by helicopter to this Presidential retreat today and was greeted by his honeymooning daughter, Tricia, and her husband, Ed ward F. Cox.

title: Blind Typist Gets Award
description: Miss Mary Lou Raia, a blind dictaphone typist at Abex Cor poration; yesterday received a citation from the Governor's Committee on Employ the. Han dicapped. The award, which was presented at a ceremony by Dr. Howard A. Rusk, direc tor of the Institute for Rehabili tation Medicine, is given an nually to an outstanding handi capped person. dicapped. The award, which was presented at a ceremony by Dr. Howard A. Rusk, direc tor of the Institute for Rehabili tation Medicine, is given an nually to an outstanding handi capped person.

title: James F. Blumstein, Lawyer, Marries Miss Andree S. Kahn
description: SCARSDALE, N.Y., June 25Miss Andrea Sophia Kahn, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ludwig W. Kahn of Scars dale, was married here this afternoon to James F. Blum stein of Nashville.

title: NEWISSUES LIST MAKES WIDE GAIN
description: The newissue market scored a strong advance this week with much of the interest cen tered on Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., the world's largest investment house, which went public.

title: Postal Pact Talks Pressed
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (UPI)The United States Post al Service and seven unions began continuous negotiations today in an effort to reach a contract agreement covering 650,000 employes of the new service that replaces the Post Office Department on Thurs day.

title: Mafia Suspects Moved After Islanders' Protest
description: ASINARA, Italy, June 25 (UPI)Fifteen alleged Mafia leaders came ashore on this tiny island off Sardinia to day with a heavy police es cort.

title: Magnuson Favors Agency To Help Ailing Companies
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (Reu ters)Senator Warren Magnu son, chairman of the Senate Commerce Committee, pledged his support tonight to estab lishment of a Government fi nancing agency to help the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation and other ailing companies.

title: DR. HAYWARD F. DAY
description: NORTH PLAINFIELD. N.J., June 25Dr. Hayward. F. Day, former chief of pediatrics at Muhlenberg Hospital in Plain field, died at the hospital on Tuesday after a brief illness. He was 64 years old and lived at 144 Roclview Avenue, North Plainfield.

title: Mrs. Alice B. Ramrua Is Married to a Judge
description: Mrs. Alice Bernstein Ram rus, daughter of Edward A. Bernstein of New York and the late Mrs. Evelyn Levin Bernstein, was married here last evening to Judge Leonard H. Sandler of the New York City Civil Court. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William B. Sandler of New York. Justice Edward J. Greenfield of the State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the Dardanelles Restaurant.

title: PAPER IN ST. LOUIS DEFENDS ARTICLES
description: The St. Louis PostDispatch yesterday published 38 columns of articles drawn from the Pen tagon papers on United States involvement in Vietnam.

title: Jersey High Court Backs ParochialSchool Busing
description: TRENTON, June 25  The New Jersey Supreme Court to day upheld the constitution ality of the state's busing pro gram for parochial and pri vateschool children, reversing a lowercourt decision.

title: Impact in Jersey
description: TRENTON, June 26The Pennsylvania Supreme Court's action in striking down the in crime tax in that state has re percussions in New Jersey across the Delaware River.

title: Scholar Reaches Israel
description: TEL AVIV, June 25  Dr. Mikhail I. Zand, a Soviet schol ar and Zionist militant whose long struggle to leave the So viet Union was backed by American professors, reached Israel by plane this morning with members of his family.

title: A Soviet Marshal Praises Ulbricht in Published Letter
description: BERLIN June 25  A Soviet marshal today publicly praised Walter Ulbricht, the veteran Communist who recently lost key positions in the East Ger man leadership.

title: FACTORIES IMPROVE LIQUIDITY POSITION
description: The liquidity position of the nation's manufacturers im proved again in the first quar ter of 1971, reflecting a reduced demand on them by customers for extended payment terms.

title: Firestone to Close Plant
description: F LL RIVER, Mass., June 25 (AP)The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company an nounced today it is closing its foamrubber plant here Sept. 30. The plant now employs about 300 persons.

title: Newsday Threatened With Suit For Use of Johnson's Memoirs
description: Newsday, the Long Island newspaper, yesterday published an account of the American involvement in the Vietnams war that it said was based on galley proofs of Lyndon B. Johnson's forthcoming Presi dential memoirs.

title: GOVERNOR SIGNS BILL TO INCREASE LULUS
description: ALBANY, June 25Gover nor Rockefeller has signed, without comment, a bill in creasing from $3,000 to $5,000 the appropriation for personal expenses for state legislators, his office announced today.

title: Brandt Urges New Talks On East German Relations
description: BONN, June 25Chancellor Willy Brandt signaled today to East Germany's new leader, Erich Honecker, that he thinks it is time to resume discussions on establishing formal relations between the two German states.

title: Art: Pleasures of English Landscape
description: The English tradition in the art of landscape, at once so romantic and so soft spoken, is appealing on sev eral counts. It celebrates all that is most lyrical, humble and affecting in the observ able world of nature. It is full of spontaneous perceptions and responses, of unexpected views and modest vistas. Yet an authentic tide of feeling carries it along whether the results are small in scale or spectacular in outlook. We are always given the sense of a specific, concrete emo tion freshly experienced.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I wish to dissent from the Policy Statement by U. S. China Scholars which appeared as an advertisement in your June 14 issue. In this many of my colleagues advocate that the Peo ple's Republic of China be granted ittt legitimate seat in all United Nations bodies as the sole Government of China.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Upstate Rock Fete Canceled
description: NORTH ROSE, N. Y., June 25 (AP) A rock festival that was to have been held this weekend in this community has been canceled by its sponsors, the North Rose Supervisor, Robert Virts, said today. Mr. Virts said the organizers had been unable to meet state re quirements regarding sanitary facilities, drinking water and insurance.

title: BOBBY BAKER'S WIFE TESTIFIES IN THEFTS
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) The wife of Robert G. (Bobby) Baker, former aid to the Sen ate Democratic majority, testi fied today that thousands of dollars worth of stolen silver ware, china and art objects, were stored in her home in Washington in the fall of 1969.

title: Menotti Opens Spoleto Festival With Boris Godunov of 1869
description: SPOLETO, Italy, June 25 The freshness of youthful mu sicianship from the United States and some practical schol arship combined to produce en thusiasm for Spoleto's resur rection of the real Boris God unov at last night's Festival of Two Worlds opening.

title: Veterans, Once Home, Want to work and Forget
description: ROSWELL, N.M.  One by one, the young men of Roswell who fought the war in Vietnam are coming home to reclaim their place in the burning desert sun.

title: Mills of U. of Maine Retains 3Shot Lead in N.C.A.A. Golf
description: TUCSON, Ariz., June 25 (AP) John Mills carded a oneun derpar 71 today to retain his threestroke lead after the third round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association golf championships.

title: Mitchell Sees Abuses of Habeas Corpus
description: HUNTSVILLE, Ala., June 25 (AP)Abuse of the right of habeas corpus by convicted criminals has clogged the Fed eral courts and is stripping jury decisions of any finality, Attorney General John N. Mitchell said today.

title: 3 Women Killed in Collision
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 25 (AP)  Three women were killed and a fourth was badly injured In a headon collision on the Connecticut Turnpike near Exit 4 shortly after 11 A.M. today. The state police identified the dead women as Mrs. Janette P. Runge, 60 years odd and Mrs. Carol M. Runge, both of Farmingdale, L. I., and Mrs. Siriratan Jon tugdee, 31, of Paterson, N. J, The survivor, Mrs. Luming San giem, 31, of Mount Vernon, N. Y., was taken to Greenwich Hospital.

title: PESO IS DEVALUED 4.76% BY ARGENTINA
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 25 The Argentine peso was cut in value to 4.40 to a dollar today, the fourth minor devaluation in less than three months.

title: DOW OFF BY 0.58; VOLUME NEAR LOW
description: Stock prices continued to ease yesterday as trading ac tivity remained near the lowest level of the year.

title: Juvenile Court Dilemma
description: In two recent cases, the Supreme Court has again confronted the fact that the juvenile court system is not working as it was intended. The Court's opinion written by Justice Blackmun is severe in its comments on the failings of juvenile courts.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Truck Deal With Moscow
description: The news that Mack Trucks, Inc., has signed a prelimi nary agreement with the Soviet Government to help design and equip the world's largest truck factory sug gests that history is about to repeat itself.

title: Paper Says Nixon Disregarded C.I.A. Advice on a War Pullout
description: CHICAGO, June 25 (AP)The Chicago SunTimes said today that Government documents re vealed that the Central Intel ligence Agency had advised President Richard M. Nixon in 1969 that if the United States withdrew from Vietnam all of Southeast Asia would remain as it is for another generation.

title: OUTBURSTS DELAY KICKBACKS TRIAL
description: NEWARK, June 25Walter Wolfe, the Huddorr County Democratic chairman who, with seven political associates, is on trial here in Federal Court on chatges of conspiracy and ex tortion, leaped from his chair three times during sessions of the trial today to disrupt the courtroom.

title: Stuttgart Ensemble Performs Josquin in a Cappella Version
description: The International Josquin Festival pursued its pleasant and instructive course on Thursday night with another large audience of professional and amateur musicologists in attendance. The third of four public concerts brought the Schola Cantorum Stuttgart to Alice Tully Hall in a cappella program of works by the Ren aissance master Josquin des Prez, conducted by Clytus Gott wald.

title: Lindsay Blames Cuts For Dump in a Park
description: Mayor Lindsay yesterday blamed cutbacks in Parks Department personnel and litter left by tourists for what a member of the House of Representatives from Mis souri called the valley of a garbage dump in Battery Park.

title: 1965: McNamara inspects American troops in Vietnam
description: LENOX, Mass.Long before the Attorney General turned on The Times to try to suppress publication of clas sified documents, historians had suf fered from the Government's denial of access to confidential records with out which they could not write serious history.

title: Broadcaster Group Elects Richard Chapin Chairman
description: Richard W. Chapin, president of Stuart Enterprises, of Lin coln, Neb., is the new chair man of the National Associa tion of Broadcasters. He was unanimously elected earlier this week in Washington, where he is undergoing treat ment for kidney stones and thus was unable to attend the meeting that elected him to head the 44member board.

title: BOND MAY GIVE UP ITS 5TH AVE. STORE
description: Bond Stores, Inc., declined to comment yesterday on trade reports that the major men's wear chain would not renew its lease on its large store on Fifth Avenue at 35th Street.

title: Boost for Quebec Separatism
description: The Quebec provincial Government's rejection of a new draft Canadian Constitution is good news only for Quebec separatists. It was a decision taken by a Liberal Government committed to seeking Quebec's goals inside the Canadian federation; but the real victor was the opposition Parti Quebecois, which aims at outright sepa ration from Canada.

title: Cyanamid Plans Rises
description: The American Cyanamid Com pany said yesterday that it planned to increase prices by about 7 per cent on its line of Cymel melamine molding com pounds used primarily in plas tic dinnerware and in the manufacture of buttons.

title: WITNESS ASSAYS THIEVES OF STOCK
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (AP) Thieves of Wall Street secu rities are sophisticated enough to learn the art of computer ized crime even if actual stocks and bonds, are replaced by an electronic bookkeeping system, an insurance executive told Senators today.

title: Jewish Parley Opposes Aid to Religious Schools
description: ATLANTA, June 25A con ference of Jewish community relations leaders affirmed today its continued opposition to any Government funding of sectar iansponsored education. Rep resentatives of Orthodox Ju daism dissented.

title: Southwest Utility Gains
description: The Southwestern Public Service; Company reported yes terday a gain of 23.1 per cent in net income for the May quarter on an increase of 10.6 per cent in gross revenues for the three months ended May 31. The quarterly report placed revenues at $23,582,671 up from $21,317,449 a year before. Net income rose to $4,865,903, or 23 cents a share, from $3, 952,512, or 19 cents a share.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Antiques: Staffordshire Is In Again
description: Blue and white historical Staffordshire, the English pottery with printed decora tion of scenes recording American events or views of significant landmarks, is com ing into Its own again after years of neglect.

title: 1965: McNamra inspects American troops in Vietnam
description: WASHINGTONThe Pentagon study disclosures engender mixed emotions, although the elements in the mix are not of equal weight. Not even a deter mined opponent of a damnable war can, I think, greet the episode with undiluted joy, for it adds new ingredi ents of unmeasurable consequence to what has become a Greek tragedy without a last act.

title: 3 With Knapsacks Cross Paths Abroad
description: COPENHAGEN, June 21 They met in the central rail road station. Say, you know where the information center is? asked Carlyn Hove, a 19yearold Seattle coed, who was carrying a knapsack.

title: Notes on People
description: Representative Wilbur D. Mills had more trouble yes terday convincing people that he is not a candidate for the Democratic Presidential nom ination.

title: Harlem Models Stress Unity Idea
description: It was at the foot of the street corner ladder of the late Harlem orator, Carlos Cooks, that Ronnie Brathwaite and his brother, Cecil Elombe Brath, learned as kids about national ism. They never declaimed from the top of it, but today, some 20 years later, they stand out prominently among the grow ing number of young African Nationalists in Harlem.

title: Rev. John J. Long, ExHead Of University of Scranton
description: SCRANTON, Pa., June 25 The Rev. John J. Long, pres ident of the University of Scranton from 1953 to 1963, died last Friday, at the age of 71.

title: Hong Kong Talks Continue
description: HONG KONG, June 25 (UPI) Hong Kong today ended the fifth day of talks with the United States aimed at working out an agreement to curb this colony's noncotton textile ex ports to the United States.

title: Security National Bank Boat to Lure Fire Islanders
description: OCEAN BEACH, Fire Island, L. I., June 25The Security National Bank, which has $lbillion in assets scattered through its 67 branches on Long Island, launched its 68th branch this week.

title: City's Ethics Board, in a Reversal, Clears Postel
description: The city's Board of Ethics has cleared Councilman Robert I. Postel of a conflictofinter est charge in the first reversal of a major opinion in its 12 year history.

title: Mortgage Money Termed Available;
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (UPI) Mortgage money con tinues to be available in siz able amounts through federally insured savings and loan asso ciations, Freston Martin, chair man of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, said today.

title: Cholera Cases and Deaths Doubled in '71, W.H.O. Says
description: GENEVA, June 24  The World Health Organization said today that so far this year there have been 64,924 cholera cases and 10,595 deaths from cholera, throughout the world, more than double the figures for the same period in 1970.

title: New Faces Help Yanks Vanquish Senators, 122
description: With Ron Swoboda playing left field and a rookie, Ron Blomberg, in right field, the Yankees treated themselves to a new look last night, and it included a 13hit outburst that routed the Washington Senators, 122.

title: A WALTER MITTY IS FASTEST OF ALL
description: EUGENE, Ore., June 25  From a practical point of view, I shouldn't be here, Dr. Delano Meriwether said today after his spectacular victory in the 100 yard dash at the national Ama teur Athletic Union outdoor track and field championships.

title: Gradual Economic Rise With G.N.P. Lag Seen
description: WASHINGTON, June 25The United States Chamber of Commerce said today that 1971 would be a year of grad ual improvement in the economy, with the gross national product estimated at $1.05 billion, well under the Gov ernment's forecast.

title: Reagan Aide Accused
description: SACRAMENTO. Calif., June 25 (UPI)Gov. Ronald Reagan's antipoverty director has been accused by a Federal auditor of having, improperly spent almost $100,000, including $2,101 on political telegrams. The tele grams allegedly were sent in behalf of George Murphy, who was then the Republican Sen ator.

title: NEPTUNE RAINCOAT IN BANKRUPTCY STEP
description: The Neptune Raincoat Com pany, a subsidiary of Beck In dustries, Inc., yesterday filed a petition in the United States District Court for a reorganiza tion under Chapter X of the Federal Bankruptcy Act. Liabil ities and assets were each listed at $1,733,230, as of April 28.

title: Gas Service Co. Offering
description: The Gas Service Company filed yesterday a registration statement with the Securities, and Exchange Commission cov ering a proposed public offer ing of a $20million firstmort gage bond series due 1991 and 340,000 shares of common stock. The offerings will be un derwritten by groups managed by Eastman Dillon, Union Se curities & Co., Inc., and Stern Brothers & Co. Net proceeds, will be used to repay outstand ing shortterm debt, incurred for financing part of the com pany's construction outlays and to retire a maturing bond issue.

title: Capital Church Is Bridal Setting Of Tila Hidalgo
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 Miss Tila Hidalgo, daughter of Edward Hidalgo of Paris and Mrs. Nancy McNeil Hi dalgo of Mexico City, was married here today tq Joseph Rice Neuhaus Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Neuhaus of Hous ton. The ceremony in St. John's Episcopal Church, Georgetown, was performed by the Rev. James C. Fen hagen. A reception was given at the Chevy Chase Club by the bride's father and step mother.

title: DR MERIWETHER, 28 AND A ROOKIE, CAPTURES U.S. 100
description: EUGENE, Ore., June 25Dr. Delano Meriwether achieved his impossible dream, Rod Milburn broke the oldest world record in track and field, and Steve Prefontaine shattered 13 min utes in the threemile.

title: Dacca Is Still Gripped by Fear 3 Months After the Onslaught
description: DACCA, June 25  People talk with foreigners in a whis per and keep looking behind them to see if anyone is listen ing. Soldiers and special police brought from West Pakistan, more than 1,000 miles away stop and search cars and buses and people carrying bundles.

title: HEALTH UNIT HERE TOBE UNCHANGED
description: Dr. Hollis S. Ingraham, the State Health Commissioner, said yesterday that state super vision of the New York City Health Department is not go ing to mean any immediate or profound change in our rela tionship.

title: 3 of 6 Adolescents Seized In Bikers Island Escape
description: Six inmates of the Adolescent Remand Center on Rikers Island escaped through a priedopen window last night. Three of them, all 20 years of age, were quickly recap tured.

title: Ecumenical Moderator
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., June 25The new modera tor, or spiritual loader, of the two  million  member United Church of Christ is a burly, handsome preacher. He is the Rev. Dr. David Griffith Col wellaecumenist, liberal theo logian and pastor. Dr. Col well, elected at a meeting of

title: Meskill and Democrats Act To End Budget Deadlock
description: HARTFORD, June 25The Republican Governor and the Democrats who control the Con necticut General Assembly moved tonight toward agree ment on a state fiscal program for the coming year.

title: AUTO PRODUCTION DECLINES IN WEEK
description: DETROIT, June 25 (AP) Automobile production in the United States dropped this week as the annual vacation and modelchangeover period got under way.

title: Savings Rate Ebbs
description: WASHINGTON, June 25 (Reuters)Net new savings re ceived by insured savings and loan associations contracted slightly in May to $2,069,000, 000 from $2,092,000,000 in April, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported today.

title: Rabbi Lands Here on Sabbath, So He's Walking to Brooklyn
description: The 39yearold chief rabbi of Milan, Italy, started on a fivehour walk from Kennedy International Airport to the Crown Heights Section of Brooklyn early this morning because a delay had forced his airplane to Iand after sun down, the beginning of the Jewish Sabbath.

title: Ouster of Soviet Official Stirs Protests
description: MOSCOW, June 25The dis missal of a publichealth in spector who refused to yield to political pressure has erupted into something of a scandal here.

title: SWEEP REPORTED NEAR FALLEN BASE
description: SAIGON, South Vietnams June 25  A hunt was reported under way near the de militarized zone today for the scores of enemy mortar and rocket emplacements that con tributed to the Government's loss of Fire Base Fuler yester day.

title: Mrs. Joy Miller, Adrian C. Israel, A Broker, Marry
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., June 25Mrs. Joy Whitmore Miller of Essex Fells, N. J., was married here this morn ing to Adrian Cremieux Is rael, a widower, of Stamford.

title: Son Ange Seeks Seventh Victory of Year Today as Belmont Meeting Closes
description: The getaway day card at Bel mont Park today will be headed by the Saranac, an al lowance test for 3yearolds at a mile. A field of eight may compete in the 64th running of the event and if all go, the gross value will be $57,100, the winner earning $34,260.

title: Draft Call Issued Despite Law's Status
description: WASHINGTON, June 25The Defense Department said today tar it was asking Selective Service officials to draft 16,000 men for July and August. The draft call, to be divided about equally between the two months, is the lowest since last December, when approximately 7,000 men were drafted.

title: ltalianAmericara League Said to Pressure Shops
description: Scores of merchants in the Bensonhurst section of Brook lyn have told the Kings County Board of Trade that they will close their stores Monday  ItalianAmerican United Day only because they are afraid of boycotts or broken windows if they stay open.

title: Confessions Of a White
description: The title is arresting. To anyone Who doesn't know who Larry King is, it is probably also misleading. Doesn't it sound like Governor Wal lace or Senator Eastland repenting in extremis a misspent life?

title: AMPLIFICATION
description: In the Magazine of March 15, 1970, Robert Sherrill, replying to a letter by Otto F. Otepka, said: Otepka was charged with, and on Nov. 5, 1963, dismissed for, violating three regulations governing the release, declassification and mutilation of government documents.

title: A Moynihan Report
description: For Daniel Patrick Moynihan, who had also served in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, his two years with Presi dent Nixon were full of complex tension. To his friends he was a renegade Democrat,

title: TWOHOUR DEBATE
description: WASHINGTON, June 26  The Supreme Court, heard two hours of arguments today and then took under advisement the Government's effort to en join The New York Times and The Washington Post from publishing Material from the Pentagon, papers on Vietnam.

title: Stamps
description: ON Thursday, the New York Post Office, as well as 31,999 other post offices through out the United States, will become part of the United States Postal Service, after nearly 200 years as facilities of the United. States Post Of fice Department. This deficit ridden governmental depart ment is being transformed into the U.S.P.S., a govern ment corporation, in an effort to bring the American mail service out of the reda condition which has existed since Ben Franklin was Post master General.

title: Recordings
description: ALFRED HITCHCOCK's horror classic, Psy cho, so numbed me when I first saw it in 1959, I didn't notice whether it had a musical background or not. I was too busy bracing for the next shock and telling my wife for hea ven's sake to open her eyes, it wasn't that bad. (She didn't; it was.) I do remem ber hearing high, screaming sounds during the bloodbath in the shower as Janet Leigh was filleted by Tony Perkins in a Mother Suit, but that was all. Now the music from Psycho and four other Hitchcock thrillers has been recorded by the composer of the scores, Bernard Herrmann, and hearing them I realize how mucha'debt Hitch owed to his composer.

title: About the black accused and the white accusers
description: In the midsixties, LeRod Jones seemed destined to become America's next great Negro literary figure. He had written several successful plays, including the prizewinning The Dutchman, had published two highly praised volumes of poetry, novel, a collection of short stories and a book (Blues People) that remains perhaps the finest exposition of black music available. Jones, was the obvious heir apparent to James Baldwin's crown. But then Jones took a sharp and unexpected turn from the gilded pathway to estab lishment literary success (to draw away from the dead body, and its spirit), first to Harlem and the Black Arts Repertoire Theater/School, and later to Newark and Spirit House.

title: Donohue, Bettering 172 Miles an Hour, Wins Pole for 500Mile Auto Race
description: LONG POND, Pa., June 26 (AP)Mark Donohue of Media, Pa., went out in the cool of the afternoon today and took the pole (position for the Schaefer 500mile race from Bobby Unser with a speed of 172.393 miles an hour.

title: James Honeycutt Weds Suzanne Propst
description: PITTSBURGH, June 26 Miss Suzanne Leake Propst and James Peter Honeycutt, members of a folkrock group known as Repairs, were mar ried in St. Paul's Roman Catholic Cathedral here this afternoon. The Rev. Thomas G. Ferris performed the cere mony.

title: THOMAS CONDUCTS THE PHILHARMONIC
description: First rate music that made no claim to profundity marked the third and last pro gram given by the New York Philharmonic in cooperation with the A.F.L.C.I.O. Presented in Philharmonic Hall on Friday night, it was repeated at Co Op City in the Bronx last night and will end the union series this afternoon at Philharmonic Hall.

title: HARVARD PLACES 3 ON ALLSTAR SOCCER
description: The New England National Collegiate soccer champion, Harvard, has placed three men on the 1970 National Soccer Coaches Association AllNew England soccer team voted by member coaches.

title: For Britain Alone to Decide
description: Now it is all up to Britain. In the negotiations just concluded in Luxembourg, the six governments of the European Community went  far to accommodate the British on those issues that were still outstanding. For eign Minister Schumann of France contributed the right note at a victory press conference when he said he no longer regarded Britain as a negotiating rival but a member of the European Community.

title: Militant Homosexuals to Stage March to Central Park Today
description: Thousands of homosexuals are expected to march from Christopher Street in Green wich Village to the Sheep Meadow in Central Park this afternoon to mark the second anniversary of a movement known to them as the Gay Revolution.

title: Vogue, Bazaar Are Changing In Own Ways

description: THE malaise that has been developing over the state of the economy seemed to broaden last week in the financial markets, in business circles, among the public and even in Washington.

title: Toward a More Secure Society
description: Of all the free Western countries, the United States remains the last to come to terms with the realities of poverty. Nearly a century ago, the Germany of Bismarck and the AustriaHungary of the Habsburgs had widows' pensions and ?? social insurance which this country did not accept until 1935. Governmentbacked medical insurance and public housing are still controversial ideas in, the United States decades after they have become commonplace throughout Western Europe.

title: COACHING SOCCER IN BRAZIL RISKY
description: RIO DE JANEIRO (UPI) Soccer coaches in Brazil have even less job security than their counterparts in United States baseball and football.

description: SAN FRANCISCOElisabeth Horn, a very tall brunette whose long hair fell down on her buckskin cape and almost covered the baby riding on her back in a rucksack, waved from the curb at the powderblue van rolling along Mission Street.

Kis singer, President Nixon's na tional security adviser.

Union one wall handball doubles cham pionship yesterday by defeating Harold Brofsky and Fred Kal man of the Brownsville Hand ball Club, 2118, 219, at Brighton Beach, Brooklyn.

title: Kerr on Bury the Dead
description: THE supply of talent never dwindles but it must first be found and formed. At the moment a producerdirector named Vinnette Carroll, hith erto best known as an actress, is doing an astonishing job of finding and forming in her tiny upstairs theater, as Off Off Broadway as Off Off can be, at 26 West 20th Street. She has just tackled, of all unlikely things, a musical ver sion of Irwin Shaw's Bury the Dead, and out of it she has brought not only an eve thing of vigorously enveloping sound but a parade of sing ing (and acting) performers skilled enough to put the best of to shame.

title: AUSTRALIA SPLIT OVER RUGBY VISIT

Corballis's Aquarius rallied to become a 1minute, 10length Soling Class winner in the 14th championship regatta of the season for Yacht Racing As sociation fleets based east of Rye on Long Island Sound.

title: HARRY J. SOHMER
description: Harry J. Solumer, president of Sohmer & Co., the piano man ufacturing concern, died Thurs day at his home. He was 85 years old and lived at 242 East 72d Street.

title: Oh, To e Rich And Sexy in Venice
description: JUST before the house lights went down at a preview of Luchino Vis conti's Death in Venice (now playing at the Little Carnegie Theater), I overheard the following con versation between two young people. By their dress, manner and vocabulary, they had already proclaimed themselves to be members of the hip New York scene, that group of achieving survivors whose identity, I suspect, is largely de fined by the consumer goods they elect to purchase, and by the promotion and advertising by which those elections are rigged. The Hip Young Man and the Hip Young Woman had obviously heard about the film's rave reviews in London, and about its 25th Anniversary Award at this year's Cannes Film Festival.

title: Key Exhibit on Court's Red Carpet
description: WASHINGTON, June 26  The grayhaired lady smiled, her eyes twinkling, as she stead just inside the colon nailed Main hall of the United States Supreme Court and of fered a document to a re porter.

description: WARSAW, June 26, (Reuters) Polish and American Amateur boxers will meet in Warsaw Aug. 5 in the first international tournament between the coun tries since 1934. Polish boxing officials said today.

title: Foreign Notes
description: Quebec's NonFor more than 40 years a suc cession of Governments in Ot tawa has tried to give Canada a constitution of her own in place of the British North America Act of 1867, which united the orig inal four colonies in the Canadian federation. Most Canadians would like to see their constitution patriatedor brought home. Some, including Prime Minister Pierre Trudeau, would like to have a Bill of Rights and the provision for a Supreme Court embodied in a new charter, as both are in the United States Constitution. Canada's existing civilrights guarantees and her federal Supreme Court are estab lished by laws that the Ottawa Parliament enacted and could repeal.

title: 2 Tarred and Feathered In Ulster Are Hospitalized
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sunday, June 27 (AP)Two men were tarred and feathered in Belfast early today. Both were taken to hospitals. One, aged 19, suffered severe burns on his legs and arms from the scalding tar.

title: Arcari Retains Crown With Knockout of Jana
description: PALERMO, Sicily, June 26 (AP)Bruno Arcari of Italy, stopped thhe Argentine chal lenger Henrique Jana, in the ninth round tonight to retain his World Boxing Council junior welterweight title.

There is a growing lag in popular support for univer sities and lowerlevel schools alike, and often education al issues  such as teach ers' work schedules and budg ets  are thrust into the political arena.

description: Offtrack daily doubles and exactas may be offered on thoroughbred races at Aque duct within a week or so, a spokesman for the city's Offtrack Betting Corporation indicated yesterday.

title: Art
description: THE issue of Conceptual Art, maybe the most pervasive avantgarde phenomenon of the day, cannot be said to have exactly electrified artworld discourse or public attention during these past (its heyday) couple of seasons  which might say something about the currently atomized state of avantgardism in general, but in any case says much about the character of Con ceptualism in particular. For there is about the movement, for all its radical ambitions to liberate art from the ob ject, something so unsensa tlonalso dismal, eventhat anything like an excited re sponse to it can seem posi tively Incongruous. As a re sult, in this case the sort of thisisit, theendofart asweknowit rhetoric that is the obligatory anthem of avantgarde movements has a more than usually irritating edge, tempting some with the opinion that, if this is what art is coming to, then the hell with it.

title: Budget Accord Is Neat in Connecticut
description: HARTFORD, June 26Demo cratic and Republican leaders of the General Assembly were reported to be near agreement today on a state tax and budg et plan for the fiscal year starting Thursday.

description: It's summer on Seventh Avenue and the living is better.

title: Man Seized in Nixon Threat
description: SHREVEPORT, La., June 26 (CPI)Federal officials ar rested William Phillip Taylor, 50 years old, of El Paso, yester day and charged him with threatening to kill President Nixon. The authorities said that Mr. Taylor wrote a letter June 17 threatening the life of the President. A Secret Service agent, Frank Farnsworth, said he had heard Mr. Taylor say, I would kill Nixon if I got the chance to go to Washington, D.C., so as to rid this country of a fake and a tyrant. I have nothing to lose.

title: Art Notes
description: WHO'D suspect that Jonathan Holstein and Gail Ann van der Hoof, a nice young couple who share an apartment, also partake of a mania? Their living room is piled high withold Ameri can quilts (more than 300, at last count); quilts in such pat terns as Shoofly and Crazy, Babies' Blocks and Roman Squares, Ships' Wheels and Log Cabins and Double Irish Chains.

title: Art
description: IT is great painters who create great art deal ers. This beautifully immodest and altogeth er accurate claim on his own behalf by DanielHenry Kahn weiler is not one likely to be disputed, at least so far as Mr. Kahnweiler's own status is concerned, either by his contemporaries or by the judgment of posterity. Of the many dealers who have pre sided over the commercial fate of modern art, creating for an often unappreciated and indeed unwanted esthet is commodity a viable eco onomic position, Mr. Kahn weiler is one of the very few to emerge as a significant historical personage in his own right. He is a man of remarkable intelligence as well as taste, and his writ ings on modern art  par ticularly his short, early study of Cubism and his later mon ograph on Juan Griswould have earned him a place in the annals of modern art studies even if he had not played an important role in the social history of the art itself.

title: Architecture
description: I'M NOT so sure about London's cleaned  up buildings. The process made Paris a milk and honey beauty, but it hasn't worked that way here.

title: One of the World's Oldest Experiments in Wilderness Preservation
description: LYNDHURST, England  We came unexpectedly upon the Queen Bower in England's 900year old New Forest near here, and we were immediately entranced. For a moment, we halfwondered if Titania, the Queen of Fairies, might appear, ac companied by Bottom the Weaver, marvellous hairy about the face. For although Shakespeare may not have had the New Forest in mind when he wrote the above lines, the setting would be perfect for A Midsummer Night's Dream.

title: Home Improvement
description: A NEW automatic glue gun that heats up ex ceptionally fast also has an unusual new kind of selffeeding tip that eliminates dripping or oozing and that makes it easy to apply glue without the tip sticking. The gun is designed to dispense either glue or calking, both of which come in special sticks that are load ed into the top of the gun. The gun heats up and is ready for use in about 30 seconds and the user can tell when it is hot enough be cause a combination workin dicator light at the front end of the housing, near the tip, comes on when the gun is hot enough. A springactu ated plunger which projects out at the rear of the handle keeps the glue stick under pressure so there is no need for the user to keep pressing with his finger to obtain a steady feed. Instead, all he has to do is press the tip lightly against the work sur face to automatically start the melted glue or calking flowing. As soon as the tip is pulled away, the flow stops. The glue and calking set by coolingin about 20 secondsand a firm bond is achieved in about 30 seconds without need for clamping.

title: Swoboda Saga II: Yank Headache or Helpful Bat?
description: He was wearing Ron Han sen's baseball shoes and Mel Stottlemyre's glove, and he had slipped over the Cana dian border like a carpetbag ger. But there he was, sitting alongside Ralph Houk in pinstripes in the home dugout, in the Bronx: Ron Swoboda of the New York Yankees.

description: PHILADELPHIA, June 26 Favorites finished third in both divisions of the Whitemarsh Handicap for fillies and mares today at Liberty Bell race track where 11.520 patrons wagered $1,153,053.

title: Art
description: THE title of a current exhibition at the Brooking Museum; Russian Art of the Revolution, suggests pic tures of charging mobs of sturdy moujiks carrying wind  blown banners and raising clenched fists aloft against a background of flaming buildings. Not a bit of it. Here we have another exhibition drawn from the years just before and just after the political revolution, but its protagonists are mem bers of an avantgarde whose involvement was with the es thetic revolution in Paris. Their contention that the va rious isms they developed as offshoots of cubism and fu turism (with a bit of express ionism) could yield an art for the people, especially a people just released from serfdom, is surely the most ridiculous delusion in the his tory of artists' theorizing. And that these artists could bamboozle themselves into adopting such an absurdity as a creative premise justi fies whatever suspicions you may want to examine in ap proaching their work.

title: What Lenny Bruce
description: ON Dec. 21, 1964, in a cavernous courtroom at 100 Centre Street, a bloated, disheveled man in a dirty, blue raincoat and faded dungarees stood before the high judicial bench. Frowning down on him was an immaculately groomed, stiff  backed magistrate, flanked by two other judges, one white, one black. Lenny Bruce, sick comedian, freespeech crusader, de fendant in the longest, costliest, most fiercely contested obscenity trial in the history of New York City, awaited his sentence. Found guilty of giving obscene, indecent, immoral and impure performances at the Cafe Au Go Go in Greenwich Village, he was asked one final, formal ques tion: Is there any reason why sen tence should not now be imposed?
