description: To The Editor:

title: Brown Gets Chaparrals Post
description: DALLAS, June 26 (UPI) Dave Brown, an assistant coach at the University of Wisconsin, was named today assistant coach and director of player personnel of the Texas Chapar rals of the American Basketball Association.

title: Readers Report
description: I don't care what you say a kid who wipes out almost an entire family, from grand mother to baby, is a monster. You hairsplitters may call him possessed if you're into witch craft. Or a schizo if you're into Brill. I call him a monster. The wonder of it all is that more folks don't suspect  after brother, cousin and mommy die violentlythat maybe this is an inside job; you would think that a lad as far out as this one  who can transmogrify himself into a chicken, and is forever furtively lurking about the premises, would arouse im mediate suspicion. It remains for a finalughdisclosure to write finis to this rather corny horror story. Its corniness should not prevent The Other from being translated into a successful horror film. That's what horror films are made of.

title: Biking Through the Wilds of Long Island: Mobs of People, the L.I.R. and Soreness
description: IT was 7:30 A.M. (not an hour I am accustomed to). The scene is Penn sylvania Station and the protagonist is acutely aware of time: time not spent sleeping. A woman of rather sub stantial girth, who is also cheerful (yes, at that hour), eyes his gleaming new white bicycle and exclaims, Where are you all going? The protagonist mum bles something about a 27mile bike hike. Oh, wonderful? she effuses. (She couldn't get on a bike herself without crushing it.)

title: RENTS' RISE HERE OUTRAN NATION'S FOR LAST DECADE
description: The New York metropolitan area outpaced the rest of the country in spiraling rent in creases during the last decade despite the existence of rent Control and rent stabilization within the city, a new survey by the Bureau of Labor Statis tics has revealed.

title: Headliners
description: Eight years ago publisher Ralph Ginzburg was convicted in Philadelphia under an 1872 law against sending obscene material through the mail and was sentenced to five years in prison. The material involved, was the magazine Eros (which died shortly after the trial), Liaison Newsletter and a book, Housewife's Handbook on Selective Promiscuity. Among the charges was that advertising for the publica tions was lurid. Ginzburg has appealed the decision several times, but though popular attitudes toward obscenity and pornography have changed since 1963, the conviction has held up. His only court victory was a reduction of the sen tence to three years. Last week it looked as though Ginz burg's fight had reached an end: The Supreme Court denied him a hearing and his lawyers advised him to be ready go to prison by midJuly. Said the publisher, I'm furious. I'm angry. But petrified I'm not.

title: True Chip Shot Turns Crooked as Crow Flies
description: VICTORIA, British Colum bia, June 26 (AP) Thelma Cooper's sparkling chip shot hit the green on the sixth hole of the Royal Colwood Golf and Country Club yes terday, but a big, black crow reached the green before she did, swooped down, picked up her ball and flew off over the trees.

title: The answer, my friends, is still blowin' in the wind
description: The official appearance of Bob Dylan's Tarantula is not a literary event because Dylan is not a literary figure. Literature conies in books, and Dylan does not intend his most important work to be read. If he ever did, his withdrawal of Taran tula from publication five years ago indicates that he changed his mind. Of course, it's possible that he's changed his mind againwith Dylan, you never know. Most likely, how ever, his welllmown quest for pri vacy, his personal elusiveness, lies behind the unexpected availability of this book. The pursuit of the artist by his audience has been a per vasive theme of his career, and the bootleg versions of Tarantula hawked on the street and under the counter over the past few years by selfappointed Dylanologists and hip ripoff artists were simply a varia tion on that theme. For Dylan to permit the release of the book now (at a nonripoff price, it should be noted) is to acknowledge the loss of a battle in his neverending war for privacy. Quite simply, his hand has been forced by his fans. He is a bookwrited now, like it or not.

title: For Young Readers: three anthologies of poetry
description: Two anthologies of modern poems, with identical aims and similar biases. The oldest poet in both books is Whitman. His work seems to mark the true beginning of the mod ern sensibility in poetry, Mrs. McCullough baldly declares. The modern sensibility? Is it that simple? One vein of modern poetry would be a fairer way to put it. Mr. Peck eschews both older poetry in which The form of a poem stood . . . as a barrier between poet and reader and modern poems full of word traps and pattern mazes requiring deep analysis and specialized train ing. Both anthologists try to catch the attention of young people with poems in open forms and plain language that dogs and cats can read. Under this narrow principle of selection, good poems get into both books, particularly into Earth, Air, Fire & Water, but also some supine nonentities. Plainness isn't alway enough.

title: Headliners
description: Gary Player of South Africa is one of the world's best golfers and long a familiar figure in American tournaments. Lately, however, he has been a frequent target of black hecklers because of his country's apartheid policy of racial separation. Last week Mr. Player took personal action clear up what he called a general misimpression. He in vited Lee Elder, the leading money winner among black American golfers this year, to participate in a tournament in Johannesburg in November. Mr. Elder accepted. A lot of people are under the impression that a black man cannot play in South Africa, and that is not true, said Mr. Player. One of the things this invitation can do is clear up that misimpression.

title: A ROCK FESTIVAL FAN IS SHOT AND 2 DROWN
description: McCREA, La., June 26 (AP) Two persons drowned today and another was shot during confrontation between a group of youths and a narcotics agent at a rock festival that has drawn 50,000 to a tract of river side farmland, the police re ported.

title: For Men Only: Three TailorMade Tours
description: EACH year, Martin Libwith, pres ident of a New York advertising firm, receives a Christmas card from Hong Kong. It is not from a friend, an associate or even a long lost relative. It is simply a friendly Yuletide greeting from his friendly Hong Kong tailor. Libwith bought two custommade suits in the British crown colony in 1968 and a brown cashmere sports coat during a visit earlier this year. I don't even have to go back to Hong Kong to get more suits made, says Libwith. They keep my measure ments on file and all I have to do is order by mail.

title: Thirtyseven: young too late, old too soon
description: What a rich pleasure this novel is. To put untidy matters promptly aside, it lingers too lodgthough the reader will not likely objectand it sags in the middle, but more than a few of the best novels are guilty of bath. St. Urbain's Horseman has virtues one counts and cherishes: its humor, whether tart or tender, is splendid; all its characters, so un like those in most contemporary comic novels, are real and rendered with the deepest compassion; its prose moves with grace from ele gance to slang; and its grasp of truth is absolutely secure.

title: Voices of Brooklyn
description: Right after World War II, when I was going to college, I used to take the elevated train home. Every evening I would pass a window where I would see a young man seated in front of a typewriter. used to wonder about him; since he worked at it every night for years, he could only be writing a novel. And I would become impatient for the train to get me home. I would rush in and begin to work on my own book instead of my homework, feeling both competitive agitation and a curious comradeship with that writer. I wonder what became of him: did he finish the novel? did he publish it? did he become famous? Or what?

title: Lang, and Jane They're Still Stars
description: THERE'S a song called I'm Still Here that Yvonne De Carlo sings in Follies. It is a hymn to the durability of all the 50yearold glamour girls who built their ca reers on the silver screen not as actresses, but as stars. It's a hardlook love chant to the Lana Turners and Jane Russells who made it to the top and held on there despite, or because of, the ups and downs in their private lives, the tabloid headlines magnifying the screen images. The song, like the women themselves, expresses a sense of survivala bouncing back with resilience that stems from years of living and experiencing and forgetting and building again.

title: Miss Alice Manning Bride of Paul Wehn
description: MORRISTOWN, N. J., June 26  Miss Alice Elizabeth Manning, who received a doctorate in anthropology last month from Columbia University, was married here this afternoon to Paul B. Wehn, who has a doctorate from Columbia in German history. The Rev. Samuel Whitney Hale Jr., a cousin of the bride, performed the Episcopal ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

title: Princeton Coach Honored
description: PRINCETON, N. J., June 26 Edward J. Donovan, head base ball coach at Princeton Univer sity for 20 years, has been named N.C.A.A. District 2 coach of the year by the American Association of Collegiate Base ball Coaches. Princeton had a 2271 wonlosttied record this season.

title: The Nation
Sports of The Times
description: Matt Snell Admits he has a bad habit. I like to have money, he says. I like to spend money. I lilte to have nice things.

title: CITY PILOT SCHOOL FAR FROM SUCCESS
description: The new South Shore High School in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn  intended to be One of The city's pioneering ventures in com??hensive edu cationwill end its first aca demic year on Wednesday be sot by many problems and fac ing an uncertain future.

title: The World
description: HONG KONGThe Chinese Communist guards at the bridge leading from this British Crown Colony to mainland China are pretty nonchalant these clays about the passage of Americans into the once forbidden country. Nines young American graduate students and four of their wives trooped across the narrow rail way bridge last week, and in Peking Premier Chou Enlai said such visits would become re ciprocal in due time.

title: Pesticide Poisons Lake in Ohio
description: PORTSMOUTH, Ohio, June 22  Until three weeks ago, Shawnee Lake was just an other quiet fishing hole in the southern Ohio hill coun try. Then somebody with half a, gallon of pesticide turned it into five acres of death.

title: In search of youth in search of itself
description: James Michener's latest novel, nar rated by a 60yearold American fi nancier who roams Europe and M rica in search of good investments, follows six young adults as they travel in search of something else, presumably themselves. The time is very much the present and, along with the generic problems of youth, each young person has a special set of circumstances with which to con tend.

title: Shortage of Funds Stops Work On Hospital Annex in Brooklyn
description: A critical shortage of funds at the Brooklyn Women's Hos pital has halted construction of new facilities for the hospital's overcrowded clinics.

title: Photography
OBSERVER
description: Once upon a time in the land of good King Richard there lived a poor highly paid, man who had denied him self a color television set and a thirty foot sailboat in his struggle to raise three stout sons.

title: Wall St. Audits Its Auditors
description: One of the great mystedes in the disastrous recession in Wall Street last year was how so many brokerage firms could suddenly find them selves in deep distress with scarcely a whimper of ad vance warning.

title: Quentin Munier, Plans to Marry Miss Mendoza
CANON LAW GROUP CRITICIZES ROME
description: A committee of the Canon Law Society of America has sharply criticized the latest draft of a proposed constitu tion for the Roman Catholic Church on the grounds that is regressive and would erode further the diminish ing respect for law and ec clesiastical authority.

title: Fireworks at Coney Island
description: Firework displays at Coney Island will begin at 9 P.M. on Tuesday and will continue every Tuesday night through July and August. The fireworks will be set off from a barge in the ocean near Steeplechase Pier. The Rheingold Breweries is sponsoring the traditional event.

title: Dual Citizenship in Brooklyn
description: When Leonard Nadel, the now president of the Brook lyn Chamber of Commerce, talks about the borough, it is not with nostalgia of the Dodgers, stickball in the streets and an egg cream on the way home from the movies.

title: The Seuffert and Is in, Its 16th Year of Serenading in Queens
description: With a fanfare of East Side West Side, the Music Grove of Forest Park, in Olanclale, Queens, last Sun day bilgan its 16th consecu tive ?? of hying up to its name. The fanfare inaugu rated, It Series of programs by the Seuffert Band that will be held every Sunday afternbod at 3 P.M. through the Labor Day weekend.

title: SALEM GAPTURES $56,500 SARANAC
description: Salem of the Christiana Stable was first across the line at Belmont Park yesterday in the $56,500 Saranac, the fea ture event on the getaway day card.

title: A Sluggish Recovery
description: If the Steelworkers strike, if the Administration moves to cut taxes or if Lockheed Aircraft goes bankrupt, the next three months will make an interesting quarter. Oth erwise, the national economy seems likely to keep strug gling to get ahead the way it has so far this year.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Movies
description: TANTRUM?, Luchino Visconti squints his heavylidded eyes, wondering if he has heard the question properly. He has. Mr. Visconti, is it true that you threw a tantrum at the Cannes Fes tival because Death in Venice did not win first prize, that you threatened never to return to Cannes, and that the only way the jury managed to calm you down was by coming up with a brand new prize called the 25th Anni versary Award?

title: Nixon and Top Aides Hold Talks on Budget
description: THURMONT, Md., June 26 (AP)President Nixon gath ered some of his top eco nomic and domestic officials today at Camp David, his mountaintop retreat, for a twoday review of budget problems.

description: EDINBURGH, ScotlandOne must never make the mistake, as I did, of mischievously pleading with a kilt specialist, Come on, tell me a good kilt story. The reaction, while polite, will probably be frigid.

title: UP TO 5 YEARS ASKED IN TRIAL IN KISHINEV
description: MOSCOW, June 26The prosecutor today asked for prison camp terms of one to five years for the nine Soviet Jews on trial in Kishinev charged with antiSoviet ac tivity.

title: The Urgency
description: The urgency that is the very essence of summer now possesses the land, overwhelming man's affairs with its incredible energy. The drive of life, the unbelievable energy of chlorophyll, the green leaf, is overwhelming, and the root that reaches into the earth itself for sus tenance is fundamental. Walk the country road, look beyond the concrete of the thruway, see the vastness vegetation from the airliner, know the greenness grass in a city park, and you can begin to understand.

title: SHAPP IS UPHELD ON SPOILS SYSTEM
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 26 The traditional system of polit ical patronage may continue unspoiled, the Pennsylvania Supreme Court ruled in a 4to3 decision this week.

title: Law
description: Children charged with of fenses punishable by 10 years in custody. Children awaiting trial in the lockedin squalor of detention centers. Children, after trial, sent to institutions with bars and cells, as bad as, or worse than, institutions for adults. Children branded for life, by family, friends and potential employers, as J.D.'s, bad kids or, simply, criminals.

title: Chaparrals Sign Collegian
description: DALLAS, June 26 (AP) Billy Jones, a former Louisiana College basketball star, has been signed to a contract with the Texas Chaparrals of the American Basketball Associa ciation, the team's executive vice president, Robert Briner, said today.

title: ERVIN DENOUNCES MILITARY CHECKS
description: ATLANTA, June 26Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr., chairman of the Subcommittee on Constitu tional Rights, today character ized as the most selfserving argument possible the conten tion of the military that sur veillance of civilians does not violate constitutional rights.

title: Quality of Education Is Debated in Red China
description: HONG KONG, June 26The introduction of workers, peas ants and soldiers into China's schools and the lowering of academic qualifications for en rollment at universities have created problems that have been discussed in the press and provincial broadcasts monitored here.

title: What Travelers Should Know About the 1,189 Americans Now Detaied Abroad
description: FOR their December, 1969 Playmate of the Month, the editors of Playboy magazine selected a model with seemingly impeccable qualitiespretty, nubile, auburnhaired, 21yearold Gloria Root of Chicago the flush of Youth and innocence, she told interviewers she loved bicycling, spearfishing and skiing. Even before the issue of Playboy in which she was to be featured appeared on the newsstands, however, young Gloria was serving illustrate more than just a magazine foldout; her case illustrated a growing problem for Americans who travel abroad when she and a male companion were busted Evros, Greece, for possession of 38 pounds of hashish.

title: They Scream for Ice Cream on Long Island
description: GREAT NECK, L.I., June 26There has been, it would seem, an ice cream boom.

title: The Campaign To Free Angela Davis ...and Mitchell Magee
description: THE drive to the Marin County Hall of Justice is north out of San Francisco on Highway 101, over the Golden Gate Bridge and through a widening peninsula of roll ing green hills and sunspeckled can yons. To the east is a curving bay shore studded with yacht harbors, houseboat communities and tiny tourist towns with mellow sounding names like Tiburon and Belvedere. To the west, beyond a magnificent stand of giant redwoods, is the be ginning of 100 miles of the most beautiful Pacific coastline in the state.

title: Loss Insurance
description: The customer assistance program of the New York Stock Exchange has required commitments totaling $120 million either to insure against customer losses in memberfirm collapses or to idemnify against losses in brokeragehouse mergers.

title: Langmaid Captures Crown In World Albacore Sailing
description: TORONTO, June 26 (AP) Dr. Jack Langmaid of Oshawa, Ont., and his daughter, Nancy, won the first world Albacore sailing championship today by taking two races in a row.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor:

title: One Down and ...
description: Tens of thousands to go. The fall of the first billboard on a primary road in Maine last month under a Federal law marks the opening of what should be a major bill board removal program. The billboard is a uniquely American act of aggression against nature and the human spirit. Billboards are known elsewhere but no other country permits mile after mile of scenery to be marred or blotted out altogether by huge signs. In most parts of Western Europe, a billboard is a rarity; in the United States it is a commonplace.

Under the terms of the committee's ac tion, unless the House defeats the rule, the sugar act legisla tion will be subjected to three hours of debate but no amend ments will be permitted.

title: AfroAsian Group Plans Dance Fete In Brooklyn Oct. 19
description: A fiveweek AfroAsian Fes tival with dance companies from Cambodia, Senegal, Mo rocco, Iran and Sierra Leone, will be presented at the Brook lyn Academy of Music from Oct. 19 through Nov. 24.

Horne of Plain field, and Howard Whiting Bbyd Jr. of Wellesley Hills, Mass., were married here this afternoon by the Rev. Gordon W. Lowden in the First United Methodist Church. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Boyd of Wellesley Hills. His father is a vice president of the Norfolk and Dedham Mutual Fire Insur ance Company in Needham, Mass. Mr. Horne is the head master of the Wardlaw Coun try Day School here.

title: TREVINO SOON TO BE ON NICKLAUS'S SIDE

title: Television
description: IF I did away with the television, the robin would seem to become four walls, you know, but if you can turn on the television, here come conversation, and musicactiv ity. It's like looking through a window at something that's going on outside. You look at the whole world through that. It's very important to have that sitting in the corner, because what would it be but four useless walls? You can't do anything about it. The tele vision set's workingno matter whether you don't feel good, it's raining or what not, you get your entertainment. There's always something.

title: Glenn, in Pollution Report, Urges Controls for Ohio

Movie Mailbag
description: ESTIMATED CABALLEROS: I have today received by messenger dove a copy of Senor Vicente Canby's review of the Moving picture Ba nanas, in the which I have part of revolution leader. I am reading in the heretoforesaid article that Seor Canby en joyes roll of Carlos Montai ban as a Castrolike freedom fighter who, at his victory celebration, goes a little nuts and declares Swedish to be the official language. Caram ba! That is me, Jacobo Morales, who perform part of loco leader this Esposito.

title: Pensions Under Fire
description: Retirement benefits offered by private industry have come a long way since the day, of the gold watch and the warm handshake, but with increasing frequency the question is being asked whether they have come far enough.

title: Spouting Horn Wins
description: STANTON, Del., June 26, (AP)Walter D. Fletcher's 3 yearold, Spouting Horn, beat six older horses today in winning the Decathlon Purse at Delaware Park.

title: what's New At the Movies?
description: THE ANDERSON TAPES, di rected by Sidney Lumet, is a caper movie in which director Lumet's quality of professionalism appears in father lovely manifesta tions to raise a by no means perfect film to is level of intelligent effici ency that is not so very far beneath the reach of art, says Roger Greenspun. As anybody who has read the movie's source will recall, The Anderson Tapes is a fiction with a gimmick, Lawrence Sanders's novel purports to be a, compila tion of tapes, depositions, Xeroxed letters and the like, by means of which the caper is revealed and inti mate secrets are put on view. The movie preserves the gimmick and improves on it. Except for Sean Con nery's laconic, attractive, beautifully subdued John Anderson, the various roles are all character vignettes of more or less detail; to do them all credit would re quire almost a complete cast listing. Over the years, Sidney Lumet has devel oped a sort of corner on the subject matter of New York, and in The Anderson Tapes' he takes his profit on it with an assured and harrowing and even good humored understanding. A great deal gets into The Anderson Tapes, which in telling its minor story shows a quite wonderful accessibility to the multi plicity of life.

title: the traveler's world
description: THERE is a fine new ship in town, if only for a few hours every Saturday, a spanking new cruise ship wearing an old and honored name, the Sea Venture, and bringing cheer to all those who love ships and treasure memories of exciting ancl relax irdays on blue water. The Sea Venture ado her maiden arrival in New York early this month, then left on her maiden weeklong cruise to Bermuda and back, and her welcome there was wildly in the old tradition of maiden voyages.

title: PROFESSOR FIGHTS FOR FLORIDA JOB
description: PENSACOLA, Fla., June 24 A former New York City social worker is fighting to keep her teaching position at a small state university in Pensacola where she and three other lib eral professors have been dis missed in the last year.

title: L. I. Sailor to Trace Bligh's OpenBoat Trip
description: MASSAPEQUA PARK, L.I., June 26A 45yearold Long Island adventurer is planning a 3,618mile voyage to re trace the openboat trip of Capt. William Bligh and his loyal crewmen following the mutiny on the Bounty in April, 1789.

title: CORNELL RUMEN GAIN PANABI SPOT

title: Son for the Littmanns
description: A son was born on June 11 in Mount Sinai Hospital to Mr. and Mrs. Neil A. Litt mann of New York. Mrs. Littmann is the former Miss Elaine Zwilling of Forest Hills, Queens. Her husband is with Shearson Hammill & Co., stockbrokers. The child has been named Paul Howard.

title: Joseph Lose Looks at Trotsky
description: TROTSKY lives  and dies in producer Josef Shaftel's The Assassination of Leon Trotsky, which is sched uled to get under way in Spain and Italy, come Sep tember. As in real life, Trot sky's tragic story will come after the downfall of the Romanovsa drama which Sam Spiegel has already put before the cameras. Spiegel's Nicholas and Alexandra, in fact, is set to open here in December.

title: Laird Voices Interest In a New Cabinet Post
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI)Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird clearly indi cated today that he would be happy to take another Cab inet post if President Nixon was reelected next year, al though he said he intended to leave his Pentagon job at the end of Mr. Nixon's first term.

title: The Detroit News Criticizes Papers for Publishing Study

title: Criminals At Large
description: The antihero has been turn ing up with increasing regulari ty in mystery fiction. He is very much present in George, Fox's WITHOUT MUSIC (Holt, Rine hart & Winston, $5.95). The narrator of this book is a writ ereditor, not unintelligent, but emotionally weak and com pletely ineffectual. He goes to Majorca with his exwife to see his illegitimate daughter  the mother has a habit of killing her children, and seems to be moving straight in that direc tion.

description: ARZACHENA, Sardinia, June 21  This village has gone through its first bandit scare and is fearful for its tourist trade.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Financial Editor: Much is being written in the United States and the European press concerning the increase of oil prices in the Persian Gulf and the Mediterranean detailing how much more money the oil countries are going to re ceive due to the recent in crease of prices. But I have not seen anything indicating that only half of that in crease will be paid to the producing countries and that the second half will be earned by the oil companies. No mention is made as to how much more the oil com panies also are going to earn from the increases.

description: Dr. Luis NievesFalcon, former director of Social Science Research at tile Uni versity of Puerto Rico, has been named a visiting distin guished professor at Brook lyn College for the next academic year.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONHad it not been for the United States, the history of South Vietnam would not have included anything that looked like a war, declared Daniel Ellsberg at midweek. By week's end, the United States had begun trying to prove that had it not been for Mr. Ellsberg, the man reported to have leaked the Pentagon Papers, there would not have been anything like the wholesale disclosure of the Pentagon's private history of the in South Vietnam.

title: ManMade Island Opposed
description: William Penn, the Depart ments of Commerce and the Treasury, supercargo ships, ecologists, the State of Dela ware and even. Daniel Web ster have been entangled in unsuccessful efforts to de velop Delaware Bay.

title: Marilyn Holmes Is Wed
description: Miss Marilyn Ward Holmes, daughter of Mrs. Hilary Holmes of New York and East Hampton, L.Y., and the late Dr. Holmes, was married yesterday afternoon to Mar shall Elliot Tullock of Larch mont, N.Y., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Marshall Elliot Tulloch. The Rev. Robert Rodie performed the cere mony in Christ Episcopal Church, Riverdale, the Bronx. He was assisted by the Rev. David Cockcroft.

title: RECREATION PARK STIRS COMMUNITY
description: The possibility that the Friends Religious Society may sell Friends Field, a recreation park in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, to the Board of Edu cation or a private developer has caused anxlety among large segment of the commu nity that wants to maintain the area as a playground.

title: Alex Johnson Suspended By Angels Indefinitely
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., June 26 Alex Johnson, last year's Amer lean League batting champion, was suspended indefinitely by the California Angels today for failure to give his best ef forts.

title: Television
description: COMMERCIALS? Yech. Situation comedies? Yech. Television in general? Yech That seemed to be the general reaction, with the intensity of objections descending in that yeching order.

title: You've Rented a Summer Place?
description: THIRTYONE days bath July and August  a compact 62day grow ing season for those who flee the city to spend the summer outofdoors.

title: Reader's Report
description: Edward Kuhn, an editor and publisher, has contrived a cool hotweather mixture of intrigue, satire, adventure and gynecolo gy. The little kingdom of Baktu, teetering somewhere in the Himalayas, is beset by a pal ace intrigue coordinated with an impending invasion. Baktu's central problem is not political but obstetric: the apparent bar renness of Carol, its Cincinnati born princess. Just when the plotting is thickest, Mr. Kuhn inflicts on Baktu an American agricultural mission, in which are spinning multiple wheels within wheels. Who is spying for whom? On whose side are the intransigent bandits? What is the role of Professor Bob Steinmetz, Carol's old lover, and a member of the agricul tural task force? The author answers these questions in his own good time, with scholarly attention to the erotic rituals of his milieu.

title: Cowboy From Bronx Performs in Rodeo
description: For six months of the year, John Meli is a rodeo cowboy who goes from town to town wrestling steers. He enters 30 of the 500 rodeos held in the United States each year.

title: MITCHELL LEADING BY 4 SHOTS AT 197
description: CLEVELAND, June 26Bob by Mitchell, bolstered by an eagle 3 on the 10th hole, ral lied on the back nine and shot a fourunderpar 67 today to take a fourstroke lead at the end of three rounds of the $150,000 Cleveland open golf tournament with a total of 197.

title: JEWS ABROAD GET NEW ISRAELI ROLE
description: Arye Pincus, the Israeli chair man of the executive of the Jewish Agency, spoke more bluntly about the new relation ship. He recalled that more than two years ago, foreign Jewish leaders had convened to discuss the human needs of Israeli society; Then you did not bear the direct burden of responsibility, he told the 300 delegates from 27 countries. Today you do.

title: Irish Ball Takes $209,300 Sweeps Derby After Favorite is Left at the Post
description: CURRAGH, Ireland, June 26 (AP)Irish Ball, ridden by Al dred Gilbert of France, stormed to a threelength victory in the a threelength victory in the $209,300 Irish Sweepstakes Derby today after favored Linden Tree was left at the post.

title: Women's Group Elects Head
description: Helen Rodabaugh Kaufman, a supervisor of social workers with the Board of Education's Bureau of Child Guidance, has been elected president of the Overseas Service League. The league, formed in 1919, is an organization of women who have served overseas in war time for the American Red Cross and who are continuing with volunteer services. Its headquarters are at the New York chapter of the American Red Cross at 150 Amsterdam Avenue.

title: 2 IVY LEAGUERS SHARE BAT TITLE
description: Pete Watzka, Cornell's sen ior outfielder from Kingston, N. Y., and Bob Schiffner, Prince ton's senior first baseman from Scarsdale, N. Y., are the co winners of the 1971 Charles H. Blair Bat, emblematic of the batting championship of the Eastern intercollegiate Baseball League. The athletic directors lof the league's 10 schools voted for the tie and duplicate awards to each after a complex set of circumstances that forced a ballot on the disposition of the title.

title: Movie Mailbag
description: TO The Editor:

title: Mrs. Campbell Wed
description: WINNETKA, Ill., June 26 Mrs. Haille Calhoun Camp bell, widow of Chesser M. Campbell, publisher of The Chicago Tribune, was married in the chapel of the Winnetka Congregational Church today to William Halsted Taft, who was formerly with Hemphill Noyes & Co., the investment house in New York. The Rev. Dr. Lawrence Emert Schwarz performed the ceremony. The couple will spend the summer at Mr. Taft's home on the grounds of the Linville (N. C.) Golf Club.

title: Students and Government Aides Deplore SummerJob Scarcity Across U.S.
description: Summer jobs are the scarcest they have been in years, ac cording to all indicators, but Gary Mack of Ironwood, Mich., has a plush one. Gary, a law student who is the son of State Senator Joseph Mack, will work as a legislative aidehis father's, at a salary that works out to $10,800 a year.

title: Prize Won by Queens Pupil
description: William Apfeldorf, a sixth grade student at Public School 177, in Flushing, Queens, has won first prize in a nationwide French contest for elementary school students, sponsored by the American Association pf Teachers of French. Six thou sand children from all 50 states participated in the contest.

title: ARGENTINA MOVES TOWARD LOTTERY
description: BUENOS AIRES, June 26 (UPI)  Instant riches could come to lucky Argentine soc cer fans starting in October.

title: A South American Bird Seems Contented on L.I.
description: VALLEY STREAM, L. I., June 26  The first known North American birth of wild monk parakeets, a spectacu lar, nonmigratory native of the South American sub tropics that may be estab lishing residence in the met ropolitan area, has been re ported here.

title: Like the Communist Manifesto rewritten for Time
description: JeanJacques ServanSchreiber, once a rising star, now seems a fall ing meteor. After his defeat by Chaban  Delmas at Bordeaux last year, he has stepped down, at least temporarily, as secretarygeneral of his Radical Party. But in France as in other Western countries, the air is heavy with a diffuse dissatisfaction. The young are alienated; the work ers militant; the good people wor ried; their government embattled. The old prewar social and economic is sues, anesthetized by war, recon struction and antiCommunism, have suddenly returned. In student worlds from Berkeley to Berlin, the weeds of ideology, supposedly paved over by apolitical technology, have broken through in a riot of energy and dis putation. Under the circumstances, it seems premature to count out Servan Schreiber's new politics and undoubt ed talents for selfpresentation.

title: Coast Fight Canceled
description: STOCKTON, Calif., June 26 (UPI)The state bantamweight title fight between Jose Luis Valdovinos, the champion, and Ruday Villagonza was canceled today after Valdovinos claimed he injured his hand in train ing. Jack Cruz, the match maker, said he called off next Wednesday night's bout when he couldn't find a suitable op ponent for the challenger.

title: Noted Student for Bowdoin
description: BRUNSWICK, Me., June 26 (AP)Dr. Robin J. Wilson, the son of former Prime Minister Harold Wilson, plans to attend an advanced mathematics sem inar at Bowdoin College July 1 Aug. 12, the college reported this week.

title: Clash of Power Groups in U. S. Seen by a Soviet Commentator
description: MOSCOW, June 26A Soviet commentator sought to explain today how it could happen that parts of the secret Vietnam papers, evidently embarrassing to the United States Govern ment, were published in The New York Times and, other newspapers.

title: Deborah M. Dey Becomes Bride Of T.F. Long Jr.
description: MADISON, N.J., June 26  Miss Deborah Morris Dey was married this afternoon to Thomas Fields Long Jr. in the Webb Memorial Chapel of the Madison Presbyterian Church, where her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Dey of Morristown, were married in 1942. The same minister, the Rev. Dr. John W. Parks, officiated.

title: Boys Harbor Helps Slum Children Chart a Safe Course in Life
description: EAST HAMPTON, L.I., June 26When Charles and David Huschle presented Boys Harbor with a 35foot Herreshoff sailboat the other day, they focused attention on an institution that has provided a safe port for thousands of slum children for 34 years.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation
description: No one knows better than the nation's No. 1 football fan that when a game plan doesn't work, the coach must be ready to scrap it. Last week President Nixon had reason to worry that his new game plan for the economy, adopted at the start of the year, isn't working.

title: Grand Circuit Will Honor Haughton
description: When Bill Haughton was a child he never bothered about his weight. If he had, it might have cost him millions of dollars.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: G.I.'s and Veterans, Seized in Picketing, Sae Texas Officials
description: AUSTIN, Tex., June 26 Eight members of the Spring Offensive Committee, a coali tion of soldiers and former G.I.'s., filed suit in Federal court this week for $50,000 in damages and an injunction against alleged pence harass ment growing out of picketing by the group of Tyrrell's Jewel ers, Inc., a national chain oper ating in military towns.

title: Miss Truesdale Wed
description: SUMMIT, N. J., June 26 Miss Cynthia Truesdale, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philemon Edwards Truesdale Jr. of New York and Acoaxet, Mass., was married here this noon to Dr. William F. Krause, son of Mr. and Mrs. Floyd O. Krause of Eau Claire, Wis. The Rev. William H. Strain, an Episcopal priest, per formed the ceremony at the home of Mrs. Lemuel Skid more, grandmother of the bride. The bride's father is president of the Truesdale Chemical Sales Company in New York. Dr. Krause's father is a professor of chemistry at Wisconsin State University in Eau Claire.

title: Princeton Six Will Open At Boston College Dec. 3
description: PRINCETON, N. J.  Prince ton University's 197172 hockey team will play a 21game sched ule, including 10 home contests and two games in the Cleveland tournament during the Christ mas holidays.

title: Proxmire Scores Pentagon On Payments to Lockheed
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 (UPI) Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, charged today that the Pentagon had paid the Lockheed Aircraft Cor poration $46.8million in dis puted and possibly unjustified claims, on its shipbuilding con tracts.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Catherine MacArthur Keyes Wed
description: NARBERTH, Pa., June 26 Miss Catherine MacArthur Keyes, granddaughter of the late, Frances Parkinson Keyes, the anther, whose husband, the late Henry Wil der Keyes, was Governor of New Hampshire and a United States Stator, was married here this afternoon to Michael Jon Feinstein.

title: Miss Elizabeth Flamrner Is Bride
description: PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., June 26Miss Elizabeth Flammer, daughter Of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Fiammer Jr. of Bronxville and Westhamp ton Beach, LI., was married here this afternoon to Robert Stewart Coates, son of Mrs. Robert Coates of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Coates.

title: For Young Readers: three anthologies of poetry
description: The Trees Stand Shining is an impressionistic collage of North Amer ican Indian songs, chants and lulla bies that mirror climates of the heart as well as of the natural world. The Nootka of the rainy Northwest Coast inquires:

title: Airlines to Begin MonthLong Meeting On Crucial TransAtlantic Fare Issues
description: Should the new youthfare bargains for transAtlantic flights be made permanent and be offered to those over 65 years old as well?

title: Congregation at Lawrence Plans $350,000 Expansion
description: LAWRENCE, L.I., June 26 Construction will begin this summer on a $350,000 expan sion program for Congregation Beth Sholom, on Broadway be tween Frost Lane and Washing ton Avenue.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: KOOSMAN OF METS BEATS EXPOS, 21
description: MONTREAL, June 26Jerry Koosman, who had lost his last four decisions, pitched a 3hit ter tonight as the New York Mets beat the Montreal Expos, 21, before 21,289 fans in Jarry Park.

title: Mahon to Coach Quintet
description: Horrace (Hoddy) Mahon, of Madison Township N.J., has been named freshman basket ball coach at Seton Hall Uni versity. Mahon has been a suc cessful high school head coach for seven years, coached the Fordham University freshman to a 154 record two years ago, and spent five years as an as sistant in high school.

title: The Laughs Are There, and They're Shakespeare's
description: EVERYONE who has ever liked performance of Merry Wives of Windsor, or even halfliked one, has probably spent the next day or two apologizing to himself and his friends for his kindly excess. Of course it's a poor thing, this play. Of course it's a hack job, whipped out for a court entertainment because Queen Elizabeth wanted to see Falstaff again, at a dis advantage, in love. Of course and of course. And yet the fact of the matter is that if we didn't know a single thing about Shakespeare, or about all the much better things he managed to do, we'd still learn to hear him, and very likely love him, in this hurried bit of slapstick.

title: The contents of a desk drawer in Tunisia
description: As distinct from those dense and intricate novels on which you'd have to make notes to get the hang of them at one reading, The Scorpion is a dense and intricate novel that organizes itself as it goes along. Flip ping, you see a miscellany of type faces, and headings and stories and dialogues and even photographs. Reading, you find it effortlessly co hesive, so ingenious a feat you're likely to overvalue it.

title: AutoRacing Deaths to Be Tallied by Safety Group
description: Injury and fatality rates in motor racing around the world will be tallied for the first time in an official census to be con ducted annually by the Motor Racing Safety Society, Karl Eric Lydvigsen, president of the professional group, has an nounced.

title: About Baseball
description: The way Willie Stargell has hit for the Pirates this year one would think he had no problems. But therewas one problem that wasn't rec tified until last week.

title: Buck Is Natural Leader
description: Clifford H. Buck, the presi dent of the United States Olym pic Committee and Chef de Mis sion of the United States team at the PanAmerican Games in Cali, Colombia, is also vice president of the International Amateur Basketball Federation and a past president of the Am ateur Athletic Union of the United States.

title: Law
description: WASHINGTONThe Supreme Court is scheduled to wind up its 1970 term tomorrow and adjourn for the summer. Apart from the case of the Pentagon Papers, the only other significant legal issue to be resolved on the last day of the session is the constitu tionality of various forms of pub lic financial aid to religiously affiliated schools, and the most celegrated case remaining for de cision  the inductionrefusal conviction of the former World's Heavyweight Boxing Champion, still known on the Supreme Court's docket (though nowhere else) as Cassius Clay.

title: JOHN J. FIALA DEAD; BRIDGE DESIGNER, 53
description: MALVERNE, L. I., June 26 John J. Fiala, a bridge designer and a specialist in movable bridges, died yesterday in Franklin General Hospital, Val ley Stream, after a short illness. He was 53 years old and lived at Horton Street.

title: Theater in Washington, D.C.
description: AS scenechange music for The Sign in Sidney Brustein's Window at the Arena Stage here in Washington, they play folk songs from the late fifties and early sixties, the kind of songs that Sidney Brustein and his friends used to listen to. One of them goes, if I heard it right, You'll know who I am by the songs that I sing.

title: Photography
description: A NEW daylight proces sor for color prints has been Introduced by Photo Materials Company, 500 N. Spaulding Avenue, Chicago, Ill. 60624. Called the Premier Daylight Color Processor, it actually consists of a daylight color processing drum, a plastic reservoir or tank which holds a large amount of water and which eliminates the need for a sink to be used as water bath, a dial type ther mometer, a set of five gradu ated measuring cups and an instruction booklet.

title: Marie Louise Mackay Wiegand Married to Daniel M. Williams
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 26 Miss Marie Louise Mackay Wiegand, greatgreatgrand daughter of John Mackay, known as the Silver King, was married here today in Old St. Mary's Roman Catho lic Church to Daniel Michael Williams, son of a San Pedro tuna fisherman.

title: Readers Report
description: The Claremont is a residen tial hotel in South Kensington for the ablebodied elderly. Res idents who have the bad taste to falter are hustled off the premises to more discreet quar ters. We are not allowed to die here, explains Mrs. Laura Palfrey to her grandson, Ludo. Well, Ludo is not really Mrs. Palfrey's grandson. He's only her pretend grandson, because the real one never comes to visit and having guests is very important at the Claremont, for morale and prestige. Ludo is a young man who picked Mrs. Palfrey up when she fell in the street. Between the two there springs up a friendship they warms them both.

title: Indonesia:
description: TERNATE, North Moluc cas, June 19Until the air field was completed seven months ago, Termite was ac cessible only by boat It is a magnificently beautiful island formed from a huge volcano.

title: Horse Show News
description: Rod Jenkins, one of the country's premier show riders, is back at his Orange, Va., home this week contemplat ing the problems that can arise from handling unfa miliar horses.

title: West Wins Coaches' Game, 35 to 28
description: LUBBOCK, Tex., June 26 (AP)Chuck Hixson of South ern Methodist fired a 23yard touchdown pass to Nebraska's Joe Orduna with. 31 seconds remaining tonight to give the West a 3328 victory in the 11th annual Coaches' All America football game.

title: Bruins Sign Bucyk, Smith
description: BOSTON, June 26 (UPI) Johnny Bucyk, a forward, and Rick Smith, a defenseman, have signed their contracts for the 197172 National Hockey League season, the Boston Bruins announced today. The signings bring to five the num ber of Bruins who are under contract for next season.

title: The Nation
description: There is a widespread belief among City Hall reporters that no one reads all the budget stories they grind, out each year. The men of Room 9, the City Hall press room, also have trou ble thinking of reasons anyone should read their stuff about budget gaps, cuts and crises.

title: LIQUORI RUNS 3.56.5 MILE
description: EUGENE, Ore., June 26 John Smith woke up this morn ing and told Wayne Collett, his roommate, college teammate and track rival, that it was time for a world record in the 440yard dash.

title: Disengagin From Vietnam
description: The war in Vietnam has lasted longer than any armed conflict out side our borders in which we have been engaged in the nearly two cen turies of our independent existence, and disengagement end complete with drawal are still question mark. The conflict has engendered divided opinions, manifested in bitter and po tentially dangerous confrontations arming our people, and we still are un certain what it was We Sought and why, where we should now proceed, and what courses of action would beat servo our national interests.

title: HANS STEINKE, 78, WRESTLER, IS DEAD
description: CHICAGO, June 26 CAP) Hans Steinke, a famed profes sional wrestler through the twenties and, thirties, died to day of Iung cancer. He was 78 years old.

title: L.I. TeenAgers Sought To Aid Film on Drugs
description: MINEOLA, L. I., June 26 The Nassau County Drug Abuse and Addiction Com mission is auditioning high school students who wish to participate in a drug educa tion film to be distributed this fall to schools and com munity organizations.

title: Soviet Yields Point And Clears the Way For a Space Treaty
description: UNITED NATIONS, New York, June 26A major break through reportedly is being made in the sevenyear Unit ed Nations effort to complete a space treaty covering pay ment of compensation for dam ages caused by objects launched into space.

title: WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, June 26A trou bled friend wants to know why the newspapers don't leave the questions of secret documents and national se curity to the President. Let us suppose that we did.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To The Editor:

title: REFEREE UPHOLDS ROWING PROTEST
description: PITTSBURGH, June 26  A series of unusual incidents high lighted the fourth annual Triad River renaissance weekend re gatta on the Allegheny River today. The rowing program was run off between helicopter pickups by the United States Coast Guard and water ski jumps plus a flying parachute water skier.

title: Margaret A. Heatley Married To Frank Kenneth Kappler 2d
description: SAN MATEO, Calif., Jane 26 Miss Margaret Anna Heatley, daughter of Mrs. Leonard K Firestone and the late Stuart A. Hadley, was married here this afternoon to Frank Kenneth Kappler 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kappler of IrvingtononHudson, N. Y.

title: Texas Seeking Title to Oil on Half of Border River
description: PORT ARTHUR, Tex., June 26Oil wells are pumping away in the eastern half of the Sabine River here, pouring roy alty money into the Louisiana state treasury, while the state of Texas broods, unable to get clear title to the western half of the river that it claims.

title: Reports Doubted
description: WASHINGTON, June 26  A Pentagon spokesman said today that it was very unlikely that Americans were involved in intelligence operations of the type described in reports from Saigon.

title: Miss Cherniack, E. A. Bering 3d, Students, Wed
description: LOS ANGELES, June 26 Miss Stacie Eden Cherniack, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Cherniack, was mar ried here this afternoon to Edgar Andrew Bering 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Bering Jr. of Washington and a grand son of Winthrop W. Aldrich, former chairman of the Chase National Bank and former Ambassador to the Court of St. James's. Superior Court Judge Martin Katz per formed the ceremony at the Bel Air Hotel in Brentwood.

title: Indonesia:
description: AMBON, June 20It is 15 miles from the airport to town along a road that looks in places as if it is about ready to fall into the sea. In fact, local officials predict that it will happen any day.

title: ExOutfielder Gets NoHitter
description: MEMPHIS, June 26 (AP) Tommy Moore of the Memphis Blues pitched a nohitter last night in the second game of a Dixie Association doubleheader against Arkansas. The Blues won the game, 40. Moore is in his first year as pitcher, hav ing spent previous years in the New York Mets farm system as an outfielder.

title: Couple With 8 Children Charged in Death of Infant
description: A Bronx couple with eight children were charged yester day with homicide in the death of their 13month old daughter.

title: Apollo 14's Rocks Reported Younger Than Was Forecast
description: SEATTLE, June 24 (Reuters) The moon rocks brought back from Fra Mauro are much younger than expected and may prompt a drastic rethinking of the early history of the solar system, a space scientist re ported today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Reader's Report
description: Let us turn back the clock to the 1950's, when television was still live and the doings of comedians were considered of such importance that schism between Sid Caesar and Imogene Coca was reported on the front page of The New York Times. It is in such a climate that this novel takes place; you have to remember the texture of the times to ac cept the hyperthyroid goings on the author describes. (The author was a producerwriter for George Gabel and other en tertainers, so he may be pre sumed to have eyewitness credibility.)

title: Mrs. Blank Has Son
description: A son was born on May 31 to Mr. and Mrs. Howard D. Blank of Scarsdale, N. Y., in the LyingIn Hospital. The child has been named William Richard.

title: BLACK COLLEGES HELD ENDANGERED
description: The Negro public colleges are in imminent danger of los ing their identity through inte gration, merger, reduced status or outright abolition, a report by the Race Relations Informa tion Center has stated.

title: SPAIN'S NEW GAME AN ECLECTIC ONE
description: BILBAO Spain, June 26 (UPI)The new game is called burutanka and it's a combina tion of soccer, tennis and vol leyball.

title: DODGERS TRIUMPH OVER PADRES, 42
description: LOS ANGELES, June 26 (AP) Manny Mota tripled home two runs and Willie Davis tripled, doubled and singled to night to spark the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 42 victory over the San Diego Padres.

title: About Pro Football
description: Mrs. Andrea Tose, es tranged wife of Leonard Tose, who is the owner of record of the Philadelphia Eagles, posed some ethical problems for pro football last week when she filed suit in Phila delphia asking the court to appoint a guardian or a re ceiver for her husband's es tate before he bankrupts it.

title: U.S. BUSINESS ROUNDUP
description: Last March the Tax Foundation, Inc., a nonprofit, nonpartisan business research and educational organization in New York, said in its Tax Review:6.5 per cent with certain ex emptions eliminated. Among those exemptions he favors discarding are automobile tradeins, restaurant meals under $1, children's clothing, fire and casualty insurance premiums, domestic fuel oil, and nonprofessional services, including haircuts.

title: Vote on Sugar Act Set
description: WASHINGTON, June 9 (UPI) The House Rules Committee set the stage today for a yes or no vote tomorrow on threeyear extension of the Sugar Quota Law. Under the terms of the committee's ac tion, unless the House defeats the rule, the sugar act legisla tion will be subjected to three hours of debate but no amend ments will be permitted.

title: JOB TRAINING HERE IS CALLED SUCCESS
description: Successes for the New Ca reers program  developing job advancement systems for poor people were reported yesterday at a Congressional hearing here, but with calls for further efforts at improvement.

title: New Postal Unit Starts Thurs day
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 Thursday marks the end of 196 years of postal business as usu alWhich the American pub lie has come to believe is usual ly bad. The Post Office Depart ment will officially become the United States Postal Service, an independent Government agency with a businesslike structure.

title: Tuition at Private Schools To Increase 12% in City
description: Tuition and other fees at the city's nonreligious private schools, which have gone up 25 per cent in the last two years, will rise by an average of 12 per cent next fall, according to a survey of about half the 60 odd schools.

title: Nathan Fried, an Engineer And Consultant, Dies at 54
description: Nathan Fried, a consulting plastics engineer, died Friday of pneumonia in the Veterans Administration Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 54 years old and lived at 1316 East 85th Street, Brooklyn.

title: . . . And I Got a Headache From Anacin
description: WITH the summer vacation period underway, I'd like to pass along a warning to fel lawtravelers: Don't try to bring drugs across borders. My own recent amusing (in retrospect) experi ence will suggest a few goad reasons why.

title: Striking Lifeguards Making Rescues
description: Long Island lifeguards who are on strike rescued several swimmers yesterday at beaches that remained officially un guarded although their three week dispute with the Long Island State Park Commission grew inceasingly bitter.

title: About Motor Sports
description: LONG POND, Pa., June 26They say here that if you want to find Bill Marvel you don't go looking for himyou simply stand in one place and, within 15 minutes, he will be sure to pass by And if Marvel is too harried to stop, all you need to do is wait a few more minutes until Joe Mattioli rushes through on one of his patrols.

title: About the black accused and the white accusers
description: The title of this collection of es says and short pieces reminds one of a word game. As one repeats Raise Race Rays Raze aloud the sounds alliterate and the words fuse. The game is derived from an oral tradition in which the storyteller uses sound, rhythm and tonal variation to heighten the expectations of his audience. Having returned to the magic of alliteration, Imamu Baraka (LeRoi Jones) proceeds to address himself to what the Nigerian novelist Chinua Achebe describes as the mind's ear. Newark Courthouse 66 Wreck (Nigger Rec Room), the first essay in the collection, gives us vivid and chilling insights into a city's lower depthsblack accused and white accusers locked in the throes of a primordial drama:

title: Seton Lindsay Bride of Gerald O'Reilly
description: Miss Mary Seton Lindsay, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Owen Seton Lindsay of East Hebron, N. H., was married here yesterday afternoon to Gerald Ambrose O'Reilly, son of Mrs. Gabriel Ambrose O'Reilly of New York and the late Mr. O'Reilly, who was a vice president of Irving Trust Company.

title: AUTHORITY SHIFTS IN POLICE MATTERS
description: A new philosophy of corrup tion control, strongly advocated and supported by Police Com missioner Patrick V. Murphy, is shifting responsibility for uncovering and prosecuting police misconduct away from headquarters and into local commands.

title: Giants Down Astros
description: HOUSTON, June 26 (AP) Bobby Bonds triggered a three run burst in the fourth inning with his 17th homer tonight as the San Francisco Giants de feated the Houston Astros, 31, before 32,025 fans, the largest Astrodome crowd since 1969.

title: Ethel Frankacau, 85, a Director Of Haute Couture Salon, Dies
description: Miss Ethel Frankau, director of Bergdorf Goodman's Custom Salon and a leader in couture for many years, died yesterday at her home, 14 Sutton Place South, of leukemia. She was 85 years old and lived also in East hampton.

title: U.S. SOCCER TEAM REPORTS JULY 10
description: The United States Olympic soccer team, which will also represent this country in the PanAmerican games, reports to Miami, Fla, July 10 for final training prior to the Olympic tourney qualifying matches.

title: Miss Metheny Lone Holdover
description: Linda Metheny, the '67 Pan American Games champion in the women's allaround, floor exercises, balance beam and vault is the only holdover on the '71 PanAm United States women's gymnastics team.

title: McMichael Sails Kangaroo to 5th Etchells22 Victory of Season
description: RYE, N.Y., June 26Howard McMichael recorded his fifth Etchells22 class victory of the season with Kangaroo on Long Island Sound today when fleet of 97 sailed in a flukey northwest breeze off American Yacht Club in the 12th Yacht Racing Association champion ship regatta on the summer schedule.

title: Queens Historical Society Installs Ludder as President
description: Henry F. Ludder Jr. was in stalled as president of the Queens Historical Society last week at a meeting in the First Unitarian Church of Flushing.

title: Emily Waterman Bide Of Endicott Peabody Jr.,
description: EAST GREENWICH, R. L, June 26Miss Emily. Greene Waterman was married here this afternoon to Endicott Peabody Jr., whose father is a former Governor of Massa chusetts. The bridegroom's father and mother, Mrs. Pea body, now reside in Washing ton.

title: Football Series Listed
description: MEMPHIS, June 26 (AP) Houston and Memphis State agreed today to a threegame football series in 1973, 74, 75. The games will be in Memphis in 1973 and 1975 and in Hous ton in 1974. No dates have been set.

title: Mrs. Victoria Galbraith Is Married
description: PLANDOME, L. I., June 26 Mrs. Victoria Galbraith and George West Saltonstall were married here this afternoon in the North Shore Unitarian Church.

title: For Men Only: Three TailorMade Tour
description: LONDONThere are three great mo ments in a man's life: the crown ing of ambition, the consumma tion of love and the final fitting of a Savile Row suit. And while these three great moments may occur more than once, they must certainly, at to day's prices, occur in that order.

title: Excerpts Taken From Summary.
description: WASHINGTON, June 26 Following are excerpts from the conclusions by the auth ors of a survey on The Hopes and Fears of the Ameri can People:

title: Coins
description: ORDERS for the new dol lar to be issued in hon or of President Dwight D. Eisenhower will be accepted starting on Thurs day, it was, announced by Mary T. Brooks, Director of the Bureau of the Mint. The first phase of the Mint's pro gram for ordering the long awaited commemoratives was just about completed with the mailing of 53 million forms to 87,000 major out lets and 1.4 million persons whose names were on the Mint's mailing list from pre vious years.

title: Padres Sign Draft Choice
description: SAN DIEGO, June 26 (AP) The San Diego Padres signed today a pitcherinfielder, Craig Settles of Point Loma (Calif.) High, their thirdround selec tion in the June free agent draft.

title: Driving a Bus for his Peace of Mind
description: Joseph J. Villanelle used to be a nervous wreck whenever he arrived for work at his Manhattan office. You see, he is a former drag racer, and he couldn't stand to watch all the mis takes made by the bus drivers who drove him from his home in New Jersey, to the Port Authority bus terminal.

title: Miss Laurie McLaurin Watson Married to Robert A. Moss Jr.
description: GROTON, Mass., June 26 Miss, Laurie McLaurin Watson acid Robert Adams Moss Jr. were married here this afternoon in St. John's Chapel of Groton School. The Rev. John Page Williams performed, the ceremony, as he had done for the parents of the bride, Mr. and Mrs. Waiter Watson 2d of Boston. He was assisted by the Rev. John Crocker, former head master of Groton and the bridegroom's godfather, and the Rev. A. L. Kershaw, rec tor of Emmanuel Church of Boston.

title: CLAUDE HARMON JR. WINS ENDICOTT GOLF
description: ENDICOTT, N.Y., June 26 (AP)Claude Harmon Jr. of Palm Springs, Calif., son of the 1948 Masters champion, took the $10,000 B.C. tournament, satellite to the Cleveland open, after a fivehole playoff today.

title: Red Bayou 151 Victor
description: CHICAGO, June 26 (AP) Red Bayou, a 151 shot owned by Dan Lasater of Dayton, Ohio, rallied in the stretch to beat Hoist Sail by a head today in the $28,350 Laurence Ar mour Handicap at Arlington Park. Red Bayou, a 151 shot owned by Dan Lasater of Dayton, Ohio, rallied in the stretch to beat Hoist Sail by a head today in the $28,350 Laurence Ar mour Handicap at Arlington Park.

title: Music
description: JACKSONVILLE is having its racial troubles, like many another city, but its cultural problems are in part solved. The Jacksonville Symphony Orchestra is flourishing once again, to the extent that it has signed a threeyear contract with a new con ductor, when, only a year ago, it was virtually out of business.

title: G. O. P.'s Klein Stressing Need for Economy
description: HAUPPAUGE, L. I., June 26John V. N. Klein, the Republican candidate for County Executive, is worried about the future of Suffolk County's economy and the ability of the county govern ment to balance its budget.

title: ExPriest in Theology Post
description: OMAHA, June 26 (Reuters) A former priest who is now married has been named acting chairman of the theology de partment of Creighton Univer sity, operated by the Jesuits. He is Michael Lawler, 38 years old, the first layman to head the de partment in the 100year his tory of the university, officials said yesterday.

title: Caribia Is Still Awash in Fiscal Troubles
description: Three months ago Andrew Kostaninidis was confident that his cruise ship Caribia, land locked here for more than two years by legal difficulties, would by now be heading for Bermuda with a full load of passengers.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTONFrom early in 1962 until midJanuary of 1963 there developed in Brit ain what can only be called a great debatea debate in the best traditions of the oldest parliamentary democ racy. It ended not in a deci sion but in a paradox, an al most comic paradox.

title: Linotype Inventor Honored
description: BALTIMORE, Tune 26 (UPI) A bronze plaque honoring Ottmar Mergenthaler, inventor of the linotype machine, has been unveiled near the site here of his tiny print shop. The linotype, invented in 1882, rev olutionized the printing indus try because it set type auto matically. The Maryland chap ter of Sigma Delta Chi, ration al journalistic society, unveiled the plaque Tuesday.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Neither the city admin istration nor those news papers and writers who have supported the city's new rent law have comprehended the adverse effect to be wrought upon tenants and landlords alike by the use of equalized assessed valuation as the basis for rent increases.

title: H. T. LUCA SCORES IN YONKERS PACE
description: YONKERS, June 26  Even before Del Insko drove H. T. Luca to a twolength victory over Veri Special in a $10,000, invitation onemile pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight, the reinsman from South Beloit, III., contended that the colt was the second best 3yearold pacer in the world. Insko al lowed that the, top spot be longed to Albatross.

title: Why They Call Lon Nol The Mayor Of Pnompenh
description: PNOMPENH.

title: Bridal Is Held for Virginia MacArthur
description: LAKE FOREST, Ill., June 26Miss Virginia Mary Mac Arthur, daughter of Mrs. Cynthia Wirtz MacArthur of Chicago and Alexander Mac Arthur of Algonquin, was married here today to Ed ward Baker Jenner Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Jenner of Lake Forest. The Rev. Don Carver performed the cere mony in St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

title: MEANINGLESS
description: To The Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Testimony on Queens Plan Is Weighed
description: Hearings conducted by the City Planning Commission in 14 Queens communities with the avowed intention of spark ing community participation in government certainly produced sparks.

title: Dance
description: THE other day we had Lincoln Kirstein, the Grand Panjandrum and Lord High Execution er of the New York City Ballet, remarking in these weekday pages how glad he was that New York City Bal let had become the Ameri can ballet Establishment. It is a gladness that I also feel. I really love this company not blindly, I trust, but well. And at the moment it is worrying me.

title: Braves' Stone Wins, 10
description: ATLANTA, June 26 (UPI) Ralph Garr singled home Mike Lum in the fifth inning as George Stone, despite giving up nine hits, pitched the Atlanta Braves to a 10 victory over the Cincinnati Reds tonight. It was the lefthander's first victory in 10 starts.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTONIn publishing the highly classified Pentagon Papers, wasn't The New York Times setting Itself up to judge the national inter est? What gave The Times either the right or the standing to make such a judgment? And anyway, Isn't the na tional interest properly the Govern ment's to define?

title: Readers Report
description: In this Australian entertain ment, a Yank goes trekking in search of a fabulous bush ranger and the bounty on his head. After escaping assassina tion by bullet, boomerang, snakebite and dingo, young Ian Christian finally has the big shootout he has been spoiling for. Mr. Scoales has cooked up all of the old wild Western chestnuts into an exotic Down Under dish, garnished with crisp humor.

title: Science
description: To anyone who has sam pled some of the tastier wild varieties of mushrooms it is obvious that they have delectable and unique flavors. For weight watchers they have the added benefit of being low in calories. There is only one problemsome of these wild varieties are deadly.

title: MARTIN W. TEICHMAN
description: Martin W. Teichman, a law yer of 60 East 42d Street, who specialized in real estate and corporate law, died Wednesday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 80 Central Park West.

title: Letters
description: To The Editor:

title: Music
description: ATLANTA.

title: Dr. Meriwether: He Can Always Go Back to the Lab
description: EUGENE, Ore., June 26 After his spectacular victory in the 100yard dash yester day, Dr. Delano Meriwether was asked to explain his sud den improvement from no vice to national champion.

title: BRONX FRESHMEN GET EARLY START
description: The 2,600 incoming freshmen of this fall's class at Lehman College in the Bronx began last week an extended registration process designed to reduce the confusion that usually prevails during registration times.

title: South Korea Devalues Its Currency by 13%
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 26The South Korean Gov ernment decided today to de value the won by about 13 per cent effective on Mon day. The International Mone tary Fund had urged Seoul to devalue its currency to curb rising imports and to stimulate exports.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONThe day after the Senate approved Senator Mike Mansfield's Vietnam troop withdrawal amendment last Tuesday, the majority leader had poached eggs with the President at the White House. Perhaps Vietnam histories still to be writ ten by the Pentagon will provide a memorandum of conversation of the breakfast table encounter between Mr. Nixon and the Dem ocratic leader who had provoked a Congressional confrontation with the President's Vietnam policies.

title: Pediatric Diabetic Clinic Established on Long Island
description: MANHASSET, L.I., June 26 A pediatric diabetic clinic described as the first of its kind in Nassau and Suffolk Counties has been established at North Shore Hospital.

title: T. D. Schumacher Weds Gail Pinkham
description: OLD GREENWICH, Conn., June 26Miss Gail Louise Pinkham and Thomas Dale Schumacher, graduates of the University of Redlands in California, were married this afternoon in the First Con gregational Church by the Rev. Francis E. Potter.

title: A Rap on Race
description: No fuss. No bother. Eliminate dirty smudges on the fingertips, broken nails, and messy erasure marks. You don't need to revise, rethink, or re write. You don't even need to write. Just think of it, folks: No more blood shot eyes, or coffee bowels, or angry friends you've stood up to work just a little longer, harder, more. Sealed inside your own angry mortal human vacuum, to be just as fatuous as Margaret Mead and James Baldwin about the crisis of our timeparticu larly raceall you have to do is talk and not listen, always avoid express ing your feelings openly, refer con stantly to other times and other cul tures with historical and/or pseudo historical truths, interrupt whenever possible, call yourself a prophet or a poet, insist that you, are being emo tionally sincere and/or objectively ra tional, and record it all on tape, to be transcribed later as a book.

title: Sealyham Judged Best at Rhinebeck
description: RHINEBECK, N. Y., June 26 To cap a day of perfect weather, Mrs. Henry Sutliff Jr.'s consistent, all  white coarsecoated Sealyham terrier, Ch. Jenmist Dougal, was named best in show today at the 29th annual MidHudson Kennel Club's allbreed event.

title: Andersen of Utah State Named to Coach Stars
description: SALT LAKE CITY, June 26 (UPI)LaDell Andersen, the Utah State University bas ketball coach, was named to day as head coach of the Utah Stars of the American Basketball Association.

title: Miss Carroll Wed To Robert Zobitz
description: SWARTHMORE, Pa., June 26Miss Patricia Carroll, daughter or Mr. and Mrs. J. Roy Carroll Jr., was married, today to Robert Lewis Zobitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward James Zobitz of Niles, Ohio. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Berarum deH. Atwood in the Swarthmore Presbyterian Church.

title: Music Mailbag
description: To The Editor:

title: 38 African Athletes To Face U.S. Team In July Track Meet
description: The Pan AfricaUnited States international track meet, scheduled for July 16 and 17, at Duke University, Durham, N. C., is being billed on the Af rican Continent as a significant preliminary to the 1972 Olym pic Games at Munich.

title: Hunting Antiques in Brooklyn
description: Nestled among the fixit shops, gas stations and apart ment houses lining Coney Is land Avenue in Brooklyn is a cluster of stores filled with furniture, fixtures, dust and nostalgia.

title: Navy Uses Rock Music to Help Addicts
description: JULIAN, Calif., June 26A group of 21 Navy enlisted men and marines, most of them teenage drug users, lounged about an old ranch house on a wooded slope of the Cuyamaca mountains recently listening to rock music heavy with the la ments of youth's despair.

title: Ellen L. Hickey Is pride Of Randy M. Waterman
description: GROSSE POINTE. Mich., June 26Miss Ellen, Louise Hickey, granddaugher of James A. Farley, former Postmaster General of the United States, and now chairman of the board of the CocaCola Export Corpora tion, and Rand, Michael Waterman were married here this morning. Msgr. William J. McCormack, the bride groom's uncle, assisted by Msgr. Edward Hickey, the bride's greatuncle, officiated at the ceremony in St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Man Jogs 6.7 Miles On His 104th Birthday
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 26 (AP)On his 104th birthday, Larry Lewis took the day off but jogged his daily 6.7 miles around Golden Gate Park. He also disclosed his formula for longevity  organic food and exercise.

title: Boockvars Have Twins
description: Twin sons were born to Dr. and Mrs. William Boock var of Hewlett, L.I., on June 11 at the Long Island Jewish Medical Center in New Hyde Park.

title: ADDISON ROTHROCK, EXNASA OFFICIAL
description: ALEXANDER, Va., June 26 (AP)Dr. Addison M. Roth rock, retired associate director of plans and programs for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, died Thursday. His age was 68.

title: The Nation
description: WASHINGTONTo readers of spy novels, the words Top Se cret conjure up a number of visions: of windowless rooms far beneath the Pentagon where be spectacled men spend days and nights under heavy guard read ing coded messages; of armed couriers and impenetrable vaults where reams of sensitive docu ments are forever shielded from the eyes of all but a very few.

title: The World
description: JERUSALEMWhat crazy existence is this we've led/ that so undermined us?/ We've kept pace with progress and rushed straight ahead/ and left ourselves behind us.Karl Kraus, Jewish critic and drama tist, 18741936.

title: MUCH OF CAMBODIA STILL HELD BY FOE
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 26One year after the depar ture of the last American ground forces from Cambodia, the Vietnamese Communists are still in control of threequarters of the sparsely populated coun tryside, but most Cambodians and foreign diplomats here still believe that the enemy has his eye one South Vietnam, not on pnompenh.

title: SALE OF REFUSE AS A FUEL URGED
description: OCEANSIDE, L. I., June 26 A new concept in the dis posal of solid waste that would use pulverized refuse to generate electricity commer cially was offered this week by Hempstead Town Supervisor Alfonse M. D'Amato.

title: Court Enjoins PostDispatch; 2d Article on Study Withheld
description: ST. LOUIS, June 26 (AP) The St. Louis PostDispatch announced today that it had been restrained from further publication of articles based on the secret Pentagon study of the Vietnam war.

title: Horton Wins Irish Golf
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, June 26 (UPI)Tommy Horton won the $14,400 Gallaher Ulster open golf championship today with final rounds of 70 and 67 for 274. Neil Coles carded a 70 and 69 to trail Horton by one stroke.

title: Elaine Em Bitel Will Be Bride
description: NEW HAVEN, June 26 The Engagement of Miss Elaine Em Bitel to Timothy Murphy has been announced by Mr. and Mrs Vincent J. Bitel, parents of the prospec tive bride. Her hand is the son of Arthur F. Murphy, president of Seagram Distill ers Company, and Mrs. Mur phy of New York.

title: News of the Rialto
description: FOR an older generation, as well as for an impressive number of the younger, the name of Thomas Wolfe signifies not only one of the finer talents but also one of the more engrossing personalities to have emerged in American fiction between the two World Wars. There was hardly a cultivated soul in the 1930's and 40's who hadn't read his largescale autobio graphical novel, Look Homeward, Angel. Many more were exposed to it when Ketti Frings adapted it for the stage and in 1958 won both the Pulitzer and New York Drama Critics Circle awards for her efforts. This morning's bulletin, therefore, happily discloses that Wolfe's The Web and the Rock, dramatized by Dolores Sutton and seen not too long ago at the Washington The ater Club, will be brought to New York. Miss Sutton, who appeared in it, will repeat her role and she may be joined by Frank Langella. The sponsors will be Cheryl Crawford, who last showed us Colette with Zoe Caldwell, and Berenice Weiler, managing producer of the American Shakespeare Festival at Stratford, Conn.

title: The Last Word: Who Wrote Ali and Nino?
description: In April, Random House published an extraordinary novel with a mysterious his tory. Ali and Nino was orig inally published in Vienna in 1937 under the pseudonym Kur ban Said,. It was then forgotten until Jenia Graman, an artist who lived in Berlin during the 1930's, recently came across a Copy of the Viennese edition and translated it.

title: Organizer for Black Politicians Honored
description: The Brooklyn Museum's Sculpture Garden was the scene of a surprise birthday party yesterday evening for Wesley McDonald Holder, a longtime Brooklyn political organizer and educator.

title: Group in South Africa Advises U.S. Business About Apartheid
description: JOHANNESBURG, South Af rica, June 27A South African civil rights organization has formulated recommendations for United States business con cerns that consider investing here, advising them how to al leviate apartheid from within.

title: Voteat18 Amendment Nearing Final Approval
description: Thirtyfour states have rati fied the proposed constitution al amendment to grant the vote in all elections to 18year olds. The 35th is regarded as almost certain.

title: Marines Lean and Mean For PostVietnam Role
description: PARRIS ISLAND, S. C., June 27The Marine Corps is still building men.

title: Authorities Seeking to Link Coast and Mexican Deaths
description: YUBA CITY, Calif., June 27 (Reuther)The authorities said today that they have asked the police in Guadalajara, Mexico, to investigate a possible link between a recent slaying in southwestern Mexico and the death of 25 farm workers near here.

title: Arabs Draft a Constitution For 3Country Federation
description: CAIRO, June, 27 (Reuters) Delegates from Egypt, Libya and Syria today completed drafting a constitution for the proposed federation linking their countries.

title: Arts Abroad
