description: AMSTERDAMThe most exciting aspect of this year's the 24thcultural Holland Festival that opened June 15 is a colorful series of free street events. Maybe the in terest is more sociological than artistic but, anyway, a lot of enthusiasm is evident here about all that is, or will be, going on in the streets. The program calls for concerts by a chamber orches tra, acrobats, pan tomime chimes concerts, clowns, barrel organs, Shake speare perprmances, folk singers, jazz formations and pop groups, and also a num ber of free lunchbreak con certs in museums and concert halls. On the first day of the festival it poured, but hot soup was distributed and most Dutch and foreign non paying spectators and listen ers were visibly delighted with this new approach, which, of course, required an increased financial contribu tion from the Government.

title: Battle on Hudson Road Renewed
description: TARRYTOWN, N. Y.The battle lines are forming once again over the question of new highway along the Hudson River in the Sleepy Hollow country of northern Westchest er County.

title: Ruth Brisbane, Singer, Recalls Era of Twenties
description: Blues, pop songs and vaude ville songs of the twenties were recalled by Kith Bris bane on Saturday night at the New School.

title: Copters Save Boy Scouts Trapped in Utah Canyon
description: GREEN RIVER, Utah, June 27 (AP)A fleet of Air Force helicopters rescued 25 Boy Scouts and their three leaders today from Desolation Canyon, where they were trapped Thursday while shooting the rapids of the Green River.

title: Oils Peabody Swift Dies at 75; Reporter and War Relief Aide
description: Otis Peabody Swift, a former foreign correspondent and pub lic relations consultant, wild was active in international re lief during and after World War II, died yesterday at his summer home in Georgetown, Me. He was 75 years, old and also lived in Plainsboro, N.J., and Ponte Vedra, Fla.

title: PETERSON IS VICTOR IN FORMULA 2 RACE
description: ROUEN, France, June 27 (AP)  Ronnic Peterson of Sweden, in a MarchCosworth, won the Rouen Grand Prix auto race today and took a 2point lead in the European Formula Two championship over Francois Cavort of France.

title: Caramoor's Setting Is Bright Adjunct To Mozart Concert
description: KATONAH, N. Y., June, 27 The opportunity of commun ing simultaneously with nature and Mozart does not arise too frequently, which no doubt ex plains the fact that last night's Mozart concert at Caramoor had been sold out for weeks. It is, in fact, impossible to com ment on the opening motet, Ave, rerum corpus (K 618), without mentioning the sur roundings, so perfectly was the radiant, serene glow of the music reflected in the majestic trees, the sunsettinged clouds, even the new moon, growing brighter by the minute:

title: Sports of The Times
description: The Supreme Court may announce a decision today on Muhammad Ali's appeal of his conviction as a draft re sister, although one Ali lawyer thinks it unlikely the Court will act before it reconvenes next October. Ali himself feigns cosmic indifference: If I beat up a woman or robbed somebody or killed a man, then I'd be worried, I'd be afraid what them judges say; but it's an honor if you go to jail for a cause. Anyway, you go crazy if you worry about that. It has now been exactly four years and two months since Ali refused to be inducted into the Army. If the Court reverses his conviction, his ordeal is over, but if it is confirmed, there might be legal haggling over sentencing that could prolong the case another year.

title: Leiters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Supreme Court Decision On Vietnam Study A waited
description: WASHINGTON, June 27The New York Times and The Wash ington Post waited today for a Supreme Court decision on the Government's effort to prevent further publication of the Penta gon's secret history of Ameri can involvement in Vietnam.

title: Irish Ball to Go in Triomphe
description: CURRAGH, Ireland, June 27 (AP)Irish Ball, Frenchtrained winner of the Irish Sweeps Derby, definitely will run in the Arc de Triomphe in October, his trainer, Phillip Mallle, said today. Irish Ball took the first prize of $149,688 in yesterday's mileandahalf turf race.

title: CITY TRANSIT SEES $147MILLION DEFICIT
description: An operating deficit of $147, 475,445 for the city's subway and bus systems for the year starting July 1 was forecast in their new budgets yesterday.

title: U.S. Jet Down in Cambodia
description: SAIGON, Monday, June 28 (Reuters(An American Drag onfly jet fighter crashed in central Cambodia last night, killing one crewman, a United States military spokesman said today. The A37 twinengined jet was reportedly flying over the province of Preyveng when it crashed from unknown causes.

title: Meredith Moves Back to Mississippi
description: JACKSON, Miss., June 27 (AP)James H. Meredith, the first Negro to enter the Univer sity of Mississippi, says he has moved his family from New York City to Jackson because on a persontoperson, dayto day basis, the South IS a more livable place for blacks than any other place in the nation,

title: SALEM IS WINNER IN WESTPORT SHOW
description: WESTPORT, Conn., June 27 Carol Hofmann's Salem, who was scheduled to compete in the PanAmerican Games until the United States team was scratched from the equestrian events, won the open jumper stake, concluding event of the fiveday Fairfield County Hunt Club horse show today.

title: Agnew Is Off on 10Nation Tour; Carries Messages From Nixon
description: HONOLULU, June 27Vice President Agnew embarked to day on a 31day goodwill mis sion that will take him to 10 friendly nations in Asia, Africa anr Europe.

title: Orders for Tools in May Hit Highest Level of 1971
description: New orders for American machine tools, a closely watched indicator of the cap ital.epending plans of manu facturers, showed a modestly encouraging rise in May. They were at the hightest level of 1971, a generally depressed year.

title: FaceLifting Erases Age In Men, Too
description: SAN DIEGOFor some men it's mere ly a matter of keeping up with this vivid age of the male peacock, hair transplants and hisandher perfume. For others, it's a part of the grim battle against youth's upper hand in today's business world.

title: ... and in Ames and Orange City, Iowa
description: AMES, Iowa, June 27When the Post Office Department vanishes Thursday and the United States Postal Service takes over, there will be no ob vious changes in the way that smallcity and smalltown post offices handle your mail.

title: WORLD BANK USED FOR U. S. PROTEST
description: WASHINGTON, June 27The United States executive direc tor on the World Bank has ab stained, as a sign of disap proval, on two recent bank loans in South Americaboth times over the Issue of proper compensation of nationalized private foreign companies.

title: Smith Challenges Tennis Big 3
description: LONDON, June 27There they areRod Laver, John Newcombe and Ken Rosewall names to revere in the top three in tennis, all safely in the quarterfinals at Wimble don, Predictably seeded one, two and three, it would ap pear just a question of which one will win the coveted crown on Saturday.

title: Man Dies in Chlorine Leak
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., June 27 (AP)One man died and about 50 Indiana families we evacu ated today when chlorine gas leaked from a barge on the Ohio River. The police said the victim, Wilbur Paehner of Cin cinnati, was on the barge trans ferring the gas to the Stauffer Chemical Co. of Louisville when the gas began escaping.

title: Fed Stirs Concern
description: The credit markets have a difficult analytical problem this week: Will a lighter corporate financing schedule pust inter est rates down, or will worry about Federal Reserve money management push rates up?

title: New Postal Setup Means Changes Here...
description: There is a new book among the dusty tomes of postal regu lations in the office of the Post master of Brooklyn. It is called The Effective Executive, and Postmaster Martin Shapiro ex pects that it will get more than its share of use when the Unit ed States Postal Service begins operations on Thursday

title: Mrs. Carner Wins Open By 7 Strokes With 288
description: ERIE, Pa., June 27 (AP) Mrs. Joanne Gunderson Carver won the United States women's open golf championship by seven strokes today with a 72 hole total of 288 at the Ka.hkwa Club course. She had a 73, one over par, on the final round.

title: YOUTH WOUNDED IN A GUN BATTLE
description: Policemen shot and arrested a 16yearold youth on the, Lower East Side yesterday after he reportedly fired three times at four pursuing patrolmen.

title: MaltaNATO Issue Near Crisis Stage With U.S. Ship Due
description: VALLETTA, Malta, June 27 Malta's dispute with the North Atlantic Treaty Organ ization is approaching a critical stage with the expected arrival here tomorrow of a destroyer of the United States Sixth Fleet and a unit of British com mandos.

title: Church Installs Moderator
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., June 27 (AP)Dr. Dale W. Brown, a 45yearold seminary profes sor from Lombard, Ill., was installed today as moderator of the Church of the Brethren at thde close of the church's annual convention here. Pro fessor Brown, who teaches theology at Bethany Theologi cal Seminary in Oak Brook, succeeds Dr. Harold Z. Bom berger of McPherson, Kan.

title: Erica Mahl Is Wed
description: WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., June 27Miss Erica Susan Mahl and James V. Zizzi, graduates of the State Uni versity College at Buffalo, were married here today at the home of the bride's par ents, Mr. and Mrs. Allen Mahl. Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Valentine Zizzi of West Seneca, N. Y.

title: Jeffrey Cooper, Lawyer, Weds Joanne Ratner
description: Miss Joanne Ratner, daugh ter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley J. Ratner of Bronxville, N.Y., wars married, here last eve ning to Jeffrey H. Cooper, son of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Cooper of Rockville Centre, L.I.

title: Roundup: Red Sox Top Orioles Again, 31
description: The Boston Red Sox are stirring again and they are doing it against the cham pionsthe Baltimore Orioles.

title: Germans See Long Mark Float Despite Pressures to Fix Rate
description: KONSTANZ, West Germany, June 27  Expectations are growing in West Germany for a long float of the mark, de spite the pressures from France and the Common Market Exec utive Commission to return quickly to a fixed rate.

title: Graduate Joins Finch Board
description: Maria Nyhart of Weston, Conn., has been selected to a twoyear term on the board of trustees of Finch College in Manhattan. According to the school, the appointment of Miss Nyhart marks the first time in the history of the school that a member of the graduating class has been named to the board.

title: Cairo Truck Plunge Kills 15
description: CAIRO, June 27 (Reuters) Fifteen persons were killed and 17 injured today when a truck plunged into a canal near the Nile River after the driver had swerved to avoid another vehicle.

title: STEADMAN DEFENDS ACTIONS S.E.C. CITES
description: Charles W. Steadman, chair man and president of the Steadman Security Corporation of Washington, D.C., said in a statement yesterday that A resolution of all issues speci fied by the Securities and Ex change Commission staff, con cerning allegedly illegal prac tices, had been sought for many months.

title: $8.5Million Contract Is Let For Battery Park City Work
description: Construction of the $1.1bil lion housing and office develop ment on 91 acres of landfill in the Hudson River off lower Manhattan moved a step closer yesterday with the awarding of an $8.5million contract for landfill and bulkhead work.

title: Rally to Detour Traffic At Columbus Circle
description: Because of the Italian American Unity Day rally scheduled for noon at Colum bus Circle, traffic in the vi cinity will be detoured as fol lows, according to the Police Department:

title: Miss Keller Wed to Kenneth Berlin
description: WILMINGTON, Del., June 27  Miss Sue Ann Keller was married here this eve ning to Kenneth Berlin in Temple Beth Emeth by Rabbi Herbert E. Drooz.

title: Robinson Lawn Concert Benefits Drug Addicts
description: STAMFORD, Conn., June 27  More than $40,000 was raised here today at a con cert on the estate of Jackie Robinson for Daytop, Inc., a drugrehabilitation center for which Jackie Robinson Jr. worked before his death In a car accident last week.

title: JOHN J. TRAYNOR
description: WEST LONG BRANCH, N.J., June 27John J. Traynor, a re tired lawyer and accountant, formerly an associate of the New. York law firm of Breed, Abbott & Morgan, died yester day in Monmouth Medical Cen ter. He was 69 years old and lived at 73 Larchwood Avenue.

title: CLEVELAND ACTING ON SEWAGE LEAKS
description: CLEVELAND, June 27Sci entists and engineers worked today to repair leaks in a sew age control sstem currently pouring 120 million gallons of sewage daily into Lake Erie.

title: Litchfield Rowing Victor
description: PITTSBURGH, June 27The Litchfield Rowing Association of Connecticut won the 400 and 1,500meter eightoared events today in the annual Western Pennsylvania rowing champion ships on the Allegheny River. Dave Robinson of the Fair mount R.A. of Philadelphia won the elite singles, defeating Tom Quinn of the New York Athletic Club by two lengths.

title: AT HOME ABROAD
description: LONDON, June 27When problems of conscience and politics are involved, the criminal law is always likely to be a crude weapon, dangerous to those who use it. That will surely be so in the case of Daniel Ellsberg. For the case may make the idea of law, as it has been applied in the context of Vietnam, seem an ironic reflection of distorted values.

title: CHURCH SEEKING WOMEN PASTORS
description: GRAND RAPIDS; Mich., June 27 The two  million  member United Church of Christ has begun a campaign here to place more women in the pulpit at salaries equal to those paid their male counterparts.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: CROSSING OF DIG BY 2 REGIMENTS OF FOE REPORTED
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 27  Military sources said to day that atleast two North Vietnamese regiments had in filtrated across the demilitar ized zone into South Vietnam in the first large enemy move ment through the zone in about three years.

title: Harvey Aria Weds Barbara Gutfreund
description: Miss Barbara Gutfreund, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Salo Gutfreund of Forest Hills, Queens, was married here last night to Harvey Zell Arfa, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Arfa of Kew Gardens, Queens. Rabbi Leon Chait performed the cere mony at the Pierre.

title: Nixon Racial Policy Scored
description: Representative Shirley Chis holm, Democrat of Brooklyn, attributed some of the limited progress of blacks trying to en ter the construction industry to President Nixon who, she said yesterday, had not backed his Administration's rhetoric with action. The Associated Press reported that Mrs. Chis holm said Mr. Nixon has never had a commitment to black citizens.

title: Heart Disease Found High in Workers Exposed to Nitroglycerine
description: A Milwaukee doctor has found that several workers in an Army ordnance plant have developed a physical depend ence on the nitroglycerine used there to make rocket fuel.

title: Jews Urged to Deal With National Issues
description: ATLANTA, June 27  Two Jewish leaders said today that American Jewish organizations were so preoccupied with Jew ish issues that they were ne glecting other problems affect ing the nation.

title: Cosmos Beaten, 31
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 The Washington Darts avenged an earlyseason defeat and knocked the New York Cosmos out of first place in the North ern Division of the North American soccer league today with a 31 victory at Catholic University stadium.

title: 4 Australian Laborites Off to Tour Red China
description: SYDNEY, Australia, June 27The leader of the La borite Opposition in Parlia ment, Gough Whitlam, flew to Hong Kong today in prepara tion for a 12day tour of Communist China.

title: Franchising's Growing Pains Found Easing
description: Franchising, which has been afflicted by growing pains re cently, may be settling down on firmer footing.

title: In Pnompenh, Hoarding and Speculation in Currency
description: PNOMPENH, Cambodia, June 26Two side effects of war, food hoarding and currency speculation, have come to the Cambodian capital in recent months, doubling the price of rice in less than two weeks and causing a money crisis.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: International Loans Listed for Week
description: WASHINGTON, June 27The following is a list of loans and other aid extended last week by United States and other international lending agencies here:

title: PALAFOX RETAINS EASTERN NET TITLE
description: PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., June 27Tony Palafox, the former Mexican Davis Cup player, spoiled Steve Ross's bid for a fourth title this season by defeating the Brooklynite, 61, 75, 62, in the final of the Eastern men's, claycourt tennis championship today. It was the sedond year in a row Palafox had taken the title.

title: CHANGE IS SOUGHT IN EXCHANGE BODY
description: William McChesney Martin Jr., a man who probably will have more to say about the future of Wall Street than any, other individual, has tenta tively concluded that a corpor ate structure should be adopted for the governing board of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Jewish Defense League Gains Adherents in Cities Across Country
description: They gather in private homes in Greenwich, Conn., in a meet ing hall in Chicago's North Side and in an office in Los Angeles. There is talk of guns and karate and the emphatic conviction that if the Jew is kicked, he will kick back.

title: Philippines Requests U.S. Not to Trim Sugar Quota
description: MANILA, June 27Philip pines officials are asking the United States Congress to re consider a House bill that would reduce the Philippines' sugar quota in the United States by about 190,000 tons. The Philippines House of Rep resentatives has adopted a res olution expressing concern over the proposed cut and its seri ous repercussions on the coun try's developing economy.

title: NEIGHBOR SOUGHT IN MURDER HERE
description: A mover's helper and handy man known to the police as Freddy, among other names, was one of several persons be ing sought yesterday in con nection with the murder of Cor nelia Michelle Crilley, 23 years old, a stewardess for Trans World Airlines.

title: Stations Cut Off Air
description: A dozen or more television and FM radio stations trans mitting from the Empire State Building were shut down for about two minutes at 12:24 A.M. today when a power surge tripped off circuit breakers in the transmitters.

title: Vote of the Week In the House
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 Following are the votes of dele gations from New York, New Jersey, and Connecticut on the major roll calls in Congress during the week ended yes terday:

title: MITCHELL TAKES CLEVELAND GOLF WITH 262 TOTAL
description: CLEVELAND, June 27 (AP) Bobby Mitchell ignored the hu midity and shot a 6underpar 65 to score his first professional victory today in the $150,000 Cleveland open golf tourna ment. His 72hole total of 262 was 22 strokes under par at the 6,643yard Beechmont Country Club course.

title: New Blood Keeping U.S. Healthy in Track
description: EUGENE, Ore., June 27Re turning to a deserted stadium long after he had finished com petition, Randy Matson trudged slowly toward an area marked off for the shotput.

title: Man in the News
description: One year ago, a 27year old hematologist at the Bal timore Cancer Research Cen ter sat in front of his tele vision set watching taped highlights of the 100yard dash at the National Amateur Athletic Union outdoor track and field championships. I think I can beat those guys, Dr. Delano Merl wether said to his wife Myrtle, who was busy feeding the cou ple's 8monthold daughter. Myrtle nodded ap provingly, with the same pa tient reassurance that all women must show when their husbands talk of climb ing personal mountains.

title: Clary Boothe Luce Shared Billing With Women's Lib
description: LOS ANGELES.Los An geles society was exposed to the women's liberation move ment here last week and no body burned a bra or jumped nudeinto a swimming pool to prove a point. In fact, neither Gloria Steinern nor Betty Fried an was even invited to the meeting.

title: Mayday Groups Planning New Protests
description: MILWAUKEE, June 27  Sponsors of the Mayday anti war demonstrations in Wash ington last spring announced plans today for new demonstra tions in August and this fall, hoping that publication of the Pentagon papers would bring even more support.

title: A Subdued Wallace Appears in Toledo
description: TOLEDO, June 27George C. Wallace came North this week end to test the political climate and raise a little money, but he didn't appear to be the George Wallace of '68.

title: 8 KILLER AS PLANE CRASHES ON COAST
description: EUREKA, Calif., June 27 (UPI) A chartered twinengined DC3 returning 24 persons from an inspection tour of a seacoast recreational community hit a sewage treatment plant on take off tonight and crashed into the Pacific Ocean.

title: Handball Favorites Advance
description: The four topseeded teams in the national Amateur Athletic Union onewall handball dou bles championship advanced to the quarterfinals at the Brighton Beach Baths in Brook lyn yesterday. They were Carl and Ruby Obert; Steve Sandler and Don Weber; Marty Decatur and Marty Katzen, and Mike Dickman and Artie Reyer.

title: Blacks Eye Militancy for Building Jobs
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 Decades of failure to open up construction jobs to minorities have left a residue of bitterness, frustration, confusion and di visiveness.

title: Bronx AfterHours Club Is Raided
description: An illegal Bronx bottle club that reportedly had been oper ating for the last two years was raided and closed by the police, early yesterday. Cocaine was found and 30 persons were ar rested.

title: Books of The Times
description: THE MIDDLE AMERICANS. Proud and Un certain. Text by Robert Coles. Photographs by Jon Erikson, 181 pages. AtlanticLittle, Brown. $12,50.

title: Personal Finance: Mortgage Rates
description: Banks in the New York area have been discerning in creased interest recently in home buying, which seems to suggest that consumers are a Little more ready to open their wallets.

title: PUBLIC EMPLOYES TOP PRIVATE IN PAY
description: Pay levels for municipal blue collar workers and for police men and firemen in New York City tended to be substantially above comparable government wage rates in five other major cities surveyed in 1970 by the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the United States Department of Labor.

title: Flood Kills 15 in Colombia
description: BOGOTA, Colombia, June 27 (Reuters)At least 15 persons were killed and 30 were report ed missing after a mountain stream burst its banks and smashed through dozens of houses in the village of Salgar in northern Colombia yester day, officials said here today.

title: Building Your Own house: Simple as an Erector Set
description: KEENE, N.H.Last Christmas, Elmer Harry Close puzzled and sweated as sembling a stroller for his 2yearold daughter, Josephine.

title: EXTEACHER LEAVES VASSAR $5MILLION
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., June 27  One of the largest be quests ever made to Vassar College, $5million was an nounced today by its president Alan Simpson.

title: Washington Notes
description: WASHINGTON, June 27  Within the next month or so, President Nixon and Secre tary of State William P. Rogers are expected to decide on a number of ambassadorial transfers.

title: Pele Draws Cheers, Boos in Tie Game Before 21,414 Fans
description: JERSEY CITY, June 27Ed son Arantes do Nascimento, better known as Pel, made an appearance at Roosevelt Sta Idium here before 21,414 fans today. As usual, his perform ance was a standoutnot only, as a player, but as an actor.

title: Senate Faces $7Billion Arms Cut Fight
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 Somewhat sooner than expect ed, the annual battle over the defense budget will be joined in the Senate this week with an attempt to impose a $7bil lion reduction in military spending.

title: General Most Corp. Sets Condition on Cudahy Offer
description: The General Host Corporation announced yesterday that its tender offer to buy the common stock of the Cudahy Company at $22 a share and the preferred stock at $25 a share is con ditional on its receiving valid tenders for at least a majority of the 3,041,235 combined pre ferred and common voting stock, or 1,520,618 shares.

title: Underground Press Active in West Europe
description: AMSTERDAM, the Nether lands, June 20One of the liveliest manifestations of American influence abroad is the so  called underground press.

title: Miss Fischer Bride of Jay Becker
description: LOS ANGELES, June 27 Miss Sydney Jo Fischer and Jay Joseph Becker, a deputy district attorney in Los An geles County, were married here this morning.

title: Miss Davis Funds Replaced
description: PORTOLA VALLEY, Calif., June 27 (UPI)The executive director of the United Presby terian Church says 20 black clergymen have restored $10,000 to the church after that amount was donated to the Angela Davis Defense Fund. William F. Thompson said yesterday that the Presbyterian clergymen had donated $500 each.

title: State to Offet 1,000 Youths Jobs Here
description: The state government is mov ing into another field of oper ations in the city. Governor Rockefeller announced yester day that the state would spon sor and direct 1,000 Neighbor hood Youth Corps jobs here, with Federal funds, as part of a statewide program this summer.

title: Venn Files a Libel Suit Against I.O.S. Dissidents
description: Robert L. Vesco, chairman of Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., has filed a libel suit for $20million against Morton I. Schiowitz, former I.O.S. chief financial officer and a major shareholder, the public relations firm of Rubenstein & Wolfson & Co. and six dissident stock holders. The suit was filed late Friday in the Federal District Court for New Jersey.

title: 5,000 Homosexuals March to Central Park for a Rally
description: About 5,000 homosexual men and women marched in a happy parade from Greenwich Village to Central. Park yesterday af ternoon in a demonstration of gay pride and solidarity.

title: Prices Up Overseas
description: BRUSSELS, June 27Bond prices on the international market have begun to firm in the absence of any new straight dollar offerings. Trading activ ity, although still mild, is at least making itself felt for the first time since the international monetary crisis erupted last month.

title: OTB Ready to Switch Action to Big A Today
description: Wagering on thoroughbred horses by the city's Offtrack Betting Corporation switches from Belmont Park to Aque duct today and everything is set to go.

title: Abrams a Reader at Service in Saigon
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 27Gen. Creighton W. Abrams, commander of Amer ican troops in Vietnam, and United States Ambassador Ellsworth Bunker were lay readers in a sparsely attend ed Ecumenical Service of Prayer for Peace, Brother hood and Christian Unity this afternoon in the Roman Cath olic Cathedral here.

title: TV PANEL WEIGHS JUVENILE SHOWS
description: DURHAM, N.H., June 27 The director of children's pro grams for Denmark's national television said today that tele vision around the world should gear itself toward factual pro grams aimed at youth.

title: Welfare Employability
description: The regressive: welfare reforms enacted bythe recent session of the State Legislature now require implentente tion. One key change requires Welfare recipients deemed employable to accept Work, either public or private employment for wages or:assignment to public works projects. Those assigned to, such projects will, be obliged, to work off the welfare grants theyWill continue to receive.

title: Japan's Voters Give Socialists Unexpected Gains
description: TOKYO, Monday; June 28 The Japanese Socialists made unexpected gains, especially in rural areas, in partial returns from the House of Councilors election yesterday. Socialist gains and losses of the ruling LiberalDemocrat party In pre fectures (provinces) with large rural populations reverse one of the cardinal tenets of postwar politics in Japanthat the So cialists are strong in the cities while, the LiberalDemocrats are supreme in rural areas.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Gubbins Wins Run on S.I.
description: Justice Gubbins of the Millrose Athletic Association won the first Staten Island Athletic Club 20kilometer run at Clove Lake Park, Staten Island, yesterday. He covered the 12.4 miles in 1 hour 8 minutes and 53 sec onds. Sixty five of the 74 start ers finished.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
description: June 28, 1971 GENERAL ASSEMBLY Special Committee on Co lonialism3 P.M.

title: Class 44: Teacher Braces for Goodbys
description: A few weeks ago teachers at Public School 198 re ceived packets of articula tion cards to fill out on each child in their class. The term is of ancient vintage in schools, but no one seemed to know just what it meant.

title: Theater: Shepard's Melodrama Play
description: Sam Shepard is one of those natural dramatists who is almost obsessed with dra matic form. In Melodrama Play, being given at the La Mama Experimental Theater Club, Mr. Shepard is as much concerned with being melo dramatic as with being play ful.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: COCKER SPANIEL TAKES TOP HONOR
description: I'll bet you 50 cents the German Shepherd wins it all, a pessimistic but hopeful Mrs. Peggy Westphal said to a fellow railbird yesterday just before the final event of the Staten Island Kennel Club's allbreed fixture.

title: Injured Umpire Site Out 2
description: PHILADELPHIA, Juno 27 (AP)Shag Crawford, the um pire who was injured during yesterday's game, missed to day's doubleheader between the Pittsburgh Pirates and Phil adelphia Phillies. Crawford ran into the retaining wall, behind first base while covering on a foul fly and suffered badly bruised ribs.

title: CHURCH SCHOOLS EXPECT AID RULE BY COURT TODAY
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 Tomorrow, on the final day of its 197071 term, the Supreme Court is expected to rule on the constitutionality of Federal and state financial aid to parochial schoolsa decision that may determine whether the Roman Catholic school system in the country can survive.

title: 1961: J.F.K., Rusk and McNamara confer
description: The furor over the Pentagon Papers has been exciting for reporters, lucra tive for lawyers, intriguing for readers in the general public and conceivably even enlighteningalthough the possi bility is great that misleading would be a more accurate word. The question now is whether the nation can derive from the experience some positive and lasting benefit.

title: Soviet Japanese Talks Set on Oil Pipeline
description: TOKYO, June 27A plan to import large quantities of So viet oil to Japan through a pipeline across Siberia is scheduled to be discussed at a JapaneseSoviet joint economic committee meeting in Tokyo early next month.

title: Giles Cards 73 for 282 And Wins Northeast Golf
description: EAST PROVIDENCE, R. I., June 27 (AP)Vinnie Giles of Richmond carded a fourover pair 73 today and won the 10th annual Northeast amateur in vitation golf tournament at the Wannamoisett Country Club.

title: China: Foreign Policy Seeks United Front
description: PEKING, June 22  Pre mier Chou Enlai, forcefully reentering the diplomatic arena, is seeking a new coali tion of nations that will inhibit the power of Wash ing and Moscow.

title: Mrs. Ginsberg Bride Of Wilmont Vickrey
description: WHITE PLAINS, June 27 Mrs. Beverly Rollnick Ginsberg and Wilmont Vick rey were married here this. Morning at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew Eichen baum, friends of the couple. Rabbi Robert Rothman of the Community Synagogue of Rye performed the ceremony.

title: British Select Tennis Squad For Wightrnan Cup Play
description: LONDON, June 27 (Reuters) Virginia Wade, Winnie Shaw and Joyce Williams were named today to the British Wightnian Cup team which will challenge the Americans at Cleveland, Aug. 21 through 23.

title: Summer TV Show Here Will Teach Reading Skills
description: A televised readingskills pro gram will be conducted this summer by the Manpower Edu cation Institute, a nonprofit foundation sponsored by labor and management.

title: Bridge: Defender Makes Full Use Of Clues to Beat Contract
description: The key to successful de fense lies in mental recon struction of the unseen hands. A defender who makes full use of the avail able clues can sometimes find a doubledummy way to defeat the hand, as West did on the diagramed deal. It was played recently In London, and West was the British playerwriter, Victor Mollo.

title: Maddox Reports a Rise In Presidency Backing
description: ATLANTA, June 27 (UPI) More people than ever be fore want Lester Maddox to run for President, says Lester Maddox.

title: Mr. Honecker's Debut
description: East Germany's Volkskammer, the country's. Parlia ment, has put off the date of the next parliamentary election by more than two months until Nov. 14, appar ently to give Erich Honecker, the new First Secretary of the Communist party, more time to stabilize the regime under his leadership. At the same time the Volkskammer also named Mr. Honecker chairman of East Germany's National Defense Council, stripping Walter Ulbricht of one more post.

title: MALLOY QUALIFIES FOR POCONO RACE
description: LONG POND, Pa., June 27 (AP)Jim Malloy, a 37year old graduate of short track racing, was top qualifier at 166.861 miles an hour as 33car lineup was completed today for the Schaefer 500mile auto race at Pocono Interna tional Raceway on Saturday.

title: Miss Krugman Wed To Philip Ellis Ray
description: NEW HAVEN, June 27 Miss Laura Krugman and Philip Ellis Ray, doctoral candidates in English at Yale University, were married in the Memorial Room at Yale's Branford College today by Rabbi Burt Siegel.

title: Rock Fiasco in Louisiana May Signal End of an Era
description: McCREA, La., June 27The rock festival cult, born in har mony and good vibrations two years ago at Woodstock, showed signs this weekend of succumbing to discord and dis illusionment on a sunbaked soy bean field in Louisiana.

title: AUSTERITY BUDGET SET IN PAKISTAN
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, June 27Pakistan, faced with the prospect of sharply reduced for eign aid during the coming year, has announced a budget that calls for stringent national austerity but provides substan tially more money for the mili tary.

title: N.E.A. LEADER SCORES NIXON ON SCHOOL AID
description: DETROIT, June 27 (AP)  The incoming president of the National Education Associa tion criticized President Nixon today for his stand on extend ing financial help to private schools.

title: GAINS IN PENSIONS RULED OUT BY CITY PENDING A STUDY
description: The city served notice yes terday on its uniformed em ployes that it would grant no pension improvements until a newly created State Pension Commission had completed studies and made recommenda tions next year on future bene fits.

title: New Teachers' Union Is Scored by Board Head
description: Isaiah E. Robinson, who this week will become the first black president of the city's Board of Education, said yester day, the creation of a new, militant statewide teachers' union would wreak havoc on boards of education through out the state.

title: The Jackson Candidacy
description: If Lyndon B. Johnson had turned down the VicePresi dential nomination at the 1960 Democratic National Con vention, Senator Henry Jackson of Washington was the favored alternative or the Kennedy entourage. As events developed, Mr. Jackson Instead served as chairman of the Democratic National Committee during John F. Ken nedy's successful campaign.

title: Stewart Rallies in His Lola to Beat McLaren beam and Take 2d CanAm Race
description: MONTTREMBLANT, Quebec, June 27At long last Denny Hulme lost a CanAm race, but it took a combination of intes tinal illness and strenuous pres sure from Jackie Stewart to beat him.

title: Deborah Schoen Wed To George M. Stern
description: Miss Deborah Nan Schoen and George M. Stern were married yesterday at the Stephen Wise Free Syna gogue. Rabbis Edward E. Klein and James H. Perman performed the ceremony.

title: West Bengal Government Plans Resignation Today
description: CALCUTTA, India, June 27, (Reuters)The 10party coali tion Government of the state of West Bengal announced to day that it would resign to morrow, making way for a period of direct rule by the national Government in New Delhi.

title: Brooklyn Bishop Finds Joy In Mending Rifts in Diocese
description: The Rev. Gerard JeanJuste was ordained to the priest hood of the Roman Catholic Church yesterday in a liturgy that employed four languages French, English, Spanish and Latin.

title: City Ballet Features 2 in Debut Roles At Season's Finale
description: Two dancers were featured in new roles over the weekend as the New York City Ballet closed its spring season at the State Theater with Balanchine's A Midsummer Night's Dream. On Saturday afternoon, Susan Hendl made her debut as Her mia, while Helgi Tomasson was seen for the first time as the cavalier in the pas de deux of Act II.

title: Warm Weather Packs Beaches in City Area
description: Record numbers of people thronged beaches in the area yesterday as the temperature rose to 89 degrees.

title: END OF ROAD IS NEAR FOR I.S. 201 DISTRICT
description: The Intermediate School 201 school complex in Harlem, one of the city's tempestuous ex periments in decentralization, will be dissolved Wednesday.

title: HUROK CONCERTS ACQUIRED BY G.E.
description: Tomorrow Entertainment, Inc., the entertainment subsidiary of General Electric founded last, December, has acquired Hurok Concerts, Inc., headed by Soi Hurok, the 83yearold impresa rio who has been importing and presenting international musi cal and dance artists here for more than 50 years.

title: Too Few Doctors?
description: SUN VALLEY, IdahoMany popular clichs in the current national debate about reforming the nation's medical system were badly battered this past week at the intensive discussions of the Sun Valley Forum on National Health.

title: Johnston and Sanderson Win Hockey Players' Golf
description: TORONTO, June 27  Ed Johnston and Derek Sanderson of the Boston Bruins won the third annual $12,000 American Airlines' hockey players golf tournament at the 6,853yard Board of Trade course today.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: ZELTWEG, Austria, June 27 (UPI)  Pedro Rodriguez of Mexico and Dick Atwood of Britain won a 1,000kilometer auto race today with their Porsche 917 on the Oesterreich track.

title: Lisa Judith Schnitzer, Student, Married to Richard J. Plavin
description: MONTCLAIR, N. J., Juno 27Miss Lisa Judith Schnit zer, daughter of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Jeahaia Schnitzer of Montclair, was married here this afternoon to Richard Jef frey Plavin. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Piavin of Woodbridge.

title: Kahane and Others Held
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 (AP) Two persons were charged today with illegally entering the grounds of the Soviet Em bassy during a rally protesting treatment of Jews in the Soviet Union.

title: CHURCH SEEKING WOMEN PASTORS
description: GRAND RAPIDS; Mich., June 27 The two  million  member United Church of Christ has begun a campaign here to place more women in the pulpit at salaries equal to those paid their male counterparts.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising: New Team at N. C. & K. Unit
description: A pair of Ivy Leaguers in their thirties have been moved into top spot of Norman, Craig & Kummel's domestic operation.

title: Westbury Downs Aiken, 95, In Metropolitan Polo League
description: BETHPAGE, L. I., June 27 Peter Rizzo scored four goals and Allen Jerkens two as the Westbury polo team defeated Aiken, 9.5, today in a Metro politan League game at Beth page State Park. Aiken was led by Pete Bostwick with three goals and Ted Shapiro with two.

title: RHEFFIC IS VICTOR IN $326,780 RACE
description: PARIS, June 27Mrs. Fran cois Dupr's French Derby win ner, Rheffic, captured the 103d running of the $326,780 Grand Prix de Paris, the toughest test for 3yearolds in the world, today.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: SELFREGULATION: NEW PLAN URGED
description: WASHINGTON, June 27  William L. Cary, former chair man of the Securities and Ex change Commission, believes that there is no practical al ternative to selfpolicing of the securities industry. But he would create an entirely new selfregulatory organization to coordinate the job and to pio neer in new industrywide regu lately techniques.

title: The Paper Jungle
description: Crime flourishes in Wall, Street's paper jungle. It is impossible to know the exact dimensions of the problem. Attorney General John Mitchell has testified before the Senate Investigations subcommittee that in 1969 and 1970 close to a half billion dollars in securities were stolen by thieves connected with organized crime syndi cates, and that more than $400 million of this loot has not been recovered.

title: Cricketers Play to Draw
description: The Staten Island Cricket Club and Jamaica Restaurant played to a draw yesterday at Walker Park, Staten Island. Staten Island had 130 runs, Jamaica Restaurant 80 for nine.

title: HaywoodGregg Duo First In Auto Endurance Racing
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON, L.I., June 27  Hurley Haywood of Chicago and Peter Gregg of Jacksonville, Fla., won over all honors today's International Motor Sports Association en durance races.

title: State's 12 Biggest Suburban Counties Will Consider a Coalition
description: MINEOLA, L. I., June 27 The chief executives of the state's 12 largest suburban counties will meet in Nassau County next fall to discuss the formation of a coalition that would serve their mutual interests.

title: Ivor Braka Weds Robin Aronsohn
description: Miss Robin Aronsohn, daughter of Mrs. Robert S. Eisenberg and Benjamin Aronsohn Jr., was married here last evening to Ivor Brake, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Brake of New York and Deal, N. J. Rabbis Louis C. Gerstein and A. Lopez Cardozo performed the cere mony in the Spanish and Por tugueso Synagogue (Congre gation Shearith Israel).

title: Boy Who Aided Vietcong Says He Was Tortured by the Police
description: DANANG, South Vietnam, June 16I am so frightened, the 12yearold boy who had worked for the Vietcong whis pered over and over.

title: Yanks Lose Pair
description: In a convincing display of what ails them, the New York Yankees scored only one run in 18 innings yesterday and lost a doubleheader to the lastplace Washington Senators, 21 and 80.

title: POLITICS SEETHING IN SIERRA LEONE
description: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone, June 17This West African country, half the size of New York State and with a popu lation only as lame as Brook lyn's, seems to have no short age of political turmoil.

title: Miss Wile and Paul K. Schwarz, Teachers, Have Garden Bridal
description: SCARSDALE, N. Y., June 27The marriage of Miss Barbara M. Wile to Paul K. Schwarz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Schwarz took place here today in the garden at the home lot the brides parents, Mr. and Mrs. Julius Wile. Rabbi Lawrence Schwartz performed the cere mony.

title: Chess:
description: Along about the turn of the century, the Franklin Mercantile Chess Club of Philadelphia, then, as now, one of the important chess centers in the East, sent play ers to New York City fre qbently to take on first the Manhattan and later the Mar shall Chess Club in team matches.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: EVERY week, more than 20.000 jobs ere advertised in The New York Times. See the Employment Columns today. Advt.

title: 3 World Lifting Records Are Bettered by Alekseev
description: SOFIA, Bulgaria, June 27 (AP) Vasily Alekseev, the Soviet Union super heavyweight weight lifter, established three world records today in the con cluding event of the 1971 Euro pean championships, the Bul garian press agency reported.

title: Expos Rout Mets 124, 7 Runs in First Chase Williams, Tie Club Mark
description: MONTREAL, June 27The Montreal Expos, smarting after four straight losses to the New York Mets, exploded for seven runs in the first inning and went on to a 124 victory today.

title: 1961: J.F.K., Rusk and McNamara confer
description: BONNI can scarcely imagine any journalist of any country who reads of the struggle of The New York Times to publish the Vietnam papers not feel ing involved. Seldom has the natural born conflict between Government and press presented itself in such a repre sentative fashion.

title: Cricket, Now in Full Swing, Is FastRising Sport Here
description: For several hours yester day afternoon, the scene at Walker Park on Staten Island resembled an English village green.

title: Oil Blast Kills 14 in Poland
description: WARSAW, June 27 (AP) Fourteen persons were killed and 56 injured when oil re finery tanks blew up in the Silesian town of Czechowice, the state television network an nounced tonight. The Com munist party leader, Edward Gierek, went to the town and visited the injured.

title: COMPLAINTS RISE AMONG TENANTS
description: The city's Rent and Housing Maintenance Commissioner said yesterday that tenant com plaints of harassment and lack of service by landlords had in creased fivefold in the last three weeks.

title: Miss Kerr Is Bride Of Webster Pilcher
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn., June 27Miss Dorothy Al lyson Kerr, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Allen Kerr, was married here this after noon to Webster Hotchkiss Pitcher, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Barron Pitcher. Both families are of New Canaan.

title: Black Owned Recording Studio Opens in Harlem Amid Optimism
description: A backowned recording stu dio opened in East Harlem last Week, with a promise from its owner that it would be the thost successful venture since white thread.

title: Miss Budweiser Captures Dodge Cup Race for Hydros
description: DETROIT, June 27 (UPI) Dean Chenoweth, driving Miss Budweiser, the national point leader in hydroplane standings, grabbed the lead at the start and went on to win the Horace Dodge Cup race for unlimited hydros on the Detroit River to day.

title: LAIRD SEEKS RAISE IN ARMS AID LIMIT
description: WASHINGTON, June 27 United States efforts to pre vent an arms race among LatinAmerican countries have had the reverse effect  ac tually starting a race and thereby reducing the money available for economic devel opment  the Department of Defense told Congress last week.

title: ORDERS FOR STEEL CONTINUING TO DRAG
description: PITTSBURGH, June 27  Steel users did not seem very worried last week about what will happen Aug. 1, the dead line for a mill strike.

title: STATES UNCEKTAIN ON FUTURE OF AID
$25Billion Deficit Hit
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI) The Federal budget amassed a deficit of $25.6billion during the first five months of the fiscal year that ends Wednes day, the Treasury reported today.

title: U.S. PULLOUT PLAN IN 1962 REPORTED
description: BOSTON, Tuesday, June 29 (AP)The Christian Science Monitor, printing what it said were excerpts from hitherto unpublished portions of the secret Pentagon papers, report ed today that for 21 months in 196264 the United States laid plans to pull almost all Ameri can troops out of Vietnam over a fiveyear period.

title: The Senate and the U.M.W.
description: The United Mineworkers under its present leadership would probably win any contest to choose the worstrun union in the country. William A. Boyle was reelected president of the U.M.W. in 1969 in an election marred by charges of fraud, coercion and intimidation. The Sec retary of Labor is now suing to set aside the election.

title: Sato's Party Suffers a Setback And Reds Gain in Japanese Vote
description: TOKYO, Tuesday, June 29 Premier Eisaku Sato's ruling LiberalDemocratic party was given a mild rebuff in Japan's upper house elections Sunday.

title: Ellsberg Yields, Is Indicted; Says He Cave Data to Press
description: BOSTON, June 28Dr. Daniel Ellsberg, deplored today that he had given the Pentagon study of the Vietnam war to the press. Moments later he surrendered to the United States Attorney here for arraignment on charges of unauthorized possession of secret documents.

title: Conferees Approve $5.14Billion Bill To Aid Education
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) Senate and House conferees reached final agreement today on a $5,146,000,000 money bill for Federal aid to education, in the fiscal year starting Thurs day.

title: Ali Wins to Draft Case Appeal
description: WASHINGTON, June 28  Muhammad Ali was cleared, by the Supreme Court today of the charge of refusing induc tion into the Army.

title: A Leak to Oppenheimer Brings S.E.C. and FundGroup Studies
description: WASHINGTON, June 28  Detailed new procedures to en sure that the monthly figures on mutualfund sales and re demptions do not again leak out and give some insiders an advantage in stock trading are being worked out by the In vestment Company Institute, the fund industry's trade asso ciation.

title: U.S. IN NEW ACTION ON CIGARETTE TAX
description: In a change of, tactics, the Federal Government filed civil suits here yesterday against three mail order cigarette com panics in North Carolina, ac cusing them of having failed to supply state tax officials with the names and addresses of purchasers.

title: Lindsay Calls Shooting An Ugly Shock to City
description: Mayor Lindsay said yester day that the outrageous at tack on Joseph A. Colombo Sr. is an ugly shock to all New Yorkers.

title: Court Bars Curb on SST
description: BOSTON, June 28 (AP)The State. Supreme Court, ruled to day in an opinion requested by the Massachusetts House that the legislature cannot enact legislation prohibiting super sonic transports from landing in the state.

title: Police Seek Photos of Scene
description: The Police Department issued an appeal to the news media for any motionpicture film or still camera photographs taken at Columbus Circle yesterday that could be used to identify those involved in the shooting of Jo seph A. Colombo Sr.

title: Talks on Cities and Counties to Conflict
description: Two leading lobbies for the nation's cities and counties will be meeting in the same city on the same day next month, but the county people do not like it and city repre sentatives apparently did not even know about it.

title: Federal Plan to Bus Students Rejected By Judge in Austin
description: AUSTIN, Tex., June 28 (UPI) In the first school desegrega tion trial since the Supreme Court upheld busing of stu dents, United States District Judge Jack Roberts rejected to day a Government plan for mas sive busing to balance Austin schools racially.

title: A Day for Victoty Outside Ring
3 Soviet Astronauts Normal On Their 23d Day in Orbit
description: MOSCOW, June 28 (UPI) Three Soviet astronauts on their 23d day in orbit, five days beyond the previously known capacity of man to endure weightlessness in spaceflight, recorded normal pulse, blood pressure and respiration rates today.

title: Pistons to Oppose Squires
description: DETROIT, June 28 (UPI) the Detrolt Pistoni of the Na tional Basketball Association announced today they have hooked their first exhibition game with an American Basket ball Association club, the Vir ginia Squires.

title: The Proceedings In the U.N. Today
A PENTAGON CURB CHARGED BY CASE
description: WASHINGTON, June 28  Senator Clifford P. Case ac cused the Pentagon today of manipulation and suppression of scientific opinion on the feasibility of detecting under ground nuclear explosions.

title: SOYBEANS RALLY, THEN FALL BACK
description: Profit taking halved a 6 centabushel increase in soy bean futures prices on the Chi cago Board of Trade yester day.

title: 13 Die in Mexico Explosion
description: MEXICO CITY, June 28At least 13 persons were killed and six were seriously injured when a building containing fireworks exploded early today in San Pablo Actipart, 20 miles south of here. Several persons are missing.

title: Corporate Bonds Gain; Treasury Issues Plunge
description: The credit markets followed several different paths yester day.

title: 39 New Air Taxi Routes Planned by Postal Service
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) Hoping to improve short haul air mail delivery, the Unit ed States Postal Service said today that it was adding 39 air taxi routes between now and the end of July at an an nual cost of $5.9million.

title: TV :LowBudget Bright Spot Sundays
HOUSE REJECTS VIETNAM PULLOUT VOTED BY SENATE
description: WASHINGTON, June 28  The House refused today to ac cept a Senate amendment call ing for withdrawal of troops from Vietnam in nine months if American prisoners of war were released by North Viet nam.

title: Bayh Bids Israel Yield Most of Occupied Land
description: INDIANAPOLIS, June 28 (AP)  Israel should give up most of the Arab territory she occupied in 1968 to ob tain a permanent peace set tlement and gain a secure boundary, Senator Birch Bayli, Democrat of Indiana, Said tonight in a news con ference here.

title: COURT HERE UPHOLDS JAP AS TRADEMARK
description: The State Supreme Court here refused yesterday to bar the use of the word Jap as a trademark for a brand of women's apparel marketed here and abroad.

title: Sports of The Times
description: So quietly that you could almost hear the odds drop, Edward Belmonte sneaked back into the jockey standings at the local horsepark while no one was looking. This is about the only quiet thing he has done in his 28 colorful years on this planet. He is better known for his outrageous choice of men's wear, or whatever it is; his red  tinted hair, his pet lion cub and his occasional tendency to land a right, across In the face of a fellow racerider.

title: FUNDS' NET BUYING AT HIGH IN QUARTER
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (Reu ters)  Institutional investors had net purchases of a record $4.2billion of common shares in the first quarter of 1971, the Securities and Exchange Com mission has estimated.

title: Buffalo G.I. Killed in War
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI) The Defense Department said today that Specialist 4 Donald P. Knutsen of Buffalo, N. Y., of the Army, has been killed in ac tion in Southeast Asia.

title: HIGH SCHOOLS TOLD TO TRY NEW WAYS
description: New York City's 92 high schools were encouraged yes terday by top school officials to try new methods of educa tionnew courses, independent study, minischools within schools, class periods of vary ing length to encourage youngsters to learn more.

title: LAIRD SEES PERIL IN $7BILLION CUT
description: WASHINGTON, June 28  Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird warped Congress today that a proposed out of $7billion In military spending would have a catastrophic impact on de fense programs.

description: HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 28 (Reuters)  Secretary Gen eral Thant of the United Na tion arrived today from New York for a rest on doctor's orders. He suffered a collapse a week ago. He will stay with friends.

Siderurrgia del Orinoco of Caracas. Scholoe mann is supplying the roughing train for a semicontinuous hot rolling mill for large strip steel as well as the strip treatment lines.

description: WASHINGTON, June 28The Supreme Court put off today a decision on the Government's efforts to block The New York Times and The Washington Post from publishing, material from the Pentagon papers on Vietnam.

description: WASHINGTON, June 28 The Supreme Court declared unconstitutional today state programs that reimburse. Roman Catholic and other churchrelated schools for in struction in nonreligious sub jects.

description: MOSCOW, June 28 (Reuters) The Soviet Union today rati fied the treaty banning the emplacement of nuclear weapons on the seabed.

title: HIGH COURT, 8 TO 1, FORBIDS STATES TO REIMBURSE PAROCHIAL SCHOOLS; BACKS COLLEGELEVEL HELP, 5 TO 4
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 The Supreme Court declared unconstitutional today state programs that reimburse. Roman Catholic and other churchrelated schools for in struction in nonreligious sub jects.

title: Separating Church From State
description: The Supreme Court in three separate decisions has dealt with the delicate question of churchstate separa tion. By a narrow 54 majority it approved the use of Federal fundsa practice that has been followed for some Oars under a 1963 law for construction of such buildings as scientific laboratories and gymnasiums for churchrelated colleges. At the same time the Court struck down as educational subsidies the grant of public money to elementary and secondary parochial schools in Pennsylvania and Rhode Island. The rulings in the latter cases were by emphatic 8to0 and 8to1 majorities, respectively.

title: Hall Takes Halfway Lead For L.I. Sound Sailing Title
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 28  Graham M. Hall of the Larclunont Yacht Club and the coach of the State University of New York Maritime College, bidding to regain the Com modore Hipkins Trophy he won in 1969, held a 2point lead today in the 20th annual Long Island Sound men's sailing championship.

title: They Mouthed Morality
description: Walt Rostow has stated the moral case for the war in Vietnam in these pages. No one who knows Mr. Ros tow doubts his sincerity or depth of moral commitment. But the issue is not what it has been said to be that those who made the decisions about the war were indifferent to Moral considerations. The issue is the impersonal one as to the actual nature of these considerations, and the kind of logic that should be used in thinking about them.

title: Protected Civic Protectors ...
description: The crying towel used so regularly at the bargaining table by New York City civil service unions gets a thorough laundering in the first authoritative study to determine how wages and benefits for public employes here compare with those in other big cities and in private industry. The, study, made by the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, indicates that most classes of municipal employes in this city rank well ahead of comparable workers elsewhere when account is taken of all forms of compensation  pay scales, pensions, vacations, insurance and other fringe items. The argument that city employes are treated as secondclass citizens, still a mainstay of the union approach to contract negotia tions, long ago ceased hhave much validity.

title: Pacific Bell Cites Gains
description: The Pacific Northwest Bell Telephone Company reported yesterday operating revenues of $115,646,000 for the three months ended May 31. com pared with $110,725,000 a year ago. Net income rose to $13, 586,000, or 36 cents a share from $12,701.000, or 33 cents a share, in the 1970 period. The company is 89.2 per cent owned by the American Tele phone and Telegraph Company.

title: Man in the News
description: The supreme Court's re versal yesterday of Muham mad Ali's draft conviction represents perhaps the great est victory in what the for mer world heavyweight boxes ing champion regards as his battle for black freedom. When I climb into the ring, Ali said once, I'm thinking about God, and I'm thinking about all those people in every ghetto in every city in the United States of America. I'm out to whup all the hypocrites in the power structure. I'm fighting for my freedom and carrying the hopes of my 30 million black people here, and that's what my mission is.

description: Anyone who dines at the Wine Cellar restaurant is in danger of having his table sold out from under him. Virtually everything in the place is for sale because the Wine Cellar is not just a dining spot, it's also an an tiques shop.

description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP)Following is the rollcall vote by which the House rejected today the Senate's call for troop withdrawal front Indochina in nine months if United States prisoners of war were released by North Vietnam. The vote was on killing a motion to order House conferees to accept the Senate provision.

Fie contracts are involved, includ ing four from the Bell Helicop ter division of Textron, Inc., and one from the Boeing Com pany's Vertrol division.

description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) The Agriculture Department announced today it had offered aid to 21 countries in three states to help repairr damage caused by drought.

description: The New York Philharmonic will expand its annual free concerts in the city parks from 12 to 15 this summer. It will also utilize three new park sites in addition to the five that it has played in pre viously. North Meadow in Manhattan's Central Park, Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx and Cunningham Park in Queens will now have con certs, as well as Sheep Mead ow in Central Park, Clove Lakes Park on Staten Island, Prospect Park in Brooklyn, Crocheron Park in Queens and the Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: Amnesty Group Says Saigon Bars Inspection of P.O.W. Camps
Amsterdam Radio Quotes Hashish Prices
description: AMSTERDAM, June 28By noon the young travelers clog Dam Square in the heart of the city. They strum guitars, exchange tips on drugs and cheap rooms and stare hard at the cameratoting tourists who walk past and gawk.

title: Notes on People
description: Charles Evers, the black Mayor of Fayette, Miss., said yesterday that Jimmy Swan, Democratic candidate for his party's nomination for Gov ernor, was the greatest threat this state has.

title: Soviet Ratifies Egypt Pact
description: MOSCOW, June 28 (Reuters) The Soviet Union ratified its friendship treaty with Egypt today. Soviet military aid is in volved in the treaty, which was signed in Cairo last month.

title: MANSFIELD IN PLEA FOR ECONOMIC FUND
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) The Senate Democratic lead er, Mike Mansfield, of Montana, protested today that funds for the Upper Missouri and Mid South Regional Economic De velopment Commissions were being held hostace to the Ad ministration's special revenue sharing proposal.

title: DANCERS ACE OUT OF HILLTOP FINALE
description: YONKERS, June 28  Key stone Hilliard, the Hickory Pride colt that captured both his $15,000 preliminary dashes in the Hilltop Trotting Series at Yonkers Raceway, winning in 2:05 15 and in 2:02 45, will not be among the starters in tomorrow night's $25,000 mile final here.

title: FORMER CITY AIDE GUILTY OF BRIBERY
description: Eugene L. Sugarman, a for mer deputy city, controller, was convicted yesterday in State Supreme Court on 11 counts of receiving bribes and taking un lawful fees totaling $88,000 and conspiring to do so.

title: Screen: 'Hellstrom Chronicle' Opens:Nature Provides Topic of Documentary
description: "The world," says the narrator of "The Hellstrom Chronicle," a man obviously privy to all sorts of secrets, including those of the emotional lives of the planets, "was created not with the sweetness of love, but with the violence of rape."The narrator, unfortunately, is never at a loss for words. He expresses a wish to have seen "the ironic smile on the Creator's face" as He was going about His business and, a little later, makes us feel almost guilty as he reminds us that insects are "free from the concept of romance" (which explains, I guess, why so few termites have been lyric poets). A perfectly well behaved (in her own terms) black widow spider is described as "throbbing with obese sexuality" as if she were La Saraghina in some arachnid "8."These asinine statements should give you an idea of the viscosity of the various assumptions by which the makers of "The Hellstrom Chronicle," the feature-length documentary that opened yesterday at the Paramount Theater, have glued together a lot of quite beautiful and spectacular footage of insect life.Considering the high quality of the photography, I suspect that many moviegoers will be willing to put up with the narration and the point of view of the film, which earlier this year was awarded the Grand Prix de Technique at the Cannes Film FestivalI, for one, must register an objection. I find it significantand depressingthat someone would feel that a film so full of straightforward scientific data should have to be hyped by the sort of scare-and-doom techniques better applied to the fiction of "War of the Worlds.""The Hellstrom Chronicle" purports to be an ultimatum to mankind delivered by a scientist, Nils Hellstrom (played by an actor named Lawrence Pressman) to the effect that if we don't watch out, the insects will inherit the earth, which, as he notes anyway, was quite comfortably inhabited by insects long before the first man appeared.The movie seems to be making a case for a sane ecological policy, which is all well and good, but it devotes most of its efforts to turning its subjects  driver ants, locusts, bees, moths, butterflies, Venus fly traps, and what notinto monsters of anthropomorphic dimension. Why else would the narrator make such a point of the fact that an insect "has no muscles to smile with, or with which to betray its thoughts?""The Hellstrom Chronicle" is less interested in defining the roles that insects play in maintaining the balance of nature than in creating nightmare visions of their world in strictly human, phobic terms. There is, to be sure, a certain fascination in watching termites at war with harvester ants, or bees disposing of the larvae of unwanted queens, or a fly being consumed by a plant. These scenes are also unpleasant, in an almost abstract fashion, as if all of the maiming, the dismembering and devouring were in themselves evil, and not simply the very well ordered system by which nature survives as well as it does.A number of cameramen contributed the individual sequences, utilizing stop-motion photography, telescopic lenses and microscopic lenses, and their work is superb. The narration and the point of view, however, are sensationally awful and, possibly, misleading. Anyone who has ever lived more than a week in a New York apartment already knows, for example, that an entente with insects must be reached if the world is to survive. I suspect that the only people who worry about whether or not a cockroach can smile are people who have never lived with one. A smile is something one just doesn't ask of a bug.

title: Advertising:
description: The Jacobsen Manufactur ing Company, Racine, Wis., a subsidiary of Allegheny Lud lum Industries, Inc., that manufactures lawncare prod ucts, power mowers, garden tractors and attachments, has appointed Young & Rubi cam, Chicago, as its agency. The previous agency was Rink Wells & Associates, Inc., whose grass, apparently, was looking greener, at least to Jacobsen.

title: Harry Ford, a Conductor And Pianist, Is Dead at 71
description: Harry Ford, a conductor and pianist who for 20 years was musical director of the Tues day night shows at Roseland Dance City, 239 West 52d Street, died Saturday in Leroy Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 1295 Grand Con course, the Bronx.

title: LORD SIMONDS DIES; EXHIGH CHANCELLOR
description: LONDON, June 28 (UPI)  Lords Simonds, Lord High Chancellor (Speaker of the House of Lords) from 1951 to 1954, died today at his home. He was 89 years old.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: It seems at last that the present Government has brought to bear against the general public a policy it has used in its dealings with third world nations and minority groups in this countrythat we are not strong enough, nor wise enough, nor mature enough, to face our mistakes and grow from them.

title: U.S. Says It Win Continue Aid to Pakistan Despite Cutoff Urged by Other Nations
description: WASHINGTON, June 28The Nixon Administration reaffirm ed today that it intended to provide, economic aid to Paki stan despite international pres sures to halt foreign assistance until the central Government reached a political accommo dation with East Pakistan.

title: FRANZ STANGL 63, NAZI CAMP HEAD
description: BONN, June 28Franz Paul Stangl, former commandant of the Nazi extermination camp at Treblinka in Poland, was found dead in his prison cell in Dsseldorf today. Half a year ago; in one of the last big war crimes trials in Germany, Stangl was sentenced to life imprison merit for having taken part in the murder of 400,000 Jews.

title: ExSenator Martin of Iowa, 78, Dies
description: SEATTLE, June 28 (AP) Former Senator Thomas E. Martin of lowa died last night In a hospital. He was 78 years old.

title: Article 9  No Title
Congress Gets Pentagon Papers, Locks Them Up
description: WASHINGTON, June 28  The pentagon papers, packed in cardboard boxes marked top secret, were delivered to Con gross today and quickly planed in locked vaults.

title: Gorman Topples Laver in Quarterfinals
description: WIMBLEDOM, England, June 28Rod Laver has been beaten at Wimbledon.

title: OBSERVER
description: One of the first problems to arise if New York City becomes a state will be picking a name fort it. Then there's the question of getting admitted to the Union; after that, the question where to locate the state capital; then, how to set up a badly apportioned legisla ture. If New York City is going in for statehood, it may as well do things right.

title: Rally Day Crowd Reacts With Sorrow and Anger
description: The ItalianAmerican Civil Rights League's second annual Unity Day rally in Columbus Circle began at noon yesterday with a prayer for the life of Joseph A. Colombo Sr. and ended at 3 P.M. with the league's president, Natale Marcone, shouting from be neath a statue of Christopher Columbus to the crowd: Go home but never forget, be proud to be an, Italian all the time!

title: Hoffa Pays $10,000 Fine
description: CHATTANOOGA, June 28 (AP)  James R. Hoffa, former teamsters president has paid a $10,000 fine imposed against him when convicted for jury tampering in 1964, United States District Court officials disclosed today. The charge stemmed gram Hoffa's trial in Nashville in 1962 on alleged Conspiracy to violate labor management laws. The case was declared mistrial after a juror announced he had been approached.

title: The Colleges Want Them... But Do They Want the Colleges?
description: Before in Mountain Lakes, the ques tion was, Where are you going to col lege? said Pamela. Batchelor, a June graduate of the high school in that up permiddleclass New Jersey suburb. Now the question IS, Are you going?

title: Article 8  No Title
Gallo: Colombo Feud Said to Have Said Been Renewed
description: Joseph and Albert Gallo, who were questioned in the shooting of Joseph A. Colombo Sr. yesterday, were reported to have renewed recently a feud with Colombo going back more than a decade.

title: Stage: 2nd Hottest Show
description: Seeing The 2nd Hottest Show in Town, which opened at the Actors Playhouse last night, did not inspire any wish in me to see The 1st Hottest Show in Town, or even The 3rd Hottest Show in Town. If this is a hot show, I think I prefer hot pants.

title: Author Goes on Trial Today For Murder in Tennessee
description: HUMBOLDT, Tenn., June 28 (UPI)Jesse Hill Ford, the au thor, goes on trial for murder tomorrow in the town ho says has turned against him because of his novel about racial big otry.

title: Commonwealth Edison Sees Higher Share et for 1971
description: CHICAGO, June 28 (UPI) Commonwealth Edison Co. pre dicted today that earnings would rise to about $3.05 a share this year but would taper off to $2.40 by 1973 if a pro. posed rate increase is not approved.

title: Article 6  No Title
Bridge: An AceQueen Combination Sometimes a Mixed Blessing
description: A player who has an ace queen combination in the op ponents' suit is entitled to regard it with affection. He may be looking at two sure defensive winners. His pleas ure diminishes if the appear ance of the dummy makes it certain or probale that his queen is schednled to be cap tured by the king.

title: MISSISSIPPI BLACK CHARGES JOB BIAS
description: BILOXI, MISS., June 28 (UPI)  A black Vietnam veteran testified today that the Missis sippi Highway Patrol had re fused to give him an application for a job, as a suit seeking integration of the patrol's uni form division opened in Federal court.

title: T.W.A. Postpones Its Stock Offering
description: Trans World Airlines post poned yesterday its planned of fering of two million shares of common stock. The company cited general stock market con ditions.

title: GERMANS BUYING NOTES FROM U. S,
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 The Treasury announced today an arrangement with the West German central bank for the sale to the Bundesbank of up to $5billion of special Treasury notes with a maturity of one to five years.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: There seems to be a perhaps un answerable inconsistency in the por tion of The Times's coverage of the secret Pentagon papers that concerns itselfhow the papers came into the hands of Times reporters.

title: NORTHERN ELECTRIC PRESSES U.S. SALES
description: MONTREAL, June 28 (Cana dian Press)  John C. Lobb, president of the Northern Elec tric Company, Ltd., says his company will make a major thrust to get a greater share of the lucrative United States mar ket.

title: Rise Asked in SmallTrade Fee
description: The New York Stock Ex change asked yesterday for multimilliondollar increase in the sales charges generally paid by small investors to buy and sell stock.

title: Market Place:
description: The more you read about pollution and the paper mills, the more you may be inclined to think that paper is a sick industry.

title: Venezuela Oil Bill Author Rejects a Trial Balloon
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, June 28 (UPI)The author of the olll reversion bill, now before the Congress, rejected today a trial balloon sent up by the oil industry that suggested a settlement of differences over the legislation through bilateral talks.

title: School Board on West Side Rejects City Budget Cuts
description: The local board of Commu nity School District 3 on the West Side of Manhattan voted last night to refuse to go along with any of the budget cuts imposed by the central Board of Education.

title: Article 3  No Title
Coast Jury Acts
ABM Fails in TestFiring
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI)A Spartan antiballistic missile, part of the Safeguard ABM system, failed to fire Sat urday in a test of its ability to intercept a Minuteman missile over the Pacific, the Pentagon said today. It was the second failure in 15 testlaunchings in the Safeguard system. The Spartan is designed to intercept and destroy ICBM's while they are still far from the targets.

title: Valdes Stops Leite In Fourth at Forum For 26th Victory
description: Rodrigo Valdes of Colombia scored a fourthround knockout over Edmundo Leite of Brazil last night before a crowd of 1,844 that paid $6,135 in the Felt Forum.

title: GEN. JOHN E. M'MAHON
description: SARATOGA, Calif., June 28 (UPI)Gen. John E. McMahon whose military career ranged from the Mexican border dis pute to World War II, died yes terday at the age of 80.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: Before the Salt Water Fly Rodders of America organ ized in the summer of 1959, the average fly fisherman limited his activities to fresh water, dreaming of a time when it might be possible for him to try for the ultimate goal, the Atlantic salmon.

title: Hard Times on Campus: A College Closes
description: GODFREY, Ill., June 27 For four solid days recently feathers of white smoke rose steadily from the Erickson Hall chimney at Monticello College here and drifted out to disappear, over the humid cornfields of southwestern Illinois.

title: BROADENING SEEN OF LOCKHEED BILL
description: WASHINGTON, June 28The Senate Banking Committee will meet behind closed doors to morrow on the Lockheed rescue bill, amid growing signs that the committee is likely to focus its attentions on a broader measure.

title: 3,500 Battle Forest Fires In New Mexico and Arizona
description: ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., June 28 (UPI)More than 3,500 men battled forest fires that were burning through 26,000 acres in New Mexico and Arizona today. Spokesmen for the United States Forest Service called the situation disastrous and seemingly hopeless.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: It is a good thing that we have newspapers free to check upon the Government. But who checks on the newspapers?

title: Pacific Platte Crash Toll 16; Chlorine Gas Leak Sealed Off
description: EUREKA, Calif., June 28 (UPI)Rescuers closed, off a leak of poisonous chlorine gas today and recovered two more bodies of the 16 persons; who were killed when a twinengine DC3 clipped a sewage treat, meat plant, smashed agaist a jagged rock and sank in the acific Ocean.

title: TroublePlagued Rock Festival Is Closed Early in Louisiana
description: McCREA, La., June 28 (AP)  Thousands of sunparched rock fans are streaming out of this rural area where a rock festival folded prematurely after drawing a crowd estimated at 50,000.

title: NEW MOTIONS FILED IN MISS DAVIS CASE
description: SAN RAFAEL, Calif., June 28 (UPI)Ruchell Magee, Angela Davis's codefendant, said today that if he could not prove he had been held in illegal slavery for the last eight years, he would plead guilty in the Marin County courthouse shootings last Aug. 7 in which a judge and three other persons were killed.

title: Austerity Budget Adopted For Schools in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 28  The financially troubled Phila delphia School Board adopted, 6 to 3, a new budget today calling for the elimination of all extracurricular activities, including sports, in the fiscal year beginning Thursday.

title: Article 5  No Title
Governor Approves PensionCost Study
description: ALBANY, June 28  Noting that state and local Civil Serv ice pension costs are expected to double by 1973, Governor Rockefeller has signed a bill establishing a state commission to investigate public pension costs, it was announced today.

title: Warlitzer Relocates Its 42d Street Store
description: If was moving day yester day at 120 West 42d Street, for the last 52 years the lead., quarters of the Wurlitzer Company.

title: IN THE NATION
description: WASHINGTON, June 28Among the other debates set off by publica tion of the Pentagon Papers is one on the solemn question whether the John son Administration lied to the people, while escalating the Vietnam war, or merely misled them artfully.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Regret has often been expressed over the fact that it is difficult, some times impossible, to get accurate news about what is really happening in Red China. There has been much specula tion, for example, about what life is really like In the new experianentail communes. I recently returned after an extensive visit to mainland China.

title: ...Kafka in Manhattan...
description: For instance, in a Iocal Social Security office one morning not too long ago there were about fifty people waiting to transact business. A sign on the pillar warned newcomers that they would have to wait more than three hours. But at only one of the three desks at which the interviewers were supposed to be found was an employe actually transacting business. A visitor inquiring where the other two interviewers were was told they were on their coffee breaks. When he tried to learn how long the coffee breaks would last, the reply was that that was none of his business.
