Meanwhile the elderly people who had come to get help with their prob lems sat and sat and sat.

title: Treasury Bill Rates Ruse at Weekly Sale
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 Yields on United States Treas ury bills rose in the Govern ment's weekly competitive sale today of these short term securities.

title: British Steel Plans To Sell Some Units To Private Industry
description: LONDON, June 28 (AP) Britain's Conservative Govern ment announced plans today to sell secondary interests of the stateowned British Steel Corporation to private industry.

title: Madness in Columbus Circle
description: In this tinderbox of a city it is hard to conceive of a more senseless and sinister episode than the shooting of Joe Colombo, allegedly by a black man who, in turn, was shot to death on the spot by persons as yet unknown.

title: CHAUFFEUR TAKES TREMONT STAKES UNDER BELMONTE
description: Only four 2yearolds com peted in the 79th Tremont Stakes yesterday as the New York Racing Association shifted its operations from Belment to Aqueduct.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters to the Editor
description: There is one sentence in your editorial of June 21 The Vietnam Papers, that does more to spotlight the whys and wherefores of our in volvement in Vietnam than all the volumes and essays that have been written to date on this subject . . . not venality, not evil motivation, but rather an arrogant disregard for the Congress, for the public, and for the inherent obligation of the responsibili ties of leadership in a democratic society.

title: Charles Szetchenyi Is Dead at 65; Headed Hungarian Grain Group
description: Charles Szechenyi, a member of a noble Hungarian family, who formerly served in the Upper House of the Hungarian Parliament, died here Saturday. He was 65 years old and lived at 114 East 92d Street.

title: U.S. Troops in Vietnam Decrease to 241,700
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 28 (AP)  The United States command announced today that American troop strength in Vietnam decreased by 3,200 men last week and totaled 241,700 last Thurs day. It was the lowest total since the end of March, 1966, when there were 231,200 American servicemen in the country.

title: Deficit in Delaware
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 28 (UPI) Mr. Peterson said today his state faced a $27million deficit because he was dead wrong when he estimated the revenue from a franchise tax.

title: Yahya Promises a Legislature Soon
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, June 28President Agha Moham mad Yahya Khan of Pakistan told his people today that they could expect to have a popular ly elected legislature in about four months.

title: COMMODITY PRICES LISTED IN THE WEEK
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 Daily index numbers and spot primary market com modity prices June 15, 1971, to June 22, 1971.

title: AMEX PRICES DIP IN LIGHT TRADING
description: Prices on the American Stock Exchange closed fraction ally lower yesterday In light trading after having opened slightly higher.

title: CONSUMER SUITS BY JERSEY VALID
description: TRENTON, June 28The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled to day that the State Attorney General had the power to initiate classaction lawsuits on behalf of consumers victimized byrice gouging.

title: Brown Returning to Run Ethical Culture Schools
description: Dr. Nathan Brown, who re tired last year as the city's Acting Superintendent of Schools to become president of a college' in Israel, was named yesterday to be the new director of the three Ethical Culture schools.

title: Kennedy Visits Japan
description: TOKYO, June 28 (UPI)  United States Ambassador at Large David M. Kennedy ar rived today for talks with Japanese officials about textiles and other economic issues con fronting Japan and the United States.

title: Colombo: A Man With Several Roles
description: Joseph Anthony Colombo Sr. was appearing at Columbus Circle in his role as a founder of the ItalianAmerican Civil Rights League yesterday when he was shot down.

title: New Drug Abuse Chief Is Told He Doesn't Have Enough Power
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 Dr. Jerome H. Jaffe, who is es tablishing in the White House a Special Action Office for Drug Abuse Prevention, was told at his first appearance be fore a Congressional committee today that he did not have enough authority to do the job.

title: General Mills Raises Earnings To a Record, for Fiscal Year
description: General Mills, Inc., a pro ducer of packaged consumer foods, textured protein food products, special chemicals, ap parel and toys and a operator of restaurants, attained record sales and earnings, in the fiscal year of 52 weeks ended May 30, the preliminary report showed yesterday.

title: Big Allis Running Smoothly, But Con Ed Eyes It Warily
description: Big Allis, Consolidated Edi son's prize millionkilowatt generstor that lay burned out and dismantled through last summer's power crisis is for the moment  roaring away, smoothly churning out electricity needed to keep New York's lights up and heat down.

title: Ciders Are Acting to Regulate Spraying of Asbestos
description: Several tons of it are sprayed into the air in American cities every year:, Those who breathe its microscopic particles will carry it with them throughout life. And sometimes, 20 of 30 years later, the deadly, effects inability to breathe or ram pant lung canceebegin to be felt.

title: Search for Plane Abandoned
description: FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., June 28 (AP)The search for a plane that disappearect Tuesday night in fog with four Connecticut men aboard was called off to day after no sign of the plane had been found. The men, who had flown to the island for a golf tournament, are presumed to have drowned when the plane dipped into the sound after taking off in heavy fog.

title: ROBERT L. THOMAS, 60, OF FORD FOUNDATION
description: Robert L. Thomas, a Ford Foundation manpower adviser in East Africa since 1963, died Saturday of a cerebral hemor rhage in Nairobi, Kenya, the foundation has announced here. He was 60 years old.

title: Newton Is on Trial Again for Slaying of a Policeman
description: OAKLAND, June 28  Huey P. Newton, a founder and the highest ranking officer in the Black Panther party, went on trial again today for the fatal shooting of art Oakland police man.

title: Fischer to Play July 6
description: Bobby Fischer of the United States will play Bent Larsen of Denmark at Temple Buell Col lege in Denver in, the opener of their 10game semifinal chess match to determine a challenger for the title, now held by Boris Spassky of the Soviet Union. The Winner of the Denver match will play the stirvivor of the match between Tigran Petrosian and Viktor Korchnoi, both of the Soviet Union, which starts Sunday in Moscow.

title: A CITY WITHIN A CITY IS GUARANTEED LOAN
description: WASHINGTON, June 28  the Federal Government an nounced today the first loan guarantee for a new community within an established city.

title: Abortion Referral Service Ordered Ended by Court
description: The State Attorney General, Louis J. Lefkowitz, obtained a State Supreme, Court order yesterday dissolving the Profes sional Scheduling Service, Inc., which had operated an abor tionreferral service here.

title: 200 More HighSpeed Cars Ordered for 3 M.T.A. Lines
description: The Metropolitan Transpor tation Authority has ordered 200 more highspeed; aircon ditioned electric cats for the Long Railroad and the Penn Central's. Harlem and Hudson Sines; it was announced yesterday.

title: Firestone Foam Unit Plant At Fall River to Be Closed
description: The Firestone Tire and Rub ber Company said yesterday that its Firestone Foam Prod ucts Company division would discontinue manufacturing op erations at its plant in Fall River, Mass., by Sept. 30. About 800 hourly and salaried em ployes will be affected.

title: Merger News
description: The USLIFE Corporation said yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to ac quire the Eastern Life Insurance Company of New York for al most $42million in stock.

title: Griffith to Box Monzon For Title in Buenos Aires
description: Emile Griffith, five times champion, signed yesterday for a 15round title fight against Carlos Monzon, middleweight titleholder, in Buenos Aires on Sept. 11 or 18.

title: ORCHESTRAS LISTED   BY KENNEDY CENTER
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 The John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts here will play host to twelve visiting symphony orchestras during the coming season. Leading off the series Sept. 19 will be the New York Philharmonic, conducted by Pierre Boulez.

title: 14 Arrested in SingIn
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 28 (UPI)  Fourteen members of an antiwar group were arrest ed today for holding a singin outside the secondfloor office of the Selective Service board at City Hall. The 14 were charged with trespassing and being disorderly persons, Po lice Chief James Regan said.

title: $2.5Million in Narcotics Seized After Tunnel Chase
description: Federal and city narcotics agents last night intercepted what they asserted was a $2.5 million drug shipment destined for the Harlem market and arrested three men after the Lincoln Tunnel had been blocked to prevent the three from escaping.

title: State Arts Council Alters Rules On Aid for Cultural Institutions
description: A cultural institution seek ing aid from the New York State Council on the Arts this year need not show a fiscal deficit to be eligible for funds.

title: Judge Bars the Sale of a Coop During Trial on AntiSemitism
description: The State Supreme Court yesterday barred the sale of a $150,000 East Side coopera tive apartment pending a further hearing into charges that a prospective buyer was rejected because he is a Jew.

title: We Have to Make Them Listen
description: It is said that power corrupts, and absolute power corrupts absolutely. We could probably expand that to include nearly absolute power corrupt ing nearly absolutely.

title: Agnew Would Visit China Despite Doubts
description: GUAM, Tuesday, June 29  Vice President Agnew said yes terday that he would be happy to visit China despite what he degcribed as personal reserva tions about its diplomatic pos ture.

title: Yanks Bow Twice, 30, 52;
description: The Yankees' hill production continued to be negligible last night as the Cleveland Indiant gained 30 and 52 victories in a twin at the Stadium and took over fourth place from the New Yorks in the American Leagne East.

title: Revival of Transit Subsidy Plan In Special State Session Urged
description: A leading civic researcher said yesterday that a revival of a proposed masstransit sub sidy package to put it on the agenda of a special state legis lative session appeared to be the only way now to avoid a rise in the city fare from 30 to 45 cents next January.

title: VERDICT OF COURT GRATIFIES DOOLEY
description: Edwin B. Dootey, the chair man of the New York State Athletic Commission, said yes terday he was pleased that Mu hammad Ali's military draft troubles have been cleared up by a United States Supreme Court ruling.

title: 2 Held on Drug Charges
description: SAN JUAN, P. R., June 28 (UPI)Two young American tourists were arrested and jailed here today on drug pos session charges when they were unable to put up $6,000 bail each. The police identified the youths as Patrick M. Steele of Minneapolis and Wayne E. Langstaff of Monroe, Mich.

title: OUTPUT OF STEEL FELL 3,7% IN WEEK
description: Steel production fell last Week by 3.7 per cent from the week before. It was, the fifth decline in the last seven weeks.

title: GEORGE KELLY, 70, EXCONGRESSMAN
description: LYON, France, June 28 (AP) George B. Kelly, a former United States Representative from Rochester, died Saturday in a hospital here. He was 70 years old.

title: Economic Index and Imports Up
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 The Commerce Department re ported today a small additional advance in its composite index of leading indicators of the economy  the seventh con secutive monthly gain.

title: MARKET DECLINES AS TRADING SLOWS
description: Investor caution ran high while volume ran low yester day on Wall Street, with turn over on the New York Stock Exchange slackening to its slowest pace of 1971.

title: Article 1  No Title
SAIGON'S TROOPS REOCCUPY CAMP
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, June 29 (AP)  The South Vietnamese command an nounced yesterday that its troops had reoccupied a dev astated artillery outpost that had been abandoned last week just below the demilitarized zone.

title: Colombo Shot, Gunman Slain At Columbus Circle Rally Site
description: Before thousands of stunned spectators and amid heavy po lice security, Joseph A. Colom bo Sr., the 48yearold reputed chief of a Brooklyn Mafia fam ily, was shot in the head and critically wounded at Columbus Circle yesterday Less than an hour before a massive Italian American civil rights rally be gan.

title: Satellite Link Planned For Teachers in Alaska
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP)The Department of Health, Education and Wel fare announced today the al location of $702,000 to pro vide health and education in struction by communications satellite to 21 isolated Alas kan villages.

title: Mr. Nixon and the Prisoner Smokescreen
description: PRINCETON, N. J.The basic con cern that emerges front extended new discussions with the delegations to the Paris peace talks of North Vietnam and the Provisional Revolutionary Government of South Vietnam is their continuing belief that the prisoner issue is a smokescreen behind which President Nixon intends to go on with the war.

title: Facts About Colombo's Attacker Vary
description: Jerome A. Johnson, the man who was killed after he shot Joseph A. Colombo Sr. yester day, was the center of myriad conflicting accounts last night as the police and neighbors tried to pull together the few known facts of his 24yearold life.

title: 3 Ask U.S. to Release '53 China Study
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 Three prominent China scholars called on the Nixon Adminis tration today to release the secret portions of a State De pertinent study of the Chinese civil war.

title: Books of The Times
description: DADA AND SURREALIST ART. By William S. Rubin. 525 pages. Abrams. $35.

title: Environment Chief Plans More Regional Authority
description: ATLANTIC CITY, N. J. June 28 (AP)The administrator of the Federal Environmental Pro tection Agency said today he would delegate considerably more power and authority to regional offices to better co ordinate efforts with states to meet air quality standards by mid1975.

title: Navy Ship Accident Kills 4
description: NORFOLK, Va., June 28 (AP) A steam fitting in an engine room of the Navy's new am phibious ship Trenton ruptured today, killing four men and injuring seven others. The ac cident occured two miles south of the United States Naval Sta tion at Guantanamo Bay, Cuba. Names of the dead and injured were withheld temporarily.

title: Louis Saw High Staff Aide
description: JERUSALEM, June 28  The Israel Foreign Ministry said to day that Victor Louis met with Prime Minister Golda Meir's top staff aide during a visit to Israel two weeks ago. How ever, official sources said no progress had been made toward reestablishing diplomatic rela tions with the Soviet Union.

title: DOCTORS DISAGREE AT TRIAL IN JERSEY
description: NEWARK, June 28Dr. David J. Flicker, chief of psychiatry at Beth Israel Hospital in New York City, testified for the Government today in the Jersey CityHudson County conspiracy extortion trial. He contradicted earlier testimony and said a de fendant on trial here had no evidence of chronic brain syn drome.

title: Soviet Critic Questions Official Art Style
description: MOSCOW, June 28  On the eve of the Fifth Writers' congress, a Soviet critic has challenged the official view that all Soviet literature must be written in the style known as socialist realism.

title: ProRegime Student Leader Slain at Saigon University
description: SAIGON, South Vietnam, June 28 (AP)  A proGovern ment student leader was shot and killed today in a Saigon University courtyard 10 days after he was named deputy chairman of the Saigon Student Union.

title: Executive Changes
description: The United Aircraft Corporation announced yesterday the election of Bruce N. Torell, 51 years old, as president of the Pratt & Whitney Aircraft division. He succeeds Bernard A. Schmickrath, 57 years old, who was elected a vice president of U.A.C. The aerospace manufacturer said the changes would be effec tive July 1 and, result from Mr. Schmickrath's personal decision to take an early retirement. Mr. Torell has been executive vice president of Pratt & Whitney since Janu ary, 1968. A native of Canada, Mr. Torell joined the aircraft engine division in 1947. He has been responsible for the development of control and igni tion systems for many of the company's jet engines.

title: GRAMBLING GAME IS RENEWED HERE
description: Grambling College, of Louisi ana and Morgan State from Baltimore will renew their foot ball series at Yankee Stadium on Saturday, Sept. 11, with the endorsement of the New York Urban League.

title: Soviet Jumper Drops In Again
description: BERKELEY, Calif., June 28 He wore a green plaid buttondown shirt, olive slacks without cuffs and a hand some watch with the inscrip tion Athens Invitational 1971 printed around the edge.

title: Trade Team in China
description: HONKONG, June 28. (Reu ters)  Canada's first trade mission to China crossed the border by train today from Hong Kong. The 24member delegation, led by the Minister of Industry, trade and Com merce, JeanLuc Pepin, will stay in China for a week.

title: Supreme Court Actions
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

title: Visit to Israel by an Agent Of Moscow Is Disclosed
description: MOSCOW, June 28The So viet authorities, despite denials, appeared today to have made lowkey efforts to establish un official contacts with Israel.

title: Mets' Rally Tops Phils, 31
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 28 Rick Wise, who tossed a nohit game against Cincinnati last Wednesday, became just an other pitcher tonight. The New York Mets beat him and his Philadelphia teammates, 31.

title: STANDARDS ARE SET ON KNITTED FABRICS
description: The Knitted Textile Associa tion, with the concurrence of the Textile Distributors Asso ciation, has issued a set of quality standards for all types of knitted fabrics. The stand ards, which have been long awaited in the textile industry, are based upon minimum de fects per linear yard and will be reviewed annually.

title: NEW COMPUTER UNIT ANNOUNCED BY I.B.M.
description: The International Business Machines Corporation yester day announced a new version of its most powerful computer unit, the Model 195. The new machine is part of the com pany's latest line, the System 370.

title: Ancient Turkish Town Enters RockMusic Era
description: SIDE, Turkey, June 25  Progress is bringing modern inconveniences to this tiny village on Turkey's south coast for the first time since the collapse of the Roman Empire.

title: Talk of Paris Shops
description: PARISThe game is get ting tougher, but half the fun of shopping in this city is trying to beat the profes sionals. Can the tourist find a boutique full of unexpected treasures before the eagle eyed scouts of American stores buy up everything for Bloomingdale's or Bergdorf's? With vir tually every Paris label now avail able across the Atlantic, it's not easy to find something that isn't already on Fifth Avenue or Main Street.

title: Solitron Delay Is Denied
description: The Federal District Court in Chicago yesterday declined the application of a stockholder for postponement of the annual meeting of Solitron Devices, Inc. The meeting will he held, as scheduled, in the Americana Hotel today.

title: MRS. SHIRLEY W. WYNNE
description: Mrs. Agnes Gertrude Ed wards Wynne, widow of Dr. Shirley W. Wynne, former Health Commissioner here, died Saturday at Mount Carmel Home for the Aged and Infirm, 539 West 54th Street. Her age was 91.

title: Senate Pays Dodd Tribute
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) Tributes were paid in the Senate today to the late Sen ator Thomas J. Dodd, Demo crat of Connecticut. Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff, Democrat of Connecticut, who led the round of tributes, said Senator Dobb had served his state and country well.

title: Air Marshal Sir William Elliot Of NATO Military Group Dies
description: LONDON, June 28Air Chief Marshal Sir William Elliot, a former chairman of the British Joint Services Mission in Wash ington and British representa tive on the military committee of NATO, died yesterday at a Royal Air Force hospital in Wiltshire. He was 75 years old.

title: Veterans' School Aid Urged
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (UPI)Senator Charles McC. Mathias Jr., Republican of Maryland, introduced legisla tion today designed to grant $1,000 a year to Vietnam vet erans who want to continue their education. The bill also would direct the Veterans Ad ministration to pay eligible veterans up to $175 monthly subsistence.

title: Tennessee District Sued
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 (AP) The Government today sued a Tennessee school district that allegedly maintains a dual school system based on race.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: The Times editorial (June 19) sup porting Secretary Richardson's initia tive in seeking direct Federal grants to Colleges and universities was both timely and constructive. Mr. Richard son's view that the nation's institu tions of higher learning need immedi ate help, net exhortations, is one that I share.

title: Banks in Paris and Vienna Join An International Banking Club
description: One of the largest and most powerful international banking clubs announced yesterday the admission of two new mem bers.

title: Young Radicals Lose Plea To Avoid Bombing Inquiry
description: DETROIT June 28 (AP)A panel of three Federal Appeals Court judges denied today a motion by six young radicals seeking to avoid appearing be fore a Federal grand jury in vestigating the bombing of the United States Capitol.

title: Excerpts From High Court Opinions on Financial Aid to ChurchRelated Schools
description: WASHINGTON, June 28 Following are excerpts from three opinions from the Su preme Court today. The first is the majority opinion by Chief Justice Warren E. Bur ger declaring unconstitutional state aid to churchrelated elementary and secondary schools in Pennsylvania and Rhode Island.

title: CONNECTICUT PACT SETS 6% SALESTAX
description: HARTFORD, June 28  The Republican Governor of Con necticut and the leaders of the Democraticcontrolled General Assembly agreed today on a state budget just three days be fore the end of the fiscal year on Wednesday.

title: Soviet in No Hurry To Pull Out of Deal With Mack Trucks
description: The Soviet Union indicated yesterday it had no immediate intention of dropping tentative plans to have Mack Trucks, Inc., help build a Russian truck plant, despite last Fri day's expiration of the dead line, set for United States Gov ernment approval.

title: BRITAIN GETS PAST A MARKET HURDLE
description: AUCKLAND, New Zealand, June 28  New Zealand was virtually in a position last week to veto British entry into the Common Market by say ingis, whether she accepted or rejected the terms negotiated for her at Luxembourg.

title: Last Rites Are Merry Ones at the Fillmore East
description: With several thousand dol lars worth of free food and beer and what one Fillmore regular described as the best vibes since the place opened, the Fillmore East closed its doors early yester day morning.

title: MasseyFerguson in Britain Wins Soviet Engine Order
description: TORONTO, June 28 (Cana dian Press)Massey Ferguson, Ltd., said today a British sub sidiary would supply 1,300 vehicle diesel engines to the Soviet Union, believed to be the largest such Soviet order ever received in Britain.

title: May Forging Orders Off
description: CLEVELAND, June 28 (UPI) Bookings of forging orders in May slipped 1 per cent, to $76.5million, from April, but gained 6 per cent over the 1970 level, according to the Forging Industry Association. Bookings for 1971 through May are 6 per cent ahead of a year ago.

title: Malta Permits Visit by U.S. Destroyer Despite Dispute With Atlantic Alliance
description: VALLETTA, Malta, June 28  Despite Malta's dispute with the North Atlantic Treaty Or ganization, a destroyer of the United States Sixth Fleet ar rived for a visit at the Maltese island of Gozo today without incident.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: In a recent edition you published a letter to the editor criticizing Presi dent Nixon's recent decision to make available to LatinAmerican countries such additional military equipment on a sales basis as they might consider important for their national security.

title: West Bengal Leaders Quit
description: CALCUTTA, India, June 28 (Reuters)  The West Bengal state government resigned to day because of a deterioration in law and order aggravated by the influx of more than five million East Pakistani refugees. Direct rule from New Delhi was expected within the next few days for the third time since February, 1968.

title: Front Page 1  No Title
description: HAVEN'T YOU ALWAYS WANTED TO KNOW how Christian Science heals? For Information about nearest Church Services, call (212) 7657770. Advt.

title: Miss Bacon Denies Bomb Plot Here and Is Continued in Bail
description: Leslie Bacon pleaded not guil ty yesterday in Federal Court here to charges that she con spired to firebomb an East Side bank last December.

title: $100,000 Fire at School
description: FAIRFIELD, Conn., June 28 The 875pupil Fairfield Woods Junior High School here was severely damaged early this morning by two fires that were described by Fire Chief Joseph J. Stopans definitely of incondiary origin. The damage to ad ministrative areas, the library and auditoriumgymnasium was estimated at more than $100, 000. The building's 40 class rooms were not damaged and officials said they expected the school to reopen on schedule next September.

title: Bergen Bank Is Acquired
description: The acquisition of the Bergen County National Bank, Hacken sack, by the Commercial Trust Company of New Jersey to pro duce a $204million institution has become effective, it was an nounced yesterday. Bergen County National, a $26million unit bank, will be operated as branch of its Jersey Citybased parent.

title: Phils Will Raise Fence To Keep balls in Field
description: PHILADELPHIA, June, 28. (UPI)The Philadelphia Phil lies, dikturhed by the number of hits That have bounced over the outfield knee for geoundfule doubles in their new stadium, will increase the height of the fence from 8 to 12 feet next season.

title: Marinduque Mining Holders To Vote on Reverse Split
description: Directors of Marinduque Mining and Industrial Corp., Manila, called a special meet ing of shareholders for July 29 to vote on a proposed onefor four reverse split of the out standing capital stock. If the split is approved, the company would have 2,443,513 shares outstanding and about 127,745 shares reserved for conversion of 6 per cent debentures.

title: Rumania Holds Atom Parley
description: BUCHAREST, June 28 (AP)  President Nicolae Ceausesu opened an international confer ence development and peace ful uses of atomic energy today. The Rumanian press agency re ported that almost 2.000 experts from 50 countries were attending.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: I read with interest the [June 17 OpEd] article by Jack Newfield, en titled Let Them Eat Lead. Mr. New field cites a serious problem in con nection with poisoning of children by paint with lead in it and accuses this Administration of ignoring it. Mr. New field has not told the whole story. Last month this Department Issued a White Paper, Towards a Comprehensive Health Policy of the 1970's, which announced its, plan for funding activ ities directed at lead paint poisoning.

title: Priest Found Dead in Hotel
description: CHICAGO, June 29 (AP) The body of a Roman Catholic priest, his hands and feet bound with strips of sheeting, was found today in his room in the Sherman House Hotel. The police said it appeared that the Rev. Carlo Barlissina, 43 years old, recently of Buf fallo, was the victim of a rob bery.

title: JAMES J. GRAHAM, LAWYER, TEACHER
description: James J. Graham, an expert on welfare law and an associ ate professor of law at the University of Arizona, died yes terday at Long Island College Hospital, Brooklyn, after having returned from Tucson for treat ment of a heart ailment. He was 41 years old and lived at 499 Fourth Street in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn.

title: Company in Pennsylvania Guilty Of Pollution Under an 1899 Law
description: PITTSBURGH, June 29The Pennsylvania Industrial Chem ical Company of West Eliza beth, Pa., was convicted by jury in Federal District Court today on four counts charging violations of the rarely used Rivers and Harbors Act of 1899.

title: Bankers Asked to Testify on Lockheed
description: Representative Wright Pat man, the Texas Democrat who heads the House Banking and Currency Committee, has asked the chief executives of the 24 banks that have lent $400mil lion to the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation to testify next month on the proposal that the Government guarantee addi tional loans to the troubled aerospace concern.

title: It Was and Is the Most Open of Wars
Rosewall eats Richey in 4Hour Battle
description: WIMBLEDON, England, June 20The result will say simply that Ken Rosewall defeated Cliff Richey in the AllEngland tennis quartefinals today. But no record book can resurrect a match that will live long in memory, a classic fought without quarter over 62 games and four hours with the center court in bedlam and a spill over crowd outside cheering the points popping on the lighted scoreboard in a frantic finish.

title: Ford's Theater Plans To Offer U.S. Ventures
description: The restored Ford's Theater in Washington will expand its offerings for the 197172 season to include a variety of American ventures.

title: Maver and Manollos Lead Qualifying in Amateur Golf
description: BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N. Y., June 29 (AP)Jim Mayer Jr. of Bedford and Nick Manollos, of Katonah tied for first today in the Westchester sectional qualifying round for the New York State amateur golf cham pionship.

title: Ukraine Leader Urges Soviet to Get Rid of Hippies
description: MOSCOW, June 29Pyotr Y. Shelest, a Soviet Politburo member, has called for a pub lic campaign to rid the Soviet Union of what he regards as the latest Western scourge hippies.

title: Scott Deplores Ruling
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP)  The Senate Republican leader, Hugh Scott of Penn sylvania, said today that the Supreme Court's ruling yester day that states may not sup plement parochialschool teach ers' pay is one that will haunt all of us. Its high cost in dollars is inestimable, he said.

title: Senate Votes $4.8Billion For Operation of Agencies
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) The Senate passed today a $4.8billion money bill to fund operations of the Treasury De partment, the United States Postal Service, the executive of fice of the President and various other agencies in the fiscal year starting July 1.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: There has been much recent discus sion on the question of whether or not we should experiment with the so called British system. of maintenance for hard drug addicts.

title: Safety Institute Set Up
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) The Department of Health, Education and Welfare an nounced today the establish ment of the National Institute of Occupational Safety and (Health. The institute will con duct research, experiments and demonstrations relating to oc cupational safety and health.

title: DR. J. RALPH JACOBY, NEUROPHYSICIAN, 99
description: A funeral service will be held tomorrow at 10 A.M. in St., Thomas Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue at 53d Street, for Dr. J. Ralph Jacoby of 880 Fifth Av enue, a neurophysician who, died Saturday in a nursing home here after a short illness.

title: Advertising:
description: The biggest thing in the lapelbutton business these days is the smile and a lot of promotion  minded companies know it.

title: Economic Analysis
description: Hello, all you vacationers out there who are looking for some light summer reading about the economy! To help you wile away the hours in the ham mock or on the front porch when it's raining, here is a grab bag of cheerful goodies: Harold C. Passer, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Upward Indica tors, reports that defense  related economic activity, after declining for about two years, may soon level off. Such a turn of events, says Mr. Pas ser cautiously, suggests that in the near future the defense sector will no longer be a major drag on the growth of the na tion's economy.

title: Books of The Times
description: This is a sneaky little curveball of a book a story that appears to be perfectly true yet reads like fiction; a memoir of events that seem outside of time; an account of failure that glows with success; a portrait of unappetizing people that makes them seem like gods; and an essentially tawdry story told with refreshing innocence. Perhaps the most puz zling part of it and probably the reason for Its ap pealis that its author, John Bow ers, seems not yet to have outgrown the naivet that made his experi ence possible in the first place. But never mind all that: the curvehall somehow sneaks past one's defenset and goes straight to one's heart. I loved The Colony and I never even it strike. It's the story of a young man from East Tem nessee who gives up his ladylove to pursue his dreams of becoming a writer. It begins one clay in the early 1950's When the young man conies across a spread in Life maga zine about the success of James Jones's war novel From Here to Eternity and the debt it owes to a writing teacher named Lowney T. Handy. The article mentions how Jones and his mentor run a writers' colony in Southern Illinois; so the young man applies for, admittance to the colony, is eventually accepted, kisses his girlfriend goodby and goes forth in his 1951 Plym outh. (Just think, he exults upon arriv ing at the colony, here I stand where James Jones wrote parts of From Here to Eternity.)

title: Tire Makers End Dispute
description: AKRON, Ohio, June 29 (UPI) The Goodyear Tire and Rub ber Company has settled a trademark dispute with the Mothers Tire Company of At lanta. Goodyear said Mothers had agreed to be enjoined per manently from using the term Polyglas, copyrighted by Good year, to describe tires. Good y year has withdrawn a claim for damages from Mothers,

title: Seoul Amnesties 4,790
description: SEOUL, South Korea, June 29 (AP)South Korea announced today an amnesty for 4,790 prisoners, including four Amer ican soldiers, in connection with the inauguration of Presi dent Chung Bee Park Thursday. The action will free 341 prison ers and reduce the sentences of 4,449 others.

title: 3 SOVIET ASTRONAUTS ARE DEAD; BODIES DISCOVERED IN CAPSULE WHEN IT LANDS AFTER 24 DAYS
description: MOSCOW, Wednesday, June 30The Soviet Union reported this morning the death of the threeman crew of the Salyut laboratory that had set a world endurance record orbiting the earth.

title: Kuhn Cited by Kiwanis
description: SAN FRANCISCO, June 29 (UPI) Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn was presented an award by the Kiwanis Inter national board of trustees today for his efforts in initiating program for drug education and prevention in baseball.

title: Democrats Pick Miami Beach for '72
description: WASHINGTON, June 29The 1972 Democratic National Con vention will be held in Miami Beach, Fla., and will open on Monday, July 10.

title: Excerpts From Nixon's Message to Senate on Public Works Bill
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 Following are excerpts front the text of a message from President Nixon to the Sen ate giving his reasons for vetoing a bill to establish a $5.6billion accelerated public works program:

title: $100,000 in Shrimp Stolen
description: About $100,000 worth of frozen shrimp was stolen early yesterday from a truck on West Street when the truck's two drivers stopped for breakfast on their way to the Fulton Fish Market. According to the police, four armed men, who Were waiting when the drivers emerged from a diner, tied the men up and forced them into a small truck. When the drivers freed themselves a halfhour later, their tractortrailer had been emptied.

title: McAdam and Hanson Take Purchase Golf by 2 Shots
description: PURCHASE, N.Y., June 29 Charles V. McAdam Jr. and Michael Hanson of the Round Hill Club had a gross bestball card of 32, 3870, one under par, at Century Country Club today to win the Westchester County Golf Association's 45th annual British Victory Cup tournament by two strokes.

title: F.B.I. Tapes 76,000 Pages on a Mafioso
description: BUFFALO, June 29  The Federal Bureau of Investigation has compiled about 76,000 pages of transcript and notes during three years of eaves dropping at a Niagara Falls funeral home operated by Ste fano Magaddino, a reputed Mafia leader, according to tes timony yesterday in United States District Court here.

title: Governor Signs Bill Restoring $51.1Million in Aid to Addicts
description: ALBANY, June 29Gover nor Rockefeller has signed bill that reappropriates $51.1 million in state aid for local narcotic addiction programs.

title: Helms of the C.I.A. Is Reported Conferring With Israeli A ides
description: JERUSALEM, June 29Rich Director of Central Intelligence, has arrived in Israel for meet ings with Government analysts, reliable Israeli sources said today.

title: Mets' Seaver Stops Phils, 30;
description: PHILADELPHIA, June 29 The Mets had an abundance of hitting and pitching tonight as they beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 30, to sweep the two game series.

title: Key Swedish Aide Resigns
description: STOCKHOLM, June 29 (Reu ters)Premier Olof Palme of Sweden announced tonight, the resignation of Foreign Minister Torstein Nilsson, who has served in the Government since World War II and took over the post in 1962. Mr. Nilsson, who is 66 years old, is to be replaced by Minister of Industry Krister Wickman, 47, who in turn will be suc ceeded by former Minister of the Interior Rune Johannson, Mr. Palme said. The changes are to take effect Thursday.

title: Japan Agrees to Take Over Okinawa Defense by 1973
description: TOKYO, June 29 (AP)The United States and Japan signed an agreement today requiring the Japanese to take over the major defense role on Okinawa by July 1, 1973. The island will be returned to Japanese control next year.

title: Executive Changes
description: The Canadian International Paper Company an nounced yesterday in Montreal the election of Joseph P. Monge as president and chief executive officer, succeeding I. H. Peck, who becomes chair man. Mr. Monge, who will relinquish his post as executive vice president of the International Paper Company, the parent company, will continue as director of both organizations.

title: GOVERNOR WARNS MAYOR ON BUDGET
description: ALBANY, June 29Governor Rockefeller touched off another bitter exchange with Mayor Lindsay today by declaring that the $525million New York City tax package authorized by the state was the last of its kind.

title: Airline to Defer Payments
description: Southern Airways, Inc., an Atlantabased carrier, has en tered into an agreement with bank and certain other creditors for the deferral of about $3.21 million in payments over the, next three years. The informa tion is contained in a prospec tus by the company for an of fering of convertible preferred stock with detachable warrants to purchase common stock. The prospectus noted that the se curities involve a high degree of risk.

title: Bid to Peking Opera Rejected
description: The New York City Center of Music and Drama has re ceived what appears to be a letter from a Chinese official lift Peking rejecting an invita tion for the Peking Opera to perform in the United States.

title: U.S. Assures Israel on Sinai Memo
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 The United States told Israel today that a temorandum sub mitted to Egypt last month by Donald C. Bergus, the ranking American diplomat in Cairo, did not represent the Admin istration's view.

title: TRUSTEE FILES PLAN FOR YALE EXPRESS
description: F. Ralph Nogg, trustee in the reorganization of Yale Express System, Inc., and its subsi diaries, filed a plan yesterday with the Federal District Court here for reorganization under Chapter X of the Bankruptcy Act.

title: Soviet Agent Said to Get Favorable Reply in Israel
description: Mr. Louis, whose visit to this country was disclosed yes terday, was reported to have made the statement as he took leave from Simcha Dinitz, political adviser to Premier Golda Meir, after a twohour meeting in his Jerusalem home.

title: Barbara S. Smith Becomes Bride
description: Miss Barbara Sim Smith, daughter of Mrs. Skinner Smith of New York and Gregory B. Smith of Stoning ton, Conn., was married here yesterday afternoon to Inge Skjelfjord, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Skjelfjord of Maloy, Norway. The Rev. John C. Calhoun performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More.

title: AMEX PRICES RISE AS TRADING GAINS
description: In steppedup trading, prices showed their strongest advance in more than three months yes terday on the American Stock Exchange.

title: S.B.C. and BrokerDealer Will File a Consent Decree
description: BOSTON, June 29 (AP)The Securities and Exchange Com mission and a Boston broker dealer firm and its president agreed in United States District Court today to file a consent decree concerning an S.E.C. suit charging violations of the commission's net capital rule.

title: Mrs. Cooperstein Leader At Locust Valley With 73
description: LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., June 29Mrs. Walter Cooperstein of Glen Oaks took the opening round lead today with a 73 in the Women's Long Island Golf Association's 54hole medal play championship. Mrs. Coop erstein won the title in 1963 and 1969.

title: Wilson to Coach Tidewater
description: DETROIT, June 29 (UPI)  Johnny Wilson, coach of Spring field in the American Hockey League, was named today to coach the Tidewater (Va.) Wings, the Detroit Red Wings' new entry in the A.H.L.

title: Providence Promotes Gavitt
description: PROVIDENCE, June 29 (AP) Dave Gavitt, Providence Col lege's basketball coach was named athletics director today. The 33yearold Cavitt will con tinue to coach basketball.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: It is stunning, literally, to see W. W. Rostow (OpEd June 22) still pushing the domino theory, and the other theories that have bloodied his hands and your hands and Lieutenant Galley's hands and my hands and the hands or all U.S. citizens.

title: 2 Are Sentenced to Death For Killing Deputy Sherin
description: BELTON, Tex., June 29 (UPI) A jury that deliberated for a total of 81 minutes found Rene Adolfo Guzman and Leonardo Ramos Lopez guilty and sen tenced them to death today for murdering one of three deputies last Feb. 15 in West Dallas.

title: Italians Tie Up Traffic, Scoring Article in News
description: About 40 members of the ItalianAmerican Civil Rights League and six black sup porters disrupted traffic for more than half an hour last night in front of the Daily News Building in a noisy pro test over an article that they charged was trying to start a race war.

title: Advertising:
description: Oscar and Emmy, Tony and Winnie have a lot in common. They're all the highest awards certain industries have to offer.

title: Eban Sees U.S. Envoy
description: JERUSALEM, June 29  The Foreign Ministry announced that Ambassador Walworth Barbour met Foreign Minister Abba Ehan in Jerusalem today, at Mr. Eban's request.

title: ABORTION BACKED BY UNITED CHURCH
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., June 29The biennial general synod of the twomillionmember United Church of Christ ended its fiveday meeting here to night after calling for the re peal of all legal prohibitions of physicianperformed abortions.

title: ... and the Public Works Veto
description: President Nixon has, as expected, vetoed renewal the Appalachian program because Congress added a sec tion authorizing $2 billion to accelerate action on public works projects across the nation. His objections to this feature of the bill are valid but not conclusive.

title: CITY SUES TO HALT RENT DECONTROLS
description: New York City sued in State Supreme Court yesterday to block the new state law, start ing tomorrow, that would re move apartments from rent controls as they become vacant.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: As a Marine stationed on Okinawa I would like to dispute the present Marine Corps policy concerning drug users. The Corps considers drugusers weaklings to be gotten rid of as soon as passible. These people, once caught, will be jailed or discharged from duty with no attempt made to rehabilitate or help them.

title: U.S. BAR ON IMPORTS IS FACING CRITICISM
description: GENEVA, June 29  A fair amount of unhappiness was expressed today over United States restrictions on imports of farm products, according to sources closce to the General Agreement on tariffs and Trade.

title: Aide Says Interest In Ali Is Increasing Bat So Is His Waist
description: Muhammad Ali was pro nounced by one of his law yers yesterday as totally out of shape.

title: MRS. J. M. MACFARLAND
description: BOONTON, N. J., June 29  Mrs. Audrey Hohenshelt Mac Farland, wife of James M. Mac farland, died today apparently of a heart attack at the home of their daughter, Mrs. James E. Bradley, 666 Parsippany Boulevard. She was 63 years old, and had moved with her husband to Roswell, N. M., last year after he had retired as a Foreign Service Officer with the United States Information Agency.

title: ETHICS CODE'S SCOPE EXPLAINED BY RANKIN
description: The more than 2,500 non salaried members of the city's 62 community planning boards are subject to the city's code of ethics for salaried workers, ac cording to an opinion by Cor poration Counsel J. Lee Ran kin.

title: East Pakistani Economy Badly Hurt as Most Transport Is Crippled
description: DACCA, Pakistan, June 26 Food scarcities are becoming serious in parts of East Paki stan, cash is short in rural areas, jute factories are badly crippled and key road and rail communications continue to be disrupted by guerrillas.

title: HALL WINS REGATTA FOR HIPKINS TROPHY
description: GREENWICH, Conn., June 29 Graham M. Hall, sailing in structor at the State University of New York Maritime College at Fort Schuyler, regained the Commodore Hipkins Trophy to day at the 20th annual Long Island Sound men's champion ship regatta. The regatta con cluded with four races after the crews had spent 12 hours on the water off Riverside Yacht Club.

title: NonWatson at Helm
description: Man in the News

title: Funeral far Stewardess Draws 1,500 in Queens
description: Cornelia Michelle Crilley, in the red jacket and blue skirt of her airline stewardess uniform, was buried yester day in Calvary Cemetery in Woodside, Queens, after a service that drew 1,500 people to her family's parish church, Saint Sebastian's, a few blocks away.

title: Bout Added to Garden Card
description: Bill Drover of Labrador and Louis Pires of Brazil, heavy weights, were added yesterday to the July 12 Madison Square Garden boxing show.

title: DR. I. DAVID SHORELL
description: MIAMI BEACH, June 29  Dr. I. David Shorell, a former Manhattan plastic surgeon who had been practicing here for some years, died today at the age of 74.

title: Ellsberg to Meet Press
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 29 Dr. Daniel Ellsberg, back at home here after having been arraigned on charges of unau thorized possession of secret documents, announced today that he would hold a news con ference on Thursday.

title: Market Place: Balance Sheets Put in Spotlight
description: Think about it. Is it pos sible that the average Ameri can family is getting poorer? Is It more difficult for Ameri cans to support their afflu ent living standards, their two oars, their collegeen sconced youngsters than it was a year or so ago?

title: Roundup: Kennedy, Red Sox Streaking
description: After 11 years as a mar ginal ballplayer with five ma jor league teams, John Ken nedy seems finally to have entrenched himself with the Boston Red Sox.

title: Nicklaus, Palmer Among 12 Named to Ryder Cup Team
description: PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., June 29 (AP)Jack Nick laus and Arnold Palmer will play on the same United States Ryder Cup golf team for the first time. They were among 12 professional golfers selected today to represent the United States against Britain Sept. 16 18 at the Old Warson Country Club, St. Louis.

title: Air Force to Try Officer For Part in War Protest
description: LAKENHEATH, England, June 29 (AP)The United States Air Force today or dered Capt. Thomas L. Cul ver, accused of having vio lated military law by demon strating against the Vietnam war, to face a general court martial.

title: Police With Cameras Begin a Drive on Prostitutes
description: Twoman teams of the Tac tical Patrol Force began taking polaroid photographs of scores of prostitutes, plying their trade on sidewalks in midtown last night.

title: Miami Judge Bars A Writ for Mother To See Baby Lenore
description: MIAMI, June 29Judge Ralph O. Cullen of Dade County Circuit Court refused today to order Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas DeMartino to allow Olga Scar petta to visit the baby she bore and then turned over to an adoption agency.

title: U.S. AND BONN RECESS TROOPCOST TALKS
description: BONN, June 29 The third round of negotiations between the United States and West Germany on offsetting the dol lar drain caused by mainte nance of American troops here ended tonight without success.

title: SCOTT DISCONTINUES DISPOSABLE DIAPERS
description: The Scott Paper Company, Philadelphia, announced yester day that it was abandoning its Baby Scott disposablediaper business and was cutting the price of its remaining inven tory.

title: Lebanese Army Reports Fighting With an Intruding Israeli Force
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 29 A military spokesman said to day that the Lebanese Army fought a twoanda half hour artillery battle with Israeli armored forces that had en tered southern Lebanon this morning.

title: U.S. Says More Arms Cargo Will Be Going to Pakistanis
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) A State Department spokes man acknowledged today that four or five additional vessels would be carrying licensed United States military equip ment to Pakistan in the next month or two.

title: The Personal Touch
description: WASHINGTONWhatever may be the value of the Pentagon Papers to historians, they offer to the political philosopher an invaluable insight into the essentially personal character of our Government and its tendency to insulate the American people from the hard debates from which vital policies flow.

title: Torture and Blubber
description: WEST BARNSTABLE, Mass.When I was a young reader of Robin Hood tales and The White Company by Arthur Conan Doyle and so on, I came across the verb blubber so often that I looked it up. Bad people in the stories did it when good people pun ished them hard. It means, of course, to weep noisily and without constraint. No gpod person in a story ever did that.

title: Senate Unit to Meet
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (Reuters)The Senate Banking and Currency Committee ar ranged today to meet tomor row on a bill to aid the Lock heed Aircraft Corporation after Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, forced a delay.

title: City Bestows on Papp Its Handel Medallion
description: The Handel Medallion, the city's highest award for cul tural achievement, was pre sented last night to Joseph Papp, founder and producer of the New York Shake speare Festival.

title: Sports of The Times
description: Harvey Q. Boatowner patted the pristine hull of his new sailboat and admired her clean, pure lines, the graceful curves and beaming brightwork. Harvey hated ugliness and filth and to him the most beautiful spectacle, therefore the most truthful, was a freshly painted boat bounding gently over sunsparkled waters.

title: Why Aid Pakistan?
description: After months of equivocation and evasion, the State Department has finally made it clear that the Admin istration intends to keep on furnishing military and economic assistance to the Government of Pakistan despite continuing acts of repression in East Pakistan that have shocked the world. This incredible policy decision defies understanding.

title: Uhlaender Quits Indians, Following Ken Harrelson
description: CLEVELAND, June 29 (AP) Ted. Uhlaender has left the Cleveland Indians and says he is quitting baseball.

title: C. C. N.Y. Gets $2.5Million Gift Fora Center for Performing Arts
Trustees to Testify Today in Senate on Car Shortage
description: The Penn Central Transpor tation Company trustees report ed to the Federal district court in Philadelphia yesterday that the huge system in May had a net railway operating less of $9,334,309 and a net loss of $18,500,774. The net loss reflects all charges to income, including those fixed charges and state and local taxes that are not being paid currently.

title: Playground for Handicapped Is Dedicated at N.Y. U.
description: A $50,000 playground de signed for handicapped pre school children was dedicat ed yesterday at New York University Medical Center's Institute of Rehabilitation Medicine.

title: City's YearOld Abortion Record Hailed
FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: PARISThe contretemps develop ing between NATO and the island republic of Malta could, unless settled I:)y friendly agreement, prove immense ly embarrassing for the defense of Western. Europe. For Malta is the plug of the Mediterranean; it is in a posi tion to block either eastwest or north south movement across those waters.

title: URUGUAY BARS HELP ON ABDUCTED BRITON
description: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, June 29An effort to free the kid napped British Ambassador to Uruguay, Geoffrey Jackson, through the good offices of Dr. Salvador Allende Gossens, the Socialist President of Chile, has failed.

title: Harte Raises Vinyl Prices
description: Harte & Co., Inc., a subsidi ary of the Diamond Shamrock Corporation, said yesterday that it would increase prices of vinyl film and sheeting prod ucts by 5 per cent a yard or pound, depending on the prod ucts involved. The products are used in furniture, juvenile items, shower curtains, notions and novelties, closet accessories and luggage.

title: The Quiet
description: The visitor to the country walks restlessly about, then sits and listens, and asks, How do you stand the silence? The countryman listens, consciously, and it isn't the silence at all. Robins are singing, and orioles, and crows are cawing in the distance. Down the road on the next farm a cow is bawling for her new calf, and up the road a tractor is chuffing in a hayfield. It isn't silence, but he knows what the visitor means, which is quiet. There an important difference between quietness and silence, and it becomes more important year by year.

title: Samuel Nickle Sr. Dead; Led Ashland Oil Canada
description: CALGARY, Alberta, June 29 (Canadian Press)Samuel C. Nickle Sr., oilman and philan thropist, died in a hospital here yesterday.

title: The Very Big Lie Technique
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Daniel Ellsberg hasn't told the rest of us anything we didn't already know. He just gave us the names and dates.

title: H. Earl Russell Jr., Diplomat, Dies Driving in the Sahara
description: RABAT, Morocco, June 29 (AP)H. Earl Russell Jr., an American diplomat, lost his way in the Mauritanian Sahara last week and died of sunstroke after his car broke down. His wife, Beatrice; their 14yearold son, Scott, and a friend, Thom as Whitcomb, were discovered by a search plane Saturday.

title: Paramus Sculpture Show Covers HalfMile
description: At a time when most of the New York art world has come to a standstill, one of the biggest outdoor sculpture shows ever held in the United States has been mounted in Paramus, N. J.

title: Article 2  No Title
description: MOSCOW, June 29 (UPI) Foreign Minister Andrd A. Gro myko discounted reports today that the Soviet Union and Istael werenegotiating for a resump tion of diplomatic relations. Mr. Gromyko, asked by a newsman about the reports, replied: They do not even deserve to be refuted.

title: Sale of Corned Beef With Excess Brine Brings $175 in Fines
description: Seven ShopRite supermar kets here have been fined for selling corned beef that was excessively corny, the Depart ment of Consumer Affairs said yesterday.

title: Nixon to Address F.B.I. Class
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (UPI) President Nixon will address the 87th graduating class of the Federal Bureau of Investi gation Academy tomorrow, the White House announced today. The main address will be made by Attorney General John N. Mitchell.

title: News Analysis
description: WASHINGTON, June 29  President Nixon's firmly nega tive decisions today on a new course in economic policy, in the face of some disheartening recent news, were based mainly on two strong convic tions, which are shared in con siderable measure by most of his advisers.

title: PriceFixing Suit Is Filed On Plastic Pipe Fittings
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) Five corporations and two executives were indicted today on charges of conspiring to fix prices of plastic pipe fittings for plumbing use.

title: The Screen: 'Glory Boy':Violence Is Outcome of Veterans' Return
description: Some movies, often the very greatest, are genuinely difficult. Some others, never the greatest, are merely obscure. It is in this second category, films that by their own confusions and inadequacies fail to make the kind of sense they so unclearly intend, that Edwin Sherin's "Glory Boy," which opened yesterday at the Baronet and Forum theaters, belongs."Glory Boy" is yet another movie made not about, but under the shadow of, the Vietnam War. When its young hero (Michael Moriarty) returns home to his father's run-down farm north of San Francisco, he brings with him a stupid but relatively harmless Army buddy (William Devane) and a Regular Army sergeant (Mitchell Ryan) who is more or less waiting put his 30 days before re-enlisting.The sergeant is no friend, merely somebody picked up because his stern jaw, his medals and his military manner will please the old man. But behind his tough exterior seethes a soul of sulfuric acid, and after he has humiliated dad, knocked unconscious a hitchhiking college girl (Topo Swope) so as to rape her, and dynamited the fish in the trout stream, it becomes fairly obvious that he is a one-man social, moral and ecological disaster.Between the father (Arthur Kennedy) and the sergeant there is a certain equivalence, for the old man has in gentler ways ruined everything he has touched (so you shouldn't miss the point, he keeps praising the farm as a Garden of Eden) and he too represents the militarism of an agethe age of World War II. The film recognizes that the two wars are not equalthe father is fallen from sentimental ideals; the sergeant is pure evil forcebut symbolically and, at last, literally, the two cancel each other out.I think this is the most significant action in "Glory Boy," though there are several others, and there is a whole household full of representative typesincluding the girl who, unaccountably, comes back to cook and clean and put flowers on the dining room table. But except for what fits together all too neatly, nothing seems to belong with anything else, and it all feels like watching a series of strung-together three-minute sketches. Sherin's direction stresses action in the middle distance not all that bad, but limiting and the multiplication of pregnant pauses  so that sometimes it looks as though the actors really are standing around wondering what to do next.Almost everybody figures out something reasonable in timeexcept for William Devane, who plays for a kind of instant insanity and ends up suggesting, say, Jerry Lewis as Macbeth. But the two principle kids, Michael Moriarty and Topo Swope, really are something specialappealing without courting appeal, sympathetic without the production of any unnecessary charm. Michael Moriarty particularly brings a rather intricate intelligence to an almost incomprehensible role. But both he and Miss Swope introduce a quality I should never have expected in this moviea quality of articulate and active lucidity.

title: 3 Met Fans Lose Suit For Rebate on Opener
description: Three Mets' fans who sued to get their money back on their tickets for the club's opening game last April 6 lost their case in the State Supreme Court yesterday.

title: Paris Council Approves Demolition of Les Halles
description: PARIS, June 29The last administrative obstacle to the destruction of the great metal sheds that once constituted the heart of the old Halles was re moved early this morning.

title: Article 3  No Title
86 FACE INDICTMENT IN THEFTS OF PAPERS
description: Thirtysix newspaper deliver ers employed at the Brooklyn plant of The Daily News and 50 newsstand vendors have been indicted by a Brooklyn grand jury on chargesinvolving news paperstealing, The News said today.

title: Newport Fete Due Friday Sans Rock
description: The Newport Jazz Festival is still wrestling over its rela tionship to rock, primarily the manifestations of rock that are evident in almost all contemporary music.

title: Consultant to Film Rating Panel Is Appointed to Be Its Director
description: Dr. Aaron Stern, a psychia trist and educator, has been appointed to the new position of director of the Motion Pic ture Association of America's Code and Rating Administra tion. Dr. Stern has been a con sultant to the industry's self regulatory organization for the past two years.

title: Lake George Winning Fighton Visual Pollution
description: LAKE GEORGE, N. Y. This summertime resort com munity, now primping for the coming vacation season, is waging a slow but suc cessful war against one of its major problemsunsight ly road signs and billboards.

title: Instead of Moving to Suburbia, While Families Went to Harlem
description: When we first moved in, I was ap prehensive but now we couldn't feel more at home anywhere, said Mrs. Alan Mason of 108 East 101st Street. On a daytoday basis it's been just great.

title: Anniuersaries
description: McDONNELLTo Mary. Thanks for 20 won derful years. The beet Is yet to come.

title: Muskie Aide Says Lindsay Will Seek Presidency as Democrat
description: WASHINGTON, June 29  The senior political aide to Senator. Edmund S. Muskie of Maine said today that he as sumed Mayor Lindsay of New York would be a candidate in the Democratic Presidential pri mary next year in New Hamp shire.

title: San Diego Agrees to Bid
description: SAN DIEGO, June 29This city yielded to White House blandishments today and agreed to make a lastminute bid of $1.5million for the 1972 Repub lican National Convention.

title: Newburgh Woman Convicted
description: GOSHEN, N. Y. June 29 (UPI) The alleged operator of brothel in Newburgh Big Nell Williams, was convicted on seven counts of promoting prostitution and illegal sale of alcohol by an Orange County jury this evening.

title: Washington: For the Record
NEW COOLING UNIT STORES THE COLD
description: An air conditioning system that at night stores coolness for use the next day, thus re ducing power demands during hot spells, is being developed at the newly formed National Center for Energy Management and Power.

title: Bank of Japan Is Taking Action to Slow Exports
description: TOKYO, June 29The Bank of Japan decided today, as a way to slow Japan's rising ex ports, tp raise all interest rates on export preferential financing loans by onefourth percentage point to a uniform 5 per cent a year. The new rate will go into effect Aug. 10.

title: F.C.C. Studies Staff Proposal For an Office of Public Counsel
description: WASHINGTON, June 29The Federal Communications Com mission is considering the crea tion of an Office of Public Counsel to help citizens to challenge not only the broad casting and telephone establish ments but the commission's bu reaucracy as well.

title: U.S. Grants Chile Credits For Military Equipment
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 The United States has granted Chile $5million in credits for purchases of military equip ment here in the first such gesture by Washington toward the Socialist Government of President Salvador Allende ossens.

title: MUSEUM ADDITION UPHELD BY COURT
description: In a 3 to 2 decision, the Ap pellate Division yesterday up held a ruling by Justice Saul S. Streit of the State Supreme Court permitting the construc tion of the Lehman Pavilion as an addition to the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: Bridge: Eisenberg Moves to Coast And Champions Lose a Man
description: The Dallas Aces, world champions for the last two years, are an Ace short this week. Bill Eisenberg, former ly of New York, moved from Dallas to Los Angeles Mon day after resigning from the world's greatest bridge team.

title: A Unit Will Manage All the I.O.S. Funds, Acting On Its Own
description: TORONTO, June 29 (Cana dian Press)  Shareholders of T.O.S. Management, Ltd., part of the giant Genevabased I.O.S., Ltd., mutual fund empire, ap proved today a reorganization that will turn it into an in dependent operating body.

title: YIELDS ADVANCE ON TAX EXEMPTS
description: Interest rates moved upward in the taxexempt bond market yesterday, raising the possibili ty that New York City could pay a record borrowing cost when it sells $282.1million of bonds next Wednesday.

title: Article 1  No Title
description: MONTREAL, June 29 (Cana dian Press)  The Pakistani freighter Padma, said to be car rying either arms or cobalt to Pakistan, arrived here today.

title: Kemper Conquers Liguori in 1,000 In Meet at Cologne
description: COLOGNE, Germany, June 29 (UPI)FrankJosef Kemper, European 800 and 1,000 meter recordholder, edged mit Marty Liguori, the American mile champion, tonight over 1,000 ineters. Kemper, of West Ger many, had a time of 2 minutes 18.9 seconds, fourtenths of second better than Liguori. Kemper's record for the odd distance is 2:16.2.

title: Soviet Aide Calls for Orthodoxy in Arts
description: MOSCOW, June 29A key literary official today de nounced those who support Aleksandr I. Solzhenitsyn and other Soviet writers who are in official disfavor.

title: Major Mafia Shootings Last Reported in 1957
description: It has been 14 years since major Mafia leaders were the targets of assassination at tempts here.

title: F.T.C. Says Ads for Pill Exploit User's Anxieties
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) The Federal Trade Commis sion accused the J. B. Williams Company today of exploiting consumer anxieties by assert ing in advertising that use of its stimulant pill, Vivarin, helped one's personality, mar riage and sex life.

title: ISRAEL HAS PLAN FOR BEIMBIJRSING JERUSALEM ARABS
description: JERUSALEM, June 29The Government proposed today to compensate Arab residents of East Jerusalem for property they held in the land that be came Israel 23 years ago.

title: Regan Wants New Rules
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 Donald T. Regan, chairman of the board of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Inc., said today that brokerage firms should be required, by law and necessary regulations, to do more than they are doing now to prevent thefts of securities.

title: G.E. Dedicates Plant Unit
description: The General Electric Com pany formally dedicated yester day a new plant that is an integral part of its Appliance ParkEast complex at Columbia, Md. The new site represents an eventual investment of more than $250million and is ex pected to employ between 10, 000 and 12,000 persons when it is completed by about 1980.

title: Priceless Right
description: Now that full voting rights for eighteenyearolds appear imminent by way of constitutional amendment, speculation inevitably focuses on the probable effects, It is all but taken for granted that politicians will go out of their way to appeal to these eleven to twelve million freshly enfranchised voters constituting 8 per cent of the new electorate, a bloc large enough to have reversed many a national election result including Presi dent Nixon's victory in 1968, Indeed, the President has candidly observed that the infusion of these youthful votes would benefit the Democratic party more than the Republican party....

title: Tripled Murder Rate Here Puts Big Burden on Detective Force
description: The number of murders in New York City has tripled in the last decade, and the rate of solution has gone down, in part because of the heavy load on the 3,100 members of the Police Department's detective division. Still, more than two of three killings are solved.

title: Early U.S. Choices in Indochina
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) The Pentagon study, as read by Senator Gravel, concluded that United States involvement in Indochina began with a choice between supporting French colonialism or Ho Chi Minh Communism and that the United States sided with the French.

title: Informants Give Mafia Reaction to Colombo Shooting
description: Dozens of underworld infor mants gave Federal law en forcement officials information yesterday about the Mafia's re action to the shooting of Joseph, A. Colombo Sr.

title: Jus Behaving First in Jump
description: Mrs. Ogden Phipps, the pe rennial leading moneywinning owner in the jumping phase of thoroughbred racing, started the local steeplechase season in proper style at Aqueduct yesterday.

title: Watson Retires as Chief, Fills Lesser Post
description: For the first time in its his tory the giant International Business Machines Corporation is today headed by someone outside the family of the late Thomas J. Watson.

title: ARTHUR J. BOWLER
description: Arthur J. Bowler, a commer cial photographer here for 35 years who had long been asso ciated with Paul Hesse's studios, died yesterday morn ing in his home at 4 Peter Cooper Road. He was 64 years old.

title: Military Court Upholds Ban on Fraternization
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (UPI)The nation's highest military court has decreed that it is illegal for an officer to fraternize with enlisted men.

title: G.M. TO LAY OFF 1,400 AT CALIFORNIA PLANT
description: DETROIT, June 29 (Reuters) The General Motors Corpora tion said today it would lay off about 1,400 of the 4,000 work ers at an assembly plant at Freemont, Calif., after the model changeover in midAug ust.

title: SESSION ON P.O.W.'S HEARS V.F.W. CHIEF
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 Herbert R. Rainwater, the com mander in chief of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, told a House Foreign Affairs subcommittee today that a logical approach to the problem of American prisoners of war in Indochina would be to have Hanoi set a date for our withdrawal con tingent upon the release of our men.

title: POLICE CONTINUE COLOMBO INQUIRY
JERSEY DEFENDANT CITES HARASSING
description: NEWARK, June 29Joseph B. Stapleton, Hudson County Treasurer, on trial in Federal Court here with seven others in the Jersey City Hudson County extortion conspiracy case, testified today that he was harassed and threat ened with jail by an Assistant United States Attorney during his five appearances before a Federal grand jury last year.

title: CITY AS 51ST STATE OPPOSED BY CELLER
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 (AP) Representative Emanuel Cel ler, Democrat of Brooklyn and chairman of the House Judici ary Committee, said yesterday that the campaign to make New York City the 51st state has my determined opposi tion.

title: ShareMoving Plan Aired
description: WASHINGTON, June 29  About 125 persons represent ing leaders and technological experts from majcr securities industry organizations, began today to try to figure out what changes should be made in the system of transferring stocks from one owner to the next.

title: Jerome A. Johnson Is Depicted By the People Who Knew Him
May Building Contracts Up 42% From Last Year
description: The total value of contracts awarded in May for all cate gories of construction projects throughout the country was $7,554,700,000, or 42 per cent above $5,331,958,000 a year ago, the F. W. Dodge division of the McGrawHill Information Systems Company reported yesterday.

title: Novelist on Trial in Killing of Negro G.I. in Tennessee
description: HUMBOLDT, Tenn., June 29 Jesse Hill Ford went on trial today for firstdegree murder in the rifle slaying of a Negro soldier.

title: HOLUB CAPTURES MET SENIOR GOLF
description: RYE, N. Y., June 29Sey mour Holub, a 57yearold aluminum window manufac turer from Linden, N. J., be came the new Metropolitan Golf Association's senior cham pion today by beating Arthur Julius, 63, of Mount Vernon on the first hole in a sudden death playoff.

title: Connecticut Tax on Commuters Falls Heaviest on High Earners
description: HARTFORD, June 29Legis lative leaders said today that the commuter tax included in the state budget that Is ex pected to be adopted tomor row would range from 2 to 10 per cent of adjusted gross in come.

title: SENATORS REJECT ARMSFUND CUTS
description: WASHINGTON, June 29 The Senate, in what was de picted by liberals as a test of national priorities, refused to day by dicisive margins to cat defense spending or to stop de velopment of a multibillion dollar space shuttle.

title: Agnew in Seoul for the Inauguration of President Park
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Wednesday, June 30Vice President Agnew arrived late yesterday bearing messages of goodwill for the newly elected South Korean leaders but with no specific diplomatic agenda of his own.

title: HAUGHTON SEEKS ELUSIVE VICTORY
description: YONKERS, June 29  Billy Haughton's three decades of driving standardbreds have re sulted in 3,400 winners for the 47yearold reinsman from Oyster Bay Cove, L.I. He has fared handsomely with pacers, having driven the winners of four Little Brown Jugs, three Canes and three Messengers. However, nowhere on the trot ting lists does his name appear as a winner of a triple crown race. Haughton still is looking for his first triumph in the Yonkers Futurity, the Hamble tonian and the Kentucky Futurity.

title: SIERRA CLUB AGREES ON REORGANIZATION
description: SAN FRANCISCO, Tune 29 (UPI)The Sierra Club has come up with a compromise plan for reorganization.

title: Stringent Rules Set for Car Exhausts
description: WASHINGTON, June 29  Final regulations described of ficially as stringent were is sued today by the Environ mental Protection Agency for the reduction of airpolluting emissions by automobiles.

title: VICTIM DESCRIBES BEATING AT RALLY
description: The man who was beaten by some of the people attending the Unity Day rally in Columbus, Circle on Monday said yester day that he was a musician and had Volunteered to play at the rally and that his offer had been accepted.

title: Birth Notice 1  No Title
description: OLUMDr. end Mrs. Saul Charles Blum (neo Jane hope Greenberg) of Edison. N.J. joyfully announce the birth of their daunh ter, Eden Jennifer, on June 29th.

title: Human Rights Association Says Soviet Group Becomes Affiliate
description: The Soviet intellectuals who formed a human rights com mittee in Moscow last year have established formal affiliation with the International League for the Rights of Man.

title: New Foundation Trustees
description: The Rockefeller Foundation announced yesterday the elec tion of three new trustees. They are Dr. Mathilde Krim, a genet icist at the SloanKettering In stitute for Cancer Research; Vernon E. Jordan Jr., the newly elected executive director of the Urban League, and Maurice F. Strong, secretary general of the United Nations Conference on Human Environment.

title: Continental Can Plans To Transfer Employes
description: The Continental Can Com pany is transferring about 100 of its nearly 1,800 New York Citybased employes to a new Metals Operations Center to be situated near Chicago's O'Hare Airport, it was disclosed yester day. The company said it has no plans to move any of its other operations or offices from New York City.

title: ItalianAmerican League Absolves Blacks of Attack
description: The ItalianAmerican Civil Rights League told its 32 chap ters in the metropolitan area yesterday that the black com munity should not be held re sponsible for the critical shooting of Joseph A. Colombo Sr., the league's founder.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Editor: On June 5 The Times published letter by George Soli arguing that there were no constitutional grounds for endjng the draft. Unfortunately, The Times identified Mr. Soil through a former association with the Ameri can Civil Liberties Union without snak ing clear that Mr. So11's view of this issue is opposite to that of the A.C.L.U.

title: WILLIAM ARTHUR PEDLAR
description: William Arthur Pedlar, an industrial engineer and design consultant, died yesterday of cancer at New York Hospital after a long illness. He was 74 years old and lived at 40 Fifth Avenue.

title: Alouettes Lose to Stars
description: MONTREAL, June 29(Ca nadian Press)Touchdowns by Joe Coffey, Gary Wood and Hugh McKinnis sparked the Ca nadian Football League All Stars to a 3013 victory over the defending Grey Cup champion Montreal Alouettes tonight.

title: Gravel Speaks 3 Hours
description: WASHINGTON, Wednesday, June 30Senator Mike Gravel read to reporters last night. what he said were parts of the Pentagon papers on the history of the United States involve ment in Indochina.

title: Norton Simon, Inc., Quitting Publishing Business
description: Norton Simon, Inc., a bil lion  dollar conglomerate, has decided to divest itself of The Saturday Review, part of the McCall's book division and other publishing properties it brought into its foodandsoft drink empire over the last four years.

title: SOLITRON MEETING ADJOURNED 3 DAYS
description: The annual meeting of Soli tron Devices, Inc., was ad journed at the Americana Hotel yesterday and was scheduled to resume Friday in Tappan, N. Y., headquarters of the electronics concern.

title: U.S. PLANS LEASES OF OIL SHALE LAND
description: WASHINGTON, June 29  Secretary of the Interior Rog ers C. B. Morton, announced to day a prototype leasing pro gram to begin private commer cial development of the vast oil shale deposits on Federal land in the Rocky Mountains.

title: Thompson Notifies Jets He'll Play This Season
description: Steve Thompson, a 245 pound defensive lineman, informed the New York Jets yesterday that he would play this season.

title: Yankees Win, 92, From Indians
description: Maybe the Yankees' problem of late has been too much sleep. After only a few winks after a double loss to the Cleve land Indians Monday night, the Yanks returned to the Stadium yesterday for an unusual 12:30 P.M. game with the Indians and promptly snapped out of a run famine to whip Cleve land, 92.

title: Chagall at Met on List For Publication in Fall
description: Chagall at the Met, a critical appreciation of Marc Chagall's two murals at the Metropolitan Opera House and of his designs for the company's production of The Magic Flute, will be published this fall.

title: The Talk of Marina Del Rey
description: MARINA DEL REY, Calif., June 29  In many ways, Marina del Rey symbolizes Southern California. For the essence of the Southland, as it is called here, is neither Hollywood nor religious fanat ics nor any of the other exotic stereotypes.

title: U.S. Plane Shot Down
